PUB-DATE: November 9, 1997

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 4726 words

HEADLINE: How To Fight City Hall

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
SO you voted for the Mayor, the rasp in his voice has almost become endearing and you are looking forward to four more years of feeling safe when you walk the dog at night. Then you find out that the city wants to put an off ramp from the Gowanus Expressway in your neighborhood, and suddenly you are sticking voodoo pins in your Giuliani doll. That makes you feel better, but it is not going to stop the ramp. You cannot afford to hire a lobbying firm of a mayoral ally like Raymond B. Harding, so what is a community to do?
In the past, taking to the streets might have been the first option. Not anymore. Ask civic activists around New York how to fight City Hall, and they react as if you asked when they last beat their wives. 
 "In the old days, we had a fight City Hall approach," interrupts Michael Clark of the Citizens Committee of New York City, in a typical reaction, "but now we encourage a collaborative approach."
Some groups still protest, of course, sometimes with success, but most prefer caution and sophistication to confrontation. Dozens of interviews with community leaders and activists and with elected and appointed officials suggest that while there are no hard and fast rules for getting things done, the most effective community groups operate like businesses these days. They have strategic plans and agendas; they network and negotiate; they issue news releases.
And they are aware that while many traditional methods for moving city government apply, the alchemy of pressure is slowly changing as a result of the confluence of City Charter revisions, the relationship between a Republican Mayor and Democratic political establishment and the governing style and personality of Mayor Giuliani. Term limits for elected officials may throw yet another wrench into the wheels.
Most of the work in the city still gets done, and many of the decisions are made, by middle managers who stay rooted through mayor after mayor.
"They're the people who run this town; commissioners don't run this town," says Rabbi Jacob Z. Goldstein, who has been chairman of Community Board 9 in Crown Heights for 18 years. Those middle managers respond less to ideology than to personal chemistry (or maybe their mood that day). They tend to be more responsive to community boards or elected officials than they are to the average citizen, so at least initially most communities work through such intermediaries.
But when the bureaucracy is intransigent, or when an issue is large or charged, or requires a policy decision, the case becomes more political: it moves up toward the commissioner, the Mayor's staff, the Mayor. At that point, if a battle is in sight, communities need a plan, and they need a thumb in the wind to know which way political winds are blowing.
The first thing to realize is that this administration did not emerge from the political apparatus of this city and that it is not especially enamored of that apparatus. Elected officials, from borough presidents to state assemblymen to City Council members, still have more access to City Hall than do the people they represent. The clever, the motivated and the leveraged still get things done. But the occasionally fractious relationship between largely Democratic incumbents and a Republican Mayor has made relying on those incumbents less dependable. Around town, there are some frustrated elected officials.
"They play games, and try to channel all contact between elected officials and city agencies through them," Kenneth K. Fisher, a Democratic Councilman from Brooklyn, said of members of the Mayor's office. Then, he said, if they do not like something an elected official does, they "tell people in agencies not to return phone calls or give meetings."
Some of that, of course, is politics as usual. When the Mayor needs a vote, relations are restored. But for community groups, the lesson is clear: pay attention to those who have a good working relationship with the executive branch at any given time.
The Mayor has demonstrated little enthusiasm for community boards, starting when he slashed their budgets. (Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone has managed to get some of the money restored.) "The first-term Giuliani administration has not been very good at consulting with community boards," said Alvin Berk, the chairman of Community Board 14 in Brooklyn. The Mayor also eliminated the liaisons that Mayor Dinkins's administration used to reach out to various ethnic groups, and has substantially lowered the profile of the Community Assistance Unit.
"The Mayor stays in touch by being out there," says Jack Deacey, a mayoral spokesman. About the community boards, Mr. Deacey said: "Are some community boards unhappy with the administration? Probably. But this administration is out in the neighborhoods in every borough."
Given these changes, and the uncertainties they have wrought, many communities have started organizing and educating themselves to work directly with city agencies or pressure city officials. There has been an explosion in the number of civic associations, particularly in Manhattan and Queens, that are becoming increasingly savvy at pressuring the city.
Other changes in the city's political workings have been institutional. Under the City Charter revision, borough presidents lost much of their real power (it has mostly accrued to the Mayor), while the City Council got two new powers: land use and budget. Land use issues, which were previously ruled on by the seven-member Board of Estimate, now require reckoning with 51 Council members. Getting access to capital budget funds is a question of convincing a committed and effective Council member.
While many community leaders complain about City Hall, citing the difficulty of getting information or getting access to the Mayor's tight inner circle (particularly after Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter, a generally respected community liaison, left to run the re-election campaign), plenty have succeeded in challenging or working with this administration.
What's the secret? Some of those who have succeeded are from Mayor Giuliani's political milieu. Perhaps they are represented by Republican Council members, or live in mayoral strongholds like southwestern Brooklyn. Or they are not from Ruth Messinger's stronghold. Others agitate on issues dear to the Mayor's heart, or have learned to frame their cause that way.
"It helps tremendously if you have an issue the Mayor cares about," said Adam Silvera, who has been fighting the rise in the number of bars on Avenue A on the Lower East Side, a quality-of-life issue.
Others have something the Mayor wants, or find the person who has enough influence to make their case. Having greater economic clout and education helps, not surprisingly. Such communities have money in the bank, lawyers on the block, urban planners around the corner -- all a big help if they are looking for an agency official to call or planning to go to court.
But such resources are not necessary. The great common denominator for communities that have been successful is persistence. In any effort to move City Hall, there are usually a few people who sweat profusely for the benefit of the many. Pester people enough, they say, and you will usually get what you want, if only because they want to be rid of you.
Here, then, are a few other rules for challenging, pressuring, prodding, cajoling, and, yes, fighting City Hall:
 
1. Think Local, but Look Global
The citizen determined to do something for a neighborhood or community faces a barrage of charges from citywide officials: parochialism, selfishness, Nimbyism, interest-group politics. So the best have learned to broaden, to find how their issue resonates elsewhere in the city.
For 10 years, Queens activists have been unsuccessfully trying to get the city to tighten regulations about where such community facilities as drug rehabilitation centers and homeless shelters, which have sprouted like wild mushrooms over the last several decades, can be situated. But for the last two years, the Queens groups have begun working with counterparts in Manhattan, Staten Island and elsewhere, and the interborough alliances are making officials take notice, said Sean Walsh, the president of the Queens Civic Congress.
"They can't play one borough against the other: the snobs in Manhattan, the hicks in Queens," he said. Carol Rinzler, whose Manhattan Neighborhood Council has also taken up the issue, said, "You can see them sitting there counting up the votes in their little heads." The chair of city's Planning Commission has promised some sort of recommendation by the end of the year.
 
2. Turn Pro and Stay Neutral
For those entering the job market, a well-pressed suit and impressive resume are half the battle. In politics, too, the appearance of legitimacy -- a board, a name, an agenda -- is worth no end of credibility. Community groups that once took to the streets have cottoned to sophistication.
"Copy letters to agencies, community boards, elected officials, so they see you know what you're doing," said Fran Vella-Marrone, a renowned civic activist in Dyker Heights.
When Kathleen Goforth wanted to beautify her Park Avenue South neighborhood, she established the Park South Mall Association (total membership: three), recruited a seven-member "advisory panel," and printed up some fancy letterhead stationery. The stationery helped reel in donations small and large from local businesses. That in turn prompted her Councilman, Antonio Pagan, to get $475,000 in city funds to green and clean the area.
Part of being professional, say community groups, is staying nonpartisan. "We have no involvement with local politics unless it is directly related to parks," said Mickey Ronan, the executive director of the Roosevelt Park Community Coalition, which has helped transform a strip of the Lower East Side from a redoubt of drug dealers and prostitutes to a haven for children and residents. The coalition can't afford such involvement: it is relying on Democratic officials to help pressure city agencies controlled by a Republican Mayor. Groups that have somehow acquired a reputation as "Democratic" say they have felt the consequences at City Hall.
 
3. Plant the Seeds, Ask the City to Water
Some naive citizens believe that just because taxpayers pay city officials' salaries, those officials will spare no effort in addressing public problems brought to their attention. In fact, city officials will sometimes put more effort into avoiding a problem than solving it. The reasons not to act are infinite, with lack of money being a particular favorite and stubborn skepticism of the problem's very existence a close second. That often leaves communities with two choices: give up and grumble, or do the initial hard work themselves, leveraging volunteer (or, if they can afford it, paid) labor to force the city to respond.
The Upper East Side had a rat problem: "Enormous rats," said Betty Cooper Wallerstein, the founder of the formidable East 79th Street Neighborhood Association and a master of politely pestering city officials. Convinced that the rodents were squeezing through the holes in city waste bins to snack on the garbage inside, the association asked the sanitation department to line all the bins. The department said it lacked the manpower.
So the association found volunteers from the neighborhood (a few of whom volunteered their doormen). For eight months they changed the liners themselves, laying the bags out for the city to collect. The rats moved on (to a less organized neighborhood, no doubt), and the city, convinced of the association's argument, arranged to have workfare recipients take over the task of liner replacement.
 
4. Horse-Trade
Counting on the Mayor or his staff to give your community something because they want to is a little like counting a lottery ticket as your Christmas fund: it's possible, but risky. The best way to get city officials to do something you want is to have something they want. Political clubs and associations used to broker such deals; now communities broker for themselves, or through community boards or local elected officials.
So when the city needed a place, fast, to store sanitation trucks it had kept under the Williamsburg Bridge, Ross Graham saw the trucks headed straight for her community board, No. 4 in Chelsea-Clinton. She knew she could fight it and lose, or she could milk it like Bessie the Cow. Among the concessions: progress on the Clinton urban renewal plan, and a new office for the community board.
A sense of timing helps: After an Arab fired on a van of Jews on the Brooklyn Bridge, Mayor Giuliani wanted to bring Arabs and Jews together. Emira Habiby Browne, the founder of the Arab American Family Support Center, used his interest to secure his help in freeing up city funds that had been promised her organization but tied up in the bureaucracy.
As important as having something to give is knowing what you will give. Negotiate like a businessman: know where you will compromise, and what you want in return. Otherwise you may find yourself in the position of one of the city's most powerful neighborhood groups, the Brooklyn Heights Association. In 1984, its battle against the construction of One Pierrepont Plaza, an office tower, was running down. At a late-night meeting, the association, headed for a loss in the now-extinct Board of Estimate, was asked what it would take to get it to drop its lawsuit against the city.
"We had no list," recalls Judy Stanton, the association's executive director. "We had no knowledge of trade-offs. This old, esteemed organization had never needed them before." They did manage to get a few small concessions but not as much as if they had planned in advance. And the tower went up.
Ms. Stanton issues this warning: In the Giuliani era, if you're arguing against an economic development effort, you face a very tough battle.
 
5. Find Allies
For communities seeking something from the city, the bad news is that the mayoral election is over--no more goodies like the end of two-fare zones and the elimination of the $1.75 toll on the Cross Bay Bridge in Queens. The good news is that the gubernatorial election is just gearing up. The Mayor may be indifferent; the Governor aims to please -- a fact some community groups have already grasped. Where an issue has even the smallest nexus with the state, enlist state officials to pressure the governor.
And he's not the only one: many of those City Council members who will be ejected by term limits aren't about to give up on public life. They are dreaming of Assembly and State Senate seats. Michael Krasner, a Queens College political science professor, suggests that term limits may even enhance constituent service (if not city government): Council members have less incentive to become policy experts, and more to deliver short-term concrete results. The trick is to find someone with more power and influence at City Hall than you have.
When the city's Muslims wanted to get alternate-side parking rules suspended outside mosques on Muslim holidays, they dispatched Asghar Choudri, the unofficial mayor of Brooklyn's unofficial Little Pakistan, to see his councilman, Noach Dear, who also happened to be the chair of the council's transportation committee. Mr. Choudri made his request; Mr. Dear responded with words most civic activists only dream of hearing: "I said, 'I want to be your savior,' " Mr. Dear recalled. He sponsored legislation and got it through the council.
Sometimes it helps to venture far from home to seek help. After 10 years of fighting for a traffic light on her corner in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Elsie Richardson was ready to write a book on city inaction. Her own Councilwoman had been no help. Then, appearing before a City Council subcommittee on parks meeting on another matter, she mentioned the traffic light. It caught the interest of Thomas Duane, a Manhattan Councilman and the subcommittee e chairman; a few months later the traffic light went up, shortly after Ms. Richardson received a letter from her Borough President's office saying she would not be getting a traffic light. "A lot of our elected officials don't know what's going on," she said.
A final hint: know who is in and who is out. In right now: Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez of northern Brooklyn, Councilwoman Priscilla A. Wooten of East New York, Representative Floyd H. Flake of southeast Queens, Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens and others who broke ranks to endorse the Mayor.
 
6. Know Where the Bodies Are Buried
In government, as in life, there are go-to people and got-to-avoid people, people who give you the runaround and people who will run around for you. There are discretionary funds given to each Councilman by the Speaker, Peter F. Vallone (although voting against his budget can jeopardize those funds) , and capital budget dollars waiting to be dispensed. The trick is to know who gets things done, and how to get what's there.
There is a reason that the most effective organizations are those with former or even current government employees in their ranks: they know how the system works. Some leave government and turn that knowledge to profit as a lobbyist, but it can also be turned to a community's profit. Ross Graham spent 21 years in state government before becoming chairwoman of Community Board 4 in Manhattan. "It helped enormously," she said. "I had ideas of who to call, what questions to have. I knew many City Council members by first name."
The good news is that decades of big government must mean that there can't be a community in New York without someone with government experience.
 
7. Use the Dale Carnegie Approach
Once you know who gets things done, stick with them and cultivate the relationship (and don't go over their head unless absolutely necessary; there is no surer way to alienate an ally than to get him in trouble with his boss). Even in a city as large as New York, a surprising amount of city business gets done on the basis of personal relationships; rarely with the Mayor himself, but with his staff and with agency staff.
"I've developed very good relationships with all the people I deal with in city agencies, and I've never had a problem getting anything from them," said Rafael Orozco, a community affairs officer in Brooklyn who has been helping housing project residents get what they need from city government for years. "Learning to talk to them and becoming friends with them will do more than all the letters in the world, because it's hard to say no to a friend."
Jacob Z. Goldstein, who has been the chairman of Community Board 9 in Crown Heights for 18 years, recalls trying to get some streets repaved and being told by a transportation official -- and friend -- that his district had maxed out its asphalt allotment for the year. "Fine," Mr. Goldstein replied, "but if you have any leftover asphalt at the end of the year, give me a call." The call came: "What streets do you want done?"
 
8. Use the Power Of Shame
Few things get a politician's attention like the threat of bad publicity or the promise of good, and this Mayor (and aspiring Senator?) is no exception. Fortunately, New York's yawning news media maw demands constant feeding, from New York 1 to local and citywide papers to local television and radio.
Anyone can get press for just about anything, and the best community advocates take it to a higher level. They keep this weapon in reserve, going public only if the city is unresponsive. Sean Walsh is biding his time as he waits for the city to deal with the problem of illegal conversions of single-family dwellings. If the Mayor does not move forward with plans to enforce city regulations against the conversions, Mr. Walsh will move forward himself by contacting the press.
Savvy media users know where to go: Local papers can effectively embarrass or shame local politicians, but not necessarily the Mayor or city officials. Concerned about the condition of shelters for battered women, Joyce Shepard, the founder of the Citizens' Action Committee for Change, went undercover as one. She went to the Comptroller, who validated her findings and promised funds. A few months later, she went back. Little had changed. Soon after, Joyce Shepard was on the cover of Newsday. She says the Comptroller's office now keeps her personally informed on improvements.
 
9. Speak Softly, Don't Lose Your Big Stick
When all else fails, there are still some good, old-fashioned ways to bludgeon City Hall into listening: litigation and legislation. They are, community advocates say, tools of last resort, but tools nonetheless. When Robert Moses tore through West Tremont with the Cross-Bronx Expressway, Mr. Krasner notes, he had the benefit of unsophisticated community groups who never thought to call a lawyer. Today, he would have a lawsuit on his hands. "It is the rare community group that does not have access to some legal talent," Mr. Krasner said.
Jack Lester, an attorney who has litigated often against City Hall, said he was actually not a fan of litigation: "Ninety-nine percent of the time you want to avoid litigation. It goes on for a long time, it is expensive."
But when groups have exhausted all other avenues and there has been a clear violation of the law, there is no other choice. When the administration takes a noncommunicative tack, Mr. Lester said, that often indicates there has been a violation of some statue or regulation. "When your phone calls stop getting returned," Mr. Lester said, "you realize you must go to court."
As for legislation, it helped stop the Brooklyn Navy Yard incinerator. Councilman Noach Dear of Borough Park said this tactic is often an effective way to prod agencies into responsiveness. His constituents, for example, have been complaining about the city's policy of collecting recycling only biweekly. If the agency doesn't change to weekly pickup, Mr. Dear said, he will sponsor legislation. "What are they going to do, have the Mayor veto it?" he said.
 
10. The Last, Last Resort
If all else fails, call the Mayor's radio program: Friday from 10 A.M. to 11 A.M. on WABC, 770 AM, (800) 848-9222.
 
Working the System: Four Victories
 
THE ARMORY FIGHT
 
ACTIVIST: Simone Sindin, founder of the Armory Action Alliance.
 
THE ISSUE: In 1995, the city's Human Resources Administration suddenly announced that the 14th Street Armory, by her home, would become the site of a central workfare placement station for men all over the city. Ms. Sindin wanted "a positive community use" for the armory.
 
THE CAMPAIGN: A community meeting brought out 2,000 people. The Alliance, representing dozens of community groups, raised funds and hired Jack Lester, a lawyer known for fighting City Hall.
 
RESULTS: On the verge of going into court, the Mayor's representatives agreed to talk and hammered out an agreement that the city would only use the armory for a year and have it be closely monitored by a task force. The city kept the agreement. The state is now considering bids for the armory.
 
HER LESSONS:
1. Focus Your Fight. Some Democratic legislators were pressing to use the issue to fight Federal workfare policy. "As community people," Ms. Sindin she said, "we weren't going to fight Federal policy."
 
2. Monitor Political Dynamics. The community negotiated directly with the city, without elected officials or the community board. "We started working with incumbent legislators," she said, "but in the end, because there was a Republican Mayor and Democratic incumbents, we thought there were political processes at work and decided to go it alone."
 
3. Threaten Litigation to Force Negotiation. "I don't think any of us wanted to go to court. The whole idea was, 'Please notice us.' "
 
BATTLING A MALL
 
ACTIVIST: Fran Vella-Marrone, president of the Dyker Heights Civic Association,; vice chairwoman of the Conservative Party in Brooklyn.
 
THE ISSUE: Fighting the Brooklyn Junction megamall, an eight-block development proposed for a residential neighborhood between Eighth and 14th Avenues at 61st Street at the nexus is of Bay Ridge, Borough Park and Sunset Park.
 
THE CAMPAIGN: Under Ms. Vella-Marrone's tutelage, residents and merchants united to lobby elected officials and aspiring officials, and cultivate the interest of the local press. They formed coalitions among dozens of neighborhood groups. And Ms. Vella-Marrone helped get a meeting with Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the City Planning Commission, through another commissioner she knew from working with the city. Through her political contacts, she helped to reach out to the Governor.
 
RESULTS: Several weeks ago, the Mayor and Governor came out in opposition to the mall.
 
HER LESSONS:
1. Broaden Your Base. "Form alliances, so it's no longer just the people across the street complaining; it's southwest Brooklyn complaining."
 
2. Know Your Arguments. "Before the meeting with Joe Rose, I said we had to get organized, have specific reasons. We broke it into issues, and different people gave facts and figures. We were professional, but he could see it was a grass-roots organization."
 
THE BURIAL GROUND
 
ACTIVIST: Mandingo Osceola Tshaka, a full-time civic gadfly in Bayside, Queens.
 
THE ISSUE: As the city was preparing to renovate the Everett A. Martins Field playground in Flushing, he discovered that more than 1,000 blacks and Indians were buried underneath. He wanted to make sure the burial ground was preserved.
 
THE CAMPAIGN: By presenting evidence gleaned from maps, death records and newspaper clips, Mr. Tshaka said, he persuaded the Parks Department to temporarily shelve plans to upgrade the park and to initiate an archeological study.
 
RESULTS: After the investigation confirmed Mr. Tshaka's suspicions, the Parks Department agreed to preserve the grave site. During the summer, Councilwoman Julia Harrison got a hefty $1 million from the capital budget to renovate the playground and restore the cemetery.
 
HIS LESSONS:
1. Keep the Heat On. Mr. Tshaka said he once spent 17 hours at One Police Plaza waiting for a public hearing to be called. "The only thing that can sit better than me is a mother hen," he says.
 
2. Follow the Money: With years of experience, Mr. Tshaka knows that the capital budget is a pot of gold. At his urging, he said, Councilman Michael Abel recently secured $1 million to fix up two Bayside schools. How did Mr. Tshaka do it? "Just picked up the phone and asked."
 
DIGGING IN HEELS
 
ACTIVIST: Yolanda Garcia, founder of Nos Quedamos ("We Stay")
 
THE ISSUE: The city was planning to raze her neighborhood in the Melrose section of the Bronx and displace the residents under an urban renewal plan.
 
THE CAMPAIGN: Ms. Garcia and others passed out flyers to spread the word about the city's plans, and then formed Nos Quedamos. A survey of the neighborhood's several thousand residents found only three who wanted to move. That fact helped enlist the support of local officials and pressure Mayor David N. Dinkins, who happened to be facing re-election.
 
RESULTS: The group forced the Dinkins administration to scrap its plan and create a new one, meeting weekly with residents for six months. She has safeguarded the plan under Mr. Giuliani, and successfully pressured the city to clean and fence vast amounts of empty land.
 
HER LESSONS:
1. Globalize the Issue. When Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the City Planning Commission, attempted to truncate the plan's public review, Nos Quedamos enlisted the help of the Borough Presidents and City Council members who worried that his success would undermine their own powers over land use.
 
2. Do the Groundwork Yourself. When trucks wanting to dump on empty land began knocking down the fences the city had erected, the Sanitation Department said it would no longer replace them. So the community identified the dumpers, then called the sanitation police, who confiscated their trucks. The fences are back.
 
3. Persist. "Keep the argument going until you win. It's like water torture: just keep going and going and going."

PUB-DATE: November 9, 1997

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1204 words

HEADLINE: A Matter of Degrees;
Grading Colleges Requires More Than Math

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
WHEN high-school seniors apply to colleges, they have all sorts of ways to compare quality, and some of them are quantifiable: the average SAT scores of the last entering class, for example, or the student-faculty ratio.
But how do states gauge how well their public universities and colleges are doing their job? A growing number of states have begun grading campuses by the numbers, such as graduation rates, rewarding or penalizing their budgets according to their success. The result is a lot of unhappy college presidents and professors. 
 Before a public university can be graded fairly, critics of the new systems say, states must first define the mission of all of its campuses and ask whether the ways of measuring success make sense. When public systems range from elite research universities to community colleges, numbers like graduation rates can reflect several factors besides the quality of instruction, starting with the quality of their students.
"Higher-education assessment is kind of silly," said Lawrence Rudner, an adjunct associate professor of education at Catholic University in Washington, and director of the national Clearinghouse on Assessment and Evaluation. "You're treating the universities as if they were a factory making hammers, as if the same raw ingredients are going into the hammers. But that's not the way universities work."
Graduation rates might seem like a logical way to gauge how well a college is doing. If most students graduate in four or five years, it must be doing a good job. If only a fraction of its students graduate in that time, it must be doing a poor job.
Only last month, the trustees of the City University of New York adopted graduation rates as one factor they will weigh in allocating new instructors among its campuses, giving more to those with higher rates.
As more states use what are known as performance measurement systems to guide public spending for higher education, graduation rates are, in fact, the most widely used measure. But as some states are discovering, grading colleges is a complex business that opens a Pandora's box of issues. While the desire to hold public institutions accountable is reasonable, some experts who have studied these systems say, the measures employed have been anything but. Often, they say, grading campuses in pursuit of improving "quality" and "efficiency" can actually backfire.
Graduation rates, for example, can easily be improved by making courses easier and encouraging teachers to give higher grades.
 
Open Admissions
Colleges can also improve graduation rates by raising admission standards, but in many cases, as in that of City University, public systems have a mission of providing access to as many students as possible, guaranteeing admission to at least a community college to anyone with a high-school degree.
Also, for many campuses with open admissions, low graduation rates reflect the economic disadvantages of their students, many of whom drop out or take longer to graduate because they have to work.
Just looking at a college's graduation rate -- or other measures like test scores, faculty salaries or student satisfaction -- without thinking about how they are connected to other issues won't necessarily improve education, educators say.
"If you are going to tie money to results, you have to think about the games that are going to be played back at the university," said Peter T. Ewell, a senior associate at the National Center for Higher Education Management Systems in Boulder, Colo. "Legislators often want a quick fix and don't realize how intricate it can turn out to be."
Advocates say it is about time that someone tried to introduce rigor into higher education policy. "It is not ideology or politics, it is just a rational approach," said Joseph Burke, director of the public higher education program at the Rockefeller Institute in Albany, who tried to start performance measures at the State University of New York when he was provost. In states that are trying performance measures, he said, "at least it has produced more attention to the goals and priorities they should have been talking about before."
For 20 years, Tennessee stood as a lonely experiment in measuring its colleges' performance, reserving about 5 percent of its higher-education budget to reward its most efficient and effective campuses.
 
More Students, More Money
Like other states since, Tennessee wanted an alternative to basing college budgets on the size of their enrollments. But the state quickly encountered problems in the measures it was using and in the results it was getting, said Trudy W. Banta, a former member of Tennessee's higher-education staff who now is vice chancellor for planning and institutional improvement at Indiana University-Purdue University in Indianapolis.
One set of problems arose, she said, when Tennessee decided to use standardized tests to measure how much its students had learned after four years of college. Because different tests had to be compared in the first years, researchers later found that measures from that period were way off.
The state also found that equity and diversity were being hurt in the drive for better quality, as campuses like Tennessee State University, a historically black college, suffered in statistical comparisons. The state gradually developed other measures to introduce more balance.
 
Encouraging Innovation
"They've gotten better," said Professor Banta, who edits a newsletter on performance assessment.
Missouri is a newcomer to measuring performance, but it is drawing attention for its careful approach. The state still uses a traditional budgeting system to determine most higher-education financing, but in 1993, it added incentives to encourage innovation.
So far less than 5 percent of Missouri's higher-education budget is distributed as incentives, but Robert Stein, an assistant commissioner at the Missouri Coordinating Board for Higher Education, said the approach has had a ripple effect.
"Not everything is as quantifiable as we would like, but it has changed the nature of the conversation," he said. "It has re-energized the faculty into feeling they can make a difference and that teaching and learning are important issues in the state."
Missouri Southern State College, for example, used incentive money to organize freshmen in interest groups that take blocks of classes together. Mr. Stein said the program worked so well that more Missouri Southern students were staying in college and their grades and test scores have risen.
While most states are still using performance to determine a small share of their spending, South Carolina recently decided to use a performance system as the basis for all higher-education spending.
A panel of business executives and politicians drafted a list of 37 performance indicators, and they will be applied quickly, with little testing. This year, the measures will determine a quarter of all new appropriations, or less than $5 million. Next year, they will determine three-quarters of all new money above the previous base. By 1999, they are to cover the state's entire $700 million higher education budget.

HEADLINE: The World;
The Jobless Are Snared In Europe's Safety Net

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
EVEN today, after years of rising unemployment, it isn't hard to see why Germany once won worldwide praise as a workers' paradise.
Full-time employees are entitled to six weeks of paid vacation. They get comprehensive health insurance, including, every four years, three weeks of "spa leave" for recuperation at health resorts, if a doctor prescribes it. Unemployment and job-training benefits can easily last more than two years. Universities are free and good. And as in most of Europe, tough laws make it almost impossible to fire people. 
 But you need a full-time job to enter paradise, and Europe is short about 18 million of them. Even though the continent appears poised for its first significant growth in years, unemployment remains more than twice as high as in the United States and no one expects it to decline much in 1998. European heads of state will meet for a summit conference on joblessness in Luxembourg this month, but few people expect any big results.
 
Sharing the Pain
 Europe's problem transcends jobs. It is also about the distribution of pain and insecurity. Largely because its laws and union contracts have enshrined so many job guarantees, the European system protects those who have jobs at the expense of those who do not. The burdens fall disproportionately on people who cannot find work, and those tend to be young high school or college graduates or older workers who have been forced out of work through plant closings and aren't considered re-trainable.
The insecurity shows up in many areas. In France, about two-thirds of all newly hired workers are on temporary contracts of less than one year. These limited-term jobs allow companies to provide benefits but escape rules making it all but impossible to dismiss workers. In Germany, 5.5 million workers are in a special category of part-time jobs that pay no more than 610 marks a month -- about $350 -- in which neither the worker nor the employer has to pay for unemployment insurance, health insurance or retirement. But the Government does.
A wealth of evidence shows that part-time work falls to young people and women in particular. More than one-third of European workers under the age of 25 are in temporary jobs, while another one-third work without company benefits as "self-employed" contractors. Part-timers account for 16.5 percent of workers across the European Union. Only one-third of the people with full-time jobs are female.
By contrast, the United States Labor Department estimates that part-time work has been fairly constant, encompassing nearly one-fifth of the American work force. Temporary workers, loosely defined to include people who don't expect their jobs to last very long, account for only 2.2 percent of the work force, according to the Labor Department. Meanwhile, American jobless rate of 5 percent remains less than half that of Europe.
Guenter Wisswede, head of the Institute for Economic and Social Psychology at the University of Cologne, said, "We now have the curious situation where companies are growing and becoming more profitable, but their success comes from being able to do that with fewer workers.
"There is a gap between workers who have secured their jobs and workers who either don't have jobs or whose jobs are endangered," Professor Wisswede added. "On the one side are people with secure jobs, who are typically highly qualified, highly involved with their work and well paid. On the other side are the workers on the margin -- young people or people over the age of 50 who can't easily be integrated into the workplace. These are the two big problem areas."
As if that were not enough, European governments are now under enormous pressure to cut social spending in order to bring their fiscal deficits down low enough to meet the guidelines for joining the new single European currency, the euro, in 1999.
The strains are becoming particularly acute as European business comes under increasingly heavy pressure from global competition. Most economists now predict that Germany and France will enjoy economic growth of more than 2.5 percent next year. European economic growth might even surpass that of the United States. The jobless rate, however, will remain at roughly current levels for at least another year.
The relentlessly bleak job picture was central to the election defeat of French conservatives and the victory of Socialists last June. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's political credibility in Germany has been severely damaged by his failure to make progress toward halving the unemployment rate by 2000, and he faces a tough re-election battle next year.
For many workers, the short-term outlook is likely to worsen. European corporations have been consumed by merger mania and tough-minded restructuring. Marginal businesses are being sold or shut down. Workers are being laid off or forced into early retirement. The drumbeat of new announcements is almost daily.
When two of Germany's biggest heavy-industry conglomerates merged their steel mills early this year, they announced that 7,000 German workers would lose their jobs over the next few years. The companies, Thyssen A.G. and the Krupp-Hoesch Group, liked the profits so much that they announced last week that they would merge all their other businesses and save an additional $250 million a year.
In an ever blunter move two weeks ago, Asea Brown-Boveri, a giant Swedish-Swiss engineering company, said it would cut 10,000 workers, most of them in Europe, and plow the savings into Asia. And Roche Holding A.G., the Swiss pharmaceutical giant that is buying a German manufacturer of diagnostic kits for about $10 billion, announced that it would cut 5,000 people, or nearly 7 percent of that company's work force.
Of course, this is Europe, and these workers aren't simply fired. Companies reduce their payroll mostly through attrition and early retirement. And in Germany, laid-off workers are entitled to as much as 70 percent of their salary for at least a year. Job-training money, for both the cost of education and the cost of living, can replace much of a person's earnings for even longer.
In some quarters, there are signs of fatalism about the inevitability of higher unemployment. The French Government under Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, a Socialist, is trying to conjure up new jobs by shortening the workweek -- while not cutting pay. The theory is that companies will hire more people if each person works less. Germany's biggest union, which represents machinery and metal workers, is pushing a 32-hour week but proposing that pay be trimmed proportionately.
Business executives, economists and even top officials at the European Commission in Brussels have loudly denounced both plans. More than one person has remarked that the shortened workweek should be taken to its logical conclusion: cut back the hours all the way to zero and guarantee everyone a job.

HEADLINE: Dissents on Iran and Iraq;
Carrots-for-China Policy Haunts U.S. in the Gulf

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
EACH in his own way, President Jiang Zemin of China and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq threw the spotlight last week on a central contradiction of the Clinton Administration's foreign policy -- a policy most notable for its heavy emphasis on trade.
During Mr. Jiang's visit to the United States, President Clinton said China was "on the wrong side of history" on human rights, but he resisted threatening trade penalties as a way of prodding it toward democracy. With Iraq, in contrast, the Administration insists that a trade embargo and the threat of military force are the only way to force Saddam Hussein to observe the norms of civilized behavior. 
 After six years of going along with this approach on Iraq, some of America's allies in the United Nations are starting to argue that what's sauce for the Chinese goose is sauce for the Persian Gulf gander. If trade is the way to get China on the road to salutary behavior, France and Russia ask, why isn't it for Iraq and, for that matter, Iran as well?
"The Chinese case destroys the American pretension to universality on human rights," the well-connected French daily Le Monde wrote in an editorial after Mr. Jiang's visit ended last week. "Are they less trampled on in Turkey or Saudi Arabia than in Iran or Cuba? The former are allies of America, which cajoles them; the latter are enemies it is bent on punishing."
As far as Iraq is concerned, French officials agree with the Americans that it's still too early to trust the Iraqi President. Last week, continuing a long pattern of defiance, Mr. Hussein tried to exploit the split between the allies by barring Americans from United Nations inspection teams, which are trying to make sure that Iraq has no nuclear, chemical or biological weapons. While emissaries tried to reason with Mr. Hussein in Baghdad, there were signs that he was using the impasse to move evidence out of sight of monitoring devices.
Despite such cheek, the United States favors staying the diplomatic course for now, in part because it recognizes that support for its tough approach is flagging.
"We are prepared to go the extra mile diplomatically if that makes other countries take firm action, if necessary, later," said James Rubin, the State Department spokesman. "But it's true that it's harder and harder to sustain support as memories of the gulf war fade."
 
Leverage
Case in point: the French. While they still don't rule out the use of force, they nevertheless see the repeated pattern of Iraqi challenges and American-led military responses as a vicious cycle that leads nowhere over the long term. They say that since sanctions would have to be eased should Iraq eventually comply fully with disarmament orders, it's better to start talking about how to do that now rather than when compliance happens.
"The more hope we can give Saddam Hussein that trade sanctions might eventually be lifted, the more leverage we have in the long run," a French official said. "If we refuse, we create growing resentment in the whole Iraqi population," he said, since the sanctions hurt the Iraqi people and not Mr. Hussein. Officials in Russia, also on the United Nations Security Council, expressed the same view.
Of course, both France and Russia may simply be tired of being led around by the nose in the Persian Gulf by the World's Only Superpower. Probably more important, they'd like to trade with Iran and Iraq about as much as America likes to trade with China. "No country has a foreign policy based solely on human rights," Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine observed recently, and American policy toward China proves his point.
After the Persian Gulf war ended in 1991 with Mr. Hussein's army driven from Kuwait -- but short of an allied push to Baghdad to oust him -- American leaders believed, or hoped, that a trade embargo and other restrictions would quickly cause his downfall. They guessed wrong. The French and Russians now argue that since the Americans are unlikely to send an army back in to finish the job, and since the world has to live with Mr. Hussein anyway, it should think about carrots as well as sticks to get him to change his ways.
Exactly what kind of carrots is not yet clear, and the French agree with the United States that now is not the time to offer them. But, they argue, a trade embargo isn't a policy; at best, they say, it can be only one element in a broader strategy to encourage moderation and engagement with the West, in both Iraq and Iran.
Clearly, feelings against either country do not run as strongly in Europe as they do in Washington. On Iran, key to the divergent views is Americans' bitter memory of the 444-day hostage-taking at the United States Embassy in Teheran starting 18 years ago this month.
 
'Critical Dialogue'
In 1995, Europeans preferred to maintain a "critical dialogue" with Iran rather than join the United States in imposing trade sanctions over the Islamic regime's support for terrorism. And in September, a French oil company, Total, joined Russian and Malaysian concerns in a $2 billion joint deal to explore an Iranian natural gas field under the gulf; the French Government backed them in thumbing their noses at American extraterritorial legislation aimed at punishing foreign firms that do business with Iran, Libya or Cuba.
Europeans who support the tough American stance on Iraq -- even the British -- detest American efforts to apply such laws to them. They depend on trade for an economic revival on the continent.
How anxious Europeans are to look on the bright side is clear in their recent policy toward Iran. All 15 European Union countries withdrew their ambassadors from Teheran last summer after a German court found the leadership there responsible for ordering a terrorist bombing in Berlin five years ago. They have not yet sent the envoys back in only because Iran insists on dictating to them the order in which they may return, with Germany returning last. The Europeans have balked.
But it's clearly only a matter of time before they do go back. American attempts to force them into a more "moral" policy just make them more determined, a fact Washington has recognized by avoiding a direct confrontation so far with France and Russia over the gas deal.
Eventually, the sanctions issue will have to be revisited with Iraq as well. Count on the European allies and the Arab countries in the gulf-war coalition to remember the China parallel.

HEADLINE: Urban Renewal;
Politicians Even A Voter Could Love

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
MAYOR PAT McCRORY of Charlotte, N.C., a Republican, is so revered that several big-name Democrats refused to take him on this year. That left him two walk-on opponents: a disciple of Lyndon LaRouche and a convicted bank robber given to sporting a pith helmet and a pair of bayonette sheaths. The Mayor practically walked to re-election Tuesday.
In St. Paul, where the Democrat-Farmer-Labor Party has long dominated, Mayor Norm Coleman switched to the Republican Party before this year's election. On Tuesday, despite his defection, Mayor Coleman won re-election easily. The next day, a draft committee announced that it would press the Mayor to run for Governor next year. 
 And in New York, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has become so politically untouchable that on election night he was surrounded by more Democrats than his fellow Republicans. That did not stop the Republican Party in Iowa from inviting him the next day to travel to the state to show his stuff for the Presidential competition in 2000. (He declined.)
In an era when elected officials are hardly beloved, occupants of this country's city halls are the closest things to model politicians. As parties become less important and as Republicans and Democrats search for ways to set themselves apart, mayors are setting the course for post-ideological, pragmatic politics.
Last week's elections underscored the trend: No sitting mayor of a large city was turned out. Most won in landslides.
Beyond their popularity, what is striking about these mayors is that they represent different parties, come from different regions and preside over cities with different problems -- yet they are remarkably similar: in a highly partisan era, none is especially partisan, and some are disliked by their own party establishments -- which could be hazardous to bigger political ambitions.
"You probably wouldn't be able to distinguish who's a Democrat and who's a Republican -- we're all managing in very much the same way," said Mayor Tom Murphy of Pittsburgh, who was re-elected Tuesday with 77 percent of the vote. "My slogan in the campaign was, 'He never forgets to pay the bill.' Sounds pretty Republican, doesn't it?" Mayor Murphy is a Democrat.
Mayor Giuliani, for one, favors abortion rights and has never been forgiven by prominent Republicans for backing Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, for re-election in the 1994 gubernatorial race. Mayor Richard Riordan of Los Angeles, a Republican, backed Senator Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat, in her re-election bid that same year. Among the Democrats, Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago has been seen by some in his party as championing an ethnic backlash. And Mayor Michael R. White of Cleveland, in an un-Democrat-like move, took on the teachers union and ridiculed Cleveland's teachers as "the inmates running the asylum."
Few are polished politicians. And despite their success on Election Day, many are not greatly admired personally. In Detroit, when people refer to "the Mayor," usually they still mean the irascible Coleman Young, not Dennis Archer, who succeeded him and was re-elected last week. Mayor Giuliani, according to polls, is more admired than he is liked. Mayor Daley is famously inarticulate. Mayor Riordan, by political standards, is almost a recluse.
Most of these mayors can point to a particular accomplishment in cities once deemed ungovernable. Mayor Giuliani touts the enormous decline in crime. Mayor Edward Rendell of Philadelphia took on his city's powerful public employee unions. And Mayor Daley took control of his city's schools.
 
The Whitman Lesson
A few years back, it was the governors -- Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, John Engler of Michigan, Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin -- who were the hot political properties, at least in the Republican Party. Three of the last four Presidents had been governors.
Now, governors risk even being eclipsed by perhaps less known politicians like Mayors Giuliani, Daley, Riordan, White, Archer and Thomas M. Menino of Boston (who ran unopposed). Mrs. Whitman, a Republican, was almost toppled last week not just by a political unknown but by a mayor, James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge, N.J.
The mayors should be grateful for the timing of the stewardships: in most cities, crime has dropped and economies have revived. "Six to eight years ago, cities were in dire shape, mayors were highly unpopular and the attitude was, 'We govern tough places, please feel sorry for us,' " Mayor Stephen Goldsmith of Indianapolis said. "This new group of mayors has a pragmatism that supersedes political differences."
Gov. George V. Voinovich of Ohio, a Republican who was Mayor of Cleveland, said showy mayors of the past are, for the most part, gone. "I used to kid that in New York City, you had to be an entertainer to be a successful mayor," he said. "But I think we reached a point in this country where people said, 'I don't care how you look, what your style is or how cute you are: Doggone it! I want to feel safe on the street when go home at night.' "
Indeed, the ascendancy of hands-on, nonpartisan mayors marks a pronounced shift in urban politics. For years, cities were the province of Democratic machines and mayors would not dare toy with unions or social welfare programs.
Their managerial experience and ability to avoid partisanship may be an asset for Mayors who seek higher office. Yet the factors that make them so popular locally can be an obstacle for those with grander ambitions. Mayor Giuliani's cachet with Democrats (45 percent of Democrats who voted Tuesday supported the Mayor) would not serve him well, for example, in Republican Presidential primaries.
"There's a certain suspicion that comes from other municipalities around the state," said Mayor Archer of Detroit, who is mentioned as a candidate for Governor next year. "Sometimes people have a sense that a mayor coming from a large urban area would only have his or her city as a priority."
Senator Dirk Kempthorne of Idaho, a Republican who was Mayor of Boise, cited himself as evidence that there was hope for advancement. When he contemplated running for mayor, he said, "I was told by political experts it was a dead-end street."
Still, the record is not encouraging. Only three mayors have made it to the White House: Andrew Johnson of Greenville, Tenn., Grover Cleveland of Buffalo, and, the closest thing to a modern politician to make the leap, Calvin Coolidge of Northampton, Mass.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 837 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
Another Decline In Unemployment
Unemployment tumbled to a 24-year low amid brisk hiring in October, the Labor Department reported. "It's a sign of a tremendously strong U.S. economy," said Allen Sinai, president of Primark Decision Economics of Boston. The rate fell two-tenths of a percentage point, to 4.7 percent, the lowest since 4.6 percent in October 1973. Most other data also pointed to a robust economy. Retailers reported unexpectedly strong October sales, underscoring the importance of Halloween goods; the Goldman Sachs retail composite index climbed 4.5 percent. The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that manufacturing unexpectedly strengthened in October, and the Conference Board said its index of leading indicators rose two-tenths of a percent in September. Also, personal incomes rose four-tenths of a percent in September, while factory orders rose for the fourth consecutive month. Demand for metals and high technology paced the gain of four-tenths of a percent. Construction spending fell unexpectedly in September, however, posting its biggest drop in almost a year, 1.1 percent.
 
MARKETS
A Rocky Recovery
Like many convalescents, the stock market had some good days and some bad ones. After being battered the previous week, the Dow Jones industrial average soared 232 points on Monday. By Friday, investors were selling -- reacting, again, to the uncertainties in Southeast Asia, as well as to the specter of inflation raised by the strong jobs data. The blue-chip average ended the week at 7,581.32, up 139.24 for the week. The Nasdaq composite index was up 8.79 at 1,602.40. . . . The New York Stock Exchange plans to drop its controversial rule No. 500, which makes it nearly impossible for a listed company to move to another market voluntarily. Nasdaq officials have long cited it, warning potential defectors that if they went to the Big Board, there would be no turning back.
 
TAXES
Vox Populi Is Heard
Were L. L. Bean's flannel shirts about to join the tea in Boston Harbor? Their phone lines jammed by angry consumers, mail order companies backed away from an agreement that the Direct Marketing Association had reached with state tax authorities to collect sales taxes. . . . Nor are Federal taxes any more welcome. The House voted by an overwhelming 426 to 4 to rein in the Internal Revenue Service, giving taxpayers new rights and authorizing the creation of a new board made up largely of private citizens to oversee the tax collectors. "The I.R.S. is too big and too mean," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader. The agency is also getting a new boss, who has promised to tame it, as well as to rejuvenate its arthritic computers. The Senate confirmed Charles O. Rossotti, co-founder of American Management Systems, a computer systems and consulting company, as commissioner.
 
COMPANIES
Levi's Cutoffs
It's not that people finally have enough jeans. It's a matter of competing while paying American workers. Levi Strauss said it would cut a third of its American manufacturing jobs, affecting 6,395 workers and closing 11 factories in four states. But it promised a generous severance package. . . . City officials halted work on Donald J. Trump's $3 billion Riverside South project in Manhattan, below, because of defective concrete. Mr. Trump said the subcontractor that poured it, Laquila/Pinnacle, would have to bear the resultant costs. . . . AT&T is cutting to 3 from 33 the number of long-distance rates paid by residential customers who do not subscribe to a special calling plan. . . . General Electric is cashing in its 13 percent stake in Lockheed Martin for $2.8 billion. . . . Boeing plans to phase out the MD-80 and the MD-90, civilian jets that compete with its 737. Boeing inherited the planes when it acquired McDonnell Douglas.
 
DEALS
Gambling on ITT
Hilton Hotels raised its hostile bid for control of ITT, only to be countered on Friday with a sweetened offer from Starwood Lodging Trust. Shareholders are to meet on Wednesday. . . . The Justice Department recommended that BellSouth not be allowed to offer long-distance service in South Carolina. . . . Microsoft is close to an agreement to invest up to $1 billion in the cable television operations of U S West, according to several people involved in the negotiations.
 
PRICES
Ceilings Are Legal
Consumers can shop for that hot new car with less fear of having to pay a premium. The Supreme Court, in one of its most important antitrust decisions in years, ruled unanimously that a manufacturer or supplier does not necessarily violate Federal antitrust law by placing a ceiling on the retail price a dealer can charge for its products. The decision was widely welcomed by manufacturers, notably those in the auto and computer industries, who said it could lead to lower consumer prices. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor noted that it remained illegal for manufacturers to impose minimum prices on dealers.

HEADLINE: DIARY: AUTOS;
Unafraid in Asia

 BODY:
Although the economic tigers of Southeast Asia may be looking more like alley cats, American and Japanese auto makers continue their Asian expansion, apparently undaunted. G.M. and Ford are building huge new assembly plants in Thailand, where a crumbling economy caused the Prime Minister, Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, below, to resign after just 11 months in office. The auto makers are also preparing to open up to five more factories in Southeast Asia and China. Toyota and Honda are cutting back production temporarily but are not changing their basic plans. . . . At home, Detroit's Big Three reported weak sales in October, the first month of the new model year. G.M. sales fell 4 percent; Ford's, 2.1 percent, and Chrysler's, 8.3 percent. Buyers showed enthusiasm only for the hottest new or redesigned models, like the brawny new Dodge Durango sport utility vehicle or the redesigned Honda Accord. Honda's sales rose 11.2 percent.

HEADLINE: United Way, Faced With Fewer Donors, Is Giving Away Less

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Justine and Jasmine Scott, 7-year-old twins, wanted to spend the summer at Challengers Boys and Girls Club, which for almost three decades has provided a haven for youngsters from the dangerous neighborhoods south of downtown Los Angeles.
"My girls didn't want to just watch their grandmother's television while I work," said their mother, Loretta Scott, a secretary. "But with the gangs, it's not safe for them to play in the neighborhood." 
 But the club turned them away, as it has hundreds of others in the last three summers, because its allocation from the Greater Los Angeles United Way, adjusted for inflation, has been cut 75 percent since 1990.
The story is the same across the country. Boys and Girls Clubs, Big Sisters, Boy Scouts, Family Service Associations and similar charities are getting less from United Way, forcing them to raise more on their own, and to deny help to people like the Scott twins.
Five years after its former national president was found to be converting charity money to his own use, United Way is in crisis, abandoned by 4.5 million people -- 20 percent of its donors. And most of its 17.7 million remaining donors give less through payroll deduction, United Way's bread and butter.
If donations had continued to rise as fast as they did in the five years before the scandal, United Way would have raised $4.14 billion last year. Instead it raised $3.25 billion, down 11 percent from 1991 but up slightly from 1995. (All figures are adjusted for inflation.) And less of that smaller amount helps the poor.
But it is far more than the betrayal of the public trust by the former president, William V. Aramony, that has battered United Way, the nation's largest fund-raising organization, which this month is winding up its annual fund-raising appeals on behalf of a federation of social service agencies. The nation's giving habits have also changed drastically as corporate downsizing ripped into the core of United Way's base: large factories and offices.
Not that Americans have turned more miserly. The American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel says that total charitable giving by individuals has risen 9 percent, or $10.7 billion, since 1991, while United Way is down 11 percent, or $400 million. But donors are often leaving out the neediest causes -- social services in poor neighborhoods.
Since 1991, donations to social service charities, a big chunk of which goes to United Way agencies, have fallen 5 percent. The big winners have been health charities and hospitals, up 25 percent, to $13.9 billion; education, up 21 percent, to $18.8 billion, and religion, up 12 percent to $69.4 billion.
This shift has been an added blow to the poor, coming as the Government has cut social-service spending.
The decline in support is most severe in older cities and in California, long a United Way trend-setter.
Donations to the New York City United Way campaign fell 17.5 percent between 1991 and 1996. A confidential study last year of large California United Ways by Bain & Company showed donations falling 7 percent annually from 1991 through 1994; they have since been essentially flat.
Donations to the Los Angeles United Way last year were half what they were in 1990. There were also declines in Orange County and San Diego. The United Way in Vallejo, north of San Francisco, ran a $600,000 deficit and is now folding into the United Way of the Bay Area, the first of what is likely to become a wave of consolidations among the 1,300 United Ways.
Thomas A. Ruppaner, president of United Way of the Bay Area, said the confidential Bain report "is telling us that we are going out of business unless we fundamentally change."
The core of United Way's problem is the loss of millions of donors who once had money deducted from their paychecks. And the trouble is compounded by slower wage growth for those who still donate.
Detailed national figures are not available, but, in a typical case, the United Way of Central Indiana found that the average payroll gift last year was $91.42, down a third from 1991.
This problem would have been much worse but for a shift in strategy by United Way, which has turned to business owners and executives for yearly gifts of $1,000 or more. These gifts provided 17 percent of United Way donations last year, up from 8 percent five years ago. In effect, United Way is now competing more with its member agencies to raise money from the wealthiest people.
The number of factories and offices holding United Way campaigns is also shrinking. Nationwide data are not available, but in Indianapolis, for example, the number of workplaces with campaigns last year was 11 percent below that of 1991.
Many people also mistakenly believe that Mr. Aramony, who is in prison after being convicted of fraud and tax evasion, is still in charge. "Only 4 percent of the public knows that we have had a change in leadership," said Betty Beene, the third United Way of America president since Mr. Aramony.
United Ways also face demands by national corporations, with fewer executives to spare, to take on more of the costs of their campaigns. In San Francisco, Chicago, Boston and other large cities, United Ways have developed regional pledge-processing centers, and Ms. Beene is about to begin a national center. These centers collect money from national employers like Wal-Mart or J. C. Penney and, for a fee, pass it on to United Ways in smaller cities.
"The costs for these pledge-processing centers seem nickel and dime to the big United Ways," said Carolyn Walden, executive director of Humboldt County United Way, in Eureka, Calif., "but that money is our budget to run small United Ways."
Traditionally, United Way member agencies could count on their annual allocations growing in proportion to total donations. That began changing in the 1980's, when reformers led by the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy started urging companies to let workers send money deducted from their pay to any charity.
United Way responded by adding charities, creating a way to channel certain donations to favored charities and urging companies to lock out rival fund-raising groups.
The reformers expected that once donors were free to give to charities of their choice, they would give more to those serving the poor and protecting the environment, especially non-United Way agencies.
But when donors specify where they want their donation used, the money tends to go to agencies with the biggest budgets, like the Boy Scouts and the Red Cross. So in many places the traditional system of spreading money around based on need has broken down.
"People who work for the big companies in the cities are not giving to the inner-city charities," said Pablo Eisenberg, founder of the reform movement, "but to their Y.M.C.A. in the suburbs."
But even the best-known agencies are suffering because United Way added many agencies to its list. Last year, the 10 largest United Way agencies received 38 percent of all United Way funds, down from 43 percent in 1985.
In other words, each charity gets a skimpier piece of a smaller pie, which means some people go without. Boys and Girls Clubs, which serve mostly poor children, counted on United Way for 21 percent of their budgets last year, down from 36 percent in 1987.
Big Sisters of Central Indiana gets 35 percent of its money from United Way, down from 67 percent two decades ago. Sally Herrholz, the executive director, said she expected United Way's share of her financing to continue to fall.
This forces her to spend more time running fund-raising events like bowling tournaments, rather than focusing on her main task: training volunteers and connecting them with girls from troubled homes. Ms. Herrholz said only half the eligible girls receive help.
A shrinking pie means a rising share of donations eaten up by overhead -- everything from running fund-raising campaigns to keeping office lights on.
Historically, United Ways have been the most efficient mass fund-raisers, holding overhead below 15 percent, but at large California United Ways overhead averaged 22 percent in 1995, the Bain study shows.
United Ways are more efficient than most people believe, a survey commissioned by United Way of America found. Of those expressing an opinion, 60 percent wrongly estimated United Way overhead at 40 percent or more.
"There is a disconnect between what United Ways do and what people think they do," Ms. Beene said. "And the reason for that disconnect is our ineptness at explaining what we do."
Within the 1,300 United Ways, sharp divisions have arisen about how to cope with the drop in popular support, the new demands of corporations and increased competition for donations.
Many United Ways are marketing themselves as a force that will solve community problems like youth violence and drug addiction. Many agency directors, though, say that that is not the proper mission and that their job is not to solve social problems but to provide services that society will always need.
"If United Way sells itself as a problem-solving agency, they will be out of business in 20 years," said John Brewster, executive director of the Boys and Girls Club in Santa Ana, Calif. "I don't solve problems. I help kids develop on their way to being adults."
To cope with less, some United Ways, like the one in Sacramento, Calif., have begun dictating precisely how member agencies can spend their money.
Nonprofit agency directors who used to count on what they referred to as "golden dollars" from United Way to pay overhead and run the programs they felt were best say that the change gives United Way too much power.
The most radical approach was taken two years ago in California by the United Ways in Orange and San Diego Counties. They dropped the system of having volunteers allocate money and substituted annual applications for money, opening the process to all charities and in essence becoming grant-making foundations.
"We drive the agencies nuts because they don't know from year to year what they will get," said Bruce Boland, chief professional officer of the San Diego United Way.
The bigger agencies, Mr. Boland added, "don't like the annual request for proposals, and they are saying, 'We formed you, United Way, and your job is to fund-raise for us.' I tell them that the system has evolved."
The executive directors of nine large San Diego United Way charities have been quietly meeting to study whether they should quit United Way and form their own fund-raising federation.
Making charities apply for grants, said Ms. Walden, the Eureka United Way executive, is "redundant and wasteful and is contrary to what we are about, which is a stable source of funding for member agencies that the community wants and needs."
Other United Ways, like the statewide one in Delaware, are trying to return to the system in which the United Way marketed itself as raising money primarily for a small group of social service agencies.
Although donor designations are still allowed, they are no longer promoted. Pledges to United Way of Delaware rose 14 percent last year compared with 1995 figures.
