HEADLINE: Clinton Stalks G.O.P. Votes In Final Push for Trade Bill

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
As the House of Representatives went into an unusual weekend session and the wheeling and dealing on President Clinton's trade legislation began in earnest, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley declared: "If you like attention, this is a good time to be undecided."
That is doubtlessly true for some lawmakers. Leaders worked all day today, for instance, to rewrite the bill's agriculture provisions in a way that might squeeze two or three votes out of the Florida delegation. 
 A freshman Democrat from North Carolina, Bob Etheridge, announced his support for the bill after he received a letter from President Clinton promising that any new tobacco legislation would "provide tobacco farmers with a safe, sound and secure future." Mr. Etheridge also obtained a pledge that future trade accords would not put American peanut growers at a disadvantage.
Representative Nita M. Lowey, who seemed genuinely undecided, spent 45 minutes at the White House Friday night, one on one with the President, without even any staff members present. Ms. Lowey, a Democrat from Westchester County, whose district includes parts of the Bronx and Queens, said today that she was still not sure how she would vote. She is torn between two sets of political friends.
The measure, meant to encourage international trade, would give the President the authority, called "fast track" in Congressional jargon, to negotiate trade pacts that Congress could vote up or down but could not amend. Every President since Gerald R. Ford has had this authority. Mr. Clinton's lapsed three years ago.
A lawmaker counting votes for the bill's proponents said tonight that he thought his side was seven votes shy of a majority. The prevailing view in the Capitol was that most of the additional votes had to come from Republicans. But so far there has been no indication that votes were switching.
In other business, the Senate passed a big spending bill but Congress stalled on related issues. Page A22.
On the trade legislation, a business lobbyist who has been counting noses concluded that the supporters and opponents of the legislation could each rely on perhaps 190 to 200 votes, and that three or four dozen lawmakers were not yet committed one way or the other. With 434 members of the House (and one vacant seat), 218 votes are needed for victory if everyone votes.
At last tally, about 160 Republicans and about 40 Democrats were committed to vote for the bill.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the Ways and Means Committee, which has jurisdiction over trade legislation, said President Clinton would have to provide 15 or 20 more votes from among Democrats if he hoped to win. But others say the bill is dependent on Republicans for the winning votes.
The vote is scheduled for Sunday, but the view in the Capitol was that it would probably be postponed if a defeat seemed likely.
Passage of the legislation, the President declared in his radio address this morning, "means that American leadership in this hemisphere and elsewhere -- not only on trade but in fighting drugs and terrorism and dealing with our other security problems -- will be strengthened."
On the horizon for Mr. Clinton and his trade negotiators is a series of complex worldwide agreements over such issues as financial services, trade in telecommunications and computer services, and opening agricultural markets.
Mr. Clinton argues that his hand is weakened if he cannot guarantee that Congress will not reopen every deal to protect the interests of a specific constituent lobby.
Opponents counter that the United States should not be striking trade pacts with countries that abuse workers and have substandard environmental safeguards.
But in the Capitol today, no one was considering the substance of the issue. "This is way past being decided on the merits," a senior Republican staff assistant said. "At this stage, it is all politics."
On trade matters, more perhaps than on any other issue that Congress faces regularly, lawmakers focus more closely on the concerns of their constituents than they do on ideology or party loyalty.
This has created some strange alliances among politicians who are usually at odds, and it explains Representative Lowey's dilemma.
From one side, Ms. Lowey is being hammered by labor unions, environmentalists and food-safety watchdogs -- all staunch opponents of the trade bill.
They are among her strongest political friends. Environmental legislation has been her calling card since she was elected to Congress in 1988, and unions contributed more than $100,000 to her re-election campaign last year.
"Lots of people blame all the ills of society on trade," she said in an interview.
From the other side, Ms. Lowey is hearing from her many constituents who work in New York for telecommunications companies, securities firms, banks and retail stores, all of whom would benefit handsomely from expanded trade opportunities. "By inclination, I'm a free-trader," she said.
To show that she is not being bought out, Ms. Lowey said today, she will reject all donations from labor unions in her next campaign if she does decide to vote against the legislation.
The House had been scheduled to vote on the measure on Friday, but the vote was postponed to give the President and his supporters time to round up more votes.
The President worked Friday night and all day today, the White House said, calling and meeting with wavering legislators. At least three Cabinet members -- Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman and Commerce Secretary Daley -- were in Congress today working for votes. The word at the White House was that some officials might even visit wavering legislators at home tonight.
An organization of more than 600 businesses that support the trade bill set up shop in a Ways and Means Committee meeting room on the first floor of the Capitol so the business lobbyists could spend the weekend buttonholing lawmakers as they came to vote on other bills.
But opponents of the bill were working equally hard. A team of labor lobbyists fanned out across the Capitol telling Democrats that the unions were the only reliable source of campaign funds and grass-roots support for Democratic candidates.
When Democratic Representatives met in the Longworth Office Building across the street from the Capitol this afternoon, the first-floor corridor -- known as Gucci Gulch because it is where the well-shod tax lobbyists hang out when tax legislation is under consideration -- was lined with labor officials who nabbed lawmakers as they came and went.
The session in the Longworth Building was angry -- "a raucous caucus," Representative Gary L. Ackerman, Democrat of Queens, called it.
Many Democratic opponents of the legislation are upset at the President for suggesting earlier in the week that they were motivated by their own political needs rather than the country's foreign and economic policy. At one point, according to people who were present, Representative Peter A. DeFazio of Oregon accused Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff, of favoring the fast-track legislation merely to improve his stock portfolio.
A few Democrats were said to have jeered Mr. DeFazio, but many applauded him.
Rumors were rampant about favors the Administration was promising in return for votes. But if deals were being cut, they were being cut outside public view, and the specifics were difficult to track down.
"The dealing is low, slow and late and not very much," said Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, relating an insight based on 42 years of experience in the House. "You find someone who can give you an honest description of what they're giving away, and I'd like to meet them."

LENGTH: 424 words

HEADLINE: ELECTION '97;
A Portrait of New Jersey Voters

BYLINE: By MARJORIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
In 1993, Christine Todd Whitman became Governor of New Jersey by defeating her Democratic opponent by 2 percentage points. This year, the contest was even closer. Mrs. Whitman defeated her Democratic challenger, James E. McGreevey, by only one percentage point.
Men, Republicans, conservatives and voters with incomes over $50,000 gave Mrs. Whitman a majority of their votes this time as they did in 1993. Mr. McGreevey was backed by most blacks, Democrats, liberals and voters under age 30. 
 Surveys of voters leaving polling stations throughout the state are used to make up this table, which shows how 71 groups have voted for Governor over the past three elections. The exit polls used are based on large numbers of respondents, making it possible to evaluate some groups whose share of the voting population makes them too small to measure in a telephone survey.
 
The Third Candidate
The Libertarian candidate, Murray Sabrin, received 5 percent of the vote, the highest percentage any third-party candidate has received in an election for the Governor of New Jersey since 1919. Candidates other than the Republican or the Democrat generally receive, at most, one or two percent of the vote. Mr. Sabrin's best showing was among conservatives and independents. He did better with men than women, particularly men aged 45 to 59. Mr. Sabrin's appeal increased with income level, with the exception of the more affluent, with incomes over $100,000.
 
Gender
The gender gap is the difference between a candidate's votes from men and from women. Four years ago, men were 8 points more likely to vote for Mrs. Whitman than were women. The difference was most pronounced among conservatives and older voters. This year, there is only a 2-point difference among Mrs. Whitman's supporters, regardless of age or political identification.
 
Economic Concerns
In 1993, voters who regarded the economic condition of New Jersey as good favored the incumbent Democrat. Mrs. Whitman was strongly backed by voters who characterized the state's economy as poor. Support was divided among those who described the economy as "not so good." This year, as incumbent, Mrs. Whitman received the majority of votes from people who describe New Jersey's economy positively. Those who perceive the economy in a negative fashion favored Mr. McGreevey. However, while about three-quarters of voters saw the state's economy as poor or not so good in 1993, about two-thirds describe it as excellent or good this year. MARJORIE CONNELLY

GRAPHIC: Table shows polling results during the 1989, 1993, and 1997 elections.
NOTE: 1997 data were collected by Voter News Service based on questionnaires completed by 1,977 voters leaving 44 polling places throughout New Jersey on Election Day. 1993 data were collected by Voter Research and Surveys based on questionnaires completed by 1,988 voters. 1989 data were based on a survey conducted by The New York Times and WCBS-TV News with questionnaires from 1,653 voters. Those who gave no answer are not shown. Third-party candidates are not shown except for Sabrin in 1997. Dashes indicate that a question was not asked in a particular year. Asterisks indicate that there was an insufficient number of respondents in that subgroup. Double asterisks represent less than one half of a percent. SECTION: Section 8; Page 5; Column 3; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 1396 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
High-Stakes Poker Is the Game for the Yankees

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Maybe the Yankees are serious about trading Bernie Williams, but their words and actions sound suspiciously as if they've been heard and seen before.
Go back to 1987 for one notorious example. Don Mattingly, in 1986, had batted .352, hit 31 home runs and driven in 113 runs. Whatever salary he sought in arbitration was his. Just by walking into the room, he could have the first arbitration-won salary of $2 million or more. 
 Just before Mattingly submitted his number, though, George Steinbrenner told him that if he won too high a salary, he probably would have to trade him. Couldn't afford those high salaries, you know.
So what did Mattingly do? The unstoppable, unflappable athlete bought the bluff and asked for $1,975,000. The chances of the Yankees' trading Mattingly at the time were less than zero. If they had, the fans would have run Steinbrenner out of town and back to Tampa.
By threatening to trade Williams if he demands too lucrative a contract in his year before free agency, Steinbrenner appears to be engaging in the same strategy he pursued with Mattingly. Why not? It worked then, and he figures it could work now.
But Williams is less likely to panic and go weak-kneed than Mattingly, because Scott Boras's clients generally hold to their positions. Sometimes that can be detrimental (see Jim Abbott with the Angels in 1992), but in Williams's case, he has to figure the Yankees would have trouble trading him because they could not come close to getting equal value.
Boras has said that Williams will not negotiate a contract with a team the Yankees want to trade him to, and what team is going to give up good players or prospects for a high-priced player it might have for only one year?
Someone might want to shed a high-priced player to offset Williams's salary, but the Yankees would gain nothing from that exchange.
The problem Steinbrenner faces with Williams is his own creation. As other clubs have followed the Cleveland Indians' lead and begun signing their young players to multiyear contracts, Steinbrenner has shunned the practice that can save a team millions.
The closest comparison to the Yankees and Williams is the Indians and Jim Thome, who like Williams is a productive hitter with power and can be a free agent after next season. Before Thome played a full season in the major leagues, the Indians signed him in March 1994 to a four-year contract with an option for a fifth year. In the first four years they paid Thome $5,325,000. Next year they will pay him $3,625,000 for a five-year total of $8.95 million.
Negotiating year by year, the Yankees have paid Williams $8,875,000 the past four years. He should be able to get at least that much in salary arbitration in February, meaning the Yankees will pay him about twice as much as the Indians will pay Thome in the same five-year period.
Having opted not to try to sign Williams early in his career and buy out his arbitration years, the Yankees are following the same path with Andy Pettitte and Mariano Rivera. As another comparison, the Angels signed Troy Percival, their closer, to a $3.5 million contract in March 1996 that calls for four years and two option years, taking him beyond his free-agency eligibility. By the time Rivera reaches that point, signing one-year contracts, he will have earned many millions more. Before last season, Pettitte was prepared to sign a three-year, $4.3 million contract, but General Manager Bob Watson told his agent that Steinbrenner didn't want to do it.
When Steinbrenner was asked why he has never signed good players early, he did not answer directly. "It may be that we will start to go that way, but who knows," he said. "You have to study it."
Asked whether he thought the Yankees would be ahead in the salary game if they had signed players the way the Indians have, he said: "That's a matter for judgment. We have guaranteed contracts. What you have to realize when you're guaranteeing it, what happens if a pitcher you sign for $5 million tears his rotor cuff and never pitches again? That's an awful lot of money to be gambling."
Steinbrenner said the decision to sign any player at any time requires a business judgment. Then he lamented the change that he said has occurred in negotiations for younger players.
"The way it was originally," he said, "the teams had the advantage in the earlier years. Players had theirs in later years. Now what has happened is players and their agents are forgetting that the first years are to be for the benefit of ownership and the team. Then when they served some time it would be to their advantage. Unfortunately, they want to remember one-half of it. The whole thing has gotten askew."
 
The Ceiling Rises
Twenty years ago, Bowie Kuhn, the baseball commissioner, put a $400,000 ceiling on the amount of cash a team could include in a trade. Everything has gone up since, including the ceiling. Here are the largest sums teams have included in trades to offset the players' salaries:
For John Olerud, Toronto gave the Mets $5 million; Kenny Rogers, the Yankees gave Oakland $5 million; Ruben Sierra, Detroit gave Cincinnati $4,875,000; Jay Bell, Pittsburgh gave Kansas City $2.2 million; Jose Canseco, Boston gave Oakland $1 million; J. T. Snow, Anaheim gave San Francisco $750,000; Dean Palmer, Texas gave Kansas City $673,343; Sierra, the Yankees gave Detroit $500,000, and Pete Harnisch, the Mets gave Milwaukee $473,896.
 
Pittsburgh's Next Step
Under the Pittsburgh Pirates' lease for Three Rivers Stadium, if the city, the state and the county do not come up with a plan to pay for a new park within two years of the team's change of ownership, it can declare its intention to move. Voters soundly rejected a plan last Tuesday, meaning the Pirates can trigger the timetable for moving in February.
But Kevin McClatchy, the team's managing partner, isn't counting down to the Feb. 14 trigger date. "The Mayor said he felt he would have some sort of direction or decision by January," McClatchy said. "So there's no need for me to make any decision on the trigger right now given his statements."
Instead, McClatchy said he is going back to running the team and letting elected officials try to develop a solution. "My main goal would be to get a new facility in Pittsburgh," said the 34-year-old owner, who has won over the cynics who believed he bought the team to move it elsewhere. "That's why I spent 18 months speaking at every Kiwanis club and Rotary club in western Pennsylvania trying to get support for baseball in Pittsburgh. I was willing to sign an ironclad 25-year lease and put considerable time and money into making that a reality. It is disappointing it didn't pass."
McClatchy said the idea of "moving the team and starting over" does not appeal to him. But, he quickly added: "It's also important that we have the ability to compete in Pittsburgh. I think in three years we could have a very good team. The real tragedy to me would be in three or four years to watch these young and talented players walk out the door."
An alternative concept surfaced after the funding proposal lost. The idea, put forward by Frank Lucchino, an influential Pittsburgh lawyer and older brother of Larry Lucchino, the San Diego Padres' president, would use public money to build a new park, but taxpayers would share in the franchise's increased value resulting from the new park.
"If the franchise is worth $70 million today, and after we build the ball park and people stream in, the value becomes $140 million," Lucchino said, "that would mean an appreciation of $70 million was caused by the taxpayers' investment. Share that with us. The numbers would have to be worked out. I suggested 50-50. That would mean $35 million is ours to go into an economic development fund to create additional jobs in Allegheny County."
Lucchino said the Pirates would have to agree with such a plan before officials could consider it. McClatchy said he had been out of town and was not familiar with the idea.
 
Angelos's Revolving Door
Peter Angelos does not like comparisons people make between him and George Steinbrenner. Sometimes, though, comparisons can't be avoided. When Angelos hires a manager for 1998, he will have had four managers in his first five seasons as owner of the Baltimore Orioles. Steinbrenner had only three.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 4; Column 5; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
When an Inmate Books the Ticket

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
GLORIA and Dan Bohan, who own a travel agency with offices coast to coast, a school for travel agents and a company that sells wholesale tickets and services to other agencies, have started a project to train prisoners to make computerized travel reservations.
At the end of October, 12 inmate reservationists from the all-women Leath Correctional Institution in Greenwood, a high-security prison in South Carolina, were still doing dry runs and taking tests. The women were selected from a large number of volunteers, many of them drug offenders. The Bohans, whose travel agency, Omega World Travel, has headquarters in Fairfax, Va., expected that at least one more big agency handling the travel of major corporations would be using the inmates. The Bohans will need more clients than their own agency's to sustain the project, which has been in development for several months. 
 The Bohans' wholesale company, Travel Wholesalers International, subcontracts many kinds of work, including reservations services, for travel agencies. Prison wages are far below market wages and there are no benefits, so such workers mean great cost savings.
Mr. Bohan stressed that no travel agency that bought services from the wholesale operation would find its individual clients plugged into the inmate reservation system without the agency's advance agreement.
To enhance clients' security, software has been created for the Bohans for use in prisons. They say it does not disclose to the reservationist the credit card number, home address or phone number of the client. These parts of the personal records maintained in computers by all travel agencies for their regular clients will not appear on the screen, they explain. The reservationist, receiving a call on an 800 number, will ask the caller's name and then deal with his or her requests. When the reservation information is complete with flight numbers and the like, the computer record will be moved electronically as a "blind transfer" to employees on the outside, who will have access to the full record and will print and deliver the ticket, after reviewing the inmate's work. The inmates are forbidden to use pencils or pens lest they retain data about travel plans.
 
T.W.A. First to Adopt Policy
The Bohans' is not the first travel company to use prisoners this way. Trans World Airlines, according to Donn Walker, a spokesman, has a reservations center employing inmates in a prison for young men in Ventura, Calif., north of Los Angeles. The center was opened in 1985 after the State of California approached the airline with the idea, he said. It has had only one security breach in that time, he said, which he thought was an enviable record.
People calling T.W.A. directly, however, do not know they are talking to prisoners. Mr. Walker said that the 40 inmates constituted less than 1 percent of the reservations staff and that if a caller asked the reservationist, "Where are you?" he would respond that he was in Ventura. T.W.A.'s four major reservations centers are in Los Angeles, St. Louis, Chicago and suburban Washington. The Ventura center operates 12 daytime hours five days a week.
Mr. Walker said that T.W.A. required an inmate to be enrolled in the facility's junior college before getting a job. The airline pays $5.39 an hour, of which 50 to 60 percent goes into a fund for the inmate when he is released. The rest goes into a fund to compensate crime victims and to pay prison expenses. Passenger information, including credit card numbers, is given to the prisoners.
T.W.A.'s use of prisoners was featured on a "Prime Time Live" broadcast on ABC News on Oct. 22. The show examined telemarketing services that use prisoners and cited the T.W.A. security breach, in which a released prisoner used a customer's credit card number to buy thousands of dollars' worth of computers and lingerie. Mr. Walker said the prisoner was arrested and convicted.
The ABC program also cited a case not connected with travel: A prisoner wrote a sexually provocative letter to a woman whose response to a survey from a company called Metromail, full of personal information, was given to a fellow prisoner to enter into a data base. Metromail has ceased using prison labor, the ABC program reported.
The use of prisoners in work projects where they deal directly with the public is controversial. The prison-labor uses discussed on "Prime Time Live" provoked criticism from people interviewed on the program on grounds of loss of privacy. The Travel section of The Times recently received a letter from a Minneapolis man who believed he had reached a prisoner when he called an 800 T.W.A. number. He complained that he did not want any prisoner to know -- by virtue of his having made plane reservations for certain dates -- when he would be away. He said he hung up and called again, getting a woman and continuing with his reservation.
Criticism has also come from the labor movement, which contends that unemployed people would be happy to have such jobs if they got the same training.
 
Goals: Job Skills and Savings
The Bohans say their project differs from T.W.A.'s in two ways: The client corporations know what they are getting into, and no personal information other than name is known to the prisoners. The Bohans say their project has two principal goals. They consider it socially responsible. The women are learning skills that will enable them to earn a living when they are released. "It makes use of talented people," Mrs. Bohan said. "We have received calls from inmates' parents to say thanks." The inmates' pay -- it starts at 50 cents an hour -- will go to a fund for them and their children. Also, in lieu of the familiarization trips that are offered to regular travel agents, airlines' free flights may be used to fly inmates' children -- most current participants' children live in New York, Ms. Bohan said -- to visit their mothers in Greenwood.
A spokesman for the South Carolina Department of Corrections, John Barkley, said that the project was important because it gave inmates vocational training and work. He said that when these prisoners were released they would receive jobs with Omega. "Ninety percent of our state's inmates go back to society," Mr. Barkley said. "It's valuable when they have work to go to."
Not surprisingly, the Bohans' other goal is lowering travel agency operating costs at a time when a second round of commission reductions by airlines has pinched most agencies. Travel Wholesalers International is a specialist in outsourcing, and sets up computer facilities in areas with a large labor pool and a low cost of living.
The three cost factors in setting up a client's flight, Mr. Bohan said, are making the reservation, which accounts for 66 percent; ticketing (12 percent) and back office expenses (20 percent). In agencies in New York, Washington and other major cities, he said, the total cost is about $35, making the cost of taking the reservation about $20. In a secondary city, he said, the total cost would be $20, making the reservation cost $14. Using inmates would put the reservation cost somewhere between $3 and $15, probably $5 to $6.
In any case, Mr. Bohan said, his company is offering corporations that are its clients a 50 percent reduction in reservation costs if they use the prisoner staff.
Mr. Barkley of the South Carolina Corrections Department said that the contract with the Bohans paid the prison system $3 for each hour of work. The inmates get 50 cents an hour until they have 160 hours of experience; $1 an hour from 161 to 320 hours and a maximum of $1.50 an hour after that. The remainder goes for administrative expenses, he said.
The program's software was designed in conjunction with Sabre, the computer reservations system owned by A.M.R., the owner of American Airlines. Mr. Bohan said that such costs, as well as the cost of two on-site supervisors, security guards and carpeting for the computer room, meant that Omega would not make a profit from the project for the first two years. He expects the present complement of 12 women to rise to 50 working on two shifts.
Norma Breeden of Omega Travel School has been in charge of the training at Leath. On Oct. 23, she gave the first part of a final exam to 12 students who had taken 250 hours of training. The results were encouraging, she said: seven got A's, three got B's and two got high C's.
Mr. Bohan said that his company had heard from prison officials in Arizona, Arkansas, Kansas, Minnesota and Wisconsin who were eager to try out such a project. He said that he was also interested in developing a similar program for state tourist boards and European countries' tourist offices in the United States.
Prisoners have been used for some years to respond to inquiries to 800 numbers used by state tourist boards in the United States. This involves no purchases, so security problems do not exist. Some state tourist officials have complained privately that tax revenue in their state is sent to another state to pay for prison labor because the second state submitted a lower bid.
Steve Loucks, director of communications for the American Society of Travel Agents in Washington, said that the organization had no position on the use of prison labor. The issue had not been put before a committee, he said. He said that ASTA was concerned only with the possibility that prisoners might retain crucial data about clients.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 34; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 981 words

HEADLINE: Word & Image;
The Postwar Trance

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
Washington and its media monitors went into a mild tizzy when the President fired his new weapon, the line-item veto, to shoot down 50 of the hundreds of Pentagon projects that Congress habitually spreads among influential members. Although Bill Clinton was careful to spare the rich contracts destined for the hometowns of the Republican leaders of the House and Senate, many of their troops have come to regret arming the White House with the power to unbundle their appropriations.
This commotion, however, has had a perverse effect. It focused attention on $391 million in Pentagon spending even as the major media again largely ignored the $260 billion that Washington blithely approves for the military each year. That sum, which is justified as necessary to fight two wars simultaneously on opposite sides of the globe, exceeds the defense spending of all other major military nations combined. And billions more will be needed if the President prevails with his plan to bring the former Communist nations of eastern Europe into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. 
 The frequent reminder from Tip O'Neill, the late Speaker, that all politics is local may explain why our politicians and news media get so excited about a few weapons contracts and base closings. But strangely, not even the enormous tax consequences of the military budget evoke much interest in the limp arguments put forward in its defense. The Pentagon insists that the United States must be poised to invade and defeat "rogue nations" like Iraq and North Korea at the same time. For nearly a decade, that has been the unshakable conclusion of what passes for the Government's "Quadrennial Defense Review."
Despite the disappearance of the Soviet Union in 1991, our generals and admirals have insisted that there must be no cuts in the number of our ground divisions, Air Force fighter wings or aircraft-carrier battle groups. That is a quarter-trillion-dollar premise but it arouses virtually no discussion in the popular press or on television. Even The New York Times has carried only one news account, one editorial and one Op-Ed article about the two-war doctrine this year. No one in Government felt any pressure to respond to that Op-Ed challenge by Lawrence J. Korb of the Brookings Institution, a former Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Reagan years. He recalled that throughout the 40 years of cold war, the United States never needed to fight more than one war at a time -- in Korea, Vietnam and the Persian Gulf. Nor did it ever prepare, as a matter of doctrine, for more than one and a half wars. Moreover, the military strength of both Iraq and North Korea has seriously deteriorated since the birth of the two-war strategy. And while there exist other rogue states, like Libya, they hardly pose the kind of threat that requires us to be ready for instant war.
At the root of the Pentagon's reasoning lies a portentous but rarely examined assertion: "If the United States were to forgo its ability to defeat aggression in more than one theater at a time, our standing as a global power, as the security partner of choice and the leader of the international community would be called into question."
Really? And reasonably so?
The only vigorous debate of that proposition occurs nowadays in academic journals. For example, Mark Danner argues in a current issue of World Policy Journal that the entire American Government is "marooned in the cold war." As evidence, he cites the Clinton Administration's rush to enlarge the membership of nato and contends that the United States is "encumbered with a policy that imposes upon the world a mindless hegemony, a predominance for its own sake." He thinks our leaders simply cannot shed the heavy armor that shaped and sustained American diplomacy for half a century.
Maybe Danner exaggerates. But it is hard not to wonder with him what we are doing with 100,000 troops in the middle of a united Germany, defending a "border" that no longer exists. It is even harder to rebut Danner and the other critics of President Clinton's rash rush to bring Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic into nato, with Slovenia, Romania and the Baltic states next in line. It will immediately cost billions to modernize the armies of those poor nations. More expensively still, they will rekindle anti-Western chauvinism in Russia. The Russians are the undeniable target of this nato enlargement, and their resentment can have dangerous consequences.
The truth is that nato has outlived its purpose -- which, in a famous aphorism, was to keep the United States in Europe, the Germans down and the Russians out. Now that the Germans are very much up and the Russians are embracing capitalism, an anti-Soviet and to some extent anti-German military alliance is hardly viable.
The old goal of promoting stability and democracy in Europe would be much more sensibly served by integrating the former Communist nations into the economic and financial institutions of western Europe, notably the European Union. But as Danner points out, the French and others rejected that course; they did not want to make their farmers compete with the cheaper produce of the east. So the United States is hastening to compensate with billions of dollars in annual military subsidies and a patently incredible promise to protect Warsaw, Prague, Budapest and later even Ljubljana with its nuclear umbrella.
Even if they were wise, these policies would need to be recognized as fateful and expensive. Yet they are moving toward Congressional ratification like the annual Pentagon budgets, with only the most cursory discussion by the national press or commercial networks. If our Government remains marooned in the cold war, it is surely because our press has lapsed into a postwar trance, grown bored and oblivious to the truly great issues of the moment.

LENGTH: 999 words

HEADLINE: Photography Firm Grows With 3 Partners

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
TAKE three photographers younger than 30, add a fatherly boss and a local bank, then back off and watch a new enterprise grow. But the company, Bernstein Associates Photographers, is not new; it was started by Herman Bernstein in the mid-1950's and in 1970 began specializing in the construction photography it is known for today.
Alan Kazin, a partner in the enterprise, said the move seven years ago to acquire Mr. Bernstein's company was a bold one. 
 "Although nothing was said, we had a feeling that Mr. Bernstein was thinking about retiring," Mr. Kazin said. "I felt comfortable initiating the subject because of our relationship. Mr. Bernstein was not only our boss, he was our mentor."
Laurie Donald, who is now president, said: "I never worked for anyone else. My first job out of college in 1984 was with Mr. Bernstein. He started in business working out of the basement of his house in Yonkers, doing commercial portraits, which eventually grew into a construction specialty. My jobs ran the gamut, starting with photo dark-room manager, ending up a photographer. It was a terrific learning experience."
The third partner, Mary Lou Pizzutello, agreed. "Mr. Bernstein was a terrific teacher," she said. "I went to work for him in 1985, starting on the lowest rung, which was washing negatives. I worked my way up to the point where one day, when a photographer failed to show up, Mr. Bernstein sent me out on the job. And I've been a commercial photographer ever since."
As for Mr. Kazin, he said, "I wanted to be a photographer from the time I was 5 when my dad gave me a Polaroid swinger for my birthday."
And his interest never flagged. After he earned a bachelor's degree in photography from the Rochester Institute of Technology, he took what he described as an entry-level job as an assistant dark- room studio manager.
"Then in 1986 I answered an ad and became a full-time photographer, doing construction and architectural shoots for Mr. Bernstein," he said. "It's terrific work. Much of what we do is for construction firms on a contract basis. We specialize in shooting a series of progress photos starting from preconstruction through topping out and ribbon cutting. Aerial shots, surveys and shooting under special conditions, like in sewers, are all part of the job."
Competition for such assignments, he added, is fierce. "Fees for a progress series range from $1,000 to as high as $40,000, so the jobs, which can last for as much as four years, like any piece of a construction project, will go out for bid."
And because some construction projects must use a certain quota of women or minority-owned businesses as subcontractors, the partners were able to have their company designated by the state as a Women's Business Enterprise.
"We figured it would give us a small advantage, a better shot at getting new business and a help in securing our position in the industry," Ms. Donald said.
Ms. Pizzutello said: "That was the easy part. The hard part was going from employees to owners. When Mr. Bernstein agreed to sell us the business for $500,000, we had to come up with a down payment."
The problem was, Mr. Kazin said: "None of us had any money. Mr. Bernstein helped us out by taking back notes as a down payment."
The three buyers then got in touch with a business adviser, Nancy Cochran, at the New York Small Business Center in White Plains.
"With Nancy's advice and guidance, we put together a business-development plan." Ms. Donald said. "It took a year to get it into shape, but we couldn't have done it without her expertise."
Obtaining a bank loan for operating capital was a major stumbling block.
"Two banks turned us down cold, and a third kept us dangling for weeks," Mr. Kazin said. "It was a local bank, Hudson Valley, headquartered in Yonkers, that had faith in us and made us a loan."
And that faith has been justified, Ms. Donald said.
"After three years we were able to pay off the bank loan, money we had borrowed from our families and Mr. Bernstein's notes as well," she said. Mr. Kazin recalled: "But the first year was tough. We worked long, long hours, but we weren't making any money. Our timing was bad. In 1990 the construction industry was hit hard by the recession. We didn't even announce that we bought the business for fear of losing clients. Two of them left but eventually came back."
But the partners agreed that the most difficult task they faced during their first year was having to cut the payroll.
In the last seven years, the partners say they have not only learned how to run a business but also how to make one grow. "We've built on the Bernstein reputation for quality and expanded our operation to cover the area from Boston to Washington," Mr. Kazin said. "We've also added new services such as industrial and aerial video. Our clients are the leading architectural, engineering and contracting firms in the East, firms like Tishman Construction Company of New York."
Thomas Hoban, vice president of the Tishman Technology Company in Elmsford, a division of the Tishman Construction Company, said the change of ownership was seamless. "They have always been very good and accommodating," Mr. Hoban said. "For example, recently we needed a construction photo document from 1987 to show a client. We didn't have it. But Bernstein found it in their archives."
Documentation of the work on Grand Central Terminal is also one of the company's projects. Other jobs include documenting the New York Hospital expansion, the rebuilding of the World Trade Center, the York Hunter construction job for Avalon Properties, the Willow project in Mamaroneck, and the New Rochelle Safety Building, which is under construction.
Last month Bernstein Associates moved from Mount Vernon into new headquarters in Harrison, doubling the amount of space. "We now have 12 full-time employees, and we're excited about reaching the $1 million mark in sales for the first time ever," Ms. Donald said.

HEADLINE: Temps, the New Wave in the Work Force

BYLINE: By ROBIN F. DEMATTIA 

 BODY:
KATHERINE LAMPOS often feels the urge to go whitewater rafting in New Mexico or visit a national park. So she does, for a week or two. That's O.K. with her boss, because Ms. Lampos, 52 years old, doesn't have one. She's a self-employed "professional temp," one of a growing number of people who work project by project rather than the classic 40-hour week.
"I may not get rich," says Ms. Lampos, who has worked 10 to 11 months each year since 1988, "but I'm earning a living and I'm never bored. If I take a permanent position, I can't leave when I want to leave or take a day off when I want to. This is a life style that you can become accustomed to." 
 Temporary workers today range from administrative support personnel to graphic designers, accountants, lawyers, marketing specialists and executives. The industry has grown from $20.5 billion in 1991 to a record $43.6 billion in 1996,and the trend is expected to continue.
"The industry is continuing to grow because it makes a lot of economic and life style sense," says Catherine Candland, founder and chief executive officer of Advantage Staffing Services, headquartered in Stamford. "When I first got into the staffing field 13 years ago, we were placing people in positions because someone was out sick or on maternity leave. The business world was not really adept at the idea of bringing in talent that was temporary. But the caliber of person doing temporary work is much more diverse now than it was then. Many people who are between 22 and 50 are starting to recognize that your career is something that you manage. And I think businesses certainly see the advantages of bringing talent in for certain projects and having a leaner core staff."
Advantage's temporary workers, who are called associates, provide temporary, interim and alternative staffing for small companies to ones in the Fortune 100. With offices throughout the state as well as in New York, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, the District of Columbia and Texas, the company reports 35 percent growth annually since its founding and projects $100 million in revenues this year. That would make it the largest company in the state owned by a woman. Ms. Candland has been on the receiving end of all sorts of recognition, including a spot on Fortune's list of America's 40 Smartest Entrepreneurs. She attributes part of her drive and success to her upbringing.
Her father being in the Air Force, the family moved a lot, and "When you move a lot when you're growing up, you tend to adapt to situations and to some degree are less reluctant to take risks," says Ms. Candland. Ms. Candland, armed with a degree in political science and set on a career in public policy, became disenchanted with her dream when she helped her Dad run for a Senate seat in Utah; he was unsuccessful. "I started to look for other playing fields were you could make a difference without so many obstacles," she said.
While living in the Washington, D.C., area, where she founded Advantage, Ms. Candland discovered an appreciation for finding temporary employment alternatives for people. "It really combines my public policy motivation with being able to do something that's tangible for people as far as career development," she says.
Advantage was one of the first temporary staffing firms to offer benefits -- health and dental plans, life insurance, 401(k) retirement plan, paid holidays, vacations, and free skills training -- to its associates as well as full-time employees. It also organized itself by practice groups (like financial services, consumer products), to better track industry trends, anticipate clients' needs and place associates in fields where they have experience. The firm boasts an associate retention rate 600 percent better than the industry average (nine months, compared to two to six weeks).
Advantage, says Bruce Donatuti, director of employment and employee relations at Oxford Health Plans in Norwalk, "focuses on customer service and seems to be able to find some of the best folks that are out there."
When Mr. Donatuti recently reduced the number of temporary staffing firms he used from 20 to 3, Advantage remained on his list. He says companies like Oxford will continue to need temporary staffing services, despite what may look like added expense.
"We pay a fairly generous hourly rate to our temps," he explained, "but if you control the use of temp staff carefully, if you just hire for what you need, like seasonal work or during peak hours, that's where you save money."
Mr. Donatuti admits that the skill level of temps can vary, especially among recent college graduates whose "reading, writing and arithmetic levels are lower than 20 or 30 years ago." But he likes hiring people who move into the temp field by choice, who don't want to work full-time because they have family issues or are at the end of their career and want to slow down a bit.
"You've got a different cadre of people who want to be temps now," he says. "They want to be part of the contingent work force and that's a fast-growing part of the work force. It used to be 6 percent and now it's probably close to 20 percent."
Megan Ferrell, for example, an art director and graphic designer in Darien, runs her own business from home after years of working for publishing and insurance firms in New York City. She also works for Advantage to supplement her income and gain access to more companies.
"In the beginning I felt like once I got to know a job, I had to leave," Ms. Ferrell says. "It's like your first day on the job constantly. But I will never be afraid to start a new job. You get better at adapting quickly."
How do corporate employees treat her? "I thought people wouldn't talk to the freelancer," she said but she found herself treated "like one of the crowd." And because she works at home, Ms. Ferrell enjoys going on-site with clients, where she can chat with other people, be exposed to different projects and learn new skills.
Some temporary workers also consider these assignments a testing ground for future employment, and the companies use that to their advantage. "Using a temp is an opportunity to check out some people," says Christine V. Walchuk, human resources manager at the Perrier Group of America in Greenwich. "That's the greatest advantage of using temps; hiring someone who has worked here a few months and we've had that honeymoon period already."
Advantage Staffing Services helps make that transition possible by screening associates. At client companies, "We interview department heads and put numeric values around attitude, reliability and initiative," explains Nancy Thomas, manager of client services at Advantage. "Then everybody who applies at Advantage goes through a similar set of questions and gets a work style guide numeric value. It puts a science around something that is such an intangible."
 
The Numbers and Market Changes
THE numbers are impressive: in 1996 total revenues of temporary help services grew 11.2 percent to a record $43.6 billion, or 6.9 percent of total non-farm employment, compared with just 1.3 percent in 1991.
Average daily employment rose 6.9 percent to 2.3 million and gross wages paid to temporary employees grew 12.8 percent to $31.5 billion. Further growth is expected to show up in the 1997 figures.
Within the industry, the traditional office/clerical sector fell from 47.6 percent of payroll in 1991 to 38.7 percent in 1996, while industrial positions rose from 27.4 percent to 31.8 percent and professional assignments grew from 2.4 percent to 6.3 percent.
"Companies are really struggling to find the talent they need," said Catherine Candland, founder and head of Advantage Staffing Services in Stamford. "And there are fewer workers coming into the marketplace, after the phenomenon of the baby boomers." She adds that many women are starting their own businesses, too, lessening the pool of available workers.
"When we started, probably 95 percent of associates were women," Ms. Candland says. "There are more men now because of the jobs we are filling -- graphics, creative artists, systems programmers. And men are doing interim and temporary work for the same reasons women always did -- it's a great way to identify career opportunities, research a new industry, get inside a company and see what the opportunities are, and have balance in their lives so you don't have to work 60 to 80 hours week."
She also finds that recent college graduates are willing to take less money for a temporary opportunity, if it gives them more balance in their lives. "They are not necessarily less ambitious," she says, "but I think this new attitude is healthy."
Ms. Candland also anticipates companies allowing associates to work from home or remote offices. "The information technology initiatives have made it so people can work from almost anywhere. We're seeing a combination of 80 percent of assignments at the client's site and 20 percent being done from another site.
"When clients consider people spending an hour or more to get to work, that's a lot of human capital tied on up the roads. They want to harness it and get productivity out of it." ROBIN DEMATTIA

HEADLINE: New at the Venerable Bush-Holley House

BYLINE: By ALBERTA EISEMAN 

 BODY:
NOTHING is left of the old tidal mill, the shipyard, warehouse, stores, fishing fleet and packet boats that formed the Lower Landing at Cos Cob in Greenwich.
 Once a thriving small harbor on Strickland Brook -- an inlet off the Mianus River less than half a mile from Long Island Sound -- the Lower Landing was a hub of 18th-century commerce but fell victim to a changing economy and to a fire that destroyed the waterfront buildings in 1899. 
 And yet its spirit lingers, captured on canvas by a group of artists now known as American Impressionists, who rented rooms in a rambling old home across the street known now as the Bush-Holley House.
The 1730's former rooming house was declared a National Historic Landmark for its role as one of the first Impressionist art colonies in the United States. In 1957 it was bought by the Historical Society of the Town of Greenwich, which operates it as a house-museum along with several smaller structures that form an evocative historic complex.
Next Saturday at 1 P.M. the Historical Society will officially unveil its most recent acquisition, the Bush-Holley Visitor Center, a former commercial building adjacent to the old house. More than just the usual place to view a video or pick up information, the newly restored and renovated structure houses three exhibition galleries: one tracing the development of the Lower Landing, one devoted to an interactive program for families and a small space that will be available for exhibitions.
The cluster of buildings was particularly attractive on a sparkling fall day. Aside from the "dear old house" itself, as the artists once called it, there is the barn where they painted and held classes and exhibitions, the new Visitor Center and the archives, built just 10 years ago but reflective of an earlier style. It is not hard to see why two generations of painters -- Childe Hassam, John Henry Twachtman, Theodore Robinson, J. Alden Weir, Elmer MacRae and others -- were so taken with the area.
Despite the concrete bridge that carries Interstate 95 across the Mianus River, dwarfing the gentle landscape around it, the river retains a bucolic look and sailboats at their moorings still enchant.
The old clapboard house -- built by the Bush family, landowners and merchants, and purchased in 1882 by the far less prosperous Holleys -- is friendly and attractive, furnished with Connecticut antiques and Holley family pieces and filled with oil paintings, etchings, watercolors, pastels and woodcuts by the artists who summered there year after year. One painter never left at all: Elmer MacRae arrived in 1887 to study with John Twachtman, married the Holleys' daughter, Constant, and lived there for the rest of his life.
The building the artists called "the house next door," the new Visitor Center, was the site of the post office by the time they were in residence. Justus Luke Bush had the home built around 1805 as a dry goods store and storehouse. The first tableau in the sound and light show that orients visitors presents him in conversation with his partner as they bemoan the hard times that followed the panic of 1837. Indeed, Mr. Bush was bankrupt at his death, despite the fine house and the thriving business he had inherited from his father and grandfather.
The next tableau depicts the building as post office 60 years later, with the postmaster gossiping with a patron about the eccentric artists living next door.
Visitors also see the portrayal of a conversation between 8-year-old Clarissa MacRae, granddaughter of the owners of the Holley House, and Childe Hassam, who painted her portrait, now hanging in the entrance hall of the house. "The exhibit will prepare visitors for a tour of the Bush-Holley House itself," said Karen Blanchfield, the Historical Society's curator of exhibitions and Collections. "They will already have information about the art colony as well as the Bush family and will be able to link the two periods."
The interactive program for families will have five stations, each offering hands-on displays emphasizing local history or art.
The opening show is entitled "The Lost Landscape of Cos Cob" and was guest curated by Dr. Susan Larkin, who is an authority on Connecticut Impressionist art and the Cos Cob Colony.
The exhibition consists of a dozen paintings and works on paper by Childe Hassam, Elmer MacRae, Kerr Eby and Charles Ebert.
The works, lent by private collectors and area museums, reflect the landscape -- both natural and manmade -- the way the members of the art colony knew it.
"Now that we have a climate controlled space to display things," said Ms. Blanchfield, referring to the handsome, brightly lighted section of the Visitor Center known as the William Hegarty Gallery, "it will allow us to borrow more works from other museums."
The Bush-Holley Historic Site and the Visitor Center, at 39 Strickland Road in the Cos Cob section of Greenwich, are open from noon to 4 P.M. Wednesday through Friday; 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Saturdays and 1 to 4 P.M. on Sundays. Hours will change after Jan. 1.
Admission to the Visitor Center is free of charge. Tickets for the guided tour of the Bush-Holley House Museum are $4, $3 for elderly people and free to children under 12.
To celebrate the grand opening of the Visitor Center next Saturday and Sunday, the public is invited to tour both buildings at no charge.

HEADLINE: The View From: Stamford;
For This Audience, Nothing but World Scale Itself Will Do

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
THE three men pored over papers as they sat amid the plush splendor of the Tara Stamford Hotel lobby one recent Sunday afternoon, trying to figure out how they were going to mesh their presentations.
"I was going to talk about Hong Kong as being the canary in the mine shaft in regard to China policy," explained Douglas H. Paal, an Asia specialist in the Reagan and Bush Administrations who now heads the Asia Pacific Policy Center. 
 James D. Seymour, a senior research scholar at the Columbia University East Asian Institute, appeared slightly chagrined. "I use the canary metaphor in my address, too," he said.
David Tsui, director of the Hong Kong Economic and Trade Office, flashed an impish grin: "You two can speak first, then I'll come in and clarify any misimpressions."
The three were not appearing before a Senate Committee, a board of directors or even "Nightline." Their audience was the Forum for World Affairs in Stamford, a group with arguably no more influence on American foreign policy than the average voter. The topic was China and Hong Kong, always a big draw according to the forum's director, Barbara Wille Chisolm.
The forum has been in existence for 51 years, and among its guests have been Eleanor Roosevelt, Barbara Bush, George Mitchell, David Gergen, Henry Kissinger and Madeleine K. Albright (before she became Secretary of State).
What draws such distinguished speakers? "We don't pay," Ms. Chisolm said. "What prompts them to travel is that they want to share their message, and get that message across to a very remarkable audience."
There are fewer than 600 members of the Stamford Forum, but among them are diplomats, reporters and many business people.
Mr. Paal, Mr. Seymour and Mr. Tsui faced a battery of questions at a recent session moderated by Kay J. Maxwell, a vice president of the Stamford-based International Executive Service Corps and a director of the forum. Among the questions: What was the relationship between the Chinese takeover of Hong Kong and the economic crises in Malaysia and Singapore? What are the implications of the recent Chinese Communist Party summit on Hong Kong's future? And in 10 years, will Hong Kong look more like China or vice versa?
When Mr. Tsui spoke of improvements at Hong Kong's main airport ("When you come to Hong Kong next year, you will land someplace less exciting.") there was knowing laughter throughout the room.
Mitchell Krauss of Stamford, a reporter for CBS Radio, can often be found chasing prospective guests to appear at the forum, of which he is a chairman. Many forum members are ordinary individuals, many of them older and retired, who find the forum a means of getting a handle on world events.
"I do think in this age of live news programming and the Internet, people still are hungry for personal contact," Mr. Krauss said. "It harkens back to a simpler time."
Ginger Heller, a board member from Greenwich, is vice president of European sales for a medical supply company. "The essence of the forum's appeal for me is the little things you hear," she said. For example, when the Soviet Premier Khrushchev's son Sergei, a fellow at Brown University, appeared, he told of how his father had once demanded the building of missiles like those of the United States -- but only two of them, to be shown off at the May Day parade and exacerbate American fears of a missile gap. "I can not tell you how many little, wonderful things like that you pick up off the cuff," she said.
Derek G. Boothby of Riverside helped investigate Iraq's nuclear capabilities for the United Nations after the end of the Gulf War. Now the director of the Europe division at the United Nations Department of Political Affairs, he views the forum, where he is a director, as a needed corrective to the American tendency of "switching off" from foreign affairs. "The forum is an ideal focal point to get people who should be interested to listen to international affairs lectures, to focus their interest," he said.
The Stamford Forum is one of 80 organizations that belong to the Washington, D.C.-based National Council of World Affairs Organizations. They include the Foreign Policy Association of Manhattan and the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations as well as smaller groups in places like Savannah, Ga., and Tyler, Texas.
Jerry W. Leach, the national director for the umbrella group, notes "Stamford's track record is one of the best in the country." Stamford Forum members like to think their reputation is in part due to the fact they have been around so long. The group's genesis was in 1946, when the United Nations was looking at a large chunk of the Greenwich back country for its headquarters. The issue split local opinion, with some neighbors favoring the idea of being "the world's capital" and others lamenting the likely loss of the area's bucolic character.
Wilbur Miller of Stamford was 31 when he founded the forum. "The United Nations was only a year old then," he remembered. "We were concerned about the larger question -- not where it was going to be, but whether it was going to be."
The first Forum function was nothing less than a three-day seminar broadcast nationwide on "America's Town Meeting of the Air," which Mr. Miller, a retired chemist, called the "60 Minutes" of its day. Mrs. Roosevelt was a special guest.
The United Nations' eventual placement in Manhattan ended the geographical controversy, but the forum went on, debating the wisdom of the Marshall Plan and, in the 1950's, the fate of Hungary's opposition to Communist rule. Then-Secretary of State John Foster Dulles "seemed to run foreign policy out of his homburg," Mr. Miller said.
Beyond the need for a United Nations, the forum was always careful never to take sides on an issue, Mr. Miller said. That non-partisan flavor helped to attract notable speakers. Frank Altschul, an investment banker from Stamford, was one of several members who helped round up Henry Kissinger and another then-professor, Zbigniew Brzezinski (who later became President Carter's national security advisor) for a discussion in 1966.
When pressed, members agree that like lower Fairfield County in general, the forum has more Republicans than Democrats. But Democrats hold some key positions, too, like Albert Sims of Greenwich, a chairman with his wife, Ruth, of the forum's great decisions panel and a former Kennedy Administration member who played a role in the formation of the Peace Corps.
Partisanship seldom intrudes on forum discussion, though. "We're not confrontational," Ms. Heller said.
Purpose is another matter. As Howard Katzen of Westport, a former forum chairman, noted, "what I'm really interested in is getting some speakers in, getting some debate."
The Stamford Forum has expanded its reach over the past decade, including a twice-yearly students' forum. Perhaps the biggest step was the Ambassadors Forum: private, off-the-record discussions with visiting dignitaries. "It's something of a joke," Mr. Katzen said of the off-the-record designation. "Often they are going to say the same thing they always say."
Ms. Chisolm noted that public seminars on the Middle East, the future of Russia, and the role of women in international affairs would be taking place. "We don't want to just preach to the converted," she said. "We'd like to reach more people, to make them aware of global issues and foreign affairs."

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND GUIDE

BYLINE: By BARBARA DELATINER 

 BODY:

FREE CHOICES
TODAY "Home and the River," a new American opera set against the backdrop of the Civil War, will be staged at 3 P.M. in the Shear Theater on the Selden campus of Suffolk Community College. Performed by the Encompass Music Theater, a Manhattan-based troupe of 14 professional singers, the musical drama, with a score by George Quincy and libretto by Benjamin Barber, tells of a Kansas rancher who goes South to fight for the Confederacy (451-4163). 
 TOMORROW Stuart E. Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of State for Economic, Business and Agricultural Affairs, discusses "Jewish History Remembered: 50 Years Later" at 8 P.M. at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck (482-5701).
THURSDAY The East End Arts Council's series of Harvest Gospel Concerts gets under way at 8 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Greenport. And before the 100-member choir, under Mary Anne McElroy's direction, calls it a season it will also sing at the First Baptist Church in Bridgehampton on Friday and the Friendship Baptist Church in Flanders on Saturday (727-0900).
"Ian Had a Little Lamb: The Cloning of Dolly" is the subject of a seminar at 8 P.M. at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory's Banbury Conference Center. Dr. Jan Witkowski, the center's director, will lecture on the implications of the recent sheep cloning in Scotland (367-8455).
SATURDAY The latest class of dogs and their disabled owners graduates from the Canine Companions for Independence program, and their graduation will be celebrated at 7 P.M. at the East Memorial Elementary School in Farmingdale. The public is invited to see the new partnerships begin (694-6938).

'LITTLE MOZART'
Dubbed the "little Mozart" when he was discovered playing classic music on an electric keyboard in the New York City subway system, David Allakhverdov has now graduated to concert halls. The 14-year-old pianist, born in Uzbekistan, performs Beethoven, Chopin and Liszt at 3 P.M. at the Church of the Open Door in Southold in the Arts in Southold Town series (734-7696).

VETERANS DAY
Although some communities will stage parades today and Tuesday honoring those who served in the armed forces, Veterans Day on the Island will be relatively low key. Today there is a special service at 2 P.M. at the Long Island National Cemetery in Pinelawn (454-4949), while on Tuesday the Calverton National Cemetery will mark the holiday at 1 P.M. (727-5410). On a less somber note, the Museums at Stony will admit veterans free from 10 A.M.to 5 P.M. Tuesday and charge all others $1 (751-0066).

DRUCKER ANNIVERSARY
At 19, Stanley Drucker, aclarinetist from Massapequa, was the youngest member of the New York Philharmonic when the orchestra hired him. That was 50 years ago and to celebrate his milestone, the American Chamber Ensemble is putting Mr. Drucker, now the Philharmonics's principal clarinetist, to work today.
He will join his wife, Naomi Drucker, another clarinetist who is the co-director of the ensemble with Blanch Abram, pianist; Eriko Sato and Deborah Wong, violinists; Lois Martin, violist, and Chris Finckel, cellist, in a program of music by Bruch, Copland, Kodaly and Poulenc at 3 P.M. in the Monroe Lecture Center Theater on Hofstra University's Hempstead campus (463-6644).

FLYING IN
The Flying Karamazov Brothers land at the Staller Center on the Stony Brook campus of the State University today at 7 P.M. Their latest entry, "Sharps and Accidentals," should give the juggler-comedians ample opportunity to display their zany skills (632-7230).

DUNES BY MOONLIGHT
Take a moonlight stroll through the Walking Dunes in Amagansett, which were the living set for "The Sheik." Group for the South Fork naturalists lead the way in a two-mile hike at 7 P.M. Friday (537-1400).

BOTANICAL TOUR
Are any of the vistas and plants captured on canvas by the Moran family about a century ago still around today? Eric Lamont, the president of the Long Island Botanical Society, will try to find out when he leads a botanical tour Saturday exploring "Nature in the Art of the Moran Family." Held in conjunction with "The Moran Family Legacy," the current exhibition at Guild Hall in East Hampton, the tour will examine landscapes the artists saw, investgating growth patterns then and now and searching for evidence of a continuation of the plant life. The tour, under the auspices of the South Fork Natural History Society, is from 10 A.M. to noon and leaves from Guild Hall (267-7944).

SALIERI STARS
The Rockaway-Five Towns Symphony Orchestra begins its season Saturday with something relatively new -- Antonio Salieri's rarely heard Concerto for Flute, Oboe and Orchestra. This work by the composer, who figured in Mozart's life, is said to be so infrequently played that, according to the orchestra, this performance might "qualify as an American premiere." Mary Shaw, the orchestra's principal futist, and Heather Donnelly, the principal oboist, are featured. Works by Brahms and Shostakovish complete the program, conducted by Raffael Adler, at 8 P.M. at the Lawrence Woodmere Academy in Woodmere (239-7828).

'VENERABLE TUNES'
The Hofstra Collegium Musicum is another outfit interested in little known music. In fact, it was founded in 1969 by Dr. William Hettrick to dig up old and obscure music. Primarily students, the troupe, under Dr. Hettrick's baton, offers "That Old Sweet Song: A Concert of Venerable Tunes in Divers Settings" at 8 P.M. Saturday at St. John's Lutheran Church in Williston Park. Among those "tunes" to be performed by oboes, horns, bassoons and serpent, an instrument built by Dr. Hettrick, is an anonymous divertimento once attributed to Haydn and later used by Brahms for his "Variations on a Theme of Haydn" (463-6644).

'SONGWRITERS' DAY'
Since the town of Riverhead has declared Saturday "Songwriters' Day" non-professional musicians who would like to be discovered get to strut their stuff for fame and cash prizes in the "Riverhead Songwriters' Showdown." The benefit for the Vail-Leavitt Music Hall is at 8 P.M. Saturday at Polish Hall (727-0900). BARBARA DELATINER

HEADLINE: L.I. Potato Packager and Idaho at War

BYLINE: By RAMIN P. JALESHGARI 

 BODY:
MORE than 50 years ago, Henry Pollak started a small business in the Hicksville farmlands selling fertilizer and insecticides to Long Island farmers. In those days, payment was in potatoes and other vegetables, a surplus the Island native turned into profit, packaging and reselling the produce to local retailers.
Now called Hapco Farms, the company is the largest vegetable packager on the East Coast, with more than $100 million in yearly sales, purchasing more than $5 million of produce yearly from ever diminishing local growers and more than 100 million pounds of spuds nationally. 
 But these days potatoes and profits are not Hapco's main concern. The Riverhead-based company is trying to fend off allegations by the Idaho Potato Commission that it misused the agency's trademark and bagged multistate potatoes as Idaho-grown.
The commission bases its allegations upon information provided by Larsen Farms, an Idaho-based potato grower from whom Hapco purchases 20 million pounds of potatoes yearly.
In order to serve Georgia markets, Hapco began packaging vegetables at Larsen's Atlanta plant two years ago. A Larsen Farms worker took a videotape of other employees dumping Hapco shipments of Wisconsin-labeled potatoes onto an assembly line feeding bags labeled "Idaho grown" and destined for Publix supermarkets. Publix is one of the largest supermarket chains in the South.
Harvey B. Pollak, Henry Pollak's son and the president of Hapco Farms, believes that the video was a setup -- staged at the warehouse after normal business hours -- by Larsen Farms.
"Larsen immediately sent that video to Publix in hopes of getting them to drop Hapco and work directly with them instead." said Mr. Pollak.
A spokesman for Larsen could not be reached for comment.
Publix responded by forwarding the tape to the Idaho Potato Commission, which mobilized to hold a hearing against the Long Island company for trademark violation. Investigations into the matter were conducted on behalf of the commission by its accounting firm, Deloitte & Touche, with the agreement of Hapco Farms.
The Riverhead packager was not prepared for the accounting firm's findings.
"I was shocked when I learned Deloitte's findings and recommendations," said Mr. Pollak, who pointed out that upon first hearing Larsen's charges, his company immediately began to investigate the matter.
"We have a policy of immediate termination for product mislabeling," he said. "And, I state emphatically that the allegations are absolutely untrue,"
Based on Deloitte and Touche's findings, Hapco was forced to pay a $200,000 fine and $65,446 in costs to the commission as settlement. The Idaho-based Larsen Farms paid $10,000 in fines.
Joe Bainton of the firm of Ross & Hardies is Mr. Pollak's lawyer. He says his client paid the fines only because he did not expect a fair hearing before the nine-member Idaho Potato Commission.
Another prominent accounting firm, Grant Thornton, conducted a second investigation and found no evidence of wrongdoing on Hapco's part. According to Grant Thornton, Hapco's packaging procedures were above-board and sales of Idaho-branded potatoes included Idaho potatoes exclusively.
Mr. Pollak hopes to get his company a fair shake before a New York State Supreme Court judge. On March 27, Hapco Farms filed a $25,000,000 lawsuit against Deloitte & Touche, whose findings, Hapco believes, directly related to the punitive measures levied against them.
The suit charges that the national accounting firm conspired with the Idaho Potato Commission and Larsen Farms to besmirch Hapco's name by deliberately providing incorrect information to the commission's hearing committee.
The accounting firm said that "We deny any liability or wrongdoing and will vigorously litigate this matter."
There is some feeling among non-Idaho potato growers and packagers that the Idaho Potato Commission is attempting to secure a monopoly on potato production for its state, even, if necessary, restricting interstate trade by strong-arming non-Idaho sellers out of business.
"'By pushing the Idaho potato so hard, the western markets have killed us out here," said Albee Zawieski, a third-generation East End farmer from Laurel, "I used to raise 650 acres. Now its just 275."
Mr. Zawieski also said that poor potato crops in Idaho over the last few years had put the already-popular Long Island white potatoes in high demand. Produce buyers from locally based Finast/Edwards supermarkets to stores as far away as South America have found that customers prefer the Long Island variety, only buying Idaho, Maine and other spuds when the Long Island area's harvest is over.
"The Idaho Potato Commission has sold a bill of goods to the consumer," said Mr. Pollak. "They've done a great brainwash job convincing the American buyers that Idaho is the one and only name for quality potatoes."
Potato production in Idaho is 13.8 billion pounds, resulting in $2.5 billion dollars in annual revenue and an average of 33 percent of the state's economy. The Idaho Potato Commission stated that it spent 95 percent of its $9 million to $ 10 million annual budget on advertising and promotional activities.
The verified complaint prepared by Mr. Pollak's lawyers, Ross & Hardies states, "The commission and Larsen sought to destroy Hapco's reputation; to ruin Hapco's program, which has become a threat to Idaho potato growers and/or shippers; and ultimately ruin Hapco's entire business operation so that Hapco's customers would become available to Larsen, and/or to other in-state Idaho growers and/or shippers."
The Idaho Potato Commission would not comment on its dealings with Hapco, or accusations that it is attempting to drive non-Idaho potato growers out of business. Nor would the agency provide information on previous enforcement of its "Idaho grown" trademark.
Deloitte & Touche said, "Hapco's attack on Deloitte & Touche's integrity is without basis in fact and appears to be an effort to shift attention from the matters addressed by the Idaho Potato Commission."
Comments on the suit levied against its accounting firm were not forthcoming from the Idaho state agency.
Louis Henry, an investigator with Deloitte & Touche's Boise office, is identified by the suit as preparing a biased report intending to hurt Hapco.
Also stated in the complaint: "Mr. Henry advised Joe Luici, Hapco's chief financial officer , that he was instructed by the commission and its attorney, Pat Kole, to find mislabeling on behalf of Hapco and not on behalf of Larsen 'at any cost.' Obviously, the commission could not allow Deloitte to make adverse findings against the state's largest farmer and the commission's largest financial contributor."
"We could easily move our operations to Idaho and be part of that state's economy," Mr. Pollak said. "We could move anywhere for that matter; nowadays our business depends on computers and phones. But we refuse to let the preferences of another state's agency make us even consider leaving Long Island.
"It's not cheap to operate here, there are more fiscally attractive locations, but this has been our home for three generations."
For Mr. Pollak, the biggest concern is not the fines paid, the close to $1 million in legal fees that the litigation is costing or even regaining the $25 million lost yearly from the dissolution of the Publix account. Instead, he said, "I just want our good reputation back."
Publix supermarkets was Hapco's first major account. The two had been doing business for 35 years, affording the Long Island company 15 percent of its overall business at revenues in excess of $20 million yearly.
At Hapco's Riverhead offices, the staff remains optimistic. Brisk business continues in the company's California, Florida, Massachusetts and Maine branches.
"We enjoy a high status because of the quality of our product and the continuity of supply we offer buyers," said Harvey Pollak's son, Andy Pollak, the company's vice president. "We're not going to give that up so easily."
Both locally and nationally, Hapco was one of the first packagers to tap into national and international markets -- even as far as Russia and South America, thus providing a never-ceasing produce supply to American supermarkets -- the reason why strawberries may be had in December or sweet potatoes in June.
In the coming months, the corporation hopes to branch out into newer aspects of packaging, including mini-vegetables, and convenience vegetables like Hapco's exclusive pre-peeled and blanched potatoes. These tubers are ready-to-use and can be fully cooked in 7 to 10 minutes and will be available in local markets this fall.
