HEADLINE: POSTINGS: $12.3 Million Expansion for the College of Aeronautics Includes 10 Classrooms and Lab Space;
A New Hangar, for Planes That Don't Fly

 BODY:
What are a parking lot full of assorted aircraft and a hangar and observation tower under construction doing opposite La Guardia Airport on the other side of the Grand Central Parkway?
They belong to the 65-year-old College of Aeronautics, which offers associate and bachelor of science degrees in such areas as aircraft maintenance, avionics and computerized design. The privately owned school is now in the midst of a $12.3 million expansion on its six-acre site in East Elmhurst, Queens, bounded by Ditmars Boulevard, 90th Street and 23d Avenue. 
 A 35,000-square-foot addition to the college's existing 75,000-square-foot classroom and lab building includes a 5,000-square-foot hangar and a three-story observation tower overlooking La Guardia's runways. The 17 permanently grounded planes, acquired over the years, will get a new parking and engine-checking area next to the hangar.
The extension, which will add 10 classrooms and more lab space, will provide a new main entrance on 90th Street. Work, begun last January, is to be completed next January.
Curved roofs, soaring ceilings, large areas of blue-green glass and a metallic-silver facade create an aeronautical theme, said Robert H. Harker of Nadaskay Kopelson Architects of Morristown, N.J., which designed the addition.
Lab space will include areas for testing aircraft components and for the study of composite materials and hydraulics and pneumatics. A jet-engine lab will be in a separate structure. The new labs will give students access to the latest in aviation technology, said the college's president, John C. Fitzpatrick.
Founded in 1932 in Newark, the college moved to its present campus in 1942. It leased its land and building from New York City until 1994 when it purchased both from the Economic Development Corporation for $3.7 million.
The existing building, which will be renovated, has 17 classrooms, lab space including one with 40 engines for conducting tests on them and a 2,500-square-foot hangar.
The school, which is seeking tax-exempt bonds from the city for the addition, is currently using a line of credit from Chase Manhattan Bank for construction costs.
Students -- 95 percent of them male -- come primarily from the city, 50 percent from Queens alone. Enrollment has grown from 825 full- and part-time students in 1986 to l,102, and is expected to reach 1,500, the school's full capacity, by the turn of the century, Dr. Fitzpatrick said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: New observation tower of College of Aeronautics near La Guardia Airport. (Steve Berman for the New York Times)

HEADLINE: The 2002 Olympics Are Transforming Salt Lake City

BYLINE: By VERNE KOPYTOFF 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY

 BODY:
UNTIL a few decades ago, the two dozen or so cities nestled between the flanks of the Wasatch Mountains and shore of the Great Salt Lake subsisted heavily on farming and the area's natural bounty of minerals and timber.
Development in Salt Lake City reflected this reliable but mild economy: a sleepy downtown filled with low-rise storefronts -- some built of brick by early Mormon settlers -- and suburbs with more land devoted to pastures than housing tracts. 
 But now the area finds itself in an unfamiliar position at the center of attention as host of the Winter Olympics in 2002, and preparations for it are accelerating what is already one of the fastest growing local economies in the country.
Not since the silver rush in the 1880's that brought saloons and prospectors' cabins to the surrounding mountain towns has this area been so transformed, this time with office towers, bobsled courses, ice rinks, tract homes and business parks. "Our economy is now broader and more stable than it was 30 years ago," said Brian Hatch, Deputy Mayor of Salt Lake City. "Now we have more service businesses, more tourism, more conventions and more warehousing since we are at a crossroads of the West."
While Olympics construction represents only a fraction of the area's 5 percent annual job growth rate over the last few years, it is at the forefront of nearly every local resident's mind. Outsiders who ask about development in the state typically get a gloating smile followed by a recitation of the dozen or so Olympic venues that have been built or are in various stages of construction and planning. Though the area is rich in ski resorts, about half the sports facilities and infrastructure for the games must be built from scratch at a cost of nearly $1 billion, according to Utah's Office of Planning and Budget. So that the cost of construction is not too burdensome on one entity, most development is being financed by partnerships between the Salt Lake City Olympic Committee and government entities and private companies.
Among the largest projects is a 10,500-seat arena, financed with $7 million from the Olympic Committee and $46 million from the City of West Valley, where the completed arena is situated. During the games, the venue will accommodate short track speed skating races and preliminary ice hockey matches (the finals will be in the Delta Center, home of the Utah Jazz basketball team). Otherwise, it will be used as a concert hall and as a home for the Utah Grizzlies, an International League hockey team that leases the arena for its matches.
Salt Lake City also lacked a place to house nearly 3,500 athletes and an adequate location for the opening and closing ceremonies. The Olympic Committee turned to the University of Utah in Salt Lake City to expand the school's football stadium from 32,000 seats to 50,000, and to build new student dormitories to serve as an athletes' village during the games. The university will pay about $98 million of the total $110 million it will take to complete the two projects.
Part of the construction for the Winter Games began even before Salt Lake City was named as Olympic host. The construction was part of the effort to win designation from the International Olympic Committee, which passed over Utah for the 1998 games in favor of Nagano, Japan. The state built the basics of a $59 million winter sports park with a bobsled course, luge course, Nordic combined tracks, several ski jumps, and a speed-skating oval located off site, funded by a small increase in the state sales tax that voters approved in 1988.
Once the games are over, the Olympic Committee will reimburse Utah for that $59 million, plus $40 million for a maintenance fund. Civic leaders hope that the park and other facilities like the ice rinks will become a training ground for winter sports competitors, much like Colorado Springs, Colo., has become a home to the American summer sports program. "If you go to Squaw Valley, which hosted the Olympics in the 1960's, there is virtually nothing left," said David Winder, executive director of Utah's office of Community and Economic Development. "We want virtually every facility built for the Olympics this time to have a lasting effect on the city."
Even without the Olympics, the Salt Lake City area, population 1.2 million, is in the midst of an unprecedented construction spree that reflects the prosperity of the local economy and the area's relatively new role as a regional corporate headquarters. In downtown Salt Lake City, at least half a dozen cranes swing overhead on several projects that when finished will transform the skyline from its gap-toothed appearance of the past.
American Stores, the supermarket chain, is building a 24-story, gray and turquoise glass edifice to serve as its main office. Nearby, the Mormon Church, based in Salt Lake City, is erecting an 18-story tower to lease as office space.
One of the area's largest landowners and real estate developers, the Mormon Church has recently completed a 330-unit brick apartment complex downtown and has started laying the foundation for a 20,000-seat assembly hall that is expected to cost $240 million. The church's high birth rate and its growing membership has rendered the old assembly hall too small.
Another source of downtown construction is government, which has outgrown some of its 1960's-era buildings. Workers are finishing the interior of a new $60 million state courthouse, and a Federal courthouse a few blocks away is in the design stage.
Though Salt Lake City has a wealth of hotel rooms, many real estate experts have predicted that several more hotels will be built downtown to capitalize on the Olympics. So far, these predictions have been only partly realized with a $185 million expansion underway at the Little America hotel and an announcement that developers will begin work on a 350-room Crown Plaza Hotel sometime this winter.
ONE part of downtown that has yet to be affected by development is on the west side, a depressed warehouse district that is literally on the other side of the railroad tracks. Civic leaders hope that it will become an entertainment area, but for now a hulking train depot, a rail yard and dozens of brick buildings sit decrepit, much of them deserted among the weeds.
Outside of Salt Lake City, in the sprawling bedroom communities nearby, economic growth has led to countless distribution centers, business parks, and strip malls.
Long reputed to have bargain-priced housing, the Salt Lake area's steady population growth of roughly two percent since 1990 has pushed the median price of a home upward in recent years by over 10 percent annually to $127,000 in 1997, compared with the national median of $123,000, according to the National Association of Realtors.
In suburbs like South Jordan, Draper and Sandy, new brick homes are being built three to an acre in developments that rise on former farmland. In 1996, housing starts for new single family homes totaled 8,800 in the area, according to the Census Bureau.
But with this growth comes some notable problems. Among those commonly mentioned is a dearth of moderate-income housing, poor city planning and some notoriously congested highways -- a situation that is being addressed with a $2 billion program to expand Interstate 15 and build a commuter and light-rail system that is scheduled to be completed before the Olympics.
"Locals sometimes complain that we are getting too big," said Jaren L. Davis, president of the Salt Lake Board of Realtors. "But we are still a small city if you compare us on a national scale."

American Stores headquarters in Salt Lake City nears completion. (Don Grayston for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Magical Yet Fragile Palette: Houses, Beaches and Shining Water

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
FROM the shoreline the water surrounding Long Island usually looks a drab gray. But from a helicopter over Fire Island on a recent morning the gentle waves were an almost luminous aqua.
"We see a variety of colors from up here," said Jeffrey Poretsky, a producer who is filming aerial views for WLIW-TV. "Yesterday we got a Caribbean blue. It was just amazing." 
 The palette is just one revelation about Long Island when seen from above.
Motorists below have come to rely on helicopter alerts to navigate expressway and parkway traffic jams. And government and business have found that aerial views are useful tools for fields like real estate and crime detection.
Earthbound residents will have a chance to see the bird's-eye view when Mr. Poretsky's program, "Visions of Long Island," has its premiere at 8 P.M. on Dec. 9.
From the air, Long Island idiosyncrasies stand out.
Spindly water towers are scattered across the horizon like giant Tinkertoys. The landscape is pocked by sumps, those deep pits carved out as recharge basins for rainwater. The straight and narrow Long Island Rail Road tracks cut along the length of the island like an endless brown zipper.
"These marshes are quite beautiful," Mr. Poretsky said. "You see the tides washing in and out and get this sense of how it's all tied together on the planet -- it's magical."
The wetlands are etched in a giant grid by hundreds of miles of skinny ditches, part of a network dug decades ago to thwart mosquitoes and malaria. Here and there stands a lonesome bay shack.
At ground level, the view across the Great South Bay is deceptively foreshortened. Only from above does its broad expanse unfold. That perspective also highlights the fragility of the slender South Shore barrier beaches that protect the main island and the tranquil bays from the pounding Atlantic surf.
Besides spectacular sightseeing, flying over the Island offers new insights.
"The first thing I did when I became the County Planning Director was to go up in a plane," the chief planner of Suffolk County, Stephen M. Jones, said. "It was a good opportunity to reacquaint myself with everything from the air. I especially wanted to see the beach erosion. When you're on the ground you can only see so far. It's more parochial. From the air you see with a more regional sense and see how the pieces fit together -- or don't fit together.
"The thing that pops out most vividly is the Long Island State Parkway system, Robert Moses' concept of a highway within a linear park. Right behind those trees is urban sprawl, which you don't see from the road."
Even driving in built-up areas, he said, "all you see are some two-story buildings. From the air, you really see the extent of the sprawl."
Flying over Babylon and Islip shows how economic and political forces have dictated contrasting uses on abutting swaths of otherwise indistinguishable flat land, the Pinelawn cemeteries, a golf course, subdivision housing, woods and commercial and industrial strips with their squared-off roofscapes and paved parking lots.
The enormous popularity of swimming pools becomes startlingly apparent. Invisible from the streets, they dot backyards everywhere with their round or rectangular shapes, all covered now with dark plastic sheets till next summer.
Developers use aerial tours and photographs to plan their projects, Mr. Jones said. "You can see where the first wave of development crashes in," Mr. Jones said, "and later where the undertow development moves back and fills in vacant parcels.
"You see the residual stream beds, little bands of woods and the encroachment of newer homes. Now you see the maturation of communities like Levittown and East Meadow. When they were built they looked raw, standing on farm fields. The trees planted then have grown up now, and in some places you can't even see the roads and houses for the tree canopies."
Suffolk is making new digitized versions of old aerial photographs "to show people what places were like before they got there," Mr. Jones said.
In Nassau a Democratic candidate for the County Legislature, Brian Mercadante, inspected his district, the 18th, by plane. He made photos for Mayor Thomas Suozzi of Glen Cove, who is using them to plan waterfront development.
Unpleasant necessities, often screened from the view of earthbound passers-by, are wide open to the overhead observer: sewage holding tanks, automobile junkyards and garbage landfills. Sand mines are gouged out of the North Shore's glacial hills like gaping wounds.
Illicit secrets are sometimes uncovered from the sky. A few weeks ago a Suffolk police helicopter crew, searching for a burglary suspect in thick woods in Wyandanch, was surprised to find a hidden patch of marijuana. Officers on foot returned to seize an estimated 2,000 plants, some 10 en feet tall, weighing a total of 1,000 pounds.
Responding to another emergency call last month, a police helicopter found two youngsters who were lost in a woods in Manorville.
"You also see a lot of beauty up there," said Mr. Jones.
Mr. Poretsky admired the geometric grace of a cloverleaf on Sunrise Highway. "Even Hempstead Turnpike looks beautiful from up here," he said, referring to an otherwise dreary shopping corridor.
From above the neat rows of marble headstones in the National Cemetery shrink into thousands of tiny white points on a deep green matrix.
Long Island's wealth impressed Mr. Poretsky as he taped Gold Coast mansions and East End resort houses. "I will never have enough money in my life to have the house of my dreams," he lamented. "And you'd be surprised how many horse farms and tracks there are that we didn't even know existed."
Sunset heralds yet another vision of the Island. "At night you see the lights along the roads and in shopping-mall parking lots," Mr. Jones said. "It's just like a circulatory system, with arteries, veins and nodes. They don't call highways arterials for nothing."
But for all it reveals about Long Island, the aerial views also obscure some earthly realities.
"From the air," Mr. Jones added, "you can't see potholes, litter, graffiti, the homeless and people waiting on welfare lines."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/The Westchester Office Market;
Leasing Out Space Left by Corporate Downsizings

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE building at 1311 Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains is in many ways typical of the problems and opportunities in the office market in Westchester County.
Built on speculation in the early 80's by the Jack Parker Corporation, it was occupied by a single tenant, a division of I.B.M. Corporation, from its opening in 1982. Like so many other buildings in this northern suburb of New York, it was hard hit by the shrinkage of large corporations, including AT&T, Nynex and, of course, I.B.M. 
 As International Business Machines shrank its workforce, it consolidated into property it owned, leaving owners of leased properties to figure out how to remarket their buildings. Since it is not likely that a single tenant can be found for the 320,000-square-foot building that sits on 27 wooded acres on Mamaroneck Avenue, the owner is remodeling it for multitenant use.
"I.B.M. was very security conscious and they built a fortress," said Robert S. Skolnick, a vice president of Jack Parker. The company only used one entrance, he noted, though three were built, and it closed off the underground parking area and used the space for storage. Even an outdoor courtyard in the center of the building was sealed.
When I.B.M. pulled out in March, Parker took control of the property. Although plans are not yet complete, the general thought is to open the structure up and add amenities like a fitness center, conference facilities and a cafeteria with indoor-outdoor seating that will utilize the central courtyard.
"We looked at the market and found it very tight in northern New Jersey and Fairfield County," Mr. Skolnick said "We saw rentals at $30 a square foot at our Parker Plaza in Fort Lee and $32 to $34 a foot in Fairfield. So we figured we could reposition the building as a corporate campus setting and try to attract companies who can't find space nearby or are planning to move out of Manhattan."
Indeed, brokers and real estate executives say a lack of space and a rent spike in Fairfield are forcing companies to consider Westchester, whose recovery from the downturn of the early and mid-90's has lagged behind Fairfield and northern New Jersey, where developers are talking again about speculative building.
For companies looking for existing office space "Westchester is the last ball game -- there is no other space in the northern suburbs," said Donald P. Eisen, Cushman & Wakefield's chief suburban office specialist. He said companies looking to move typically do not want to wait the 18 to 24 months it takes to complete a new building. "Everybody wants action now," he said.
According to figures compiled by Newmark & Company Real Estate, a total of 485,637 net square feet of space was leased in Westchester in the third quarter of the year, which is almost as much as the previous two quarters.
As a result, the vacancy rate declined, from 17.3 percent at the beginning of the quarter to 15.9 percent at the end. Fairfield remained steady at about 13 percent. Nevertheless, corporate downsizing has left large spaces, like the Parker property, hanging over the market, while demand comes in smaller bites.
"The market continues to be hampered by an imbalance in the supply and demand for office space," said Michael Klein, executive director of Insignia/Rostenberg-Doern. He noted that more than one-third of the available office space in Westchester was in blocks of 250,000 square feet or more, while the majority of recent leases have been for 5,000 square feet or less.
"Westchester is clearly a pocket that has not fully recovered," said Jon Halpern, president of Halpern Real Estate Development. "The corporate consolidation lasted a little longer here and went a little deeper." Mr. Halpern, who is also a member of the board of the Reckson Associates Realty Company, a real estate investment trust, which is active in most New York suburbs, cited the case of the Tarrytown Corporate Center.
"When I.B.M. pulled out we had 450,000 square feet to market," he said. "When we put Ciba-Geigy in there the market was getting so tight that we were thinking it might be time to build again. But then Novartis bought Ciba and moved 170,000 square feet worth of people out."
Mr. Halpern said that he expected to be able to lease that space within 12 months, but said it is a good example of how decisions made at a distant corporate headquarters can affect a local market.
Another adverse effect of corporate shrinkage is an overstatement of the amount of property on the market, said Carl Austin, president of Austin Corporate Properties. "The problem is that the statistics include buildings that are in mothballs, and not actually on the market," Mr. Austin said. When corporations left buildings, many owners lost control to their lenders.
"The lenders are not going to invest in those buildings, so they are effectively off the market," Mr. Austin said. "They may be recycled as residential or retail properties, but meanwhile they distort the statistics."
Mr. Skolnick said that since the Parker Center was originally a speculative building, it was flexible enough to handle multiple tenants. Since it has three major sections, each with its own entrance and lobby, several tenants could appear to have their "own" building.
"Instead of a corporate headquarters, we might get several divisions who take 100,000 to 150,000 square feet each," he said. "We could have two or three different companies, and give each one a separate identity."
"It is actually three buildings that interconnect," said Barry Gosin, the chief executive of Newmark, which is marketing the project. "It is going to be modernized, renovated and repositioned for more than one tenant."
Despite the difficulty in matching space to prospective tenants, economic pressure is going to force more companies to make things work in Westchester, real estate executives say.
"There has been a real transition in Fairfield," said Mr. Klein of Insignia/Rostenberg-Doern. "Eighteen months ago rentals were in the $17-$18 a foot range. Now in downtown Stamford it is $30 to $34 a foot as is -- with no work."
He said that as companies that signed up during the real estate recession in the early years of the decade come to the end of five- to seven-year leases, many are likely to look elsewhere. "The decision will usually be to look farther up the Connecticut coast or consider Westchester." Mr. Klein said rental rates in Class A buildings in Westchester were $20 to $22 a square foot, which could represent a big savings from a Stamford or Greenwich location.
INDUSTRY executives note that the Westchester office market is now dominated by institutional investors who have the capital to invest in renovating buildings and the staying power to make it through recessions. Most of Mr. Halpern's holdings were acquired by Reckson, while the Robert Martin portfolio was purchased by the Cali Realty Corporation. A third portfolio, the Shulman holding of 24 buildings, is now owned by the General Motors Pension Fund and the Principal insurance company.
"We have these new players in the market now," Mr. Austin said. "They are careful not to overpay, but they are aggressively pursuing investments."
Mr. Austin said Westchester still retains its structural advantages, such as good transportation links to New York City as well as the appeal of the suburbs. "When a company looks to relocate from Manhattan," he said, "we can show them the good schools, the country club and stable taxes."
As difficult as the transition from being host to corporate headquarters to host to multitenant properties has been, the end result will be a stronger real estate base in the county, said Mr. Halpern. "Those buildings that were occupied by a single corporate tenant are being reoccupied by a diverse group of strong tenants who are growing, not contracting," he said. "The residential market here is tremendously strong and that is usually a precursor to commercial activity."
But others sound a note of caution. Mr. Eisen of Cushman & Wakefield said anyone who expected to fill empty corporate palaces without substantial modification is probably dreaming.
"The corporations are still cautious," he said. "The 80's are not that far away. People are still a little shy about committing to sprawling corporate campuses. We don't have the huge space-growth companies that we had in the past."

LENGTH: 1256 words

HEADLINE: Trying To Win A Park (And Jobs)

BYLINE: By STEPHEN L. PURDY 

 BODY:
SIX FLAGS Theme Parks, a Time Warner Company with 12 parks in operation, is coming to New England. The company, known for its fantasy and adventure exhibits and rides tied to corporate properties like Bugs Bunny and Superman, is aggressively marketing locations, with things appearing to have narrowed down to East Hartford and Hopkinton, R.I.
East Hartford has the demographics and Hopkinton has proximity to established resorts, in Six Flags' estimation. What the company has its eye on in Connecticut is the 600-acre Rentschler Field formerly used by Pratt & Whitney. 
 Bill Moore, vice president of theme park development for Six Flags, says talks with Pratt & Whitney are going well. He adds a park of this scope -- $280 million, 300 acres -- is unusual in today's economy and that "We expect people from all over will want to come see, just as they went to Disney."
Visitors, he adds, would be attracted from as far away as Boston, Albany, Philadelphia and Montreal.
Chuck Coursey, a spokesman for the company, says that research shows 30 percent of visitors will stay at least one night at an area hotel, in addition to visiting other attractions. Supporters of the plan in East Hartford, looking to a theme park to help revive an economy shaken by military and retail losses, want to play a major role in regional development. They believe Six Flags' capital investment and estimated 3.5 million visitors a year will help the town do just that.
"It's the type of project that can create a spark for the entire region," says East Hartford's Mayor, Robert M. DeCrescenzo, who initiated talks with Six Flags in February after reading the company was considering a North Stonington site. "They've got the right state, just the wrong town," he told a lawyer working with Six Flags.
Pratt & Whitney, meanwhile, is saying little. "The most recent discussions we've had with Six Flags," said Gary Minor, a spokesman, "have been very good ones." Still, he added, "We weren't going to talk to anybody about a use of the field unless it was something we deemed positive for East Hartford, greater Hartford and the state."
This past summer, the East Hartford Chamber of Commerce organized a trip of 40 business, government and community people to the nearest Six Flags park, in Jackson, N.J. "We were pleased by its cleanliness, quiet and organization," said Mary Beth Reid, the chamber's executive director.
In observing Six Flags' construction in New Jersey, she felt the company would respect the East Hartford terrain. "What I found in Jackson was you didn't know you were there until you got inside the park," she explained.
In turn, she thinks East Hartford's site, with its highway accessibility and trees planted to soften airplane noise, will help a theme park.
Drivers should be able to enter the park without using local streets, said Mayor DeCrescenzo. "If we are smart about the traffic planning, we can make it imperceptible to the existing neighborhoods, one of which is my own," he said.
The director of finance at the Connecticut Rivers Council Boy Scouts of America, based in East Hartford and serving 127 cities and towns, is considering ways a theme park can merge with his organization's goal to establish life skills in young people. Six Flags' potential for summer jobs is considered a particular asset.
The East of River Chambers of Commerce Association, a group of chamber members from six towns and county organizations around East Hartford, has studied the potential impact of a theme park and prepared a collective position. Before releasing it, however, each member must clear it with his or her executive committee. The group's director, John N. Anderson, says he has little doubt the body will come out in strong support of Six Flags.
State Senator Gary D. LeBeau, a Democrat of East Hartford, thinks Pratt & Whitney and Six Flags are "within inches of signing a proposal." He believes Six Flags will negotiate financial aid with the state in the form of tax incremental financing (revenue collected at admission used to pay a bond the state would back). Senator LeBeau says it's vital East Hartford get Six Flags. North-central Connecticut, he explains, needs another engine of growth. "With one stroke," he says of the park, "we diversify."
Harry Henninger, president of Kennywood Entertainment, which operates three amusement parks in Pennsylvania and is new owner/operator of Lake Compounce, counters that Six Flags ought to make a proposal on vacant land now available at the Bristol park 20 miles away. "Instead of building this megapark in East Hartford," he said, "let's take the $100 million worth of value in Lake Compounce now, add to that, and make that the megapark. That way everybody wins."
Six Flags answers that a Hartford opening would only benefit the Bristol/Southington center. Promotion, Mr. Moore says, would include all media, television, radio and newspaper, and would encourage the state's tourism groups.
Andrew J. Meade, chairman of the Southington Town Council, isn't convinced. "If Six Flags comes to East Hartford or the state, it would be disastrous for Lake Compounce," he said. He says Kennywood worked well with the state in last year's joint development, and that the state may be throwing away its investment and betraying Lake Compounce. "The state gave its word, put up money for Lake Compounce and brought these people in, let them believe Lake Compounce would be the amusement park in the area."
He adds that the state will end up spending millions more dollars to reconstruct already overburdened roads for the Six Flag project. It's foolishness, he adds, to think visitors there would ride down to Lake Compounce. More generally, he accuses the state of considering too many service- and low-paying jobs. A strong manufacturing base, he says, has long been protection during slow economic times.
Along with Bristol's Mayor Frank N. Nicastro Sr., he has written to the Gov. John G. Rowland expressing concern.
Dean Pagani, spokesman for the Governor, said "The Governor has clearly signaled to everyone involved that he doesn't want an investment in Six Flags to hurt Lake Compounce. The state has, over the years, made continuing investments there. Obviously, the Governor doesn't want to invest in a new project that's going to kill another one."
For Senator LeBeau, however, "The issue here is not East Hartford versus Bristol -- it's Connecticut versus Rhode Island." If Six Flags is across the line, he says, "Lake Compounce is going to be wiped out."
P. Anthony Giorgio, Hartford area economist whose Capitol Region Growth Council led the regional economic strategy MetroHartford Millennium Project, says that, along with the jobs, hotel and restaurant business Six Flags would provide, it would boost Millennium-encouraged regional initiatives such as a new science museum/magnet school in East Hartford, a possible ESPN headquarters, and the redevelopment of area colleges with a downtown Hartford anchor.
Most important, he says, we can't ignore that some analysts are projecting Six Flags may provide the state with $1 billion in revenue over the next decade.
Mr. Giorgio says those who accuse the region of avoiding manufacturing are wrong. "I have 800 jobs with area manufacturers I can't fill," he says, "because I don't have skilled workers." Finally, in support of Six Flags in East Hartford, he says, "Arts and entertainment is big business, one of the major economic drivers of any successful region."

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 7; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1229 words

HEADLINE: Going for Election: Mudslinging or Just Presenting Facts?

BYLINE: By PEGGY McCARTHY 

 BODY:
NEGATIVE campaigning was one of the losers in last Tuesday's municipal elections, according to politicians who survived it. What's referred to as mudslinging by victims and pointing out factual allegations by attackers didn't work in Waterbury and Orange where incumbents won re-election.
Orange Democratic First Selectman Robert C. Sousa predicted that his victory would bring an end to "negative, personal campaigning" not only in his town but in the whole state and country. "It sounds melodramatic, but it is important. People are very, very upset." 
 Mr. Sousa, a lawyer who two years ago was the first Democrat ever elected First Selectman in Orange, survided a campaign in which opponents tried to make an issue of his legal representation of a Ku Klux Klan leader in civil matters. He defeated Albert (Skip) Clark, a Republican, and Daniel V. Presnick of the Orange Taypayers Party.
In Waterbury, Philip A. Giordano, a Republican, was elected to a second term in his heavily Democratic city after a campaign in which allegations about his personal life attempted to upstage the Mayor's talk of eliminating the budget deficit. On election night, he claimed victory over "rumors, innuendos and fabrications of truth." During the campaign, he denied rumors that he was the father of an illegitimate child, faced questions about being found by the police with a female staffer at night in a parked car, and confronted a battle over whether the police should release a tape of a 911 call from his home. Mr. Giordano defeated Democratic State Representative Thomas F. Conway.
In Westport, Diane C. Farrell, a Democrat, and her supporters expressed pride about sticking to the issues in her successful campaign to oust the incumbent Republican First Selectman, Joseph P. Arcudi. But Republicans insisted there were subtle references on the part of Democrats to Mr. Arcudi being the defendant in a sexual harrassment lawsuit that had been settled out of court.
Whether Mr. Sousa is correct -- that people will reject negative campaigning in the voting booth -- remains to be seen. But indications are that negative campaigning itself will continue to be an issue.
The state's senior United States . Senator, Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat of East Haddam, recently criticized his party's state chairman, Edward L. Marcus, for statements Mr. Marcus had made connecting rumor-plagued Mr. Giordano with Gov. John G. Rowland, who campaigned for the Waterbury Mayor. Mr Dodd recently told a Fairfield audience that Mr. Marcus "crossed the line" in a press release about Mr. Giordano. It was titled, "Waterbury Mayor Caught with City Hall Staffer" and subtitled, "Another Rowland Ally You Just Can't Trust."
The Republican State Chairman, Christopher DePino, also attacked what he called Mr. Marcus's "shoot-from-the-hip style." He had written to Mr. Dodd before the Senator made his remarks, asking for "a public response" to the Democratic chairman's "continuing attacks on Governor Rowland and the personal nature of those attacks."
In an interview, the Democratic chairman defended his strategy, saying he was making "factual allegations." Mr. Marcus said, "I intend to criticize Rowland when he deserves it. That's one of the functions of the Democratic chairman when you have a Republican Governor, to point out the failings of the Republican governor. I have been doing that consistently, effectively, properly."
Mr. Marcus, whose term expires in January of 1999, said "there's a likelihood" of his seeking the chairmanship for another term.
In the municipal elections that took place in 159 towns throughout the state, Republicans scored upsets in Hamden and East Haven, while in Branford, Democrat Anthony (Unk) DaRos ousted incumbent Republican First Selectman Dominic A. Buonocore.
Hamden Democratic Mayor Lillian D. Clayman, who had indicated interest in running for Secretary of the State, was defeated by Republican Barbara A. DeNicola, whose father and brother have also served as Hamden mayors.
In East Haven, Democratic Mayor Henry J. Luzzi lost to Republican Joseph Maturo Jr. East Haven has been in the public eye recently because of an incident in which a police chase resulted in the death of an unarmed New Haven man. Mr. Luzzi has defended the actions of the police officer. East Haven has also been the defendant in a lawsuit brought by the N.A.A.C.P. (page 12).
In Greenwich, where there had been controversies concerning the police department, the sewers and the closing of Byram Park due to pollution, there was a tight race between incumbent Republican Tom R. Ragland 3d and Democrat Stephanie H. Sanchez. Midweek unofficial results showed Mr. Ragland with a 117-vote lead. But Democrats were elated because it was just the second time in 100 years that two Democrats, Ms. Sanchez and Richard Bergstresser, were elected to the Board of Selectmen. Republicans outnumber Democrats in Greenwich by more two-and-a-half-to-one.
In the large cities, incumbents ruled. After easily winning election to a fourth term in Bridgeport, Democratic Mayor Joseph P. Ganim said he would soon make an announcement about whether he would run for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination against Congresswoman Barbara B. Kennelly of Hartford. On election night Mr. Ganim said, "I'm committed to my city and its future. I'm equally committed to my state."
Stamford Mayor Dannell P. Malloy defeated a severely underfinanced opponent, Republican Charles E. Klein. After his first, two-year term, Mr. Malloy will begin Stamford's first four-year term of office for a mayor. Mr. Malloy attributed his victory to a reduction in crime and unemployment, investment in schools, and physical improvements like road repairs and new sidewalks.
In New Haven and Hartford, where the Democratic mayors had no Republican opposition, New Haven Mayor John DeStefano Jr.and Hartford Mayor Michael P. Peters were re-elected over independent candidates.
In Fairfield, Democratic Kenneth A. Flatto won the open First Selectman's seat, beating Republican John P. McCarthy, while Republican Mayors Frank J. Esposito, of Norwalk; William W. Dickinson Jr., of Wallingford, and Mark A. Lauretti, of Shelton, were all re-elected. Guilford Republican Samuel Bartlett defeated Democrat Marianne Sullivan in an open contest.
Democrats were successful in Middletown, East Hartford, New Britain and Danbury. Dominique Thornton is the new Middletown Mayor and Timothy D. Larson was elected Mayor of East Hartford, while Lucian J. Pawlak was re-elected in New Britain, and Gene F. Eriquez keeps his job in Danbury.
In Milford, a new third party, which campaigned mainly on its opposition to low-income housing in the city, grabbed five seats on the city's Board of Aldermen. The party, called Citizens for Milford's Future, which had received a donation from William F. Buckley Jr. of Stamford, is an offshoot of the local Republican party. The city's Republican mayor, Frederick L. Lisman, had no opposition to his re-election bid.
According to figures provided by the Secretary of the State's office, there were 1.8 million voters registered on the active voters list, a 2.4 percent drop from the Presidential election year.
Decreases typically occur after Presidential years, but this year's drop is the lowest since 1973, according to the state figures.

HEADLINE: What's Really Needed To Help Students

BYLINE: By PEGGY MCCARTHY 

 BODY:
AN advocate for children with learning disabilities, Ann W. Seigel, of West Hartford, said she gets an upset stomach every time she hears talk of reducing the number of children being diagnosed with learning problems. Ms. Seigel says she worries that if educational services are cut for these children, the risk of their dropping out of school will rise sharply and they could become unemployable, or even commit crimes. Ms. Seigel said she gets sicker with fears that parents of other children will rally to support cuts in special education programs.
"There've been a lot of bad vibes across the country" about learning disabled students, said Ms. Seigel, whose grown son has learning disabilities. "There's been bashing that they're not truly disabled, that the parents are buying the labels. When you live with a youngster and you know he has a disabling condition that you can't see, it's very disturbing." 
 But the Bridgeport Superintendent of Schools, James Connelly, sees a need for streamlining the special education process and program. He said he has seen children from, say, Honduras or El Salvador being inappropriately labeled as learning disabled because they had missed years of school in their own countries.
"There's a tendency if you don't know what to do with them, put a special education label on them," he said, explaining that such misidentification helps drive special education costs up when a good language program would be more effective. He maintained that a "one-size-fits-all" philosophy of addressing learning problems has put more children in special education programs than need to have been there.
Lumped together as special education students are children with mental retardation, blindness, deafness, cerebral palsy, dyslexia, attention deficit disorder and a variety of other problems, such as difficulties in learning how to read and write.
The focus of most of the state's attention is on children classified as learning disabled, a broad label that generally describes people with at least average intelligence who have trouble understanding spoken or written language. They may have problems listening, thinking, speaking, reading, writing, spelling or doing math. The Olympic athlete Bruce Jenner who grew up in Newtown, for example, has dyslexia, which means he might see a letter like b as a d. He has said that it was easier to participate in the Olympics than it was to be called on to read in school.
Nearly 14 percent of public school students have been identified as needing special education and some 48 percent of those have been classified as learning disabled, according to figures compiled by the State Department of Education. "We're not trying to throw out special education. We're not trying to take away services," said Thomas Murphy, a spokesman for the Education Department. "But," he added, "we have to question whether 14 percent of our students are special education students."
In Connecticut, more than two-thirds of special education students spend most of their time in regular classrooms, and receive fewer than 10 hours a week in supplemental instruction, according to a draft report on special education written by the department. About 8 percent have been placed in private schools, which can cost tens of thousands of dollars a year. This is paid for by the school district where the child lives -- or lived, in instances where the state has removed children from their homes.
The report cites an increase in special education students from 3 percent in 1992-93 to 13.9 percent in 1995-96, a 4 percent exit rate from special education programs, and suggests that too many students are being identified as learning disabled.
Recommendations in the report that have prompted considerable debate include:
* Increasing the placement of special education students in the regular classroom (the educational jargon is "mainstreaming").
* Reducing what is called the "prevalence rate" of children needing special education.
* Increasing the number of students who leave special education programs during their school career.
* Decreasing the use of the label "special education" or "learning disabled," which the report states places a stigma on children, resulting in low expectations.
A recommendation to place more focus on the teaching of reading, and to retrain and better prepare teachers to tailor reading lessons to individual needs has received more widespread support. The report states that research shows a "direct linkage between the label of learning disabilities and the inability of children to acquire reading skills."
But the Connecticut Education Association, the state's largest teachers' union, has a different point of view, said Daria M. Plummer, association president.
"I know for a fact teachers know how to teach reading," she said, adding "it's incomprehensible to think you can put children of all abilities, including children with learning disabilities, in one classroom and simply say the teacher can teach each one totally." Children with learning problems, she said, often need extra help from specially trained teachers.
In interviews, advocates for special education insisted that the numbers of students identified are not alarming, but reflect what studies show as the proportion of people with learning problems in the population. They said Connecticut has the fifth highest percentage of special education students in the country because of proficiency here at identifying such children.
Special education advocates said that although some learning disabilities are caused by use of alcohol and drugs by pregnant women, most are genetic and can't be cured. So, they said, some learning disabled children appropriately need support throughout their education. But they said that some chldren who are diagnosed with learning disabilties at a young age and are given help, learn to compensate for them and can eventually succeed in the regular classroom.
The suggestion in the report that a stigma is attached to being a special education student has triggered emotional reaction. Beryl F. Kaufman, executive director of the Connecticut Association for Children with Learning Disabilities, said before diagnosis, children with learning problems have been given other labels by classmates, parents, siblings and teachers. "They're called dumb, retarded, stupid," she said, and added, "Are they saying, if there were no special education, these kids would not have self-esteem problems?"
Mainstreaming isn't a clear-cut solution, the advocates say, pointing to studies showing that mentally retarded children succeed well in regular classrooms, but some learning disabled students need to be in less noisy settings.
An educational psychology professor at the University of Connecticut, Miriam Cherkes-Julkowski, described the state report as "anti-special education." It has prompted "a terrible fear that special education will be lost completely, and then, what will happen to these children," she said. The fact that Federal law requires provision of special education has heartened advocates.
Concerns about costs for special education have been expressed by officials of towns and school districts. Those costs include salaries for specialists like psychologists and speech and language therapists, legal fees when parents appeal for more services for their children, and residential placements made by such agencies as the State Department of Children and Families. The report states that special education represents 17.8 percent of local education spending.
Municipalities want to see the state assume a greater share of these costs and will be asking the General Assembly to take action to do so in the 1998 session, said James Finley, legislative liaison for the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities. Until 1995, the state provided a separate grant for special education. Since the general education and special education grants were merged, increases in special education costs have not been reflected in the single grant, Mr. Finley said.

HEADLINE: Volunteer Center To Help With Jobs

BYLINE: By FELICE BUCKVAR 

 BODY:
THE Volunteer Center of United Way in White Plains will take part in the county's effort to get recipients of the Temporary Assistance to Needy Families program into job training and jobs.
Benefiting from the center's Community Work Experience Program, besides the 700 needy families chosen to take part, will be the nonprofit and governmental agencies to which the center has been directing volunteers since it started in 1949. A $999,800 agreement between the county and the center is sponsored mostly with Federal funds with 38 percent coming from the state and the county. 
 Bill Straubinger, the center's president and director for the last 16 years, said: "We were chosen because we have expertise in placing people in community service. The program's recipients will acquire the job skills they need and solid work experience. The agencies and organizations will receive about 20 hours of service from each worker. Our goal is eventually to move the people from community service to private-sector jobs." The center also works with about 60 corporations.
The 1996 welfare law requires that the county have 25 percent of its recipients of the Temporary Assistance to Needy Families program in work or work-related activity by the end of this year. The number increases to 30 percent by the end of 1998 and to 50 percent by 2002.
Programs helping people to go from welfare to work have already had an impact on about 300 individuals working in community service or county government. "I was about to give up hope," said Robert Baker of Greenburgh, now a cook at the Whitney Young Head Start program in Yonkers. He learned cooking in the Army, then worked at Howard Johnson's and the Ground Round. When he lost his last job, he received unemployment benefits, then went on public assistance. But he got a job through a program called Pride in Work, tailored to able-bodied people on home relief. "The work's rewarding and it gives me independence," he said. He works five days a week, eight hours a day and said, "It would be a great thing to have more people in that type of program."
Brenda Williams of Yonkers, a teacher's aide at St. Peter's Child Care Center in Yonkers, said she, too, started on public assistance. She would have lost her benefits if she had not gone into Pride in Work, which led to her job at the center. "They hired me, and they're sending me to school to get certified," she said. "I don't have to pay anything for school, and I'll be able to get a job elsewhere with my qualifications and experience. You really can't beat this."
The project director for the volunteer center's new program, Pat Tomassi, is on the board of the Volunteer Center. She previously worked for AT&T as manager of public relations for Westchester and Long Island. "My background is in linking the nonprofit and corporate sectors," she said. "I see this program as a challenge to get people on welfare back on their feet, to make them feel motivated and develop their sense of self-worth."
Besides the project director, other new positions being added to the center's staff include a supervisor at the Regional Job Center planned for Mount Vernon, two work-experience coordinators and part-time job coaches. Mr. Straubinger also said he hopes to get "a lot of volunteers -- 50 or 60 -- to adopt a family and call once a week to ask, 'How are you doing?' "
Recipients of Temporary Assistance to Needy Families will first be summoned to the Department of Social Services to determine their eligibility for the work program. People who are incapacitated and cannot work and people who take care of a child under 1 year old or a disabled child or adult are among those who will not be referred to the program. The eligible recipients will be placed according to their needs in job training, job search or directly into community service work.
The percentage of recipients who must be involved in work or job training is substantially higher than it used to be, said Dennis Packard, assistant commissioner of the Department of Social Services' Office of Benefits Issuance. It includes people who have not worked after receiving benefits for two years. In addition, there is a five-year lifetime limit for federally financed benefits. Information about the volunteer center's work-experience program can be obtained by calling 948-4452.

HEADLINE: $400,000 Median Price Sets County Record

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
CONSUMER demand during the third quarter of the year drove the median sale price of a single family house beyond the $400,000 mark for the first time since the Westchester County Board of Realtors began collecting data in 1981.
There were also more closings of residential real estate sales in Westchester in July, August and September than in any quarter measured by the Board of Realtors, with realtor member offices reporting a total of 2,712 sales, a 5 percent increase over the same quarter last year. 
Single-family houses, cooperatives and two-unit to five-unit multiple-family houses all set sales records. Only condominiums fell short of a record, nevertheless making the second best showing since 1981. Much of the increase in single-family houses was because of the activity in properties selling for $1 million or more. There were 73 such sales in the third quarter compared with the average quarterly count of 20 to 30 properties.
An extraordinarily high rate of co-op sales, 334 reported closings, were the most for any prior quarter, resulting in the first substantial dent in the co-op inventory since the early 1990's. Third-quarter closings result from marketing and sales activity that take place in late spring and early summer. A major factor during that period was the continuing decline of mortgage interest rates from their peak in March and April. Average rates in the New York City area on 30-year conventional mortgages fell below the 8 percent level in late May and dropped to 7.5 percent by late July. PENNY SINGER

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Construction Bustles at an Old Hospital's Grounds

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

DATELINE: CENTRAL ISLIP

 BODY:
SIGNS of new construction are everywhere on the grounds of what once was the Central Islip Psychiatric Center, with industrial space, housing and a $212 million Federal building and courthouse all under way.
The 100-year-old hospital, which occupied 684 acres along Carleton Avenue north of the Southern State Parkway, phased out its operation over several years, shutting down its remaining space last December. 
 "There was a little bit of a delay because of the recent recession, but over the past two years implementation of our master plan is going incredibly well and is fascinating to watch," said Thomas A. Isles, planning director for the Town of Islip, which adopted a master plan for the property in 1989. "Over half a billion dollars of public and private investment has already come in."
The New York Institute of Technology, whose main campus is in Old Westbury, led the way for the revitalization of the hospital property by purchasing 546 of its 684 acres over a four-year period ending in 1986, paying New York State $5.5 million.
The institute has since refurbished many of the former hospital buildings on the east side of Carleton Avenue as classrooms and dormitories, spending an additional $55 million on renovations. It now has 1,600 students on its 175-acre campus here and has been selling off the balance of its property for uses dictated by the town's master plan. It has also donated 85 acres, including a nine-hole golf course, to the town for recreational purposes and 57 acres to Suffolk County for a courthouse and office center. An additional 30 acres is owned by the town.
"The promise of Central Islip as we envisioned it is coming to fruition and it's extraordinary to see it," said Matthew Schure, the president of the institute. The college agreed to purchase the hospital property after several other educational institutions rejected the town's proposal to convert the grounds into a college campus.
"When we first came we were in the midst of an empty psychiatric center and the nearby business district was decimated," Dr. Schure said. "Now it's all back. Businesses are moving in, housing is being built, courts are built and more are coming."
The recycling of the hospital can become a model for others to follow, Dr. Schure added. "If others around the country ask, 'What can we do with our empty facilities?', an answer can be found right here in Central Islip," he said.
The main academic areas on the campus here are devoted to architecture, culinary arts, advertising, education and criminal justice. A telecommunications area is to be added next year. The institute is also considering turning a building known as Robbins Hall into a performing-arts center.
Under the town's master plan, 125 of the 564 acres purchased by the college can be developed for industrial and retail space and 68 acres for housing. The 495,000-square-foot John P. Cohalan Jr. Center, a courthouse and county agency complex, was completed in 1992. And an 822,000-square-foot Federal building and courthouse now under construction on 29 acres -- 22 donated by the county and 7 bought from the college -- is to be completed in 1999.
The industrial-retail park, which under the zoning can contain up to 1.3 million square feet, is part of a one-square-mile Economic Development Zone designated in 1987 and scheduled to expire in 2004.
Within the zone -- which does not include the college or the courthouse complex, but does include some of downtown Central Islip south of the Long Island Rail Road tracks -- businesses reap substantial property tax benefits and a 46 percent reduction in power rates, among other advantages.
UNDER the property-tax abatement within the zone, only land, not improvements are taxed for the first seven years and full taxes on improvements are not levied until the 11th year following completion. Tax abatements on improvements are also available to homeowners. Manufacturers also get a 10 percent state tax credit on their investment in land, buildings and equipment.
The New York Institute of Technology still has 11 acres for sale within the industrial park at $250,000 an acre. And the town is considering extending the Economic Development Zone to include 20 adjoining acres it owns so that it, too, can be developed for industrial purposes. "We have gone from zero jobs in the park in 1992 to 1,200 jobs and expect to be up to 1,500 jobs in a year or two," said William G. Mannix, Islip's director of economic development.
The first business to move into the park, Creative Bath, a manufacturer of decorative bathroom products, arrived there in 1992 and is currently adding an 180,000-square-foot building to the 300,000 square feet of space that it occupies. The company has 640 employees and expects to hire 100 more when the new building is completed in December, said its president, Mat Meinzinger.
Mr. Meinzinger said he was now considering purchasing some of the land zoned for offices "because with the courts coming in there is a need for office space."
Other occupants of the park include the Dimac Marketing Corporation, a mail-order business, which moved into its 245,000- square-foot building last month; Cintas, a uniform manufacturer that moved into 55,000 square feet last month, and J.M.R. Graphics, a printing company, which moved into 12,000 square feet in 1993.
The residences being built on 68 acres include Park Row, a town-house development on 61 acres on the east side of Carleton Avenue that will eventually include 487 two- and three-bedroom units, with current prices ranging from $142,990 to $189,990. All but 120 of the houses are sold. The original developer was the Parr Development Company of Ronkonkoma, but the project is now owned by Pacific Bay Homes of Newport Beach, Calif.
Opening in March on 7.2 acres on the west side of Carleton is Bishop McGann Village, a 125-unit rental project for low-income elderly tenants being built by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre. The two- and three-story buildings will contain one-bedroom apartments for which households making no more than $24,000 are eligible.
The apartments have all been allocated to winners of a lottery held in August. Occupants will pay no more than 30 percent of their income for rent, with the balance to be paid out of Federal subsidies.
THE John P. Cohalan Jr. Center, where 750 people work, includes State Supreme Court, District and Family courtrooms, along with offices of the county attorney and other county agencies.
The new Federal building designed by Richard Meier and Partners of Manhattan and the Spector Group of North Hills is expected to employ 1,300 people. It will initially contain 23 courtrooms and offices for various federal agencies, with an expansion to 39 courtrooms planned for the future.
In addition, Touro College, of Manhattan, will be building a new law school next to the court complex. Gov. George E. Pataki recently signed legislation enabling Touro to purchase 18 acres owned by New York State. A preliminary design for the $25-million building, on which construction is expected to start next year, has already been developed by the Spector Group.
Retail and office development is expected to follow once the other pieces of the master plan are more or less in place, said Mr. Isles, the Town Planner. The 27 acres zoned for those uses can contain up to 130,000 square feet of retail space, 50,000 square feet of offices and a hotel with up to 300 rooms.
Still indefinite are plans for the buildings and the roughly 100 acres still owned by New York State. Among ideas being explored is recycling some of the 781,000 square feet of structures for housing or for additional educational purposes. Suggestions for the vacant land include construction of a minor league ballpark.
"It's all very exciting, and so much is happening, but unfortunately real estate brokers and investors still don't have a good image of Central Islip," said Nancy Manfredonia, executive director of the Central Islip Civic Council, a local civic group. "Our major problem has been getting the word out about this amazing half-a-billion-dollar investment in our community."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Stalled Shopping Center Starts Up in Piscataway

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY

 BODY:
STALLED by three years of litigation, a project has begun to turn 50 wooded acres in the center of this Middlesex County community into a 421,000-square-foot shopping center.
Centennial Square will take shape over the next 18 months on the former industrially zoned tract, which is at Stelton Road and South Washington Avenue and backs up to Interstate 287. Garden Homes Commercial, a division of Garden Homes, both based in Short Hills, took over the project last September two months after a suit challenging its approvals and the site's rezoning was resolved. The earlier developer chose not to proceed with the project. 
 The project will be the largest retail development and the first in nearly eight years in the township, said Anne M. Gordon, Piscataway's public information officer. Its significance to the township is that it will bring in jobs and help keep the community's tax base balanced, she said.
While a spate of high-density housing went up within Piscataway's 20 square miles over the last decade, corporate downsizing left much of its office space empty. Commercial tax appeals also took a toll in the township, which is now undergoing a resurgence, said Ms. Gordon.
She noted that the developer of Centennial Square would also build the long-awaited final 2,200-foot stretch of Centennial Avenue, which runs in front of of the site. It will complete a road project that began 40 years ago.
Centennial Square is proceeding at a time when the state's retail market, helped by an improving economy, is healthy, retail brokers said. They said that while some national retailers continue to file for bankruptcy -- including Rickels, the home-improvement chain -- others are expanding in the state or entering it.
At the same time, space left dark in centers in less than prime areas is being reconfigured for new users. As a result the retail vacancy rate for the north and central parts of the state is 7.5 percent, down slightly from the same time last year, according to the Schultz Brokerage Services group in Woodbridge.
"New Jersey is a targeted growth area for national companies and the reason is demographics," said Jonathan B. Schultz, president of the brokerage. "They are all fighting each other and the stronger well-capitalized public companies that need to expand to increase their market share are replacing weaker ones."
"Big box" retailers like Target, the discount department store chain, and Lowe's, a home-improvement chain, are among the new arrivals. Meanwhile, Wal-Mart continues to open new stores in the state.
Lowe's is making its first foray into the state with a 114,700-square-foot store, plus a 30,000-square-foot garden shop, at Centennial Square, which is being designed as a "power center." The International Council of Shopping Centers, based in Manhattan, defines such centers as an open-air retail strip with 250,000 to 750,000 square feet of space and three or more large specialty stores, also known as "category killers."
Another anchor tenant at the center will be Wal-Mart, which will open a 134,843-square-foot store. Sports Authority and Office Max have also committed to take 43,000 and 23,000 square feet, respectively, said Scott T. Loventhal, a vice president at Garden Homes Commercial. Financing for the $45-million project is coming from the company's own equity and a $30-million construction loan from Fleet Bank.
NATIONALLY, such shopping centers with three or more large stores and outdoor parking are growing, but not as rapidly as in the past, due in part to the consolidations and mergers of some national retailers, said Mark Schoifet, a spokesman for the Shopping Center Council. Last year 54 such power centers were built or started, compared to 75 the year before, according to Mr. Schoifet's group.
But in New Jersey, said Richard J. Brunelli, who heads a retail brokerage firm bearing his name in Old Bridge: "category killers are driving the construction of power centers in the state."
Within a 15-mile radius of the Piscataway project, for example, plans are being advanced for six other power centers, ranging in size from 200,000 to 750,000 square feet, Mr. Schultz said. Tough approval processes combined with the scarcity of properly zoned sites will temper the pace of new projects, he said, and Mr. Brunelli agreed.
The absence of those factors as issues at the Centennial Square project was among the reasons Garden Homes Commercial moved ahead, said Mr. Loventhal. "It is an opportunity to seize in a strong retail market," he said.
The concept of the power center also made sense, he added, "because what consumers look for today is price and convenience and these big-box retailers provide both."
The township rezoned the site at the start if this decade. And in 1994 it granted approvals to the earlier developer, the Gibraltar Development Corporation of Clearwater, Fla.
But the start of the project was stalled by a lawsuit was filed in Superior Court in Middlesex County by two nearby shopping center owners and a retailer, all in neighboring South Plainfield. Their suit contended, among other things, that in granting its approvals Piscataway's Planning Board did not adequately consider the traffic impact from the Centennial Square project.
After three years of litigation the court decided in favor of Piscataway and Gibraltar. Before the court's decision, a settlement had been reached with the retailer, a supermarket owner. Ultimately, however, Gibraltar decided not to develop the site.
When Garden Homes Commercial acquired the site it agreed, as part of the original approvals, to complete the final section of Centennial Avenue, which Mr. Loventhal said "will reduce congestion in the area." The new section will have four lanes, divided by a median, and two traffic lights.
He said that even though the site was between two regional shopping hubs -- the Bridgewater Commons Mall in Bridgewater and the Woodbridge Center in Woodbridge -- the demographics in the immediate area could support more retail activity. Some 300,000 people with an average household income of $58,000 live within a five-mile radius of the site, it is close to the Piscataway campus of Rutgers University and 155,000 cars pass the site each day, Mr. Loventhal said.
The demographics also appealed to Lowe's, which started its expansion into the New York metropolitan area last year.
"There is a tremendous amount of do-it-yourselfers and not a lot of alternatives for consumers," Clarissa S. Felts, a spokeswoman for Lowe's, said of her company's move into the area in general and to Piscataway in particular. The company, based in North Wilkesboro, N.C., is considered a competitor to Home Depot, which has a store a mile from Centennial Square.
Mr. Brunelli, the broker, said Centennial Square "should work" because it will provide convenient shopping to local consumers.
The project, designed by Silverstein Buckman, architects of North Brunswick, will comprise a group of six one-story buildings, instead of one L-shaped interconnecting strip of stores, spread over the irregularly shaped site. In addition to the four anchors there also will be some 20 smaller shops, of 3,000 to 7,000 square feet on average, Mr. Loventhal said.
Rents are to be $15 to $25 a square foot, he added, noting that the first stores are expected to open by Christmas of 1998, with the entire project set for completion the following spring.
