HEADLINE: Attack of the 90-Foot Teen-Agers

BYLINE: By LINDA LEE 

 BODY:
THIS is a quiz: Gavin, Leonardo and Claire, J. T. T; extra points if you can name all five Spice Girls; extra, extra points if you know Buffy the Vampire Slayer's last name.
If the answers come immediately to mind: Rossdale, the lead singer of Bush; two movie stars, DiCaprio and Danes; Jonathan Taylor Thomas from "Home Improvement," and Emma, Victoria, Mel C, Mel B and Geri, then there is no doubt you are very clued in, or under 17. (If you know that Buffy's last name is Summers, you've been watching too much WB.) 
 Just three or four years ago, pop music was dominated by angry rappers, and movies all starred some familiar 30-something face on the cusp of making $20 million per. Now, an epochal change seems to be taking place. A long-anticipated younger generation has taken control of the stick shift of pop culture (and with a full tank of gas; thanks, Mom and Dad!). Before you can say "MMMbop," they have shifted toward a blend of the 1950's and the millennium, with bright pop songs, interchangeable teen-age heartthrob stars and mindless yet ironic movies like "Starship Troopers," about giant bugs, and movies like "Scream," about slashers in the closet.
The most popular film in America for the last month has been "I Know What You Did Last Summer," a campy horror picture aimed at 15-to-20-year-olds that stars a new crop of heartthrobs, like Ryan Phillippe and Jennifer Love Hewitt. Angst-free, chart-topping pop by Hanson, the Backstreet Boys and the Spice Girls -- whose second album, "Spice World," was just released -- is back with a vengeance. Television shows like "Party of Five" and "Buffy" are stamping out legions of barely postpubescent actors.
Douglas Coupland, who labeled his age group with his 1991 book "Generation X," said he has noticed the proliferation of "all these seemingly modular kid units flattening out the media-scape."
"At the core of pop culture these days we find Mentos, Goosebumps and Hanson," he went on. "And that's fine. The kids have got their own thing going. Good. 'The edge' is over. Adults can stop wearing leather jackets now."
Although young idols come and go with each generation -- remember New Kids on the Block? David Cassidy? Fabian? -- what is notable about the newest wave is that idoldom itself has moved front and center in the culture, in a way not seen since the youthquake triggered by the baby boom in the 50's and 60's. That is no surprise, given that today's teen-agers are the boomers' children.
They are variously known as the echo boom (born after 1982, under the sign of Baby on Board), the baby boomlet or Generation Y. Why not just call them the Tamagotchi Generation? They like things technological and cute (like the 1995 movie "Babe"); they are open to the global marketplace and insist on their right to irony. And unlike the electronic pets called Tamagotchis, the Tamagotcheratis will never die as long as marketing people are willing to push their buttons.
"We've already seen the impact of the baby boomlet in recent years, with the phenomenal success of things like Power Rangers or Beanie Babies or Tamagotchis, where savvy marketers have been able to build billion-dollar businesses based on the baby boomlet through their kids' years," said Richard Leonard, a vice president of the Zandl Group in New York, which does market research on young people. "Now that they are teens, there are future opportunities."
School enrollment in America last year broke the record levels previously reached in 1972. This year, 52.2 million children are in school; high schools and junior high schools are overflowing.
In the early 90's, fan magazines for teen-agers like Tiger Beat went into a circulation slump, but the genre has bounced back, and new titles, like Twist and Jump, are springing up. In February, People will spin off Teen People.
"Right now, the teen market is exploding," said Lisa Lombardi, the editor in chief of Twist, whose second issue is on newsstands now. "There are going to be more teens in the next 10 years than in the last 25. And teen-age girls have a lot of disposable income."
Although both boys and girls buy movie tickets and CD's, teen-age magazines are read almost exclusively by girls. Boys may drool over Daisy Fuentes dressed in hip-huggers on MTV's "Singled Out," but they don't care about her favorite color. The hunger for such personal trivia, the province of the magazines, is mostly a craving of girls.
Antonia Pocock, 12, a seventh grader at Hunter High School in Manhattan, reads Seventeen, YM, Teen, Top Model and Mademoiselle. She knows who Mr. Phillippe is. "He's cute and a good actor," she said. And thanks to her magazines, she knows he is going to be in a movie next year called "Studio 54." She added helpfully, "It's about a club."
Three thousand miles away, and three years older, some media skepticism creeps in. Vanessa Silverton Peel, a 15-year-old in the ninth grade at the Oakwood School in Los Angeles, said: "The idea of what teen magazines are into is so far off. Every other word is 'babe.' The headlines are '101 Ways to Tell if He Likes You.' Not very often is there an article on preparing for the S.A.T.'s or something you would actually need. Their celebrities don't extend beyond Jared Leto and Jonathan Taylor Thomas, all the teen-age kids who are in bad sitcoms."
Still, she, too, is a fan of Mr. DiCaprio, the gold standard of heartthrobdom these days, whose new film, "Titanic," opens next month. She also watches "Sabrina, the Teen-Age Witch" on television and listens to Tori Amos, Jewel and Fiona Apple.
Ms. Pocock and Ms. Peel may be members of an emerging new mass audience. Remember the complaint that pop music was too fragmented? That was before rap turned softer and Hanson, the Spice Girls and Aqua, who had an out-of-nowhere hit with "Barbie Girl," arrived.
"Pop music is back," said Carmen Cacciatore, the East Coast senior director of artists and repertory for MCA, who signed Aqua for distribution in April. "Kids are getting upbeat, quirky, fun music coming through the radio."
Right now, the cycle is feel-good pop that dwells on perennial subjects like "Quit Playing Games (With My Heart)," from the Backstreet Boys; though at its strongest it takes on issues like being raped at 12, by Fiona Apple, who is 20.
"The music now is in contrast to Nirvana or grunge, all the Angst-driven stuff," said John McDaniel, 28, the music director of KNHC, a radio station that is part of the Seattle public school system. "A lot of the music now doesn't have a negative energy. It's fluffy. It seems more a lighter note."
Why no Angst, the staple of many earlier teen-agers' tunes? In their book "Generations" (1991), William Strauss and Neil Howe predicted that the generation born after 1982 would develop a wholesome, upbeat pop culture, partly because of their parents' reactions to the cynical pop embraced by Generation X. The new generation, Mr. Howe said, "is being taught to be good citizens, not to think too deeply about the issues."
Roger Rosenblatt, an essayist for Time magazine and "The News Hour With Jim Lehrer," sees it this way: "This generation doesn't have a war. The economy is good. They have drugs a bit, but it's not attached to anything important. They have no political agenda. They have created pop culture lite. The vacuity of this generation, its manifestation, or the parody of it as in 'Scream,' may all be a result of these young people wanting less."
The Tamagotchi generation -- for whom a serious crisis is "The cable's out!" -- clamors for hoots like "Scream," or the media-savvy cool of movies like "Clueless," the 1995 film that may mark the first expression of this cohort's buying power, or this year's "Men in Black," a knowing send-up of science fiction.
Music and movies are where new stars can zoom fastest into youth consciousness, but the new cable channels are creating teen-age stars, too. There are innumerable shows on WB, Fox and UPN (networks most people over 40 can't even find) that star inexpensive unknowns, this generation's Mouseketeers, in shows like "Party of Five." WB alone has "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," "Sister, Sister" and "Smart Guy," and in January will have "Dawson's Creek," already being hailed as the next "My So-Called Life," the show about high-school life that gave Ms. Danes her start. She has gone on to movies ("Romeo and Juliet") and awards shows (the VH1 Fashion Awards).
Bari Nan Cohen, the 24-year-old entertainment editor of YM magazine, who has seen the pilot episode of "Dawson's Creek" on tape, said: "I'm nuts about this show. It talks about the experience of being a teen-ager in high school in the most honest and direct way." Perhaps not coincidentally, "Dawson's Creek," which deals with issues like masturbation and romances with high school teachers, was written by Kevin Williamson, 32, who seems to be at the epicenter of the new culture. He also wrote "Scream" and "Scream 2," opening next month, and "I Know What You Did Last Summer."
Do baby boomers and Gen X'ers care about the teen-age idols? Yes, if the next Tom Cruise is among them. No, if Harrison Ford and Robert Redford will just keep making movies, and if Bob Marley's albums will continue to be released in new formats.
Paul Verhoeven is the director of "Starship Troopers," which opened on Friday and stars a new generation of potential idols, like Casper Van Dien. Mr. Verhoeven sat in a midtown restaurant in Manhattan recently and read down a list of 40 names of hot young stars, like Matt Damon, Brendan Sexton 3d, Melissa Joan Hart and Jared Leto.
"I only know 10 percent of those names," said the director, who admits that his two daughters, 23 and 25, have to clue him in on pop culture. His own film, he said, did not rely on stars. "Giant insects, that's the sell," he said.
But teen-age magazines put out 12 issues a year. Someone has to be on the cover, and it probably won't be a giant insect.

HEADLINE: September Tool Orders Set High for Year So Far

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Domestic orders for machine tools rose 13.4 percent in September from the month before as manufacturers purchased more tools than in any month this year, an industry survey said.
Orders from American companies for machine tools produced in this country and abroad rose to an estimated $710 million in September from a revised estimate of $626 million in August, the Association for Manufacturing Technology and the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association reported. 
 Actual machine tool orders by American manufacturers, which are used to calculate the broader estimates, totaled 4,218 units in September, rising 13.4 percent to $525.30 million from a revised $463.25 million in August, the industry groups said.
The numbers indicate "continued and broad confidence in all sectors of our economy," Ralph J. Nappi, president of the machine tool association, said.
Machine tools are used to shape and assemble metal in products ranging from diesel engines to dishwashers. Analysts watch tool orders to gauge industrial output, consumer demand and business investment.
September's estimate pushed orders for the first nine months of this year to $6.1 billion. That is 12.6 percent higher than in the corresponding period a year earlier. Estimated orders for September were 8.2 percent below the $773 million estimated for September 1996.
The two industry groups originally estimated that August orders had risen 10.2 percent to $703 million.
September's gain was the third increase in five months, and in part reflected increased orders by small and medium-sized manufacturers, the association said.
Tool makers expect sales to rise the rest of this year and in 1998.

HEADLINE: Poor Workers Turning Down Employers' Health Benefits

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
More Americans than ever are being offered health insurance through their jobs. Even so, a Government study finds, more and more workers, especially those who earn low wages, are declining to take the benefit.
The study, to be published on Monday in the journal Health Affairs, challenges assumptions that for the most part the 41 million Americans who are uninsured lack coverage because their employers do not offer it. 
 The study says that in the decade from 1987 to 1996, the percentage of all workers offered insurance grew to 75.4 percent from 72.4 percent but that the percentage of all workers holding it slipped to 60.4 percent from 63.9 percent.
That the number of uninsured Americans remains stubbornly high in spite of a robust economy poses a troublesome and costly challenge for Congress and the Clinton Administration.
The uninsured turn to charity for care or to Medicaid, the Federal-state insurance program for the poor and disabled. Just to try to cover half the nation's 10 million uninsured children, Congress and the White House have agreed to spend $24 billion over five years.
The new study "brings up a new dimension of the debate," said Paul R. Ginsburg, president of the Center for Health System Change, a research group in Washington. "The focus used to be, 'Why don't more firms offer insurance?' Now when we talk about the higher cost of health insurance, we also have to worry about the decisions of employees."
Barbara Steinberg Schone, an author of the study, said: "It's not enough to make sure there's access. We have to get workers to take up the coverage that's offered, and if they're not taking it up, we have to understand why they're not."
Ms. Schone and her co-author, Philip F. Cooper, economists at the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research in the Department of Health and Human Services, attributed workers' reluctance to buy insurance in part to their difficulty in paying their share of the premium.
They note that health insurance premiums leaped 90 percent from 1987 to 1993 while wages for all workers rose 28 percent and stagnated for the lowest-paid workers. The increase in health care costs has slowed sharply since, but wages, especially of the lowest-paid workers, have continued to lag.
As a result, Mr. Cooper and Ms. Schone report, 75.8 percent of workers earning $7 or less an hour signed up for insurance through their own job or a family member's last year, compared with 89.4 percent a decade ago.
They found a similar decline for workers younger than 25 and less acute declines for black and Hispanic workers -- all groups that earn less, on average, than adult white men. The study found no significant change in levels of insurance coverage among workers who are 55 or older or those earning more than $10 an hour: about 90 percent of those workers are covered.
Twenty years ago, said Paul Fronstin, a research associate at the Employee Benefit Research Institute here, workers merely signed up for insurance. Employers who offered it paid the full cost.
Typically today, he said, a worker contributes $1,596 a year for subsidized family coverage by a health maintenance organization, or $396 to insure only himself. For someone making $7 an hour, the contribution for the family policy is 11 percent of the worker's total wages.
"Some don't want to pay for it," Mr. Fronstin said. "Some can't afford it."

HEADLINE: His Congress Says No, No, Zedillo

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 9

 BODY:
President Ernesto Zedillo, who likes to take credit for steering Mexico through a democratic transition, is learning the virtues of patience as he deals with a Congress that fell under opposition control in July for the first time in seven decades.
Mr. Zedillo adopted a long-suffering look earlier this fall when an opposition lawmaker, responding to the President's state of the union message, told him bluntly on national television, "Every one of us is equal to you." 
 Now Mr. Zedillo has a new headache: getting foreign travel plans approved. The 1917 Constitution, reflecting a legal tradition dating back to when a similar restriction was placed on Spanish monarchs, bars the President from leaving Mexico without congressional authorization. But no modern President has faced problems getting rubber-stamp approval.
Last week, however, Congress exerted its authority on this matter, too. Mr. Zedillo sent a single request to Congress to make four presidential trips. After considerable debate, the Congress voted a green light for him to travel to Venezuela for a summit meeting of Latin American presidents over the weekend and to the United States, where he is to meet President Clinton on Friday.
But lawmakers rejected Mr. Zedillo's request to travel to an economic summit meeting in Vancouver, Canada, later this month and to Nicaragua in December.
The Congress said it would reconsider the rejected requests if Mr. Zedillo provides more information.

HEADLINE: Newly Elected Opposition to Fight Zedillo's Budget

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 9

 BODY:
President Ernesto Zedillo could face the greatest political test of his presidency starting this week as opposition lawmakers, in control of Congress for the first time in recent history, try to challenge his economic policies by rewriting Mexico's 1998 budget.
The $100 billion budget that Mr. Zedillo is to present to Congress on Tuesday would continue the tight-money, export-oriented policies that have helped nurse Mexico's economy to recovery after its near-collapse three years ago. 
 But lawmakers in the lower house of Congress, which the Constitution empowers to "review and approve" the budget, have said they intend to make sweeping changes.
They want to raise the salaries of Mexico's 2.5 million public employees, sharply increase money for schools, hospitals and farm support programs, triple federal revenues shared with the country's 2,400 towns and 31 states and finance a relief program for millions of Mexicans swamped by debt. At the same time, the opposition lawmakers say they intend to cut taxes.
The stakes for the United States are large any time basic economic policies are debated here. Mexico is America's third largest trading partner, after Canada and Japan, and hundreds of thousands of workers cross into the United States when production slows at Mexico's factories and farms.
In recent days, Mr. Zedillo has attacked the opposition's proposals as unrealistic "populism." Government economists have warned that since tax revenues have plummeted in the three years since a 1994 devaluation of the peso, the Government cannot increase spending much without creating huge budget deficits.
But opposition leaders say they are determined to reorder Government priorities after years of austerity during which Mexico's minimum wage has plunged to $3 a day and classrooms and hospital emergency rooms have crumbled into disrepair.
"We intend to make deep corrections in this budget," said Rogelio Sada Zambrano, economic affairs coordinator in the lower house for the National Action Party, known by the acronym PAN, known for its pro-business views. "We intend to confront the enormous deterioration in Mexicans' quality of life, and the vast breach between the haves and the have-nots."
The challenge to Mr. Zedillo may come as a surprise to Wall Street. After the opposition victory in the July 6 elections, several financial analysts and newsletters predicted, incorrectly, that the President could easily protect his economic policies by renewing the Government's informal alliance with the PAN, which has supported free-market reforms under both Mr. Zedillo and his predecessor, Carlos Salinas de Gortari.
But so far the PAN has instead allied itself with the three other opposition parties in a bloc known as the Group of Four. Together, the opposition parties won 262 of the 500 seats in the lower house. Mr. Zedillo's Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, has 238 seats.
How long the opposition alliance will last is unclear. The roots of the largest opposition parties, the PAN and the Party of the Democratic Revolution, or P.R.D., reach back into a history of ideological enmity.
Manuel Gomez Morin, who helped found the PAN in 1939 during the presidency of Lazaro Cardenas, who nationalized Mexico's oil fields, was a fierce critic of Mr. Cardenas's view that government should play a central role in the economy. The P.R.D. was founded in 1987 by Mr. Cardenas's son, Cuauhtemoc, and others to give new expression to Lazaro Cardenas's ideas.
But many of the PAN's 121 newly elected congressmen are ranchers, small-town professionals or presidents of business groups, elected by farmers angry with Mr. Zedillo's economic policies because they cannot get agricultural credit or by homeowners drowning in mortgage debt.
Aides to Mr. Zedillo have expressed surprise at the strong views among many PAN deputies.
"We're seeing a lot more populism in the PAN than we expected," a senior Government official said. "Many deputies are real zealots."
The opposition parties have failed so far to reach formal agreement on any common statement of budget priorities. But their congressional leaders speak in similar terms about raising spending, lowering taxes and using the budget process to change Mr. Zedillo's economic policies.
"We intend to make changes that will allow us to use the budget as a fundamental factor in national development, strengthening the internal market, better distributing national income, and increasing salaries," said Ricardo Garcia Sainz, the P.R.D. chairman of the lower house's powerful budget committee.
The opposition parties also share a commitment to work together to attack the Zedillo Administration's bailouts of the financial and highway systems, which have channeled billions of dollars to Mexico's biggest banks and construction companies.
How do they intend to pay for all the new spending? Several opposition lawmakers said they expected that vast savings could be found by eliminating secret budgets used by PRI governments for supplementary salaries, unnecessary spending on travel and other items they see as waste. They have proposed in talks with Treasury officials that 3 of 14 ministries be eliminated.
Perhaps the most popular idea among all the opposition parties is to cut taxes, especially the value added tax, which Mr. Zedillo and PRI lawmakers increased during the 1995 financial crisis.
Voicing an argument made by Republicans in the Reagan Administration, Mr. Garcia Sainz, Mr. Sada and other opposition politicians have asserted recently that reducing the tax, which has suppressed consumption by increasing prices, could actually result in increased tax revenues.
But a study by officials in the Tax Administration Service, the Mexican equivalent of the Internal Revenue Service, concluded that reducing the value added tax from 15 to 10 percent, as the opposition has advocated, would cost the Treasury about $3 billion a year. Eliminating the three ministries, the study found, would save only about $360 million.
Jorge A. Chavez Presa, the Treasury Under Secretary who has been holding talks with the Congress, complained that opposition lawmakers "don't understand the word 'tradeoff,' the idea that if you gain something it will cost you something."
"They say to us, 'Lower the taxes, and I also want you to increase the spending,' " Mr. Chavez said. "They want lemon sherbet, watermelon sherbet, raspberry sherbet. We say, 'But you can only have one.' They say, 'No, I want all three.' "
The opposition leaders shrug off the criticism.
"We're entering a new era in which the executive isn't going to impose laws on us," said Porfirio Munoz Ledo, the P.R.D. leader in Congress. "We're going to change the economic model."
"When the Government gives resources to the poor, everybody condemns it as populism," he said. "But when they transfer Government funds to the rich, what's that called? Rich-ism?"

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Reading the Landscape of the New West

BYLINE: By VERLYN KLINKENBORG 

 BODY:
Between Casper, Wyo., and Denver, Colo., Interstate 25 bends through several landscapes, each distinctively Western. Some are agricultural, like the plowed ground near Wheatland, Wyo. Others, like the stretch south of Douglas, Wyo., have the wide-open look of high grassland rising into rimrock and pines. Whenever I drive this road, I'm struck by the forgotten complexity of a terrain I thought I knew well. Each new vista seems to offer something surprising -- an enormous power plant set in a Frederic Remington landscape, a trio of 55-gallon drums laid out in a dry riverbed by a die-hard barrel racer or, most surprising of all, the spareness that is still this region's most characteristic feature.
Near the Colorado border, I-25 crosses I-80. The country looks the same south of that landmark, but everything else has changed. The volume of traffic swells. I-25 becomes a spillway of vehicles sluicing toward Denver and Colorado Springs. Even the look of the traffic changes, becoming less and less rural and more and more Californian -- fewer rusting stock trailers and more BMW's. Housing developments begin to march across the horizon. The foreground becomes a blur of commercial real estate signs. Downtown Denver is still an hour away. 
 A shift has been taking place all across the interior West, a region that has grown faster than the rest of the country for most of this decade. The changes are as much a matter of sensibility as they are of demographics -- the emergence of a New West out of what has been, for some time now, not quite the West of old. I can savor the difference by driving from Dixon, N.M., to Santa Fe or from Three Forks, Mont., to Bozeman. It surfaces when I buy an espresso in Sheridan, Wyo. -- a state where the coffee used to be as weak as the politics is strong -- or check my E-mail from a truck stop that also sells replacement parts for cattle prods. The pattern of these changes, palpable to anyone who lives in or merely loves the West, have now been captured in a new study released by the Center of the American West at the University of Colorado. It is called "Atlas of the New West" and published by W. W. Norton.
What this atlas portrays are the cultural, economic and social dimensions of a major population shift whose meaning is just beginning to be understood. Its causes are at once obvious and yet so elusive that William Riebsame, the atlas's general editor, writes, "The West's current boom . . . seems different than past migrations and is difficult to characterize." There is no shortage of easy explanations, the kind I hear at feed stores and fly-fishing shops alike. "Californians," some people say. "Easterners,"' say others. Everyone else blames retirees or snowboarders. They are all correct.
The American West has geographical borders, of course, but its real borders are mythological. Their erosion brings with it a real uneasiness, even if the myth of the West -- that paradise for the self-reliant -- was never really accurate. I always took it for granted that the West's economy rested on mining and ranching. But in the New West, "Less than 1 percent of employment . . . is supported by mining, and only .06 percent of jobs are associated with ranching," the atlas reports. One way to glimpse the West is to count, as this atlas does, the number of professional rodeos. But an altogether different picture emerges if you map, as this atlas also does, the airstrips capable of serving private jets or the Orvis franchises and Land Rover dealerships.
What does the West look like if you chart all the Hispanic radio stations and gay newspapers? What if you map all the breweries, microbreweries and home-brew clubs, as well as the places where you can buy The New York Times? What if you map the New Age outposts and cowboy poetry festivals? What if you color in all the land within 10 miles of paved highway? What you get, of course, is a still-frame version of the ambiguity of reality itself, a reality that inspires the people of the New West and at the same time sticks in their craw.

HEADLINE: PENTAGON TO TRIM THOUSANDS OF JOBS HELD BY CIVILIANS

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Under pressure from Congress to reduce the Pentagon's bureaucracy before ordering more cuts in troops or weapons, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen plans to trim thousands of civilian jobs at the Pentagon and transfer thousands more military personnel out of their headquarters and into the field, officials said.
The reductions, which Mr. Cohen and Vice President Al Gore are to announce on Monday, are part of what the officials said would be a sweeping plan to reorganize the Pentagon's bureaucracy, to streamline operations and to otherwise save money that could then be better spent developing new weaponry. 
 As part of the plan, Mr. Cohen will also revive the Clinton Administration's request to hold two more rounds of base closings, in 2001 and 2005. Earlier this year, Congress refused to authorize two new rounds, with lawmakers arguing that the Administration had to do more to save money elsewhere before shutting bases that offer enormous economic benefits to their constituents.
Altogether the plan, called the Defense Reform Initiative, could save as much as $6 billion a year in the Pentagon's budget, which this year totals about $250 billion, according to the officials, who discussed details on the condition of anonymity.
"Looking downstream, we don't have enough money and won't have enough money to pay for the weapons we need," one official said today. "The only way to get more money is to try to squeeze it out of the other parts of the operation."
Much of the plan, particularly the proposal for new rounds of base closings, will require Congressional approval. And that, by no means, is assured.
Senator Strom Thurmond, the South Carolina Republican who is the chairman of the Senate Committee on Armed Services, said today that he would certainly work with Mr. Cohen to reduce the Pentagon's bureaucracy but would not support cuts that "hamper national security." He also said it was "unfortunate" that Mr. Cohen planned to propose more base closings.
"We're just getting over some of the other base closings we've had in the past," Mr. Thurmond said.
Over the next five years, the plan would eliminate 30,000 administrative jobs out of about 140,000. Civilians holding those jobs would be let go, either through attrition or layoffs, while military personnel in those positions would be reassigned to duty elsewhere.
The reductions would cut the Office of the Secretary of Defense by a third over the next 18 months, to 2,000 jobs from 3,000. Over five years they would eliminate 27,000 jobs from the 130,000 at the 13 defense agencies that provide support to the armed services, like the Defense Intelligence Agency and the Defense Finance and Accounting Service.
On the military side, an additional 2,500 jobs would be reassigned from administrative duties. The Office of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and its related staff would be cut by 29 percent, reducing a total of 2,600 jobs to about 1,950 over the next five years. In addition, 10 percent of the 18,000 troops and officers assigned to military headquarters around the nation and the world would be reassigned to combat rather than administrative duties.
Those cuts, one official said, represented "an effort to get more people out of headquarters and into the field."
Mr. Cohen's plan comes six months after he presented the Quadrennial Defense Review, which is supposed to be a strategic blueprint for the military in the 21st century. That review was heavily criticized because it made no dramatic changes in battlefield doctrine and eliminated no weapons programs. It did call for still more cuts in active-duty troops, bringing the total to below 1.4 million, down from 2.1 million at the end of the cold war.
The Defense Secretary ordered up the new plan, the officials said, because he wanted to turn attention to changing the Pentagon's administrative bureaucracy, including civilian and military workers, as well as the support services that many believe are inefficient or duplicative.
It remains to be seen how effectively the cuts will be imposed, since bureaucracies often have a way of resisting them. The officials also acknowledged that the Pentagon has thousands of hidden jobs, which are not part of the administrative budget but financed elsewhere in the Government. Some of those jobs are evidently among the ones slated for elimination.
But in keeping with an overriding mantra of Government these days, a senior Defense official involved in the plan's preparation said it would help the Pentagon operate more like a business. "We are still a 1960's organization operating in the 1990's," the official said.
The plan was assembled by a committee appointed by Mr. Cohen that included executives from private industry. The committee was headed by John J. Hamre, who took over as Deputy Secretary of Defense in July after serving as the department's chief financial officer since 1993.
Beyond eliminating positions, the plan would restructure the Department of Defense itself, creating one new agency to oversee defense security and another to oversee treaty compliance and threat reduction. This move would consolidate agencies and eliminate one of the department's 13 assistant secretaries.
The plan aims to increase reliance on computers, eliminating the use of paper in contracts and financial services by 2000. And it would allow private companies to bid against Government workers to provide services from utilities to payroll.
Mr. Cohen is unveiling these proposals now, the officials said, to get a head start on next year's budget, which the Pentagon and the Administration will prepare in January. After criticism last spring that Mr. Cohen was not doing enough to remake the Pentagon, the officials appeared eager to discuss details of the plan to draw attention to these efforts.
Many of the changes are not likely to generate opposition in Congress, but the base closings, which would eventually make up a third of the $6 billion in annual projected savings, have a dim fate at best.
In the first four rounds -- in 1988, 1991, 1993 and 1995 -- the Pentagon closed or realigned 152 major bases and 235 smaller installations on the recommendation of bipartisan commissions. While some of these bases remain open as they slowly phase out of existence, the closings and loss to the local economy have shaken a lot of towns around the country, not to mention their representatives in Washington.
Mr. Cohen's newest proposal would put off any new closings until after Mr. Clinton leaves office.

HEADLINE: Troubled Economy Stirs Fears in South Korea

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Relaxing on a couch in the basement of the upscale department store he manages, Kwak Yang Seo sat back and mused that because of this country's long economic boom, he has never known anybody who lost a job.
"Yet," he quickly added. 
 Mr. Kwak may soon have the opportunity to broaden the spectrum of his acquaintances. His department store company -- New Core, the 25th-largest conglomerate in South Korea -- entered bankruptcy proceedings a few days ago, and Mr. Kwak may have to start laying people off. Indeed, he may himself be laid off.
"I never expected a big company like this to go bankrupt," Mr. Kwak reflected, shaking his head in bewilderment. And heads like his are shaking all over South Korea as one of the most miraculous of Asia's miracle economies finds itself foundering -- pessimists say sinking -- in a turbulent sea of bankruptcies, bad debts and tight credit.
The South Korean currency fell to a record low today, just as the stock exchange was setting its own record for biggest one-day plunge, with the leading market index dropping 6.9 percent. The stock market has now lost more than half its value in the last two years; a record number of bankruptcies is expected this year, and, most wounding of all, there are growing whispers in international financial circles that South Korea could become "the next Thailand."
Most economists and business executives predict that South Korea will eventually make it to dry land again, perhaps emerging stronger for the experience. But the economic turmoil that swept through Asia was so swift and stunning that some wonder aloud whether South Korea could be the next economy to implode.
"You guess on the basis of past performance that they'll probably muddle through," William H. Overholt, a managing director in Hong Kong for Bankers Trust, said of the South Koreans. "But you wake up late at night and wonder, 'What if they don't?' "
While most experts, particularly those living in South Korea, think that a catastrophe will be averted, there is no doubt that a tumble by South Korea would reverberate around the globe. In contrast to Thailand, which was at the center of the last round of trouble, South Korea is an industrialized economy, the 11th-largest in the world, with $110 billion in foreign debt and industrial giants like Samsung, Daewoo and Hyundai.
Over all, South Korea's economy is two and a half times the size of Thailand's, and its trade is more than twice as great. Western banks are far more extended to South Korean companies than to Thai institutions, and there is also a security dimension: 37,000 American troops are based in South Korea to deter an attack by a North Korean Government that many think is always sniffing for weakness in the South.
Such links make bankers like Mr. Overholt nervous and raise fears of a chain reaction that would topple South Korean banks and set off a global banking and market crisis.
"Problems in Thailand and Indonesia could be the straw that breaks the back of a Korean bank, and a couple of Korean banks going under could be the straw that breaks the back of a Japanese bank, and then it starts to get really interesting," Mr. Overholt said.
Still, no one has ever made money for long betting against South Korea. South Korea's success is legendary, its per capita income rising from $90 in 1961 to more than $10,000 today. South Korea still has tremendous strengths, and for all the talk of recession, the economy this year is still expected to register growth of about 6 percent.
The parallels with Thailand that worry some experts are overextended and overleveraged businesses, mountain ranges of bad debt, weak political leadership, meager foreign currency reserves and a sagging currency that raises the cost of repaying foreign debt. But the experts and South Korean officials alike emphasize that the differences between the two countries are enormous.
"Korea is Korea; Thailand is Thailand," noted Finance Minister Kang Kyong Shik, weary of the comparison. In an interview in his office in the National Assembly, not far from the glittering towers of Seoul's financial district, Mr. Kang argued that South Korea was in far healthier shape than Thailand or some other Southeast Asian countries.
One key difference is that Thailand had enjoyed a huge speculative bubble that simply popped. In contrast, South Korean real estate prices never inflated as they did in Bangkok or Tokyo.
A second is that Thailand and other countries tried to defend a dollar-pegged exchange rate that had become unsustainable. In contrast, the South Korean won is not pegged to any currency and fell 8 percent last year and 15 percent more so far this year against the dollar.
At this exchange rate, South Korea is becoming much more competitive in foreign markets, setting off an export surge that is cutting the current account deficit. Partly because of that surge, there are signs that South Korea is beginning to recover.
So why the sense of crisis?
One fundamental reason is that for decades risk taking has always paid off in South Korea in an economy bouncing along at annual growth rates of 10 percent. Conglomerates -- or chaebol, in Korean -- tended to finance their growth by borrowing rather than by issuing stocks or bonds, so they are highly leveraged.
But at the same time that South Korean companies were building vast factories, they were facing a domestic slowdown and growing competition from imports as the Government gradually lowered trade barriers. In addition, South Korea lost competitiveness in foreign markets against countries like Japan and Mexico, whose currencies fell against the dollar and whose products therefore became cheaper.
So far this year, 7 of the nation's 30 biggest chaebol have sought bankruptcy protection. Those bankruptcies and others have rippled into the banking sector. South Korean banks have long had their own shortcomings -- like virtually no serious credit analysis of potential borrowers. Banks traditionally tended to shovel cash in whatever area the Government directed them.
"They do not evaluate," said Jung Yong Seung, an economist at the Korea Institute for Industrial Economics and Trade. "They just lend."
By official reckoning, about 6 percent of all bank loans are substandard or nonperforming, but Do Sang Youl, a bank analyst at Hyundai Securities, estimates that by American accounting standards the proportion at the nationwide banks would rise to an astonishing 30 percent.
"It's very difficult for us to estimate the bad loans because the accounting is not transparent," Mr. Do complained.
The mounting bad debts have caused tight credit for South Korean businesses, with local and foreign banks alike reluctant to lend. The bad debts have also led people to wonder aloud whether South Korea could become the center of a new foreign debt crisis.
One worrisome sign is that South Korea's foreign-exchange reserves are only $30 billion, and some of that apparently is committed in foreign- exchange contracts that will soon become payable. This level of reserves is equal to less than the three months of imports that are normally considered prudent.
The broader challenge for South Korea is to revamp itself to become a more nimble and market-oriented economy. But South Korea has strong unions that are particularly wary of economic liberalization. Union leaders like Kim Chul Hong, the affable 38-year-old president of the union at Housing and Commercial Bank, are accustomed to steady income gains and are horrified by calls for layoffs and reorganization.
Mr. Kim, who is leading a strike at the bank, is demanding pay increases and assurances that there will be no job cuts. He argues that the banks are not in grave difficulties and that in any case the Government will always bail them out.
"Obviously the bankruptcy of a commercial bank would cause big problems," he said. "But while this may happen overseas, this is highly unlikely in a major city like Seoul."

Korean Stocks Higher
 SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, Nov. 10 (Reuters) -- Trying to recover from a selloff last week, stocks were trading higher here today, after the Government said it would announce stabilizing measures this week. At midday, the Korean composite index was up 26.60 points, or 5.37 percent, at 522.30.
In Japan, the Nikkei index of 225 issues ended the morning down 44.35 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, at 15,792.01. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 697.51 points, or 4.22 percent.
 In Hong Kong at midday, the Hang Seng index was down 55.80 points, or 0.55 percent, at 10,048.70. On Friday, the index lost nearly 3 percent.

HEADLINE: Gambling in the Middle of Nowhere;
Oneidas' Casino Wins Without Slots or Eastern Seaboard

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: VERONA, N.Y.

 BODY:
When the tiny Oneida Indian Nation opened the Turning Stone casino here in the heart of New York's corn and dairy country in 1993, many people scoffed at the notion that it would ever approach the raw earning power of Las Vegas's gaudy temples of gambling.
Situated 30 miles east of Syracuse, Turning Stone is half a time zone from the gambler-rich Eastern seaboard. A bunker-like structure barely visible above the surrounding farmland, it was surprisingly muted, with a neon-free interior topped by a skylight that actually allowed gamblers to distinguish night from day. It did not serve alcohol. And, most important, New York State law did not allow it to have slot machines, by far the most profitable of gambling games. 
 But Turning Stone is proving that when it comes to slaking the public's seemingly endless thirst for high-stakes gambling, location and image aren't everything.
Though the Oneidas do not make their earnings public, gambling industry analysts say that Turning Stone, the state's only casino, is among the country's most successful, with annual revenues of several hundreds of millions. And with nearly three million visitors in 1996, it has become one of upstate New York's biggest tourist attractions, lagging not far behind venerable Niagara Falls in star power.
"They do phenomenal numbers," said Jason Ader, a gambling industry analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company. "Slots is where most casinos make 70 percent of their profits. But if you just look at table games, on a per table basis, Turning Stone is up there with Mirage, Foxwoods."
The signs of the Oneidas' new prosperity are plentiful. They are now the largest employer in Oneida County, with 2,800 workers, 90 percent of whom are non-Indians. Once consigned to a 32-acre reservation, the 1,100-member tribe has acquired nearly 5,000 acres of land, which is monitored by its own 43-member police force. The tribe has opened a T-shirt printing plant, bought a cattle farm and built tribal housing and community centers. When it holds ribbon-cutting events, state senators and members of Congress routinely show up.
Now, in what is perhaps their crowning capitalistic achievement, the Oneidas have opened a 285-room, $50 million hotel adjacent to the casino that includes an expanded gambling area, luxury boutiques and some of the fanciest restaurants in the region. Next door, an 18-hole golf course is taking shape and could open in 1998. A convention center is on the drawing boards. All this, the Oneidas say, is being done without partners, with only bank loans backed by their own profits.
The Oneidas' building boom is being fueled by two concerns: first, that Congress may someday rescind the law that has made it possible for Indians to open casinos, and second, that their upstate New York-northern Pennsylvania market is falling prey to Canadian casinos in Niagara Falls and Montreal. The Mohawk tribe is also considering opening casinos on its New York reservation along the St. Lawrence River.
"They are building as fast as they can and as big as they can, so whoever comes along later has to play a big game of catch-up," said Matt Connor, features editor of International Gaming and Wagering Business, a monthly trade magazine.
Ray Halbritter, the suave, Harvard-trained Oneida leader who also carries the title C.E.O. of Nation Enterprises, resorts to a tribal aphorism to explain his goal for building an entertainment empire. "Even if gambling did not exist, we would want to be a tourist destination," he said. "We're looking to the seventh generation."
Comparing his casino's blackjack tables to his forefathers' land, Mr. Halbritter said, "We always believed the great greed of the non-Indian people would someday close this door to prosperity." He added, "Everybody is happy if Indians are broke."
A stroll through the new hotel on an October Friday night provided abundant evidence that the Oneidas are anything but broke these days. The hotel was booked and the gambling areas were crowded. People lined up for two hours outside the casino's nightclub for a Chubby Checker concert. Truck drivers in jeans and baseball caps chewed on hamburgers at the casino's 50's style diner, while more fashionably dressed couples browsed through the designer clothing and Waterford crystal in one of the boutiques.
Many people were local residents who said they come to the casino regularly because it is the best source of night life for miles around. "What else is there to do?" asked Kathleen Miller, 52, of Rome, N.Y. "Go malling?"
An Italian visitor said to a cashier, "This is an oasis in the middle of a wasteland."
With the hotel, the Oneidas expect to draw gamblers from more distant cities like Pittsburgh or Boston. They have infused a bit more pizazz into their operation, putting neon lights in the gambling areas and adding stage shows with dancing girls to their entertainment repertoire. They are considering ending their ban on alcohol, which was instituted to underscore the problem of alcoholism among Indians. And they may even remove the skylight in the old gambling area, which was emblematic of the original casino's unorthodox style. Most casinos do not have clocks or windows, in the hope that gamblers will lose track of how long they have been playing.
"We wanted to build something that could compete with the market," Mr. Halbritter said. "This is new, it's glitzier, it's glamorous."
Aware that their prosperity might breed resentment among neighbors, the Oneidas have made some efforts to share their wealth. Though the nation contends that all its new real estate is tax exempt, it has begun paying local school districts and municipalities more than $320,000 a year under a program called the Silver Covenant Chain of Friendship. And they have pledged to spend $750,000 on a campaign promoting the region's tourist attractions.
Not everyone is impressed. Assemblyman David R. Townsend Jr., a Republican from Oriskany, said in an interview Nov. 7 that the Oneida casino had not spurred the creation of new businesses in the region, but had taken commerce away from existing stores and restaurants. And the Silver Covenant program has not replaced the tax dollars the Oneidas have drained by taking prime real estate off the tax rolls, he said.
"The only thing that has opened since the casino went in was a car wash down the road from them," he said. "And now the Indians are building a car wash, so they'll put this guy out of business, too."
But people working at the casino and hotel said they were grateful to have found jobs in this hardscrabble, high-unemployment region.
"I was so happy I was accepted for this job," said Lisa Santillo, 28, of Herkimer, who works behind the hotel's registration desk. "If you're looking for anything other than minimum wage jobs around here, you won't find it."

INDUSTRY: SIC6211 SECURITY BROKERS, DEALERS, & FLOTATION COMPANIES (66%);

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
After Days of Deal-Making Trade Bill Is Still in Limbo
Still short of votes after working through the weekend, President Clinton and his Republican allies decided early this morning to delay for a second time a House vote on expanded trade negotiating authority to the President. The decision potentially gave Mr. Clinton another few days to salvage legislation he has called crucial to the economic health of the country. But it was not clear how Mr. Clinton could round up the votes that had eluded him all weekend. A1
 
Clinton Urges Stand on Iraq
President Clinton urged the United Nations to take "very strong and unambiguous action" to force Iraq to comply with international weapons inspections. The President also warned Iraq not to follow through on threats to attack American spy planes on United Nations missions. Iraq halted the inspection teams for a seventh day. The Security Council is to meet today to consider its response. A1 

Asia's Next Economic Crisis
There are growing whispers in international financial circles that South Korea, one of the most miraculous of Asia's miracle economies, could become "the next Thailand." The country has found itself floundering in a turbulent sea of bankruptcies, bad debts and tight credit. A3
 
No Meeting for Netanyahu?
In an apparent sign of Washington's displeasure with the pace of peace talks, no meeting has been planned between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and President Clinton next week during Mr. Netanyahu's scheduled visit to the United States. Mr. Netanyahu's aides sought to play down the omission, but Israeli leaders have rarely visited without a call on the President. A6
 
Turkey Frees a Critic
The Turkish Government yielded to intense pressure and released a blind social critic, Esber Yagmurdereli, who began serving a 23-year prison term last month. Turkey said it was releasing him on health grounds, but the Anatolian news agency said the sentence had been "suspended for one year." A5
 
Buenos Aires's Honest Mayor
Promising to curb corruption, Fernando de la Rua became the first elected Mayor of Buenos Aires last year, a post previously appointed by the President. Since then, he has carried out a crackdown virtually unprecedented in a country where bribes, payoffs and kickbacks are part of everyday life. A11
 
Budget Battle in Mexico
Mexico's President, Ernesto Zedillo, could face the greatest fight of his presidency this week from opposition lawmakers who want to challenge his economic policies. The opposition, which has control of Congress for the first time in modern history, said it wants to make sweeping changes in Mr. Zedillo's budget for 1998, including pay increases and tax cuts. Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen plans to trim thousands of civilian jobs at the Pentagon and transfer thousands more military personnel out of their headquarters and into the field, officials said. The reductions, which are to be announced today, are part of what the officials said would be a sweeping plan to reorganize the Pentagon. Altogether, the plan could save as much as $6 billion a year in the Pentagon's budget, which this year totals about $250 billion. A1

I want to pray a little bit." Tribe Makes Casino Work
The tiny Oneida Indian Nation is proving with its Turning Stone casino that location and image are not everything when it comes to satisfying the demand for high-stakes gambling. The casino is in the middle of farm land, it does not serve alcohol and it has no slot machines. HEADLINE: Already Struggling, Dominicans Sink Deeper Into Poverty, Study Finds

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

 BODY:
A new study of Dominicans, New York City's largest and fastest growing immigrant group, has found that they have stumbled badly in the 1990's on the road to the American dream. Their per capita income has declined precipitously. Unemployment and poverty have risen substantially, as has the proportion of Dominican families headed by women with no spouse around to help out financially.
These social and economic setbacks have worsened the position of Dominicans relative to other groups in the city, including Puerto Ricans, blacks and Hispanic residents in general, and have further entrenched Dominicans at the bottom of the city's economic heap. 
 The deteriorating status of Dominicans is a worrisome trend for the city because the group is growing so fast and because Dominican children make up a disproportionate share of students in city schools, principally because Dominicans are younger on average than other New Yorkers and have more children, researchers say.
The city's Dominican population has grown at a remarkable rate, rising from 125,380 in 1980 to 332,713 in 1990 and to 495,000 this year -- and is expected to top 700,000 by the year 2000 if current patterns persist. And while Dominicans now make up about 7 percent of the city's population, they comprise an estimated 10 percent of its schoolchildren. Almost half the Dominicans in the city live below the poverty level.
These are among the findings in a socioeconomic profile of Dominicans in the city to be released today. Researchers in Columbia University's Latino Studies Program and the City University of New York's Dominican Studies Institute at City College based their conclusions on an analysis of annual Census Bureau surveys.
"Dominicans came looking for better jobs and living conditions and to improve their lives," said one of the two principal researchers, Ramona Hernandez, a sociologist at CUNY. "What you see is that this is not materializing for a majority of them."
Professor Hernandez and her colleague at Columbia, Francisco Rivera-Batiz, an economist, say they believe that the city should put more emphasis on attracting industries that employ unskilled workers and on investing in education. The progress of Dominicans will largely depend on improvements in their educational status, they say. As in many other immigrant groups, many Dominican adults need literacy and English language instruction, while children need better schools.
"The lack of a planned response by the public school system to enrollment growth has resulted in severe overcrowding of the schools in which Dominican children are enrolled," the researchers say in their report.
The bustling shopping areas along Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue in Washington Heights, the city's largest Dominican neighborhood, in upper Manhattan, and the apparent profusion of Dominican shopkeepers disguise a far less hopeful reality, the researchers say.
Only 7 percent of Dominicans in the labor force in the city were self-employed in 1990, below the city average of 9 percent. The vast majority of Dominicans must look for work in a job market particularly unfavorable to them, the researchers say.
A number of demographic factors have made Dominicans vulnerable to the erosion of opportunities for the unskilled in the city and the further contraction of the blue-collar manufacturing sector in the 1990's.
Dominicans in New York City, which is home to 6 out of every 10 Dominicans in the United States, are predominantly unskilled and have relatively low levels of educational attainment, even when compared with residents of the Dominican Republic, the study found.
In 1996, only 4 percent of the city's Dominicans had a college degree, as compared with 9 percent in the Dominican Republic, and 55 percent had not graduated from high school, while 44 percent lacked a high school diploma in the Dominican Republic.
Dominicans are much younger on average than New Yorkers generally (28 years old versus 36) and a large proportion are new to the United States and still struggling to learn English. Both their relative youth and lack of proficiency in English are disadvantages in the job market, researchers say.
The fact that so many Dominicans immigrated so recently and have had relatively little time to establish themselves economically has also contributed to their lagging performance in income and employment.
Among the study's findings was the sharp rise in Dominican households headed by women, to 49 percent in 1996 from 41 percent in 1990.
The study does not detail rates of welfare use among Dominicans, but city demographers found that 29 percent of Dominican households received public assistance in 1990. Among the foreign born, only people from the former Soviet Union had a higher reliance on welfare, with 37 percent. All other immigrant groups, except for Hondurans, had welfare-use rates lower than the 13 percent for the city population as a whole.
Given the economic plight of Dominicans since 1990, welfare use among Dominican women may have risen, Professor Rivera-Batiz said.
Both he and Professor Hernandez said they were shocked to discover how deep the drop was in per capita income among Dominicans and how steep the rise was in poverty.
From 1989 to 1996, per capita income declined 23 percent, to $6,094 a year, in inflation-adjusted dollars, while the poverty rate rose to 46 percent from 37 percent -- almost double that for the city as a whole.
The unemployment rate for Dominicans in the city rose to 18.8 percent in 1996 from 17.2 percent in 1990.
Dominicans began migrating to the United States in significant numbers in 1962, after the 1961 death of Rafael Trujillo, the dictator who had enforced highly restrictive policies on leaving the island. As economic conditions in the Dominican Republic worsened, particularly in the 1980's and 1990's, Dominican immigration to the United States soared.
Professor Hernandez said her family was among the thousands drawn to America by the lure of opportunity -- and is also among the majority whose hopes have often been disappointed. She is the only one of her parents' three children in the United States to make it through college and into a profession.
Her father, 66, recently retired as a school janitor but still does maintenance work part time. Her sister and her sister's husband each work two jobs to support their four children. And her brother is a laborer.
"It's painful that you have been let go by your own country and come to a new place dreaming of a better life and that does not happen," Professor Hernandez said.
Her voice charged with feeling, she added, "Education is crucial."

HEADLINE: Senate Adjusts Legislation, Hoping to Remove Obstacles and Avoid a Veto

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The Senate voted tonight to consolidate the three remaining Federal spending bills for the 1998 fiscal year into a single piece of legislation. It also voted to strip out or soften most of the issues that have stalled the bills and drawn veto threats from President Clinton.
The legislation, known as an omnibus bill, passed on a unanimous voice vote and was sent to the House. The bill would allow the appropriations bill for the District of Columbia to include the spending bills for the Departments of Commerce, State and Justice, for the Federal judicial system, and for foreign operations. 
 Hoping to avoid a veto by Mr. Clinton, the Senate removed a school voucher provision from the District of Columbia spending legislation and made it a stand-alone bill.
Earlier in the day, House Republican leaders and the White House agreed to a compromise over a controversial method for estimating the population in 2000, the major issue that had stalled the spending bill for the Departments of Commerce, Justice and State. But the foreign operations section of the omnibus bill still includes language that prohibits Federal money for overseas family-planning organizations or programs that support abortion services.
Both the House and Senate passed a bill by voice vote late tonight that would keep Government agencies with unfinished budgets operating for another day, up until midnight Monday.
And House and Senate negotiators announced that they had reached an agreement on a six-month extension of the highway bill to give legislators until next spring to complete work on a six-year plan. The legislation would provide $9.7 billion to the states for transportation projects and assures each state that it will have at least half the Federal transportation funds that it received in 1997.
The moves came near the end of a day of furious political horse-trading. While Administration officials and Republican leaders lobbied on one front for votes on expanded trade authority for the President, negotiators huddled elsewhere trying to resolve the issues that stood between passage of the spending bills and adjournment for the year.
The major breakthrough was over the census fight. Under the deal, the Census Bureau would be allowed to proceed with a test next year on the use of statistical sampling, as the Administration wanted. But in return, Republicans won an agreement that allows the House Speaker to file a lawsuit challenging the use of sampling and requires the Government to pay for the lawsuit.
That provision angered many Democrats to the point that many said tonight that they would vote against the spending bill for Commerce and the other departments. But the White House, confident from the start that census sampling will withstand a court challenge, has argued that the Speaker or any other opponent of the plan could have filed lawsuit in any case.
Beyond just counting heads, the question of whether the Census Bureau uses sampling in the 2000 population assessment has significant political impact, because it could determine which of the major political parties will control the House of Representatives.
Republicans oppose census sampling mainly because a large number of the undercounted people are immigrants and other minority groups, who tend to live in heavily Democratic areas. Counting them, the Republicans fear, would allow House districts to be redrawn to the Democrats' advantage. Republicans, who now hold a 22-seat majority in the House, have said they could lose as many as two dozen seats because of sampling-driven redistricting.
Republicans also argue that the Constitution calls for an "actual enumeration" of the population to apportion seats in the House.
The political struggle over the 2000 census is entwined in the bill that appropriates money for three of the largest Cabinet departments -- Commerce ($3.2 billion), Justice ($1.13 billion), and State ($5 billion) -- as well as the Federal judiciary system ($3.2 billion).
The Census Bureau, which is part of the Commerce Department, wants to use sampling to improve on the 1990 Census, which failed to count more than 10 million people and counted 6 million twice or in the wrong location.
Census sampling is similar to the method used in public opinion polling but is more sophisticated.
Under the agreement that was worked out late Saturday but only announced today, the Census Bureau would receive $31 million to pay for two tests next year, in addition to its regular budget. One test would be conducted in Sacramento, Calif., using statistical sampling. The other test would be conducted in rural areas of South Carolina using the traditional house-by-house method augmented by the mailing of more census forms and advertising.
Martha Farnsworth Riche, the director of the Census Bureau, called the deal "an operational truce."
"It allows us to go ahead and gives us an opportunity to validate a plan we think will be more accurate and cost less money," she said. "At the same time it allows us to validate a nonsampling plan."
The deal also called for an eight-member Congressional monitoring board to review the Census Bureau plans for 2000, including sampling. The board, split equally between Republicans and Democrats, would need a majority vote of five.
Republicans had originally proposed a seven-member board that would consist of four Republicans and three Democrats. The White House had appeared to accept that deal on Saturday until Congressional Democrats balked and forced a new deal late Saturday night.
The Republicans and Democrats remained far apart over issues that have created an impasse in the appropriations bills for the District of Columbia, where a Republican plan for school vouchers has provoked a veto threat, and for foreign operations, which has become embroiled over abortion.
 
District of Columbia
The District of Columbia spending bill, covering about $820 million, is the smallest of the 13 appropriations bills. But it traditionally ranks as one of the most contentious because of fights over such issues as abortion and the Administration's decision to block a section of Pennsylvania Avenue in front of the White House for security. The political battle this year has been over school vouchers.
Republicans have included $7 million in the bill to provide vouchers for 2,000 low-income children to attend private schools. But Democrats, including the President, have opposed the idea, arguing that it would erode the public school system. Mr. Clinton has said he will veto the District of Columbia bill if it reaches his desk with the voucher provision.
 
Foreign Operations
The $12.8 billion spending bill for foreign operations covers foreign aid, including the annual economic and military assistance to Israel and Egypt and $770 million to the former republics of the Soviet Union. It also includes money for such programs as peacekeeping ($78 million) and the Peace Corps ($222 million).
But the bill has become a political hostage to a debate about overseas family-planning programs.
A provision known as the Mexico City Policy in the foreign operations bill prohibits the use of Federal money for overseas family-planning programs or for organizations that provide abortion services or lobby for those services. Since 1995, conservative Republicans in the House have tried to expand that language to include programs and organizations that use their own money for abortion services.
The Clinton Administration has steadfastly opposed that prohibition. In the last few days, however, Republicans have tried to leverage their support for President Clinton's desire for enhanced trade authority, or so-called fast-track legislation, to persuade him to drop his opposition.
But Mr. Clinton said today that the issue was non-negotiable.
"We're not going to trade a matter of principle on the Mexico City issue to carry fast track," he said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."

HEADLINE: Quick Fix Won't Solve Asian Currency Crisis

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Jeffrey D. Sachs (Op-Ed, Nov. 3) provides the right diagnosis of the Asian Tiger malady, but the medicine he proposes -- letting the "Asian currencies float downward, so that these countries' exports will be cheaper and therefore more competitive" -- is wrong. This would merely mean that Southeast Asia would again be able to undersell and put other workers and factories elsewhere in the world out of work. Latin America (and China and Eastern Europe) would lose export market share in the United States, the European Union and Japan. 
 The loss of jobs and production in Latin America would pass the currency-crisis disease back to our important export markets there. We should have learned from the Depression that using exchange rate declines rather than improved productivity to achieve a competitive edge is merely a policy for each country to "export unemployment."
The real medicine must involve increasing the global demand for goods and services to keep pace with productive capacity so that workers and factories around the world can be fully employed to provide the goods that consumers deserve. That medicine cannot be administered until the economic myth that unemployment cannot be lowered without reigniting inflation is put to rest.
 
PAUL DAVIDSON
Knoxville, Tenn., Nov. 3, 1997
 
The writer is editor of the Journal of Post Keynesian Economics.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Quick Fix Won't Solve Asian Currency Crisis;
Banks Hurt Themselves

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Wrong Medicine for Asia" (Op-Ed, Nov. 3): Jeffrey D. Sachs's argument rests on the assumption that the Southeast Asian countries have been victimized by forces not of their making and out of their control. In fact, they are victims of their own financial organizations, which knowingly made ill-considered investments or gambled in foreign exchange and lost. 
 The questions now are who will bear the loss and fix the system so that the problem will not recur. Deposit insurance for small investors, suffering for larger investors who should have known better, fiscal restraint to pay for cleaning up the mess, and monetary stability -- these strike me as the "right medicine" for governments and the International Monetary Fund.
 
WILLIAM LASSETTER
Charlottesville, Va., Nov. 3, 1997

HEADLINE: Trial of Au Pair Reveals Unease in U.S. Society

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9

 BODY:
Anne Bernays, a Cambridge novelist and teacher, caught it early and bad. She would eat her lunch in front of the television, so as not to miss a moment of testimony. She would tell acquaintances about the trial that had hooked her, and the "incredible pre-Raphaelite face" of the defendant. What got her, she said, was "the dark undertone, that secret fear in the back of every mother's head that the people she's left her kids with are going to hurt them."
A month ago, Ms. Bernays was the only one in her circle of friends following the Louise Woodward case. Now, it seems as if the whole country is talking about what has become known as the nanny trial -- a phenomenon that cultural commentators say is deeply revealing about the current state of American society. 
 At dinner parties, at bus stops, on call-in shows and in on-line chat rooms, the story of the 19-year-old British au pair, convicted of murdering her employer's 8-month-old son, has absorbed the country's attention as no criminal case since the 1995 trial of O.J. Simpson.
Television executives say the audience for live courtroom coverage is the biggest in two years. And anticipation of Judge Hiller B. Zobel's decision on whether to overturn Ms. Woodward's conviction, which he plans to post on the World Wide Web -- and which could come as early as Monday -- is so great that on-line users complain it is clogging some Web sites.
All this over a "shaken baby" death, a crime committed hundreds of times a year, a case devoid of the celebrity sparkle and racial overtones of the Simpson trials, or the mass tragedy and political import of the Oklahoma City bombing trials.
So what, exactly, is going on?
Several factors are intertwined in a kind of "historical serendipity," said Paula Fass, a professor of history at the University of California at Berkeley and author of "Kidnapped: Child Abduction in America" (Oxford University Press, 1997).
Like virtually every other commentator, she pointed first to a deep sense of unease about the welfare of American children, now that most mothers work outside the home.
"That's an ongoing concern, and it tends to erupt in various places," Ms. Fass said. "This nanny trial is one of those eruptions -- kidnapping concerns are another eruption, and concerns about sexual predators are another eruption -- and this has been going on for 20 years, as mothers have entered the work force in larger numbers. It comes from a conflict and ambiguity in the culture, a sense we still don't feel easy about that fact."
Adding to that tension, she said, is the relatively new trend of televised trials, which give viewers a sense that they know as much as the jury, and the rise of interactive media, from chat groups to call-in shows, that encourage everyone to have an opinion.
Others note that the Woodward case has a particular power to evoke strong opinions, perhaps because almost everyone has relevant experience, whether because they have children, or have been baby sitters, or simply remember their own childhood caretakers.
"Everyone can be an expert on this," said David Nasaw, an American cultural historian at the City University of New York. "Everybody could be an expert on the O.J. Simpson thing, and in this case, even more so, everyone can be an expert on whether shaking babies can kill them and on nannies and all the rest."
Such experiences, some analysts believe, drove interest in the Woodward case to a sudden, critical mass because it fed a national hunger to share common narratives and dramas.
"The commercial culture, the mass media, are one of the only ways we have of creating a national culture, and it does what sports used to do for men," Mr. Nasaw said. "It creates a public in a way that other events don't or can't."
Erik Sorenson, Court TV's vice president for programming, said the public response to the Woodward jury's Oct. 30 guilty verdict brought to mind "The Perfect Storm," the best seller about fishermen overtaken by a squall.
"It reminds me of a big Nor'easter that is beyond any kind of human ability to control or predict," he said. Mr. Sorenson noted that some at Court TV initially questioned whether the Woodward trial was even worth broadcasting.
Mr. Sorenson attributed the case's pull not only to its child-care issues but its legal ones as well, coming at a time when viewers had finally recovered from the overdose of the two O.J. Simpson trials.
"Legally, alone, you have a bushel full of issues," he said. "The all-or-nothing strategy of the defense; whether a jury's verdict should be sacrosanct; whether defense lawyers are unethical slobs because they'll make up any story they can, to get someone off; whether prosecutors are heartless deal-drivers because they overcharge."
The broader national context -- coming at a time of peace, economic health, low crime and dull elections -- also played a part in the phenomenon, some said.
"I think we have an ongoing sort of trial circus," said Caryl Rivers, a professor of journalism at Boston University and author of "She Works, He Works" (HarperCollins, 1996).
"In the 1920's, tabloids covered the sensational trials all the time," she said. "We're at peace, the economy hasn't crumbled, there's no pressing international story that sort of impacts our lives. We are now looking at different things to divert us. I think we are probably going to have these things come up regularly."
Ms. Fass of Berkeley shared that view, adding that with the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, public displays of emotion seem to have gained a new acceptance.
Once the guilty verdict came in, many people also seemed to find some emotional empathy for Ms. Woodward, who is scheduled to spend at least 15 years in prison before she is eligible for parole. A Boston Herald poll taken on Nov. 4 among 306 Massachusetts residents found that 90 percent wanted her conviction either reduced to a lesser charge or nullified altogether.
Even before she was convicted, Ms. Woodward was a compelling figure whose wholesome looks and soft voice contributed to her trial's popularity.
As Deborah Eappen, the mother of the dead child, Matthew Eappen, said in a CNN interview with Larry King, "The idea that someone who looks 'normal' or friendly or young or -- I hate to use stereotypes; a young, white, soft-spoken, British-accented, intelligent girl could harm your child -- it's terrifying to people."
The image projected by the Eappens, too, contributed to interest in the case, many say: both are doctors in their early 30's, living in a starter house in the pleasant Boston suburb of Newton.
"These are basically fairly middle-class characters with which people can identify," said Shari Thurer, a psychologist and author of "The Myths of Motherhood" (Penguin, 1996). But class works against the Eappens as well, she said, because "people who see the Eappens as privileged therefore connect with Louise."
Certainly, the intensity of the emotional response has left Mr. Sorenson of Court TV and others shaking their heads.
"I read a lot of mail like this: 'I feel for the Eappens. Nobody's talking about the baby. Who's looking out for little Matthew?' And I think: 'Three weeks ago they'd never heard of little Matthew!' " he said. "It's a combination of something missing in our lives, but on the other hand something richly afforded to us in our lives, and it's a very peculiar phenomenon."
