HEADLINE: Clinton and Allies Fall Short, Again Delaying a Trade Vote

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Monday, Nov. 10

 BODY:
After a weekend of frenetic deal-making and lobbying but still falling short of votes, President Clinton and his Republican allies decided early this morning to delay for a second time a House vote granting expanded trade negotiating authority to the President.
Shortly before 2 A.M., the majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, said the House would recess until Wednesday, leaving open the option of returning to the trade bill later in the week. 
 That decision potentially gave Mr. Clinton another few days to salvage legislation he has called crucial to the economic health of the country. But it was not clear how Mr. Clinton could make the headway and round up the votes that had eluded him despite offers of Presidential help in campaign fundraising.
Action on the bill also could be delayed until next year, although such a postponement would be a clear defeat for Mr. Clinton, since the bill's chances are considered even dimmer in an election year.
Opponents of the President -- predominantly members of his own Democratic party -- predicted that they would prevail. "They don't have the votes," said Representative Jerrold L. Nadler of New York. "I think we've won."
A defeat for Mr. Clinton on the trade legislation would represent his most severe legislative setback since his proposal for national health care died in 1994.
Earlier on Sunday night, Republicans had expressed guarded optimism, even though Mr. Clinton had a majority of his party in the House firmly arrayed against him. "I'm not promising we have the votes," Mr. Gingrich said in the afternoon as the House moved toward a long night of emotional discussion on the trade legislation known as fast track.
But the Georgia Republican said that if could get within five votes of victory he would "roll the dice" and take a vote. He also held open the possibility of pulling the legislation off the floor. "I don't want the President to be summarily defeated," he said. "I think that would be America being defeated."
The House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, who has been leading the battle against his own party's President in opposition to the fast-track legislation, met with his head counters on Sunday and declared, "I believe that we'll win this vote."
Republicans who attended a closed-door party caucus Sunday afternoon where Mr. Gingrich pushed for support said the Speaker tried to bring around recalcitrant Republicans loath to give Mr. Clinton a triumph. "The Speaker is trying to convince the Republicans that a fast-track vote now is a Republican victory and a Clinton defeat," said Senator Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho, who was sitting in. "If he is successful in doing that, fast track will pass, and if he is not, it may not come to a vote, or, if it does, it would be defeated."
Other Republicans said Mr. Gingrich sought converts by arguing that passage would help the country and deal a huge defeat to organized labor. Talking to reporters after the session, Mr. Gingrich referred to Democrats as fearful of "Washington labor bosses."
In a significant sign of Mr. Clinton's problems, three Democratic Representatives -- Nita M. Lowey of Westchester, Chaka Fattah of Philadelphia and Juanita Millender-McDonald of California -- announced that they had decided to oppose the trade measure. Only one previously undecided Democrat, Representative Zoe Lofgren of California, said she had come down "a reluctant yes."
Ms. Lowey, whose district runs into the Bronx and Queens, said she decided that the trade bill in the end "just wasn't good enough." She also said that good legislation should be able to pass on its merits, not on arm-twisting and deals. "This week has not brought honor to this House," she said. "A disillusioned and cynical public believes the Capitol is awash in deal-making and threats."
The legislation under consideration in the House extends the authority that Presidents since Gerald R. Ford have had to negotiate trade agreements that Congress can either approve or disapprove but not amend. Mr. Clinton let the powers expire midway through his first term, rather than risk a vote that would splinter Democrats just as he was trying to avoid a primary challenge and assure his re-election.
The Administration contends that such Presidential powers are crucial to America's world standing because Mr. Clinton would be hampered in striking deals if America's trading partners thought that any pacts they negotiated with the United States could be refashioned by Congress.
Next to the summer's balanced-budget agreement, the trade bill has been considered the most significant battle of this session of Congress.
A temporary delay would give Mr. Clinton time to search for votes before Congress adjourns, almost certainly this week, but a postponement until next year would be a significant defeat for the President. Most political strategists believe that the measure would only become harder to pass in a fractious election year.
Republicans generally have supported Mr. Clinton's free-trade position. But Democrats have been sharply divided, depending on how they view the changes being wrought by the global economy.
While centrist Democrats like Mr. Clinton contend that Americans stand to gain from an economy dominated by high technology and an educated work force, they are outnumbered in the House by Democrats who see blue-collar workers forced into a "race to the bottom" through competition with developing countries that do not have the labor laws and environmental protections of the United States.
Organized labor and environmental groups -- both at the heart of the Democratic constituency and out in force in the corridors of the Capitol this weekend -- ferociously oppose the bill. They contend that the legislation is flawed because it does not include binding promises that Mr. Clinton, in expanding global trade, will use the ultimate weapon of trade sanctions to force developing nations to improve their treatment of workers and to protect the environment.
For weeks, Mr. Clinton has been struggling to bring enough Democrats to his side to win. Doing so with Republican support would also allow him to claim a bipartisan victory. But Mr. Clinton, who has proved eminently flexible in his ideology, no longer has a reservoir of good will among House Democrats.
In a contentious meeting with the White House chief of staff, Erskine B. Bowles, on Saturday, many House Democrats angrily expressed suspicions that Mr. Clinton was willing to barter his position on such issues as international family planning funds to win Republican votes.
In an appearance on Sunday morning on NBC's "Meet the Press," Mr. Clinton tried to smooth over some of the Democratic fury. He said that "as a matter of principle" he would not alter his position on family-planning funds to win Republican votes. That stand by the President apparently prevented Mr. Gingrich from rounding up as many Republicans as he needed to make up for the President's lack of Democratic support.
All day and into the night Sunday, the President's senior aides -- including Mr. Bowles; his legislative liaison, John Hilley, and his chief delegate to the United Nations, Bill Richardson -- continued to work for votes in the Capitol. In the search for votes over the weekend, lawmakers said, the White House had promised lawmakers protections for peanuts, wheat, cattle, wine and tobacco. The President had also been offering to hold fund-raisers for individual Democrats who fear the consequences in next year's campaign if organized labor turns against them.
At one point Sunday night, Representative David R. Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat, asked Representative Robert Livingston, the Louisiana Republican who chairs the Appropriations Committee: "Does the gentleman know how many bridges the President has promised today for fast-track votes?"
Mr. Livingston mischievously replied, "The gentleman does not have enough fingers for that."
For some House members, the trade vote is about political survival. Democrats in particular believe that the support of the labor movement is far more crucial to their chances of re-election next year than the support of Mr. Clinton, who has carried no coattails for Congressional Democrats. For others, particularly from certain manufacturing or agricultural regions of the country, it is a referendum on the North American Free Trade Agreement of 1993, which Mr. Clinton also pushed through Congress primarily with Republican votes.

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 2; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1645 words

HEADLINE: In Books, It's Boom Time for Spirits;
Angels, Conversations With God, Even Fairies and Elves Sell Well

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
The hot line to heaven is open for sales.
When Neale Donald Walsch placed his emergency 911 appeal for spiritual comfort, he writes, God seized control of his pen, dictating two best-selling books of conversations that reveal a laissez-faire moral framework for life: "Do what you want to do." 
 Angels also took an active role in the preparation of "The Messengers," reports Nick Bunick, who says that while he was on tour to promote his steadily selling "as told to" book of angelic encounters, people spotted seven-foot-tall lavender and blue beings hovering nearby.
With such a rising din of celestial conversation, how do earthbound publishing executives verify heavenly access for a book deal? The simple answer is they don't, but it helps if the author is sincere and God has charisma and good grammar.
Most of the major New York publishing houses have acquired books with such spiritual themes or are scouting for promising authors nurtured by smaller presses. Publishers are well aware that as the millennium approaches, the theme of divine communication, in all its other-worldly varieties, is growing in popularity and shifting from the shelves of New Age bookstores to the mainstream ranks of best-seller lists.
In the realm of the written page, fairies are advising authors on rebirth while elves in baggy pants are providing technical assistance on grape production. Angels are sending messages through automatic writing or, in the case of the Archangel Michael, channeling through a computer keyboard. Authors are engaging in vigorous debates with God and Jesus through inspirational writing, while Buddha is also weighing in by means of what one writer characterizes as "scientific remote viewing."
Typically, these nonjudgmental books offer a reassuring blend of major religious philosophies, mixing a Christian emphasis on love, a Buddhist stress on tolerance and a Hindu belief in reincarnation. The focus is often on the individual, a strategy at odds with the mainstream teachings of seminaries, which stress social action and community commitment. "This is a religious experience, which society manifests in times of transition," said Bruce Chilton, a professor of religion at Bard College and an Episcopal priest. "Much of what comes out of the New Age movement is an attempt to address the postindustrial economy -- the likelihood that a person will change jobs and careers, the likelihood of changing spouses several times."
Mr. Walsch, for example, is the author of two spiritual books, which have emerged in the mainstream of the New York Times best-seller list for nonfiction, "Conversations With God, Book 1" and "Conversations with God, Book 2." The first volume remains on the best-seller list with more than 800,000 copies in print.
A former radio talk show host in Oregon and the father of nine, Mr. Walsch, 54, seems an unlikely divine messenger, but then that is his message: anyone can share jokes and folksy conversation with God, even a former altar boy and lapsed Catholic with a history of five marriages, a troubled career and a passion for the music of John Denver.
"People have acquired a new level of willingness to look for alternative answers," said Mr. Walsch, who also recently established a spiritual counseling hot line and a personal growth foundation. "I think that has to do with the growing awareness that the past ways haven't worked: our political setup, our social conventions, our theological constructions. The house of cards is coming down."
Clearly, the exploration of spirituality is attracting readers. Despite a tough climate for book sales, religious titles are steadily growing in popularity, growing more than 40 percent from 1990 to 1996 and now total more than $1.1 billion a year, according to the Book Industry Study Group.
 
Baby Boomers Reach the Right Age
 Publishers theorize that the baby boom generation, facing its own mortality and the loss of parents, is driving sales. A recent survey of readers by the same group indicates that purchases of religious books increase with the age of the customer. Readers who turn out for lectures by New Age authors are women more often than men and usually have some college education, publishing executives say.
"I think the new millennium brings more of an appreciation for things that are less mundane and more magical," said Nancy Mostad, an acquisitions manager for Llewellyn Publications in St. Paul, which has been publishing spiritual books since 1901. "People are feeling a sense of alienation from their religious training, and so rather than going through a priest or a rabbi, they want to have contact with the higher beings, whether angels, God or fairies."
This year the company published "The Elves of Lily Hill Farm," in which Penny Kelly describes her enduring relationship and regular conversations with a small clan of elves led by Alvey, a 22-inch-tall spirit in baggy pants and feathered hat.
Mrs. Kelly, 49 and a lapsed Catholic, said she first encountered the elves while strolling through her 57-acre Lily Hill Farm in the southwest Michigan town of Lawton. Initially skeptical, Mrs. Kelly said, she soon was making regular visits to the elves to seek advice on increasing her annual grape harvest to 100 tons.
Her book includes a special section offering tips to readers on elf communication. "Any time you go into a park, you'll find an elf," she said. "If you have a potted plant on your terrace, you may be able to communicate with an elflike intelligence."
Some companies remain leery of books claiming divine access. Morgan Entrekin, publisher at Grove/ Atlantic Press, said he would have qualms about publishing a book that reported spiritual communication as fact.
"These books seem to be fairly benign," he said, adding, "Perhaps they should be slightly more skeptical about the claims they make in their flap copy. Quite honestly, it's stuff I bypass."
But other publishing houses see it differently.
"As publishers, our job is to take a writer's message to the public," said Susan Petersen, senior vice president of Penguin Putnam Inc., which is now the publisher of the first volume of "Conversations With God." "The issue for us is: Is the person sincere? And do I think that what the person has to say will be of interest? Does it hang together?"
Spiritual inspiration doesn't guarantee luminous prose. One of the few authors whose writing draws praise in reviews is the Brazilian writer Paulo Coelho, the international best-selling author of "The Alchemist" and "The Valkyries: An Encounter With Angels."
In an interview, Mr. Coelho cautions readers to be wary of depending on authors for their spiritual salvation. "This is a great danger to rely on masters and gurus and reincarnation," he said. "The spiritual path is an individual one and it cannot transfer responsibility."
For publishers, the risk resides not in the message but in the sales potential. It gives them spiritual comfort to know that a religious book has a demonstrated sales appeal. For example, Penguin Putnam Inc. contracted to publish Mr. Walsch's first volume of conversations after noting that the book had sold more than 100,000 copies for Hampton Roads, a small press in Charlottesville, Va. (Hampton Roads is now publishing the second volume.)
Looking for a book with similar spiritual appeal, Pocket Books discovered "The Messengers," a self-published title that had sold more than 20,000 copies in the first month of its debut in the Northwest, where Mr. Bunick promoted it with a billboard campaign featuring a flaxen-haired angel. Pocket Books paid Mr. Bunick's company, Skywin, a $1 million advance for the rights to "The Messengers" and a follow-up book.
 
The Advance Money Goes for Publicity
 Mr. Bunick, 61, a prosperous Portland, Ore., businessman whose parents were Orthodox Jews, commissioned a ghost writer, G. W. Hardin, to tell his story of angelic visitors and his reincarnation as the Apostle Paul.
After its publication in August, "The Messengers" hovered for a while just below books published in the New York Times best-seller list but still in the top 30. And Mr. Bunick has invested much of his advance in increased advertising and hiring an independent California publicity agent. He has also enlisted volunteers to operate an advice hot line for readers who encounter angels of their own after reading his book.
Surprisingly, Mr. Bunick said, he has encountered little resistance or cynicism about his claims that he was an apostle or that angels visit his friends and were hanging around the book tour.
"There are only three possibilities," he said of his experiences. "The information is accurate or I fabricated it or I have been having delusions."
Richard Abanes, a writer and the author of the soon-to-be published "Defending the Faith: A Beginner's Guide to Cults and New Religions," said that part of the appeal of such spiritual books was that they were nonjudgmental and offered more excitement than sterner mainstream religions."Everything, including truth, has become so relative," he says. "If it seems to be true, that's good enough."
Mr. Walsch, who said he has received enough material to write as many as five volumes of spiritual conversations, says he is not trying to persuade anyone that God is literally steering his pen.
"Without wanting to be argumentative," he said, "I don't really care what you believe. I am not trying to convince people of anything, and so what people believe on some level is irrelevant. I'm simply sharing."
Mr. Walsch concedes, however, that his parochial schoolteacher, Sister Ricardo, may take a dim view of what happened to a student who once had ambitions of becoming a priest. "I think she would say, 'Hmm, it's what I would have expected of Neale, although I'm sorry he has much of his doctrine wrong."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up vs. Mark and Yen; Pound and Swiss Franc Gain

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday to a 10-month low against the British pound and a five-and-a-half-month low against the Swiss franc, but inched to a second consecutive six-month high against the Japanese yen as currency traders sought refuge from Asia's economic turmoil.
The dollar finished marginally higher against the German mark as both currencies rose against the yen. The Japanese currency suffered broadly after blue-chip stocks tumbled in Hong Kong and Tokyo, and South Korea's won tumbled to a record low against the dollar. Dealers bought currencies of European countries that would be less affected by the region's struggles. 
 The pound was particularly strong against the yen, indirectly helping the pound's value vs. the dollar, partly because Britain will not participate at the start of Europe's planned common currency in 1999. Trader concern about the new currency's stability sometimes holds back the mark and Swiss franc, Europe's main safe-haven currencies.
"The pound is probably the real star right now," said Elliott Dix, vice president of foreign exchange at the Signet Banking Corporation in Richmond.
Sterling also benefited from Britain's high interest rates, which were increased last week for the fifth time since May. In comparison, traders said they did not think the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates when its policy-setting committee meets tomorrow.
In late New York trading, sterling cost $1.6961, up from $1.6909 late Friday, the highest against the dollar since Jan. 6. The dollar also settled at 1.3887 Swiss francs, down from 1.3912, its lowest since May 20.
The dollar was quoted at 124.40 yen, up from 124.22.
The dollar finished at 1.7077 marks, up slightly from 1.7067.
Traders said that as the week progressed they would be scrutinizing the outcome of tomorrow's Fed meeting, as well as developments in the Persian Gulf. Iraq has vowed to expel American arms inspectors, and increased tension could cause a rise in oil prices that would particularly hurt Japan's already sluggish economy and put further downward pressure on the yen. Japan is dependent on imported oil.

HEADLINE: Nissan's Profits Jump as Exports Offset Slump in Japan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 10

 BODY:
The Nissan Motor Company said today that pretax profit rose 47 percent in the fiscal first half as cost reductions and higher exports offset a slump in Japanese sales.
Nissan, Japan's second-largest auto manufacturer, is fighting to increase domestic sales by focusing on the booming market for sport utility vehicles and station wagons, where it has trailed its rivals, including the Toyota Motor Corporation, the nation's biggest car company. 
 Auto sales in Japan have declined every month since April, when the Government raised the national sales tax, eliminated tax rebates and raised health insurance premiums -- steps that cost the average Japanese family $1,600 a year. Analysts do not expect car sales to begin to increase until next April.
Nissan rolled out more models in the fiscal first half, but its Japanese market share fell four-tenths of a percentage point, to 20.6 percent. Unit sales in Japan decreased almost 9 percent.
"It's very tough," said Kanemitsu Anraku, the Nissan managing director for accounting and finance. Nissan's performance "depends on the Japanese economy," he said.
The gloomy outlook for the domestic market prompted the auto maker to cut its forecast for profit in the full fiscal year by 9 percent.
In the fiscal first half, which ended Sept. 30, pretax profit increased 47 percent, to 45.36 billion yen, or $366 million, from 30.91 billion yen a year earlier. Net income more than tripled, to 38.50 billion yen from 11.63 billion yen.
Sales rose 2 percent, to 1.776 trillion yen from 1.738 trillion yen.
The results were for the parent company only. The auto maker will report earnings for the full corporate group later.
Saul Rubin, an auto analyst at SBC Warburg Japan Ltd., said that because of Nissan's strategy of increasing its share of the market for sport utility vehicles and station wagons, "they have actually done reasonably well in Japan." He said, "At long last, Nissan is beginning to pull back in that segment."
Exports grew 26.3 percent in the half. The weaker yen, which allows Japanese exporters to price their products more competitively overseas, helped offset the decline in Japanese sales.
Exports to the United States rose 11 percent, to 148,000 units, led by the Maxima luxury sedan, the Pathfinder sport utility vehicle and the QX4 luxury sport utility vehicle. But sales fell 10 percent, to 369,000 units.
Closer to home, exports to Thailand declined. Shipments to Malaysia and Indonesia gained. The Southeast Asian countries, especially Thailand, are suffering because of speculative attacks on their currencies and economic problems. But analysts said Nissan did not depend on the Southeast Asian market as much as some of the other Japanese car makers.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 529 words

HEADLINE: 'Fast Track' Is Derailed

 BODY:
President Clinton has been dealt a vengeful rebuke by Democrats over free trade. Mr. Clinton sounded the right note yesterday when he vowed to fight again next year for legislation granting trade negotiating authority to the President. But it will be an even harder fight as the President suddenly finds himself struggling to overcome the image of a lame duck in Washington. Another aspect of the defeat was that the philosophical arguments over trade and other matters may now be overwhelmed by the politics of the 2000 Presidential race.
All recent Presidents have won "fast track" authority, in which the trade agreements they negotiate get an up-or-down vote in Congress. There were more than 90 votes among House Democrats for the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993, when lawmakers were loath to oppose a first-term President. But yesterday Mr. Clinton could barely muster half that number in his party, and the bill was withdrawn. That was a slap for Mr. Clinton and Vice President Gore. 
 Much has changed since Nafta. A newly muscular A.F.L.-C.I.O. threatened to punish Democrats who voted for the "fast track" legislation this year. Perhaps more important, Representative Richard Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, fought fast track as if it were the start of his expected Presidential campaign against Mr. Gore. Liberal Democrats were also tired of being battered by Mr. Clinton's strategy of embracing G.O.P. positions on budget cuts, crime and welfare, and they paid him back with a rattling blow to White House prestige. That leaves hanging the huge political question of whether the President's policy of pulling Democrats and Republicans together into a somewhat conservative parliamentary majority is dead.
The current boom ought to have made Democrats more confident that, on balance, lowering trade barriers is good for the American economy. The Administration calculates, for example, that a third of the 13 million jobs added to the economy in the last five years have come from industries that export. But Washington cannot now press American trading partners to open up their markets without an American willingness to open its own.
Mr. Clinton's defeat was not simply a result of recalcitrance in his own party, of course. Many conservative Republicans did not want to hand him a victory even on something they supported philosophically. Their ultimate demand was for the White House to give in on language prohibiting American foreign aid to any organization that performs or promotes abortion. The President was right to refuse to go along.
The failure of the "fast track" bill was the President's biggest reversal since the health-care proposal failed in 1994. This time, however, it also seemed to reflect a loss of patience in both parties with the way they have been roped together on bipartisan budget deals all year. If the "fast track" bill comes up again next year, Mr. Clinton and House Speaker Newt Gingrich will have to do a better job persuading the lawmakers to set their parochial interests aside in favor of long-term gains for the economy as a whole. For now, narrow political interest has carried the day.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Finish Mixed On Quiet Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities were mixed in quiet trading yesterday, as those with longer maturities outperformed the middle and short ends of the market. Analysts said market participants were waiting for the meeting tomorrow of the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee and a report to Congress on Thursday by Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman.
Today, in observance of Veterans Day, there will be no Government bond trading and no trading in bond- related financial contracts on commodity exchanges. Though stock markets will remain open, there will be no trading in corporate bonds, municipal bonds or mortgage- and asset-backed securities. 
 Yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond rose 6/32, to 99 25/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 6.14 percent from 6.16 percent on Friday. The price of the two-year note was down 1/32, to 99 27/32, raising the yield to 5.71 percent from 5.69.
A lack of money flows from Asian markets to Treasury securities contributed to slack buying yesterday. Some investors, expecting Asian markets to drop over the weekend, were holding long positions in bonds, hoping to take advantage of price gains from any "flight to quality" by investors seeking greater safety. That also put pressure on the weekly auction yesterday of new three-month and six-month month bills.
At the auction, the new bills were both sold at an average rate of 5.16 percent. The bid-to-cover ratios, a measure of demand, were not as strong as last week, when the turmoil in world equity markets was driving more investors to the safety of Treasury securities. This week the ratios were 5.11 to 1 and 4.33 to 1, respectively, compared with last week's 6.12 and 6.11, respectively.
Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said overall market volume was on the light side as market participants awaited the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, even though most analysts expect it to keep interest rates steady. Mr. Regan cautioned, however, that there was always an outside chance that the central bank might decide to move anyway, particularly after the surprising strength of the October employment report last Friday.
"Comments by Fed officials, the employment report and other market data received last week have made market participants sit up a little straighter," Mr. Regan said. "Looking at the tight labor markets has put some constraints on the enthusiasm of the last several weeks."
Because of the continuing uncertainty in the Asian and Latin American markets -- whose gyrations had sent many investors into bonds over the last few weeks -- and jitters over new tensions in the Middle East, the bond market is likely to remain volatile this week, Mr. Regan said.
The Fed last raised rates in March, when it increased the Federal funds rate to 5.50 percent from 5.25 percent.
On Thursday, Mr. Greenspan will be speaking to the House Banking Committee on the Asian financial crisis; also that day, the Commerce Department will report on productivity and labor costs during the third quarter. On Friday, the Producer Price Index and retail sales data for October will be reported.
With such important reports looming, yesterday was the first session in about two weeks during which the bond market went back to worrying about the domestic economy after being caught up in the turmoil of world equity markets. If investors had focused on the American economy during that period, bond prices almost surely would have fallen because of concern about inflation prompted by indications of strong growth.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Stocks Stage a Retreat, With the Dow Falling by 28.73

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Most stock indexes fell yesterday, as continued concerns about slower growth in international markets, particularly Southeast Asia, erased early gains.
The declines came despite improved performance yesterday in Brazil and South Korea, two markets that were under pressure last week. 
 Reflecting investors' concerns that the problems in those markets have not been fully resolved, American companies in sectors believed to have large exposures to selloffs in those regions, such as technology shares, were among the most actively traded and were the leading decliners. Financial services companies like Travelers Group, American Express, Citicorp, Chase and Merrill Lynch also fell.
But telecommunications stocks like AT&T, GTE, SBC Communications and BellSouth ended higher, after MCI Communications accepted a sweetened takeover bid by Worldcom, for $36.5 billion in cash and stock, which would be the biggest merger in American history.
"It is a very good likelihood that Asia's contagion will be bigger than we thought," said Greg Smith, chief investment strategist at Prudential Securities, during a conference in New York yesterday.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 7,552.59, down 28.73 points, erasing early gains of as much as 74.9 points. Pacing the average's decline were technology companies like I.B.M., 97 11/16, down 1 13/16, and Hewlett-Packard, 60 1/2, down 1 7/16. However, advances exceeded declines on the Big Board, 1,459 against 1,431. Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 6.38 points, closing at 921.13. And the technology laden Nasdaq composite index lost 11.68 points, to 1,590.72.
Among major market indexes, only the Russell 2000 index managed to eke out a small gain. The index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks finished at 435.40, up 0.18 point.
Although fourth-quarter earnings of most American companies are not likely to be affected by the Southeast Asian markets' decline, market strategists are beginning to say the overall economy could slow beginning in early 1998.
"I don't think the correction is over," said Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company. "I think there was a little bit too much complacent congratulations that people gave each other for having survived" the record 554-point selloff on Oct. 27.
However, the forecasts of analysts who follow individual stocks do not yet signal a significant downturn, market strategists say.
Current earnings forecasts by I.B.E.S. for 1998 -- 15 percent for the S.& P. 500 is "a very rosy forecast for a world dealt something that has got to slow it down," Mr. Smith said, adding, "I am decidedly neutral about the next 6 to 12 months."
An expected fourth-quarter earnings shortfall did hurt one company's stock yesterday. CKS Group, which designs advertising and multimedia marketing campaigns, plunged 22 7/8, to 13 3/8, after saying that its fourth-quarter profit would be 6 cents to 10 cents a share, sharply below analysts' forecasts of 24 cents.
The downturn is a result of slower sales to its largest customers, said Steven Horan, an internet services analyst with Nationsbank Montgomery Securities.
CKS is trying to win bigger contracts, but will be unable to do so in a timely manner until it reorganizes its operations. The company realized that this will squeeze earnings this quarter and probably will remain a problem into 1998, Mr. Horen said.
"I really do believe these guys will be back," Mr. Horen said, adding that with the current problems "you can't value this thing as a 40 percent" earnings grower.
A technology issue, Read-Rite, declined 1 11/16, to 17 1/2. The disk drive component maker, said it expected earnings for its fiscal first quarter ending, Dec. 31, to falter because of overcapacity and depressed prices. The stock of other drive-component makers also fell, including Hutchinson Technology Inc., Western Digital Corporation and Seagate Technology.

HEADLINE: THE BATTLE FOR MCI: THE CONSUMERS;
A Pragmatic Agenda For Residential Service

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Bernard J. Ebbers, the president of Worldcom Inc., has built his company into a powerhouse and a Wall Street favorite by sidestepping the dregs of the telecommunications industry -- the messy, less profitable business of catering to residential phone customers.
Yet Mr. Ebbers spoke eloquently yesterday of how Worldcom's $36.5 billion merger with the MCI Communications Corporation would create a "stronger, more capable player" in the industry, an aggressive innovator that would certainly "benefit American consumers." 
 Worldcom's interest in residential customers has come recently. When Worldcom made its initial bid for MCI last month, John W. Sidgmore, the vice chairman of Worldcom, said that Worldcom might well sell MCI's 20 million residential customers to other long-distance companies. The next day, Worldcom quickly issued a statement saying it would "not abandon MCI's residential long-distance customers."
Worldcom's new-found concern for residential customers, analysts say, is mainly a pragmatic accommodation, a requirement for regulatory approval for its merger. The public policy justification for deregulating the phone industry in the landmark Telecommunications Act of 1996 was that fewer restraints and increased competition would benefit consumers, who would enjoy lower costs, new offerings and improved service.
The new and better world of telecommunications, most economists and industry analysts agree, will arrive eventually. But they also agree that it will arrive first for business customers and only later for most of the nation's 100 million households.
Until the benefits of increased competition are widespread, analysts say, Federal and state regulators will give careful scrutiny to huge telecommunications deals like the Worldcom-MCI merger. Indeed, the deal will require the blessing of the Department of Justice, the Federal Communications Commission, state regulatory agencies and the European Commission.
"The companies can't dump consumers out of these deals, " said Eli Noam, the director of the Institute for Tele-Information at Columbia University's business school. "The companies have to play the game of bowing to consumer interests, no question. For all the rhetoric of deregulation, telecommunications is still a heavily regulated industry."
Most analysts expect the Worldcom-MCI merger to be approved eventually. But an even bigger deal -- the AT&T Corporation's contemplated acquisition of the SBC Communications Inc., a regional Bell company -- proved too much for regulators to swallow. Even though AT&T never officially acknowledged the widely reported talks between the two companies, the very idea of the merger brought an angry reaction from Reed E. Hundt, then chairman of the F.C.C., who said a merger of AT&T and a Bell company would never withstand antitrust scrutiny.
Such mergers, analysts say, will someday be accepted but not until politicians and regulators can point to evidence that deregulation is delivering lower bills and improved service for consumers. "The Government wants to see some of the fruits of deregulation, especially for all those residential customers who are voters, before it opens the gates all the way," said Bryan Van Dussen, director of the telecommunications practice at the Yankee Group, a research firm in Boston.
Worldcom and MCI say the merged company will be able to offer customers a bundled service of local, long-distance and Internet access. Executives of the two companies talked about making these packaged offerings -- priced at less than they would cost separately -- to residential customers eventually.
"But businesses are clearly going to see the benefits first," said Chris Landes, a consultant at Telechoice Inc., a research firm in Verona, N.J. "Consumers will not benefit initially."
The business-first rollout may be politically unpalatable to some, but it makes economic sense. Indeed, it is the way costly new technology has been dispersed in society for more than a century. Alexander Graham Bell presented the telephone as a product for the masses, but it was first used as a business-to-business tool, connecting stores and factories. Initially, only businesses could afford phones and they supplied the investment funds for building the nascent network. Once built, the network could also profitably support households as well, making the telephone a mass-market utility.
The same process, analysts say, should apply in the modern age of digital communications. Still, in the residential phone market, as in others, some customers will be sought out first by the companies.
The first group of households likely to be offered one-stop shopping for bundled phone, Internet and other services will be the 16 million affluent households with incomes of $75,000 or more. They run up higher phone bills and they have personal computers connected to the Internet.

HEADLINE: Clinton Adviser Agrees to Settle Conflict Charge Over Stocks

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, agreed tonight to pay $23,043 to settle conflict-of-interest charges arising from his failure to sell oil company stocks.
Mr. Berger was told to sell the Amoco stock by the White House counsel's office three years ago, when he was deputy national security adviser. He said he had forgotten to do so for more than a year. 
 He thus became the second national security adviser in the Clinton Administration to run afoul of the conflict-of-interest statutes. His predecessor, Anthony Lake, also forgot orders to divest himself of energy stocks. Mr. Lake paid a $5,000 civil settlement last year, weeks before he withdrew his nomination to become Director of Central Intelligence.
The national security adviser theoretically has the power to move the world price of oil by advising the President to take military, political or economic action in oil-exporting foreign nations. The Justice Department said tonight that Mr. Berger did take actions, directly or indirectly, that could have affected the value of the stock, but that there was no criminal intent in his failure to sell the stock, only absent-mindedness.
"This was a mistake," Mr. Berger said in a statement issued by the National Security Council tonight.
The $23,043 represents the price increase and dividends in the stock, held by Mr. Berger's family, from the time he was told to sell it in March 1994 to the time he finally remembered to do it in June 1995, the Justice Department said.
It said there was no evidence that Mr. Berger intended to violate conflict-of-interest laws.
In a settlement filed in Federal District Court here, Mr. Berger said White House lawyers told him of the potential conflict of interest nearly four years ago. He said he meant to sell the stock, but let the matter slip his mind. A review of his financial disclosure statement in June 1995 prompted him to sell the 1,500 Amoco shares. The stock was in trusts, managed by trustees, not by Mr. Berger. Neither Mr. Berger, a prominent Washington lawyer before joining the Administration, nor his wife took active roles in managing those trusts, the Justice Department said.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: THE STRATEGY;
Crumbling Walls: U.S. Effort to Isolate Both Iran and Iraq Is Fraying Badly

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
For six years, the United States has tried to rein in and isolate Iran and Iraq at the same time. The current confrontation with Iraq shows how much harder it gets, year by year, to keep Saddam Hussein under control. And perhaps more ominously, it comes as Iran is moving on its own toward breaking free of American-led restraints.
On Iraq, the American-led coalition is merely fraying, because President Saddam Hussein's crude challenges to the United Nations and the international system are creating temporary, collective unity against him. 
 But the parallel effort by the United States to contain Iran through economic sanctions is falling apart.
While the world's attention is on Iraq, where Mr. Hussein is preventing United Nations inspectors from monitoring what remains of his weapons program, senior American officials think the situation in Iran is much more dangerous in the long run. The United Nations has no comparable international monitoring of Iran's efforts to develop weapons of mass destruction and missiles capable of hitting Israel, Saudi Arabia and Europe, those officials said.
Yet Washington's efforts to impose on the rest of the world its policy of isolating Iran is causing deep rifts with its closest allies in Europe and Canada, as well as with Russia. The rift focuses on American efforts to impose sanctions on foreign companies that trade with Iran.
As Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright struggled last week with Iraq and tried to make some progress on the stagnant Israeli-Palestinian talks, other senior American officials were engaged in quiet, top-level discussions with the Europeans and Russians about Iran and how to avoid a situation in which the United States would actually impose punishment on foreign companies that do business there.
Formulated after the Persian Gulf war, the policy of trying to control both Iran and Iraq quickly acquired the label "dual containment." Now it seems in tatters.
"On dual containment, coalition cohesion is fraying, and it worries people like me," said Phebe Marr, a senior fellow at the National Defense University. "But it is much less frayed on Iraq than on Iran."
Richard Murphy, a former Assistant Secretary of State for Near East Affairs, said: "We have let our policy get frozen. It was sufficient to say 'dual containment.' But that's not a way our Government can afford to act."
Dual containment was a slogan created for a speech by President Clinton in May 1993. Congress turned it into a reality with the Iran-Libya Sanctions Act of 1996, proposed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, and embraced by Mr. Clinton.
Today, almost all of America's allies think that the policy as it applies to Iran is not working. "A reassessment of Iran policy is long overdue," a senior European diplomat said. "The United States is isolating itself more successfully than it is isolating Iran."
A senior British diplomat says the American effort to punish foreign companies for doing business in Iran is wholly unacceptable. "It throws us on the other side of the debate," he said.
The 1996 law requires sanctions against companies that invest more than $20 million in Iran's energy industry, but does allow the sanctions to be delayed or waived in the national interest if the countries involved show movement toward deterring terrorism from Iran.
Under the act, the United States is currently investigating five foreign energy companies that have announced two large deals with Iran. Those deals were interpreted as a direct challenge to American policy.
The most attention has been paid to a French oil company, Total, which on Sept. 28 signed a $2 billion contract to explore for gas in Iran. In fact, Total is a minority shareholder, with 40 percent of the deal, while 30 percent is held by Petronas, a Malaysian company, and another 30 percent by Gazprom, the huge Russian company that used to be the Soviet Ministry of Natural Gas and was run by the current Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin. The Russian Government itself still owns 40 percent of Gazprom.
The Americans are also investigating a $180 million deal to develop an offshore Iranian oilfield called Balal signed by the Canadian company, Bow Valley Energy Ltd., and its Indonesian partner, Bakrie Minarak.
Stuart E. Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, is in Europe working on those cases. Frank Wisner, a Clinton special envoy, is in Moscow on a mission to get Russia and its newly privatized companies to stop helping Iran develop missiles that can carry nuclear, chemical or biological weapons.
The latter issue has become a hot topic in Congress, with hundreds of legislators supporting draft legislation to punish Russian and other companies proven to be helping Iran's missile program.
Senior European diplomats say that American officials have told them they are looking for reasons to waive the sanctions against the five energy companies in the Iran energy deal. But Mr. Eizenstat says that the law is being followed with vigor.
"We are not looking for an excuse to exercise a waiver," Mr. Eizenstat said in a telephone interview from Frankfurt. "We are pursuing this investigation with alacrity, and sanctions are a very real, live option if these activities are found to be sanctionable after our investigation is completed."
But other senior American officials stress that the point of the 1996 legislation is to change Iranian behavior and make it harder for Teheran to develop missiles and other weapons, and to support terrorism. They admit that European nations are not important to such programs in Iran. Russia, China and North Korea are involved in such illicit weapons development but the Chinese have now promised to stop any nuclear cooperation with Iran.
The Europeans say the Americans are asking them to tighten existing restrictions on aiding Iran in developing weapons or missiles. This might allow the Clinton Administration to win a waiver of sanctions from Congress.
While the Clinton Administration still argues that economic pressure works against Iran, a senior British diplomat says that while sanctions have hurt the Iranian economy, "it has not made a jot of difference to Iran's aspirations to develop weapons of mass destruction, or to its work on those weapons, or to its support for terrorism."
"U.S. policy on Iran has sounded good but has not worked," he added. "This is a situation where the American system forces the United States to act against its own interests."
Another European diplomat agreed, saying that what will change Iranian behavior is Iranian politics, and that the United States should be encouraging more moderate trends there, finding ways to carefully boost the newly elected President, Ayatollah Mohammed Khatami.
"Except for Turkey, Iran is the only real country in the region, with 3,000 years of history," a European diplomat said. "It's a complicated country, with a real intellectual life. It's not Iraq. We should not have business as usual, because Iran is a dangerous country. But we can affect it and we should be talking to it."
American policy makers have told some allied diplomats privately that if it were not for the 1996 law -- and concern that Iran will be proven responsible for the truck-bomb attack on Khobar Towers in Saudi Arabia, which killed 19 American servicemen -- Washington would be reviewing its Iran policy.
But American officials say they are looking at each day's intelligence from Iran for "serious signals" of altered Iranian behavior on the key issues of terrorism and weapons and missile development.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Worldcom Raises Its Offer And Wins Deal With MCI
MCI Communications said it had agreed to be acquired by Worldcom for about $36.5 billion in cash and stock, a sweetened offer that would result in the richest merger in American business history.
The agreement came after British Telecommunications, which had a $19 billion deal to buy MCI, agreed instead to sell its stake in the company to Worldcom. Apparently left out in the battle for MCI is GTE, which had bid $28 billion. Page A1. 

Trade Bill Fails
President Clinton conceded that he lacked the Congressional votes for a bill that would have renewed the President's authority to negotiate trade agreements that Congress can either approve or disapprove but not amend. The Republican leaders of the House and Senate indicated that it was probably dead for the foreseeable future. A1.
 
Kodak Cuts to Be Detailed
Kodak's chief executive, George M. C. Fisher, is expected to disclose a long-awaited turnaround plan. While thousands of layoffs and other cuts are seen, some analysts were speculating that the measures would not go as far as they would like. Market Place. D16.
 
Dow Average Loses 28.73 Points
Stocks fell, giving up early gains, as investors worried about weak foreign markets. The Dow industrials closed at 7,552.59, down 28.73 points, with I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard leading the decline. The Nasdaq composite index fell 11.68 points, to 1,590.72. D16.
 
Treasuries were mixed in quiet trading ahead of tomorrow's meeting of the Fed's monetary policy committee. The 30-year bond yield fell to 6.14 percent from 6.16. D23.
 
The dollar fell to a 10-month low against the pound and a nearly six-month low against the Swiss franc on demand for currencies insulated from Asia's problems. D14.

Indonesian Bank Closings Set
Indonesia's Finance Minister insisted on the forced closing of three ailing banks partly owned by relatives of President Suharto, attempting to send a strong signal that the Government is serious about making painful economic reforms to deal with the Asian financial turmoil. A3.
 
Half a world away but touched by ripples from the same crisis, Brazil announced a drastic program of tax increases and spending cuts aimed at slashing its budget deficit and restoring international confidence in its currency and economy. A7.
 
Nike to Do It Differently?
Nike surprised Madison Avenue, saying that it was seeking ideas to build its flagship Nike brand from another agency in addition to Wieden & Kennedy, which developed the campaigns carrying the familiar "Just do it" theme. Nike is now seeking ideas from Goodby, Silverstein, too. Two other big marketers, I.B.M. and Ford, are also taking a second look at plans for blue-chip accounts. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D12.
 
Waste Hauler To Sell Foreign Unit
Browning-Ferris agreed to sell its overseas operations to a unit of Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux of France for $1.45 billion, ending the Houston-based waste collector's international expansion plans. D8.

Nissan Profit Is Up Sharply
Nissan reported a 47 percent rise in pretax profit, to $366 million for its fiscal first half, thanks to cost reductions and higher exports. But a gloomy outlook for Japan's domestic market prompted the company to cut its profit forecast for the full year by 9 percent. D9.
 
Comcast Reports Loss
Comcast, owner of the QVC cable shopping network, reported a loss, as expected, for the third quarter, reflecting start-up costs and losses at affiliates. D12.
 
Retailer's Tepid Summer
May Department Stores, owner of Lord & Taylor and Filene's, reported weaker-than-expected profits for the July-September quarter, sending its stock lower. D8.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Above 43d St., Every Second Still Counts

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
ON Friday, as she does every week, Kim Ramos phoned the Treasury Department and the Census Bureau for a set of numbers, which she handed to Laszlo Szabo, who computer-crunched them into a new battery of figures, which became the latest readings of the "national debt clock," which flashes on a nondescript building at West 43d Street and the Avenue of the Americas, aka Sixth Avenue.
And which has been a New York fixture since 1989, as people in midtown know. It is a tireless conscience, reminding us about the unconscionable growth of the United States debt. 
 If you had looked up at 43d and Sixth just before noon yesterday, you'd have seen that the tally stood at $5,427,672,390,421, unless you blinked for a second, in which case it was already up to $5,427,672,392,301, give or take a fin. (For the numerically challenged, that is $5.4 trillion-plus, or more than Bill Gates is worth. The sum grows at about $1,880 a second, and each family's share, the clock said yesterday in tacit disapproval, is $66,759.)
A conscience is a wonderful thing, especially when it shines without pause, save for the occasional burned-out bulb. But one person's conscience can be another's scold, and you have to wonder if the distinctions in this case have become blurred.
We are now told that the annual Federal budget deficit is a shadow of its former self: a mere $22.6 billion, compared with $290.4 billion five years ago. It is the smallest deficit since 1974. As a percentage of the nation's economic output, it is, to use the technical language of economists, bubkes. Why, Washington is talking giddily about a possible surplus in a couple of years, which means that the overall debt could actually be reduced.
In other words, it may be safely said that the message behind the national debt clock has been received and acknowledged. And so a question arises: might it not be time to give it a rest on Sixth Avenue? To talk to the people behind the clock -- more like a tote board, really -- the answer is no.
Thedevice was the brainchild of Seymour B. Durst, the real estate developer, who died two years ago and who liked the burgeoning national debt about as much as he did restrictive zoning codes. The task of building and maintaining the gizmo fell to the Artkraft Strauss Sign Corporation, which makes most of the dazzling signs in Times Square. It assigned two employees, Ms. Ramos and Mr. Szabo, to keep the numbers up to date each week, a chore that Mr. Szabo, for one, is happy to perform. "I believe that this debt is going to come back to haunt everybody," he said.
A MEN, said Douglas Durst, who succeeded his father, Seymour, as president of the Durst Organization. The clock goes on, he said, in tribute to his father and as recognition that we are not out of the debt woods. "Hopefully, we can soon show the effects of the budget surplus," Mr. Durst said.
"Should there be one," he quickly added, his voice carrying a hint of skepticism.
Since his clock has hung in for so long, it's surprising that others have not seized on the idea as a way to convey their own messages. "It is odd, because it's the oldest advertising medium known," said Tama Starr, president of Artkraft Strauss. "The posting of information in public places goes as far back as ancient Egypt."
Several years ago, Ms. Starr put together a "national death clock" in midtown, for a man who wanted to depict graphically the high number of shooting victims in this country. That sign did not last, however.
Why not new ones? Obvious choices could be matters of high national import, like the number of abortions performed, or women raped, or children abused.
But grimness need not be the only criterion. Simple quality-of-life issues matter, too. Imagine seeing for yourself how many Starbucks outlets open in New York every hour. Or how many times per minute the Mayor is asked whether he's running for higher office. Or how many Marv Albert stories per day appear in the local media.
One problem is that these signs are not cheap. The debt clock cost $150,000 to install, and needs $3,000 a year in maintenance, Mr. Durst said. And for all his troubles, he can never be sure that anyone really pays attention. Typical was a well-dressed man striding purposefully yesterday toward the subway station at 42d and Sixth. Did he ever look at the debt clock?
"Never," he replied crisply before disappearing below ground, where messages come mostly, as a modern troubadour has put it, in the words of the prophets written on the subway walls.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 4; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 910 words

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: THE HISTORY;
7 Years of Evasion, Tons of Illicit Arms

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
A seven-year game of hide-and-seek has allowed President Saddam Hussein to preserve his power to make chemical, biological and nuclear weapons capable of killing millions, United Nations and United States officials say.
While only about two dozen missiles are believed to be at his disposal today, the Iraqi leader could put together a destructive arsenal if political and economic sanctions are lifted, using the materiel and expertise he has hidden from weapons inspectors, United States officials say. 
 President Hussein's military and intelligence officers have used everything from paper shredders to preposterous excuses to keep the inspectors at bay. In the last six months, Iraq has presented the inspectors with a series of "cock-and-bull stories," as one United Nations official put it today.
A United Nations report issued last month contained a laundry list of those lies. Iraq delivered a report on its biological warfare program that was six years late and patently false. It lied about its destruction of missile launchers. It failed to account for missile warheads and engines. It tried to conceal its program to produce nerve agents.
This is so despite the cease-fire resolution that Iraq signed in 1991 at the end of the Persian Gulf war. The resolution gave United Nations inspectors the right to travel anywhere in Iraq to insure that weapons of mass destruction were not being made and to destroy them if found.
As a consequence of this continuing deception, Mr. Hussein still has tons of materiel for making nerve gas and germ weapons, and his Government keeps working on ways to put them into roughly 25 medium-range Scud missiles he has squirreled away, United States military and intelligence officers say.
The Iraqi leader has rebuilt his most important military assembly lines, including a missile plant. His nuclear weapons brain trust remains intact. He has all the equipment and expertise he needs to resume making weapons of mass destruction.
"His production capability has been put on hold" since the gulf war, said Gary Milhollin, a leading private analyst of weapons proliferation. "But his research effort has gone forward. We have to assume his scientists have progressed in understanding how to make better weapons of mass destruction."
The Iraqis have conducted covert operations and deception schemes to hide from the United Nations inspectors. In September they emptied chemical and biological weapons sites of incriminating evidence out the rear door of a building and kept inspectors waiting at the front door.
In the past, Iraqi officials have asserted that weapons-related documents and equipment were accidentally lost when they fell off the back of a truck, were destroyed in riots at a hospital or were tossed out with the trash by a housekeeper.
In a tale that gained mythic status among the United Nations team, Iraqi officials said one set of military records had been burned in a medical file cabinet by a defective X-ray machine.
"They almost never volunteer information," said one official familiar with the inspection team's work. "They wait until confronted with such overwhelming evidence that they are forced to confess their concealment and their lying."
The Iraqi campaign of concealment began days after the gulf war ended. "Iraq decided, in April 1991, to divide its missile force into two parts," said a report dated Oct. 6 issued by the United Nations Special Commission overseeing Iraqi weaponry. "It would present one part to the commission for destruction and illegally retain the second part."
Ever since, Iraq "has continued to try to develop chemical and biological weapons, and possibly even acquire nuclear materials," while "playing a hide-and-seek game" with the United Nations, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said today.
In the beginning, United Nations inspectors focused on Iraq's nuclear weapons programs. They were able to find and destroy its technically advanced imported equipment for enriching uranium to be used in nuclear warheads.
"But they have not found the overall database for his nuclear weapons program," Mr. Milhollin said, "which lets one scientist build on the work of another. You can't destroy weapons research and development unless you kill people. And we know he has not disbanded any of his ballistic missile, nuclear weapons and chemical-biological working groups."
To protect those working groups, three elite services -- the Iraqi Intelligence Service, the Special Security Organization and the Republican Guard -- run an amply financed, highly sophisticated program to secretly import weapons equipment and to undermine inspections.
For example, in September a United Nations team on a 10-day inspection tour of suspected chemical and biological weapons plants "recorded evidence of the removal or movement of documents and records and the destruction of documents" at three sites, the Oct. 6 report said. The documents were hidden and destroyed "while the team was waiting to be allowed to enter."
This kind of resistance is one reason why the United Nations search-and-destroy mission against Iraq's biological weapons has been "unredeemed by progress" since it started, the report said.
Last month, the Iraqis gave the United Nations a declaration of "full, final and complete disclosure" of the biological warfare program. That report, the United Nations said, "fails to give a remotely credible account" of the program.

HEADLINE: THE TRADE BILL: THE IMPACT;
A Handicap, but Clinton Still Has Trade Leverage

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Until today, no Congress had ever blocked a major American initiative toward freer trade since Franklin D. Roosevelt started slashing America's sky-high tariffs in 1934. Even in the depths of recession, the closing of steel and textile mills in the 1970's, and the rise of Japan in the 80's, Congress always came to the reluctant conclusion that freer trade benefits more American workers than it harms.
So what culminated early this morning, when President Clinton angrily concluded that neither persuasion nor deal-making would attract the votes he needed for broad authority to negotiate new trade accords, marked a resounding change. It began with the heated debate over Nafta four years ago, and gathered speed even in an economic boom that has made the country the world's sole economic superpower. 
 But in a world where trade is conducted with increasing disregard for government policies, does the angry statement that thundered off Capitol Hill change very much? Will the President really be hamstrung as he tries to negotiate trading rules with countries that suspect Congress will rewrite any concessions he makes?
Just as important, will other nations -- particularly Asian countries looking for any excuse in their economic turmoil to hold off demands that they open their markets -- use the action of Congress as an excuse?
"There's a lot we don't yet know about what this will mean," Commerce Secretary William M. Daley said today as the Administration was licking its wounds. "But anyone who believes this is just a blip may not be thinking it all the way through."
Most likely, the effects on American power will be subtle, and may not play out for years. President Clinton, for all his protestations, will hardly find himself powerless in the economic arena.
Just as the President has a huge range of military options available to face down military threats, his economic arsenal remains fearsome. He retains broad authority to declare economic sanctions, even closing the huge American market to trading partners who refuse to open their own. After all, even without so-called fast-track negotiating authority, Mr. Clinton has struck more than 100 trade accords since 1994, including major agreements with Japan and China. None, however, required changes in American laws, and thus Congressional approval.
While the President is armed with plenty of sticks, however, what Congress denied him this weekend was any carrots. And in the next few years, he may need plenty.
The art of trade negotiating these days has less to do with one-on-one confrontations with other countries -- the talks that get most of the headlines -- than with the numbingly complex talks that involve scores of nations at a time. Those are the accords that, in the last year, have greatly eased the barriers around the world to trade in computers, chips and telecommunications equipment, areas where the United States is the competitive champion. A full agenda of impending negotiations, in hard-fought areas that range from agriculture to computer services, will be starting in the next two years.
"I'd like to think we can still move ahead with an ambitious trade agenda," Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, said today, trying to put the best face on things. But Ms. Barshefsky is a realist, and she knows that she cannot credibly promise changes in American laws if Congress has the power to reopen whatever deal she strikes.
In short, without fast track authority, one of Ms. Barshefsky's former deputies noted, she cannot utter this sentence: "If all of you do A, B and C, here's what the United States can do for you in return." And Ms. Barshefsky herself, arguing her case in the halls of Congress for the last few months, insisted that unless American negotiators hold the power of dangling incentives, "many other countries will not negotiate with us."
In many cases, that may be true. But in others, economic Realpolitik will take over, Congress or no Congress. America remains the world's biggest market, and the one where every Indian entrepreneur, Italian designer and Malaysian automaker wants to sell his goods.
"There will still be progress, because there are companies around the world that share an interest in getting rid of the political obstacles to doing business," said Mickey Kantor, the former trade representative and a veteran of scores of negotiations. "The only question is whether those deals will be struck with us, or around us. The Canadians understand that. The Europeans understand it. It's only Congress that is having trouble with it."
But the vast majority of Mr. Clinton's own party told him during this debate that American trade policy is skewed in the wrong direction. They sought to equalize the terms of competition between workers in the United States and other countries rather than focus on protecting intellectual property rights or other corporate interests.
The House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, who led the opposition to the fast-track bill, said, "What we are looking for is the chance to put workers' interests first."
While Congress and the White House argue over priorities, however, the risk is that other nations will use Washington's stalemate for their own purposes. And often those purposes are to hold off pressure for them to open up.
"You'll see a lot of interesting reactions in the next few days," predicted Robert Pastor, an Emory University political scientist and expert on relations with Latin America. "Publicly, a lot of countries will express disapointment. But privately there will be relief, especially in countries like Brazil, which was not ready to move quickly to a free trade area of the Americas. And Congress has just given them the excuse."
The first test may come later this month, when President Clinton meets Asian leaders at their annual summit meeting, in Vancouver, British Columbia.
The first of those meetings, in 1993, was brimming over with optimism. Asia was booming, and talking about creating a regional free trade zone. Mr. Clinton was fresh from his victory in Congress for Nafta, the trade agreement that linked the United States, Mexico and Canada, and preaching the need for a foreign policy that spread democracy by spreading the tentacles of trade.
The mood this year will be very different. Battered by currency devaluations, stock market crashes and failing banks, the Asian nations are not in a hurry to let in a lot of new competition. And Mr. Clinton is not exactly in good shape to give speeches about how America is leading the way. He could have the same problem in the spring, at a Latin American meeting in Santiago, Chile, where he is supposed to follow up on a commitment to extend Nafta throughout Latin America. "It could be a pretty hollow summit," Professor Pastor said.
If so, Mr. Clinton has learned, his own inattention to the domestic repercussions of Nafta may be to blame.
"Members of Congress would come in and say 'This is hard for me; two plants closed in my district in the past year,' " said Gene Sperling, the head of Mr. Clinton's National Economic Council. "Then they would raise their hands and say, 'I know, I know, the closings had nothing to do with Nafta.' "
That may be the true lesson of the fast track debate. The reality, Mr. Clinton insisted until his voice grew hoarse, was 4.9 percent unemployment and a booming economy. But the perception across America is that trade agreements lead to anxiety about whether jobs will disappear. And perceptions won the day.
