HEADLINE: THE TRADE BILL: THE WHITE HOUSE;
Party, Spurned, Repays Clinton With Rebellion

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Since he first announced for the Presidency in 1991, Bill Clinton has almost always kept the Democratic Party at arm's length, saying that his ambition was to rise above the "brain-dead politics" of both parties. To prove his independence from his party, Mr. Clinton stiff-armed Democrats on welfare, crime and the balanced budget.
Then he tried to do it again, this time on trade policy. He got Republicans on board. But his staff miscalculated in drafting the bill, the President insulted Congressional Democrats, and the longstanding estrangment between Mr. Clinton and the Congressional wing of his party became outright rebellion. 
 Just after 2 A.M. today, his fellow Democrats chewed off the arm that Mr. Clinton had used to hold them off. They left him, at least for now, a President without a party.
In the end, he was unable to command enough loyalty or fear to win even a quarter of the votes of the House Democratic Caucus. Mr. Clinton's own party has dealt him one of the most humiliating political defeats of his Presidency.
The trade debate also marked the unofficial beginning of the 2000 Presidential campaign. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader and the captain of the anti-fast-track forces, emerged a decisive victor over Vice President Al Gore, who hewed to the Administration line and will pay the price in lost labor money and organizational support.
The President need not look far for the roots of his failure to win so-called fast-track negotiating authority, the power Presidents since Gerald R. Ford have had to negotiate trade treaties that Congress can approve or reject, but not amend.
Interviews with participants on Capitol Hill and senior White House staff members revealed that a number of mistakes and miscalculations by the White House contributed to the President's loss today. Some of the errors were tactical, some substantive and some personal.
But the most surprising mistakes were made by the President, who late last week said that he would win the trade vote easily if it were held in secret, suggesting that lawmakers who opposed the measure did so only because they feared retaliation by labor or environmental groups.
He then compounded the error by asserting that a vote for the bill was a "no-brainer," implying that opponents were acting irrationally.
Those words came back to haunt the White House on Saturday in a bitter confrontation between Representative Peter DeFazio, an Oregon Democrat, and Erskine B. Bowles, the President's aristocratic chief of staff.
Mr. DeFazio, recalling the President's characterizations of the bill's opponents, lashed out at Mr. Bowles, whose wife's family made a fortune in textiles in the South. Calling Mr. Clinton's questioning of lawmakers' motives "outrageous and insulting," Mr. DeFazio said it was tantamount to accusing Mr. Bowles of favoring fast track not on its merits, but to increase the value of his stock portfolio. Several members of the Democratic Caucus jeered at Mr. DeFazio. But others applauded -- and it was their votes that cost the President.
Winning would in any event have been difficult for the President because the issue went to the heart of the Democratic Party's dispute over trade and domestic economics. Many Democrats see blue-collar workers forced into a "race to the bottom" through competition with developing countries that do not have the labor laws and environmental protections of the United States.
But the depth of Mr. DeFazio's anger made it abundantly clear that the President's own discordant words had made success impossible.
This morning Mr. Clinton vowed to try again next year to pass the fast-track bill and offered a partial apology for his words.
He said many Democrats who opposed the trade bill were doing so because of concerns about their constituents, not out of fear of labor retaliation. "I did not question their integrity," the President said, "I questioned their judgment."
But Mr. Clinton's failure was about more than a relatively arcane trade measure. It was a result of long estrangement between him and the Democrats. He declared the party intellectually bankrupt six years ago when he said he sought a "third way" between heartless Republicanism and failed liberalism.
His missteps in his first two years in office cost Democrats control of Congress in 1994. His appropriation of the party apparatus to support his re-election drive last year left the party under a legal cloud and $15 million in debt -- and the Republicans still in charge of both houses of Congress.
He allied himself on the trade issue with the Republican leadership: Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Speaker, and Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Senate majority leader. He waited until late -- mid-September -- to introduce his version of fast-track legislation.
By then organized labor had been in the field for months, working in Congressional districts across the country to drum up opposition.
In late August union members were told to begin flooding their legislators with letters and phone calls, and they did. That flood grew in September. For example, at Steelworkers Local 2705 in Hibbing, Minn., the local's 700 members sent a total of 1,800 letters to the local Congressman and to Minnesota's two Senators.
Labor leaders, often working with environmental groups, also organized anti-fast-track demonstrations in Chicago, Dallas and New York City. At one baseball game in San Francisco, the teamsters' union gave out peanuts and scorecards printed with an anti-fast-track message on the back.
When Mr. Clinton finally did introduce a bill, it was written to attract Republican support and did not include protections of labor and environmental standards demanded by Democrats and allies in the union and environmental movements.
A senior White House aide involved in drafting the bill said the approach reflected the Administration's arrogance as well as inRepublican flexibility. Republicans, the aide said, insisted that the bill not contain language on labor or environmental protections.
"We figured we always pull these things out in the end and we'd pull this one out, too," said the official, who insisted on anonymity.
As the President was unveiling his fast-track bill in the East Room of the White House, opponents across Pennsylvania Avenue were shouting anti-free-trade slogans.
Supporters of free trade -- chiefly big corporations that thrive on exports -- did not begin their lobbying effort until this fall. Big business sat and did nothing, said a wrathful Presidential adviser looking for scapegoats.
There are other causes of the President's defeat. After his narrow victory in 1993 on the North American Free Trade Agreement -- another issue that left the Democrats split -- Mr. Clinton did little to follow through on promises made to secure Democratic support.
He was forced to make similar promises last week to assemble the votes he needed. But according to members of Congress who heard his urgent appeal, it had lost its allure the second time around.
"We got nothing but broken promises out of Nafta," said Representative Esteban Torres, a California Democrat and a leader of the Hispanic Caucus. "I don't think anybody in the caucus appreciated the smoke-and-mirrors pitch he made to us."
Mr. Torres said Hispanic members of Congress were particularly concerned about job loss and environmental degradation along the Mexico-United States border. Despite pledges that such problems would be addressed by Government programs, the Clinton Administration never followed through.
"It was just a terrible, terrible failure," he said.
Ten members of the caucus sent the President a letter late last week saying they would not support the current trade measure because of the disappointments of Nafta. Those 10 votes would have given Mr. Clinton a majority.
One fast-track supporter and White House adviser said the failure to deal with opponents' concerns had been fatal. "These guys were not driven by labor money but by their own constituencies," said this adviser, who insisted on anonymity.
And, this adviser added, this time the President's trademark procrastination cost him in a big way.
"It reminds me of how I got my term papers done in college," the adviser said, "but that's no way to run a country."

HEADLINE: Power Lunch Is 2 in a Row, Just New York Minutes Each

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
In the hushed forest-green of the dining room at Le Bernardin in Manhattan, people are racing against the clock. On any weekday, at least five or six of the 35 tables are having the "Timely Lunch," a menu introduced in May that promises four stars in 30 minutes or less.
Think of it as a kind of "foot on the gas" dining experience geared toward the finish line. "They're here for a purpose -- business," Maguy Le Coze, Le Bernardin's owner, said of her midday clientele. "Eric, my chef, pushed me to do something faster, because we had customers saying, 'We're in a rush.' " 
 Ms. Le Coze and her 30-minute lunch bunch are not lone speeders. Thirty minutes would have left Kal Ruttenstein, fashion director of Bloomingdale's, with 10 minutes to kill. Mr. Ruttenstein has done business over lunch at 44, the Royalton Hotel restaurant, in 20 minutes -- between fashion shows.
His order: rare tuna. "I couldn't have done it if I'd asked for it well done," Mr. Ruttenstein said.
In the red-meat economy of 1997, the business lunch is executive bread-breaking at a kind of neck-snapping pace. For anyone who can remember the three-martini lunch, meet the 0.3 martini lunch. Hold the martini.
"You're basically trying to make a phone call with a meal," said Jerry Della Femina, chief executive of the advertising agency Jerry & Ketchum.
If you can do lunch in half the time, you can also do it twice. At least. Some business diners are double- and triple-decking their lunches like club sandwiches.
"The idea of entertaining at lunch is an oxymoron now," said Sally Quinn, a journalist and author of "The Party: A Guide to Adventurous Entertaining" (Simon & Schuster, 1997). "People don't drink; they eat salads. They want in and out."
If nobody has the time for lunch, nobody's giving it up, either. The power breakfast and the early-bird, 5:30 working dinner are not about to unseat the business lunch in restaurants across town or across the country. But the midday time-belt cinch has produced odd bulges. "People are definitely trying to do in one hour what they did in two," said Susan Lyne, executive vice president of the motion picture group at Walt Disney Company. "There's no foreplay to lunch anymore," she added.
More than two dozen restaurants in midtown report similar Type-A feeding behavior at lunchtime, from media-industry heavies like Michael's and the Judson Grill to the Four Seasons and 57-57, both popular with the investment and banking communities.
How is the double lunch done?
"You have one lunch at 12:15," said Marcy Posner, an agent at the William Morris Agency. "You make your next lunch at 1:30. It's not hard to do -- some people like to eat early, some late."
Ms. Posner holds the fort at her regular table at Michael's. The restaurant resets it between guests. "It's a finely timed thing," Ms. Posner said. "But people are very understanding about your having a limited amount of time. Sometimes I introduce them," she added.
Restaurants will also hold two tables and move a host between guests, when introductions between interested parties would be more collision than collusion. Think of it as culinary call-waiting.
"The host will inform us: 'Listen, I have two guys; I don't want the one to know the other is here,' " said John Sheedy, the day manager of 57-57. "We have a very big restaurant -- we would arrange to have the second guest at the other end from the first table."
Mr. Della Femina, an East Hampton restaurateur himself, has bounced in and out of three restaurants for one lunch.
"An appetizer at the Four Seasons with one client, then a bowl of clams as a main course with another client at '21,' dessert and coffee with a third," he said. "It's not about socializing; it's about being able to discuss things without associates running in and out of your office."
How does Mr. Della Femina effect the delicate art of taking leave of his first guest?
"You say, 'I have an appointment,' " he said. "The worst thing you can say to someone is, 'I'm leaving you now because I'm going to have lunch with someone else.' "
Some people run a quick defense about the game of musical tables and musical guests. Anna Wintour, editor of Vogue, says she never double-lunches. She's still smarting from being serial-breakfasted by the "very famous film executive" who stacks his guests like pancakes. She discovered the list next to his plate when he got up to go to the bathroom. "There was someone scheduled every 15 minutes," she said. "I was horrified."
It should surprise no one, but the double lunch is also bicoastal.
"I've done it at the Grill," said Bob Bookman, an agent at Creative Artists Agency, referring to the Grill on the Alley in Beverly Hills, Calif. Mr. Bookman lunches out four days a week and occasionally double-lunches. He's up front about it with both parties." You disclose what you're doing," Mr. Bookman said. "You say: 'I have this problem; I need to see both of you.' "
Robert Spivak, a founding partner of the Grill, said, "It's much more prevalent in the last year." He fingers "the aggressive newcomer."
"It's the agents," Mr. Spivak said, "who are finding they can get more deals done."
Some industry folk base their lunch bookings on the same yield-management that the airlines' use: they double-book and assume that someone will fail to show. "It's a crisis-motivated town, so I know I'll have cancellations," said one Miramax marketing executive who insisted on anonymity.
For now, popular business restaurants in Chicago, Boston and Washington report that the rest of the country seems to be holding the line at the single lunch, though the business hour has been shrunk past a psychiatrist's hour: to 45 minutes.
Spruce, a restaurant in Chicago popular with advertising and publishing executives, has an Executive Privileges program. Regular lunch guests pre-program their visits by filling out a questionnaire about food and service preferences. It helps return them to their desk in under an hour.
Dan Sachs, the owner, has seen no evidence of the serial lunch.
"This is Chicago, not New York," he said.
Once an open field for the big bicoastal players, the 30-minute lunch is becoming more routine for the average unstoppable New Yorker, who looks at a pause in the day like lunch the way a cabbie looks at a red light.
"With my to-do list -- the things I have to cross off -- when my day starts at 6:00 and ends at 9:30, I have to squeeze every moment in I can," said Karen Druziako, divisional vice president of Access Accounting Professionals, who ordered the $32 prix fixe "Timely Lunch" last week at Le Bernardin. (Two-courses, not three -- coffee, no dessert -- shaves $10 and 30 minutes off the regular prix fixe.) Ms. Druziako will meet up to 9 people at breakfast, from 6 to 7 A.M., and often has multiple lunches, commuting between her own table and a client's table.
"Do I want to work that way? Absolutely not," she said. "But you only have certain hours in the day to do business. The people I meet with -- we're all doing the same thing. It's basically time management."
The 30-minute lunch and the double lunch may be bringing more people together, but it's dividing as it conquers.
"I'd call it the indigestion special," said Ken Aretsky, owner of Patroon, who claims to have seen no 30 minute record-setting or double lunches.
Nor has Drew Nieporent, owner of Nobu and TriBeCa Grill. "They're lucky enough to get the first table," he said.
At some restaurants, including Lespinasse, business lunchers are booking in and checking out more quickly this fall. "It's easier to get a reservation for lunch than it was a year ago," said Janie Esparza, assistant to the chef, Gray Kunz, confirming what managers at Chanterelle and Le Bernardin had to say. At Lespinasse 70 percent of the lunch crowd is choosing the prix fixe, the quickest full meal one can order.
But it's still too soon to tell whether cutting into the business hour will cut into profits. "If it became more popular, we'd have to sit down and rethink it," said Sally A. Sarmiento, general manager of Le Bernardin, speaking of the Timely Lunch.
 So what do the powerful put down to stay light as prizefighters on their feet?
"The Cobb salad at Michael's -- without the bacon, without the avocado," said Susan Lyne at Disney.
"A rare hamburger and a micro-waved potato," Anna Wintour said, describing her Concorde-like one-course meal.
 Why the rush? Is it only a quick cash-in on economic opportunities in a bull business market, or is it something subtler? If time is precious, there are those who will try wearing it on their sleeve.
"Time is a currency now, whereby people maintain their status," said Dr. John Robinson, director of the Americans' Use of Time Project at the University of Maryland. "One way of demonstrating your power is to make your time scarce. 'I'm too busy -- a.k.a. too important -- to spend the whole lunch on one deal, or one meal.' "
Juliet Schor, a Harvard economist and the author of "The Overworked American: The Unexpected Decline in Leisure" (Basic Books, 1992), said: "It's a longer-term trend than just a good economy."
"Business lunches in restaurants are a visible conspicuous consumption norm," she explained. "When those intensify, people have to do it just to stay in the game. The new status symbol might be, 'Was I the solo guest?' "
Dr. Robinson has good and bad news for get-aheaders who meal and deal quickly to succeed. "We found that time is irrelevant," he said, referring to a study published this year. "There doesn't seem to be much relationship between how people spend their time and their success. "You could have a five-minute lunch and close a deal, and an extra five minutes could mean a disagreement."
Dr. Robinson's next time-study project: sex.
Don't ask.

HEADLINE: Blacks' Story of Harassment Is the Backdrop for New Fines

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
William and Gloria Smith finally found a place they wanted to live in 1993, on two acres of land in Belle, W.Va., just south of Charleston. Two years later, they put up a home.
That is when the trouble began. 
 For more than a year after they moved in, the Smiths contend, members of the family living next door harassed them with racial epithets, threatened them with weapons and several times tried to run Mrs. Smith off the road while she was driving. Once, the Smiths say, a white cross appeared on the neighbors' lawn -- with toy ducks, painted black, hanging from the crossbar.
The Smiths are black. Their neighbors, John and Mary Hobbs and their son, John Wayne Hobbs, and his wife, Brenda, are white.
Until today, the Smiths' travails were little-known outside the Charleston area. But today, as President Clinton convened a conference on hate crimes, the Smiths were included in a news conference at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, where Housing Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo announced that the Administration would increase civil penalties for hate crimes committed in any neighborhood.
Using the Smiths' case as an example, Mr. Cuomo said that if the any of the Hobbses were found liable under the new regulations, each could be fined $11,000 for every offense, with a total limit of $55,000. Under the previous regulation, a first-time offender could be fined $11,000 for all the acts he was found to have committed.
""We would like to be able to say this case is unique," Mr. Cuomo said. "It is far from unique. We have received about 34,000 complaints, although this situation is somewhat more dramatic."
The Hobbses had little to say on the matter. Mary Hobbs declined to comment and said her husband, a retired laborer, would have nothing to say. "But I deny all accusations," Mrs. Hobbs added.
John Wayne Hobbs, an unemployed truck driver, said there was "no truth" to any of the Smith complaints. "I don't recall any of that happening," he said.
West Virginia has relatively few black residents, just 3.1 percent of the state's 1.7 million people, according to the 1990 census, which also showed that of the 1,408 residents of Belle, only 10 were black.
Mr. Smith, 30, a Navy veteran and now a lineman for a power company, said it did not take him and his wife long to decide that the Hobbses did not want them and their three children, Courtney, 5 years old; William, 4, and Cierra, 18 months, living next door.
"It is very difficult to raise children when you live next door to hatred," Mrs. Smith, 26, said.
Mr. Smith continued: "You wonder if they are going to break your windows out, if they're going to burn your house down."
The Smiths began legal proceedings against the Hobbses last March, by filing housing discrimination complaints with HUD and with the West Virginia Human Rights Commission.
The housing agency found probable cause to take the case before an administrative law judge or into Federal court. The Smiths have until Nov. 18 to decide which route, if any, they will pursue.
In interviews with the investigator, Ira Goldstein, witnesses corroborated some of the Smiths' accounts.
The report states that one witness, who was not identified, said John Hobbs told her that he "planned to gather poisonous snakes, i.e. rattlesnakes and copperheads, and put them on the Complainants' dwelling site."
Mr. Smith said that since the investigation began, the Hobbses have not bothered his family.

HEADLINE: THE TRADE BILL: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON RETREATS ON TRADE POWER; PROSPECTS SLIGHT

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton conceded today that the trade legislation he had called crucial to the nation's global leadership was dead for this year, and the Republican leader of the Senate said that the measure's chances of being passed are even more remote for next year, when Congress is up for re-election.
"Politically it will probably be next to impossible," Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, said. 
 The early morning announcement by Republican leaders that they were shelving the bill at Mr. Clinton's request, rather than allowing the measure to be defeated, marked Mr. Clinton's most severe legislative setback since his proposal for national health care died in 1994.
The House legislation would have extended the authority that all Presidents since Gerald R. Ford have had in negotiating trade agreements that Congress can either approve or disapprove but not amend. Mr. Clinton let those powers lapse three years ago rather than risk a vote that would have splintered the Democrats. He sought to renew the powers only this year.
The decision to shelve the bill came after a long weekend of increasingly desperate arm-twisting and political wrangling by the White House --and considerable efforts by the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich -- that still left supporters short by a handful of votes.
For Mr. Clinton, the defeat indicated that despite his high popularity he has been unable to sell his vision of trade expansion to either the American public or a significant section of his own party. Many on Capitol Hill were saying quietly that the setback was the beginning of the President's lapse into lame-duck status.
The legislative defeat also marked the first time in decades that any President had lost a major Congressional initiative toward freer trade.
"I sense a tone of protectionism that is harder than I have seen in the 27 years that I have been in Congress," said Representative Bill Archer, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, who had worked with the Clinton administration to draft the bill.
Today Mr. Clinton, seeking to minimize his loss, said he would "regroup a little bit and find a way to succeed." The President denied that his loss on this issue was as significant as his defeat on national health care, which he described as "caught up in politics and partisanship in even a more profound way."
He said of health care, "When it was dead, it was dead. This is not dead. I will be very surprised if we are not successful in developing a bipartisan, constructive, successful approach to fast track before this Congress is over."
But Mr. Gingrich was cautious about assessing when the legislation could be revived.
Organized labor and House Democrats, who overwhelmingly rejected the trade policy of their party's President, were jubilant. Democratic leaders predicted that their strength would force Mr. Clinton to rethink his approach to the global economy, and to use the power of trade sanctions to keep developing nations from lowering labor and environmental standards to win in the global marketplace.
"The real question before us now is whether we can connect our values of environmental quality, worker and human rights to our economic policy," said the House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, who trumped the President and set down a marker for 2000, when he is expected to mount a primary challenge against Vice President Gore.
Mr. Gephardt said he would introduce a trade measure later this week that he thought could command support from a vast majority of Democrats and some Republicans.
But Representative Tom DeLay, the House majority whip, who had been seeking Republican votes for Mr. Clinton all Sunday night, said, "We are not going to rewrite a bill to suit Mr. Gephardt."
Mr. Clinton today tried minimize his differences with his fellow Democrats. "We have been having a debate in our party for several years on the question of trade and its role in our economic future," he said. But he noted that despite the defeat of his position in the House, "We clearly have a majority of the Democratic mayors and governors, and we had a majority in the Senate."
Mr. Clinton revived the drive for the fast track measure in his State of the Union address in January, but he then failed to introduce a bill until September.
Business groups who were on his side held back their support until they had seen the actual legislative language. And that gave a head start in the lobbying wars to organized labor, which ferociously opposed the measure and began running television commercials against it over the summer.
Republicans generally supported Mr. Clinton's free trade position, but the question demonstrated how sharply the Democratic Party is divided over the changes in the global economy.
Mr. Clinton has argued that Americans stand to gain from an economy dominated by high technology and an educated work force. He has repeatedly argued that a third of the 13.5 million new jobs that have been created during his Presidency are trade-related.
But many House Democrats contend that blue-collar workers are being forced into a "race to the bottom" by competing with developing countries without the labor laws and environmental protections of the United States.
Also hanging over the debate was the North American Free Trade Agreement of 1993, which Mr. Clinton pushed through Congress primarily with Republican votes. "Nafta did not turn out as good as it could have," Mr. Gephardt said today. "It did not turn out well for the American people."
On Sunday night, despite a weekend of frantic lobbying and deal-making by the White House and the muscle of Mr. Gingrich, the House was thought to be six to eight votes short of the majority needed to pass the trade bill. Mr. Gingrich said that on any usual piece of legislation he would have taken the gamble of holding the vote and seeing if any last holdouts came to his side.
But he said it was not prudent to roll the dice on trade legislation. "Putting the prestige of the President on the world stage and having people see defeat is a very high risk," he said.
Today Mr. Clinton attributed his defeat not just to rebel Democrats, who stood 80 percent against him, but to Republican conservatives who were holding back their votes unless the President would change his policy of allowing United States funds to go to international family planning organizations that counsel abortions.
"Had we been able to resolve that, I think we would have gotten enough votes on the Republican side to go with the Democrats' votes we had to pass the bill," Mr. Clinton said.
Republicans disagreed. They said that even if the family-planning issue had been settled on their terms, the trade measure would still have been defeated because of the President's inability to sway more Democrats. "There were better than four Republicans ready to vote yes for every Democrat ready to vote yes," Mr. DeLay said.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Alcohol Taxes Favored To Help Poor, Study Says

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
Most New Jerseyans would prefer an additional tax on alcohol and cigarettes to pay for health care for poor, uninsured patients at hospitals, according to a survey released yesterday.
Of 800 respondents, 76 percent supported raising taxes on cigarettes and 73 percent would raise taxes on alcohol, said Rick Sinding, executive director of New Jersey Health Decisions, a consumer group. 
 Nearly $300 million a year is taken from the State Unemployment Trust Fund to pay for charity care under a law that expires in December. Mr. Sinding said 30 percent of respondents favored that method, which replaced a surcharge on all patients' hospital bills.

HEADLINE: Public Housing Shows Its Age;
A Crisis of Advancing Repairs and Declining Money

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
In the 57 years since Mayor Fiorello La Guardia laid their cornerstone to the strains of a brass band, Vladeck Houses on the Lower East Side have embodied the promise of public housing.
Zigzagging gracefully through blocks once crowded with the Corlears Hook slums, they tell the neighborhood's immigrant story on every door buzzer: older Jewish and Italian tenants, joined through the years by Chinese, Puerto Rican and now Dominican familes, struggling to make a start. 
 But while the Vladeck Houses hold true to their mission, they have trouble holding out the rain.
Roofs are spiderwebbed with cracks. Football-sized chunks of concrete have crumbled from ceilings. Dozens of frustrated residents, like Paula Patterson, 77, have leaks they angrily compare to showers. "The ceiling gets patched up," she says, "and it falls right down again."
As the city's public housing system turns 62 this year, it is beginning to show its age. At least a dozen of the oldest housing projects -- more than 140 buildings around the city, containing nearly 10 percent of the system's 180,000 apartments -- suffer from serious structural problems, City Housing Authority officials say.
But as the authority moves to fix the problems, taking more apartments off rent rolls for major repairs than at any time in its history, it is confronting a crisis: Over the last three years, Congress has cut almost $100 million, or about a fourth, of the authority's annual budget for major capital repairs.
In a sense, New York City's public housing has become the victim of its own relative success.
Compared with most big-city public-housing systems, New York's housing projects have traditionally been considered remarkably stable -- in large part because they have had a high proportion of working people. And so, while other cities have found themselves forced to demolish failing high-rise complexes, New York's projects have endured.
But now, New York housing officials say the cuts in Federal aid, especially coming on top of similar sharp reductions in Federal money for day-to-day operations, threaten that distinction.
"We're faced with a situation where we have some very difficult choices to make," said Paul T. Graziano, the authority's general manager.
The cuts by Congress, which supplies almost all of the authority's money, were made by the Republican majority in response to years of demonstrated waste and fraud in many cities, and have stung every large housing authority in the country. In Los Angeles, two-year repair jobs have been stretched to five or more. In Cleveland, officials have left some older projects only half renovated, with waterlogged walls, cracked sewer pipes and some apartments vacant because they are unlivable. In several other cities, long-planned repairs have been postponed.
But housing experts say the New York system is in the worst straits, not only because of its size (it is the nation's largest public housing system, with 600,000 residents, more than the population of Seattle) but also because it is in one of the nation's most crowded and expensive cities.
Other authorities can save money by demolishing their oldest buildings -- most of them are only partly occupied anyway -- and replacing them with smaller projects spread over more land, but New York cannot. Its buildings are nearly full, it has little extra land to build on, and officials say that high construction costs mean that even multimillion-dollar repair projects are cheaper than tearing down and rebuilding in New York.
Compounding the cuts, the authority must dip into the diminished repair money to pay for two vast emergency projects: it recently had to conduct a $125 million effort to sandblast flammable paint from stairwells after flash fires killed two tenants, and it must embark on $250 million in renovations to make about 9,000 apartments accessible for the disabled.
The lost repair money could have paid for three or four huge, and sorely needed, rebuilding projects, officials said. Without it, they acknowledge, they have been forced to concentrate on projects in the most dire need, like Vladeck, where roofs are to be replaced beginning early next year, and the 59-year-old Williamsburg Houses in Brooklyn, where a $35 million overhaul is now under way.
Meanwhile, the city has deferred major work on other older projects, like the 60-year-old Harlem River Houses in East Harlem, which are a designated city landmark. More than 50 apartments there now sit vacant -- some have been empty for more than two years -- because of structural problems, as officials plan a long-awaited renovation project, now expected to begin next year.
The delays suspend tenants in a kind of infuriating limbo. "Pieces of paint and rocks kept falling down in my bed and on the couch and the tables," said Idena Banks, 51, a Harlem River tenant who moved out of her crumbling apartment two years ago to a lower floor. "They've been saying they were going to fix this place for I don't know how long."
Among other projects needing work, Marcy, Gowanus, Sumner and Sheepshead-Nostrand Houses in Brooklyn, and Wald Houses in lower Manhattan and Marble Hill Houses in the Bronx await major repairs for cracking concrete and bricks, a process known as spalling, officials say.
But at those and other older projects, an increasing amount of rebuilding money must be used for simply patching up ceilings, walls and aging plumbing, wiring and boilers until they can be replaced.
"When money gets tight, it is the capital improvement that gets deferred," said Nicholas Calace, an assistant deputy general manager, whose office speaks derisively of the triage maintenance jobs as "five-to-tens" -- a reference to how long the work will last.
"You've got to provide heat," said Mr. Calace. "You've got to provide elevator service. Bigger things have to wait."
The needs are made more dire because, for the last several years, the Federal Government has provided only about 85 percent of the money that the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Renewal estimates that housing authorities should have for day-to-day operations. Those cuts have forced many authorities to consider abandoning the very premise of public housing as a provider of last resort for the neediest.
Drawing sharp criticism from advocates for the poor, New York City has joined other authorities in considering turning over buildings to private managers and charging higher rents by increasing the number of working-class tenants, who can pay more. In the meantime, the authorities have trimmed their staffs, leaving maintenance and janitorial positions unfilled. (The New York authority is cutting its work force of 15,000 by at least 1,000 through attrition.)
Earlier this month, Congress passed an appropriations bill for the current fiscal year that provides the nation's housing authorities with the same amount of money it provided the previous year: $2.9 billion for operations and $2.5 billion for capital repairs and new construction. But housing officials complain that the appropriation is really a cut, because the price of labor and supplies continues to increase.
So authorities face a painful choice: Do they use all their scarce capital repair dollars to fix crumbling buildings? Or do they shift some of those dollars to make up for shortcomings in maintenance, so buildings need fewer capital dollars down the road?
Representative Rick A. Lazio of Long Island, a leading Republican in Washington on housing policy, said one reason for the cuts was that many authorities wasted the money they were given or did not use it at all. In Washington, for example, officials now say $180 million in unspent capital money piled up over more than six years.
"There has to be accountability," said Mr. Lazio, the sponsor of a measure to dismantle much of the Federal regulatory system for public housing. "We have to know that the money is being spent wisely."
The New York authority's managers, regarded as among the most effective in the country, contend that they have spent their money wisely and are being unfairly punished for others' mistakes. They warn that problems are growing.
At a time when 130,000 people are on waiting lists to get into public housing, slightly more than 1,600 apartments, out of the total of about 180,000, are not available to rent now because they are under repair or waiting to be repaired. And 3,480 more are not available because they are being rebuilt for the disabled. As recently as 1992, there were no units off the rent rolls, said Mr. Graziano, the general manager.
But the number will probably continue to rise for several years as reconstruction needs arise and projects take longer to start and complete.
In the Vladeck Houses -- where the five-year, $30 million reconstruction project will begin next year, and 33 families have been moved out of their apartments into other buildings -- engineers suspect that beach sand was used to mix some concrete. Salt and organic matter in the sand caused steel bars to rust, creating fissures in the roofs that let in rain.
In one building, the drizzle got so bad that workers recently resorted to hanging a tin slab beneath a hallway ceiling. Rain still pours in, but now it runs down the slab and back outside through a rubber hose dangling from a window. Gaspare DeGaetano, the authority's director of construction, surveyed the contraption on a recent tour of the project and, shaking his head, pronounced it "true Rube Goldberg."
"But it's what you have to do," he said, "until you can address the problem."

HEADLINE: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: THE OVERVIEW;
Iraqi Assails U.S. at the U.N. And Says Albright Is a Liar

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, sharply attacked the United States today as he pressed his country's case at the United Nations, calling Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright a liar. But Iraq failed to make good on its threat to shoot down American U-2 surveillance flights over Iraq as the flights resumed today.
In Washington, the United States sent its strongest signal yet that it may be preparing for military action in Iraq when Defense Secretary William S. Cohen and Gen. Henry H. Shelton, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, canceled trips to Asia that had been scheduled for this week. 
 For now, the United States was pursuing the course of diplomacy, and along with Britain called on the Security Council to impose new sanctions on Iraq. The actions are to retaliate for Iraq's threat to expel Americans serving on the international arms control team established to monitor Iraq's compliance with the 1991 cease-fire agreement that ended the Persian Gulf war.
Mr. Aziz continued to try to water down the existing sanctions today, presenting Secretary General Kofi Annan with a list of new demands that included taking part in any future Security Council debate on Iraq and substituting "neutral" aircraft for the U-2's.
Iraq's recent behavior has aroused such widespread outrage that diplomats here said they were optimistic that the new sanctions would be adopted as early as midweek, even though similar ones failed to win passage just three weeks ago.
The American representative here, Bill Richardson, said the draft resolution had four parts: a condemnation of President Saddam Hussein's Government for its recent challenges to the United Nations inspection system; a demand for full cooperation in the future; a ban on international travel by high Iraqi officials, and an unspecified threat of further actions if problems continue.
"If there's no Iraqi compliance, all bets are go, all options are open," Mr. Richardson said.
He called the draft proposal "a strong resolution with teeth that would send an unmistakable message to Iraq."
The crisis with Iraq began on Oct. 29, when Iraqi officials said they would expel Americans on the arms-inspection team, and threatened to shoot down American U-2's. They acted after signs that the consensus to continue sanctions on Iraq was fraying. But their actions appeared to have stiffened the resolve at the United Nations, and Mr. Aziz met a cool reception here today in his meetings with the Secretary General and other diplomats.
Mr. Aziz criticized Ms. Albright in a news conference today outside the Security Council. On Sunday Ms. Albright, appearing on a television news program, called President Hussein a "congenital liar."
Asked about Ms. Albright's statement, Mr. Aziz said, "Those who accuse the others of being liars, they are liars."
A reporter then asked, "So Madeleine Albright is herself a liar?" Mr. Aziz replied, "I hoped she wouldn't be, but unfortunately she is."
Mr. Richardson said later that he was personally offended by the insult to the Secretary of State.
During Mr. Aziz's meeting with Mr. Annan, the Iraqi argued that there were too many Americans on the arms-inspection teams and that the U-2 surveillance planes used to back the disarmament commission in Iraq were working for Washington, not the United Nations. The Security Council has not decided whether to give Mr. Aziz a hearing.
"He did not give me the answer I had hoped for in Baghdad," Mr. Annan said later at a news conference, flanked by three high-level envoys he sent to Iraq last week. "He hasn't given it to me yet."
In a reply to the Secretary General, the Iraqis included with a letter a list of demands for changes in the way sanctions are applied and reviewed by the Security Council. The demands include the appointment of an international team of experts to judge whether Iraq is in substantial compliance with the arms-destruction program, and if not, a statement of what needs to be done, while sanctions are gradually dismantled.
In addition to reducing the role of Americans and having the U-2's replaced by "neutral" aircraft, Baghdad wants to put off limits to inspectors any sites deemed important to national security. Inspectors had begun to conclude that important information and perhaps weapons stocks they seek are under the control of Mr. Hussein's Republican Guards.
Mr. Annan had asked Mr. Hussein to revoke his decision ordering Americans working on the inspection commission out of the country.
In Baghdad today, the Government made a show of moving families with babies and small children into Mr. Hussein's lavish palaces to act as human shields for their leader against American attacks. United Nations officials say the Iraqi President, driven by fears about enemies from within and without, sleeps in a different bed almost every night. Iraqis told arms inspectors that sophisticated poison-detection kits found by the United Nations were used to test his food.
Mr. Aziz is finding that foreign governments and United Nations officials are not cutting him much slack now. Mr. Hussein's action against Americans in Iraq has cost him sympathy, if only temporarily. Today Mr. Aziz stopped short of new threats to the United States or the United Nations, and seemed resigned to the presence of Americans in Iraq if their numbers were reduced.
On his way to New York, the Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister met in Paris today with Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine of France. After that meeting, the Foreign Ministry issued a statement saying France had told Mr. Aziz that Iraq's threats to Americans were "in violation of Security Council resolutions, as are any action that are liable to hinder the activities of the Special Commission."
Mr. Aziz met here with Sergei Lavrov, the Russian representative, and envoys from the nonaligned movement, as well as with Qin Huasun, China's representative and this month's Security Council president.
"We are ready to fulfill all our obligations," Mr. Aziz said after his meeting with Mr. Qin. "We have no intention to enter into a conflict with the Security Council or the Special Commission. It is in the best interests of Iraq to finish this job." But he also repeated Iraqi demands that a timetable be established for the end of sanctions, which Washington says is out of the question.
The Security Council also heard reports today from Mr. Annan and the envoys he sent to Baghdad last week -- Lakhdar Brahimi of Algeria, Emilio Cardenas of Argentina and Jan Eliasson of Sweden -- as well as Richard Butler, the executive chairman of the inspection commission.
Mr. Cardenas, a banker and former Argentine representative at the United Nations, said in an interview today that he had come away from the trip to Baghdad with the sense that the Iraqis, because of their extreme isolation. had unrealistic expectations of what they could get away with. The country has been under blanket sanctions since its invasion of Kuwait in 1990 and cannot hope to have them lifted until certified to be free of weapons of mass destruction.
The Argentine envoy also said that with "government by terror" in Iraq, there were few voices speaking out for alternative policies.
But Mr. Cardenas, who as a Security Council member negotiated with Iraq more than a year ago to establish the plan for limited oil sales to pay for food and medicine, said he was stunned by the real suffering he saw in Baghdad. He said that the country seemed to be "in the doldrums" and that even in well-off sections of the capital electricity was in short supply, water was unsafe and unreliable and sanitation standards were very low.
"People are thinking daily about their fight for survival," he said. He believes that when the crisis is over, the Security Council should look again at how to alleviate the hardships of average Iraqis, perhaps by adjusting the "oil for food" agreement to allow some public services to be repaired.

Mr. Aziz was leaving the Security Council after talking with its president, Qin Huasun of China; a meeting with Secretary General Kofi Annan took place earlier in the day.

HEADLINE: Post Plans a Printing Plant For the Bronx or Jersey City

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The New York Post is negotiating with New York State officials to lease a site in an unused rail yard in the South Bronx for a $150 million printing plant, while simultaneously considering an alternative location in Jersey City.
The company is trying to secure a 17-acre tract that straddles the Harlem River yard and an adjacent parcel that has a bus terminal. The Post is also negotiating for tax breaks for the plant. The company is also meeting officials in Jersey City about tax incentives at two potential sites near Liberty State Park, including one that has a printing plant for The Daily News. 
 The Post prints the paper in the former Journal-American building on South Street, near the Brooklyn Bridge, that William Randolph Hearst built in 1926. The company has said it wants to be in a new plant by early 1999 and is buying four-color presses.
Martin Singerman, president and publisher of The Post, owned by News America Publishing, confirmed that the company was negotiating with the two states. But, he said, The Post has told New York officials that it wants to remain in the city.
"We told them upfront we would do everything possible to stay in New York City," Mr. Singerman said. "But we have to hedge our bets and make sure we're protected, since there's only one site available in New York City. If this doesn't work out, we would probably find ourselves going to New Jersey."
Last year, the city gave News America a $20.7 million package of sales-tax exemptions and low electricity rates for its headquarters at 1211 Avenue of the Americas, at 47th Street, after it had threatened to move some employees out of the city.
News America had transferred 400 employees to the midtown building from South Street a year earlier.
Both The New York Times and The Daily News have been given tax breaks when building new plants. In 1993, The Daily News announced that it would move its printing operations from Brooklyn to Jersey City, after New Jersey had given the paper $35 million in cash and tens of millions of dollars in tax breaks. The New York Times received a $29 million tax package in 1992 for a new printing plant in College Point, Queens.
The State Economic Development Commissioner, Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, who has met executives from The Post, said he had been unaware of the News America tax break last year. He added that he was optimistic that the state would be able to offer an attractive plan for the printing plant.
The Post has been searching for a location off and on since 1994, when it announced that it would buy new presses. On several occasions, The Post returned to the dormant 96-acre rail yard, which is operated by the Galesi Group, a developer, under a long-term lease from the state. The location is close to highways and has a rail spur, which could be used to deliver newsprint. "The question is whether we can get the site at the appropriate time," said David W. Levinson, a broker at Insignia/Edward S. Gordon, which represents The Post. "We're getting a significant amount of cooperation."
The talks are complicated by The Post's attempt to lease a nine-acre area with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus garage that is not scheduled to close for several years. The site also sits next to a proposed $440 million paper mill that would transform waste paper from trash into rolls of newsprint.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 17, 1997, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Nov. 11 about The New York Post's plan for a new printing plant referred incorrectly to incentives offered to The Daily News in 1993 to move to Jersey City. Though the amount was widely reported at the time to be $35 million, The News calls that figure exaggerated. Its grants and loans totaled at least $15 million, along with other incentives.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Demo-Labor Party

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The "new" Democrats have been routed by the old. The Democratic Party is now America's Labor Party. Richard Gephardt has replaced Al Gore as front-runner for the Democratic nomination in 2000.
Surely the man in the White House will have his successes, and his chosen successor's name recognition will maintain Gore poll ratings. But the chickens of triangulation are coming home to roost. 
 What a spectacle: the Oval Office arm-twister himself, and all the President's men, were unable to get more than one in four House Democrats to give him "fast track" authority to negotiate trade deals without Congressional amendment. Symbolically, the left wing of the House, behind minority leader Gephardt, rose up and declared its abhorrence of the middle of the road.
John Sweeney, boss of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., made it happen. He proved he had the money, the troops and the clout within the Democratic Party to call the shots. One tactical Clinton blunder was to blurt out the truth about Sweeney's domination. "I wish we could have a secret vote in the Congress -- we'd pass it 3 or 4 to 1" -- was rightly taken by insulted House Democrats to mean their votes were sold for union money or cast in fear of union punishment.
Another Clinton blunder was to become the first President to let his all-or-nothing trading power lapse, delaying the vote last year lest it conflict with his No. 1 Priority: getting re-elected. He subordinated all other considerations, from honest fund-raising to global economic leadership, to his personal political interest.
Now we come to the strategic blunder. Much has been made of Clinton's political brilliance in responding to the 1994 debacle by moving to the center, adopting the G.O.P.'s balanced-budget goal, stealing the opposition's clothing by putting trade ahead of human rights.
But to what end? Clinton in the first year of his second term is like Bush in the last year of his only term: an exhausted volcano. The Comeback Kid, having left his political home, has no place to come back to.
By straddling the fence; by being liberal on affirmative action while taking conservative positions on crime; by escalating class war while abandoning New Deal entitlements; by enshrining deficit reduction while ducking on Medicare and Social Security reform; by rattling the saber at Saddam while neglecting our missile defenses -- our most pro-choice President has stripped Americans of our choice of directions.
Centrism is fine when it is the result of competing interests. Thesis; antithesis; synthesis. But centrism is vapid when it is the suffocator of interests, seeking to please rather than striving to move. Clinton's approach, in most cases, has been to follow the primrose path of polling down the middle: his motto has become a firm "there must be no compromise with compromise."
That's why we right-wingers, though saddened by this setback to free trade, welcome the emergence of the Demo-Labor Party. It has an identity, even a soul; it knows where it stands and is willing to take that principled stand; and it is a loser.
Demo-Labor is a loser, that is, in national elections that offer choices on the economics of redistribution, or the politics of central control, or the folly of multilateralism.
But Demo-Labor can be a winner in primary elections in the party of the left. It has the money and the bodies, while Bill Clinton's self-absorption has bankrupted the party and decimated its roster of elected officials. (In terms of electoral results in Congress and statehouses, Clinton is the best Democratic President the Republicans have ever had.)
What's next? Having established his dominance, Sweeney will go underground. Having shown Clinton his impotence, Democrats in Congress -- especially Gephardt -- will now feed the duck limping around the White House with great deference.
That will be a charade, of course; the power has passed. The coattail-free President with the non-transferable popularity has been outbid, and his displeasure no longer strikes fear in the Democratic ranks.
Sweeney's Demo-Labor task now is to attract urbanists, greens, minorities and especially women; to secure bedfellowship with Perot-Buchananites, and to find an attractive lefty who can play the centrist without actually selling out.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies Again vs. Yen On Weak Outlook for Japan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose to its third consecutive six-month high against the Japanese yen yesterday on expectations that officials in the United States and Japan will let the yen weaken further as Japan's economy shows more signs of faltering.
The conspicuous silence from both countries about the dollar's strength contrasted sharply with the situation earlier this year, when officials in Japan complained as the dollar rose above 120 yen, prompting traders to sell dollars. 
 "Now, they're likely to say let's lay off or they're going to fall into a full-fledged depression," said David Moline, a currency trader at Norwest Bank in Minneapolis. "Japan has to let the yen devalue to compete" with other exporters, he said.
The dollar settled at 125.03 yen in New York, up from 124.40 late Monday, to reach its highest level since May 7. The dollar was unchanged at 1.7077 German marks.
The British pound rose to its highest level of the year against the dollar, in part because of increased demand after Britain's Government reported that inflation exceeded its targets last month. The report suggested that the Bank of England, which has raised interest rates five times since May, could raise them again. Higher rates tend to increase demand for a currency.
In late New York trading, the pound was quoted at $1.7044, up from $1.6961 late Monday. The pound is now at its strongest since Jan. 2.
Trading was thin yesterday because of the Veterans Day holiday in the United States and Armistice Day in some European countries.
The dollar could rise as high as 130 yen in coming weeks, surpassing the 127.50 yen reached on May 1, which was its highest in four and a half years, said Alan Kabbani, senior currency trader at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C.
A weak yen can help Japan by reducing the price of exports, one of the few strengths in an economy struggling with slow growth, falling stocks and a debt-heavy banking system.
The yen also suffered after Taku Yamasaki, head of the Policy Affairs Research Council of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, said the Economic Planning Agency would acknowledge on Friday that the economy was stagnating.

HEADLINE: Small Grants Help Poor To Start Own Businesses

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
Mildred Robbins Leet and Glenn Leet could easily be gardening and socializing their way through their golden years. There are apple and cherry trees to tend on their wraparound terrace overlooking the Upper West Side and friends and associates, cultivated during two lifetimes of public service, to keep up with.
But the Leets have more pressing concerns. There's world poverty, for one. So at ages 75 and 89, respectively, Mrs. Leet and her husband are still fighting the battle, one they began 18 years ago with the founding of the Trickle Up Program, a nonprofit organization that gives modest amounts of seed money to poor people to start businesses. 
 The idea is simple: to elicit the entrepreneurial spirit, one person at a time. And all those seeds have sprouted into something quite significant. Since 1979, Trickle Up has helped create 65,000 small businesses, mostly based at home and mostly started by women.
"People all have potential," said Mrs. Leet. "The question is how are you going to reach them."
Mr. Leet added, "Many of the great American fortunes began very, very small."
As did their organization. In fact, it started with only $1,000 of the Leets's own money, a few computers on the couple's dining room table and a part-time secretary.
This summer, Trickle Up moved into offices at 121 West 27th Street, and this year its 14 full-time staff members plan to give away $1 million in 115 countries.
That is all the more remarkable because the program does not give the money in $100,000 clumps like venture capital companies, but in amounts more akin to passbook savings accounts: entrepreneurs in the United States can get a maximum of $700; overseas, they get $100.
Of course, $700 goes only so far, but Trickle Up says it is enough money to get a small business going. A group of women in Nepal used the money to parlay their skills in doll-making into a business that caters to tourists. A man in Maine began a business selling lacquered walking sticks that he makes out of the trunks of discarded Christmas trees.
"It's a first step toward getting them on their feet," said Daniel Delehanty, the organization's deputy director for development education and special projects. "We want people to develop a track record so they can go on to get a loan from a community development center or a small loan from a bank."
Trickle Up relies on a worldwide network of community development organizations, churches and women's groups to help identify promising candidates for its start-up grants. In foreign countries, where Trickle Up has operated since its inception, entrepreneurs receive $50 upon acceptance of a basic business plan and $50 a few months later as long as the recipient has saved 20 percent of any profits.
In the United States, where Trickle Up began fostering entrepreneurship only three years ago, the initial grant is $500, and the $200 balance comes soon after. The difference in the grant amount between the United States and overseas reflects the higher cost of living in this country.
The organization, which receives money from individuals, foundations, corporations and governments, recently helped start its 400th business in the United States, committing grant money to a woman in the South Bronx who wants to buy a computer to start a word processing business. Three-quarters of its business start-ups in the United States have occurred, in fact, in New York City.
There is, for instance, Maria Miranda of Queens, who last year discovered her life's passion after she made her first hat. With the installment of $500 from Trickle Up, she bought fabric and trim and paid her electric bill.
She has since sold 1,000 hats. She was just approved for an $8,000 loan from the Women's Venture Fund, a nonprofit group in Manhattan that helps women in business.
The Leets met through their involvement in international development in 1973. He was president of Save the Children Federation and had been the first chief of the Community Development unit of the United Nations. She was a member of the International Peace Academy and a past president of the National Council of Women. "We kept hearing the same words over and over again," Mrs. Leet recalled. "It was, 'How do you reach the poorest of the poor?' and 'How do you encourage the participation of the people?' "
In the United States, sorting out who is truly on the economic margins and who is not can be a challenge. "When you work in developing countries, it's so much easier," Mr. Delehanty said, "because basically everybody is really poor."
Trickle Up recently prepared economic guidelines for American candidates -- conditions that would make banks beat a retreat. Household incomes should be less than 175 percent of the federally set poverty level. Recipients typically have either a tarnished credit history or none at all. And a history of being on welfare is a plus.
"Most small businesses in this country are started with help from friends and family," Mr. Delehanty said. "When you're talking about people who don't have friends and family with money, it's very difficult."
The organization's studies show that about 80 percent of the businesses it has helped are still going after one year.
Leaders in international development praise Trickle Up for its emphasis on economic issues at the grass-roots level.
"People recognize the importance of health and education, but too often there's not enough focus on livelihoods," said James Gustave Speth, administrator of the United Nations Development Program, which has contributed to the organization. "Trickle Up has worked with the poorest of the poor and has focused on this issue."

HEADLINE: Stocks End Mixed in Moderate Trading as the Dow Rises 6.14

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Despite overnight gains amongAsian markets, broad equity indexes in the United States ended mixed yesterday, as stocks meandered for a second consecutive session characterized by moderate trading volume.
Indeed, even though markets in Japan and Hong Kong firmed and South Korea's sustained only minimal losses earlier in the day, the United States market failed to retain most of the gains it made at the start of its session. 
 With the bond market closed in observance of Veterans Day, stocks also lacked a barometer on interest-rate trends.
Caterpillar was a victim of the market's malaise. Shares of the company, a maker of heavy equipment, fell 2, or nearly 4 percent, to 48 3/16 on concern that events in Asia and Latin America create uncertainty about the company's overseas business. In addition, President Clinton's failure to win expedited trade negotiating authority may have hurt the stock, analysts said.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 7,558.73, up 6.14 points, after trading up as much as 47.15 points. Shares of large multinational companies like DuPont, Procter & Gamble, Johnson & Johnson and Coca-Cola led the advance.
Despite its positive finish, the average of 30 blue-chip stocks was undermined not only by Caterpillar but negative financial news from Eastman Kodak and General Motors as well.
Among broader market gauges, Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 2.65 points, to 923.78. The Nasdaq composite index, heavily weighted with technology stocks, fell 5.86 points, to 1,584.86.
Declining issues outpaced advancers, 1,486 to 1,336, on the New York Stock Exchange.
"The downward bias is not a great sign," said Alan Bond, chief investment officer at Bond Procope Capital Management in New York. "With the improvement in Asia, it's not quite as firm as I would have liked to see."
In fact, the stock market's inability to strengthen more on such a light trading day could portend further declines, said Jim Benning, a vice president at Bankers Trust New York.
"I think people are just concerned that the problems in Southeast Asia are spreading slowly," Mr. Benning said. "At the moment, the U.S. economy looks fine, but that could change. And stocks were up so high. Prices were based on a rosy scenario till the end of time and that's not realistic."
Traders and analysts said that the market was largely unconcerned about today's meeting by the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee because an interest-rate increase is seen as unlikely.
In addition, little new information is expected to be disclosed tomorrow when the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, and Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers are scheduled to testify before Congress about Asia's financial turmoil and its impact on the United States economy.
Shares of MCI Communications and Worldcom were the two most actively traded issues yesterday following Monday's announcement that the two companies would merge in a deal valued at $36.5 billion.
But questions about the merger -- including those about the stringent regulatory scrutiny it is expected to draw and worries that Worldcom's growth could slow as it raises its debt burden to finance the deal -- weighed on the stocks.
Worldcom closed at 30 1/4, off 11/16, with nearly 23.5 million shares traded. MCI closed unchanged at 41 1/2, on 19.8 million shares traded, after gaining more than 4 on Monday.
Kansas City Power and Light shares fell 1 1/4, to 27 13/16 on concern that Western Resources might renegotiate its agreement to buy the utility for about $2.7 billion in stock and assumed debt. Western Resources shares rose 1 5/16, to 37 11/16.

HEADLINE: Further Restraint Is Sought For Improvement Districts

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Seeking to curb the growing influence of business improvement districts, the City Council leadership is releasing a package of proposals today that would make it harder to create and maintain the self-taxing districts and would also more closely regulate them.
The proposed rules would be the first major constraints on the districts -- widely credited for improving the quality of life throughout the city -- since the Council authorized them 15 years ago. They would also force the 39 districts, which often have broad management discretion, to open up their management practices and more actively involve property owners within their boundaries. 
 In a report scheduled to be released today, the Council found that many property owners felt poorly informed about district operations and that some complained about managerial abuses. Still others said they felt their districts were unnecessary, thus subjecting them to an unfair tax. Under a BID, property owners must pay a special tax that the city collects and the business district then uses to improve the area.
Property owners in the Grand Central district, for example, contended that the district's leaders carefully orchestrated a vote to kill plans by property owners to institute spending guidelines. They also contend that the leaders unilaterally dropped one of the area's largest property owners from the district's board because he opposed some of their practices. The report concluded that the district's leaders went to great lengths "to obtain unfettered control and power within the BID."
"After closely reviewing BID's and their operations, everything points to the fact that there are abuses and potential abuses that have to be rectified," said Herbert E. Berman, chairman of the Council's Finance Committee, which produced the report. "And as long as they have the imprimatur of government, they should be required to adhere to certain standards."
The Finance Committee now must draft bills to enact the proposals, which have the backing of Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and therefore are likely to be approved by the full Council.
The report highlights a tension that has existed since the BID's were first authorized. While the special districts have been praised for using their tax dollars to pick up garbage, hire security guards and otherwise supplement city services, questions have been raised by property owners and others about whether the districts have become mini-governments that operate with too little oversight.
The districts' leaders, who have not seen the Council's report, would not comment in detail when told about the proposals. But they have long warned against overregulation, saying too much municipal bureaucracy would make it difficult for them to operate efficiently.
Rudy Washington, Deputy Mayor for Community Development and Business Services, said the Giuliani administration would review the proposals. He noted that the administration had already instituted some limits on the districts, including a decision last year to restrict the districts' ability to sell bonds to finance multimillion dollar projects.
"This administration supports BID's 100 percent because they've made major improvements to the city," he said. "But we also realize that, like anything else, there needs to be checks and balances."
While many of the Council's proposals can be enacted through changes in local law, some would require the approval of the State Legislature because the districts were created under state laws governing special assessment districts.
Sheldon Silver, Speaker of the State Assembly, said he was open to the Council's proposals. "We'd be delighted to look at anything that they think addresses the problems and concerns in the city," he said.
Gretchen Dykstra, president of the Times Square Business Improvement District, noted that the association last year issued a Code of Professional Standards and Practices. "It was an attempt by the BID's to come up with best practices and guidelines for BID managers," she said.
The Council report acknowledges that the association's code was intended to "insure full disclosure, accountability, democratic representation and power sharing within all of the city's BID's," but suggests that the code is largely ignored by some district managers. One of the Council's proposals would require each district to adhere to the code in order to be certified by the city's Department of Business Services.
A number of the proposals are intended to correct problems the Council encountered at the Grand Central Partnership, one of the city's largest districts. Many complaints were directed at the partnership's president, Daniel Biederman, who also runs the 34th Street and Bryant Park BID's and draws salaries from the three BID's totaling nearly $400,000. The Council would like to prohibit Mr. Biederman and anyone else from managing more than one BID. Dan Pisark, a spokesman for the partnership, said Mr. Biederman and other district leaders would have no comment until they had reviewed the report.

HEADLINE: THE TRADE BILL: POLITICS;
Gephardt, Long on Sideline, Scores a Touchdown at Last

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
For years, Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader in the House, has fought the lonely battle. He has opposed major trade bills, the balanced-budget agreement and changes in welfare, popular initiatives that united the Republican-led Congress and the Democratic President, split House Democrats and left Mr. Gephardt a minority within the minority.
Now, in a stunning turn of events, this once and future Presidential candidate suddenly finds himself in the winner's circle. His victory has brought humiliating defeat to the President of his own party and was achieved largely by standing still, with the minority leader simply holding to a longtime position and allowing Administration blunders and other events to move the issue his way. 
 President Clinton's retreat on "fast track" trade authority marked Mr. Gephardt's most successful rebellion in a string of recent splits with the Administration that have helped the 56-year-old Missourian define himself as an economic liberal and carve out his own identity for the Presidential contest in 2000.
With Vice President Al Gore carrying the flag for the Administration in favor of the fast-track bill, the maneuverings over the last week had all the markings of the opening round of the Democratic Presidential primaries. Mr. Gephardt's stance reinforced the view that he intends to make himself the undisputed alternative on the left to Mr. Gore, by building support among labor and environmentalists.
The question now is whether Mr. Gephardt can capitalize on his success by articulating a new message on trade based on worker rights and saving the environment, or whether he simply fostered an image as a captive of big labor who speaks only for other House Democrats increasingly dependent on union cash for re-election.
Representative Paul McHale, from the industrial Lehigh Valley of Pennsylvania, was one of more than 160 House Democrats who sided with Mr. Gephardt on the fast-track bill. But he has reservations about the long-term viability of Mr. Gephardt's position.
"Dick's view may appeal to a limited constituency within our party," Mr. McHale said. "But for a candidate to become identified with the defeatist principles of protectionism rather than optimistic engagement is not only bad economic policy, it's misguided politics."
Yet, other Democrats, as well as Republicans, say Mr. Gephardt is now in a position to capture the important organizational support -- and dollars -- of union labor, which has backed Mr. Gore until now but worked hard to defeat the trade bill.
And several Democrats say Mr. Gephardt scored points with them by his posture.
"Dick Gephardt's stock has risen tremendously," said Representative Bill Pascrell Jr., a first-term Democrat from New Jersey who is a strong supporter of organized labor. "Gore came into my district to campaign for me, but having seen how the Administration operated on this issue, I have some serious questions. Gephardt is a bridge-builder; Gore is caught up in 21st-century macroeconomics."
The effects of trade on American workers have long been Mr. Gephardt's signature issue. Indeed, his advocacy of retaliation against countries like Japan that ran up huge trade surpluses with the United States was the cornerstone of his failed Presidential campaign in 1988.
His aides acknowledge that his message -- essentially, that workers of the world should unite -- is premised on a downturn in the economy and seems inherently pessimistic. ("People are insecure," he says.) But they insist that by the 1998 House elections, his midnight-in-America posture will reflect a prevailing Democratic view and will help the party recapture the House.
Whatever his ability to build on his success, in the trade fight Mr. Gephardt's position mirrored a widespread disaffection of House liberals who believe that Mr. Clinton has deserted them on the entire agenda of reducing income disparity in America.
One House Democratic leader, Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, said that a "robber-baron capitalist" mentality had prevailed since the Republicans won control of Congress three years ago and that Mr. Clinton, perceiving that he had no choice but to work with the Republicans, had bought into it.
The fast-track bill, Mr. Obey said, was "a further walking away from the traditional values of the Democratic Party."
Unlike the White House, which garnered promises of some votes only by promising rewards in return, Mr. Gephardt had few sweeteners to offer.
"We don't have the assets that the White House has," one aide said ruefully.
Instead, his success seemed largely a result of factors beyond his control: widespread unhappiness in the House over the effects of the North American Free Trade Agreement, and uncharacteristic political blunders by the Clinton Administration. These included the President's accusation that Democrats who did not support the bill were in the pocket of union bosses, and a White House fire-sale atmosphere suggesting that the Administration would barter away almost anything for a vote favoring the legislation.
This gave Mr. Gephardt the chance to claim the moral high ground.
"Please, Mr. President," he implored over the weekend, "don't trade Democratic values for Republican votes."
Throughout the hours and days of negotiations before Republican leaders canceled the House vote at 2 o'clock on Monday morning, Democrats, labor allies and environmentalists dropped in at Mr. Gephardt's office to report the latest news, and wavering lawmakers came by for earnest discussions about the bill.
Each bit of news that he received about the struggle was conveyed to him by other House Democrats or by reporters. He had no communication with the White House, and Mr. Clinton never called him when the battle was over.
Now his successful opposition to the measure can only chill his already icy relations with the Administration. And the words that he spoke in January 1995, after Mr. Clinton had been blamed for the Democrats' losing control of the House for the first time in 40 years, seem ever more true.
"House Democrats," Mr. Gephardt said then, "are an independent organization."
