HEADLINE: El Paso Journal;
Clothes Sold by Pound Attract Mexican Buyers

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: EL PASO

 BODY:
Carmen Hernandez rummaged carefully through the racks at Ropa por Libra, the downtown El Paso store she has visited two or three times a week, nearly every week, for the past 20 years.
The 73-year-old Mrs. Hernandez, who is from the neighboring Mexican city of Ciudad Juarez, studied a children's shirt carefully, inspected and rejected a blouse, then took a pair of men's trousers and finding no stains or rips whatsoever, nodded her head in satisfaction. A few moments later, she took a small bundle of clothing and tossed it onto a scale at the counter. At $6.99 a pound for a little more than two pounds, her total bill, for six items, was $15.22. 
 So goes a typical transaction at Ropa por Libra -- which means clothing by the pound -- an El Paso institution that has counterparts in cities all along the 2,000-mile United States-Mexico border and that offers a window on a quirky area of trade between the two nations.
Taken together, what is sold in these stores are estimated to be one of this nation's biggest exports -- in volume, if not in dollars -- to its southern neighbor: used and discarded clothing.
Many of the clothes are used items plucked, for pennies, from the storehouses of charitable groups, while others have been bought new at greatly discounted prices from manufacturers and retailers, either because they had imperfections or because the whole line of clothing had been discontinued.
"People know they can get incredible bargains here," said Ed Garcia, the irrepressible manager at Ropa por Libra. He has been involved in the family-owned business for nearly all of his 49 years.
"You take this beautiful skirt right here," he said, placing a red pleated skirt with a label that said "American Fashion Woman/Made in U.S.A." on a scale that seemed identical to those used to weigh produce at a grocery store. "That'll be .49 pound, at $6.99 a pound," he continued, reaching for a calculator and punching in the numbers. "Call it $3.43. "I'm telling you, you go to buy that in New York or Boston, that's going to cost you $60."
As he spoke, customers browsed through the three levels of the store, which is adorned with photographs of Barbra Streisand, Frank Sinatra, Katharine Hepburn and nearly all the American Presidents, as well as huge Spanish lettering offering items like camisas (shirts), pantalones (pants) and chaquetas (jackets).
However they got here, the clothes wind up in stores and warehouses in border cities from the Gulf of Mexico to the Pacific Ocean, and they are often bought by Mexican customers like Mrs. Hernandez, who said she planned to cross back over the Rio Grande, wash and iron the clothes she bought, and sell them in the open markets of Juarez. She hoped to make a profit of as much as 50 cents on each sale; with the proceeds, she would be back at Ropa por Libra in a few days.
The trade, in many ways, illustrates the economic disparities in the two nations. The clothes may be considered rejects in the United States, but not at all in Mexico.
"There are some beautiful clothes here that the Americans don't seem to want," said another customer from Juarez, Alicia Medina, 68, who was browsing in Ropa por Libra's "Bargain Basement," in which all items cost $1 or less. "I love shopping for my grandchildren here, just looking all around."
The booming trade in ropa usada, or used clothing, is not without some controversy in Mexico, where the authorities have become increasingly concerned about bulk sales of the clothes at American stores. The customers pay American sales taxes but bring the goods into Mexico and re-sell them in open markets. Under that system, Mexico rarely collects any customs duties or taxes on the goods, and officials have vowed to crack down on those engaged in high-volume sales of used clothing.
Still, even among the Mexican authorities, there are different interpretations of regulations on the trade. The head of the customs office in Matamoros, across the Rio Grande from Brownsville, Tex., said that bringing used clothing bought outside the country into Mexico is "completely forbidden," while a spokeswoman at the customs office of the Mexican Embassy in Washington, said that "a reasonable amount according with the duration of your trip" was acceptable for import.
In any event, Mexican officials admitted that it would be extremely difficult to sort a person's own clothing from recent purchases outside the country. Their real target is the large importers. The trade continues unabated for those involved in selling used clothes on a small scale, such as some customers of Ropa por Libra.
If the store was busy here recently, a few blocks away the atmosphere was frenetic at its warehouse store on Paisano Drive, "La Bola de Oro," which means the ball of gold, a few hundred feet from the border. There the customers, almost all of them Mexican citizens, typically pool their resources to buy 35-pound bundles at $1.50 to $1.79 per pound.
But unlike Ropa por Libra, where customers select the clothing, those who come to La Bola de Oro buy the bundles, many of which are trucked directly from New York and Los Angeles, without knowing exactly what's rolled up inside.
"You never know what you'll get when you buy a bundle," Mr. Garcia said. "But there are always things in there that really are gold -- they can wind up being big sellers in Mexico -- and others that won't be. So the idea is, it all comes out in the wash."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mexican citizens buy used or imperfect clothing by the pound in the El Paso store Ropa por Libra and re-sell it at home. Mexico is cracking down on bulk traders in such goods who evade tariffs at the border. (Bruce Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Buona Notte, Guten Tag: Europe's New Workdays;
With Unemployment High, the Continent Experiments With the Time Clock

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: BOLOGNA, Italy

 BODY:
For 20 years, Amadeo Nassetti's routine had been as immovable as the huge machines he works on at a factory here owned by Bonfiglioli Group. He put in the same eight hours a day, starting at 8 A.M., five days a week.
But last year, his 21st at Bonfiglioli, a world leader in the manufacture of gearboxes and electrical motors, Mr. Nassetti suddenly needed a dance card to keep track of his schedule. Instead of 40 hours a week, he found himself working fewer than 32, and in rotating shifts starting as far apart as 6 A.M. and 10 P.M. Some weeks he worked four days, others five; some weeks he worked Saturdays, in others he had four-day weekends. This fall, the 57-year-old Mr. Nassetti has a 34-hour week, with most Saturdays and Sundays off. The only thing that has remained the same is his salary. 
 Mr. Nassetti's shorter but far less predictable schedule is corporate Europe's answer to an bitter debate now sweeping the Continent about jobs. As politicians, labor leaders and employers argue over the age-old vision of cutting working hours, some bigger companies, like Bonfiglioli, have already taken out the ax. But they are doing it to enhance their competitiveness, particularly internationally, and not to help cut unemployment, as some are urging, by letting those without work take up the slack.
"It was not really an issue of reducing hours but of gaining flexibility," said Sonia Bonfiglioli, the company's chief executive.
Adding jobs has been the goal of left-wing politicians and union leaders searching for ways to slice Europe's persistently high unemployment, double the level in the United States. If the Continent cannot increase the size of its economic pie, they argue, then workers should make do with a smaller slice -- though no less pay -- so that more people can come to the table.
The idea has caught on in Italy, where the Government recently pledged to trim the maximum legal workweek to 35 hours, from 40, by the year 2001. The French have made a similar vow.
But those moves have isolated Paris and Rome from the rest of the 15-member European Union, which rejects the idea as ineffective. And they have splintered labor into angry camps.
Some in labor's mainstream say a rigid system of shorter hours, by itself, could actually cost jobs by adding expense to European companies that already have trouble competing effectively in the global market. Shorter hours should be negotiated on a company-by-company basis, the mainstream says, with cuts in pay, if necessary, and above all with an eye to increasing a company's productivity.
But those on the left say governments must require employers to redistribute work, after shortening hours, to create new jobs. Otherwise, they argue, the exercise only serves to cement the privileges of existing employees. France and Italy, however, are tending toward a system that would not require new hiring. Instead, the Government would merely provide incentives to add workers, through tax breaks, perhaps, or subsidies toward the social security and health costs of any new employees.
As the debate rages on, more and more companies, like Bonfiglioli, say they cannot wait for a resolution. Growing into the role of multinational players, they have an immediate need to deal with surges and declines in the global economy, and one way is to be flexible with hours.
In short, the goal for these companies is not social engineering, but corporate re-engineering. Mr. Nassetti is working less but arguably harder, given the wear and tear of an ever-changing schedule. And while Bonfiglioli did some hiring, that was only because there was more demand for its products.
In arguing against legislation to force lower hours on a company without allowing other changes in work rules, Ms. Bonfiglioli said, "Reducing hours only makes sense under conditions of greater flexibility."
The twists and turns of the debate are all on display at Bonfiglioli. Since it negotiated a deal with its unions to cut the hours of Mr. Nassetti and his colleagues, its payroll has grown to 930 from 863.
Such results make proponents of shorter hours exult. Nerio Nesi, the economic spokesman of the Communist Refoundation Party, which demanded and got the pledge of a national law mandating a 35-hour week, cites his party's slogan, "Work for everyone, by working less." Companies can pay for the extra employees, he said, by dipping into profits.
But Ms. Bonfiglioli begs to differ.
In 1995, her company found itself with a sudden surge in demand for its sophisticated gearboxes and motors, as economies around the world emerged from recession and sales of the automobiles, farm tractors and other machinery that contain gearboxes jumped. Last year, the company, which was founded in 1956 by Ms. Bonfiglioli's father, Clementino, had sales of $207 million, compared with $98 million five years ago.
The sharp rise in orders presented the company with some difficult decisions, however. More overtime, the classic recipe for bolstering production, was prohibitively expensive, with metal workers in the company's seven factories pocketing 25 percent bonuses for overtime on Saturdays and 50 percent on Sundays. Moreover, the construction of a new factory was risky: if demand fizzled, Bonfiglioli would be stuck with a surplus plant and staff.
But by winning the right to move Mr. Nassetti and others around to night and weekend shifts as production needs dictated -- and without having to pay them at overtime rates for the privilege -- the company was able to greatly increase output with a minimum of additional employees. And because it could use the existing factories more efficiently, by keeping the machines running virtually around the clock, there was no need to build an extra plant.
Changes like these largely reflect the new realities of doing business on a global stage. Faced with the vagaries of international markets, many European companies are trying to find ways to be responsive without incurring excessive fixed costs. The goal is to create so-called breathing factories, in which production expands and contracts with demand, like a living organism.
Companies in the United States, of course, went through similar adjustments in recent years as they cut millions of jobs, switching instead to contract workers and outsourcing to remain competitive. But in Europe, with rigid social structures, strong labor unions and far higher unemployment, the pressure to achieve flexibility is even greater.
And indeed, Ms. Bonfiglioli acknowledges she was only copying a model for cutting working hours that was created in Germany several years earlier by Volkswagen, Europe's largest auto maker. At that time, VW faced the possibility of having to lay off about a third of its work force in Germany, or about 30,000 people, as an aging product line and the European recession combined to hollow out demand.
To avoid the huge layoffs, Volkswagen negotiated a complex package in 1993 with the powerful metal workers' union to cut the average workweek to less than 29 hours -- from 36 hours -- distributed over four days. In return, the union agreed to have wages reduced by up to 15 percent.
VW saved 20,000 of the 30,000 jobs, but in exchange it got the right to increase the workweek to as many as 35 hours, without paying overtime. Now, revived European economies and a renewed product line have caused demand to soar.
Peter Hartz, Volkswagen's chief of personnel and architect of the plan, says his goal is to extend the program to all 280,000 employees around the world.
And Volkswagen's model has found emulators elsewhere in Germany. In Munich, BMW operates its factories on similar principles, based roughly on a four-day week. Siemens, the electrical and electronics conglomerate, was able to save 5,000 jobs at one factory with a similar deal.
What animates the left's drive for shorter hours, say experts like Aris Accornero, a professor of industrial sociology at Rome University, is the conviction dating back to Karl Marx and other classical leftist theoreticians that "life, in effect, begins after work." Historically, however, the proposal has been "the daughter of desperation, not of hope," Professor Accornero said.
In the Great Depression, the Geneva-based International Labor Organization broached the idea of shorter hours, and in France, the leftist Government of Prime Minister Leon Blum put it into effect, slashing the week's hours to 40, from 48, the professor said. In the United States, socially innovative companies like Kellogg, the cereal maker, experimented with a 36-hour week.
Yet rarely do shorter hours serve to create more jobs, Professor Accornero said. Indeed, to regain productivity lost by shorter hours at equal pay, companies usually respond with better organization of work, which often means more stress for the remaining employees and more automation, which further reduces jobs. And the experience at Volkswagen bears this out.
"We got jobs, at the price of more intensive work," said Hans-Jurgen Uhl, the secretary general of the worker council at VW's main German plant, in Wolfsburg. "There is a subjective feeling of increased performance, and the work force will continue to drop." Where once two secretaries toiled, now there is one, he said, and while workers once took an extended coffee break to celebrate a colleague's birthday, they now do it after hours. Meanwhile, the drive to greater productivity continues, translating into fewer jobs.
Thanks to new manufacturing technology, said Hans-Peter Blechinger, a Volkswagen spokesman, VW's new Golf compact takes 20 hours to build, against 30 to 33 hours for the outgoing model. "In the medium term, we foresee a drop in employment because of productivity improvements," he said.
To get more productivity out of workers, VW is even trying to squeeze out the old notion of life beginning only after work. The goal of Mr. Hartz, the personnel head, is to turn each VW worker into an "entrepreneur on the factory floor, who acts decisively without orders from above to achieve the company's goals." Volkswagen and the unions hammer the message again and again at the work force. To induce workers to identify further with the company's goals, VW initiated a stock purchase program.
But such efforts to bind workers to their company's life only serve to accelerate what Kurt Vogler-Ludwig, a labor market specialist at the IFO Institute for Economic Research in Munich, describes as a widening split among European union leaders. Those who believe that embracing such a philosophy is the only road to preserving existing industrial jobs are increasingly at odds with more radical leaders, he says, who accuse the mainstream unions of essentially selling out to management to preserve the perks of those who are still employed.
"Now the unions represent more and more the interests of those with jobs," Mr. Vogler-Ludwig said.
For their part, the mainstream unions were angered by the demand in Italy for a 35-hour week. A nationwide law would shackle negotiating flexibility, their leaders said, and ultimately destroy jobs.
"We should have a reduced number of hours," said Sergio D'Antoni, head of the CISL union. "But we also have to reduce the cost of work."

But a few companies in Europe, seeking more flexible schedules to reduce costs and improve productivity, are achieving the same goal for different reasons, adding to conflicts among labor, business and government. HEADLINE: To Streamline, G.M. Will Take Charges Up to $3 Billion

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would take a charge against earnings of $2 billion to $3 billion as early as the fourth quarter to pay for job cuts, write-downs in the value of some factories and other changes intended to streamline the company in the long term.
G.M. said the actions were prompted by its continuing study of the competitiveness of its major lines of business. It did not announce what the exact moves would be, even though they could cost the auto maker as much as it has earned in the last six months. The bulk of the job cuts are expected to come in Europe, where G.M. is struggling to compete with a newly resurgent Volkswagen. 
 Wall Street was surprised by the charges, and drove G.M. stock down $1.8125, or 2.8 percent, today to $63.625. At least two auto analysts lowered their fourth-quarter earnings estimates. Analysts' earlier consensus view was that G.M. would earn $2.04 a share in the fourth quarter, according to First Call.
Still, most auto analysts applauded the moves for the long term. "G.M. is trying to be pro-active, to cut costs quicker, so that whenever a downturn comes, they'll be better prepared for it," said Scott F. Merlis, president of Merlis Automotive International, an independent automotive research firm based in Westport, Conn. "It is good news in the sense that G.M. is accelerating its cost-reduction efforts."
G.M. disclosed the huge charges as part of a lengthy filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission related to the spinoff of its Hughes defense unit to Raytheon, a move that is expected to bring a net gain of $3.9 billion to $4.5 billion in the fourth quarter. G.M. said the charges of $2 billion to $3 billion after taxes, which amount to $2.85 to $4.27 a share, would come in the fourth quarter or early next year. Analysts expect the company to take the charges in the fourth quarter because they would be more than offset by the hefty gain from the Hughes sale.
Fourth-quarter earnings could be crimped by higher-than-expected costs of rebates and by the economic turmoil in emerging markets, G.M.'s chief financial officer, J. Michael Losh, told analysts at a dinner Monday in New York. Incentive levels reached an average of $992 a vehicle in the third quarter, and G.M. expected them to be at least that high in the fourth quarter.
Mr. Merlis, who lowered his fourth-quarter estimate today by 10 cents, to $1.88 a share, said that increased incentives -- he expects them to average $1,000 a vehicle -- would come because of the fierce competition for sales of sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks.
Some of the $2 billion to $3 billion in charges will stem from actions already announced. For instance, in September G.M. put on the block three businesses from its Delphi auto parts unit: its coil springs operations in Michigan, its lighting business in Indiana and Louisiana, and its seating business in Michigan and several countries abroad. None has yet sold. Together, the three businesses employ 11,300 people, and G.M. said it hoped new buyers would preserve those jobs.
G.M.'s European division, Opel, had already told its unions in Belgium that it planned to lower costs, probably by laying off 1,900 workers. And it was scrambling to identify cost savings elsewhere in its European operations, with workers across the European Union fearing further job cuts. Still, the previously announced Delphi divestiture (which is likely to result in asset writedowns) and the job cuts in Belgium were not expected to result in charges of more than $500 million -- a fraction of the $2 billion to $3 billion in charges.
The United States factory seen most vulnerable to being closed is the giant Buick City complex in Flint, Mich., which has a work force of nearly 10,000. It was scheduled to build the Buick LeSabre through the 1999 model year, but it had not been assigned a car or truck to build afterward. The complex also contains a truck engine factory and several smaller components assembly lines.
"The global automotive industry, including the components and systems market, has become increasingly competitive and is presently undergoing significant restructuring and consolidation activities," G.M. said in its regulatory filing. "All of the major industry participants are continuing to increase their focus on efficiency and cost improvements, while announced capacity increases for the North American market and excess capacity in the European market have led to continuing price pressures."
David Bradley, an auto analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities Inc., said he was heartened by the prospect of the charges because future earnings were likely to be better. "Their cost structure isn't where it needs to be," he said, and the announcement "tends to imply that the restructuring mentality continues." He expected the charges would come not from huge factory closings but from the write-down of overvalued assets, including uncompetitive factories.
Mr. Bradley said the timing of the charges was tied to the Hughes sale. "It has become quite fashionable at very large U.S. companies to find an offsetting loss whenever you have a large gain," he said.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: In MCI-Worldcom Theory, New View of Competition

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Consolidation is good for competition.
That is the conventional wisdom emerging within the telecommunications industry, and it seems to contradict the goals of the Telecommunications Act of 1996. Or does it? 
 If Worldcom Inc. completes its $36.5 billion takeover of the MCI Communications Corporation, the deal would bring to nearly $100 billion the total value of the mergers in the telecommunications industry since the act was signed last year.
To some politicians and regulators, all this deal-making has perverted the law's purpose, which was to create new choices in communications as many big companies battled head to head, with consumers picking the winners and enjoying lower prices. From this viewpoint, consolidation raises the specter of very few companies offering take-it-or-leave-it choices, with little if any reduction in prices.
Critics note, for example, that instead of two neighboring Bell telephone companies like Nynex and Bell Atlantic raiding each other's territories, consolidation has resulted in the merger of those companies -- with consumers in each region still having only one local telephone company.
But the thinking on Wall Street and within the industry these days is that true competition and price reductions will come only through the formation of a handful of national players -- companies big and rich enough to build their own networks and compete head on with full lineups of local, long-distance, Internet and other communications services.
Rather than deprive consumers of potential options, the thinking goes, mega-mergers can create companies powerful enough to invade one another's markets and bring competition to the masses.
No one is arguing this case louder than Bernard J. Ebbers, the chairman of Worldcom who has engineered dozens of telecommunications mergers and is set to run the combined MCI Worldcom, which would be the No. 2 long-distance company.
"This is in the best interest of the Telecommunications Act," Mr. Ebbers said at the news conference on Monday, when he announced the MCI-Worldcom agreement. MCI Worldcom, he said, would become the only company so far to build alternative networks to serve both residential and business local telephone customers. "And we intend to pursue that very aggressively," he said.
If MCI Worldcom does build local networks to compete for residential customers against the entrenched local telephone companies, it would be the first to do so. The investment required to create a new residential local telephone network is huge, and so far no company has made it.
When politicians like Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, the chairman of the Commerce Committee, which oversees the Federal Communications Commission, criticize the Telecom Act or how it is being carried out, they generally cite the failure of any company to provide a broad local telephone alternative for residential customers.
Instead of more choice in local telephone markets, the number of regional Bells has declined to five from seven as Bell Atlantic acquired Nynex for $25.6 billion in August and SBC Communications acquired Pacific Telesis for $16.7 billion in April.
Yet, despite the outcry in Washington over consolidation, those deals won Federal regulatory approval fairly easily. And it does not appear that the MCI-Worldcom merger will die in Washington, either.
It was a different matter last summer, though, when the AT&T Corporation and SBC Communications were not so privately discussing a merger and Federal officials indicated their adamant opposition.
And therein may lie a public-policy contradiction. It appears that Washington may be willing to countenance a kind of incremental consolidation that may in fact do little to usher in competitive choices but may prove reluctant to sign off on the kind of mega-mergers that some experts think may be a prerequisite to full-blown competition.
That is in part because the takeovers already approved have essentially been what economists call horizontal mergers, in which the merging companies already offer the same services.
Because the four Baby Bells that became two were already dominant in their regions, allowing them to merge did not directly enhance their market power, analysts said. As such, the deals passed antitrust scrutiny. And so might the merger of MCI and Worldcom, which together would control only about a quarter of the long-distance telephone market.
Horizontal mergers are attractive to companies because they allow their participants to save large sums of money as they consolidate operations. Worldcom and MCI, for example, are projecting billions of dollars a year in cost savings.
Mr. Ebbers and many defenders of such mergers say that some of those savings can then be used to expand into new markets. Of course, some of the savings can also generate the earnings-per-share growth valued so highly by Wall Street.
But some executives and analysts are convinced that horizontal mergers alone will not create companies with heft enough to break into entrenched local telephone markets. What is needed, many say, are vertical mergers -- the combination of companies offering different though complementary services. Local and long-distance companies, for example, could combine their resources, expertise and brand names to expand into markets now controlled by powerful incumbents.
"The Government, if they really want competition in all of the markets, will have to permit vertical mergers as well, or you will never get the level of competition desired," said Frank Governali, a telecommunications analyst for Credit Suisse First Boston.
AT&T tried a vertical merger earlier this year, when it tried to combine with SBC. But Reed E. Hundt, who was chairman of the F.C.C. at the time, torpedoed the negotiations by calling such a deal "unthinkable." No one knows just how the F.C.C.'s new chairman, William E. Kennard, would handle such a proposal.
Telecommunications executives and investment bankers, who earn substantial fees when they arrange mergers, are among those arguing that vertical mergers could be even better for consumers than horizontal ones.
How? In a vertical merger, where the companies have been offering different services, the combined company cannot hope to save as much by eliminating duplicate operations. And so, the advocates argue, the newly combined company would have stronger incentives to move quickly into new markets -- as a way to generate new revenue rather than simply increase the profitability of its existing business.
That is the theory, at least -- though not one that Washington has yet been willing to put to the test.

HEADLINE: Iraqi Official Says Baghdad Will Continue to Defy U.N.

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Iraq's Foreign Minister said today that his country saw no alternative to its stand of defiance against the United Nations and remained committed to its threat to expel American weapons inspectors.
The Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf, offered no hint of flexibility in a confrontation that has now lasted two weeks. Instead, Mr. Sahaf said Baghdad had been "put in a corner" by the American-led policy that has subjected Iraq to seven years of crippling economic sanctions with no sign of respite, and that his Government was acting in the view that "there is no hope." 
 "A shock now is a necessity, a necessity so that the Security Council, a very responsible international body, should listen," Mr. Sahaf declared at a news conference in Baghdad. He appeared to be referring both to his Government's decision to prevent Americans from taking part in United Nations weapons inspections and to its vow to expel American inspectors unless diplomacy now under way in New York produces a satisfactory outcome.
Appearing in a dark green military uniform, and sitting beneath a portrait of President Saddam Hussein, Mr. Sahaf also reiterated an Iraqi threat to shoot down any American spy plane that enters Iraqi airspace, as U-2 aircraft do regularly as part of the ongoing United Nations effort to monitor Iraq's weapons programs.
And although they did not put forward any new proposals, the Foreign Minister's remarks seemed intended to serve notice around the world that Iraq saw little to lose in refusing to heed United Nations dictates.
"There is a deliberate plan to perpetuate the sanctions imposed on Iraq," Mr. Sahaf said, speaking in English. "We are put in a position where there is no hope -- it is a hopeless position -- and we have no other alternative but to defend our rights, to say the facts, and to stop dealing or cooperating with the elements who are blocking the way toward lifting sanctions."
Mr. Sahaf met with reporters in the early evening, Baghdad time, long before the end of a long day of verbal sparring at United Nations headquarters in New York, where an Iraqi delegation headed by Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz has been trying to present his Government's case.
Iraq first threatened on Oct. 29 to expel American inspectors, but it has agreed to suspend action until the current round of United Nations diplomacy could be completed. It has continued, however, to turn away American inspectors who seek to gain entry into Iraq, and it continued even today to prevent operations by United Nations weapons teams because they included Americans.
With the United Nations apparently heading toward confrontation instead of accommodation with Iraq, Mr. Sahaf seemed to indicate that expulsion of the half-dozen or so American inspectors left in Iraq might now not be far away.
Asked if Iraq was still committed to that threat, the Foreign Minister answered, "This is for sure."
The Baghdad newspaper Babel, which is owned by President Hussein's eldest son, said in an editorial published today that Iraq should reject "any promise or sweet words" that the United Nations might offer with the aim of putting an end to the crisis. The newspaper, which generally reflects official thinking, asserted that Iraq should accept nothing short of "an official and clear document which guarantees two demands: neutrality of inspection teams and setting a time frame for lifting the embargo."

HEADLINE: THE TRADE BILL: BUSINESS;
Executives Say Trade Bill Defeat Will Hurt Economy

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The managers of many American businesses said today that the inability of Congress and the Clinton Administration to pass a measure granting the President broad authority to negotiate trade deals could cost companies and the economy dearly in the long run.
The outcome, which organized labor hailed as a victory for its demands that trading partners be required to improve workers' rights and environmental standards in return for access to the American market, came as a shock to some executives. They said they had assumed that the combination of a Republican majority in Congress and an Administration that is strongly pro-free trade would be sufficient to insure the passage of the measure, which was withdrawn in the House early on Monday when it became clear it would be defeated. 
 "It seems to me common sense to give the President that power because we're missing huge opportunities to do trade deals and create jobs in this country," said Michael S. Starnes, the chairman and chief executive of M. S. Carriers Inc. of Memphis, a trucking company.
"The ramifications for the economy could be serious," Mr. Starnes said. "I'm concerned that we'll end up exporting jobs rather than products."
And while many executives said in interviews today that they blamed organized labor for dooming the trade measure, some also faulted the business community for not doing a better job of making its case to members of Congress.
As they conducted a post-mortem on one of the most bitterly fought political battles in years, politicians, lobbyists and analysts agreed that business groups had simply been unable to create the ground swell of grass-roots support for their pro-trade position that labor unions created in opposition to the measure.
Whatever benefits "fast track" negotiating authority might bring to the economy and workers, they said, lawmakers heard about them primarily from lobbyists and senior business executives, not from workers and other voters in their districts.
"When big business goes head to head with unions, the unions clean their clock," said one Republican aide in Congress who was involved with efforts to pass the trade bill. "It's nice for a C.E.O. to come and sit on a sofa across from a Congressman and support free trade. But the other side is generating hundreds of phone calls, thousands of postcards and picketing outside the member's district office."
Some business executives said the trade battle had already led them to rethink their strategies for promoting their agenda in Washington. Among other steps, they said, they will do more to sell their own workers on the benefits of trade and encourage employees to make their opinions known to their members of Congress.
"We were working pretty hard," said Ronald Bullock, the chairman of the Bison Gear and Engineering Company in St. Charles, Ill., "but I think that we did not do enough in employee involvement, to help our employees contact their Congressional representatives to help sell the bill."
"We have to do more in helping our employees understand why this is good for the country, and in helping them to voice their concerns," Mr. Bullock said.
Many executives said the most immediate danger was from European and Asian competitors who are making inroads into fast-growing markets in Central and South America while the United States is effectively precluded from negotiating market-opening deals in those regions.
Eventually, they said, the same thing will happen in other parts of the world. And as it does, American companies will increasingly shift production from the United States to those regions in order to escape tariffs and other trade barriers, causing an acceleration of the trend that has seen manufacturing jobs migrate for decades to other nations.
"When we go, the jobs go," said Dennis W. Sheehan, the chairman of Axia Inc., a manufacturer in Oak Brook, Ill., which is under growing pressure to follow its major customers, including appliance makers, to new plants in other countries.
The automobile industry strongly supported the trade bill. But, reluctant to jeopardize their increasingly warm relations with the United Automobile Workers union, a leading opponent of the measure, auto executives made few public statements this autumn in favor of fast-track authority, preferring to confer with members of Congress in private.
Some business groups disputed the idea that they had failed to sell their case effectively, and said the main problem was that President Clinton had waited until September to disclose the details of the trade legislation.
"It is clear that the business community did a very good job in a short period of time," said Thomas Donohue, the head of the United States Chamber of Commerce. "It's also clear that if the President had come out with the bill sooner, we would have had a better chance of getting more supporters."
The Maytag Corporation had sales and administrative employees contacting more than 100 members of Congress to push for passage of the fast-track bill.
"But the opposition had an easier story to sell because they linked it to some of the bitterness left over from the Nafta debate," said Douglas Horstman, the company's vice president for government affairs, referring to the ratification of the North American Free Trade Agreement, with Mexico and Canada, in 1993. "Some of the labor unions played that theme very well."

HEADLINE: Russian Partner in Iran Deal Postpones Its Bond Offering

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Facing extraordinary pressure from Washington, a major Russian partner in a project to explore for natural gas in Iran today postponed a bond offering to raise up to $3 billion.
The postponement has temporarily headed off a decision by the Clinton Administration about whether to impose sanctions on the companies involved. 
 The Russian natural gas monopoly, Gazprom, cited uncertain market conditions in announcing the delay in a deal that had put the Clinton Administration in an awkward position. The lead underwriter for Gazprom is the American investment bank Goldman, Sachs, which might be found liable for its role under a Federal law aimed at punishing Iran.
The law -- the 1996 Iran-Libya Sanctions Act, which was devised to punish companies that invest more than $20 million in Iran's energy sector -- is being challenged by this deal, a $2 billion contract to pump natural gas signed by Gazprom, the French company Total and the Malaysian oil company Petronas.
The Gazprom postponement gives the Clinton Administration and its allies time to come up with a solution, but it does not make the problem go away. At the White House today, key Cabinet secretaries met in a so-called principals' meeting to discuss the competing interests involved -- American national security, deterrence of Iran, relations with allies, relations with Russia, relations with Congress and the impact of any new sanctions on the reputation of American markets.
"This is a very tough one," a senior Administration official said. "There are a lot of competing interests, and the coherence of our Iran policy is at stake."
Stopping the Gazprom financing would punish a key Russian company, partly owned by the Russian Government, that is vital to the success of Russia's shaky market economy. It would also punish Goldman, Sachs, a big contributor to President Clinton's campaign whose former co-chairman is the powerful Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, without stopping any other foreign company from underwriting Gazprom.
Stopping the financing would also short-circuit a process of investigation of the companies, called for under the law, and disrupt negotiations with European allies about how to deal most effectively with Iran and its efforts to develop weapons of mass destruction and the missiles to deliver them.
Adding to the pressure on the Administration, Congress had begun to discuss how to punish Goldman, Sachs and is already holding up the issuing of further Export-Import Bank credits to Gazprom.
On Wednesday the House of Representatives is expected to pass legislation that would sanction newly privatized Russian companies that are helping Iran develop longer-range missiles. While the Senate is not expected to take up the legislation until after its recess, the Administration will try to use the threat of the new sanctions to get Moscow "to behave on Iran," another senior official said.
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia has been told about the difficulties that Gazprom and its partners present on Iran.
Mr. Clinton spoke to Mr. Yeltsin by telephone about Iran on Oct. 29. He reminded the Russian leader that he had stood by Mr. Yeltsin when no one else did, and that he needed Mr. Yeltsin to take the Iran problem more seriously, said a Clinton contributor who heard about the call from Mr. Clinton himself.
Iran's support for terrorism and its potential threat with new missiles to Israel and moderate Arab countries has been an important issue for American Jews.
Asked at a Palm Beach, Fla., lunch on Oct. 31 about the Iran sanction cases, Mr. Clinton said he opposed outside help to Iran. "We're in an intense debate within the Administration now about what exactly we ought to do about it," he said. Mr. Clinton said he disagreed with "most of our allies -- they all think we're all wet," adding, "But I just believe that we should not be conducting ordinary business with a country that funds, trains and supports terrorists."
No one at Goldman, Sachs would comment publicly on the Gazprom announcement. While Gazprom has good financial reasons, after the Russian stock market drop, to postpone the bond offering, both Gazprom and Goldman, Sachs have good political and strategic reasons not to force a challenge to the Clinton Administration now, American officials said, just when it is trying to salvage its Iran policy without starting a sanctions war with the rest of the world.

HEADLINE: Abortion Issue Imperils $3.5 Billion U.S. Payment to the I.M.F.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Angered over the Clinton Administration's stand on abortions overseas, Senate Republicans are threatening to withhold the $3.5 billion the Administration wants to use to deal with financial crises, like those in Southeast Asia.
In 1995, in the wake of the American-led bailout of Mexico, the Administration proposed that the International Monetary Fund create a $48 billion reserve, provided by 25 nations, that could be used to handle future emergencies. A major reason was to insure that the United States would not have to bear the brunt of future bailouts. 
 In the last three months, the I.M.F. has said it will lend $17 billion to Thailand and $10 billion to Indonesia, as part of a broad international effort to stabilize their currencies and shore up their failing banks.
But on Monday, after the failure of President Clinton's effort to persuade Congress to grant him new authority to negotiate trade accords, the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, suggested that the money could be deleted from the foreign aid budget. He suggested that the outcome would depend on Mr. Clinton's willingness to accept anti-abortion restrictions on the use of American funds in population programs overseas.
Mr. Clinton refused to change his position on the abortion issue last weekend, even though that concession could have won enough votes from conservative Republicans to assure the passage of the "fast track" trade bill. Because Mr. Clinton has said that the $3.5 billion financing for the I.M.F. is a high priority, it has become the natural next target of those seeking restrictions that would stop money from going to foreign organizations that provide abortions or lobby governments to change abortion laws. The proposed Senate restriction would not apply to organizations that counsel patients to consider abortions.
Mr. Lott has also suggested that Republicans may drop from the bill $926 million that the United States owes to the United Nations in dues that are now deeply in arrears. Should the United States fail to pay, the United Nations would have the right to suspend its seat in the General Assembly, though not in the far more powerful Security Council.
The $3.5 billion would comprise the first American contribution to a financial credit line called the "New Arrangements to Borrow." It arose from the annual summit meeting of the world's largest industrial countries in 1995 in Halifax, Canada. Worried by the stresses that the collapse of the Mexican currency placed on financial markets around the world, Western leaders called for a new fund that could be used to stabilize nations in sudden, deep distress that threatens to rocket around world financial markets.
That is exactly what happened in Southeast Asia. Already, Asian nations have grown nervous that the United States will fail to make its contribution -- a step that might encourage other countries to do the same -- and they have begun discussing alternatives.
One, proposed by Japan in September, would create a special fund for Asian nations, perhaps outside of the I.M.F.'s jurisdiction. That would greatly diminish American influence over bailout programs, and could weaken the ability of the Fund to require austerity measures for countries like Thailand and Indonesia.
"We think the funding is in significant jeopardy," an Administration official said today. "But this has become a political football over abortion, rather than a discussion of how to keep countries afloat."

HEADLINE: For Messinger, No Regrets (and No Parade)

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
There was a parade yesterday, but Ruth W. Messinger did not go.
Five weeks ago, five months ago -- even five years ago -- that would have been unthinkable. Ms. Messinger's dream of becoming the mayor of New York City was still alive then, and the nurturing of it required appearances whenever and wherever the news cameras might be present. It required smiles when she did not feel them and sore feet that kept on moving. 
 But yesterday, while other politicians plodded down Fifth Avenue to mark Veterans Day, Ms. Messinger reclined on a couch in her Central Park West apartment, missing the parade for what she said was the first time in a decade.
Call it a luxury of defeat.
It is probably one of the few that Ms. Messinger will allow herself.
For in every other respect, the woman who just a week earlier had lost by an overwhelming margin to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was indistinguishable from the Democratic nominee who had hustled endlessly around the city, seeking a level of support that consistently eluded her.
In her sunlit living room, she talked about the educational crisis gripping New York City in the same dire language that she had used for months on end. She issued warnings about the city's high unemployment rate, as if still making a case to voters.
And she made clear, with every unprompted soliloquy and prescription, that while she may opt out of the parades, she will not be left out of the debate.
"All I know is that I will continue -- professionally and, small p, politically -- to work on the issues that I talked about in this campaign, which are the issues that I have worked on and talked about for 20 years," Ms. Messinger said.
She does not yet know specifically how she will do that once her term as Manhattan Borough President expires at the end of this year. She has no firm plans or job offers. She is not currently eyeing any other political office.
But it became clearer than ever yesterday that what she was doing and saying on the campaign trail in recent months was no temporary audition, nor was it a curtain call.
"Let me be very clear," she said yesterday, using the same locution and stern tone she had in her campaign, "the things that are going well in New York City -- which I tried very hard to recognize and acknowledge during the course of the campaign -- are not sufficient to affect the quality of life for a huge number of New Yorkers."
Why, then, was Mr. Giuliani re-elected? In her comments yesterday and in an article she wrote for this week's Village Voice, Ms. Messinger gave reasons that were beyond her control. A week's distance from the election had not changed her conviction that she and her advisers did not bungle the race.
What undid her candidacy, she said, was a mood in the city and the country of willful ignorance about problems beyond crime and the economy; news coverage of her campaign that she felt ignored some of the other issues she discussed and some of the enthusiasm she generated and the fact that Mr. Giuliani raised and spent almost twice as much money as she did.
She also said that her candidacy was hurt by the timing of the primary just eight weeks before the election, and that if challengers are to have a fair chance against incumbents in New York, primaries should be moved up to the spring.
She said that in retrospect, she perhaps should have spent more money before the Democratic primary, so that she could have won it more decisively and had a better "bounce." But, she said, until the day or so before the primary, polls suggested that she was in good shape. As it turned out, she narrowly missed having to face the Rev. Al Sharpton in a runoff.
Although Ms. Messinger never publicly focused on the long odds against her, she said she always recognized them, even when she began laying the groundwork for her candidacy three years ago.
Some supporters urged her to wait until 2001, but she was not sure that the odds would be better then, she said. The Democratic field would probably be larger and stronger, she noted, and she might not make it out of the primary.
"I do think a Democrat will win in 2001, and I thought that then," Ms. Messinger said of the next mayoral race. "But I didn't think there was any logic that said I would be that Democrat."
Besides, Ms. Messinger said, she fervently believed that there were issues that Mr. Giuliani was ignoring and that it was crucial for the future of the city that an informed Democratic challenger hold the Mayor's feet to the fire.
At no point, she said, did she lose all hope she might win. Although her husband, Andrew J. Lachman, said that his optimism ran dry about three weeks before Nov. 4 and that he told his wife then that she might want to begin thinking about what else to do with her life, Ms. Messinger said she woke up on Election Day feeling that at least a slight chance of victory existed.
"In a country and a city where turnout is constantly terrible and where you don't know how low turnout is going to be and who is actually going to decide to turn out, it's stupid not to think of every election as winnable," she said.
Yet there was not a scintilla of palpable sadness in her face or voice yesterday, despite the insistence of friends and political colleagues that her mayoral dreams were ardent and go back a decade or more. There was only the serious, all-business aura that Ms. Messinger always exhibits, which may be both the key to her endurance and the limit to her ambition.
Two days after the election, she turned 57, but said she did nothing special to celebrate her birthday. Then, she and Mr. Lachman took a long weekend in Bridgehampton to unwind. Ms. Messinger read a book about homeless New Yorkers and the city's policies and failings in dealing with them.
There is no political office other than mayor, she said, that would satisfy her desire to effect the kinds of changes in the city that she would like to see.
Does that mean she would consider running again?
"Nothing is out of the question -- nothing," Ms. Messinger said. Then, she waved aside further inquiries into that possibility. There were issues and problems she preferred to discuss.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In her Central Park West apartment yesterday, Ruth W. Messinger looked back on the mayoral race she lost to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. She vowed to continue to press issues she raised in the campaign. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.N.'s Council Moves to Block Travel by Iraqis

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The Security Council moved today toward all but certain passage of a resolution that will punish Iraq by banning travel by its officials, trying to avert military action by the United States. But no mention will be made of authorizing the use of force or other "serious consequences" if Iraq fails to comply, as the United States had wanted.
Washington, however, has taken the position from the beginning of the crisis over Iraq's order to expel American arms inspectors that Washington already has the Security Council's authority to respond militarily if necessary. 
 The resolution does allow for "further measures as may be needed." And diplomats here are seeing more signs that United Nations action alone may not be enough to force President Saddam Hussein to back down on his expulsion order.
Behind the scenes, diplomats say it is the possibility of an American military strike, which few other nations would support, that is pulling the Council together to condemn Iraq with one voice and to target Iraqi officials with new sanctions that were not supported three weeks ago.
A European diplomat said today that he could only hope that France and Russia, which oppose military action and tougher sanctions, are at the same time delivering a very strong warning to President Hussein in Baghdad, or else the Iraqi leader will once again misread the message the United Nations is sending.
Here and in Baghdad, Iraqi officials hardened their positions, hoping against all signals to the contrary that they can bargain for a reduction in the sanctions that have crippled the country's economy since the Persian Gulf war.
The Iraqi Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf, said there was no alternative but to "stop dealing or cooperating with the elements who are blocking the way toward lifting sanctions."
The 15-member Council is expected to pass a resolution on Wednesday that will, in addition to imposing a ban on the foreign travel of Iraqi officials, do several things: leave open the possibility of unspecified "further measures;" suspend further reviews of sanctions, and demand that President Hussein cooperate fully with a disarmament commission overseeing the destruction of Baghdad's weapons systems.
Bill Richardson, the United States representative, said tonight, after the Council adjourned, that it was a good resolution with "near-unanimous support." A question still hangs over China's vote, but diplomats do not expect a veto.
"It is a resolution that has teeth, that has united the Security Council once again," he said.
Russian, French and Chinese diplomats said today that Iraq must play by the rules set up in 1991, after Baghdad's defeat in the war. In Egypt, which holds a rotating Security Council seat this year, President Hosni Mubarak called on President Hussein to climb down and avoid a new crisis in the region.
Today's resolution made mention of a statement by the Council two weeks ago that held out the possibility of "serious consequences," but stopped short of repeating that threat.
While the Clinton Administration continues to insist that strong Security Council action is preferred and that an American military response is a distant possibility, the Iraqis seem bent on forcing Washington's hand with their unwillingness to budge from positions adopted since Oct. 29, when they ordered Americans on the arms investigation team out.
Iraq insists on an easing of sanctions, a timetable for the end of the embargo, and a smaller American presence among investigators who can make the call on whether Iraq is complying with the 1991 agreement to disarm under international supervision.
Today, for the eighth time in nine days, Baghdad blocked efforts by the monitors to enter suspect Iraqi sites because United States citizens were among the inspection teams. United Nations officials refuse to send out teams stripped of American experts.
As days pass, concern grows that Iraq may be taking advantage of the suspended inspections to hide potential arms or produce biological or chemical compounds. Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen addressed this fear today.
"Iraq would not be able to reconstitute a serious weapons program in a matter of days," he told reporters in Washington. "If the delay were to carry on for months, then that would be a different situation. That's why time is of the essence here to get Saddam Hussein to fully comply with the inspections regime."
And at a Veterans Day ceremony today at Arlington National Cemetery, President Clinton said, "These inspectors since 1991 have discovered and destroyed more weapons of mass destruction potential than was destroyed in Iraq in the entire gulf war. They are doing what they should be doing. They must get back to work, and the international community must demand it."
Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, described the confrontation succinctly today when he left a meeting with Qin Huasun, China's representative at the United Nations and this month's Security Council president. Mr. Qin told Mr. Aziz that Iraq would have to comply with the rules before it gets a hearing on any substantive issue.
"I have not been given any concrete promise that there will be a change in the position of the Council," Mr. Aziz told reporters. "And I on my part did not give a concrete promise for change. If you do not have a change on the part of the Security Council, you cannot expect a change in Iraq."
Mr. Aziz, who has not been given an opportunity to address the Security Council, got into a spirited exchange of insults today with Richard Butler, the Australian arms control expert who is executive chairman of the United Nations Special Commission, the body disarming Iraq.
Mr. Butler challenged Mr. Aziz to take a look at the facts about the disarmament mission. Mr. Aziz has been saying that more than 30 percent of the commission jobs are held by Americans and that more "balance" was called for.
Mr. Butler said at a news conference that the top nationality on the 180-member commission, with offices in New York, Bahrain and Baghdad, was Chilean, with 22 percent of the jobs. The Chileans provide helicopters and crews. Americans held 14 percent of the positions, and next, Britons were at 11 percent, New Zealand 9 percent, Iraqis 6 percent and Australians 5 percent.
Mr. Aziz, making a spirited appearance at a microphone placed outside the Security Council, countered that the Iraqis were all low-level employees of no consequence. Americans, he said, held a disproportionate number of sensitive jobs. "So this is a falsification," he said of Mr. Butler's account.
Mr. Butler, who earlier called the accusations by Iraq "wrong on all counts and distasteful," noted that some of the Americans are in New York doing "some of our really dangerous work, like bookkeeping."
He said that when the Iraqis produced a list of Americans to prove their point, they included Britons, a Canadian and a Dane among them. Mr. Butler called this "disturbing and maybe pathetic."

HEADLINE: KODAK TO LAY OFF 10,000 EMPLOYEES IN A 10% CUTBACK

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company, which has spent more than a decade reducing its work force, said yesterday that it would cut another 10,000 jobs, the biggest layoff announcement this year by any American company.
Kodak was once known as the "Great Yellow Father" in its hometown of Rochester because of its paternalistic employment practices. But it has been forced to shrink drastically as competition with Fuji of Japan has hurt its biggest business, film, while futuristic photographic products have not caught on as the company had hoped. 
 The measures are the most drastic yet by George M. C. Fisher, Kodak's chief executive, who, when he was hired in 1993, was praised as a corporate visionary with a plan to restore the company's growth but has instead seen profits languish. The company hopes to save $1 billion in the next two years through the job reductions, equal to 10 percent of the work force, and other cuts.
Mr. Fisher acknowledged yesterday that he and his team might not have tackled the problems as quickly as they should have. "We are really mad at ourselves that we got into this situation, but we are out of denial, and determined to get back on track," he said.
In Rochester, where roughly one-third of the company's employees are concentrated, the cuts are sure to have lasting effects. Because of Kodak's philanthropic and research financing, Rochester is still in some respects a one-company town, and many Kodak workers and retirees have large portions of their investments tied up in the company.
For many of these families, the anxiety caused by the announcement was heightened by the fact that the company did not say what businesses or cities would bear the brunt of the layoffs.
Mayor Bill Johnson said that while Kodak had promised him that it would not move any lines of business out of Rochester, the company had made it clear that it "will not create new job possibilities here in the near term."
Nevertheless, the Mayor noted that Rochester had absorbed heavy layoffs in the past, and still had one of the lowest unemployment rates -- 4.2 percent -- in New York State. "There will be short-term pain for the individuals who lose their jobs, but there is a resiliency in the Rochester economy," he said.
Maybe so -- but others wonder whether there is a similar resilience inside Kodak. "After these layoffs, the level of commitment, morale and loyalty is going to be extremely low," said Donald Wilson, a professor of management at the Rochester Institute of Technology.
To be sure, Kodak has been steadily trimming its work force, paring some 40,000 jobs since 1983, and settling at a slimmed-down 94,800 workers by the end of last year. Kodak has traditionally cushioned its employment blows, offering employees rich severance packages to leave on their own, and limiting actual dismissals. But the new cuts will go deeper than ever before. The latest move follows one in late September when the company dismissed 200 of its 1,000 top managers and announced that it would eliminate 10 percent of its sales and administrative staff.
Although the company would not say which cities or operations would be hardest hit by the latest cuts, most analysts expect that marketing, finance and clerical workers will bear the brunt of the layoffs.
The reported earnings of Kodak will be reduced by at least $1 billion, or about $2 a share, in the fourth quarter, to account for severance packages and to write down assets.
Downsizing is not the only weapon in Kodak's cost-cutting arsenal: the company will also pare $150 million off its research budget. And, it is looking at outsourcing, partnerships and various consolidations of operations to squeeze costs out of its manufacturing processes. "We intend to take significant amounts of cost out of the cost of goods sold," said Daniel A. Carp, Kodak's president.
Still, the company's announcement left Wall Street, where the cuts had been widely anticipated, hungering for more. The company's shares, which had risen in the last two weeks, fell 6 percent yesterday -- closing at $62.1875, down $4.0625 -- as investors decided that the measures would not go far enough in improving profits.
Behind much of Kodak's trouble has been the disappointment in the relatively new digital photography business, which involves devices that take pictures and "develop" them using electrons instead of film and that transmit images electronically, as if they were files of data.
Mr. Fisher, who came to Kodak from another high-technology company, Motorola Inc., had once predicted that the digital operations would break even this year; instead, they will probably lose more than $300 million.
In the past, Kodak had been able to fall back on its hugely lucrative film and processing-paper business to buoy earnings when other product lines were flagging. But this time around, Kodak is steadily losing market share to Fuji, which has been undercutting Kodak's prices. The problem has been worsened by the strength of the dollar, which has made Kodak's products relatively more expensive overseas.
Worldwide, each company has about one-third of the film market. In the United States, Kodak still has roughly a two-thirds share, but it has been losing two to three percentage points a year to Fuji, its closest competitor. In Japan, the situation is reversed, with Fuji holding 65 to 70 percent of the market; Kodak, which holds a much smaller share, has long complained of trade barriers.
Analysts said that much of the disappointment on Wall Street yesterday was caused by a lack of specifics about what Kodak would do. "There are still two wild cards," said John Gavin of American Express Financial Services. "How much will Kodak cut film prices, and when will digital finally be profitable?"
So far, Kodak has resisted permanent price reductions as a way to counter Fuji. But it has held several promotions that could easily be taken for price cuts. And, while Mr. Carp is adamant that Kodak "will not lead prices downward" he made it clear that Kodak would not tolerate a further widening of the price gap, which has gone as high as 30 percent in some markets.
That uncertainty has some analysts a bit uneasy. "What Fuji does will become as important as what Kodak does," Robert P. Curran of Merrill Lynch said. Similarly, B. Alexander Henderson of Prudential Securities said, "We're going to be watching Fuji's prices pretty closely, because if they go down again, so will Kodak's earnings."
Fuji insists that it never has, and never will, engage in a price war. In fact, it even raised prices in June. And next month, Fuji, which had been importing film from the Netherlands to sell in the United States, will open a plant in North Carolina, effectively wiping out any advantage from currency fluctuations. "We are going to compete by raising our brand awareness in the marketplace, not by a price war," said Paul A. Hudak, a Fuji vice president.
There is another wild card in the rivalry between Fuji and Kodak. Last year, Kodak filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization, contending that Fuji and Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry were collaborating to keep foreign products out of Japan. The United States Government and the European Union joined in the complaint. The trade organization is expected to decide soon whether to intercede on Kodak's behalf.
Analysts were full of suggestions yesterday as to where Kodak should consolidate and prune its businesses, regardless of the outcome of the battle with Fuji. Many analysts proposed, for example, that the company set up a joint venture for its X-ray film business, which has been under extreme pricing pressure from group purchasing organizations in medical care.
And he made it clear that Kodak would go after every possible retail opportunity. It is, for example, accelerating efforts to push into many more retail outlets its photo manipulation machines, which let consumers crop, enlarge or otherwise enhance photos. And, it is putting more advertising behind products, including the Advantix -- a hybrid camera that uses digital imaging and conventional film.
"Our business is not film, or digital cameras or electronics," Mr. Fisher said. "Our business is pictures, in any form, and we can't lose sight of that."

HEADLINE: 5,000 Absentee Ballots Are Seized in Miami Fraud Inquiry

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 11

 BODY:
State officials have seized more than 5,000 absentee ballots as part of an investigation into possible fraud and vote-buying in last week's mayoral election.
Mayor Joe Carollo received 49.6 percent of the vote, while former Mayor Xavier L. Suarez received 46.8 percent. Since neither received more than half of the vote, a runoff will be held on Thursday. 
 The investigation followed a tip last month that an individual affiliated with the Suarez campaign was buying absentee ballots, though that person has not been charged, investigators said.
But then Manuel Amador, who said he was a campaign volunteer for Mr. Suarez, was charged with three counts of vote fraud last week after an undercover agent said Mr. Amador had agreed to buy three absentee ballots bearing the names of dead voters.
Mr. Suarez, who received 2 out of 3 absentee ballots cast, has denied that Mr. Amador worked for him, but also said he believed that Mr. Amador was entrapped.
Investigators have also focused on Alberto Russi, 92, a volunteer for a City Commission candidate, Humberto Hernandez. Mr. Russi's signature appeared as a witness on at least 90 absentee ballots, officials said, including one purported to have been signed by Manuel Yip, who died in 1993.
A search of Mr. Russi's house on Monday yielded 75 absentee ballots already filled out for Thursday's election, state investigators said.
"What was strange is that many of those 75 had his address," said Jourdan Doyle, regional director of the Florida Department of Law Enforcement. "So he was obviously having these ballots sent to his house, possibly without the knowledge of these voters."
Investigators said they also found 21 voter registration cards at Mr. Russi's home.
Lawyers for Mayor Carollo have filed suit to nullify the absentee ballots and declare him the winner.
Mayor Carollo, who weathered a financial crisis stemming from the city's $68 million budget deficit in the past year, and Mr. Suarez, who was Mayor from 1985 to 1993, are bitter rivals.
Both men have waged overwhelmingly negative campaigns, with debates punctuated by shouting matches in Spanish and English.
Both are Cuban-Americans, an important factor in a city that is more than 60 percent Hispanic.
Whoever is elected will be the city's first strong mayor, with added powers.
The Dade County Elections Supervisor, David Leahy, said that in a city with many elderly voters, absentee ballots presented a great potential for fraud.
In recent years, people known as ballot brokers have become more common, Mr. Leahy said. The brokers buy or manipulate voters into giving them signed, blank absentee ballots that can then be cast for any candidate.
The only requirement is that the ballots be counter-signed by a witness, and much of the time these are campaign workers, Mr. Leahy said.
"I think it's healthy that this is out in the open and we're dealing with it,," he said of the current investigation.
Mr. Leahy said restricting the absentee system would be a hardship for the disabled and the elderly.
Dario Moreno, professor of Political Science at Florida International University, said that placing a limit on the number of absentee ballots that one witness could sign might help reduce vote fraud and rescue the city's damaged image.
"This reinforces the Wild West image that the city of Miami has, where scandals and corruption are the usual ways the city does business," Mr. Moreno said.

HEADLINE: Mental Care Coverage Costs Little, Study Finds

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Giving employees mental-health coverage on par with the insurance they receive for physical ailments would involve only minimal costs for employers, according to a study.
The findings by Roland Sturm, an economist at the Rand Corporation, a research organization in Santa Monica, Calif., come less than two months before Federal legislation to help achieve parity between mental-health and medical coverage goes into effect. 
 The law generally bars businesses from providing higher annual and lifetime caps for physical diseases than for mental illness.
Mr. Sturm's study appears in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. He examined data from 24 public-employer health plans with more than 140,000 enrollees each.
All the plans used a common managed-care feature in which medical care and mental health services are provided separately and employers "carve out" mental health care to a subsidiary or an independent vendor.
Mr. Sturm found that removing the typical $25,000 yearly limit on mental health benefits would raise employers' group insurance costs by only about $1 an enrollee a year.
The most expensive changes he looked at would increase an employer's cost by no more than $7 an enrollee. He said his findings applied only to carve-out plans. But most managed-care plans that offer mental health benefits do it through carve-out arrangements. Mr. Sturm acknowledged that most of the employers were in the Midwest and were not in the private sector, where most of the work force is employed.
"The data are not necessarily representative for all industries or for other geographic regions in the country," he wrote.
He examined data from 1995 and 1996. Most previous cost estimates for parity between the two areas of coverage involved much older data reflecting the state of managed care in its infancy and found that the costs would be four to eight times higher than his projections, Mr. Sturm said.
The new law, which will take effect on Jan. 1, does not require employers to offer mental health benefits. But if employers do offer them, the limits on coverage must be equal to those for physical ailments. The law does not apply to some small businesses.
A spokesman for the American Association of Health Plans, which represents managed-care companies and over 1,000 health plans covering more than 140 million people, called Mr. Sturm's report "a very interesting and thoughtful study" but said further research was needed to determine how expensive parity would be.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Waiting Game: Easier to Play On Level Field

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
DUST clouds hung in the sunny rooms of Gregory Bortnik's home, where work crews broke through floors and walls with jackhammers and drills. They had got a late start on the project, since Mr. Bortnik had only closed on the three-story brick house in Bensonhurst a few days earlier. No problem. In the month that it will take for renovations, his family will double up with their oldest daughter on Long Island.
"We must wait," he said. "We have no choice." 
 Those words could be his motto, perhaps engraved on a plaque by the door. Ten years ago this week, Mr. Bortnik and his family arrived in Brooklyn after having waited, if not wasted, the previous 10 years while Soviet officials first granted, then denied, permission to emigrate. The bureaucratic flip-flop left them with no possessions and no professions. Mr. Bortnik lost his job as an engineer and became a shoemaker, while his wife, Faina, went from dentistry to cosmetology.
They persevered because they felt they had little to look forward to in a country where opportunities for Jews were limited. Before he decided to leave, Mr. Bortnik once thought his years of service had entitled him to a promotion at work. Instead, the job went to a new man while he was told bluntly, "You forget who you are."
"Over here it doesn't matter who you are," he said. "If you are smart and want to reach something, you can. There, they don't want you. But they don't want you to get out."
The Bortniks lived in the Ukrainian city of Nikolayev, close by their parents. Mrs. Bortnik remembered hearing stories about her grandfather, who had traveled to America in the early 1900's with relatives and earned some money. He had managed to save enough to bring over his family, and he returned home with tickets in hand. But the Russian Revolution changed his plans, and the family stayed.
By the 1970's, Mrs. Bortnik knew she had to leave. "To live in Russia, you always have to remember you are Jewish. When you see that attitude coming from some person, it's one story. But when it comes from the Government, it's different."
Already a dentist working at a large medical center, she figured it might be easier to leave if she became a cosmetologist and worked in a smaller setting where there were fewer bosses to object.
The Bortniks and their parents moved to Tiraspol in Moldavia to be closer to Government immigration offices. In 1981, they got word that their exit papers had been approved. They sold their furniture and gave up their apartment, only to be told by an official that a mistake had been made.
"For that moment, we didn't have anything," Mrs. Bortnik recalled. "I told him I have two kids. How did he think I was going to raise them? What was I going to tell them, that we have a great Government? That we have a great country?"
The official reply: Go home.
They did, although they lived in an apartment they never furnished. To do so would have been acknowledging they were staying. Mr. Bortnik took up the unfamiliar tools of a shoemaker. "If you're an engineer, your hands are clean and your skin is so soft," he said. "When I worked as a shoemaker, my hands bled for the first year. It was like I cut my life for that country."
To survive, he cut off his thoughts.
"You decide to leave, you live in a bottle," he said. "Everything around you is not real. I cut off all the lines to that country. I just thought about when I could leave."
IN 1987, with glasnost in the air, permission finally came. Within a few months, a Jewish aid group helped them and their parents settle in Brooklyn.
The Bortniks have done modestly well. One daughter is in college and another is a computer programmer married to a doctor. Mr. Bortnik worked as a chauffeur and shoe salesman until he got a job in construction. He has a small company now, with two employees. After years working for others, Mrs. Bortnik wound up unemployed when her boss closed up her salon without warning. Now she owns a day spa with the grand name Faina Bor Spa Palace of Beauty. She works six days a week.
"We don't feel like we're from another planet," she said. "We live a normal life, like everybody."
That includes setbacks, like a delayed closing on a house. Small matter. They had a decade of practice before arriving.
"Only an idiot would think there would be no problems," Mr. Bortnik said. "But in this country, you can do something with these problems."
