HEADLINE: Shelters Improve Under Private Groups, Raising a New Worry

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
The first time Elizabeth Squires ended up at the Park Avenue Armory women's shelter two years ago, she found a place she described as forbidding, marked by discourteous guards, indifferent social workers and cold meals.
But when she returned last year, dramatic changes had occurred. The city had given up day-to-day control of the Manhattan shelter for single women and turned it over to a private operator. Security guards had shed their uniforms and their sometimes hostile attitudes. The accommodations were still spartan, with women given a cot in a vast armory hall, but counselors made themselves available every day, and the meals became something that residents like Ms. Squires actually looked forward to. 
 "Before, the food they served looked like worms had been in it," said Ms. Squires, 54, a scrappy woman who said that eviction from a Queens apartment led her to the shelter system several years ago. "It was hard getting used to the new people even though the old ones weren't that great. But they made good changes, changes for the better."
Changes like those at the Park Avenue Armory are happening citywide as the Giuliani administration takes the city out of the business of running shelters for single adults and hands the job over to private nonprofit organizations that many experts contend are better equipped to handle the homeless.
To date, the city has given contracts to nonprofit companies to run 33 of the city's 40 notoriously troubled shelters for single adults -- from the cavernous Fort Washington Armory in Washington Heights to the Sumner Armory in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, to the Charles H. Gay men's shelter on Wards Island.
The city turned to the nonprofit agencies in the 1980's after experts realized that the single homeless were not just without housing, but that they often had other problems that contributed to their homelessness and required support services. The nonprofit agencies, proponents of privatization say, are better prepared to work with the homeless because their workers are trained specifically in areas of mental health, substance abuse and unemployment, while the city essentially relies on all-purpose case workers. By this time, the city had already begun shifting to a privatized system for homeless families.
"I've seen some of those shelters with my own eyes and I welcome the change that they are operated under," said Joel Sessor, president of Partnership for the Homeless, a longtime network of private shelters that provides housing, job counseling and health services but does not run any of the former municipal shelters. "Historically, government has been the provider of last resort and it really showed here in the city."
But there is a downside to the transformation of the shelters, advocates for the homeless say. The city is allowing people to stay in the shelters for a longer time, to take advantage of the improved services, and as a result, the advocates say, there is less pressure to create permanent housing, the ultimate cure for homelessness.
Last year, 1,934 single adults were placed into permanent housing from the shelter system, a higher figure than in 1994 and 1995 but lower than the city's peak in 1993, when 2,351 people were moved into permanent housing, according to a report released last month by the Citizens Budget Commission, a government watchdog group.
Privatization, however, has increased the annual cost of shelter beds from $18,000 to $23,000.
"We like privatization, but it's not enough to go forth and privatize everything in sight," said Mary Brosnahan, executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless, an advocacy group that recently released a report on the city's privatization efforts. "They must redouble their efforts so people can transition out of a privatized system. People are not leaving the shelters because there is no place else for them to go."
The coalition's report faulted the Giuliani administration for cutting the budget for the city's Department of Homeless Services by $87.4 million over three years. The cuts, the coalition said, have come at a time when the number of single adults in city shelters has increased by 1,000 since 1994 to an average of more than 7,000 per night. With single adults and families combined, the city provides shelter for an average of about 23,000 people a night in large congregate spaces like armories and welfare hotels. Over the course of a year, more than 86,000 different people cycle through the system.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, in a pre-election discussion with reporters and editors of The New York Times, embraced privatization, arguing that the improved social services that result allow homeless people to become more independent.
The effort by the Giuliani administration to privatize the shelter system reflects a policy change that began in 1981, when Mayor Edward I. Koch signed a consent decree that made New York the first city in the nation responsible for the direct care of homeless people. Most cities rely on charitable and nonprofit groups.
At the height of the crisis, more than 25,000 people were crowded onto the drill floors of sprawling armories with barely enough room between cots for walking. Fights often broke out between shelter residents and guards. Substance abuse and mental health issues were not being addressed.
"I used to go to shelters just to make it clear to civil servants that they had to make sure people had cots, blankets, cribs and formula for infants," Mr. Koch said. "You had to do that often, shake up civil servants who had gotten lax. Religious and other private groups do well because they have incentives. They're not bound by unions or civil service laws."
The city could not undertake privatization then because of a lack of providers, Mr. Koch said.
But by the time Mr. Koch left office in 1989, families -- as opposed to singles -- were being moved from large open-floor shelters into permanent housing -- mostly rehabilitated apartments. Today the vast majority of the city's 83 shelters for families are run by nonprofit organizations.
In 1992, the New York City Commission on the Homeless, headed by Andrew Cuomo, now Secretary of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, called for privatizing shelters for single adults, urging an array of social services to encourage the transition into permanent housing.
The Giuliani administration has used the report as its blueprint, and dozens of providers have emerged, including the Salvation Army, Volunteers of America and the Housing Enterprise for the Less Privileged organization, which is headed by Maria Cuomo Cole, who like Andrew is a child of former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Shelters have been downsized and upgraded. The Fort Washington Armory, which once housed about 800 men on drill floors, now houses about 200 men in small dormitories of about 20 beds each. Sixty-five percent of the beds in the adult shelter system get financing to provide alcohol and substance abuse treatment and employment services.
Steven Banks, director of the Legal Aid Society's Homeless Rights Project, noted that some of the open-foor shelters like Wards Island are still too large for even private agencies to run. He also pointed out that families still have long waits at the central processing center in the Bronx called the Emergency Assistance Unit, where they are evaluated before being admitted into shelters. Yet he also offers praise.
"The city's approach was to simply provide three hots and a cot without trying to meet the needs of homeless people to move on with their lives," Mr. Banks said. "They were simply warehouses of despair. Now, there is a much greater focus on providing the necessary services like mental health."
More than a decade ago, the East Third Street Men's Shelter in Manhattan was emblematic of all that was wrong with shelters. Scores of homeless men loitered outside the crowded building just off the Bowery. Employees were arrested for selling drugs.
Today, the shelter, handed over to Project Renewal, a nonprofit group, in 1994, is a tightly managed 200-bed site with substance abuse treatment and job training.
On a recent Friday night, dozens of men sat around watching a movie, workers dished out chocolate and vanilla ice cream and delivery men brought in orders of chicken wings. In the basement, men painted and shaped sculptures in an art room and honed computer skills in the lab. They could even receive hair cuts in a windowless barber shop.
The Park Avenue women's shelter, which houses 100 mentally ill women and has been run for 18 months by Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, a private charity founded in 1894, is among the best examples of how privatization has improved conditions.
Nancy Wackstein, the organization's executive director and the director of the Mayor's Office of Homelessness under Mr. Dinkins, said that when her organization first arrived the shelter resembled "the back ward of some mental institution." Workers spent days sanding floors, throwing out decrepit furniture and exterminating rodents. The women were skittish, angry and even violent because they were not receiving the medical attention they needed, she said.
The barrack-style sleeping quarters still exist, but administrators and other workers encourage orderliness, checking bags for contraband and garbage.
Most important, clinical social workers began arriving every day and a psychiatrist began keeping office hours three days a week. Security guards were replaced by program aides, who not only act as security but help distribute meals, remind women about their medical appointments and listen when they have problems, Ms. Wackstein said.
Before Lenox Hill took over, the television was the sole source of distraction. Now, the days are filled with aerobics, bingo, sewing and classes for people preparing to move into their own apartments. Instructors teach them how to dress when they see an apartment, and how to complete a lease and work out a budget in order to pay their rent on time.
Ms. Squires, dressed in a floral dress, a pink sweatshirt and dark sunglasses, talked readily about the different face of the Park Avenue shelter.
"When I was here the first time around, you could have coffee and stay around watching soaps all day," Ms. Squires said. "Now, things are better. You have stuff to do."
Despite such comments, critics worry that the comforts and greater attention will lessen the pressure to move homeless men and women out of shelters. The report of the Coalition for the Homeless said that more people are staying longer, leaving little room for newcomers. With winter just around the corner, advocates are concerned the city will be unable to provide shelter for all who need it.
Officials within the Giuliani administration respond that longer stays are a sign that they are helping people get better, which could help break the cycle of homelessness.
"The issue today is more than housing," said Gordon Campbell, Commissioner of the city's Department of Homeless Services. "We're attempting to understand the underlying causes of homelessness. People are staying longer in the shelters because they are receiving the help that they need."

HEADLINE: THE TRADE BILL: LABOR;
Labor Victory On Trade Bill Reveals Power

BYLINE: By JILL ABRAMSON with STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The stinging blow to President Clinton's trade policy delivered by House Democrats reflects the growing political aggressiveness of the nation's labor unions, their ability to mobilize members and labor's increasing importance in financing Democratic candidates.
Of particular importance in the defeat of the trade bill on Monday, which was labor's biggest legislative victory in years, was an important shift in the Democratic Party's financial center of gravity. 
 Union money has grown increasingly predominant for House Democrats, whose financial support from business began drying up after Republicans won control of Congress in 1994. By 1996, contributions from labor's political action committees jumped to 48 percent of PAC donations to House Democrats, up from 33 percent in 1992.
To be sure, labor's money was not the only reason why so many Democrats joined the labor-led mutiny to defeat the President's efforts to expand his power to negotiate free-trade agreements.
Many Democrats were unhappy with the results of the North American Free Trade Agreement passed in 1993, and many voiced concern that the "fast track" trade bill did too little to protect environmental and labor standards overseas.
Labor unions began mobilizing against the fast-track measure last spring and waged an energetic pressure campaign, aimed at Democrats and Republican House members in districts with many union members. Union members showered members of Congress, especially House Democrats, with tens of thousands of letters and phone calls asserting that the fast track authority would be bad for workers. Labor's effort against the trade bill was joined by environmental groups, consumer safety groups and civil rights organizations.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. went on the air in 20 key Congressional districts with advertisements opposing the measure in mid-September and had spent $1.5 million to $2 million through the end of last week, said Denise Mitchell, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. spokeswoman.
It was labor's biggest showdown with the White House since unions lost their battle in 1993 over Nafta. "We saw this as a battle for the soul of the country," Ms. Mitchell said.
After a decade in which many Democrats, including President Clinton, refashioned themselves as New Democrats, labor's victory complicates the efforts of some Democrats to be more business-friendly. Many Democrats joined groups like the Democratic Leadership Council, which receives money from some of the corporations that supported the fast-track bill. The council spent $200,000 on television advertising supporting President Clinton's trade policies.
The fight also unfolded at a precarious time for Democrats. The Democratic Party is $15 million in the red, so it is not all that surprising that so many Democratic lawmakers chose to stand with organized labor rather than with the President because they were mindful that unions had become the largest donors to Democratic Congressional campaigns and that unions also mobilized the most campaign foot soldiers.
"The Democratic Party is bankrupt, everyone knows that, said Thomas J. Donohue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, "and the only money these guys can get is from the unions."
For John J. Sweeney, the fast-track fight was his biggest triumph by far since he took the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s helm two years ago on a platform promising to revive union power both in Washington and at the bargaining table. The victory was especially sweet for Mr. Sweeney after he lost a huge political battle last November: the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s $35 million campaign to help Democrats regain control of Congress.
"This is really a big win," Mr. Sweeney said. "We can't lose sight of what it was all about in terms of the economic vulnerability that so many people are experiencing with this recovering economy. That's where the White House missed the boat. Ordinary Americans oppose fast track. They worry that while the economy is booming most of the rewards are passing them by."
Republican House leaders, who supported President Clinton's position on the trade bill, were quick to explain their defeat by citing the clout of union money and they complained that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. threatened to withhold money from recalcitrant members.
But in reality, overt threats were not necessary. Most House Democrats are well aware of the fact that labor union political action committees have supplied their campaigns with a growing percentage of PAC donations.
Before the Democrats lost control of the Congress, business PAC's were stuffing campaigns with money, $25.2 million in 1993 and 1994. But in 1996, they gave only $16.7 million to House Democrats, while labor PAC's stepped up their giving, to $36.8 million in 1996 from $31.8 million in 1994.
"Money follows power," said Larry Makinson, deputy director of the Center for Responsive Politics. "When all that business money was coming in, Democrats were happy to be part of the country club set. Now they've come home to labor. With fast track the Democrats were reminding themselves where they came from since their new suitor walked out of the door with the Republicans."
Besides its debt, the Democratic Party was defeated and badly outspent by the Republican Party in major contests in Virginia, New York and New Jersey earlier this month. Although the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is having a successful year, having raised more than $10 million, Democratic candidates are nervous about their party's ability to fully finance House contests next year in the mid-term elections.
Some of the Democrats' business soft money donors, the wealthy individuals and corporations whose donations fall outside the Federal election laws, have been scared off by the campaign finance imbroglio. Unions, however, have continued to give generous soft money donations to the Democrats.
Under the guidance of Tony Coelho, the former House whip and Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee chairman, the Democrats in the 1980's successfully courted business donors, using their chairmanships of major financial committees as a lure. Once the Democrats lost their majority, however, "the Coelho bubble burst," Mr. Makinson said.
Al From, president of the Democratic Leadership Council, said the fast-track defeat should make business donors reassess their strategy.
"The business community really has to think very hard about ignoring House Democrats," Mr. From said. "Even though the Democrats are in a minority, if business doesn't get every single Republican vote their issues can be placed in jeopardy."
While the Republican leadership asserted that Big Labor's strong-arm tactics were what doomed fast-track, labor leaders say fast track lost because of "Little Labor." It was not the chiefs, union leaders say, but the tens of thousands of Indians in Ohio and elsewhere who wrote the letters, made the phone calls, went to protests and met with their representatives in Congress. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. set up an 800-telephone number that union members could call to be connected to their members of Congress, the apparel workers' union ran ads in Spanish-language newspapers, and the teamsters broadcast anti-fast track ads on radio stations that truckers listen to. All told, members of the steelworkers' union sent 160,000 handwritten letters to Congress.
Many lawmakers who opposed fast track had studied what happened to several dozen Democratic members of Congress who defied labor and voted for Nafta in 1993, and lost to Republicans in 1994, partly because many disaffected union members did not go to the polls that year.
"We told a lot of Congressmen that this issue is very important to our people, and if you don't support us on it, that will affect the way our members feel about you next November," said Jay Mazur, president of the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees.
Union leaders sought to build on their failed Nafta effort, concluding, for instance, that they had to cooperate more with environmental groups and consumer safety groups to block fast track. At the farmers market at Embarcadero Center in San Francisco, the teamsters union distributed fliers stating that Nafta has led to imports of unsafe fruits and vegetables, and that the fast track authority would do likewise. Decrying Nafta's environmental effects on Mexican border towns, unions also held demonstrations with Friends of the Earth and the Sierra Club in a half dozen cities.
"We didn't want to talk just to union members, we wanted to talk to a broader audience to say that this is bad for families, even if your job is not on the line," said Steven Trossman, an anti-fast-track strategist with the teamsters.
Even as the union movement rejoiced over its fast-track victory, that success brings some problems for labor. Bruised and angry, businesses are is vowing to redouble efforts against the newly muscular labor movement and relations with the White House are badly strained.
Mr. Sweeney said he hoped to cooperate again soon with the President -- on a new trade bill more to labor's liking and on other issues. And while the fast track fight cemented ties between labor and many Congressional Democrats, some centrist and conservative Democrats, including Mr. From, feared that the fight would weaken the Democratic Party. These centrists say the visibility of labor's clout will push the Democratic Party further left, thereby alienating many Americans. And White House officials worry the party has been hurt by the fractures resulting from the battle.
Labor leaders say they warned the White House last August that if it submitted a trade bill they did not like, unions would fight.
But the White House rejected labor's pleas, fearing such a bill would not be palatable to Republican leaders.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12
 
U.N. Readies a Move Against a Defiant Iraq
The Security Council, seeking to avoid a military resolution imposed by the United States, was poised to pass a resolution punishing Iraq with a travel ban and demanding that President Saddam Hussein cooperate fully with an international commission charged after the Persian Gulf war with monitoring Iraq's disarmament. The crisis began when Iraq ordered American inspectors on the team expelled. A1
 
Muslim Atrocities in Sarajevo
Witnesses in Sarajevo, along with previously secret court documents, revealed that Muslim militias and paramilitary units killed scores of Serb civilians who remained in the city when it was under siege by Bosnian Serb forces in 1992. A1
 
4 Americans Killed in Pakistan
Four U. S. citizens and one Pakistani were killed early today when gunmen opened fire on their vehicle in Karachi, the authorities said. No one has claimed responsibility for the killings, but they follow the conviction Monday of a Pakistani for fatally shooting two employees outside C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va. The State Department has warned Americans in Pakistan to watch out for possible retaliation for the conviction. A3
 
Russian Bond Sale Is Delayed
Gazprom, the giant Russian natural gas monopoly, postponed a $3 billion bond offering. The company attributed the delay to uncertain market conditions, but it has been subject to pressure from Washington for its role as a major partner in a project to explore for natural gas in Iran. The Clinton Administration was itself under pressure to impose penalties on Gazprom and its French and Malaysian partners for investing in Iran, which the United States accuses of supporting terrorism. A10
 
Affirmative Action Wins Abroad
In a decision that could affect affirmative action programs in all 15 European Union countries, the European Court of Justice ruled in favor of a law passed by a German state government enhancing women's access to public-sector jobs. The European Union's highest court ruled that preferential hiring and promotional practices could be used to correct earlier discrimination. A7
 
Violent Scuffle in Bethlehem
Israel opened a new fortified complex encasing Rachel's Tomb, a Jewish shrine in an Israeli-controlled part of Palestinian-controlled Bethlehem. A nine-year-old Palestinian boy was shot in the head and critically wounded by an Israeli soldier firing on stone-throwing protesters. A3
 
New Twist in Mexican Routine
Mexico's Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, presented the new federal budget to his country's Congress and was duly applauded by members of the Government's party. This time, however, the lower house is controlled by an opposition alliance which has declared its intention to make broad revisions to the budget. Mr. Ortiz's proposed budget increased spending on health care and education for the poorest Mexicans by 20 percent. A5
 
NATIONAL A14-28
 
Resurgent Labor Being Felt By Democrats in Congress
The stinging blow to President Clinton's trade policy delivered by House Democrats comes at a time when labor's hand has been growing stronger within the Democratic Party. Labor's victory also reflects an important shift in the party's financial center of gravity. Union money is once again predominant, especially for House Democrats, whose financial support from the business community began drying up after Republicans won control of Congress in 1994. A1
 
The managers of many American businesses said the inability of Congress and the Clinton Administration to pass the trade measure granting the President broad authority to negotiate trade deals could hurt companies and the economy. A28
 
Powell Rules Out Campaign
Retired Gen. Colin L. Powell said he had no intention of seeking the Republican nomination for President or any other political office in 2000. General Powell said he lacked "the passion" for political life. A18
 
Doctors Endorse Evidence
A group of outraged pediatricians specializing in child abuse signed a letter released by the Massachusetts Society for the Prevention of the Cruelty to Children, supporting the medical evidence in the prosecution's case against Louise Woodward. Ms. Woodward was convicted of second degree murder in the death of a child in her care, but sentenced to time served by a judge. A14
 
Election Fraud in Miami?
Florida State officials have confiscated 5,200 absentee ballots as part of their investigation of possible fraud and vote buying in last week's mayoral election in Miami. The investigation began with a tip last month that someone in the campaign of former mayor Xavier Suarez was buying absentee ballots. A20
 
Fighting a 'Bad' Protein
Studies show that new treatments for two completely different diseases -- rheumatoid arthritis and congestive heart failure -- may involve blocking a useful protein that sometimes turns disastrously bad. A22
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6
 
Burden for Homeless Care Shifts to Private Groups
The Giuliani administration is taking the city out of the business of running shelters for single adults and giving the job to private nonprofit organizations that many experts contend are more equipped to handle the homeless. But advocates for the homeless argue that improved services are allowing the city to let people stay in the shelters for a longer time, and as a result, there is less pressure to create permanent housing -- traditionally the main goal of the city's policy on the homeless. A thick file that teachers and administrators at the Children's Storefront School in Harlem kept on Sabrina Green provides a detailed account of how promising her life could have been -- before she was found dead in her older sister's apartment last week in the Bronx. The sister and her husband have been charged with manslaughter in the death of the 9-year-old girl. B1

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 176 words

HEADLINE: Don't Look to Israel for Help Against Iraq;
Pay the U.N. Bill

 BODY:

To the Editor:
President Clinton has called on the United Nations Security Council to respond with "unambiguous action" to President Saddam Hussein's defiance of United Nations authority to carry out weapons inspections in Iraq (front page, Nov. 10). It remains to be seen if Mr. Clinton will get the response he seeks. 
 American leadership and prestige in the world organization are at a new low because of the United States' failure to live up to its financial obligations there. If the United Nations is to serve as an instrument of American foreign policy, as Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has argued, American leadership is necessary. It makes little sense to make that task more difficult by creating a financial crisis. If the United States seeks to lead the world in neutralizing Mr. Hussein's threat to world stability, it cannot treat the United Nations with disdain.
 
BENJAMIN RIVLIN
New York, Nov. 11, 1997
 
The writer is director of the Ralph Bunche Institute on the United Nations, CUNY Graduate Center.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (97%); IRAQ (94%);

COMPANY: UNITED NATIONS UNITED NATIONS (94%); UNITED NATIONS (94%); UNITED NATIONS SECURITY COUNCIL (84%); UNITED NATIONS SECURITY COUNCIL (84%);

HEADLINE: European Jobless Need Their Safety Net

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"The Jobless Are Snared in Europe's Safety Net" (Week in Review, Nov. 9) does an excellent job of describing Europe's quandary on unemployment. It might be inferred that Europe would be better off adopting the hire-and-fire system of the United States. 
 However, before the Europeans do that, they should ask themselves who is better off: the young American flipping hamburgers at minimum wage with no health insurance and not enough money for decent housing, medical care or transportation, or the young, unemployed European with guaranteed access to health care, decent housing and welfare benefits.
 
KEVIN TWINE
South Orange, N.J., Nov. 9, 1997

HEADLINE: European Jobless Need Their Safety Net

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Jobless Are Snared in Europe's Safety Net" (Week in Review, Nov. 9):
While laws (even constitutions!) and union contracts enshrining job guarantees are a cause of European unemployment, your suggestion that those who have full-time jobs benefit at the expense of those who do not is false. It is the fully employed who carry the burden of the safety net for those who are not working or are working only part time. 
 The progressive income tax system makes this possible. Thus, net pay for white-collar jobs in Europe is lower than it is in the United States. Rather than have inequality of incomes, Europe prefers the equality of social guarantees.
 
SANDOR JOO
Greenwich, Conn., Nov. 9, 1997

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances Against Yen On Economic Doubt in Japan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar surged against the yen as Japanese stocks tumbled on concern that Tokyo would not soon remedy the country's economic ills.
"What's brought the dollar here is fundamental concern about the Japanese economic situation and the realization that the only thing left to do is let the currency weaken," said Seth Garrett, global head of spot currency trading at Credit Suisse First Boston. "The yen's move has been steady but unrelenting." 
 The Nikkei index of 225 leading Japanese stocks fell 2.73 percent in overnight trading, closing at its lowest level since July 1995.
The market slump hurts the yen because global investors selling Japanese equities often convert the yen proceeds to other currencies.
The yen's weakness makes Japanese exports more competitive, and exports could account for as much as half of the nation's economic growth this year, economists estimate.
Earlier this year, when Japan's stocks were climbing and the economy was showing signs of recovery, Japanese officials protested when the dollar rose to more than 120 yen.
Now, as the deepening crisis in Asia threatens to hurt demand for Japan's exports and Japanese banks stagger under the weight of bad loans, the Government may have little choice but to let the yen weaken, analysts said.
The dollar rose as high as 126.52 yen before settling in late New York trading at 126.32 yen, up from 125.03 yen on Tuesday -- the first time since May 5 that the dollar has crossed the 126-yen level.
The dollar pared early gains against the German mark after the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged yesterday afternoon.
While the move had been expected, it fanned speculation that Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, may raise rates before the United States does.
"The Bundesbank has tightened and it may tighten again," said Steve Gallagher, an economist at Societe Generale.
Higher interest rates tend to help a currency by making deposits and bonds denominated in it more attractive.
In New York trading, the dollar settled at 1.7183 marks, up from 1.7077 marks. The British pound fell to $1.7033 from $1.7044.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
A Run on Coffee Stockpiles Sends Prices to 4-Week High

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Coffee rose to a four-week high yesterday as strong demand and delays in shipping newly harvested beans from Latin America sent United States exchange stockpiles to an 11-month low.
Stockpiles of coffee in warehouses monitored daily by the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange plunged 36 percent Monday to the lowest level since December 1996. The supply drain comes after heavy rain at Mexican coffee plantations because of Hurricane Rick. That delayed shipments from Mexico, the largest exporter of beans to the United States, just as roasters stocked up on raw coffee to process before peak winter demand. 
 "Look at the level of coffee stockpiles in warehouses: they are very low, and the crops are arriving here late," said Stephen Smith, president of South Futures Ltd., a coffee trading company in Miami.
Demand from American roasters has drained exchange stockpiles. They fell by 7,999 132-pound bags, to 14,302 bags, on Monday from Friday, the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange said. Coffee for December delivery rose 3.4 cents, or 2.2 percent, to $1.5965 a pound on the exchange, the highest closing price for a most-active contract since Oct. 15.
In other markets, gold sank to a 12 1/2-year low and wheat slid.
Gold fell as the Federal Reserve left short-term interest rates unchanged, amid few signs of inflation, while concern persisted that some central banks would sell more gold. Demand for gold generally rises in times of inflation.
Several central banks have recently announced plans to sell part of their gold reserves on the open market, increasing supply at a time of lackluster investment demand. December gold fell $2.20, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $308.40 an ounce on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest for an active contract since March 1985.
Wheat for December delivery slid 4.75 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $3.4475 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade, the lowest for a contract closest to delivery since July 22. American exporters in the marketing year through Oct. 30 shipped 13.4 million metric tons of wheat, down 9.5 percent from a year earlier, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
With turmoil abroad, some wanted the Fed to ease credit.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
WHEN the expected happens, markets are not supposed to react. And certainly not with the violence seen yesterday afternoon after the disclosure by the Federal Reserve that it would not change short-term interest rates.
That lack of action had been forecast by virtually every Fed watcher. And yet, within minutes of the announcement, bond prices leaped and stock prices sagged. 
 That divergence is interesting. And so is the fact that some traders seem to have been hoping -- or fearing -- that the Fed would do something. It appears that some traders now think there is a risk of the American economy slowing in response to events around the world. And so, whatever the seers said, the Fed's failure to ease credit by cutting interest rates appears to have bothered some traders.
In recent years, the stock market and the bond market climbed together. And when they suffered temporary reverses, it was usually on strong economic news that scared the bond market. But that linkage has broken down in recent months, and yesterday's moves provided further evidence of the decoupling.
To the bond market, an easing would increase economic strength, and perhaps threaten a rekindling of inflation. After all, the United States labor market is very tight right now, with unemployment last month reported at 4.7 percent, a 24-year low. So the Fed's inaction looks good.
But stock traders have different concerns. The Fed's meeting came on another day of turmoil in world stock markets, and the failure to act could be seen as an indication the Fed was not willing to do anything to stem that turmoil and its possible economic consequences. "They are worried that stock markets are saying there is a fundamental slowdown around the world," said Byron Wien, the chief United States equity strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company. A Fed easing might help to restore confidence, some think.
The foreign turmoil has had a dramatic impact on Wall Street expectations regarding Fed policy. Only a few weeks ago, the general opinion was that if the Fed did act, it would be to raise rates. That made sense given the strength of the American economy, as was indicated by last week's strong employment report.
Now, said Bruce Steinberg, Merrill Lynch's chief economist, that strength "has no bearing on future policy moves." He thinks that the next move will be an easing, although he does not expect it until sometime in 1998, after it becomes clear the economy is slowing.
It is always risky to ascribe rationales to price moves in markets as volatile as the American stock market has become in recent months. Many seem to buy and sell stocks not because of any actual economic convictions, but simply in response to whatever the trend appears to be. And the sharp fall in American stock prices yesterday came on a day when many markets were weak. The plunge that began just after the Fed announcement came about half an hour after the Brazilian market halted trading for 30 minutes when circuit breakers went off with that market down 10 percent for the day.
In any case, the worry seems to be concentrated among money managers, not mutual fund investors who send cash to those managers. And there is no evidence of widespread public selling.
Still, yesterday the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds, at 6.16 percent just after the Fed acted, soon fell to 6.10 percent as bond buyers appeared. And the Dow Jones industrial average, at 7,520 just after the Fed move, ended the day at 7,401.32 as investors tried to reduce their stock holdings.
That has been the trend since midsummer. On Aug. 12, the 30-year Treasury yield stood at 6.67 percent, its recent high. And on Aug. 6, the Dow peaked at 8,259.31. Bond investors have done quite well since then. Stock investors have not.
Such moves are consistent with economic worries of deflation or recession. Either would be a boon to Treasury bonds, but would threaten the high levels of corporate profits. While there is a lot of talk about deflation coming from Asia as troubled economies and companies sell products at any price they can get, there could be an impact on American corporate profits even if the impact stopped well short of producing an overall decline in consumer prices.
It is remarkable to see traders worried about economic slowing at a time when measures of the domestic economy look generally good. This economy is less open to shocks from abroad than are most, simply because of its size and diversity. But, for now at least, it appears that the possibility of such shocks is worrying stock traders, and that some of them were disappointed that the Fed was unwilling to ease credit in the face of falling markets around the world.

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Asian tigers may falter, but the Japan lion is the worry.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
BANKS, securities brokers and insurance companies, once too eager to cash in on booming real estate and stock markets, are awash in bad debts. While the economy remains in many ways sound -- the savings rate is high, unemployment is low, the work ethic is strong -- creditworthy businesses cannot borrow and a recession is imminent. Yet political leaders, buffeted by contradictory advice and compromised by financial ties to special interests, lack the will to act decisively.
Yes, the description fits Thailand, Indonesia or Malaysia. But the country in question is Japan, the ailing lion among a pack of faltering tiger cubs. And the consequences of Japan's looming financial crisis are far more likely to have an enduring impact on world markets than the travails of smaller Asian economies. "Comparisons with 1930 are not out of line," warned John Makin, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute's Asian Studies Program. 
 While the world no longer views Japan as unstoppable, its current difficulties have generally been interpreted as no more than a rite of passage on the route to economic maturity.
But the Japanese financial industry is in deep trouble. Banks and insurers took a huge hit when the 1980's bubble in property burst and with the subsequent fall of stocks, which served as collateral for many loans. Hardly anyone outside the Government disputes that most banks, including some of the giants, are insolvent.
Much the same thing happened in Texas after oil prices fell in the early 1980's, and in New England in the late 1980's after real estate soured. In between, many savings and loan associations went under. Through it all, the American economy hardly faltered.
Why, then, have financial problems choked off growth in Japan for much of the decade? For one thing, the Japanese banks' net liabilities are probably a larger portion of the economy. "This thing has been building for years," reminded Steven Radelet, an economist at Harvard's Institute for International Development.
The United States is also concerned about the matter. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin recently sent a letter to the Japanese Finance Minister asking that Japan's financial system be stabilized as quickly as possible.
The Japanese Government has been in deep denial. In America, regulators closed or merged lending institutions fairly quickly once they recognized the magnitude of the problem. And when the deposit insurance system ran out of money, Washington howled and hunted for scapegoats -- and then quickly coughed up the cash.
In Japan, by contrast, the Government has not been willing to bail out large depositors or lenders. "It's very difficult to get direct subsidies for anyone but farmers," said Gary Saxonhouse, an economist at the University of Michigan.
But oddly, the Government has been forthcoming with the indirect subsidies that have allowed the problem to fester. Regulators require pension funds to hold half their assets in bank deposits or Government bonds. And households have few alternatives to keeping their savings in banks. Mr. Saxonhouse points out that roughly 60 percent of liquid household assets are in banks in Japan, compared with about 25 percent in America.
This permits the banks to pay token interest -- and thus to stay open. But every spare yen is stashed in short-term Government paper, making it almost impossible for any but blue-chip corporations to borrow. "The banks are zombies," Mr. Makin argues -- lenders in name only.
For better or worse, this impasse is likely to be broken next spring with Tokyo's version of the Big Bang -- sweeping deregulation of the financial sector that opens the door to domestic and foreign competition. The interest rate that banks will need to pay to keep deposits is bound to rise sharply, most likely forcing the Government to acknowledge that the banking sector is flat broke.
Mr. Saxonhouse predicts a happy ending. Once the banks' problem formally becomes the depositors' problem, he predicts, the Government will step in to protect against a run on the banks and a Depression-style implosion of the money supply. And once the system is restructured, Japan will end up with leaner, more competitive capital market -- one in which lenders are less apt to finance speculative bubbles and more likely to serve small and medium-sized businesses.
Mr. Makin isn't so sure. "This is end game," he agrees. But the Government's record of delay and denial, he allows, hardly suggests it is prepared to manage the restructuring. That would require large public outlays at a time when the Government budget is deeply in deficit. Arguably worse, it would probably require the merger of Japanese lenders with the likes of Citibank or Deutsche Bank -- and a sunset to the insular, uncompetitive financial culture that has long been a source of pride to Japan as well as its Achilles' heel.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
America's Hollow Embargo on Iran

BYLINE: By PHILIP TAUBMAN 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran

 BODY:
Anyone who thinks the United States is conducting an effective embargo of Iran ought to visit the Iranian capital. It is flooded with American computers, drilling equipment and parts for everything from trucks to tanks. Ask Iranians about the embargo and they smile. "We get whatever we want," one businessman told me.
The reality here could not be more detached from the debate in America about whether to penalize French, Russian and Malaysian companies that plan a large gas development project with Iran. The United States has so failed to enforce its own ban on trade with Iran that the notion of trying to stop foreign companies from doing business here seems laughable. Iran offers a preview of what may happen with the sanctions against Iraq if Washington cannot come up with a way to make them more acceptable to other nations. 
 The Iran embargo, as far as I could see during five days in Iran, exists mostly in the minds of Congress and the Clinton Administration. It certainly does not exist in one typically affluent home I visited, where the kitchen features new General Electric appliances, including a washer, dryer and a Profile refrigerator with a through-the-door ice dispenser.
Here is how easily the ban can be evaded. A trader in Teheran telephones an appliance company in the United States and says he is calling from Dubai, a small Persian Gulf state. He places an order for 1,000 washing machines, has them shipped to Dubai and then arranges for payment from a Canadian bank where the Iranian has opened an account. Since the goods are shipped to Dubai, American customs agents raise no objection. Once the washing machines reach Dubai they are transshipped to Iran.
I heard variations on this theme from Iranian traders. Some use middlemen in the Middle East, Europe and Canada. Some move their cargoes through Germany, others prefer Canada and still others use Singapore, Australia, Turkey and even Afghanistan, which is so chaotic almost anything can be smuggled across its border with Iran. But Dubai dominates the illicit trade, and its warehouses are said to be jammed with American goods. Banks in Germany, Austria and Switzerland seem to be the financial institutions of choice for laundering payments to American companies.
Some American businesses seem unaware of the ultimate destination of their products, but they must be the exception. In most cases it should be clear by now that many goods going to Dubai are headed for Iran. In the case of spare parts for airplanes, trucks, drilling equipment and telecommunications networks, the part numbers should be a giveaway because they can be linked to equipment sold to Iran either before the latest embargo or before the Iranian revolution in 1979.
Though the Customs Service is hampered by the innocuous destinations listed on shipping manifests, Iranian traders contended that bribes had been paid to get particularly sensitive items by, including computer equipment and spare parts that can be used to maintain military equipment and missiles. They declined to be more specific.
The only inconvenience of the embargo is higher prices, produced by additional shipping charges and profits extracted by traders who charge a premium for evading American law. As a result, lower-priced French, German and Japanese goods have become more popular in a market that was once dominated by American products.
Embargoes have no chance of success if they are not enforced. President Clinton looked decisive in banning all trade with Iran in May 1995, and Congress added a boycott last year that calls for sanctions against foreign companies that engage in sizable transactions with Iran and Libya. If Washington intends to exercise that additional power, it should first get serious about the embargo on American companies.

LENGTH: 861 words

HEADLINE: Emerging Markets' Slump Taking Toll on U.S. Banks

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Rumors of the demise of the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Helu were greatly exaggerated yesterday, but it is a measure of the skittishness afflicting emerging markets that false reports of his death had the power to briefly disconcert traders paid to keep a close eye on the Mexican economy.
But what is very real amid this nervousness is increasing unease about the continued exposure of large United States banks to economic woes in Latin America and Asia. 
 "The broader issue emerging-markets problems raise is about the sustainability of earnings for banks and whether expectations for earnings power are too generous," said Judah Kraushaar, a bank analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company. "You feel a sense of being frozen. It's hard to know what the downside risks are because of uneven and relatively poor disclosure by banks about where their market risk resides. And there are businesses such as currency trading that could still do quite well."
Such uncertainty has dealt body blows to bank stocks over the last few weeks, and the pummeling continued yesterday. The Chase Manhattan Corporation's shares plunged $5.625, or 5 percent, to $106.75; Citicorp's shares dropped $7.0625, or 5.7 percent, to $116.375; the BankAmerica Corporation's stock sank $1, or 1.4 percent, to $69.875, and J. P. Morgan & Company's shares fell $4.6875, or 4 percent, to $109.375, all in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Those banks are, respectively, No. 1, No. 2, No. 4 and No. 5 in the country and each has substantial emerging markets operations. All of the banks declined to comment on any financial headaches they may or may not be experiencing abroad, though Chase is known to have suffered heavy paper losses trading in Latin American and Russian derivatives and debt.
Trading in Chase and Citicorp shares was briefly halted when the stock market opened yesterday because of imbalances in buy and sell orders. Trading volume for both stocks was extremely heavy. Shares of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation and the BankBoston Corporation, also major players in Latin America, fell 3.5 percent and 3.4 percent, respectively, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Brazilian stock market plunged more than 10 percent yesterday, in tandem with the Mexican stock market, which fell 4.25 percent. Nerves were briefly frayed by the false report of Mr. Slim's death, reflecting the influence he wields in the Mexican business world. He is the controlling shareholder and chairman of Telefonos de Mexico and is chairman of Mexico's largest conglomerate, Grupo Carso S.A.
The Latin American selloffs were preceded by market drops in Asia, where the Japanese stock market fell 2.7 percent and Hong Kong's stock market lost 4 percent.
Investors' uneasiness about big banks was heightened yesterday after George Salem, a bank analyst with Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company, cut his investment ratings on Chase, BankAmerica, and J. P. Morgan to "hold" from "buy," citing the economic crisis in Asia. He retained a "hold" rating on Citicorp.
"The crash in Hong Kong established a new, more ominous phase of this problem," Mr. Salem said in a telephone interview yesterday. "I think this is going to be a two-to- four-year problem rather than a two-to-three-month problem."
Mr. Salem, who memorably went bearish on bank stocks a couple years ago just before a thundering bull run began in those stocks, said his downgrades were spurred by "how all of these emerging markets have congealed into one risk."
But Mr. Salem deferred to a higher authority when asked to elaborate on what might be some important differences among the economic problems facing Malaysia, Thailand, Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea, Brazil and Mexico.
"I think it's better to ask an expert," Mr. Salem said. "It's not my area of expertise."
To be sure, global market downturns have resonated across borders and there is much to be concerned about if Asian or Latin American economies weaken further -- particularly as the United States economy and companies that are doing business abroad are affected. But some analysts remain sanguine, pointing out that the volatility could offer profitable opportunities for some banks.
"Frankly, what goes on in Asia in the short term is beneficial in terms of trading results and turns away a lot of the new entrants into emerging markets who thought there was limited risk," said Diane Glossman, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. "There is absolutely nothing new in Asia."
Mr. Salem also tempered his remarks by contrasting the current uncertainties with the big losses that plagued banks just a decade ago. "This is not a solvency call," he said. "This is not the 1980's. This time the banks aren't huge lenders -- with the exception of Citicorp. What you have is a threat to earnings power in that part of the world."
For his part, Mr. Kraushaar said he now favored regional bank stocks such as the Bank of New York Company, the Norwest Corporation, and the Republic New York Corporation because they are "conservatively managed" and "have less than average exposure" to credit problems arising in the United States.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Move Up As Stocks Take a Tumble

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
For the most part, Treasury securities again danced the dance with stocks yesterday, gaining as stock prices retreated in response to further erosion in the Asian markets.
Although traders were watching Federal Reserve policy makers closely yesterday, the decision to keep short-term interest rates unchanged for the fifth time this year was what most bond market participants were expecting. Short-term rates have not changed since March 25, when the Federal Open Market Committee increased the Federal funds target rate, which is the rate that banks charge one another for overnight loans, to 5.50 percent from 5.25 percent. 
 Kim Rupert, economist at Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, said, "The Fed makes policy decisions on a risk-to-reward trade off, and currently the risks favor a steady stance."
The strength in the October employment report on Friday, which showed joblessness at 4.7 percent, a 24-year low, would have been sufficient for the Fed to push rates up, Ms. Rupert said, but global instability argued against it. Also, she continued, given the lack of domestic prices pressures and the belief that recent turmoil could slow growth slightly, the Fed can afford to wait.
Nevertheless, there is concern among some participants that yesterday's inaction increases the chance that the Fed is slowly losing its opportunity to slow economic growth before it accelerates further and causes inflation to gain a foothold.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 20/32 yesterday, to 100 13/32 in a relief rally, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 6.10 percent, from 6.14 percent on Monday. On Tuesday the bond market was closed for the observance of Veterans Day.
"U.S. bonds are fairly valued at current levels and should continue to perform well as long as the Southeast Asia crisis is on the front pages of newspapers and continues to spill over into Latin America," said David Thompson, director of funds management and senior fund manager at BankBoston. "However, if the U.S. economy does not start to decelerate as it progresses into the fourth quarter and early months of the new year, we could face a different situation and market outlook."
Mr. Thompson who oversees investment management for $9.5 billion in mutual funds and collective funds at BankBoston, says the minimal risk to American bond investors is that foreign investors could decide to sell Treasury securities. Projected forward, the Treasury currently estimates its market borrowing needs will be only $20 billion in the first quarter, close to half a year ago, and will be satisified with bills and their regular biweekly two- and five-year note auctions.
"There will be an increasing scarcity of longer-dated paper for at least the next four months," he said. "Consequently, longer-duration bond strategies are favored."
Stephanie Davis, fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said, "The Fed's decision to leave interest rates unchanged has provided the market with some relief for the moment." However, she added, "The other shoe will drop in the form of Producer Price Index and retail sales on Friday and the Consumer Price Index next Tuesday." In the interim, she says, look for interest rates to remain stable.

HEADLINE: Hearing on Hidden Fees for 401(k) Plans

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Hidden fees are being charged to some of the 401(k) plans that 25 million workers use to save for retirement, but full disclosure of fees would lead to lower costs, leaders of the industry said at a Labor Department hearing today.
Many business owners are unaware of all the fees charged by companies that invest 401(k) money and maintain records, said Ted Benna, the retirement consultant who identified the law's potential as a savings vehicle for the masses. 
 "Participants think they are getting a fund at a normal management fee. and then they find out they are paying" as much as 1.5 percentage points more than expected, he said.
Extra fees "mean that the magic of compound interest is working against us," said Stephen J. Butler, the president of Pension Dynamics, a Lafayette, Calif., consulting company. He said that the excessive fee problem was greatest at small companies.
Even many large employers do not understand how to compare the fees charged by competing mutual funds, insurers, banks and other service providers, said Kenny Lee Adams, president of (k)la, a San Francisco company that sells a system for comparing 401(k) fees.
Uniform pricing standards that would let workers compare 401(k) plan investment returns as easily as consumers can compare mutual fund returns "would be simple" to develop, said Matthew P. Fink, president of the Investment Company Institute.
But Lynn D. Dudley, vice president of the Association of Private Pension and Welfare Plans, said that requiring disclosure of specific fees would inhibit development of new 401(k) features and that disclosure of total fees was sufficient.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 318 words

HEADLINE: Fast-Track Falsities

 BODY:
The refusal of House Democrats to give the leader of their party "fast track" authority to negotiate trade pacts is disturbing testimony to the power of organized labor's campaign money -- and of flagrantly false rhetoric.
Opponents declared that their action would prevent President Clinton from entering into another pact as harmful as the North American Free Trade Agreement, signed with Mexico and Canada in 1993. After all, Mexico soon sank into recession and created a trade deficit for the United States. But Nora Lustig of the Brookings Institution shows that Nafta's impact on America has been trivial. 
 The Mexican economic crisis, not Nafta, created the trade deficit. The revealing fact is that Mexico's recession drove exports from Europe and Japan down by about 25 percent while exports from the United States under Nafta fell only about 2 percent. Contrary to Ross Perot's jeremiad, the number of displaced American workers has been small, and most of them quickly found new jobs.
Fast-track opponents raised the fear-mongering claim that trade with developing countries creates a race to the bottom for the wages of American workers. But American wages closely mirror American productivity. Trade cannot threaten productivity in American companies, so it does not threaten wages of most American workers. Indeed, history shows that trade boosts productivity, raising wages in America and, even faster, in previously low-wage countries like South Korea and Taiwan. The race, then, is to the top.
There is a legitimate concern that imports, though driving consumer prices lower for everyone, can whittle down the wages of America's least-skilled workers. But the actual impact has been small and there are far better ways to help the few displaced workers who are forced into lower-paying jobs than to stomp on trade and thereby make the entire country substantially poorer.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: The Fed Holds Rates Steady As It Weighs Global Risks

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Torn between fear of incipient inflation at home and concern about unsettling financial markets around the world, the Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged and ride out the storm for a while longer.
The decision had been widely expected by economists and investors, who saw little chance that the central bank would risk upsetting the global markets by raising rates, even though there is mounting evidence that inflationary pressures are building in the American economy. 
 But it highlighted the delicate situation faced by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, as he sought to keep the long economic expansion enjoyed by the United States on track while also taking account of his vast influence over markets and economies in the rest of the world.
As if to illustrate just how volatile an environment Mr. Greenspan faces, markets tumbled once again today. Sharp declines in Asian and Latin American markets caused jitters on Wall Street, where investors appeared increasingly convinced that slowdowns in foreign economies would hurt profits of multinational companies and slow growth in the United States.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 157.41 points to close at 7,401.32. It was the steepest drop in the index since the 554-point decline on Oct. 27.
Although the financial turmoil has the potential to do the same thing as a rate increase by the Fed -- slow the economy sufficiently to keep it from overheating -- Fed officials have made clear over the last several weeks that they still view an outbreak of inflation as a real possibility.
Mr. Greenspan said last month that continuing declines in the unemployment rate -- currently at 4.7 percent, a 24-year low -- at a time of strong domestic growth could set off a process in which higher wages would lead to price inflation.
Many analysts believe that if the financial markets were calm the Fed would have seriously considered raising interest rates today, and could still do so in the next three months.
Still, Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues have also been keenly aware that the combination of falling stock prices, tumbling currency values and weak banking systems in other countries, particularly in Asia, holds risks for the global economy and for the United States in particular. Raising rates now could make the situation worse by pushing down stock and bond prices and further weakening foreign currencies relative to the dollar. Mr. Greenspan is to answer questions about the international markets from the House Banking Committee Thursday morning.
Even as the Fed's policy-making committee was meeting today, the stock market in Brazil, the latest nation to be buffeted by the round-the-world financial turmoil, was falling more than 10 percent.
"Against that kind of backdrop, the Fed doesn't have a lot of choice, and in that sense their decision today was not difficult," said Ian Shepherdson, the chief economist at HSBC Markets in New York. "In the longer term it gets much more difficult because they will have to take account of the domestic situation."
Despite some early warning signs of inflation, including a 4.2 percent increase in hourly earnings over the last year, the Fed has left rates unchanged in recent months because actual gauges of prices have remained stable or in some cases have fallen.
Some economists have even been making a case in the last few months that the real danger to the economy is from deflation -- an across-the-board fall in prices -- rather than from inflation. Their argument is built on the premise that the slowdown in the Asian economies, combined with global overcapacity in many industries, could lead to falling prices around the world.
Other economists believe that fears of deflation are vastly overblown, especially since falling prices are likely to be limited to manufactured goods, while prices for services are likely to continue rising. In any case, the deflation argument has so far received only a cursory hearing with the Federal Reserve, where the focus has been squarely on strong economic growth and the pressures that could ignite inflation in the United States.
"All the dangers seem to be on the inflationary side, not the deflationary side," Alice M. Rivlin, the Fed's vice chairwoman, said last week.
The Federal Open Market Committee of the Fed will next meet on Dec. 16, and economists said the chances of a rate increase then, so close to Christmas, were almost nil.
But economists are already vigorously debating what situation the Fed will face at its subsequent meeting, in February. One camp believes the global financial upheaval will slow the American economy enough so that no rate increase will be needed and perhaps a rate cut could be justified later in the year.
"There is as logical a case for a rate cut next year as for a rate tightening," said James Glassman, an economist at Chase Securities in New York.
The other camp holds that for the last year or two the economy has always seemed to be just months away from slowing to a more sustainable pace, but then continued to grow at a robust pace and to create new inflationary pressures. With unemployment low and possibly heading lower, consumer spending strong and business investment running at high levels, even a downturn in Asia and Latin America might not be enough to eradicate inflationary pressures in the United States.
"The Fed has erred on the side of caution up to this point," said Gail D. Fosler, the chief economist at the Conference Board, a business group in New York. "As we get into 1998, they may have to take a risk and raise rates to signal that they will take a stand against the inflationary pressures that are present."
Economists will be looking particularly hard over the next few months for indications of whether productivity -- the output of a worker in one hour -- is rising fast enough to offset the increases in wages. Corporate profits have remained strong enough this year to suggest that productivity continues to outpace wage gains, economists said. But with companies increasingly being forced to pay more to attract the numbers and quality of workers they want, it is unclear how long that situation will continue, they said.

HEADLINE: Building a Classier Image;
Las Vegas Hotels Woo Blue Chip Visitors

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
The newest way to make an impression on the garish Las Vegas Strip is through Impressionism itself. The Bellagio, a luxury hotel being built in a city known for its girlie shows, clanging slot machines and the Liberace Museum, will have its hallways graced by about $130 million worth of paintings by the likes of Renoir, Monet and Picasso.
Down the road, Circus Circus Enterprises, known for a flagship hotel that features $29 rooms, $3 all-you-can-eat buffets and trapeze acts high above the blackjack tables, is building a resort that will include a hotel managed by the tony Four Seasons Hotels Inc. 
 Las Vegas is adding a little elegance to its ebullience, a little class to its crass. The latest mantra here is go upscale: attract upper-middle-income vacationers -- not necessarily avid gamblers -- who might normally head for Palm Springs or La Jolla, Calif.; Scottsdale, Ariz., or Santa Fe, N.M.
Behind the move is a change in the economics of Las Vegas. In the past, rooms, food and entertainment were mainly loss leaders, sold cheaply to lure customers into the casino.
But as Las Vegas has broadened its appeal, the average visitor is dropping less at the roulette table. At the low-priced Circus Circus hotel, for instance, "A lot of people are sleeping there but not playing the casinos," said Glenn Schaeffer, the president of the parent company.
So he and other casino owners are trying something radical: to turn a profit on rooms, food, entertainment and shops. In 1996, these nongambling revenues accounted for 47 percent of the Strip's total, up from 42 percent in 1990, the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority says.
Still, the average hotel rate for all of Las Vegas has only crept up to $58, so hotel keepers think there is room to charge even more by making accommodations more luxurious. Higher room rates are also needed to recover the costs of the extravagant theme hotels now under construction, like the $1.5 billion Bellagio, which hopes to charge an average of about $165 a night, a new high for Las Vegas.
Risks abound in this strategy, though. Visitors may balk at high room rates if cheap ones are still plentiful, and giant hotels run the danger of becoming impersonal. Most important, though: Can Las Vegas absorb all these new rooms?
Las Vegas, of course, has been redefining itself for a decade.
In recent years it has shed some of its Sin City reputation and turned itself into a playland for middle-American families by building hotels with theme-park-like attractions -- erupting volcanoes, battling pirates and Greenwich Village street scenes. This attracted mainly low-budget vacationers lured by the inexpensive hotels and meals.
But the latest moves, if they succeed, will broaden the market further and help transform this desert hub into a more traditional resort, with golf, tennis, spas, ritzy shopping centers and gourmet restaurants.
The Bellagio is far from alone. The Desert Inn is just completing a $200 million renovation aimed at making it the first five-star hotel in Las Vegas. While most hotel-casinos require guests to run a gantlet of slot machines to find the registration desk, the Desert Inn, owned by the ITT Corporation, features a lobby five stories high, and not a bing or a bong within earshot.
The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company is entering the Las Vegas market, agreeing to manage a 526-room hotel in the new 640-acre Mountain Spa Resort being built on the outskirts of the city by Jack Sommer, owner of the Aladdin Hotel.
Ritz-Carlton and Marriott International, which owns 49 percent of Ritz, have also signed letters of intent to manage hotels to be built on the property of the MGM Grand. ITT's Caesars Palace, long considered one of the most upscale hotels, has just added a new, even more luxurious 1,200-room tower.
The new establishments are not necessarily aimed at the high rollers who bet up to $200,000 on a single hand of baccarat. Las Vegas already treats them very well indeed.
The Las Vegas Hilton offers high rollers free penthouse suites, each more than 12,000 square feet, with private pools and lawns, furnishings befitting Versailles, and tuxedo-clad butlers on duty 24 hours a day.
Nor are the moves aimed at families with children. While the building of theme hotels has made Las Vegas more of a family place, gaming executives -- perhaps spooked by the murder of a 7-year-old girl in May in a casino in Primm, Nev. -- now say that was never the intention.
"Every time I saw kids in Las Vegas they were crying," said Stephen F. Bollenbach, president and chief executive of the Hilton Hotels Corporation. Even Mr. Schaeffer of Circus Circus says: "We're not McDonald's that advertises to kids. We're Wendy's, where parents want to go and the kids can find something to eat." No, the goal is more upscale visitors, yuppies and DINK's (dual income, no kids).
The proportion of visitors bringing children, while doubling since 1990, is still only 11 percent, and that is why strategies are being re-evaluated. MGM Grand Inc. is cutting the size of its unprofitable theme park in half. It will use the space for the new Ritz and Marriott Marquis hotels, a conference center and a spa with six swimming pools, waterfalls, a river and private cabanas.
And food, often neglected in a place famous for groaning breakfast buffets and unlimited prime rib, is also getting ritzier. One pacesetter has been Rio Hotel and Casino Inc., which has used fine food and an all-suite environment to become one of the faster-growing properties in the city. Still, insisted the chairman, Anthony A. Marnell 2d: "Las Vegas is not trying to change its image. It's just addressing an apparent desire" of more demanding consumers.
Rio has hired well-known chefs like Jean-Louis Palladin, formerly of the Watergate Hotel. It spent about $400,000 to buy part of Andrew Lloyd Webber's wine collection when it was auctioned and added it to a large wine cellar run by a master sommelier from the Ritz hotel in London. Now, Rio is even thinking of opening a restaurant in New York.
Other trendy restaurants that have opened in Las Vegas in the last few years are Wolfgang Puck's Spago, San Francisco's Fog City Diner and Mark Miller's Coyote Cafe. Bellagio will house the first branch of Le Cirque outside New York.
As for high-end shopping, the Forum Shops, situated at Caesars Palace and developed by Simon DeBartolo Group, has been a big success since it opened in 1992 and has just doubled its size, adding retailers like Bernini, Emporio Armani and an F.A.O. Schwarz store with a three-story-high Trojan horse in front. Of course, this being Las Vegas, every locale must have a themed attraction, so statues come to life in the fountains, re-creating the destruction of Atlantis.
Some business executives here worry about becoming too snobby. "The danger is that Las Vegas loses the reputation as a bargain," said Ellis Landau, chief financial officer of the Boyd Gaming Corporation, which owns the Stardust hotel. "We still need that."
That, of course, assumes the upscale move succeeds, which is far from assured. "It's awfully tough to change your product image and move upscale," Craig Sullivan, the chief financial officer at Primadonna Resorts, said at the recent World Gaming Congress and Expo here. In an attempt to change its image, for instance, Circus Circus, whose stock price has been battered this year from more than $37 to around $23, is thinking of changing its name.
Even though business executives and higher-income vacationers might spend $200 or $300 a night on a hotel in New York or Los Angeles, that does not mean they will pay that much in Las Vegas, where perfectly decent rooms are available for less than $100.
Some of the new high-end hotels will have thousands of rooms, making it hard to deliver personalized service. "What happens is people are treated like cattle and the quality of the experience goes down," said John Koster, president of the Desert Inn, which has 715 rooms.
Air service is another bottleneck. While overtaxed McCarran International Airport is adding new gates, it is served mainly by Southwest Airlines and America West Airlines, discount carriers without much first-class or business-class service. Direct flights from East Coast cities are rare.
The biggest risk is whether Las Vegas can absorb all the high-class rooms and shopping malls. Las Vegas is in the midst of a building boom that over the next few years could add 20,000 to 60,000 rooms to the 104,000 already here.
Named for a resort area in northern Italy, the 3,000-room Bellagio, being built by Mirage Resorts and scheduled to open in the fall of 1998, will have a nine-acre man-made lake with what is promised to be a spectacular fountain show.
Hilton's 3,000-room Paris, to open in 1999, will cost about $760 million and feature a 50-story replica of the Eiffel Tower. In addition to its 400-room Four Seasons hotel, Circus Circus's $800 million Project Paradise will have its own 3,400-room aquatic-theme hotel-casino in which guests will be able to swim in a pool with sharks -- separated by an acrylic wall.
The grandest of all, if it gets enough financing, might be the nearly $2 billion Venetian being built by Sheldon G. Adelson, who made his fortune selling the Comdex computer trade show to a Japanese entrepreneur. It will have 6,000 suites and will be a re-creation of Venice, complete with canals and gondoliers who croon in Italian.
So far, the city has worked on the premise that supply breeds demand -- build it, and they will come. And sure enough, as the castle-shaped Excalibur, the pyramid-shaped Luxor and other theme hotels have sprouted one after another, the number of visitors has continued to rise.
But this year, Las Vegas is feeling the effects of overbuilding. In the first eight months of the year, the supply of rooms rose 10 percent, but there were only 4 percent more visitors. So much for raising room rates. Rooms for two in midweek are being advertised for $35 at the Frontier and $55 even at the relatively high-end Rio.
The Stratosphere, a new casino at the seedier north end of the Strip, built as a huge tower with a roller coaster on top, is operating under bankruptcy protection. Some other less spectacular properties are also ailing, and a shakeout is expected.
"We are beyond building spaces, we are building conversation pieces," said Alex Yemenidjian, president and chief operating officer of MGM Grand, which is controlled by the financier Kirk Kerkorian. "There will be eventually a half a dozen properties in Las Vegas that will command 90 percent of the public attention, and then every other property will be a dormitory."
