HEADLINE: Delay in Presenting Data Brings Attention to Program on Infants

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Public health researchers said today that the Clinton Administration had canceled a presentation of preliminary data suggesting that an ambitious Federal program to reduce infant mortality had fallen far short of its goals.
The preliminary data were collected for an evaluation of the Healthy Start program, which was begun in the Bush Administration. The Federal Government gives a total of $100 million a year to 60 cities and counties with high infant mortality rates. The money is spent on health care and social services, in an effort to reduce the rates by 50 percent. 
 Administration officials confirmed that they had told the researchers not to disclose their findings at this time but said the data were incomplete, so that no reliable conclusions could be drawn.
The data were to have been presented today at the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association in Indianapolis. The Healthy Start program is being evaluated by public health experts at Mathematica Policy Research, a social research center in Princeton, N.J., under a $4.8 million contract with the Federal Government.
Joanne Pfleiderer, a Mathematica spokeswoman, said: "The Government chose to cancel the presentation. We regret that it was canceled."
The authors of the study, listed in the program for the meeting, are Lorenzo Moreno, a demographer at Mathematica, and Barbara L. Devaney, an economist.
Dr. Claude Earl Fox, a pediatrician and acting administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration, a unit of the Public Health Service, said: "We asked Mathematica not to release the data because the data are not complete. It's not an issue of trying to hide the data."
By ordering the researchers to withhold their data, the Government generated far more interest in the program than it would otherwise have received in Indianapolis.
Dr. Fox defended his agency's action, reported today in The Philadelphia Inquirer. "It's too early in the project to expect it to have an impact on the infant mortality rate," he said.
The data, for 1994, come from 9 of the 16 sites included in the evaluation. Melissa T. Skolfield, a spokeswoman for the Department of Health and Human Services, said, "The Healthy Start program was just getting up and running in 1994, so the data are not very useful."
Dr. Fox said it would be "tragic" if Congress cut spending on the program because of the preliminary data. Other researchers said that while Healthy Start could do some good, the goal of a 50 percent reduction in infant mortality was an unrealistic goal chosen for political reasons.
In an interview, Dr. Fox said: "Reducing infant mortality rates by 50 percent is still a goal, but we are also looking at broader indicators of infant and maternal health. Do more women receive prenatal care? Are fewer babies born at low birth weight? Do children have a regular source of pediatric care?"
The infant mortality rate for the United States has been declining in recent years, but it is still higher than the rates for Japan and many European countries.
The gap between blacks and whites in the United States is as worrisome to public health experts as the overall rate. The infant mortality rate for blacks in the United States is more than twice the rate for whites. Federal health officials said they would disclose the data for 1994 when they had information on all 15 sites.

HEADLINE: Helen Church, 95, Nutritionist

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Helen Nichols Church, a pioneering nutritionist who began her career telling Howard Johnson what to serve at his very first restaurant and ended it as the last word on the nutritional content of more than 8,000 popular foods, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Lakewood, N.J. She was 95 and had been the editor of Bowes and Church's Food Values of Portions Commonly Used.
It was Anna dePlanter Bowes, a Pennsylvania nutritionist, who first recognized that official nutrition tables listing the amounts of various vitamins and other nutrients in arbitrary laboratory portions of basic foods had little relevance to real world kitchen and dinner table conditions. 
 Few housewives, she knew, would actually serve, say, exactly 100 grams of lean meat. Some were known to mix several meats and maybe even some onions to prepare meat loaf, and others went so far as to serve their families elaborate casseroles.
With the assistance of Mrs. Church's husband, Dr. Charles F. Church, a Harvard-trained public health specialist, Miss Bowes in 1936 began publishing nutrition tables based on commonly used portions of a variety of prepared foods.
Mrs. Church was deeply involved with the project from the beginning, eventually becoming co-editor and succeeding her husband as editor after his death in 1976. She later recruited Jean A. T. Pennington, who has continued the project, which is now going into in its 17th edition and covers some 8,500 food items from basic fruits and vegetables to Big Macs and other popular prepared foods. A native of LeRoy, Ill., Mrs. Church, who grew up doing chores on a family farm (and never tired of telling her pampered sons how easy they had it), met her husband at the University of Illinois, where she received a degree in home economics.
She worked for a while as a clinical dietitian at New York Hospital, but after her marriage in 1928, she moved to Boston, where her husband was in medical school, and became the dietitian in charge of Mr. Johnson's first restaurant, in Quincy, Mass.
After a stay in Philadelphia, the couple eventually settled in New Brunswick, N.J., where Dr. Church became chief medical officer at E. R. Squibb & Sons, and he and Mrs. Church worked together on successive revisions of Bowes and Church's, spending countless evenings on the screened side porch of their home on Nichol Avenue going over columns of figures.
Mrs. Church also put her nutritional training into practice with a vengeance. An excellent cook, she was not content to serve her family precisely balanced meals.
As her 67-year-old son, Charles Jr. recalled yesterday with a decades old wail, "I had to eat peanut butter instead of candy."
In addition to her son, of Normandy Beach, N.J., she is survived by another son, David, of Berkeley, Calif.; a sister, Marjorie Whitmore, of Pontiac, Ill.; a brother, Sheldon Nichols, of Spring Hill, Fla.; four grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seems to Rule Out Meeting Between Clinton and Netanyahu

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The White House appeared today to rule out a meeting between President Clinton and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel during Mr. Netanyahu's visit to the United States next week, although American spokesmen took pains to say that this did not represent a snub to the Israeli leader over the lack of progress in Middle East peace talks.
"We plan to meet with the Prime Minister at some appropriate point, but I'm not aware there's any meeting planned any time soon," said Michael McCurry, the White House spokesman. "I haven't heard any concern from the Government of Israel." 
 The President does have plans to meet this week with King Hussein of Jordan, who was released on Tuesday from the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., after medical tests. That left the White House and State Department in the awkward position today of explaining why the President would see the King but not the Prime Minister.
They portrayed it as simply a scheduling problem between the American and Israeli leaders. "It's not a question of whether there will be a meeting with the President and Prime Minister Netanyahu, it's a question of when," said James Rubin, the State Department spokesman. "And so that's a scheduling matter."
The Israeli Embassy in Washington did not respond to calls for comment.
Mr. Netanyahu is to arrive in the United States on Sunday for appearances before American Jewish groups and has visits scheduled to Los Angeles and Indianapolis. Both the President and Mr. Netanyahu are scheduled to be in Los Angeles on Monday, with Mr. Clinton expected to leave there on Monday morning.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is to meet with Mr. Netanyahu this Friday in London, where she will stop en route to an American-sponsored Middle East economic conference in the Persian Gulf state of Qatar that will include Israeli representatives. She will arrive in Doha, the Qatari capital, on Sunday and leave the same day.
Mr. Rubin suggested that the Secretary of State was a suitable proxy for the President in meeting with the Israel leader.
"Secretary Albright has been working on the Middle East peace process on behalf of the President," Mr. Rubin said. "And when Prime Minister Netanyahu meets with her, I can assure you, President Clinton very quickly finds out what he said."
The United States expressed disappointment today that Egypt and several other Arab nations invited to the economic meeting in Qatar had announced that they would not attend in protest over the stalled Arab-Israeli peace talks.
Today Bahrain, Morocco and the United Arab Emirates announced that they would not attend the conference, which was intended to promote economic cooperation between Israel and its Arab neighbors.
"Are we disappointed by the failure of Egypt and other countries to go? Yes, we are," Mr. Rubin said, describing the conference as "an important part of the peace process." He added: "It's important to keep it going even when the process itself is experiencing difficulty."
Even Israel has not said whether it will send a high-ranking delegation to the conference.
The Israeli Foreign Minister, David Levy, said today that Israel would be represented at the meeting, but that it was unclear whether he would himself go to Qatar.

HEADLINE: Economy Hotel Is Planned On West Side by Schrager

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
Ian Schrager, the Manhattan-based hotelier known for his ultracool but expensive brand of hospitality with hotels like the Royalton and Paramount, plans to convert the current home of WNET-TV, Channel 13, on West 58th Street into a hotel that he says will offer a more downscale version of cool.
Mr. Schrager and his partner in the hotel project, Northstar Capital, took control of the property last week after months of complicated negotiations involving WNET and the building's two other owners. The partnership paid $49 million for the 475,000-square-foot, 25-story property -- by far the largest of Mr. Schrager's three New York hotels. 
 Constructed in the 1920's as a women's residence with an emphasis on fitness, the building still has its original basketball court and swimming pool. Mr. Schrager said the 1,000-room hotel, at 356 West 58th Street, would retain that identity, becoming a "modern Y.M.C.A., an urban spa in the middle of the city."
And more like a Y.M.C.A., the rates will be for the budget-minded. Instead of the $155 to $330 a night for a double room at his other hotels in Manhattan, rooms in the new hotel will run about $75 a night.
"He wants to do the Old Navy equivalent of the Gap in the hotel business," said Arthur Adler, a partner in the lodging and gambling consulting group at the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand. "He wants to create cheap chic."
The renovation will be designed by Philippe Starck, the French designer who transformed the interiors of the Royalton and Paramount Hotels into strangely beautiful and minimalist spaces as familiar to design-conscious New Yorkers as to the well-heeled hipsters who stay there.
The building, the former Henry Hudson Hotel, has been the headquarters of WNET since 1973. It owns the first nine floors of the building and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center had owned the top half of the building. Most of those rooms had been rented out to college students in recent years by a nonprofit housing organization. There are also more than 100 permanent rent-stabilized residents in the building.
For its part, WNET will use its nearly $10 million profit from the sale to move its headquarters, and 400 employees, sometime next year to 450 West 33d Street, at 10th Avenue. The public television station signed a 21-year lease on Monday for 192,000 square feet of space on one and a half floors in the building, which also houses The Daily News.
WNET said it would switch its television operations over to digital technology, buying all new equipment. "The lively real estate market for hotel space has provided a fortuitous opportunity for 13 at the very moment that we are facing the staggering costs of converting to digital technology," said William F. Baker, WNET's president.
The new office space will allow WNET to create state-of-the-art post-production rooms, while the building's roof will support a satellite antenna. "In a city of skyscrapers, it's no easy matter to find a new home that satisfies our broadcast requirements," said Mr. Baker, who added that WNET still needed to raise $10 million for its new digital operation.
The hotel deal came about after St. Luke's, which owned the 11th through 24th floors, signed a contract for $24.4 million to sell its space -- technically a single condominium unit -- to an outside developer. St. Luke's purchased those floors in the 1980's with the intention of housing nurses and doctors, but in recent years had rented the space to Educational Housing Services.
But WNET, which wanted to move anyway, had the right of first refusal on the St. Luke's space. Philip R. Weiss, a managing director with the Insignia/Edward S. Gordon Company, a real estate brokerage, said yesterday that he had approached Mr. Schrager this spring about the building. Mr. Schrager agreed to put up the money so that WNET could buy out St. Luke's. The station, in turn, immediately "flipped" the newly acquired upper floors to Mr. Schrager. And last Wednesday, he signed a contract with WNET to purchase its own floors for $25 million.
Like St. Luke's, WNET had bought its floors from Irving Schatz, a real estate investor, after renting from him for years. Mr. Schatz, in fact, still owns part of the ground floor along West 57th Street where D'Agostino is a tenant, as well as the 10th floor and the penthouse floor.
According to Mr. Weiss, Mr. Schatz has agreed to rent the 10th floor to Mr. Schrager on a long-term basis but will hold onto the ground floor. Attempts to reach Mr. Schatz by telephone were unsuccessful.
Mr. Schrager said he would "renovate around" the rent-stabilized tenants. He will offer to buy out some tenants, he said, while the others will remain. "It's a fact of life that when you buy a building in New York City, you're going to have rent-stabilized tenants," he said.

HEADLINE: Unanimous Security Council Tightens the Vise on Iraq

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The Security Council, in a unanimous vote, made good today on its intention to impose new sanctions on Iraq, including banning foreign travel by Iraqi officials who do not cooperate with a United Nations disarmament commission. But Iraqi officials immediately said they would defy the demands, raising new questions about what will happen next.
The Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, said in a statement in New York that the resolution was "unjust" and would be ignored. 
 "Iraq rejects and condemns the Security Council resolution and stresses that the resolution will not scare it," Mr. Aziz said in the statement, released here by the Iraqi News Agency.
However, the United States representative at the United Nations, Bill Richardson, said, "the message has been clear."
He added: "The Security Council has been united. Iraq must comply or face consequences. We are not precluding any option including the military option."
The Clinton Administration and the British Government take the view that the use of force is already authorized by existing United Nations resolutions. And they say that view is underlined by a provision in today's resolution calling for unspecified "further action" against Baghdad if President Saddam Hussein does not rescind an order to expel American weapons inspectors.
Russia has another opinion, however. Speaking to reporters this afternoon, Sergey Lavrov, the Russian representative here, said that any proposed use of force would have to be approved by the Council. France and China agree. All three nations have a veto in the Council.
In addition, the Russians and Chinese both raised the possibility that the Council would have to look anew at Iraqi sanctions and the work of the disarmament commission. China's representative, Qin Huasun, said in his Council speech today that "three feet of ice could not be created in one day of cold weather," suggesting that the impasse between Iraq and the United Nations had deeper roots.
In its resolution, the Council also condemned Iraq for threatening to shoot down U-2 surveillance planes, blocking inspections and hiding equipment during the current crisis and called Iraqi actions "a threat to international peace and security." President Clinton has said that the United States would view any attempt to shoot down a U-2 as an act of war.
In Baghdad, arms inspection monitors were again barred from entering sites they wanted to investigate because there were Americans on the team.
Mr. Aziz, who has been in New York arguing Iraq's case, did not ask to address the Security Council today, after it became evident that all 15 Council members supported the resolution.
While the United States and Britain did not get as strong a resolution as some Western officials may have initially preferred, the fact remains that the Iraqis have done considerably worse. A diplomatic gain made three weeks ago, when the Council was seriously divided over the travel ban, has been reversed, and Baghdad has suffered a diplomatic setback.
On Oct. 23, China, France, Russia, Egypt and Kenya abstained from support of even a watered-down resolution postponing consideration of the ban until April. That ban now takes immediate effect.
Reflecting the views of several smaller nations on the Council, Costa Rica's representative, Fernando Berrocal Soto, said the decision he had to take went beyond "legalisms." The Council faced a fundamental political challenge with implications for the future, he said.
Iraq's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf, went on the offensive against the United States at a news conference in Baghdad a few hours before the vote.
He repeated Iraqi threats to expel American arms inspectors and shoot at American surveillance aircraft. He charged in a news conference that Washington had stepped up military preparations against Iraq, and -- switching from English to Arabic -- he pleaded with Arab nations not to provide operating bases for the United States.
Mr. Sahaf, whose news conference was seen here live on CNN International, said there had been 984 violations of Iraqi air space since Oct. 29, the day Iraq announced it would expel American inspectors. He said the United States was flying not only U-2 aircraft over Iraq but also TR-1 spy planes, which were used in the Persian Gulf war. The TR-1 is a subsonic, single-seat reconnaissance plane that can fly as high as 70,000 feet.
Mr. Sahaf accused Washington of browbeating the Council and creating a "hysterical atmosphere" at the United Nations.
Council members have told Iraq, he said, "of tremendous pressures exerted on them, of threats they had received, even blackmail."
Mr. Richardson described Mr. Sahaf's explanation as "rubbish."
The resolution adopted today cancels until April the regular 60-day reviews of sanctions imposed on Iraq after the 1990 invasion of Kuwait. Until the United Nations Special Commission, which is charged with disarming and monitoring Iraq, certifies that the nation is free of prohibited weapons, a comprehensive embargo remains in place. It leaves the Iraqis permitted to sell only limited amounts of oil to raise money for food, medicine and other needs.
A list of Iraqis who will be barred from international travel will be drawn up by a Security Council sanctions committee, working with the Special Commission and its chairman, Richard Butler, an Australian arms control expert. The list will be given to all United Nations member governments. Iraqis on legitimate diplomatic missions will be exempt.
The resolution allows for lifting the ban if Mr. Butler reports that Iraq has given inspectors "immediate, unconditional and unrestricted access to any and all areas, facilities, equipment, records and means of transportation which they wish to inspect."

HEADLINE: Cabinetry Factory Is Being Converted By Federal Express

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
Federal Express is converting a former cabinetry factory in Canarsie into its largest distribution center in Brooklyn, a further sign of the transformation of much of the city's industrial base from manufacturing into warehousing and shipping.
The overnight delivery company, based in Memphis, will open the center in a 170,000-square-foot building at 107-23 Farragut Road, along the industrial fringes of the Canarsie and New Lots neighborhoods. 
 Federal Express, which will lease the building from Cargex Properties of Manchester, N.H., now operates a distribution plant in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, in addition to locations in Maspeth and at Kennedy International Airport in Queens, said the company's broker, Barry Rosner of Williams Real Estate Company.
Federal Express said the new center would employ up to 175 people when it opens next June, many of them transferred from Sunset Park.
The new distribution center will be in the Flatlands Industrial Park, a 100-acre project developed by the Rentar Development Corporation on city-owned land, beginning in 1967. Felice Bassin, senior vice president of Rentar, said all but two manufacturers have left the park. Laird Plastics and Arrow Lock Manufacturing Company are all that remain.
Still, the industrial park is fully occupied, Ms. Bassin said, because of the arrival of numerous distributors and service and shipping companies.
The Federal Express building is part of the trend. Cargex Properties bought the building for $3.9 million from Jafci Management, headed by Joseph and Frank Ingarra. The Ingarras also ran the defunct Duralab Equipment Corporation, which made metal cabinets and countertops for health care, pharmaceutical and scientific companies.
Moshe Siegel bought Duralab's assets at a bankruptcy auction in June.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Falls 157 Points After Declines Overseas
The fallout from a worldwide slide in share prices continued to rattle stock markets in the United States. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 157.41 points, or 2.08 percent, at 7,401.32, after bigger declines in some overseas markets.
Even the Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates -- which typically would have been seen as a positive sign because it could aid economic growth -- failed to start a rally. Page D10. 

The stocks of big American banks like Chase Manhattan and Citicorp were among the biggest decliners -- dropping 5 percent and 5.7 percent, respectively -- because of worries about their overseas exposure. D4.
 
Brazilian stocks plummeted more than 10 percent, continuing a selloff in which the country's market has lost most of its gains for the year. D10.
 
Kmart President to Step Down
Warren Flick, who as president and chief operating officer of Kmart has been credited with helping improve the troubled retailer's merchandise strategy, will retire after only two years at the company, for medical reasons. D6.
 
Caspian Oil Flows to the West
In Azerbaijan, foreign oilmen and regional leaders celebrated the start of the first direct flow of crude oil from the Caspian Sea to the West since the breakup of the Soviet Union. It signaled an initial triumph in a three-year United States-backed effort to break Russia's blockade of energy exports from the former Caspian republics. D2.
 
Big Theater Chain In Deal to Be Sold
Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the Dallas investment firm, agreed to buy United Artists Theater Group, the nation's second-largest cinema chain, with nearly 2,200 screens, for $300 million. The deal for United Artists, a company descended from a Hollywood studio founded by silent-screen stars more than 70 years ago, reflects the rapid consolidation in the theater business. D9.
 
Bond Prices Rise
Prices of Treasury securities climbed, as stock prices retreated and investors looked for a safe haven. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.10 percent from 6.14. D17.
 
Dollar Higher Against the Yen
The dollar surged against the yen, settling at 126.32 to the dollar, on concern about the Japanese economy and Tokyo's slumping stock market. D8.
 
Coffee Futures Prices Climb
Coffee futures prices rose to a four-week high, with demand strong and Latin American shipments delayed. D8.
 
Undisclosed 401(k) Costs
Some of the 401(k) plans that 25 million workers use to save for retirement are charged hidden fees by companies that invest the money and maintain records, industry experts said at a Labor Department hearing. Full disclosure of fees would lead to lower costs, they added. D4.
 
S.E.C. Cites Lack of Disclosure
Peter R. DeGeorge, chairman of a small company in the home-building business, has agreed to pay almost $300,000 to settle a Federal complaint that he secretly used company money for his own benefit, the S.E.C. said. The company failed to tell shareholders that it had spent more than $300,000 to market a product called Nutrapro, the Fat Loss Coach, which Mr. DeGeorge owned with a friend, the S.E.C. said. D6.

HEADLINE: F.B.I. Men Sent to Karachi To Investigate the Slaying

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Federal counterterrorism officials said today that they had no hard evidence to link the killing of four Americans in Karachi to a Pakistani immigrant's conviction, 28 hours earlier, on charges of murdering two Central Intelligence Agency employees in 1993.
But suspicion was strong enough that the Federal Bureau of Investigation dispatched a team of agents to Karachi today. Their orders are to gather evidence, not to conduct a full-scale terrorism investigation, because Attorney General Janet Reno has not certified that the slaying of the four men and their Pakistani driver was an act of terrorism. 
 They were told to proceed cautiously. "There is a fear" that they might be in danger of falling into a trap set to avenge the conviction of the Pakistani immigrant, Mir Amal Kansi, one Government official said.
"The fear is that the idea behind the shooting was to lure the F.B.I. to Pakistan and attack them -- that they will target the F.B.I. for snatching Kansi," said the official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified by name or agency.
F.B.I. agents, working with C.I.A. officers and State Department officials, arrested Mr. Kansi in Pakistan five months ago after a four-and-a-half-year manhunt. They flew him to a Virginia jail without a formal hearing after the arrest, which touched off anti-American protests in several Pakistani cities, including Karachi.
The attack reverberated into the Virginia courthouse where the jurors who convicted Mr. Kansi will soon begin weighing whether to impose a death sentence.
This morning, Mr. Kansi's lawyers sought a mistrial, asserting that jurors were terrified by the killings. The judge in the case denied the motion, saying he saw no sign the jurors were shaken. He ordered them sequestered tonight to shield them from news of the killings. He previously ordered that the jurors' names and addresses be kept secret permanently.
Counterterrorism officials said today it was not immediately clear why the car carrying four American oil-company contractors was chosen as a target by the gunmen in Karachi. One said the gunmen might have picked "a random opportunity to go after what looked like Americans."
In the five months since Mr. Kansi's arrest, Americans citizens in Pakistan have received several warnings, official and unofficial, to look out for their safety.
In June some leading political figures in Pakistan, including Gen. Mizra Aslam Beg, the former army Chief of Staff, warned that the arrest and extradition of Mr. Kansi would ignite anti-American violence comparable to the street protests in Iran in 1979.
In October, after the particularly brutal slaying of five Iranians in Pakistan's old capital of Rawalpindi, the State Department warned American citizens in the country to "exercise extreme caution concerning personal security."
And on Monday night -- Tuesday morning in Pakistan -- the State Department issued a worldwide warning to "Americans traveling abroad" that "the potential exists for retaliation by Kansi's sympathizers." That warning was based on common sense rather than a concrete threat, a State Department official said today.
News of the conviction spread throughout Pakistan on Tuesday. The attack took place about 8 A.M. today in Karachi, about 28 hours after the jurors in Virginia returned their guilty verdict.
Political tensions and anti-American feelings are high in parts of the Islamic world, fueled by the standoff between Iraq and the United Nations and by the deterioration of peace negotiations in the Middle East, as well as the conviction in the C.I.A. case, Government officials said.
They said unspecified threats have been made against the dwindling number of countries scheduled to attend the American-sponsored economic conference scheduled for next week in the Persian Gulf emirate of Qatar.
Many countries, including Egypt, are boycotting the conference -- intended to promote business ties between Arab nations and Israel -- to protest the near-collapse of peace talks.
Secretary of State Madeline K. Albright said today that her plans to attend the Qatar conference and travel to Pakistan next week were unchanged. She said the United States "will leave no stone unturned until we find the perpetrators of this horrible crime."
The killings in Karachi appear to be the deadliest politically motivated attack against American civilians overseas in two years, United States counterterrorism officials said today.
Not since four American contractors lost their lives in a still-unsolved bombing in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Nov. 13, 1995, have so many United States civilians been killed in an attack that appeared to be politically motivated, the officials said.
Government officials pointed out today that the killings bore an outward resemblance to the slaying on March 9, 1995, of two Americans driving to work at the United States Consulate in Karachi. That crime is also unsolved.
Jackie Van Landingham, a secretary, and Gary Durrell, a communications specialist, were killed six weeks after F.B.I. agents in Pakistan arrested Ramzi Ahmed Yousef -- the man convicted today of masterminding the World Trade Center bombing in 1993.
On the record, Government officials said no hard facts conclusively linked the latest shooting to Mr. Kansi's conviction. "We do not have direct evidence that links those two," said the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry.
But counterterrorism officials in Washington and the police in Karachi agree that there appears to be a strong circumstantial connection.
The jurors who convicted Mr. Kansi heard medical testimony today, presented by defense lawyers seeking to persuade them not to impose a death sentence in the penalty phase of the state court trial. The testimony suggested that Mr. Kansi's brain was damaged, impairing his ability to think clearly.
The prosecutors who won the verdict against Mr. Kansi on Monday presented testimony strongly suggesting that his motivation for killing the two C.I.A. employees was anger at United States foreign policy in the Middle East.
No evidence at the trial showed that Mr. Kansi was a member of any organized group. His case was conducted as a murder pure and simple, not a matter of terrorism.
But one of the F.B.I. agents who arrested Mr. Kansi, Bradley J. Garrett, testified that the defendant had told him he was particularly furious over the bombing of Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, the treatment of Palestinians by Israel and the perceived power of the United States and the C.I.A. over Islamic countries like Pakistan.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The New American Politics

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Well, I guess it's official now: America has a four-party system.
That's the most important lesson to come out of Monday's decision by Congressional Democrats to reject President Clinton's request for "fast track" authority to sign more international free-trade agreements. I see a silver lining in what Congress did, even though it was harebrained. Maybe now at least the American public, and the business community, will fully understand what politics is increasingly about in this country, and will focus on which of America's four parties they want to join. 
 Me, I'm an Integrationist-Social-Safety-Netter. How about you?
To figure out which party you're in let me again offer the Friedman matrix of globalization politics. Take a piece of paper and draw a line across the middle from east to west. This is the globalization line, where you locate how you feel about the way in which technology and open markets are combining to integrate more and more of the world. At the far right end of this line are the Integrationists. These are people who believe that freer trade and integration are either inevitable or good; they want to promote more trade agreements and Internet connections from one end of the world to the other, 24 hours a day.
Next go to the far left end of this line. These are the Separatists. These are people who believe free trade and technological integration are neither good nor inevitable; they want to stop them in their tracks. So first locate yourself somewhere on this line between Separatists and Integrationists.
Now draw another line from north to south through the middle of the globalization line. This is the distribution line. It defines what you believe should go along with globalization to cushion its worst social, economic and environmental impacts. At the southern end of this line are the Social-Safety-Netters. These are people who believe that we need to package global integration with programs that will assist the "know-nots" and "have-nots," who lack the skills to take advantage of the new economy or who get caught up in the job-churning that goes with globalization and are unemployed or driven into poorer-paying jobs. The Safety-Netters also want programs to improve labor and environmental standards in developing countries rushing headlong into the global economy.
At the northern tip of this distribution line are the Let-Them-Eat-Cakers. These are people who believe that globalization is winner-take-all, loser-take-care-of-yourself.
Now everyone in the fast-track debate is in my matrix: Bill Clinton is an Integrationist-Social-Safety-Netter. Newt Gingrich is an Integrationist-Let-Them-Eat-Caker. Dick Gephardt is a Separatist-Social-Safety-Netter and Ross Perot is a Separatist-Let-Them-Eat-Caker. That's why Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gingrich are allies on free trade but opponents on social welfare, and why Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Perot are allies against more free trade, but opponents on social welfare.
As I said, I'm an Integrationist-Social-Safety-Netter. I believe that the technologies weaving the world more tightly together cannot be stopped and the integration of markets can be reversed only at a very, very high cost. Bill Clinton is right about that and Dick Gephardt and the unions are wrong.
But Mr. Gephardt and the unions are right that globalization is as creatively destructive as the earlier versions of capitalism, which destroyed feudalism and Communism. With all its positives, globalization does churn new jobs and destroy old ones, it does widen gaps between those with knowledge skills and those without them, it does weaken bonds of community. And the Clinton team, the business community and all the workers already benefiting from the information economy never took these dark sides seriously enough.
One hopes they now realize that this is one of the most fundamental issues -- maybe the most fundamental issue -- in American politics. You can't just give a speech about it one month before the vote, you can't just have your company buy an ad supporting it the day before the vote, you can't just summon a constituency for it on the eve of the vote. You have to build a real politics of Integrationist-Social-Safety-Nettism -- a politics that can show people the power and potential of global integration, while taking seriously their needs for safety nets to protect them along the way. Build it and they will come.

HEADLINE: In Letter, Rubin Warns Japan It Must Bolster Limp Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
In another sign of Washington's concern about an escalation of the financial crisis in Asia, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin wrote a private letter to his Japanese counterpart late last week warning that the health of Japan's banking system was deeply imperiled and urging strong action to spur the Japanese economy.
Details of the letter have leaked out in both Japan and the United States in recent days, though the Treasury Department, citing the traditional confidentiality of correspondence between finance ministers, has declined to release the text. 
 Reports about the letter's content appear to reflect the Clinton Administration's fears that the choking off of Japan's long-delayed economic recovery, worsened by a sharp fall in the Japanese stock market, could set off a crisis like the one that moved from the markets of Southeast Asia to those of New York and Latin America in the last month.
Mr. Rubin's letter, as described by people who have seen its content, apparently does not directly refer to the weakening Japanese yen, which makes Japanese goods more affordable overseas. The yen fell today to 126.32 yen to the dollar, a six-month low. But Mr. Rubin repeated his warning that Japanese officials should not be tempted to export their way out of their troubles -- a move that would greatly increase America's trade deficit.
It is unclear precisely what words Mr. Rubin used. Still, he has often said publicly that Japan's recovery should be fueled by "domestic demand-led growth."
While Mr. Rubin's letter was directed at Japan, it is increasingly clear that the Administration's immediate worry these days centers on what Japan might do in response to a potential financial collapse of South Korea, Japan's closest neighbor.
The South Korean currency has plummeted in recent weeks, corporate bankruptcies are spreading, and its banks are teetering under the weight of bad loans that many experts think vastly exceed the banks' corporate equity. In recent days, officials in Washington and Tokyo have made little secret of their concern that a free fall in the South Korean currency could put pressure on Japan to let the yen fall as well.
South Korea is one of Japan's fiercest regional competitors, and American officials worry that Japanese industry may urge the Government to make sure that South Korea's devaluation does not undermine Japanese businesses by making Japanese exports less competitive than South Korean ones.
"There's a potential here for an enormous train wreck," one senior Administration official said last week. "It's not clear, however, that there is much we could do to prevent it."
The immediate result, American officials think, could be a huge rise in the American trade deficit with Asia next year. One leading trade economist, David Hale of the Zurich Insurance Group, estimated recently that America's trade deficit with the world could expand to $250 billion to $300 billion by early 1999, up from $192 billion last year.
But the trade imbalance could rank among the least of the problems. Japanese banks, securities houses and insurance firms have struggled for several years because of the implosion of the Japanese real estate market and the fall of the stock market. They are particularly vulnerable now because they are also exposed to enormous losses in Southeast Asia. A collapse in South Korea could lead to a new round of trouble across the Sea of Japan.
Japan and the United States could also come under great pressure to engineer a South Korean aid package, though the Korean finance ministry, in a long and defensive statement issued today, insisted that it would need no outside help. To compound matters, South Korea is in the middle of a hard-fought presidential election campaign in which the ruling party could lose power for the first time in modern Korean history. In the midst of that campaign, the Government is reluctant to seek aid or take austerity measures.
Economists in the United States and Europe are clearly unconvinced that South Korea can make it on its own. "The U.S. will probably have to play a dominant role in a Korean aid package because it is difficult to imagine Government in either Seoul or Tokyo accepting one which placed a major responsibility on Japan," Mr. Hale wrote recently. But that could prove politically impossible in Washington, where Congress balked two years ago at approving a bailout of Mexico. South Korea's status as a key American military ally in Asia might not be enough to sway those in Congress who think the United States should not put money at risk rescuing foreign countries, even if the real purpose is to stabilize the world economy.
Letters between Mr. Rubin and Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, his Tokyo counterpart, are not unusual, but this one comes at an extraordinarily sensitive time. It is unclear why Japanese officials first leaked some of the content of the letter to Mr. Mitsuzuka, a longtime Liberal Democratic Party politician who several years ago served as Japan's trade minister.
They could have been paving the way for the release of a Japanese fiscal stimulus package next week. But it is also possible that Japanese officials are seeking to establish that the country is facing pressure from abroad to take more drastic, politically unpopular steps to rescue its financial sector, including closing the weakest banks and bailing out depositors.
"This is a case where gaiatsu might help," a senior Japanese official said, using the Japanese term for foreign pressure.

HEADLINE: Gulf Alliance: A Falling Out

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 12

 BODY:
In the heady aftermath of the Persian Gulf war of 1991, American officials dreamed of transforming the Arab coalition that helped to oust Iraq from Kuwait into a new Arab coalition for peace.
They envisioned an Arab world no longer unified by romantic notions of solidarity, but riven by self-interest, with warmongers like Iraq to be punished into submission while peacemakers like Egypt and Syria reaped rewards for good conduct. 
 But after seven years of dashed expectations, what is now taking shape has the trappings of an Arab revolt.
The same Arab governments that rushed troops to the Saudi desert now stand united in opposition to the use of military might in the current confrontation between the United States and Iraq over Baghdad's threat to expel United Nations arms inspectors. As the Security Council voted today for more sanctions against Iraq, new questions were raised about the next stage in the crisis. Page A6.
Some of America's gulf war allies are echoing Iraqi calls for an end to economic sanctions against Baghdad.
And, even more tellingly, an American-backed economic conference that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is to attend this weekend in Doha, Qatar, now appears likely to include no more than a smattering of Arab participants. Among those who have refused Qatar's invitation to join an Israeli delegation around the table are Egypt and Saudi Arabia, the United States' most important allies in the region.
While the main focus of American diplomacy this week has been to line up support for the Security Council resolution, the stands taken by Arab governments outside the United Nations chambers have served as an important reason for American constraint.
"If the United States had pushed for a tougher stance on Iraq, it was plain to everyone that the Doha conference would have metamorphosed from a mere embarrassment to a disaster," a Western diplomat here said.
Nevertheless, with so many Arab countries staying at arm's length from Ms. Albright and her Israeli counterpart, David Levy, the year's most important gathering of Arab officials will now take place not in Doha, but at an Islamic summit meeting next month in Teheran, the capital of Iran, to which neither the United States nor Israel will be invited.
Even today, the Iraqi Government sought to exploit the emerging differences between the United States and its gulf war allies. Iraq's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf, pointed out to reporters in Baghdad that public opinion in many Arab countries now "stands clearly against the Americans."
Behind the renewed sense of Arab solidarity toward Iraq and against the United States has been a feeling that in the relationship between Washington and Arab capitals since the gulf war, basic understandings have been broken.
While the United States assured its allies that the isolation of Iraq would change Baghdad's behavior, the only tangible effect of the campaign has been the widespread suffering of the Iraqi people, according to this view.
And while the United States, from the time of the Middle East peace conference of 1991, has promised an evenhanded effort in promoting a broader Arab-Israeli settlement, its many Arab critics say it has failed to do so in practice.
Instead, according to this view, the Clinton Administration has simply acquiesced in a backsliding by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel that has sent Arab-Israeli relations plummeting to their lowest level in more than four years.
"A consensus within the Arab world now is that American policy toward Iraq has been overkill and that the Iraqi people have needlessly suffered," said Mohammed Sayed Saeed, a policy analyst at the Al Ahram Center for Strategic Studies in Cairo. "At the same time, Arabs believe that they have been treated as inferiors by the United States while Israel, which went back on its peace agreements, enjoys complete American protection."
Such thinking has been bubbling for many months in the Arab press and in the comments of some Arab officials. But the combination of the showdown with Iraq and a buildup to the economic conference that included last-minute American efforts to rally Arab support has begun to reveal just how deeply the resentment is felt.
Even President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, whose country acted as host for the previous conference, in November 1996, declared that his Government would stay away this time because previous efforts had produced nothing of substance and "because the Israeli Government never carries out its promises."
Of the Arab states that sent troops into battle against Iraq, only Syria has openly sided with Baghdad in the current crisis. Finding that its participation in the gulf war coalition led only to stalemate in its effort to reclaim territory conquered by Israel and secure a lasting peace, it has made a major effort in recent months to improve relations with President Saddam Hussein's regime, even opening the border between the two countries for the first time in 15 years.
Even Kuwait, which Iraq invaded and annexed in 1990, has avoided any hint of provocation. On Monday the Government, normally outspoken in support for tough measures against Baghdad, said the crisis "between Iraq and the Security Council is an issue related to them and Kuwait has nothing to do with it."
Indeed, the absence of any threat to another Arab country by Iraq in the current crisis has only added to Arab reluctance to oppose Baghdad.
The Arab League, which sent troops to Saudi Arabia in 1990 eight days after the invasion of Kuwait, has in this case declared its "complete rejection" of military action even if Iraq carries out its threat to expel American weapons inspectors. The United Arab Emirates, an important gulf war participant that has since called for a lifting of sanctions against Iraq, has warned through an official Government newspaper that an attack on Iraq -- "the defeated and the paralyzed" -- could be interpreted only as "an attack against the whole Arab nation."
And while Egypt, which holds a rotating seat on the Security Council, voted in favor of today's measure tightening sanctions against Iraq, Mr. Mubarak has publicly expressed the hope that "there will be no military operations against Iraq," while the semi-official newspaper Al Ahram, in an editorial earlier this week, endorsed the broad outline of Iraq's complaints.
The idea of "Arab solidarity" has been floated often in recent decades, but often as little more than a slogan that fails to take into account rivalries of interest and ambition.
But its role has also sometimes been underestimated. Because of a shared culture and language, a sense of kinship among Arab peoples is felt much more deeply than that which exists, for example, between Americans and Europeans, and it has contributed to popular outrage in every Arab capital at the plight of Iraqis at the hands of the United States.
In an important sense, the resistance now being shown by Arab leaders toward the United States and its policies amounts to stepping back in line with a public opinion they had previously been willing to flout.
That kind of uninhibited sentiment was on display this evening at a demonstration in Cairo where a committee of Arab women denounced the economic sanctions against Iraq as "a weapon of mass destruction." It was also evident on Monday in the West Bank and Gaza, where hundreds of Palestinians staged demonstrations that gave voice to the Arab creed that "the enemy of my enemy is my friend."
"Oh Saddam my dear," the demonstrators chanted in the West Bank town of Ramallah, "drop your bombs on Tel Aviv."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Japan's Trade Surplus Soars in 6-Month Period

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus soared 75.7 percent in the first half of this fiscal year compared with figures from the corresponding period a year earlier, the Ministry of Finance said today. The ministry said the current account surplus, the broadest measure of trade in goods and services, rose to 5.81 trillion yen, or $46.1 billion, from April to September. It said the surplus in merchandise trade increased 52.7 percent, to 6.25 trillion yen, or $49.6 billion. 
 In September, the current account surplus climbed 63.7 percent, to 1.17 trillion yen, or $9.2 billion, and the trade surplus rose 30.4 percent, to 1.23 trillion yen, or $10 billion. The surplus has ballooned this year as a result of surging exports, car exports to the United States in particular, combined with a weak domestic economy. Economists said they expected the rising trend in the current account surplus to continue.

HEADLINE: 4 Americans Slain in Pakistan; Link to Killing at C.I.A. Is Seen

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Gunmen leaped from a car during the morning rush hour in the central business district here today, fired virtually at point-blank range and killed four Americans working as auditors for a Texas-based oil and gas company and their Pakistani driver. The police said they were looking for at least four men in what they called a terrorist attack.
The five victims, employees of Houston-based Union Texas Petroleum, appeared to have died instantly when the assailants circled the Americans' station wagon and riddled it with bullets. 
 As the assailants fled, abandoning their car a short distance away, the victims lay in their vehicle for 40 minutes under the gaze of a rush-hour crowd before being taken to the Aga Khan Hospital five miles away, where they were pronounced dead.
Executives of the American company's Pakistan subsidiary identified the dead Americans as Ephrahim C. Egbu, 42; Joel B. Enlow, 40; William L. Jennings, 49; and Tracy L. Ritchie, 41. The executives said the Americans, all of Houston, had been in Karachi for varying periods of up to three weeks preparing the local company's annual audit, and had found nothing in the company's books that might have provoked the attack. The dead driver was identified as Anwar Mirza, 51, of Karachi.
The attack, which police officials said was probably linked to the conviction of a Pakistani in the killing of two Central Intelligence Agency employees outside Washington, sent shock waves through the small American community here, already traumatized by an attack in March 1995 in which two American diplomats were gunned down as they drove to work in the city.
After taking a call from Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif expressing Pakistan's condolences, Arnold G. Hoffman, president of Union Texas' Pakistan subsidiary, called the killings "a terrible and tragic loss for the families, Union Texas and for Pakistan."
He added, "At this time, we do not know the reason for this attack and we are fully cooperating with local officials in their investigation."
Police officials called the shooting as "a vicious, organized terrorist attack." They said that two of the suspects, described as being clean-shaven and in their mid-20's, hijacked the Honda used by the assailants from a textile factory owner Monday in Karachi, a city that has become synonymous in Pakistan for waves of ethnic and sectarian violence that have killed at least 5,000 people in the last five years.
Other than that, the police appeared to have no firm clues.
Nevertheless, senior police officers said the most likely motive had been to avenge a Pakistani citizen, Mir Amal Kansi, who was convicted by a jury on Tuesday in Fairfax, Va., of murdering the two Central Intelligence Agency employees in a 1993 shooting, and of wounding three other C.I.A. men, outside C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va.
Militants in Mr. Kansi's native province, Baluchistan, had vowed to seek revenge after Mr. Kansi was seized by American and Pakistani agents during a stayover in the Pakistani city of Dera Ismail Khan in June, then flown to the United States aboard an American military plane without any extradition or other court hearing in Pakistan.
Mr. Kansi's conviction was a leading item in Pakistani radio and television news reports on Tuesday night and in newspapers this morning.
The State Department was concerned enough about a possible attack on Americans after the Kansi verdict that it issued a formal advisory in Washington on Tuesday warning Americans in Pakistan to be especially alert because of the risks of retaliation by Mr. Kansi's sympathizers, and to avoid visiting Baluchistan and other areas of Pakistan.
But several American business executives living in the city said the first they knew of the State Department warning was when they read accounts of it in this morning's Pakstani newspapers, at about the time the Americans were killed.
One American executive with a family living in the city said the American community relied on a warden system, in which Americans pass on warnings of enhanced security risks that are passed on to them by the American Consulate.
"But I checked with several of the wardens, and none them knew a thing about the Kansi warning,' he said. "I guess that somewhere along the line the communications failed."
In a telephone call to the consulate to inquire about the issue, officials said they were too busy to discuss any aspect of the killings.
For many Americans here, the killings shootings were eerily similar to the 1995 attack, which occurred on the airport highway about three miles from the scene of today's incident. Although Pakistani officials said at the time that one of the Americans who died in the 1995 shooting, Gary Durrell, was known to them as an employee of the Central Intelligence Agency, no motive for the attack on the diplomats was ever established, at least publicly.
When Pakistani officials announced this summer that a man held in Karachi Central Prison on another charge had confessed under questioning to having been part of the gang that carried out the 1995 attack, a breakthrough in the case seemed possible. But several months later, no charges against the man, who uses the gangland nickname Tufu, have been brought.
Asked about the case today, jail officials said that Tufu had claimed to have been in a backup vehicle for the attack on the diplomats, and had said that he did not know why the diplomats had been killed.
Comparing the 1995 killings and the attack today, some Pakistanis suggested that both incidents, rather than being reactions to particular actions or policies of the United States, could have sprung from the same anti-American feeling among some Pakistani Muslims that prosecutors in the Kansi case have given as Mr. Kansi's motive for killing the C.I.A. employees, Lansing Bennett and Frank Darling.
In the Fairfax court, the prosecutors said Mr. Kansi had been motivated by anger at United States policies that he believed created suffering among Palestinians, Bosnian Muslims and others.
In recent years, Pakistan, having lost all American military and economic aid because of its covert program to develop nuclear weapons, has tried to attract new American business investment here, but even this has faltered as a result of endemic political corruption and the threat posed by terrorism.
Although Karachi has a population of more than 12 million people and serves as the hub of industrial and financial activity for a country with a population of 130 million, there are fewer than 100 American business executives here.
Union Texas, the employer of today's victims, is one of the largest American companies here, employing 600 people and producing about half of Pakistan's oil production.
After the killings today, the number of Americans here seemed likely to fall still further. At the Sheraton and Pearl Continental Hotels 300 yards from the scene of today's shootings, where the four dead Americans had been staying, other American executives who were ordered out of Pakistan by their companies in the hours after the killings lined up at travel counters to book the earliest flights home.
"I told my boss I'd rather stay and complete my business," an American insurance executive said as he booked a flight through Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, to Istanbul, where he said he made his base. "But I wasn't given any choice. My boss just said: 'Get out there. We're not going to take any risks.' "

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

 
INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
4 Americans and Driver Die in Attack in Pakistan
Four Americans and their Pakistani driver were shot and killed as they drove through Karachi's central business district. The assailants fled, but police officials suspected they were avenging the conviction of a Pakistani citizen this week for killing two C.I.A. employees in Virginia in 1993. A1
 
Federal counter-terrorism officials in Washington said they feared the killings were a ploy to lure F.B.I. agents to Pakistan where they could be attacked. A10 

The four Americans were roving auditors who checked the books at Houston-based Union Texas Petroleum's overseas operations. A10
 
Sanctions Are Imposed on Iraq
The Security Council voted unanimously to impose new sanctions on Iraq for failing to cooperate with a United Nations disarmament commission. The sanctions included a ban on foreign travel by Iraqi officials, but Baghdad said it would ignore the ban, and again barred a team of inspectors from entering sites they wanted to investigate. A6
 
United Nations Begin Reform
The General Assembly approved a package of United Nations administrative reforms proposed by Secretary General Kofi Annan. None of the measures approved responded to demands being made by members of the Congress before the United States pays more than $1 billion in arrears to the organization. Mr. Annan made a special appeal for the creation of the post of Deputy Secretary General. A13
 
Election Date Is Fixed in Kenya
Kenya's electoral commission announced that the country's general elections, which most analysts expect President Daniel arap Moi to win, would be held on Dec. 29. Opposition leaders accused Mr. Moi's allies on the commission of rushing the election to give challengers less time to campaign. The Constitution required that elections be held before the end of the year, but recent electoral reforms led many to believe they would be delayed. A11
 
Famed Fugitive Remains Free
Brazil's supreme court rejected a British request for the extradition of Ronnie Biggs, who escaped from jail two years after robbing a Glasgow-to-London mail train in 1963. The court deemed Mr. Biggs's involvement in the celebrated "Great Train Robbery" as void under Brazil's 20-year statute of limitations. A5
 
Damaged Basilica Will Reopen
A part of Assisi's 13th century Basilica of St. Francis, badly damaged by recent earthquakes, will probably reopen to the public on Nov. 30, the church's custodians said. The Rev. Nicola Giandomenico, a spokesman for the Franciscan friars who live in the church complex, said security checks on the lower part of the basilica showed it was structurally safe. He reiterated the friars' hope that the upper basilica be reopened permanently in 2000. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A14-25
 
Congress Relaxes Rules On Residency for Refugees
Seeking to avert a backlash against Republicans, Congress is relaxing two provisions in a 1996 law that threatened to uproot hundreds of thousands of immigrants living in the United States. Lawmakers have agreed, in the waning days of this year's session, to exempt thousands of refugees from civil wars in Central America from sweeping new deportation rules. As many as 150,000 Nicaraguans would receive automatic permanent residency. A1

Justice Department officials have urged Attorney General Janet Reno to extend an investigation that could lead to the appointment of an independent prosecutor to examine Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's role in a decision to kill an Indian casino project, law-enforcement officials said. A20

New Guidelines on Asthma Care
Modest doses of inhaled steroids combined with other drugs control asthma as well as or better than high doses of steroids, while reducing the risk of side effects from long-term use, two studies have found. A23
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6
 
Jury Convicts Leader In Trade Center Bombing
A Federal jury in Manhattan convicted Ramzi Ahmed Yousef of orchestrating and helping carry out the deadly bomb plot at the World Trade Center in 1993. After deliberating for three days, the jury also convicted a second man, Eyad Ismoil, whom prosecutors accused of driving the van that carried the bomb into the Trade Center's underground garage. The bombing left six deaths, hundreds of injuries, millions of dollars in property damage and changed the way many New Yorkers viewed their security. A1
 
Investigators say they may never learn whether the plotters in the bombing had the backing of a government or Middle East terrorist group or acted independently, raising cash from family members and friends. And much about Mr. Yousef, from his background to his name, remains a mystery. A1

The F.B.I. has written to the families of victims of T.W.A. Flight 800 saying that it is closing its investigation because it has found "absolutely no evidence" that a criminal act -- such as a bomb or a missile -- brought the plane down off the coast of Long Island in July of 1996, killing all on board. A1
 
Gambling Cruises Set to Start
A company plans to begin daily gambling cruises out of midtown Manhattan as early as next month. The company will offer overnight cruises into international waters -- where casino gambling is legal -- for about 1,000 passengers per trip. B1

Fed Rates Unchanged
Torn between fear of incipient inflation at home and concern about unsettling financial markets around the world, the Federal Reserve voted to leave interest rates unchanged and ride out the storm for a while longer. The decision had been widely expected by economists and investors, who saw little chance that the central bank would risk upsetting the global markets by raising rates, even though there is mounting evidence that inflationary pressures are building in the American economy. HEADLINE: House Yields to Clinton in 2 Spending Bills

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Rushing to complete work and to adjourn for the year, the House of Representatives yielded to the Clinton Administration early this morning in passing 1998 fiscal year spending bills for foreign operations and for the District of Columbia.
The votes came after midnight and Republican leaders' removal of amendments that President Clinton had found objectionable. But in a bow to the conservatives who were behind the amendments, Republican leaders agreed to allow those issues to be voted on in separate, stand-alone legislation. 
 The compromise was a major victory for Mr. Clinton, who had threatened to veto the spending bills because of the contentious issues. But it is a bittersweet victory since it comes on the heels of his failure to win one of his major legislative goals of the year, enhanced trade authority, or fast-track legislation.
The House on a voice vote Wednesday night approved an interim Federal highway bill that would provide about $15 billion in transportation grants to the states for the next six months. Under the plan, which House and Senate negotiators agreed to on Sunday, each state would receive at least half the Federal transportation money that it received in 1997, giving Congress until next spring to work out a permanent six-year plan.
With the fast-track legislation off the political landscape, the last major pieces of legislation facing the first session of the 104th Congress are a vote on a bailout for Amtrak and passage of the spending bills for the Departments of Commerce, State and Justice and the Federal judiciary system; the District of Columbia; and for foreign operations.
The House is expected to adjourn later today after completing work on the spending bill for Commerce, State and Justice. The Senate is to begin voting on the three remaining spending bills and the highway bill today and to complete its work as early as Friday.
The nearly $13 billion spending bill for foreign operations passed in the House on a vote of 333 to 76 after Republican leaders restored $385 million for international family-planning programs and removed language that would have prohibited Federal funds from going to overseas programs or organizations that use their own money to promote abortion. But instead of a lump sum, the money will be allocated over a year at a rate of 8.34 percent, or $32 million a month.
An official of Population Action International criticized the plan as "doling out money by the teaspoon."
"This is an unhappy compromise and no way to fund one of the world's most respected programs," said Victoria Markell, vice president of the population organization. "Rather, it is a way to cripple it."
Current Federal law, under the so-called Mexico City Policy, already bars the use of Federal money for overseas abortion services, but anti-abortion forces in the House had tried to expand that language.
The Republicans also stripped from the foreign operations spending bill three provisions that are dear to the White House: reauthorization of the State Department, the United States' payment of nearly $1 billion in back dues to the United Nations and $3.5 billion to help the International Monetary Fund bolster tottering economies in Southeast Asia.
Those three provisions will be lumped into a separate piece of legislation along with the language on international family planning that was removed from the spending bill.
International organizations like the United Nations and the International Monetary Fund are frequent political targets of conservative Republicans. But the current fight comes at an especially crucial time.
The International Monetary Fund has announced that it will lend $17 billion to Thailand and $10 billion to Indonesia as part of an effort involving 25 nations, including the United States, to stabilize their currencies. Without such action, world leaders fear that other Southeast Asian nations will face similar problems.
Administration officials, led by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, met Wednesday evening with Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Republican leaders in an effort to negotiate a compromise over the issues.
The District of Columbia spending bill was approved on a voice vote. The bill, with $820 million, had been held up because of a fight over a Republican plan to provide $7 million for a school voucher program. It would provide $3,200 vouchers to 2,000 children from low-income families in Washington to allow the children to attend private schools. Democrats, including the President, opposed the idea, arguing that it would erode the public school system.
The Senate voted on Sunday to remove the voucher proposal from the spending bill and to make it a separate bill, and the House leadership decided on Wednesday to go along with that approach.
The major breakthrough on the Commerce, Justice and State Departments bill came in the weekend when Republican leaders and the White House agreed to a compromise over a disputed method of estimating the population in 2000.
The Census Bureau would be allowed to proceed with a test next year on the use of statistical sampling, as the Administration wanted. In return, Republicans won an agreement that the House Speaker would be allowed to challenge in court the use of sampling and that the Government would pay for the lawsuit.
That provision angered Democrats to the point that many said Wednesday night that they would vote against the spending bill for Commerce and the other departments. But the Democrats conceded that they lacked the votes to defeat it.
The bill appropriates money for three of the largest Cabinet departments -- Commerce ($3.2 billion), Justice ($1.13 billion), and State ($5 billion) -- as well as the Federal judiciary system ($3.2 billion).

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
American International Group, which already has a sizable presence in lower Manhattan, is expanding by 135,636 square feet at 110 William Street, the 32-story tower at the corner of John Street.

Among the other tenants of the 848,592-square-foot building, constructed in 1958, are the city's Economic Development Corporation and Department of Business Services. DAVID M. HALBFINGER

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
Malaysian Leader Faces Vote After Comments

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad will face a vote of confidence in Parliament over his reported remarks that a Jewish conspiracy was behind Malaysia's currency crisis, his deputy said today.
The move comes in response to demands in the United States Congress that Mr. Mahathir resign or apologize for comments last month about Jews. 
 Mr. Mahathir is expected to win the vote in the lower house of Parliament, where his National Front coalition controls more than 85 percent of the seats.
The coalition's motion for a vote will be presented at the earliest possible date in the current session of Parliament, Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said.
Mr. Mahathir has denied making anti-Jewish statements, saying he had only denounced George Soros, the American financier, who he had noted is a Jew.

HEADLINE: Global Stock Slide Reaches U.S. as Dow Falls 157.41

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

 BODY:
The fallout from a worlwide slide in share prices continued to rattle stock markets in the United States yesterday, sending all the major indexes tumbling sharply.
 
 Fears that a global economic slow-down could pose a threat to corporate profits everywhere, initially depressed stocks in Asia and Europe, then in the Western hemisphere.
 The worries are so severe that even the Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates at yesterday's policy meeting - typically seen as a positive sign for economic growth - failed to spark a rally.
 In fact, after the Fed announced its decision, shortly after 2 P.M., the Dow Joes industrial average nose-dived. It closed down 157.41 points, or 2.08 percent, at 7,401.32 - and is now down about 10.4 percent form its record close on Aug. 6.
 Much of the fallout yesterday followed a slide of nearly 4 percent in the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong.
 For several weeks, stock markets around the globe have gyrated in tandem, making one thing clear, analysts say: the economies and stock markets around the word are undeniably linked.
 "Some regions are much worse off than others, but it's clear that world economic growth will slow next year," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "The U.S. is still going to have a decent economy, but we're going to get a negative growth shock."
 The slump in share prices here is not just a knee-jerk reaction to falling prices elsewhere, analysts say, but a fundamental concern over the prospects for earnings growth.
 "We're getting worries about earnings and carnage in the technology sector because that's where some of the big earnings were," said David Shulman, the chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers. "Asia is much worse than people think, and the Asian contagion has moved to Brazil."
 In Brazil, the selloff erased some of the world's biggest 1997 stock gains. Yesterday, the Bovespa Index, which peaked in July, fell 10 percent, prompting exchange officials to halt trading for 30 minutes. In three months, the Bovespa has lost nearly 50 percent.
 A Brazilian Government austerity plan of spending cuts and tax increases aimed at taming a growing budget deficit seems to have shaken faith in the economy, and prospects for earnings growth next year.
 "A month ago, we thought Brazil was going to grow 3.5 percent, and now it looks like it's not going to grow," Mr. Steinberg at Merrill said. "It seems that widening parts of the world are being pulled into this defationary cauldron."
 While no analysts believe the situation is as severe in the United States as in Brazil or Asia, there are growing concerns that a deflationary episode abroad could reduce earnings prospects at home.
 "You've got a major international catstrophe brewing," said Don R. Hays, a strategist at Wheat First Butcher Singer, adding, "You've got a stock market that's more overvalued than at any time in history, and so investors are taking some air out of the ballon."
 Among the hardest hit sectors yesterday were banking and technology, both of which are viewed as sensitive to a slowdown in the Pacific Rim.
 Shares of Chase Manhattan fell 5 5/8, to 106 3/4, and Citicorp fell 7 1/16, to 116 3/8. Texas Instruments also fell sharply, down 12 1/2, to 93 3/4, after a Robertson Stephens analyt lowered earnings estimates.
 Shares of Worldcom dropped for the third consecutive session since the company agreed to acquire MCI Communications, falling 1 15/16, to 28 15/16, or 1/16 below the price Wold-com had set to guarantee its offer of each share of MCI. At the new price, Worldcom would offer MCI shareholders $50.89, worth of Worldcom stock instead, shaving the overall value of the deal to $36.39 billion from $36.47 billion.
 Other sectors are also vulnerable. Volkswagen A.G., Europe's large auto maker, is cutting production in Brazil, and General Motors is already warnings of weakness overseas and falling earnings expectations.
 Few shares were spared yesterday. On the Big Board, a little more than seven stocks fell for every two that rose in heavy volume of more than 588 million shares.
 But Laszio Birinyi, a market strategist at Birinyi & Associates in Greenwich, Conn., said that investors continued to quietly buy up shares of blue-chip issues. "Our attitude is the bull market is still intact," he said. "Even though everyone's concerned about Asia, few are actually leaving the party. The selling is not as intense as the prices reflect."

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 41; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk
