HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Art in Miami Now Extends Beyond Deco

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
Move over, "Miami Vice." Make ready for Miami nice.
The metropolis of south Florida is fast developing into an arts center. In fact, it may already have the richest cultural life of any city in the southeastern United States. 
 There are plenty of images to the contrary, of course: the white stretch limos, the Baywatch blondes, the nouveau riche extravagance, the mindless hours of sun worship, the murders of German tourists and of Gianni Versace. Some people think a sentence that contains the words "art" and "Miami" must be a grammatical error.
But just by itself, the southern end of Miami Beach has: (1) the greatest assemblage of Art Deco buildings in the United States; (2) the home auditorium of a ballet company that faithfully upholds the Balanchine tradition, and (3) the most comprehensive collection of early modern design in the world, not to mention an ever-changing cast of wacko street characters, who do things like dress up as Mondrian paintings for Halloween.
Lenny Bruce once derided southern Florida as the place where neon comes to retire. Fair enough. But Norman Van Aken, the area's most gifted chef, redresses the balance with a much more positive, equally epigrammatic comment. "Miami," he says, "is where the future comes for tryouts."
All around Dade County -- in Miami, North Miami, Coral Gables and Coconut Grove -- there are splendid feasts for the mind as well as the senses.
In the last decade or so, Miami has become the hub of banking, commerce and transportation in the Caribbean, and wealthy businessmen from Venezuela, Colombia and elsewhere maintain homes here, shuttling in and out. A long-lived local joke says that Miami is no longer the southernmost big city in the United States but the northernmost big city in Latin America. Calle Ocho, Eighth Street, the bustling main street of Little Havana, is the heartland of Hispanic Miami. At the corner of Southwest 13th Street stands a stark memorial to those killed in the bungled Bay of Pigs landings, marked with an eternal flame and a Spanish inscription recalling the fiasco of April 17, 1961.
This is a new city, peopled almost entirely by men and women who were born elsewhere. Many are refugees from the icy Northern winters; many more are refugees from politically or economically repressed parts of the Caribbean. Now they are trying to grow together ethnically, politically, commercially and culturally.
"You could have the same demographics in New York or L.A., and it wouldn't mix," said Bonnie Clearwater, director of the revitalized Museum of Contemporary Art in North Miami, who has lived in all three cities. "Here, for some reason, it does."
To see how life used to be lived here, you could do worse than begin at Vizcaya, the lavish winter home of James Deering, an International Harvester tycoon who between 1914 and 1916 caused there to arise on the steamy shores of Biscayne Bay a grand faux-Renaissance villa, complete with pipe organ.
Like Hearst, Deering plundered Europe for his New World showplace, taking a gate from a Pisani palace and a tinted plaster ceiling from the Rossi Palace, both in Venice. He liked Venice. His stone breakwater is shaped like a barge, with obelisks perched upon it, and Venetian-style striped poles rise from the water near the landing.
Another dreamer, George Merrick, built Coral Gables a decade later. He called it "The City Beautiful," a slogan that seems less far-fetched, even now, than most developers' coinages. The centerpiece is the romantic, Mediterranean-style Biltmore Hotel, newly restored and worth a visit even if you do not stay there; all around it, on streets mostly named for Spanish cities, are tile-roofed bungalows shaded by fig trees and live oaks. Coral Gables has its allusion to Venice, too: an enormous public swimming hole, the Venetian Pool, cut from a rock quarry and festooned with ferns, palms and waterfalls.
The Art Deco district of South Beach has not only been preserved but also turned into the city's symbol. More than 650 buildings from the 1930's, centered on Ocean Drive, have been restored, many as hotels, and painted butterscotch, turquoise, mint green, coral and teal. (Teal is Miami's color, whether we are talking about Don Johnson's sports coats, the uniforms of the football Dolphins and the world champion baseball Marlins or the signs identifying tow-away zones.)
You can buy guidebooks or join tours at the Art Deco Welcome Center at 1001 Ocean Drive. Among the choicest buildings are the blue-and-white Park Central Hotel, at 640 Ocean Drive, by Henry Hohauser; the Clevelander, at 1020 Ocean, with a flying-saucer sculpture, and the Leslie, at 1244, lemon yellow with handsome fluted columns. The Cardozo, a fine Streamline Moderne building at 1300 Ocean, is undergoing a second restoration. Versace lived at 1114 Ocean, an atypical Mediterranean palace, and died on its steps.
As you walk, notice the high jinks on the beach opposite: an architect manque building a minutely detailed sand castle, complete with turrets and cannon; improbably fit men and women Rollerblading; beefcakes doing push-ups.
The local tradition of quality architecture, dented a bit in the 1950's and 60's, has been picked up by Arquitectonica, a Miami-based firm with a worldwide practice. Three condominiums on Brickell Avenue near downtown Miami -- the Palace at 1541, the Imperial at 1627 and the Atlantis at 2025, with a red triangle on the roof -- show the exuberant style to advantage: bright colors, skillful massing and always some little geometrical trademark.
In Miami Beach, the firm has built an award-winning parking garage at Sixth and Collins, with the openings between levels cleverly masked with bushes and vines that cut down on air pollution (and the visual kind as well).
Ms. Clearwater's museum, currently showing the work of the French sculptor Annette Messager, is housed in another standout local building, a simple, flexible structure by Charles Gwathmey composed of cubes and cylinders.
There is something slightly absurd about walking out of the brilliant sunlight of South Beach into the Wolfsonian collection a couple of blocks inland. Sadly, few people try to jump the cultural hurdle that divides the two; the Wolfsonian, whose name represents a longing by the donor Mitchell Wolfson Jr. to share the glory of Washington's Smithsonian, is all too often empty.
My goodness, what a mistake that is, even in the most benign weather! You begin the tour of this old warehouse with a glimpse of the scintillating frontispiece from a theater in Norristown, Pa., and continue through items selected from a collection of 70,000 pieces. Familiar names like Christopher Dresser and Josef Hoffmann and Victor Horta are represented, but so are obscure designers of ephemera like bond certificates and newspaper ads.
The Miami City Ballet performs a few blocks away, at the Jackie Gleason Theater. (The people in charge of nomenclature hereabouts seem stuck in the 1960's; Arthur Godfrey Road crosses the island a few blocks to the north.) The ballet company has been assembled and trained by Edward Villella, one of Balanchine's premier male dancers. Mr. Villella's group is crisp, powerful and utterly devoted to the master's vigorous Neo-Classical style.
Just down the street, the New World Symphony, a training orchestra that draws promising musicians from around the world, performs regularly under the baton of Michael Tilson Thomas. And across the water in Coconut Grove, one of the nation's oldest regional theaters offers the likes of Jack Klugman and Tony Randall.
So we come at the end to a special, secret place. It is called the Kampong, and it was the home for many decades of Dr. David Fairchild, the plant explorer who brought blood oranges and cashews and tung oil and durum wheat to North America. Unlike the public garden named for Fairchild, this one is private, which is its joy (no crowds) and its curse (a chronic lack of money).
The Kampong is planted with tropical fruit trees ranging from the key lime to the pomelo. On some trees, Larry Schokman, the director of horticulture, has made grafts that yield blossoms two or three times a year. He showed us one hybrid with one parent from Ghana and the other from Brazil.
Fairchild Tropical Gardens, nearby, were heavily damaged in the hurricane of 1992. But the Kampong survived almost intact, with an amazing Ficus Bengalensis at the entrance, 351 feet around, roots dangling in the air, and a long vista down to the sea, interrupted by a shimmering lagoon.
 
Wonders Await Beyond the Sand And the Surf
 
Here is information about places in Miami mentioned in the article, along with tips on where to stay and where to eat.
 
Where to Stay
 
BILTMORE HOTEL, 1200 Anastasia Avenue, Coral Gables, (305) 445-1926, is a magnificently restored 1926 landmark, with a tower patterned after the Giralda in Seville, Spain; a two-story lobby with a stunning painted ceiling; a 17,000-square-foot swimming pool, and comfortable rooms at relatively sane prices. Through Dec. 31, daily room rate, $239 for one person, $259 for two people; after Dec. 31, $259 for one person, $279 for two.
THE DELANO, 1685 Collins Avenue, at 17th Street, Miami Beach, (305) 672-2000, the hot spot on South Beach, is Ian Schrager's all-white fantasy, with a forest of unadorned columns in the lobby echoed by a forest of palms outside. Philippe Starck's bathrooms are handsome but only marginally practical. Giddy clientele. Through Dec. 21, daily room rates, based on double occupancy, $295 to $395; after Dec. 21, $315 to $415.
THE GRAND BAY HOTEL, 2669 South Bayshore Drive, Miami, (305) 858-9600, in Coconut Grove, belies the area's Bohemian origins with its acres of marble and finely finished guest rooms, all of which have terraces. Fresh flowers abound. Through Dec. 31, daily room rate, based on double occupancy, $255; suites range from $350 to $1,200; after Dec. 31, rooms are $300, suites, $350 to $1,400.
THE INTER-CONTINENTAL, 100 Chopin Plaza, Miami, (305) 577-1000. Businessmen who need a central location might choose this hotel, which overlooks Biscayne Bay. Rooms have a Latin flavor; service is willing but sometimes inept. Through Dec. 31, the daily rate for the weekend based on double occupancy is $165; after Dec. 31, the rate is $205. Midweek through Dec. 31, the daily rate ranges from $185 to $245; after Dec. 31, the rate is $225 to $265.
THE SHERATON BAL HARBOUR, 9701 Collins Avenue, Bal Harbour, (305) 865-7511, one of the better convention hotels, also suitable for families, is right on the beach, with a swimming pool incorporating a suspension bridge and waterfalls. The best shopping in South Florida is just across the street. Through Dec. 18, daily room rates, $190 to $280; after Dec. 18, $235 to $325.
 
Where to Eat
 
NORMAN'S, 21 Almeria Avenue, Coral Gables, (305) 446-6767. Norman Van Aken helped create New World cuisine, an amalgam of France, Florida and Latin America. At Norman's, Miami's best restaurant, he cooks a dozen dishes that sound hideously complicated but taste perfectly integrated, like rum-and-pepper-painted grouper with a mango and habanero chile sauce. Equally original wine list.
CHEF ALLEN'S, 19088 Northeast 29th Avenue, at 191st street, North Miami Beach, (305) 935-2900. Another of the founding fathers of the new regional style is Allen Susser, who has a way with fish (e.g., grilled swordfish with sweet potato hash) and desserts (bananas four ways). If the food at Chef Allen's is not quite as subtle as Norman Van Aken's, it's still very good.
THE BLUE DOOR, at the Delano, (305) 674-6400, is a stage for the South Beach follies, but it's a superb restaurant, too, especially when Claude Troisgros, the consultant chef, is there to cook his sauteed foie gras with star fruit and jumbo ravioli filled with taro mousseline. Scion of the three-star Troigros clan of Roanne, France, he ran C.T. in Manhattan and now lives in Rio.
PACIFIC TIME, 915 Lincoln Road, Miami Beach, (305) 534-5979. Nothing could be less likely a few blocks from the Atlantic than a restaurant called Pacific Time. But there it is, and Jonathan Eismann turns out mouth-watering Pacific Rim dishes. A few of our favorites: a starter of Korean kimchi, skate in a delicate curry-infused broth and a side of perfectly cooked baby bok choy.
JOE'S STONE CRAB, 227 Biscayne Street, Miami Beach, (305) 673-0365, has been there forever -- well, 85 years. It still serves delicious hash browns, good Key lime pie (though the chief piemaker recently died) and the world's best stone crab claws, with shells, as Damon Runyon wrote, "harder than a landlord's heart."

VIZCAYA MUSEUM AND GARDENS, 3251 South Miami Avenue, Miami, (305) 250-9133. Open daily, 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Admission, $10; $5 for children 6 to 12; free for those under 6. Decorative arts from the 16th to 19th centuries.

"Collection in Focus," a display of new acquisitions that are part of the permanent collection; "Annette Messager: Dependence Independence," an installation, and paintings and sculpture by David Rohn. All through Nov. 30. Open Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.; closed on Mondays. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly; on Tuesdays, all visitors pay what they wish.

Open Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, 11 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.; closed on Mondays. Admission, $5; $3.50 for students, the elderly and children 6 to 18 years old; free for children under 6 and on Thursdays, 6 to 9 P.M. Exhibitions: "Art and Design in the Modern Age," "Culinary Culture," "Wish You Were Here" and "Visionaries in Exile."
THE KAMPONG, 4013 Douglas Road, Coconut Grove, (305) 442-7169. Private garden. Tours on the first Sunday of every month at 2, 3 and 4 P.M.; in December, the tours will be on Dec. 14. Suggested donation, $10; $5 for students and children 5 to 16; free for children under 5. Reservations required.
FAIRCHILD TROPICAL GARDENS, 10901 Old Cutler Road, Miami, (305) 667-1651. Open daily, 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., except Christmas. Admission, including guided tram tour: $8; free for those under 13.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Why Do Americans Gorge On Gothic?

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

NIGHTMARE ON MAIN STREET
Angels, Sadomasochism and the Culture of Gothic.
By Mark Edmundson
190 pages. Harvard University Press. $22.95.
 What do the following have in common: the Academy Award-winning film "Silence of the Lambs"; slasher movies like "Nightmare on Elm Street," "Scream" and "Halloween"; the new popularity of body piercing and tattoos; the sadomasochistic photographs of Robert Mapplethorpe; the horror novels of Anne Rice and Stephen King, and lurid news stories about serial killers, child molesters and demonic possession? 
 As the scholar Mark Edmundson points out in his absorbing new book "Nightmare on Main Street," they're all contemporary manifestations of the Gothic, an esthetic that reveals "the dark side, the world of cruelty, lust, perversion and crime that, many of us at least half believe, is hidden beneath established conventions." The Gothic not only relies upon certain familiar conventions (a hero-villain, a heroine in distress, a terrible place, unrelieved fear), but also purveys a distinctive vision, a dark, pessimistic view of the world as a place in which time present is shaped by time past, and "much of life has been scripted in advance."
As a literary form, the Gothic was invented by Horace Walpole in his 1764 novel "The Castle of Otranto" and developed further by such writers as Monk Lewis, Ann Radcliffe, Mary Shelley and Edgar Allan Poe. The popularity of late 18th-century Gothic narratives, Mr. Edmundson suggests, reflected an unease with the social and cultural changes unleashed by the French Revolution; it pointed up the chaotic emotions seething beneath the Enlightenment's surface of reason and helped goad readers into a recognition of their own suppressed passions.
Why has the America of the 90's witnessed a resurgence of the Gothic? Why have tabloid stories about O. J. Simpson, John and Lorena Bobbitt, and Andrew Cunanan captivated the public imagination? Why are Goth fashions and music suddenly in vogue? Why has the "X-Files" become a hit television show? No doubt part of the appeal of the Gothic is that it provides a reassuring framework for controlling free-floating anxieties (both millennial anxieties and more everyday anxieties about crime, illness and economic security) by converting them into suspense. The Gothic thrives, Mr. Edmundson argues, in a world in which "those in authority -- the supposed exemplars of the good -- are under suspicion," a world in which cynicism ("the conviction that the worst truth that you can come up with about any person or event is the most consequential truth") is a given.
Two other reasons are advanced by Mr. Edmundson for the current ascendancy of the Gothic. The first concerns reactions to the social changes wrought by the 60's and highlights the prominent role that "transgressor blacks like O. J. Simpson and Michael Jackson" and "enraged women like Lorena Bobbitt, Tonya Harding and the purported victims of once-repressed sexual abuse" play in current Gothic scenarios. "Fin-de-siecle American Gothic is often motivated by a drive to turn back the clock," Mr. Edmundson writes, "to get the uppity women, the blacks, and the young back into their place."
The second reason cited by Mr. Edmundson concerns the decline of faith in a benevolent, active God. "There is something to gain in accepting the harsh belief that the world is infested with evil," he writes, "that all power is corrupt, all humanity debased, and that there is nothing we can do about it. With the turn to contemporary Gothic -- no-fault, dead-end, politically impotent though it may be -- we recover a horizon of ultimate meaning. We recover something of what is lost with the withdrawal of God from the day-to-day world. With the Gothic, we can tell ourselves that we live in the worst and most barbaric of times, that all is broken never to be mended, that things are bad and fated to be, that significant hope is a sorry joke, the prerogative of suckers. The Gothic, dark as it is, offers epistemological certainty; it allows us to believe that we've found the truth."
Coexisting with contemporary Gothic is what Mr. Edmundson calls a "culture of easy transcendence," exemplified by the movie "Forrest Gump." This pop transcendence is a degenerate form of Emersonian optimism, a belief that one can move on, move past, move through all traumas, that one can shrug off the shackles of the past. It is manifested in the Pollyanna-ish belief in angels, and the proliferation of self-help gurus and 12-step programs.
"Productions like 'Forrest Gump' and the angel books invert the Gothic," Mr. Edmundson writes. "But in another sense facile transcendence reinforces the culture of terror. The very insubstantiality of the easy transcendence scenarios, their status, acknowledged even by some of their consumers, as simple wish fulfillment, testifies to the absence of plausible hope for many Americans." It underscores "the despair that often underlies the current quest for self-renovation."
Given the flimsiness of the "easy transcendence" ethos, the author argues, the Gothic impulse continues to insinuate itself in the American psyche -- with disturbing effects. "Dead-end, no-fault, paranoiac: our current Gothic modes invite us to be afraid, but not, in general, to fight back," he writes. "They suggest that we're our own worst enemy and propose no cogent defense. They counsel us to despair about political change and social reform. They offer us only the satisfaction that can come from complete fatalism, from giving up."
Drawing upon his considerable knowledge of American and European literature, Mr. Edmundson, who teaches English at the University of Virginia, does a nimble job of situating the current Gothic craze in context with philosophical developments, while at the same time assessing its social consequences. The book's occasional weaknesses stem from his tendency to overcompress his arguments and his eagerness to make his thesis as wide-ranging as possible. Some of his Gothic citations are decidedly debatable (does "The Lion King" really provoke and exploit "fear of predatory adults"?), and some of his discussions of major literary movements like modernism and romanticism are reductive and glancing at best.
Such quibbles, however, are eclipsed by the cogency of Mr. Edmundson's ideas. "Nightmare on Main Street" is a provocative and often illuminating book.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A Canadian agency group hopes to persuade potential clients to take a look north of the border.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
WHEN advertisers introduce campaigns with provocative or contentious creative elements, they often say they are trying to "push the boundaries." Now an agency association is asking them to consider doing that literally.
The Institute of Canadian Advertising, a trade organization based in Toronto, is undertaking an unusual initiative to convince American marketers to consider shops north of the 49th parallel when they award accounts. The effort being sponsored by the institute, which is the Canadian equivalent of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, carries the theme -- what else? -- "Push the boundaries." 
 "Canadians are not well known for standing up and saying, 'Look at me,' " said John A. Harding, executive vice president of the institute. "But we have a story to tell."
"An advertiser in New York doesn't think twice about using an agency from Minneapolis or Portland," he added. "It's just as conceivable to look at an agency north of the border." (Or in the case of Detroit area advertisers, south of the border.)
The ambitious initiative includes print advertisements, direct and interactive marketing and a public relations campaign, all meant to generate requests for a videotape and booklet about the abilities of Canadian agencies. The effort is indicative of the growing globalization of advertising as multinational marketers increasingly look at results rather than passports.
"Where ideas come from is not as important as whether or not they work," said Andy Krupski, chairman of the institute's business development committee, who is president and chief executive at the Grey Canada unit of Grey Advertising in Toronto. "This is the first step in a continuing program to make sure the world is aware of the talent that's in Canada."
The initiative offers a lengthy list of what the institute describes as the advantages of hiring Canadian agencies, from favorable exchange rates to efficient production facilities to experience in ethnic marketing.
"Our industry has to work in two official languages by law," Mr. Krupski said, referring to English and French, "and in three or four by a market perspective. Because we have a lot of constituencies, we have to make ideas strong enough to work across cultural lines."
"And typically we do that with fewer dollars than may be afforded in the U.S.," he added, "which may make us more agile and frugal."
But persuading Americans that other countries can be capable of effective work is a challenge not unlike withstanding a Canadian winter without a warm coat.
"U.S. chauvinism" is daunting, said Stan Sutter, editor of Marketing Magazine, a weekly trade publication in Toronto, who described the initiative as "calling the bluff of all the companies that say they believe in globalization."
"If globalization is real," he asked, "why not use an agency in Toronto, Vancouver or Montreal?"
Another reason the institute is prospecting for American clients, he said, is that "since the recession of the early 1990's, it's been tough on the agency industry here." "Accounts keep going south," he added.
O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the association of American agencies, echoed that.
"A lot of companies are handling Canada out of the United States," he said, "which eventually leads to a consolidation of Canadian assignments -- handled by Canadian agencies or Canadian offices of U.S. agencies -- at U.S. agencies."
"I know the people up there quite well," he added, referring to the managers of Canadian agencies, "and they're good, smart ad people. But there are some pretty good agencies here. The ultimate test is whether the work will be as good as they can get here."
At least one advertiser has decided that a Canadian agency ought to handle an American assignment. TDL Group Ltd., a unit of Wendy's International that operates the Tim Hortons chain of Canadian doughnut and coffee shops, is using its Canadian agency, Enterprise Creative Selling, to create campaigns to introduce Hortons in American markets like Detroit and Columbus, Ohio.
"We believe our agency up here understands our business and the message we need to get across in a new market," said Patti Jameson, corporate communications director at TDL Group in Oakville, Ontario. "There is some merit in saying that opening a store in Buffalo is very similar to opening a store in Mississauga," a Toronto suburb.
But last month, Northern Telecom in Brampton, Ontario, shifted its corporate advertising account from one American agency (J. Walter Thompson San Francisco, part of WPP Group) to another (the Bozell Worldwide unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt in New York).
Indeed, Mr. Krupski said, one goal of the initiative is to remind Canadian advertisers "not to forget there's some good talent up here, too."
Several agencies in Toronto are contributing to the effort: the Harrod & Mirlin unit of True North Communications and the Saatchi & Saatchi Canada unit of Cordiant P.L.C., which worked on the print ads; Grey Interactive, which designed a World Wide Web site (http://www.ica-ad.com), and Spectrum Public Relations, part of the BBDO Canada unit of Omnicom Group.

SECTION: Section A; Page 35; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 719 words

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
Meet Yesterday's Men

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Richard Gephardt, meet William Hague. The Democratic leader in the U.S. House and the Conservative leader in Britain are pointing their countries and their parties in the same direction: backward toward economic and political disaster.
The two men are trying to undo the policies that have given their countries unparalleled prosperity. In the United States, it is the 60-year-old policy of free international trade. In Britain, it is membership in the European Union. 
 Mr. Gephardt has just had his greatest success: leading an overwhelming majority of Democrats in the House to kill President Clinton's fast-track trade legislation. A few days later Mr. Hague led the Tories in the House of Commons in futile opposition to an E.U. treaty -- opposition that, if it had succeeded, would very likely have led in time to British withdrawal from the Union.
A nostalgia for the bad old days grips both men. Or so one must conclude on examining their arguments.
At the heart of Mr. Gephardt's opposition to the trade legislation was the argument that free trade costs American jobs. But that can be true only if jobs are a zero-sum game, so that using Malaysians instead of Americans to make sneakers adds that much to U.S. unemployment. And that is not what happens.
Over the last four years, with the lowest trade barriers in its history, the United States has added more than 11 million jobs to its total employed. The U.S. unemployment figure is now the lowest in 24 years: 4.7 percent.
British unemployment stands at about 6 percent, again the lowest figure in years. Britain has benefited greatly from its membership in the European Union, not just economically but in the greater variety and sophistication of life here. But Mr. Hague and his cohorts are unapologetic Little Englanders, longing to be once more an island apart from Europe.
The Congressional Democrats and the British Conservatives are alike in another respect. Both have changed their historic positions on the issue.
It was the Democrats, starting with President Franklin Roosevelt, who led the United States away from the policy of high tariffs -- a policy that had helped to bring on the Great Depression. American business was largely protectionist then but has come to favor free trade strongly, as British industry supports full participation in the European Union.
And it was the Conservatives, under Prime Minister Edward Heath, who in 1972 finally took Britain into what was then the European Common Market. What an irony that the same party is dominated in the House of Commons today by members who seem to believe, in the old saying, that the wogs begin at Calais.
It was the Labor Party that used to have the largest share of Little Englanders. As recently as 15 years ago, Labor, then dominated by its left wing, wanted to withdraw from Europe.
Today New Labor, as Prime Minister Tony Blair christened the party, has only a minor, lingering anti-European wing. The Blair Government is still fudging its position on when or how it will join the E.U.'s great current project, a single European currency, but it has said it will join if and when the economic factors favor British participation.
Even more strikingly, the labor union movement here is strongly for Europe -- and for the common currency. The Trades Union Congress used to be so backward in its political-economic outlook that it was famously caricatured by the cartoonist David Low as a cart horse.
All this points to a great difference between the two countries: a difference in political leadership. Tony Blair, accompanied by modern union leaders, has turned the moderate political left in this country toward forward-looking policies. In the United States, Richard Gephardt's Democrats and their union allies want to stop the world and get off.
Much of the failure has to be laid to Bill Clinton. Of course an American President has far less ability to influence legislators than a prime minister does. But President Clinton has hardly tried over the years. He has run for himself, not for the Democratic Party.
And Mr. Clinton did not even try on the trade legislation until too late. He, and all of us, will pay the price if the world reads Mr. Gephardt's victory as the end of American leadership for expanding world trade.

HEADLINE: Fed Solidly for Steady Rates on Sept. 30

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Despite concerns over increased wage pressures, Federal Reserve officials voted 10 to 0 to keep interest rates unchanged at the end of the third quarter, according to minutes issued today.
The Fed also kept rates unchanged at this week's policy meeting, minutes of which will not be released until after the next meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee in December. 
 At their Sept. 30 meeting, committee members reviewed economic data that suggested brisk activity, paced by robust consumer and business spending. But "despite widespread indications of tight labor markets, increases in labor compensation had been moderate in recent months, and price inflation remained subdued," the minutes said.
Although Fed forecasters earlier told the committee they expected the economy to expand faster than expected during the second half and early 1998, they said growth would moderate to a more sustainable rate later.
As a result, the committee voted to keep the Federal funds rate unchanged at 5.5 percent. The rate is what banks charge each other for overnight loans.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Finishes Lower vs. Yen For the First Time in 10 Days

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar ended lower against the yen yesterday for the first time in 10 days on concern that the Bank of Japan might sell dollars to curb the United States currency's rise.
Against the mark, the dollar rose for a third day as the United States stock market rebounded and concern ebbed that Germany might soon raise interest rates. Klaus-Dieter Kuhbacher, a member of the Bundesbank's policy-making council, suggested that higher rates in Germany were not justified. 
The dollar's decline against the yen came after Japanese reports that the Ministry of Finance and the Bank of Japan had considered selling dollars for a week, leading some currency traders to speculate that the central bank might already have intervened.
"The market got the impression the Bank of Japan had been selling," said Dennis Pettit, manager of foreign exchange at the New York branch of the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan. "Though no one said they saw them doing it, the rumors caused some panic selling."
In late New York trading, the dollar cost 126.07 yen, down from 126.32 late Wednesday. The dollar cost 1.7243 marks, up from 1.7183. The British pound cost $1.6987, down from $1.7033.
The dollar pared most of its losses against the yen after the London-based IBCA ratings service downgraded credit ratings of three major Japanese banks and was considering doing the same for three other Japanese banks.
While the yen's weakness can benefit Japan's struggling economy by making exports less expensive, Japanese officials have in the past complained when the dollar rose quickly in a short period.
"The dollar's been on a one-way street for the last two and a half weeks," said David Ogg, manager of foreign exchange at Dresdner Bank. "This takes some volatility out of it."
The dollar is up 13 percent against the yen since touching a seven-month low of 110.65 yen June 11.
"I can't imagine that the U.S. is terribly happy about the yen weakening as much as it has," Mr. Pettit said. "They can live with it as long as it's a short-term phenomenon. The question is how long before it becomes permanent."

HEADLINE: Productivity In U.S. Surges; Fastest Pace In Five Years

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The productivity of American workers grew in the third quarter at the fastest pace in five years. The unexpectedly strong rate eased fears that labor shortages could lead to renewed inflation.
Productivity surged at an annual rate of 4.5 percent from July through September, helping to push unit labor costs down three-tenths of a percent, the Labor Department said today. 
 The growth in nonfarm productivity, which represents the output per number of hours worked, was the fastest since a 5.9 percent annual rate during the final three months of 1992. Many analysts were expecting a growth rate of 3 percent.
Mark Vitner, economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., said the steep productivity gain was "simply unheard of this late into a business expansion."
Productivity is considered the key to Americans' standard of living because greater efficiency means businesses can increase wages without raising prices as workers produce more in the same amount of time.
"Such high productivity growth implies downward pressure on inflation," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "Unit labor costs declined, which means that the recent pickup in wages should be of little concern because productivity gains will offset them."
The drop in labor costs, which typically represent two-thirds of the price of a product, was the first since the second quarter of 1994.
The department also provided further evidence that the labor market remained tight, as unemployment has fallen to levels not seen since the early 1970's. It said that first-time claims for jobless benefits fell last week by 6,000, to 310,000. It was the 10th consecutive week that claims remained below 320,000.
The third-quarter productivity report followed a 2.4 percent growth rate in the three previous months. Those performances contrasted with growth that averaged only about 1 percent a year since the early 1970's, after robust advances in excess of 3 percent annually in the 1960's. It rose just 1.3 percent last year.
The overall productivity increase was led by a 9.8 percent jump in the manufacturing sector, largest since a 12.5 percent gain in the second quarter of 1982.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "U.S. Productivity"
Index of output per hour of all people in nonfarm businesses. 1992 = 100, seasonally adjusted. Chart shows the quarterly change at annual rate from 1993 through 1997. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: Shortsighted Arab Diplomacy

 BODY:
Arab countries that favor long-term stability in the Middle East are making a sad mistake by boycotting this weekend's economic conference in Qatar and by resisting more forceful steps to keep Saddam Hussein from developing weapons of mass destruction.
Staying away from the fourth annual Middle East and North Africa economic conference at Doha, Qatar, can only hurt the stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace process. The meeting is designed to build the kind of economic links that brought reconciliation between traditional foes like France and Germany after World War II. But when countries long committed to peace, like Egypt and Morocco, and American allies like Saudi Arabia stay away, they reinforce the efforts of extremists on both sides of the Arab-Israeli divide. 
 The reluctance of many Arab countries to apply meaningful international pressure on Saddam Hussein over his escalating challenge to United Nations arms inspectors is similarly self-defeating. Most of those inspectors are now leaving Iraq, after Baghdad's expulsion yesterday of the six American members of the U.N. inspection team. But as Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait demonstrated, it is the Arab Middle East that would face the first and gravest dangers should the Iraqi dictator build any deliverable biological, chemical or nuclear weapons.
The countries shunning the Doha conference say they are expressing anger at Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and at America's refusal to condemn Mr. Netanyahu's policies toward the Palestinians. They also want to show Israel that there will be no end to its economic isolation in the region if it refuses to follow up on the Oslo peace agreements. But the Netanyahu Government cares little about economic bridges with the Middle East, preferring to cultivate trade and investment ties with Europe and East Asia.
It was the United States that pushed hardest for Arab countries to participate and is now most discouraged by their absence. Jordan, Kuwait, Oman, Tunisia, Yemen and the host, Qatar, are the only Arab countries planning to send official delegations. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright will attend, but the absence of so many of her Arab counterparts shows how readily setbacks in one area of Middle East peacemaking lead to further reversals elsewhere.
The rare gesture of hope was made by King Hussein of Jordan. Despite his rage at a bungled Israeli assassination attempt in Amman earlier this fall, he is sending a representative to Doha. Others should learn from his vision and courage.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE POLICY MAKERS;
Crisis in Asia No Big Threat, Fed Chief Says

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, teamed up with the Clinton Administration today to offer soothing comments about the turmoil in global markets, saying the problems in Asia and elsewhere should not threaten prosperity in the United States or the soundness of the nation's financial system.
While pointing out possible risks from the crisis to the United States and the rest of the world, Mr. Greenspan said the difficulties that had created such volatility in stock markets around the world could even benefit the United States by helping in a small way to suppress inflation. 
 The Federal Reserve has been increasingly concerned that the strong growth in the domestic economy at a time when unemployment has fallen to a 24-year low could lead to rising prices and thwart the long expansion. The Fed voted on Wednesday not to raise interest rates, concerned that tightening monetary policy would further destabilize markets around the world and betting that the American economy might slow sufficiently to avert any inflationary outbreak.
Mr. Greenspan's comments heartened investors somewhat today. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 86.44 points to close at 7,487.76, partly offsetting Wednesday's 157.41-point decline.
Asked during his appearance before the House Banking Committee today whether the situation in Asia significantly threatened the world economy and international financial system, Mr. Greenspan said no.
"I think we have fallen far short of something where we have serious threats," Mr. Greenspan said. "The reason it requires our attention is that we don't wish it to become something which is a far more serious threat to the system."
Mr. Greenspan's assessment was largely the same offered by Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, who appeared alongside him in fielding questions about the crisis.
Mr. Summers said the "direct and indirect impact on our economy of a prolonged period of lower growth in Southeast Asia, and the large decline in its currencies, is potentially significant."
But, Mr. Summers said in his prepared testimony, the Administration does not see "significant risk to United States financial institutions or to domestic financial stability as a whole as a result of the turbulence to date."
Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Summers said the fallout from problems in Asia could worsen if steps were not taken by the United States and international financial institutions to restore stability.
They made low-key pleas to the Republican leadership in Congress to restore $3.5 billion in additional financing for the International Monetary Fund requested by the Administration. The financing was deleted from spending bills today in the House and Senate because of a political dispute over American support for family-planning programs abroad.
Mr. Greenspan stayed closely to comments he made about the Asian turmoil before a Congressional committee two weeks ago.
He said the trouble in Asia would reduce American exports to the region and diminish profits of companies that operate there. He said there could be indirect effects on the American economy as the problems of Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea put pressure on the Japanese economy.
"To date, the direct impact of these developments on the American economy has been modest, but it can be expected not to be negligible," Mr. Greenspan said.
Questioned about whether a $160 million trading loss by the Chase Manhattan Bank in October signaled broader problems in the American banking system because of events in Asia, Mr. Greenspan said the loss posted by Chase was not particularly big.
"The losses that are involved in those trades in no way threaten in any means whatever the financial status of that institution," Mr. Greenspan said.
Before the Asian crisis is over, he added, "there will be lots of other losses recognized, but they are in nowhere near the orders of magnitude which threaten the financial system of the United States nor any of the major banking institutions in the developed world."
Mr. Summers used much of his presentation to justify American involvement in international efforts to stabilize the economies and financial markets of Asia and, increasingly, Latin America.
But the Administration's policies came under attack from liberal Democrats for supporting countries like Indonesia. They said the Administration was ignoring human rights abuses, corruption and other problems in Indonesia, and demanded that the Administration make financial aid contingent on improvement in those areas.

HEADLINE: An Ultimatum for Iraq

BYLINE: By Robert M. Gates; Robert M. Gates was Director of Central Intelligence from 1991 to 1993.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Perhaps the most important of the United Nations Security Council's decisions after the Persian Gulf war in 1991 was its resolution that Iraq's program to build weapons of mass destruction must be eliminated.
Before the war, Iraq had significant stockpiles of chemical and biological weapons, and programs to develop even more sinister weapons, including nuclear ones. As a result of the war and the subsequent intensive inspections carried out by international teams, many of these weapons have been destroyed. 
 But far from all. And now -- in part because of our own indecisiveness and inattention -- we find ourselves in a stare-down with Iraq. If this continues for more than a few days, we should address Saddam Hussein in the only language he understands: force.
Since the end of the war, the Iraqis, trying to preserve their programs for chemical, biological and nuclear weapons, have lied to United Nations inspectors and engaged in a deadly game of hide-and-seek. For diplomatic reasons, the United Nations has never fully revealed the extent of physical abuse and mistreatment of its inspectors in Iraq. Nor has it fully revealed the extraordinary deception, subterfuge, trickery and other obstructionism used by the Iraqis.
Over the years, the weapons inspectors and the Security Council have shown remarkable patience and persistence in dealing with Mr. Hussein's efforts to thwart the will of the United Nations. And the inspectors exposed and destroyed many of these fearsome weapons and the associated equipment.
Then, last month, the Iraqi dictator issued an ultimatum: if Americans were included in the inspection teams, the teams would be barred from doing their work.
When Mr. Hussein first made those threats, Kofi Annan, the Secretary General of the United Nations, sent a diplomatic mission to Baghdad to urge reconsideration. (He must have forgotten about the stream of similarly feckless missions before the 1991 war). After that mission failed, the Security Council tightened economic sanctions somewhat. But the inspectors are still blocked from doing their work -- yesterday, they began leaving Iraq -- and it seems clear that Mr. Hussein is moving or hiding his weapons or equipment. So what now?
The Clinton Administration has worked to maintain the Security Council's strong support for the sanctions as long as Mr. Hussein refuses to comply with all the resolutions, including his refusal to allow the inspections. That effort, over time, has become more challenging as Russia and France, in particular, have pursued oil and other contracts with Iraq worth billions of dollars, to take effect once the sanctions are lifted.
However, it appears that President Clinton has failed to make an effort, both personally and through senior advisers, month after month and year after year, to maintain and nurture the coalition that defeated Mr. Hussein.
Maintaining a core of support within such a fragile alliance requires constant attention. The diplomats of both the Soviet Union and France continuously tried to undermine the coalition in 1990 and 1991, and only frequent telephone calls from President George Bush to Presidents Mikhail Gorbachev and Francois Mitterrand kept them on board. At its highest levels, the Clinton Administration must remind Russia, France and others that Mr. Hussein must fully comply with the United Nations resolutions. Mr. Clinton should point out to these nations that if the desire for unilateral political and economic gain in the Middle East causes them to lose their resolve, their relations with the United States will suffer.
Further, Mr. Hussein probably has begun to question long-term American resolve as well (a question that perhaps began to form when the war ended with him still in power). In 1994, when he rushed tens of thousands of troops to the Kuwaiti border, the Administration quite laudably sent reinforcements to the region and made clear that it was ready to deal with any new aggression. However, when the Iraqi forces were pulled back, our own were quietly withdrawn, and Mr. Hussein paid no price for his bluff. This was a military opportunity missed. Similarly, when Mr. Hussein last year violated the "no-fly zone" in northern Iraq and re-established his position there, the United States threatened retaliation, but then never acted.
By this fall, Mr. Hussein presumably had concluded that fissures in the coalition and the American failure to respond forcefully to his maneuverings in the past had created an environment in which he could challenge both the United States and the United Nations Security Council over the inspections.
He must not be allowed to succeed. The minimum acceptable outcome of this confrontation must be both the new, tightened sanctions just adopted by the Security Council and a complete reversal by Iraq on weapons inspections -- allowing inspectors to proceed unhindered regardless of their nationalities. Moreover, there must be an aggressive push to find out what Mr. Hussein has been doing in the absence of the inspectors.
 Failing this, the United States -- preferably with the full support of the Security Council, but at least with whatever coalition support it can muster, or alone if necessary -- must act forcibly to remind the Iraqi military that it will pay a heavy price for Mr. Hussein's obduracy, arrogance and defiance. A few dozen missiles launched against Iraq would be an inadequate response. Mr. Hussein has easily absorbed such attacks before and then boasted to his people and his neighbors that he can take whatever the Americans dish out.
 No, the next strike should be a powerful air and missile campaign targeted on the Republican Guard divisions that sustain Mr. Hussein's regime. That campaign, focused on military targets, should continue until he relents on inspections. In addition, Iraq's generals must be reminded by our actions -- again and again, if necessary -- that their forces will pay a terrible price when Mr. Hussein takes on the United States and the United Nations. This not only would weaken the regime, but it may also eventually induce the Iraqi army to remove this man, who imposes such awful sacrifices on his own people even as he builds new palaces for himself.
Surely, we know now that force is the only thing Mr. Hussein understands. We have known since 1990 that faintheartedness disguised as reasonableness in dealing with him is an invitation to further depredations.
If Mr. Hussein fails to reverse course on inspections within a few days, the United States must act, and it must deliver a message understandable not just by him, but by his army. Insistence upon full compliance with all United Nations resolutions and enforcement of those resolutions is the only acceptable path. The alternative is a megalomaniac with weapons of mass destruction.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE AUTO MAKERS;
Brazilian Slowdown Forces Rethinking and Retrenching

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Southeast Asian auto sales have collapsed, and now the other shoe has dropped for the world's biggest auto makers.
After years of spectacular growth, the Brazilian auto market -- the largest of any emerging-market country -- is facing a severe slowdown as the Government there has doubled interest rates, raised income taxes and slashed spending to prevent Asia's currency turmoil from spreading across the Pacific. 
 The Ford Motor Company said today that it would halt production at Brazilian factories for about a week beginning Friday, and had already warned that fourth-quarter profits would be hurt by the Brazil slowdown. Volkswagen A. G. and the General Motors Corporation are also cutting production, while Fiat said today that it would take the expensive step of offering heavily discounted interest rates to lure buyers.
Auto makers remain optimistic about long-term prospects in Brazil, which has a growing middle class eager to buy cars. The Mexican peso's sharp drop in December 1994 caused lasting damage to auto sales there, but Brazil has resisted devaluation of its currency, the real. Auto analysts nonetheless said today that the problems in Brazil were likely to hurt auto maker profits in the fourth quarter and into next year.
"So far, this does not seem to be another Mexico," said Scott F. Merlis, an independent auto analyst in Westport, Conn., who expects Brazilian sales into next year to be flat to slightly down.
Had the Government not acted to protect the real, things could have been worse in the long run, auto makers and analysts agree. "Given the Government austerity plan, it seems that the odds of the Brazilian auto industry imploding have diminished, but the odds of sustained growth have also diminished," Mr. Merlis said.
Because Brazil has no domestically based auto makers, European and United States companies have the most to lose. The biggest in Brazil's auto market, Volkswagen, has said it will cut production at its two Sao Paulo factories from five days a week to three. Latin American sales account for about 15 percent of Volkswagen's profits. Fiat, Brazil's second-largest auto maker, said today that it would trim the monthly interest rates charged to car buyers from 3.8 percent to 2.79 percent, or 39 percent on an annualized basis. Car sales have plunged partly because the Brazilian central bank has doubled the cost of borrowing -- annualized base lending rates are now 46 percent. A third of Fiat's profits come from Latin America, Jack V. Kirnan, an auto analyst at Salomon Brothers, estimates.
General Motors is the third-largest auto maker in Brazil, and has only modestly trimmed production by suspending one shift of workers as of last Saturday. About 15 percent of G.M.'s profits come from Latin America, and Mr. Merlis estimated that the trouble in Brazil could reduce G.M.'s 1998 earnings by $125 million.
Andre Beer, an executive at G.M. do Brasil, said it was too early to determine the full effects of the Government's economic package. He said that if necessary the company would eliminate more shifts and take extra holidays and export more cars, using layoffs only as a last resort.
While auto makers could increase exports from Brazil to Argentina and other neighbors as long as their economies remained strong, analysts said large-scale exports from Brazil to the United States or Europe were unlikely. Many of the best-selling cars in Brazil are tailored to developing markets.
Ford is Brazil's fourth-largest auto maker. It builds two pickup trucks and two small cars there: the F-series and Courier pickups and the Fiesta and Ka cars. It ships some to Argentina, while it imports from Argentina Ranger pickups and the Escort to sell in Brazil.
Ford has been struggling in Brazil for some time. Last year, it lost $572 million in Latin America, but this year, it is expected to earn about $200 million there. The Brazilian turmoil is likely to halt that improvement, Mr. Kirnan said. Just last month, Ford signed a letter of intent with the Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul to spend up to $500 million building an additional assembly plant there.
Among American auto makers, the Chrysler Corporation has the least to lose, for now, because it ships cars and trucks from the United States, Austria and Argentina to Brazil and can sell many of them in those markets instead. Chrysler sold just 8,805 vehicles in the first 10 months of the year, and has reduced sales expectations for the year from 12,000 to 10,000, Evelyn M. Mariperisena, a spokeswoman, said.
But next year was to have been Chrysler's big year: in June, it plans to open a $350 million factory near Sao Paulo with the capacity to build 40,000 Dakota pickup trucks a year. It is building an engine factory nearby in a joint venture with BMW, with production to begin in 1999. Chrysler for now has no plans to delay the factories, Ms. Mariperisena said.
While slower sales are the biggest problem facing auto makers in Brazil, further measures were announced today that could hurt their profits. Mercosur, the South American free trade zone, announced it would increase import duties by 3 percent on most products, which would include auto parts, but not fully assembled cars and trucks.
Delphi Automotive Systems, G.M.'s parts unit, with 12 factories in Brazil building parts for Volkswagen, Fiat, Ford, and G.M., along with other auto makers, has already reduced the number of parts it builds daily and has ordered fewer days' worth of parts from its suppliers, said David G. Bodkin, a spokesman.
Because Delphi's parts have just 40 percent Brazilian content on average, the tariff increase will raise its costs, Mr. Bodkin said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE INVESTORS;
Despite Market Turmoil, Cash Keeps Pouring Into Mutual Funds

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
In a demonstration of resilience following October's stock market turmoil, mutual fund investors have continued to funnel new money this month into mutual funds that invest in the largest American stocks, analysts say.
Indeed, despite three sharp market dips this year, cash flows into all stock funds in the first 10 months of 1997 have outpaced those recorded in the corresponding period last year, which was by far the best year ever for equity mutual funds. Since January, this year's cash flows had been lagging well behind last year's record pace, but strong numbers for October pushed the total for the year so far ahead of that for the first 10 months of 1996. 
 Investors did hesitate briefly in their fervor for equity funds when stock prices plunged on Oct. 24. And since then, they have made net withdrawals from funds that invest in foreign stock markets, which have fared poorly in the face of Asian currency devaluations and questions about Latin America's economic outlook, and from some types of small-stock funds.
But two independent trackers of cash flow data say that by the end of October, investors had resumed adding to their investments in broad United States equity funds, including the index funds that have proved so popular this year.
"There certainly is a large contingency that believes the market will continue to go up," said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services, an Arcata, Calif., company that tracks weekly cash flows. In the two weeks since Oct. 29, investors added $1.7 billion to stock funds of all types.
Similarly, Trim Tabs Financial Services, of Santa Rosa, Calif., reported that cash flows to domestic stock funds have gained strength in three out of four of its twice-weekly reporting periods since Oct. 27.
The Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group, reported yesterday that fund investors added an estimated $21 billion to stock funds last month, down from $25.8 billion in September but up from $13.5 billion in October 1996. That brings the total this year to $198 billion, exceeding the $192 billion that stock funds received in the first 10 months of 1996, on their way to a record 12-month total of $221 billion.
For nearly three years, as record amounts of money have flowed into stock funds, analysts have wondered how fund shareholders would react if the stock market suffered a decline measuring more than 10 percent of the Dow Jones industrial average -- an event that had not occurred since the fall of 1990.
At its closing price on Oct. 27, the day that the Dow industrials fell 554 points, the bellwether index was more than 13 percent below its recent high. But investors held firm, contributing to the market's recovery despite continued market declines overseas. At yesterday's closing price of 7,487.76, the Dow industrials had moved back to within 10 percent of the record close, 8,259.31 on Aug. 7.
Stock prices have now gone through three sharp downdrafts this year, but in each case mutual fund investors have proved less likely to dramatically slow their new investments than they were in a similar period last year.
In July 1996, for example, when the Dow industrials swooned by nearly 7 percent in a week's time, cash flows into stock funds fell by more than 60 percent from the previous month's level.
This year, however, when stock prices dipped in March, August and, most recently, October, the amount of cash flowing into stock funds fell by much smaller amounts, measuring from 18 percent to 47 percent.
Last month's strong cash flows appear even more remarkable in light of recent big declines in overseas stock markets. According to both AMG and Trim Tabs, investors steadily withdrew money from international stock funds in October and so far this month.
The October cash flows reported by the trade group imply that much of that money was shifted into domestic stock funds, which would help to explain some of the resilience in American stocks since last month. Money flowing out of international stock funds could have given portfolio managers extra ability to buy domestic stocks at bargain prices in late October, despite the fact that fund managers had the lowest level of cash in their portfolios in nearly 21 years.
At the end of September, the average domestic equity fund had 5.1 percent of its assets in cash. Not since December 1976 had the level been lower, according to the trade group.
Final details on the Investment Company Institute's cash flow report, including a breakdown of the flows between domestic and international stock funds, will be released near the end of the month.
Much of the week-in, week-out strength in stock fund cash flows stems from participants in retirement programs, who typically have a certain amount of money automatically deducted from their paychecks each week, Mr. Adler said.
Therefore, the weekly and monthly cash flows "don't necessarily reflect short-term confidence," he said. "In those cases, investors have not made any decision except to continue to invest for the long term."
Retirement plans account for a growing portion of mutual fund assets, which this year topped $4 billion. At the end of 1996, retirement plans held 35 percent of all mutual fund assets, the Investment Company Institute reported recently.
Those assets are split about evenly between individual retirement accounts and employer-sponsored retirement plans, such as 401(k) and 403(b) plans. Although contributions to individual retirement accounts fell after the 1986 overhaul of the Tax Code, the accounts have continued to grow as employees moving from one company to another roll over assets from company-sponsored plans into the individual accounts.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Yanks Need To Be Patient On Williams

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
THIS notion that the Yankees must trade Bernie Williams if they do not sign him to a long-term contract within several weeks is patently absurd, nothing more than a line of organizational propaganda as George Steinbrenner tries to pressure Williams into surrendering the leverage he has waited years to have.
The manipulative and flawed thinking goes like this: If Williams does not soon break and agree to their five-year, $37.5 million offer or perhaps a better one yet to come, the Yankees would be crazy to allow him back under another one-year deal. They could not take the risk of his leaving as a free agent next winter and getting nothing in return for their best all-round player. 
 Silly Question: Then where would they be?
Obvious Answer: Where they typically are, perusing the aisles of baseball's 24-hour talent supermarket.
If there is one thing an owner like Steinbrenner does not have to worry about, it is winding up where the Rangers did, unable to fill the hole in their offense after Mark Messier walked out on them. No restricted free agency and no shortage of teams desperate to unload high-priced talent add up to a crazy buyer's market for baseball's aristocrats.
The game's best starting pitcher, Pedro Martinez, will be changing teams in about 20 minutes because the Montreal Expos, who have surrendered a future Hall of Fame wing in recent years, simply can't afford him. Florida's World Series hitting star, Moises Alou, barely made it out of the Game 7 parking lot before his $5 million salary was dumped on Houston for two pitchers named X and Y. Just add Martinez and Alou to the growing list of transient stars in a sport where Mark McGwire could make a run at a 36-year-old home run record last summer then be pointed in the easterly direction of his previous blast.
McGwire. Larry Walker. David Justice. Albert Belle. Kenny Lofton. John Wetteland. Tino Martinez. Roger Clemens. Given the way marquee players and ordinary players have been changing teams, baseball should consider its own Home Shopping Network, as a replacement for those microscopically rated games of the week.
Hero today, gone tomorrow. Alou will be followed out of Miami by more multimillionaire Marlins, as the champs go on the cheap after payroll inflation brought them 15 minutes of fame, albeit at 12:30 in the morning. Florida is now baseball's poster franchise, its leading example of volatility, of how too many teams operate with a vision that is barely past their nose. Yesterday, the Marlins were the toast of culturally rich South Florida, and many points south. Today, they are toast.
I made this point to Williams's agent, Scott Boras, the other day, suggesting that his client should consider the possibility of landing with a team that would pay him more but whose field of dreams could, like Florida's, instantly turn to mud. Boras laughed -- a bit too derisively, I thought -- and asked: "Who creates a more volatile working environment than George Steinbrenner?"
On a day-to-day basis, that is true. But few owners in sports are as consistently competitive year to year, and that counts heavily, the way baseball's business is going. Steinbrenner's deep pockets and his insatiable appetite for success and the attention it brings will always keep Williams, a quiet star, protected in the lineup and the clubhouse.
It is not my business to tell the Yankees what they should offer Williams any more than it is to tell Williams what to take. But Boras insisted that Williams -- not pleased at how Steinbrenner has low-balled him in the past while spending freely on other team's free agents -- will roll the dice under another one-year deal and give Steinbrenner another chance next winter.
"We know what the market will be for him," Boras said. "And we just need one team."
Williams could get hurt, or have a lousy year. If he is willing to take those risks, why shouldn't the Yankees? Why should they dump a 29-year-old center fielder who has been a career-long Yankee, a Puerto Rican star in heavily Hispanic New York, without playing this out to the bottom of the ninth? No one is going to just hand the Yankees equal value to rent Williams for a year. If they should lose him next year, believe me, able-bodied replacements will suddenly become available. Poor teams will continue to regretfully jettison their stars. Steinbrenner will always have more money than they have. He can afford to wait this Williams thing out, and should.
The way baseball is going, Ken Griffey Jr. will be on that 24-hour supermarket shelf before long.

HEADLINE: Paybacks for Riders Sought As Transit Surplus Increases

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
The cash surplus at New York City Transit grew by an additional $19 million during September as riders continued to flock to buses and subways, according to figures to be officially released next week.
The new flood of money brought the surplus for the first three quarters of 1997 to $129 million and brought renewed calls from rider advocates for the transit agency to give the money back to riders in the form of fare cuts or increased service, lest it be snapped up by the city or the state. 
 When the agency, then known as the Transit Authority, ran up a $113 million surplus in 1994, the advocates have said, the city essentially claimed the money for itself by cutting its subsidies for student subway passes by that amount, leaving the authority to make up the difference.
But as they have for two months, officials at New York City Transit's parent agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, declined yesterday to outline their plans, if any, for the extra money.
"We are pleased with the numbers and continue to monitor the situation," said Tom Kelly, a spokesman for the M.T.A. He said officials might say more on Monday when the numbers are released at the transit agency's monthly committee meeting.
According to the figures released Wednesday by the Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, an independent watchdog group within the agency, revenue from bus and subway riders exceeded expectations even more in September than in the previous two months, when the increases were so steep that officials said they were puzzled by them.
Bus revenue was 14 percent more than expected in September; subway revenue, up more than 6 percent. At the same time, revenue from the taxes that subsidize mass transit ran almost 10 percent ahead of schedule, a dividend of the city's continuing economic boom.
The surplus is a product of many factors, several of them tied to the big jump in ridership that followed the introduction of free bus-to-subway transfers in July. Transit officials had predicted that revenue would fall as more two-fare riders took advantage of the free transfers, and they drew up their budget accordingly.
What has happened instead is that the existence of the transfers has apparently attracted riders to the system who had avoided it altogether before, and thus revenue has increased, though not nearly as dramatically as ridership.
When a surplus was first revealed last month, transit officials played down its significance, saying that a few months of increased ridership were not a basis for making plans and warning that the gains could disappear overnight.
But with three months left in the agency's fiscal year and New York City Transit's cash flow only growing healthier, rider advocates expressed impatience.
"The M.T.A. can deny for only so long that it's sitting on a pile of cash," said Joseph G. Rappaport, the staff coordinator of the Straphangers Campaign. The group, along with the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, has called on the M.T.A. to offer riders 12 fares for the price of 10, rather than the 11-for-10 deal the authority plans to begin offering in January.
Alan H. Foster, the citizens advisory committee's associate director, said that the money could also be saved to go toward future debt payments.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE STREET;
Calmer Trading Overseas Helps Bolster U.S. Stocks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks ended higher yesterday, bolstered in part by calmer markets overseas and by expectations that economic slowdowns in Asia and Latin America would keep United States interest rates low.
Such expectations overcame, at least for a day, concerns on how the overseas turmoil will hurt profits of American companies. Investors confidence was heightened in part by comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. He told the House Banking Committee that the problems in Asia and other regions would not threaten prosperity in the United States and could even help hold down inflation. 
 The turmoil in Asia and Latin America "ultimately will be beneficial to the U.S. economy, our stock market and also our bond market," said Robert Bloom, chief investment officer at the Friends Vilas-Fischer Trust Company in New York, which manages $2.4 billion.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 86.44, or 1.2 percent, to 7,487.76. The Dow began the day with an 87-point gain, tumbled to a 51-point loss and bounced back up again in a furious rally late in the session.
Other market indexes were higher. The Nasdaq composite index rose 16.02 points, or 1 percent, to 1,557.74, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 10.70, or 1.2 percent, to 916.66.
United States stocks were also helped by gains in Hong Kong and Brazilian stocks. The Hang Seng index of 33 stocks, the Hong Kong market's main stock index, rose 112.87 points, or 1.17 percent, at 9,720.78. Brazil's 51-share Bovespa index, which fell 10.2 percent on Wednesday, closed up 250.02 points, or 3.20 percent, at 8,07203 yesterday.
"There's a seesaw going on here," said Andrew M. Brooks, vice president in charge of equity trading at T. Rowe Price Associates. "The Asian situation continues to be troublesome and of concern, and we're struggling to find some direction."
In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 leading issues recovered from sharp losses to end down just 6.9 points yesterday.
Early today, however, Japanese stocks were lower. At the midday recess in trading, the Nikkei was down 206.29 points, or 1.34 percent, at 15,220.98.
Among individual issues, AT&T rose 2, to 48 3/4, for the biggest percentage rise in the Dow industrials, The Sprint Corporation rose 3 1/4, to 57 1/2, and the BellSouth Corporation gained 11/16, to 49 5/8. Worldcom Inc.'s acquisition of the MCI Communications Corporation puts pressure on big telephone companies to merge or form alliances, analysts say.
Computer-related shares, which plunged on Wednesday on concern that Southeast Asia's financial woes would hurt their profits, rebounded yesterday. Texas Instruments Inc. rose 3 3/4, to 97 1/2, after losing 12 1/2 points yesterday. The Dell Computer Corporation rose 5 1/16, to 77 1/16.
Auto and chemical shares sank. General Motors fell 9/16, to 62 1/4, and The DuPont Company lost 2, to 57.
Oil service stocks fell on concerns that sales cannot increase because drilling rigs are booked solid and that price increases could delay some drilling by oil companies in the future, analysts said. "That's worrisome in the environment of very robust valuations," said Byron Dunn, an analyst with SBC Warburg Dillon Read Inc.
The Cooper Cameron Corporation lost 3 5/8, to 70; Tidewater Inc. fell 3 3/8, to 62, and the Halliburton Company fell 2 13/16, to 53 1/2.

HEADLINE: South African Tycoons Apologize for Gaining From Apartheid

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 13

 BODY:
For the last three days, South Africa has been treated to a remarkable sight: the chief executives of the nation's biggest corporations and banks lining up to apologize for their actions over the last century.
The venue is the Truth and Reconciliation Commission's hearings into the ways business supported apartheid or violated human rights during the era of white rule. Since the Commission's attention is usually focused on grieving families and police torturers, the parade of men in sober but beautifully cut suits was unusual. Also unusually, their submissions were meticulously prepared, and not one witness wept. 
 Mining executives admitted that exploiting racial and tribal divisions helped cut labor costs. Afrikaner executives admitted that close association with government officials won them contracts. However, all concluded that the economy would have been far stronger if apartheid had never existed because it brought the world's wrath down on them.
Not everyone said "sorry." Some sounded more sincere, some less, and there was some cattiness in the halls as captains of industry quietly graded each others' performances. In general, one mining executive observed, the new bosses of Government-controlled institutions like the Land and Agricultural Bank and the Eskom electric utility offered the most heartfelt apologies, for acts by long-gone predecessors.
No unsolved murders were elucidated, but the executives were specific in detailing some things they regretted. Sanlam, an insurance conglomerate, expressed sorrow that the killing of Steven Biko took place in a building it rented to the police. Anglo-American, the huge conglomerate founded on gold mining, expressed regret that it never built family housing for more than 1 percent of its black miners. However, executives were careful to place it in context: Anglo-American had wanted to build family housing for 10 percent, but was forbidden to do so by the Government.
That plea for understanding was characteristic of the tone of the hearings. For years, many executives in the liberal English-dominated business community took the line that apartheid was evil, but they were powerless to stop it. Labor and anti-apartheid activists retorted that if corporations were brave enough to quit paying taxes, apartheid would crumble.
Very few executives openly opposed apartheid until the mid-1980's, when sanctions began crippling the economy. Meanwhile, many companies helped the Government evade trade sanctions, thwart the oil embargo and the United Nations arms embargo so effectively that the country built a powerful arms industry and even nuclear weapons.
The hearings, intended to show that apartheid was as much business as politics, began with Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu, the chairman, saying he was disappointed at some "glaring absences." White labor unions, white farming and wine-making cooperatives and the oil companies had offered no submissions.
Today, Cedric Savage, chief executive of Tongaat-Hulett, a sugar company employing 20,000 South Africans, handled sharp questions about his company's relations with the security police, its handling of the killing of an anti-apartheid activist on its property and whether it amassed its vast plantations legally.
"You feel as if you're on the rack," he said afterward, adding that he believed in what the commission was doing. "You're defensive, but you're not wanting to be."
