HEADLINE: Gains for Treasury Bonds Are Pared by Stock Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices overcame early weakness yesterday, only to fall victim again to a rally in stocks.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond ended unchanged at 100 13/32, leaving its yield at 6.10 percent. 
 Support for bonds came from a Government report that showed third-quarter productivity was larger than expected and from comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.
In testimony before the House Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan indicated that the Southeast Asian financial turmoil would dampen export growth in the United States, muting inflationary pressures.
"The forces that have emerged out of the Southeast Asian difficulties are imparting a disinflationary effect on the United States and others," Mr. Greenspan said.
Analysts said that Mr. Greenspan's comments gave some market participants hope that the Fed would not raise rates in the months to come.
On Wednesday, the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy making panel, as expected, left short-term interest rates unchanged. While recent strong economic reports have revived concerns that the Fed would soon raise rates, the turmoil in Asia appears to have stayed the Fed's hand.
"The fact that the Fed did not tighten the Federal funds rate at yesterday's F.O.M.C. meeting despite surprisingly strong recent domestic economic data indicates that the Fed really views the potential ultimate U.S. consequences of the Asian financial crisis as possibly serious," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc.
But he added, "Looking ahead, we still do not expect the Fed to tighten at its final 1997 F.O.M.C. meeting."
Treasury securities also received a lift after the Government reported that nonfarm productivity rose 4.5 percent in the third quarter, exceeding expectation and posting the largest gain since the fourth quarter of 1992.
Many economists have pointed to productivity gains as the reason inflationary pressure remains contained despite robust growth.
Yesterday's productivity report was "a big positive for the inflation outlook despite the effects of a tighter labor market," said Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities.
Mr. Harris of Paine Webber noted that strong productivity gains also effectively raised the Fed's speed limit for noninflationary growth.
Traders said the Fed was in the market yesterday for the second time this week as a buyer of coupons with maturities ranging from Nov. 15, 1999, to Oct. 31, 2002, even though there had been expectations of what is generally referred to as a "coupon pass."
"Despite constructive comments from Mr. Greenspan," said David Ader, regional director at Technical Data in Boston, "a coupon pass and an amazingly constructive production report, the bond market could not lose its fascination with equities."
Bond prices fell in the afternoon as stocks climbed. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day up 86.44 points, or 1.17 percent.
Today, the bond market turns its attention to reports on October retail sales and producer prices.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Co-op in Unusual Site Pushes Plan Toward Goal

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
Like a sentinel, the 42-story Citylights building looms over Long Island City's scattering of stooped row houses and aluminum-sided homes with their chain-link-fenced backyards, dwarfing even the smokestacks of abandoned factories and the steeple of St. Mary's Church just to the east.
The residential tower -- with its three hues of brick, terraces and gently arched roof -- seems plucked from Manhattan's affluent precincts and plunked among the auto body shops, loading docks and weeded-over train tracks along spits of land and inlets that etch the Queens shore of the East River. 
 Eighteen months ago, there was only a hole in the ground.
But since January, 10,000 potential buyers have made inquiries about a building that even its sponsors saw as unusually situated, and 6,000 have filled out financial questionnaires.
"Sales have been brisk," said Fred Harris, vice president of the Trotwood Corporation, a Mellon Bank subsidiary that, along with real estate stalwarts like Worldwide Holdings, William Zeckendorf Jr. and James Wolfenson, has developed Citylights.
What government planners envisioned in the early 1980's was a Battery Park-like development called Queens West. Sixteen sites along a mile of waterfront were designated for residential buildings, with 20 of the 78 acres set aside for green space and an esplanade. Only now, with construction of Citylights, has that grand plan begun coming to fruition.
So, to the west through the wide windows of the 521-unit co-op, the saw-toothed skyline of Manhattan glitters on the far side of the river, and to the north, cables draped like a Victorian-era necklace swoop toward ornate finials atop the Queensboro Bridge.
"Seems like a superb place to grow a residential community," said Herbert Sturz, president of the Trotwood Corporation.
Queens West is a partnership involving the Port Authority, the New York City Economic Development Corporation and the Empire State Development Corporation, with the goal of transforming what Mr. Sturz called the "pioneering site" that is Long Island City.
Along with a novel financing plan that allows some "pioneers" to buy apartments for less than $25,000, it was that opulent view, wrested from an essentially industrial neighborhood, that developers of Citylights hoped would bring in buyers.
Contracts have been signed for 228 of the 521 apartments, and about 100 are already occupied. "We expect to sell out by June," Mr. Sturz said.
With more than 6,000 applications filed, a lottery was held to handle the first 4,000, those received by March 1. But it was not a pure lottery, because the sponsors committed to set aside 70 units for households with incomes below $57,000 a year.
"We've attracted waiters and waitresses, architects and court clerks, teachers and some very wealthy people," Mr. Sturz said. The remaining 2,000 applications will be handled on a first-come, first-served basis.
The application process has not always been smooth.
"My patience was tested through a number of unnecessary delays; you really need to be persistent," says one message on a web site devoted to the Queens West development: www.licweb.com/qwbbs.
"They don't answer their voice mail," said Martin Hollander, a Suffolk County resident who would like to buy a one-bedroom apartment. "I'm disquieted by their clumsy handling of the applications. The problem is people like to make plans."
The problem, Mr. Harris said, is a deluge of people hungry for a good deal.
Prices at Citylights have been kept considerably lower than market rates in affluent sections of the city through an unusual financing structure.
Normally, a buyer makes a down payment of about 20 percent and obtains a personal share loan (the co-op equivalent of a mortgage) to pay off the rest of the purchase price. Then, a part of the shareholder's monthly maintenance charge is used to pay off the so-called underlying mortgage obtained by the developer to finance the entire building. But the developers of Citylights have, in effect, reversed the process, making it possible to keep the purchase price low while increasing that part of the maintenance used to pay down the underlying mortgage.
The $85.6 million mortgage for Citylights has been financed by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Housing Investment Trust, with the mortgage insured by the Federal Housing Administration, permitting the trust to charge only 7.75 percent interest a year.
So, rather than charging market-rate prices for the units and using the money from sales to pay off the underlying mortgage, the developers have set purchase prices low and charged higher than normal maintenance fees to help pay off the mortgage.
The relatively low mortgage rate and the low sales prices have allowed many families who have insufficient funds to qualify for an individual apartment loan and even, in some cases, to pay the entire purchase price without obtaining a loan. Because a higher proportion of the maintenance pays the interest on the underlying mortgage, a higher proportion of the maintenance is tax-deductible, keeping the after-tax cost lower than in a comparable building.
Now, a new pricing schedule is about to be submitted to the State Attorney General's office. Under the plan, 154 of the 521 apartments will be priced at or below $30,000, with the lowest price -- for a third-floor studio on the building's north side -- set at $10,994 and a maintenance charge of $540. The most expensive apartment in the building will sell for $225,000, with a maintenance of $2,730.
More typically, a one-bedroom apartment on a lower floor with a dining room that could be converted to a small bedroom will cost $25,250 with a maintenance charge of $1,250. That apartment's share of the underlying mortgage, payments for which are included in the monthly maintenance, is estimated at $133,000. And a similar one-bedroom unit on the 39th floor, would be $69,000 with maintenance of $1,760.
Lori Sanford-Ross, a refugee assistance agency manager, and her husband, Sid Ross, a playwright, paid $38,500 for a two-bedroom overlooking the river and moved in two months ago.
"It's true there's no great produce store around here, no butcher shop, but it's becoming more like a neighborhood," Ms. Sanford-Ross said.

HEADLINE: In Slap at U.S., Israel Reduces Role at Talks

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 13

 BODY:
With growing numbers of Arab countries staying away from the Middle East economic conference in Doha, Qatar, to protest against Israel's policies, Israel announced today that Foreign Minister David Levy would not attend.
The announcement said that the Industry and Trade Minister, Natan Sharansky, would lead the Israeli delegation instead. 
 The announcement dealt a final blow to American efforts to keep the three-day regional conference at a respectable diplomatic level. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is scheduled to attend part of the conference, and she had made direct appeals to Israel and to moderate Arab countries to take part.
But the announcement by Egypt that it would stay away from Doha -- along with Morocco and Saudi Arabia, among Arab countries friendly to Washington -- dealt a serious blow to the conference and prompted Mr. Levy to cancel. The Israelis were reported to be further concerned that the Emir of Qatar, Sheik Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, , would not receive Mr. Levy, while Shimon Peres, former Prime Minister under the Labor Party, and a guest at Doha, was certain of a warm reception.
In announcing his decision to pull Egypt out, President Hosni Mubarak accused the Israeli Government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of undermining peace efforts with the Palestinians by continuing with the expansion of settlements and by failing to honor commitments under the Oslo agreements. "All contacts, meetings, conferences, shuttle missions and all international efforts have failed to achieve progress as the Israeli Government never keeps its promises," he said. The process was at a "dead end," he declared.
Other Arab officials said the boycott was also aimed at the United States, which is blamed by many Arabs for failing to put pressure on Israel to honor obligations undertaken under American sponsorship.
So far, the Palestinian Authority of Yasir Arafat has not announced its intentions. In fact, only four Arab states in addition to Qatar have confirmed they will participate this year -- Jordan, Kuwait, Oman and Yemen. Syria and Lebanon have boycotted all the annual conferences, while Libya and Iraq have not been invited.
The first two Middle East and North Africa conferences, in Casablanca in 1994 and Amman in 1995, drew large numbers of participants and were held in an air of high optimism. Both Yitzhak Rabin and Mr. Peres -- who were Prime Minister and Foreign Minister at the time -- attended. At last year's conference in Cairo, the mood was considerably more dour, but Mr. Levy did attend.
In an interview with an Israeli newspaper published today, and again in comments in Gaza today, Mr. Arafat declared that even if no agreement is reached with Israel by the end of the century, he would proclaim a Palestinian state. The Oslo agreements set a five-year timetable for a final settlement between Israel and the Palestinians, which was to be reached by the end of 1999.
"They had better listen well," Mr. Arafat told the tabloid Yediot Ahronot. "We will declare the establishment of an independent and sovereign Palestinian state before the end of the century. That is our right and our duty to our people who have made so many great sacrifices so as to be a free people in its land -- in the land of its forefathers."
"We will declare the establishment of a state whether Netanyahu wants it or not. That will happen at the conclusion of the five years of the interim agreement according to the Oslo Accords, in other words, after September 1999. Even if part of the state remains under occupation and contains settlements. This mission cannot be stopped by any force in the world. It is our sacred right."

No Snub Intended; Just a Delay
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who was omitted from President Clinton's schedule for next week, will instead be invited to meet with Mr. Clinton in early December, a White House spokeswoman said today.
"We don't have a precise day, but we're closing in on one," said the spokeswoman, Anne Luzzato.
In what was characterized by some as a snub, White House officials said earlier this week that Mr. Clinton's schedule could not accommodate Mr. Netanyahu next week, when he will be in the United States on a speaking tour. Mr. Netanyahu, not due to return until February, will make a special trip to Washington early next month, an Israeli diplomat said.
Ms. Luzzato denied any slight to the Prime Minister, saying his meeting had "always been a matter of 'when, not if;' now we have the 'when.' "

HEADLINE: Iraqi Action Halts Effort To Curb Arms

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Iraq's expulsion of six American weapons inspectors today brought an effective halt to an effort that has been at the center of the United Nations mission in Iraq for nearly seven years. Richard Butler, the head of the United Nations team charged with ferreting out Iraqi efforts to acquire weapons of mass destruction, said that only a skeleton staff would be left in place after all United Nations inspectors are withdrawn Friday.
Iraq's decision to make good on its threat to expel the Americans was announced in an afternoon television broadcast that included wartime footage of flames, blood and human suffering in an effort demonstrate the Baghdad Government's resolve. 
 The order covered all of the American inspectors in Iraq as part of a United Nations team, and it declared that they would not be permitted to return "until the American Administration and the Security Council decide to review their irresponsible policy and their dealing with Iraq," according to the Iraqi broadcast.
Mr. Butler tried to persuade Iraqi officials to permit the Americans to postpone their departure until Friday morning, so that they might join the 78 other inspectors who are being withdrawn aboard a United Nations flight to Bahrain. But Iraqi officials refused that request, insisting that the Americans travel overland and depart by day's end.
The Iraqi News Agency reported that the Americans left Baghdad shortly before 11 P.M., local time, and television pictures showed their convoy of Toyota Land Cruisers heading toward the divided highway that crosses the rugged desert to Amman, at least 12 hours away.
As it has since it first declared its intent to expel the American inspectors on Oct. 29, Iraq proclaimed its willingness today to cooperate with United Nations inspectors from every country other than the United States.
But the United Nations has repeatedly refused to accept such conditions.
Iraq has grown increasingly frustrated in recent months at its failure to win an easing of the crippling economic sanctions maintained by the United Nations -- and insisted upon by the United States -- since its forces invaded Kuwait in 1990. It has accused American inspectors of acting as instruments of an effort by the United States to maintain those sanctions in perpetuity.
Those charges have been angrily rejected both in Washington and by the United Nations.
Over the last week, the Iraqi Government had suspended the expulsion of Americans while there seemed to be some chance that the United Nations might agree to scale back their role. But after it became clear that the possibility did not exist, Iraq ratcheted the confrontation to a new level of crisis.
Mr. Butler said in New York that all but nine of the remaining weapons inspectors in Iraq would leave on the flight to Bahrain on Friday morning. He said that the team to be left behind would be too small to maintain an effective regime of monitoring and inspecting Iraq's weapons facilities. That effort is intended to insure that Iraq carries out obligations imposed by the Security Council after the Persian Gulf war.
These include the destruction of nuclear, chemical, biological, and conventional weapons or their components and allowing the United Nations to monitor important sites to insure that Iraq does not resume its weapons-building efforts. As American officials including President Clinton have pointed out in recent days, the team's work has led to the destruction of more Iraqi weapons than were destroyed by weeks of relentless American and allied bombardment during the 1991 war.
But the United Nations team has not carried out any inspections since Oct. 29, when Iraq first blocked American inspectors from those operations and the United Nations declared that it would not proceed without them. The inspectors are expected to remain in Bahrain, a staging area for the United Nations operations in Iraq, for some time.
Most of the 105 weapons inspectors and logisticians in Iraq packed their bags two weeks ago in preparation for a swift departure, a United Nations official in Baghdad said by telephone tonight. But the official described a scene of hurry and some tension as the Americans and others made ready to leave today.
In the last week, the number of organized demonstrations in Baghdad has increased sharply, with several taking place outside the United Nations headquarters there, where hundreds of young men have gathered almost daily to shout their disapproval of the United States and the United Nations. Even after the departure of the inspectors, some 400 other United Nations personnel will remain in Baghdad, and a spokesman there, Eric Falt, said today that the security situation could be best described as "calm but generally tense."
Iraqi officials have said they are prepared to bear the consequences of defying the United Nations, and in recent days they have opened presidential palaces to hundreds of ordinary citizens, who have taken up places there as a deterrent to possible American bomb or missile strikes.
Diplomats in Baghdad say that at the same time, long lines have begun to appear at gas stations and some stores, an apparent sign of apprehension at the prospect of military action.
Since the United Nations began its bid several years ago to oversee the destruction of Iraqi weapons, it has weathered dozens of confrontations between its personnel and Iraqi officials who have barred them from key sites, often for days at a time.
The United States has taken significant military action against Iraq three times since the Gulf war, but none of those confrontations was over the issue of access for arms inspectors. The strikes -- two in 1993, and one last year -- were in response to other Iraqi violations of United Nations rules and to Iraq's alleged role in ordering an assassination attempt against former President Bush in Kuwait.
In seeking to play down the significance of Iraq's expulsion order, Tariq Aziz, the Deputy Prime Minister, told reporters in New York that the United Nations inspection team "could fully perform its duties" with inspectors of its choosing -- "except the Americans."
Mr. Aziz said that Iraq was determined only to force an end to the dominant role played by Americans on the inspection team "so that it becomes a real and genuine international organ, not an American-led organ." He said that Mr. Butler alone should be considered responsible for the loss of inspections that would result from his decision to withdraw inspectors of other nationalities.

HEADLINE: Honda, Beating Out G.M., Plans to Build Cars in China

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Beating out a competing bid by the General Motors Corporation, the Honda Motor Company announced today that it had won the right to manufacture passenger cars at a plant in southern China.
Honda executives said the venture, their first auto assembly operation in China's perplexing car market, would involve a $200 million investment with two local partners to produce a model resembling the Honda Accord. Honda will take a 50 percent stake. 
 Yet Honda is essentially betting it can succeed where the French auto maker PSA Peugeot Citroen failed. Honda plans to use the same plant in Guangzhou that Peugeot vacated early this year, frustrated by low output, rising debt and squabbles with its local partner.
Honda executives, like their counterparts at other auto makers, expressed faith that the long-term potential in China's passenger car market was worth the considerable near-term difficulties, like bureaucratic interference, inadequate sourcing and an insular distribution network.
"We believe the Chinese market has the potential for further expansion in the future," Yoshihide Munekuni, Honda's chairman, told a news conference in Tokyo. "We will study the possibility of exports from the Chinese plant in the future."
General Motors expressed disappointment, but said it would not affect a larger commitment to G.M.'s $1.5 billion plant now under construction in Shanghai, where it plans to produce Buicks in 18 months.
"We regret that it was not possible for Opel/G.M. to reach agreement with the authorities in Guangzhou," G.M. said. "We believe our proposal, which provided a substantial investment in Guangzhou, would have been a viable business opportunity for all parties concerned."
Honda's local partners are the Guangzhou Auto Group Corporation, which Peugeot executives blamed for making their venture more trouble than it was worth, and the Dongfeng Motor Corporation, already a partner with Honda at a plant that produces engine and suspension components for export to other Honda plants in Asia.
The new Honda venture plans to start modestly, calling for just 30,000 vehicles a year. The first cars will be assembled in late 1999, Honda said.
The new venture will also give Honda its first automobile sales channel in the Chinese market, Mr. Munekuni said in Tokyo, where the No. 3 Japanese auto maker's plans were announced together with an upbeat earnings report timed to coincide with a visit to Japan by China's Prime Minister, Li Peng. Honda said earnings rose 33 percent in the six months ended Sept. 30, powered by strong exports to the United States and Europe.
Mr. Munekuni promised that the new venture would not assume Guangzhou Auto's existing debt, though its size was not disclosed.
"Debts of Guangzhou Peugeot Automobile will be settled by the Guangzhou government," he said.
The first step in a long series of approvals that Honda must win, the Honda chairman added, is to apply to the central Government for permission to start a feasibility study on the venture. Formal approval of the venture will follow at a later date, barring insurmountable obstacles.
Guangzhou Auto hopes to become one of a handful of auto-making conglomerates that emerge in China in the coming decade. Officials in Beijing have said they hope to consolidate the nation's 123 auto assembly plants into a dozen companies as part of an overall plan to make the nation's cumbersome state-run industry more efficient.
Though its potential is tantalizingly large, China's auto market is still relatively small. Passenger cars account for only about a quarter of the 1.5 million vehicles assembled here, which are mostly trucks and vans.
One perennially touchy issue in China's car manufacturing is the amount of local content in autos made by international car makers. Honda said 40 percent of the China-made Accords would be made with local components in the first year, though that number is expected to rise in subsequent years.
Required to work with a local partner, international auto makers have rarely been able to profit in China. The outlook for car makers has grown hazier in recent months, as car sales have dropped, and the recent economic downturn in Southeast Asia is not expected to help.
By contrast, Honda's most lucrative markets are in the West, which was reflected in the six-month earnings report the company released today. Helped by the diminished value of the yen, Honda's exports almost doubled to meet strong demand in Europe and the United States. Honda vehicle sales rose 16 percent in the United States, to about half a million. A popular seller was the CR-V sport utility vehicle, which Honda began selling in the United States in February. European buyers snapped up CR-V's and Civics.
The export markets compensated for weak sales in Japan. Like Japan's other car manufacturers, Honda has been hurt by an increase in the Japanese sales tax, the elimination of tax rebates and an increase in health insurance premiums. Also, mini-cars, which produce less profit, are accounting for a bigger portion of Honda's domestic sales.
In the fiscal first half, which ended Sept. 30, net income rose to 126.49 billion yen, or $1.02 billion, from 94.91 billion yen a year earlier. Sales increased 13 percent, to 2.794 trillion yen from 2.479 trillion yen.
Honda also acknowledged that the Southeast Asian economic crisis would hurt its sales in the region. It lowered its full-year forecast for production in Asia outside of Japan by 30 percent, to 130,000 units. But it raised its full-year export target by 21 percent, to 570,000 autos.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE FALLOUT;
Chase's Trading Losses in October Totaled $160 Million Before Taxes

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Whipsawed by the economic turmoil sweeping across Asia and Latin America, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's largest bank, said yesterday that it had suffered a pretax trading loss of $160 million for October.
Chase said the loss after taxes would be about $100 million and would threaten the New York bank's ability to meet operating earnings growth of 15 percent for the year. The announcement by Chase was its first confirmation of reports that sharp drops in the price of emerging-market debt during the last week of October had made a significant dent. The bank said it did not expect trading results for November to be as grim. 
 Chase had overall trading revenue of $1.9 billion in the first nine months of this year.
Chase's Latin American trading operation primarily makes a market in Mexican, Argentine and Brazilian sovereign debt through its New York and London trading desks. Smaller regional desks in those countries trade bank notes and similar instruments. Traders said sharp downturns in Brazil did the most damage to Chase, though the bank has also been sideswiped by tens of millions of dollars in trading losses in Russia.
Analysts had been expecting Chase to earn $2.27 a share for the fourth quarter and $8.61 a share for the year, according to a consensus estimate by First Call. First Call said 5 of the 20 bank analysts it surveys lowered their estimates for Chase yesterday, reducing the fourth-quarter consensus to $1.82 a share.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Chase's shares rose 50 cents, to $107.25, after a big decline the day before. The price of the stock, which had plummeted over the last few weeks, apparently already reflected the trading losses. Other bank stocks rebounded more sharply, and it is becoming clear that serious emerging-market losses appear to be limited to Chase. Banks have started filing their third-quarter reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and any material trading losses suffered by the end of October would have to be reported in those filings.
A Citicorp spokeswoman said that "nothing we've experienced requires us to change our practice of not discussing results." A spokeswoman for J. P. Morgan & Company said her bank had nothing material to report. Traders said the bank did not suffer any sizable emerging-market losses in October and was still in the black for November.
The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said it was not planning to make any disclosures regarding trading losses. The BankAmerica Corporation, which has had average trading revenue of $70 million a month this year, said October results were below that average but still positive for the month. The BankBoston Corporation did not respond to inquiries.
"We believe that the severity of this situation will prove to be specific to Chase rather than impacting each of the major dealer banks to a similar degree," said Diane Glossman, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. "If there's anything else bigger than a bread box, they'll have to disclose it."
Ms. Glossman said she had lowered her fourth-quarter earnings estimate for Chase to $1.90 a share from $2.27 and her 1997 estimate to $8.30 a share from $8.65.
Peter Tobin, the chief financial officer of Chase, declined to break out the trading losses by country. And he said foreign exchange and derivatives trading "did very well -- no issues there."
Mr. Tobin said that trading revenue accounted for only about 15 percent of Chase's total revenue and that he expected the bank over all to earn substantial profits in the fourth quarter and for the year. He said the turmoil that began in the last week of October, after economic downturns in Asia set off a decline in Latin American markets, was unique.
Nonetheless, Judah Kraushaar, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, said: "The trading hit was larger than I expected. They've been saying that their currency and derivatives trading was O.K., so this looks like the emerging markets really hurt them."
And banks may not be out of the woods yet. Financial markets remain volatile, meaning that banks could still be vulnerable to damage from overseas.
"This whole environment is still unfolding," Mr. Kraushaar said. "This is a work in progress, unfortunately."

HEADLINE: Sale of One Penn Plaza Could Happen Today

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Steven Roth's Vornado Realty Trust is expected to win out in the bidding for One Penn Plaza, a 2.4-million-square-foot tower next to Madison Square Garden, in a deal that would give the publicly traded company control of about one-third of the real estate in the neighborhood.
Mr. Roth may sign a contract as early as today to buy the property, according to two real estate executives who spoke on condition of anonymity. One of them said Vornado would pay more than $420 million and would have to make a down payment of 10 percent. 
 If the deal is completed, Vornado will have invested more than $700 million in the area since March. Although the blocks surrounding Madison Square Garden and Pennsylvania Station do not attract blue chip corporations or command the high rents of midtown, Vornado is betting that the area will become the next booming retail and commercial mecca in the city.
"Steve Roth is a big believer in the retail value of all the space that surrounds Penn Station," said Richard Baxter, a senior managing director at Insignia/Edward S. Gordon Company. "His strategy focuses on economies of scale. Between the hotel, the office space and the retail, he'll create value in the entire area."
But gaining control of One Penn Plaza presents a thorny challenge for Mr. Roth, whose company is one of the most voracious buyers of real estate in New York. The building's owners are the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company which has a 43 percent stake, and two feuding partners: Leona Helmsley, who holds 28.5 percent, and Peter Malkin, who heads a group that also has 28.5 percent. The land beneath the building is owned separately by Sarah Korein, one of the city's wealthiest landowners, and is not for sale.
Met Life initiated the sale in October when about a dozen prospective buyers submitted bids for the 25-year-old tower, which was recently renovated for $26 million. Company officials would not comment.
"We're in the final stages of marketing the building, but it would be premature to discuss any of the details," said Tricia Brown, a spokeswoman for Met Life.
According to executives close to the talks, Vornado submitted the highest bid and has held discussions with all the other partners.
Met Life's partners, however, have the right to match any offer within 30 days and to buy the property themselves. Mr. Malkin, who is in a bitter public battle with Mrs. Helmsley, has said privately that he wants the tower. Mrs. Helmsley has indicated that she would sell her interest for the right price, just as she is trying to sell most of the $5 billion Helmsley real estate holdings. But few people who know her believe that she would let One Penn Plaza go to Mr. Malkin, a partner whom she excluded from the funeral of her husband, Harry Helmsley, in January.
Mr. Malkin's prospects for buying the building are complicated by the fact that his group includes Alvin Schwartz and Irving Schneider, also former partners of Mr. Helmsley. Mr. Schneider has allied with Mrs. Helmsley against Mr. Malkin and may try to block the purchase.
"We haven't seen a contract yet, but we will look at all our options carefully," said Mr. Schwartz's lawyer, Howard Graff of Baer, Marks & Upham. "We're prepared to do what we have to do to protect our client's interests."
In any event, Mr. Malkin alone could make it difficult, though not impossible, for Vornado to take over the building, or he could agree to a sale.
Vornado has been a speculative juggernaut. In March, the company took over 2 Penn Plaza and 11 Penn Plaza, two towers looming over Madison Square Garden with a total of 2.7 million square feet, when it acquired the real estate portfolio of Bernard Mendik in a $656 million deal.
Mr. Roth's company then bought a 50 percent stake in June in the 1,700-room Hotel Pennsylvania, across the street from Madison Square Garden, as part of a $160 million joint venture with Planet Hollywood International and the billionaire Ong Beng Seng. At the same time, Vornado added three small office buildings on 34th Street.
Vornado is also among a group of eight companies vying for the landmark Chrysler Building at 42d Street and Lexington Avenue.

HEADLINE: Former Mayor Wins an Upset In Miami Ballot

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Former Mayor Xavier Suarez upset Mayor Joe Carollo today in a runoff election that had been filled with mud-slinging and charges of ballot fraud.
With all precincts reporting, Mr. Suarez had 23,598 votes, or 53.2 percent, while Mr. Carollo had 20,739 votes, or 46.8 percent. 
 The runoff was necessary since Mr. Carollo failed to win a majority in the regular election last week.
Mr. Carollo sued to have the absentee ballots in last week's mayoral election thrown out because of allegations of ballot fraud. Mr. Carollo had a majority of regular ballots but Mr. Suarez won about two-thirds of the absentee ballots.
Last night Mr. Suarez said: "We won by more regular votes, non-absentee ballot votes. What are they going to say now? We did everything by the book."
Mr. Suarez had complained that news coverage of the allegations had hurt his campaign and his reputation.
State Attorney Katherine Fernandez Rundle has called on a grand jury to investigate the absentee ballot process in Dade County and the Florida Department of Law Enforcement has seized over 5,000 absentee ballots from last week's election. Two men, one who said he was a volunteer for the Suarez campaign, have been arrested and charged with ballot fraud.
The State Law Enforcement Department for the first time monitored the election, checking absentee ballots as they were turned in to election headquarters.
Mr. Carollo battled many critics as he struggled to weather the storm of a $68 million budget deficit last year and has fought to clear the city's name amidst a slew of corruption scandals. Mr. Suarez has argued that the Mayor had exaggerated the city's financial crisis in order to elevate his status as the politician who saved the city.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
Congress Votes Down Foreign Policy Proposals
Congress voted down a White House plan to make overdue payments to the United Nations and rejected contributing more money to the I.M.F. for financial crises. A1 

Iraq Expels 6 Americans
Iraq expelled six American members of an arms inspection team and put them on the road to Amman, Jordan. The United Nations responded by announcing that all inspectors would be withdrawn form the country immediately. A10
 
President Clinton denounced Iraq's action but stopped short of ordering a military retaliation. A1
 
Attacks Threatened in Pakistan
The Aimal Secret Committee, a previously unknown group, claimed responsibility for killing four American oil company workers and their driver in Karachi, Pakistan. The group threatened more attacks if Mir Aimal Kasi, a Pakistani convicted of killing two C.I.A. workers in Virginia in 1993, gets the death penalty. A3
 
Attrition Riddles Qatar Summit
Israel announced that Foreign Minister David Levy would not attend the Middle East economic conference in Doha, Qatar. The Israeli delegation is to be led instead by Natan Sharansky, the Industry and Trade Minister. Several Arab countries had signaled their protest of Israeli policies by deciding not to attend, leaving only Jordan, Kuwait, Oman and Yemen as confirmed participants in what was once supposed to be an important regional conference and diplomatic forum. A11
 
Informer Shielded Rabin's Killer
A Jewish militant who worked as an informer for Israel's Shin Bet security agency failed to report threats by Yigal Amir to kill Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, months before the assassination, according to secret findings of a state inquiry that has been made public. The informer had a history of eluding his handlers and pursuing his own violent campaign against Arabs and promoting far-right extremist groups. A9
 
Not a Bank Holiday in Indonesia
Fourteen thousand police officers and riot troops patrolled the streets of Jakarta as Indonesia's Government designated a day for hundreds of thousands of depositors to begin to retrieve a portion of their savings from the 16 troubled banks that were closed earlier in the week. The Government has allocated money for depositors to recover up to $5,700 from their accounts. A3
 
Afghanistan, Land of Onions?
Pino Arlacchi, the head of the United Nations drug control agency, announced a plan to root out opium poppies around the world within 10 years. He said he would try to convince peasants to grow legal crops, like onions, instead of the lucrative poppy, which provides the raw material for heroin. His first focus would be Afghanistan, whose militant Islamic leaders have promised to ban cultivation of the plant. A6
 
NATIONAL A14-33
 
AIDS Drugs Don't Kill Virus But Can Remain Effective
Powerful drug combinations being taken by many people infected with the AIDS virus do not eliminate it from the body, scientists have found. Neither does the virus develop resistance to the drugs in people who follow the strict dosage schedule, but the dormant infection means those using the combination therapy must continue it. A1
 
Congress Ends Mixed Session
As the 105th Congress ends its session it can boast of one bipartisan achievement: legislation to balance the budget and cut taxes. But the ill-will and stalemate of the session's closing weeks point to a return to sharp partisanship next year. A1
 
Instant Expulsions at Border
On-the-spot expulsions at United States borders are one result of a new law that gives immigration agents sweeping powers to exclude noncitizens summarily, powers that previously belonged only to judges. In the seven months since the law took effect, more than 23,000 people have been expelled this way with no access to legal help and, in most cases, were permitted no appeal. A1
 
New Warning on Diet Drugs
Americans who took either of two diet pills removed from the market in September should have medical checkups for evidence of possible heart damage, health officials said. They estimated that 1.2 million to 4.7 million people in this country have used the prescription drugs either singly or in a combination popularly known as "fen-phen." A26
 
Donation Was 'Hush' Money
The First Lady's former chief of staff, Margaret Williams, told House investigators that Johnny Chung, a discredited fund-raiser in President Clinton's re-election campaign, was such a relentless pest in seeking Administration access that his $50,000 campaign donation was finally accepted at the White House to "quiet him," and not to transact some improper quid pro quo. Marines Get Army Apology
The Army's senior personnel official, Sara E. Lister, apologized to the Marine Corps after she described the Marines as "extremists" who were at risk of "total disconnection with society." The comments prompted calls on Capitol Hill for her resignation or dismissal. A30
 
Lawmaker Seeks Tobacco Data

Safety Board Inherits T.W.A. Crash Inquiry
With the FBI ruling out sabotage in the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 off the coast of Long Island last year, the National Transportation Safety Board is now engaged in an engineer's worst nightmare: the search for a mysterious flaw that may be lurking in airplanes that are still flying. Even if the board is never able to say precisely what caused the Boeing 747's center fuel tank to explode, the engineers hope to identify additional changes in design or maintenance that could reduce the risk of similar disasters. A1
 
Guilty Plea in Insurance Case
A California man pleaded guilty in Manhattan to Federal charges that he defrauded nearly 1,600 investors of $95 million by promising them quick profits through buying the life insurance policies of terminally ill people. Such purchases, known as "viatical settlements," have become increasingly popular, especially for people with diseases like AIDS who can no longer work and have difficulty paying their medical bills. The State Board of Regents will formally vote today to make it harder to earn a diploma in New York, requiring that the class of 2005 and beyond take three years each of mathematics and science and pass college-preparatory exams in five subjects. B2

Stocks recovered more than half of the previous day's losses, bolstered by calmer markets overseas and by expectations that slowdowns in Asia and Latin America would keep United States interest rates low.

HEADLINE: Misguided Iran Sanctions

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Nov. 11 news analysis on American efforts to impose sanctions on foreign companies that trade with Iran highlights a foreign policy dilemma: isolating Iran at the cost of alienating allies. In a porous world, sanctions are ineffective. Saddam Hussein is still in power in Iraq, Libya is indifferent and North Korea, Vietnam and Cuba have all survived.
Where United States foreign policy has been successful, it was based on constructive engagement: apartheid in South Africa, Communism in Eastern Europe, Arab-Israeli peace. A policy based on exclusion and sanctions tends to radicalize rather than tame the target. 
 Secretary of State Dean Acheson's methods for containment of Communism pushed Mao Zedong to greater extremes, and Mr. Acheson's dealings with Gamal Abdel Nasser further radicalized the Egyptian leader. Likewise, imposing more sanctions on Iran will result in further radicalization.
 
NAJMEDIN MESHKATI
GUIVE MIRFENDERESKI
Los Angeles, Nov. 12, 1997

HEADLINE: James Laughlin, Publisher With Bold Taste, Dies at 83

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
James Laughlin, the fiercely independent publisher, editor and poet, who, as the founder and longtime head of New Directions, published many of the most consequential and revolutionary writers of his time, died Wednesday on the way to Sharon Hospital from his home in Norfolk, Conn. He was 83.
The cause was complications following a stroke, said Griselda Ohannessian, the managing director of New Directions. 
 A man who combined bold taste with a gentle demeanor, Mr. Laughlin made a major contribution to literature as well as to the field of publishing. The list of his writers is staggering in its length and artistic complexity. He was Vladimir Nabokov's first American publisher and also printed the work of Tennessee Williams, William Carlos Williams, Ezra Pound, Henry Miller, Djuna Barnes, Dylan Thomas, Delmore Schwartz and John Hawkes, among many others.
There are large publishing houses and small presses -- and then there is New Directions, a one-man operation that grew to become one of the most influential book companies in the United States. "He was the greatest publisher America ever had," Brendan Gill, an author and critic, said yesterday. "Look at his backlist: there's nothing comparable."
As the poet Donald Hall said in an article in The New York Times in 1981, two things were paramount on Mr. Laughlin's list: "the assumption of quality and the assumption that these books would not sell in the marketplace."
He added that Mr. Laughlin started New Directions "in the service of verbal revolution," but he also reprinted Henry James, E. M. Forster, Ronald Firbank and Evelyn Waugh "when other publishers would not." Mr. Laughlin was, Mr. Hall said, a publisher "of the middle way," someone "who by low overhead, by infusions of capital from the responsible rich, by wit, or most likely by all three -- can choose with taste, publish with economy and keep a good book in print."
Mr. Laughlin published "The Crack Up" by F. Scott Fitzgerald; Beat poets including Lawrence Ferlinghetti and Gregory Corso; as well as authors in translation (Pablo Neruda, Garcia Lorca, Boris Pasternak, Jorge Luis Borges, Yukio Mishima), and on and on. He was indefatigable in his search for the new and adventurous. In a field often known for its timidity and for its concern for profits above all, Mr. Laughlin was a maverick. As he once said, "I don't have any business acumen. I'm not good at deals and can't cope with agents." What he could cope with were the personalities of some of the most difficult and temperamental authors.
With a characteristic boldness, he would take chances on anyone he considered an original. At the recommendation of Pound, he took on William Carlos Williams and Henry Miller. Williams brought him to Nathanael West and Miller encouraged him to reprint Herman Hesse's "Siddharta," which became one of New Directions's best sellers, along with Ferlinghetti's "Coney Island of the Mind." T. S. Eliot recommended Djuna Barnes.
Because of his willingness to listen to all suggestions and his close friendship with many of his authors, he thought of them as "an extended family," a family whose favored members included Pound and Nabokov. He studied with the former and he went butterfly hunting with the latter, although, for his own outdoor endeavors, he preferred to ski, swim and play golf.
For all of his editorial instinct, occasionally a book eluded him. He published Thomas Merton's poetry but delayed reading "The Seven Storey Mountain" until he returned from a skiing trip and found that Harcourt, Brace had accepted it. In 1954, Nabokov sent him a copy of the manuscript of "Lolita," and asked him if he would be interested in "publishing a time bomb." He liked the novel, but had hesitations about the subject matter. He suggested that the author send the novel to Olympia Press in Paris, which published it.
The support for these experimental authors derived from a family fortune in iron and steel. Mr. Laughlin was born in Pittsburgh. His great-grandfather, James Laughlin, had founded the family business, which became the Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation. As a boy, James Laughlin 4th was taken by his father to visit the Laughlin mill. He compared it to the Inferno: "It was scary -- tremendous slabs of hot molten steel coming out of those giant furnaces, terrible noise, huge cranes carrying metal over your head all molten." And he made up his mind that he would never enter the business.
At the Choate School in Wallingford, Conn., he studied with the translator Dudley Fitts, and became editor of the school literary magazine. In 1933, before he entered Harvard University, he published a story in Atlantic Monthly. His aunt, Leila Laughlin Carlisle, was an important influence in his youth and he often visited her at her home in Norfolk, Conn. She encouraged his literary interests while trying to temper his enthusiasm for works of a more radical nature. She doubtless would not have approved of "Lolita."
As a student at Harvard, he majored in Latin and Italian. Because he was unhappy over the conservatism of teachers such as the poet Robert Hillyer, who would leave the room when Pound or Eliot was mentioned, he took a leave of absence in the middle of his sophomore year. He went to France, where he met Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas.
Then he wrote to Pound in Rapallo, Italy, and when the poet responded with the words, "Visibility high," he went to visit him. He stayed for six months, studying in Pound's personal "Ezuversity." In 1935, after reading Mr. Laughlin's poetry and crossing out most of the words, Pound said, "You're never going to be any good as a poet. Why don't you take up something useful?" He suggested that he become a publisher, which proved to be the most salutary advice for Mr. Laughlin as well as for the world of publishing.
Back at Harvard, and still an undergraduate, he started New Directions with money from his father. He published books out of a cottage at his aunt's home in Norfolk, Conn., and stored copies in his college room. New Directions eventually moved to New York; he continued to live in Norfolk.
His first book, published in 1936, was "New Directions in Prose & Poetry." It cost him $396 to print 700 copies, which he sold for sold for $2 each. Loading his Buick with copies, he became his own traveling salesman. The book was an anthology of experimental writing whose contributors included Elizabeth Bishop, Kay Boyle, E. E. Cummings, Henry Miller, Marianne Moore, Gertrude Stein, Ezra Pound, Wallace Stevens, William Carlos Williams -- and Tasilo Ribischka. The last writer was identified as "an Austrian now living in Saugus, Mass., where he is a night watchman at a railroad grade crossing; this gives him lots of time to think." Ribischka was Mr. Laughlin's pseudonym.
Despite his reputation for thriftiness -- paying low salaries and delaying royalties when money was short -- he nurtured writers in various ways, economically as well as artistically. While publishing Delmore Schwartz, he hired him as an editor and later paid for his visits to his psychiatrist, without telling him. He would also lend money to writers.
In the 1940's, he began to publish a series called "Five Young American Poets" (the poets included Tennessee Williams, Randall Jarrell and Karl Shapiro). He also reprinted authors (Fitzgerald, Forster, Stein) in a New Classics series and published critical works under the title, "Makers of Modern Literature."
Despite Pound's discouragement, he continued writing poetry, and his reputation as a poet grew. Hayden Carruth praised Mr. Laughlin's work for "the layering voices of wit, irony and fantasy" and "the breadth of literary sources." In his own poetry, he paid homage to Greek and Latin models as well as to Pound and Williams. His book "New and Selected Poems" is scheduled to be published next year by New Directions.
His correspondence with his authors fills volumes: a series published by W. W. Norton that already includes Henry Miller, Pound, Schwartz, William Carlos Williams and Kenneth Rexroth. Typically, the letters are mostly "to" Mr. Laughlin rather than "from," with the publisher taking a more reserved position as listener and responder.
In the Schwartz-Laughlin collection, there is a letter from the publisher while visiting the family ski lodge in Alta, Utah. Taking time out to reflect on priorities, he wrote: "What is life for but to enjoy it, and certainly in the scales of happiness a fine day in the bright sun and snow on one of our mountains here is of more worth than publishing a book by a dyspeptic author." Then he added a note of cautionary advice: "Do not become a cheap writer. Keep up your standards. It is better to be read by 800 readers and be a good writer than be read by all the world and be Somerset Maugham."
He is survived by his wife, Gertrude Huston Laughlin of Norfolk; a daughter, Leila Savitch of Manhattan; two sons, Henry, of San Francisco and Paul, of Ann Arbor, Mich., and six grandchildren.
In 1992 he was awarded the National Book Foundation Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters. In an essay adapted from his acceptance speech, he wrote, "It took 23 years for New Directions to get into the black. But I've enjoyed a situation that every publisher must envy. No trips to the bank to beg for a loan. Little worry about the bottom line. If a good manuscript came along that I feared wouldn't sell much, we could do it."
Then with the honesty of an artist who knows the value of money, he added, "Of course, none of this would have possible without the industry of my ancestors, the canny Irishmen who immigrated in 1824 from County Down to Pittsburgh, where they built up what became the fourth largest steel company in the country. I bless them with every breath."

HEADLINE: S.D. Paine, 65, Art Collector and Donor

 BODY:
Stephen D. Paine, an art collector and museum benefactor, died on Saturday at Beth Israel Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 65 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.
The cause was respiratory failure due to post-polio syndrome, his wife, Susan Woods Paine, said. 
 Mr. Paine, an investment counselor who retired in 1995 as partner and senior vice president of the Wellington Management Company, was born in Cambridge on April 7, 1932, and raised in Brookline. He graduated from Deerfield Academy in 1950 and Williams College in 1954, with a degree in economics. In 1955, he contracted polio while serving in the United States Air Force and began to study art during his recuperation. He emerged from his illness confined to a wheelchair but with what was to be a lifelong passion for art.
He began by collecting the drawings of the Abstract Expressionists in the early 1960's and was soon a regular visitor to galleries in Boston and New York, known for his discerning eye and eclectic taste. The works that he and his wife gave to the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, where he was a trustee for more than 20 years, included paintings, sculptures and prints by such artists as Kandinsky, Robert Rauschenberg, Helen Frankenthaler, Jean Dubuffet and David Smith.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by two sisters, Priscilla P. Fuller of Minneapolis and Sarah P. O'Brien of Scottsdale, Ariz.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Tax Breaks Provided For Publisher's Move

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
City and state officials have agreed to provide at least $4.3 million in tax breaks to the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company to subsidize its move to new offices at 63 Madison Avenue, at 28th Street, from the company's longtime headquarters four blocks away at One Park Avenue.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the tax breaks were tied to the creation of new jobs. Ziff-Davis, a computer magazine publisher that is owned by the Softbank Corporation of Japan, has promised to add 1,332 jobs, up from 738 now, over the next 22 years. 
 Ziff-Davis will receive $4.3 million in sales tax exemptions toward the purchase of new equipment. John Powers and Carol Nelson, real estate brokers at the Insignia/Edward S. Gordon Company, represented Ziff-Davis.
The city has also agreed to a limit on future increases in property taxes that Ziff-Davis will have to pay at 63 Madison. Mr. Powers said that the property-tax cap would save the company an extra $5 million over the 22-year period. But city officials said that property taxes would have to rise at a furious pace for Ziff-Davis to see such a saving.
Unlike some companies that have received tax incentives to stay in New York, Ziff-Davis never searched for a headquarters outside the city, Mr. Powers said. But he said that without the tax incentives, the company would have moved some operations to San Francisco or Boston. DAVID M. HALBFINGER

HEADLINE: CONGRESS DEPRIVES CLINTON OF MONEY FOR U.N. AND I.M.F.

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Congress voted today to defeat the carefully negotiated plan to make overdue payments to the United Nations and rejected contributing more money to the International Monetary Fund to help stave off foreign financial crises.
By a voice vote, the Senate approved a foreign operations spending bill of nearly $13 billion for 1998 -- without providing for United Nations and I.M.F. payments. The House had passed similar legislation 333 to 76 shortly after midnight. 
 The White House spokesman called the votes "boneheaded."
A spokesman for Secretary General Kofi Annan said the action "is going to make a difficult situation even more difficult" financially at the United Nations.
But the spokesman, Fred Eckhard, said the refusal to pay dues would probably not scuttle American attempts to build a unified front against Iraq because "on a big strategic issue like this, nations will act in their national interests."
The fight over money for the two international agencies became entwined in the domestic battle over abortion, and it dominated the final hours of the first session of the 105th Congress.
In the last few days, the Administration has mounted an extraordinarily strong lobbying effort to rescue the money for the international agencies. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin spent several hours on Capitol Hill on Wednesday night meeting with the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, and other Republican leaders. And Ms. Albright also talked one-on-one by telephone with the conservative legislators who backed the anti-abortion amendment to the spending bill.
Indeed, the Administration has spent a year trying to pave the way for the payments, and it appeared it had made significant gains when Senator Jesse A. Helms, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, was persuaded to support the plan. But it came undone because of the anti-abortion provision.
With this defeat, President Clinton lost two of his top foreign policy initiatives and -- despite Mr. Eckhard's denial -- could be hamstrung when it comes to dealing with two looming crises. The United States is seeking support at the Security Council for action against Iraq, and is working through the I.M.F. to contain the financial confusion in Asia.
"This is a particularly ill-timed move by Congress at a moment when we are attempting to work with the United Nations to build an international support for an appropriate response to provocations by Saddam Hussein," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman. "It is utterly boneheaded for Congress to fail to meet the commitments that the United States has at the U.N. in terms of our arrears."
Mr. Gingrich, who only days before had been allied with President Clinton in a failed attempt to win passage of a bill that would have given the President enhanced authority to negotiate trade agreements, found himself leading the attacks against the White House today. But Mr. Gingrich allowed the abortion issue to be tied up with the financing issue by conservative Republicans who want to extend the reach of the so-called Mexico City Policy, which bars use of Federal money for overseas abortion services or lobbying for such services.
Under the threat of a veto, Republican leaders on Wednesday removed the anti-abortion provision from the foreign operations spending bill and provided $385 million for international family-planning programs. But in a bow to conservatives who were behind the amendment, led by Representative Christopher H. Smith, a New Jersey Republican, Mr. Gingrich agreed to remove three issues dear to the White House and hold them hostage: reauthorization of the State Department, the United States' payment of nearly $1 billion in back dues to the United Nations and $3.5 billion to help the International Monetary Fund create the fund to bolster ailing economies.
If Mr. Clinton wants that money for the United Nations and the I.M.F. he will have to accept the anti-abortion provision next year. Democrats condemned this as a "political poison pill," putting the President in a position where he would have to oppose legislation he wants because of an issue he finds objectionable.
"Mr. Gingrich made a decision that if Chris Smith cannot win on Mexico City, then no one else should win on anything," said Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the senior Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee. "It does not punish Bill Clinton," Mr. Obey added, "it punishes the country."
The Republicans also brought up the abortion issue when the President was trying to solicit votes to give him the expanded trade authority he worked to win.
International organizations like the United Nations and the I.M.F. are frequent political targets of conservative Republicans. But the current fight comes at an especially crucial time for the Administration.
The I.M.F. issue may be especially vexing.
As part of an effort involving 25 nations, including the United States, the fund is seeking to set up an emergency credit program called the New Agreements to Borrow. It would supplement existing I.M.F. funds and could be used to loan money to countries that find themselves in extraordinary financial straits, as Mexico was in 1995.
The Administration has led the drive, in part because it wants to avoid taking the lead in future bailouts, as it did in the case of Mexico. Instead, it is seeking to assure that the I.M.F. has sufficient funds to play that role.
As was the case in the last week's fight over the trade-authority bill, Mr. Gingrich was the political point man again today. "The problem only exists in the House and only with the House leadership," Mr. Obey complained.
Even some Senate Republicans were riled by the House Republicans.
"I'm really disturbed about that," Senator Ted Stevens, an Alaska Republican and the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, told reporters this afternoon. "It's very bad."
Mr. Stevens said he had tried and failed today to persuade House Republicans to send a "clean" bill to the President with the money for the United Nations and the International Monetary Fund. He said the only option left to him was to try to pass a supplemental appropriations bill in the spring that would provide the money.
In the last major vote of the year tonight, Congress approved the spending bill for the Departments of Commerce, Justice and State, including a compromise over a much-debated method of estimating the population in 2000.
The Census Bureau would be allowed to proceed next year with a test of the use of statistical sampling, as the Administration wanted. But in return, the Republicans won an agreement that the House Speaker would be allowed to legally challenge the use of sampling and that the Government would pay for the lawsuit.
The spending bill appropriates money for three of the largest Cabinet departments -- Commerce ($4.3 billion), Justice ($17.5 billion), and State ($5 billion) -- and for the Federal judiciary system ($3.2 billion). On the Commerce bill, the House voted 282 to 110, and the Senate approved it by a voice vote.

HEADLINE: Mexico and U.S. Take Steps on Arms, Drugs and Border Issues

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
President Clinton and the Mexican President, Ernesto Zedillo, said today that the United States and Mexico had made modest progress in resolving a number of the central problems in their complex diplomatic relationship.
But President Clinton acknowledged that United States trade relations with Mexico and other Latin American countries had been set back by his failure to persuade Congress to grant him enhanced trading authority under a measure known as fast track. 
 Mr. Zedillo told a business audience on Thursday that he had a "tremendous expectation and hope" that fast-track legislation would pass, helping to accelerate trade throughout the Americas. The legislation would permit Congress to adopt or reject trade agreements, but not to amend them.
Mr. Clinton did not concede defeat on the trade measure, however. "I think that this is not the last chapter in this story," he said in a photo session with Mr. Zedillo at the White House this morning. "I believe that you will see some more movement early next year."
The Administration believes it needs the new negotiating power to complete the hemispheric free-trade zone that President Clinton has pledged to build by 2005.
"I would urge our friends throughout Latin America not to overreact to the House vote," Mr. Clinton said. "This story is not over yet."
The two Presidents signed a multinational accord to fight trafficking in illegal weapons, announced that they would work more closely on drug interdiction, agreed upon new extradition rules for criminals and promised cooperation on economic development and environmental projects along the 2,000-mile United States-Mexico border.
The weapons accord was signed by 28 North and South American nations at the Organization of American States today. It marked the first time that a group of countries has agreed to work together to halt the black market in arms.
The agreement mandates that the countries that sign require that all firearms made within their borders carry indelible markings indicating the serial number and name and place of manufacture. The accord also requires countries to maintain an effective licensing system for all weapons imports and exports.
Officials said today that the agreement does not require the United States to impose any new rules on gun manufacturers or importers, but it does commit the Administration to vigorous enforcement of existing laws.
The Governments also concluded a protocol to their extradition treaty this week that will permit temporary extradition to allow cross-border criminals to be tried in both countries while evidence is fresh.
Drug traffic through Mexico to the United States remains a substantial irritant in the relationship, United States officials said. Barry McCaffrey, a retired Army general who heads the White House drug control office, said that as much as 50 percent of the cocaine consumed in the United States flows through Mexico and that Mexico should do more to end its role as a shipment point on the route for South American cocaine.
But Mexican officials have responded that the problem is the demand for drugs, not the supply. The two countries today completed plans for a conference to be held in March in El Paso to discuss ways to improve interdiction of drugs and reduce demand on both sides of the border.

HEADLINE: Think Tank;
New Vision of Eden as a Scientific Garden

BYLINE: By Paul Lewis 

 BODY:
Ever since Plato wrote the "Republic," idealists have been setting out their visions of the perfect society. Thomas More, who wrote "Utopia" in 1516, wanted to restore the traditional village and fend off the emerging market system that allowed "rich men to buy up all." The Frenchman Charles Fourier believed man could rationally determine the most harmonious social unit: by his calculations, 1,620 people on 5,000 acres. In the 1780's, the religious, communal Shakers began establishing villages with celibacy as the cardinal principle; seven decades later, John Humphrey Noyes founded the religious and socialist Oneida community, where every woman was the wife of every man and vice versa.
The latest entrant to the utopian ranks seems to be Freeman J. Dyson, the 73-year-old mathematician and former physicist, who is now a futurologist at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J. Like the scientific utopians at this century's start, Mr. Dyson says technology provides the bridge to a heaven on earth. 
 He conjures up a world where trees, not oil wells, produce fuel, where rural villages are the major source of wealth, and former slum dwellers are hooked up to the Internet.
In his vision, new technologies pointed in the right direction could create such a poverty-free utopia, leapfrogging the dishearteningly slow efforts of the World Bank and other do-gooders to promote development.
Mr. Dyson laid out his theory in a lecture in Manhattan last week sponsored by the Carnegie Council on Ethics and International Affairs. His starting point was the way rural villages in Britain, Germany and France are abandoning agriculture to become residential centers for the middle class and sites for business and light industry.
These villages became sources of wealth, he argued, because "they have what wealthy people seek, peace and security and beauty." He then asked himself the obvious question, "How can a God-forsaken Mexican village become a source of wealth?"
His answer: "The sun, the genome and the Internet can work together to bring wealth to the villages of Mexico just as the older technology of electricity and automobiles brought wealth to the villages of England."
"Technology guided by ethics has the power to help billions of poor people all over the earth," he explained. "The thousand megawatts of solar power falling daily on every tropical square mile is enough to support "a dense population with all modern conveniences."
Of course, photoelectric conversion is expensive, but in time, geneticists could develop mutated trees "that convert sunlight to liquid fuel and deliver the fuel directly through their roots to a network of pipes," Mr. Dyson said. Then "economic forces will move industries from cities to the country."
Finally, all these new rural production centers could be linked via the Internet, allowing "people in remote places to make business deals, to buy and sell, to keep in touch with friends, to continue their education."
The obstacle, he said, is not that science cannot achieve this, but that technological research is heading in the wrong direction, concentrating on "making toys for the rich."
Genetic researchers, for example, seek mainly to advance human "high-tech medicine," which primarily benefits the rich, while manufacturers prefer to upgrade products, keeping them "out of reach of the poor."
Mr. Dyson said ethical values as well as the desire for profit can drive technological research just as technology sometimes influences human values. Thus the Protestant work ethic, which emphasized personal responsibility, fathered capitalism and the Industrial Revolution. But what made the spread of Protestantism possible in the first place was the invention of printing, because it popularized the Bible.
What research into this holy trinity of solar energy, genetics and computers now needs, Mr. Dyson said, is "a strong ethical push" to get all three technologies working in tandem to create "a socially just world."

HEADLINE: Foreign-Policy Vandalism

 BODY:
In an extreme example of legislative irresponsibility, the House of Representatives on Thursday abruptly killed the carefully negotiated compromise on the United States' delinquent dues to the United Nations. It also deleted an urgently needed spending provision for the International Monetary Fund, which is trying to contain a dangerous Asian financial crisis.
The House Republican majority did not particularly object to the I.M.F. spending or the U.N. provision, which the White House had worked out with Senator Jesse Helms. The G.O.P.'s purpose was to hold these essential items hostage until the next session so as to coerce President Clinton into supporting an anti-abortion measure. The measure would deny Federal money to any overseas family planning agency that performs abortions or lobbies to change abortion laws. 
 Earlier this week, Mr. Clinton accepted a painful defeat over "fast track" trade authority because he refused to accept the anti-abortion language. Then House members tried to hold the entire $13 billion foreign operations spending bill hostage to their cause. Finally, they resorted to assaulting the I.M.F. and weakening the United Nations in the midst of the Iraq crisis. The White House went only slightly overboard in characterizing their logic as "boneheaded."

HEADLINE: Confidence Of Consumers Remains High

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Despite recent stock market gyrations, the nation's consumers have actually grown more confident about current economic conditions, the Survey Research Center at the University of Michigan told clients today.
Whether consumers would grow more cautious as the value of their securities portfolios shrank has been a matter of debate. But it appears that as a group they view the situation much as does Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. In late October, Mr. Greenspan called the stock market decline in the United States a "salutary event" that might help keep the buoyant economy from overheating by curbing consumer spending. 
 Government figures released today supported the notion that the economy was not growing so rapidly as to lead to inflation. Retail spending fell, while the prices that producers receive for their goods rose only slightly.
Most startling, the confidence of consumers in current conditions climbed to a new high for this economic expansion, which began in the spring of 1991.
"Although the largest number of consumers since the 1987 crash reported hearing of the decline in stock prices, nearly as many reported hearing of rebounding stock prices," the Michigan polling group said in its preliminary report for November. "Consumer confidence has remained remarkably strong."
The rise in the overall confidence index was to 106.1 from 105.6, according to a subscriber, with a major component, the appraisal of current conditions, surging to 115.5 from 109.8.
This upbeat assessment comes at the beginning of the holiday shopping season and after two months of declining retail sales. Retail sales edged down two-tenths of 1 percent, to $213.7 billion, in October, the Commerce Department estimated today. That report for October was accompanied by a revision in September sales figures to a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent from what had been an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent.
Though consumers appear to have pulled back from their blistering summer spending pace, economists said they still had considerable buying power and the will to use it.
The latest sales figures had "quite a weak tone," said analysts at Macroeconomic Advisers in St. Louis, but a slide at automotive showrooms depressed the total. Otherwise, retail spending posted a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent.
"We've got momentum" across a broad front, said Brian M. Jones, an economist at Salomon Brothers.
The price report, reflecting what the nation's producers obtain for their goods, showed a third consecutive increase following seven months of declines.
Still, analysts said the slight upward drift was not enough to concern the Federal Reserve. They noted that the rise was minimal, at one-tenth of 1 percent, and that without the wide-swinging food and energy components, there was no producer inflation at all last month. The price of raw materials registered a jump of 4 percent, mostly because of a surge in the price of natural gas.
"Prices just keep coming in with hardly any sign of inflationary pressures," said Howard Keen, chief economist at Conrail Inc.
Sales of durable goods, mainly motor vehicles, fell nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, to act as the main drag on retail sales. Automotive dealers reported a 2 percent decline in receipts, while merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes saw a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent. Sales of furniture and other items for the home were unchanged.
Last month's total sales were 3.4 percent greater than those of October 1996, before any adjustment for inflation.
