HEADLINE: French Speakers Meet Where Few Will Hear

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Under siege in Africa, intimidated on the Internet, fighting for its life in Indochina, the embattled French language is rallying its defenders this week in Vietnam, a former colony of France where less than 1 percent of the 75 million Vietnamese still speak French.
"Everybody wants to learn English to get a job," said Duong Bay, who got his at the Foreign Ministry by pursuing English studies at the university here. 
 Even Nguyen Lan, a 90-year-old professor who compiled the leading Vietnamese-French dictionary, has calling cards in Vietnamese and English, not French. His secretary had them done that way without asking, he said.
Most people here in northern Vietnam stopped using the French language when Ho Chi Minh defeated the French Army in 1954. In the south, French stopped being the language of choice for younger members of the elite during the American military buildup of the 1960's.
Nevertheless, from today until Sunday, President Jacques Chirac and leaders of more than 30 other countries, including some with only a passing acquaintance with French, are meeting here to fight for the francophone way in a world depressingly (to some of them) anglophone.
All this constitutes a historical oddity that might baffle Ho Chi Minh, himself a French-educated Vietnamese Communist leader who sacrificed millions of his compatriots' lives for independence from French tutelage and, later, American influence. For his country is joining its former colonial master in an effort to try to use the French language as a way to build a bloc of countries determined to stand up to the global assault of Anglo-American cultural, economic and political influences.
"The English that is spreading around the world is Anglo-American, not the pure English of Shakespeare," said Margie Sudre, a French legislator, born in Vietnam, who held the job of Secretary of State for Francophone Affairs in the French Foreign Ministry when the conservatives were in power.
"We don't want the French language to lose its richness and purity," she said.
On Sunday, despite some grumbling from African countries spearheaded by Burkina Faso that wanted a black African to head the organization, the Franco-summiteers are expected to elect Boutros Boutros-Ghali of Egypt, the former United Nations Secretary General, as their own Secretary General, a permanent spokesman to the rest of the globe for the next four years.
"I see it as a regional grouping," Mr. Boutros-Ghali said of the French-speaking movement in a recent interview with Le Figaro magazine. "It should become a way of defending cultural diversity. If everybody wears the same clothes, speaks the same language, has the same customs, we risk having a global fascist-type regime."
There's nothing phony, the defenders of French say, about holding a "Francophonie" summit meeting in a place where French is hardly spoken.
"Even though the percentage of Vietnamese who speak the language fluently is not very great, quality is more important than quantity," said Pham Khac Lam, a fluent French speaker who heads a committee dealing with the millions of Vietnamese who live abroad.
To the Vietnamese, holding their first international summit meeting shows that they have arrived, and to the French, the conference is a kind of beau geste well worth France's 70 percent share of the $17 million cost.
For if English is the global medium of commerce and communication par excellence, French is the message itself to francophones.
The "Conference of Chiefs of State and Government of Countries Having French in Common," to give this session its formal name, includes representatives of 46 member countries and two associate members, Portuguese-speaking Sao Tome and Principe and Romanian-speaking Moldova.
Some members, like France, Ivory Coast, the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Haiti, actually use French as their official language, even if in some of them the mass of people speak something else.
In others, like Canada and Belgium, it is one of two or more official languages, and in about 20, like Romania, Bulgaria and Egypt, it is widely studied or, as in Vietnam, used to be popular but went out of vogue with independence.
The Canadian provinces of Quebec and New Brunswick have full membership, and New England, where more people now study Spanish in school than French, has observer status, as does Louisiana.
If these countries and regions constitute the French-speaking world, it is potentially powerful, since it accounts for 10 percent of the world's gross national product and 9 percent of its population. But in all the world there are, by official French count, only 105 million "genuine" francophones -- people who use French every day.
That is not even half as many English speakers as there are in the United States, not to mention Britain, India and the rest of the world. It is fewer people than live in Brazil, where Portuguese is spoken.
Another 55 million people in former French colonies in Asia, Africa, America and the Caribbean use French occasionally, and an additional 100 million people scattered around the world have studied it.
What the French-speaking lands have in common is a sense of mission to resist the anglicization of the globe. Meetings like the current one are expected somehow to help them acquire at least some of the cultural and business clout that English-speakers get, in the French view, as a free ride.
"As soon as you get two or three business leaders together, you start speaking English," said Jean Gandois, who until last month was president of the main employers' organization in France.
That is one reason that France spends close to $1 billion a year in aid, education grants, language training programs and credits to spread French civilization around the world, including $88 million for the Francophone Agency, a coordinating organization in Paris that will form the basis of Mr. Boutros-Ghali's new secretariat.
France also spends more than $100 million a year on 1,056 Alliance Francaise centers that teach French in 134 countries and goes to extraordinary lengths to protect French language and culture at home.
Laws require popular music radio stations in France to make sure that 40 percent of the songs they broadcast are French and television stations to show French programs, but to little avail.
Francois Bayrou, an opposition leader, complained in the French Parliament the other day that one consequence of the insidious Anglo-Saxon influence was that criminals in French courts had begun referring to judges as "Votre Honneur," L.A. Law-style, instead of the traditional "Monsieur le Juge."
The defensiveness goes so far that when rebels overthrew the military dictator Mobutu Sese Seko in Zaire, now the Congo, earlier this year, some French commentators speculated that the American military advice they say the rebels benefited from was aimed at subverting the biggest French-speaking country in Africa to the Anglo-American orbit. The country's new Government boycotted the conference today, saying it was protesting France's longtime support for Mr. Mobutu.
Last year Mr. Chirac vetoed former Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen of Denmark as Secretary General of the NATO alliance, solely because he thought the Dane's French was not good enough to preserve French as one of NATO's official languages.
Mr. Chirac, who on Wednesday started the second visit to Vietnam since 1954 by a French head of state, also tried unsuccessfully to keep the United States from forcing Mr. Boutros-Ghali out of his job at the United Nations, where he had vigorously defended French as an official language. Kofi Annan of Ghana, who took over the post in January, had to demonstrate command of French before Paris gave its approval.
French and other diplomats now hope that Mr. Boutros-Ghali will be able to use diplomacy to keep inter-African conflicts from flaring up again and to manage them if they do erupt, averting the danger of meddling from any English speakers with designs on the area.
Against such high hopes, there is a certain reality to be faced, and it is evident here. Hanoi, swarming with motorcycles, seems as on the make and culturally overwhelmed as Saigon did in the 1960's, at the height of the American war. Now Vietnam is unified as a Communist country trying to practice capitalism, and France is only a distant memory. And Mr. Bay estimates that for every student studying French in Vietnam, there are at least 30 learning English.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Le Van Khoi, 85, owner of a traditional-medicine shop in Hanoi, is one of the few Vietnamese who can speak French, 43 years after his country won independence. Leaders of French-speaking countries are meeting in Hanoi to discuss ways to resist what they see as the anglicization of the globe. (Reuters)
 
Map/Chart: "OVERVIEW: The World of French"
More than 60 countries and territories are in the francophone world, but that does not mean that most of the people speak the language in most of those countries. Au contraire. (A notable exception is Vietnam. Another is Haiti, where French is the official language but only a tiny percentage - the elite - use it in preference to Creole.)

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief Attacks Congress Over Back Dues

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 14

 BODY:
In an unusually sharp criticism of Congress and the anti-abortion lobby that on Thursday killed a plan to pay the United Nations more than $1 billion in back dues, Secretary General Kofi Annan today called the vote "unreasonable and regrettable."
He also noted that the action, which officials say will push the organization into its most serious financial crisis in coming months, came in the same week that Washington was using the Security Council to garner support for American policy on Iraq. 
 Diplomats from France, Britain, Japan and other allies of the United States expressed shock and dismay at the rebuff from Washington, especially at such a delicate moment.
"This can't be good for the position of the U.S. in this organization," said a European diplomat here who did not want to be identified by name or country. "We had been promised time and time again that if certain conditions were met, the bills would be paid. The conditions were met, and we are not being paid a penny."
At a news conference, Mr. Annan said that while he did not feel personally betrayed by Washington, "if there is a betrayal, it is a betrayal of the international community and the United Nations system."
"It is both unreasonable and regrettable that the legislation was held hostage to the entirely unrelated domestic policies of abortion," Mr. Annan said. "I am disappointed and concerned."
Today the European Union also "deplored" the vote in Congress, said Jean-Louis Wolzfeld, Luxembourg's representative at the United Nations and current chairman of the Union nations here. In a statement today, the Europeans said the United States was endangering reforms of the organization while contributing to its deepening financial crisis.
"We noted also that Europe pays all its dues promptly and without conditions," Mr. Wolzfeld said.
On Thursday, both houses of Congress voted against a plan negotiated with the Clinton Administration that would have authorized overdue payments to the United Nations and additional money to the International Monetary Fund.
"We're supposed to be the leader of the world, and we shouldn't be doing things like this," said David E. Birenbaum, who is chairman of the Emergency Coalition for U.S. Financial Support of the United Nations, a lobbying group that includes all former American Secretaries of State on its board.
Mr. Birenbaum, who was the American representative on budgetary matters at the United Nations mission of the United States until last year, said the Congressional action revealed more about rivalries among Republicans and legislative self-indulgence than it did about the American public's attitude toward the United Nations. "Americans don't want us to be deadbeats," he said in an interview today.
The United States is the United Nations' largest debtor, responsible for about 60 percent of all unpaid debts. Congress has demanded that American payments be reduced before all debts are settled, an issue that is now being discussed by other member nations.
Mr. Annan said today that the action on Thursday was not going to help these negotiations, or talks on other demands by members of Congress whose aim is to reduce the size and activities of the United Nations.
The Secretary General said he would call an emergency session of a General Assembly panel on finance to look for ways out of a looming crisis. The United Nations had intended to apply the money the Clinton Administration had assured it was coming to repay money borrowed from the organization's peacekeeping fund -- money owed to countries that contribute troops to peacekeeping missions.
"The crisis will come quickly and deeply," Joseph E. Connor, Under Secretary General for Administration and Management, said today, He said he conveyed that message last week to Senator Rod Grams, Republican of Minnesota, who has been a critic of the United Nations.
The United Nations is not permitted to borrow money commercially. It depends entirely on contributions or assessments from its 185 member nations. These assessments are calculated on a country's proportion of the world economy.
United Nations officials, angered by Congressional accusations that the United Nations is bloated and unwilling to cut back its staff or programs, say the organization's budget has been kept at a no-growth level since 1994 -- during which time the United States budget has increased 16 percent. While the United States Government has cut back its staffing by 12 percent, the United Nations has cut its staff 24 percent.
Mr. Annan said the Congressional vote had come, ironically, "on the day after the General Assembly endorsed a major complement of my proposals for institutional reforms."
Some Congressional voices were raised in support of the United Nations today. Representative Eliot L. Engel, a New York Democrat who is co-chairman of the House United Nations Working Group, drew a direct link to the Iraqi crisis.
"Just as we are readying the nation for military action," he said, "Congress is taking a disastrous step to undercut our ability to build a coalition of nations at the U.N."

HEADLINE: Agencies Told by Mayor to Prepare for Budget Cuts

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration is warning city agencies that though the local economy is rebounding and tax revenues are greater than expected, they must prepare for the possibility of new spending cuts next summer to help close large budget gaps projected for the years ahead.
The administration's Office of Management and Budget sent a memo to the heads of the agencies on Thursday, calling on them to find areas where they could reduce spending. The memo was part of the administration's preparations for the 1999 fiscal year, which begins next July 1. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is to present his preliminary 1999 budget in January. 
 "We must deal with these budget gaps firmly and prudently," said the memo, which was signed by Joseph J. Lhota, the director of the city's Office of Management and Budget.
Randy M. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor for operations, said yesterday that the administration had sent this type of memo to city agencies every November since Mr. Giuliani became Mayor. Mr. Mastro referred to the process as an exercise that seeks to insure that agency officials are focused on containing spending.
"This approach has served us well over the last four years," Mr. Mastro said. "We intend to continue to hold the line on overall city spending and achieve economies of scale and savings wherever we can."
The Office of Management and Budget asked some agencies to consider cutting as much as 11 percent of the parts of their budgets that are financed by city tax revenues. It said the agencies should achieve any reductions in the number of workers through attrition or redeployment.
Although the goals for cuts are high, it is unlikely that they will be enacted, officials emphasized. The administration usually sets high targets for cuts and then carries out only a portion of them.
What is more, if the local economy continues to grow and Wall Street's profits do not sag, the city will end its 1998 fiscal year on June 30 with a large surplus. The administration could then roll the surplus into the 1999 fiscal year, helping to close a projected budget gap of $1.8 billion. The projected gaps for the two years after that are more than $2 billion annually.

HEADLINE: Bonds and Currency Take Turns On Seesaw as Stock Markets Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
A resurgence in global stock markets yesterday helped erase the remnants of Wall Street's midweek tumble, but the rebound was partly overshadowed by other volatility that hurt the dollar, buffeted bonds and sent gold prices down to 12 1/2-year lows.
The day of wild swings in the credit and currency markets resulted from rumors that Japan's Government and big financial institutions, which collectively own enormous amounts of United States Treasury bonds, will be forced to sell some to finance an economic revival plan and stabilize a wobbly banking system. 
 The frailty of Japan's economy was reflected in its stock market yesterday, which was conspicuously weak, falling 2.2 percent. The plunge in gold, which has been eroding in value for much of the year, reflected widespread fear that central banks were shedding some of their reserves before the metal declined even further. On Wednesday, Germany's Bundesbank, the second-largest holder of gold behind the United States, said it had lent some gold to traders. Last month, Switzerland said it planned to sell a substantial portion of its reserves.
Most stock investors, by contrast, enjoyed a day of resilience and price gains notably absent for many of the trading days since Oct. 27, when economic problems in Southeast Asia touched off a global rout that has been reverberating through financial markets ever since. Markets in Hong Kong, Singapore, Thailand and most other Southeast Asian countries stabilized or strengthened yesterday, as did markets in Europe and Latin America.
Wall Street analysts said that investors were finally beginning to conclude that the selloff in the United States, although much less severe than the one in Asia, was a little bit overdone. The favorable reaction helped push the Dow Jones industrial average up 84.72 points, or 1.13 percent, to 7,572.48, its second straight gain of more than 80 points. The advances more than erased the 157-point slide in the Dow on Wednesday and left the widely followed index down only 8.84 points for the week.
Broader indexes also gained. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 11.69 points, or 1.28 percent, to 928.35, and the Nasdaq composite index jumped 25.77, or 1.65 percent, to 1,583.51, led by technology stocks, a key factor in overall stock advances yesterday.
Despite continuing fears about a global economic slowdown, Byron R. Wien, the chief equity strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, said he expected share prices to continue to rise.
Mr. Wien, who for some time had considered prices excessively high, said that because of the recent setbacks, the market was no longer overvalued.
Stocks also were helped by favorable economic news that showed declines in consumer spending and benign inflation, suggesting that the economy is not expanding so quickly that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates.
At the same time, a widely followed consumer-sentiment survey conducted by the University of Michigan showed Americans were increasingly upbeat about the economy, suggesting that the stock market's gyrations are not causing them great concern.
"Everything pointed to a reasonably strong market today, and we got what we were expecting," said Philip J. Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management. "The overseas markets were healthy, and the economics here were healthy."
The stamina of the United States economy, particularly compared with that of Japan, also helped the dollar advance in early foreign-exchange trading to a six-month high of 127.25 yen. But late in the day, the dollar tumbled and settled at 125.62 yen, largely on the rumors of impending Japanese sales of Treasury securities.
Currency traders said the rumors were credible because of a string of evidence of a weakening Japanese economic and financial system.
On Thursday, for example, the IBCA ratings agency in London downgraded the credit ratings of three of Japan's biggest banks and said it might do the same to three other Japanese banks. Earlier in the week, reports arose that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin had written an extraordinary letter to his counterpart in Japan expressing deep concern about Japanese economic problems.
Treasury securities initially rallied on the reports showing slow growth, scant inflation and optimistic consumer sentiment, briefly pushing the yield on the 30-year bond, a barometer of interest-rate trends, to a 21-month low of 6.087 percent.
But the rumors of Japanese selling quickly erased those gains as other buyers turned into sellers, which depressed prices and pushed yields back up. That left the 30-year yield unchanged for the day at 6.10 percent.
Despite the volatility in the bond market yesterday, analysts said the underlying fundamentals point to further strength.
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and senior portfolio manager at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said the economy's strength and moribund inflation were potent reasons why the bond market could surge.
"There is little in the way of convincing hard evidence from the economy that says the Fed has to tighten," he said. Moreover, further skittishness in stocks could contribute to an investor migration to Treasuries.
The tumble in gold briefly pushed prices below $300 an ounce before it recovered slightly, but the metal still settled at its lowest level since March 1985. On the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, gold for December delivery fell $4.50 an ounce, or 1.5 percent, to $304.30. It was the biggest one-day drop since Switzerland announced on Oct. 31 that it planned to sell some gold.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 636 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

For Store Workers, Christmas Comes Early
From $100 signing bonuses to discounts on choice merchandise, workers hired by merchants for this year's holiday selling season are benefiting from acute labor shortages. The lowest unemployment level in a quarter century has forced retailers to offer extraordinary lures to attract part-time help.
 But the shortage of help could be trouble for shoppers, who may find that the customer-service and cashier lines in malls and stores in coming weeks are more aggravating than in previous seasons. Page A1.
 
Siemens Buying Westinghouse Unit
Westinghouse Electric sold its power-generation business to Siemens of Germany for $1.525 billion. In doing so, Westinghouse confirmed that it would sell its remaining industrial businesses instead of spinning them off into a separate company. Westinghouse will become a media company, and on Dec. 1, will change its name to CBS. D2. 

McClatchy Shares Tumble
Shares of McClatchy Newspapers lost 19.8 percent following the news that it would buy the Cowles Media Company, publisher of The Star Tribune of Minneapolis, for $1.4 billion, including $90 million of assumed debt. McClatchy plans to keep The Star Tribune and sell Cowles's other businesses. McClatchy shares fell $4.625, to $28. D3.
 
VW May Purchase Rolls-Royce
Volkswagen expressed interest in buying Rolls-Royce Motor Cars, setting up a possible bidding contest with German rival BMW for the luxury British auto maker. D3.
 
Waste Hauler Takes a Charge
Waste Management Inc. took a charge against earnings of $173 million before earnings and restated its accounts for the last two years. The action comes a month after its chief executive resigned abruptly after only three months on the job. D2.
 
Japanese Stimulus Plan
Stocks in Japan fell sharply after the ruling Liberal Democrats outlined a second plan to stimulate the economy. The plan disappointed investors because it did not mention income tax cuts or public works spending. D3.
 
Narrower Loss Recorded by TCI
Tele-Communications Inc.'s third-quarter loss was narrower than expected due to cost reductions and a renewed focus on the company's cable business. TCI stock rose 3.5 percent on the news to $24. The stock has risen 85 percent since a year ago. D3.
 
Top Court to Review Sex Bias Issue
The Supreme Court has agreed to decide when an employer can be held liable for a supervisor's sexual harassment of a lower-level employee. The issue has divided the lower courts in the decade since the Justices ruled that the creation of a hostile environment in the workplace, through pervasive sexual harassment, is a form of illegal sex discrimination. A11.
 
Business Criticizes Trade Red Tape Rival European and United States corporate executives who conferred in Rome recently agreed that duplicate regulations, not tariffs, hinder an expansion in trade. They proposed that if a product or factory passes inspection on one side of the Atlantic, it should be automatically accepted on the other. D14.
 
A $7.4 Billion Accounting Giant
Ernst & Young, the accounting firm, said that its domestic revenue for its fiscal year was $4.4 billion. Ernst & Young has agreed to merge with a rival, KPMG Peat Marwick, which has reported $3 billion in revenue. The merger partners have yet to agree on a name for the combined, $7.4 billion entity. D2.

Bill Would Delay New Bank Rules
Senator Lauch Faircloth, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee's subcommittee on financial institutions, introduced a bill that would stop new derivatives rules from the Financial Accounting Standards Board from taking effect for banks unless regulators first certify the standards. D14.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IS SENDING 2D CARRIER TO GULF

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
President Clinton signaled with words and with the dispatch of an aircraft carrier today that the United States is prepared to act -- with or without its allies -- to prevent Iraq from developing the ability to use chemical or biological weapons.
A day after the United Nations withdrew its weapons inspection team following Iraq's expulsion of the six American members, Mr. Clinton ordered the aircraft carrier George Washington and four other ships to the Persian Gulf, joining a fleet led by the carrier Nimitz. 
 The redeployment, a potent symbol, also bolstered the ability to strike Iraq hard, even if neighboring countries refuse permission to stage attacks from or over their lands.
Adding to an intensifying sense of confrontation, Mr. Clinton appeared twice at the White House today to issue stern warnings to President Saddam Hussein to back down and allow United Nations inspectors to resume their searches. He called Iraq's pursuit of major weapons systems "one of the three or four most significant security threats that all of our people will face."
At one point Mr. Clinton suggested that the United States was prepared to maintain sanctions against Iraq as long as Mr. Hussein remained. "What he has just done," the President said, referring to the expulsions, "is to insure that the sanctions will be there till the end of time, or as long as he lasts."
One of the biggest hurdles the Administration faces in garnering support has been a growing sense that the sanctions are hurting ordinary Iraqis, and a growing realization that Mr. Hussein has little reason to cooperate, given the the dim prospects that the sanctions will end soon.
The President's remarks undercut those diplomatic efforts, which continued with some urgency today.
Mr. Clinton met at the White House with King Hussein of Jordan, who "loosely related" the lack of support from Arab allies to frustration over the stalled Middle East peace talks, a senior Administration official said.
In Scotland, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright met with Britain's Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, who announced that Britain had ordered an aircraft carrier, the Invincible, to the Mediterranean from the Caribbean and put a squadron of Harrier jets on heightened alert.
"Our strategy is to combine intensive diplomacy with a robust military presence in the Gulf, which we are convinced is the best way to convince Saddam Hussein to reverse course," Ms. Albright said in London, where she met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in an attempt to to revive the peace talks.
It will take at least a week for the George Washington to reach the Persian Gulf. Short of a direct Iraqi threat to American aircraft -- including U-2 spy planes, which are to resume flying over central Iraq for the United Nations as early as Sunday -- it does not appear military action is imminent.
But in Iraq, the Government appeared to brace for an attack. Television broadcasts show families gathering in one of Mr. Hussein's palaces to act as shields, for example.
In a news conference at the Pentagon, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Henry H. Shelton, called the redeployment "a prudent measure to demonstrate how seriously the U.S. takes both this challenge to the authority of the U.N., and also the continued pursuit of these dangerous weapons" by Iraq.
The United States still does not have assurances from the Saudis that they will allow attacks from Saudi Arabia, where more than 100 American planes are based, even though Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen has consulted with the Saudis, an Administration official said.
The Administration is also seeking Saudi support to dispatch an "air expeditionary force" of 20 to 30 fighter jets and bombers to the region, officials said. The force, which could use equipment already in Saudi Arabia, could support long-range B-52 bombers and possibly B-1's, which have never flown in combat.
Having the George Washington in the gulf with the Nimitz will double the number of fighters and bombers that could attack Iraq without crossing any country's airspace. The United States will also have more than a dozen ships capable of firing cruise missiles deep into Iraq.
But keeping the emphasis on diplomacy, Mr. Clinton promised to "work intensively with our allies and our friends in the region" to force Mr. Hussein to change course. He said he would be calling world leaders, and aides said they would include President Jacques Chirac of France and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, whose governments have opposed military action now.
Ms. Albright is also expected to meet with her counterparts in Europe and the Mideast before attending an economic conference in Qatar and then going to India and Pakistan.
In Turkey, where the United States and Britain have about 50 planes patrolling northern Iraq, Foreign Minister Ismail Cem said the United States had not asked for permission to launch attacks on Iraq.
"I would prefer that nobody asks us something which will be considered hostile by any other power," he said. "But these are realities. If these realities emerge, we will make the correct choice, the rational choice."
Despite the sanctions imposed after the gulf war and several military strikes by the United States since then, President Hussein has continued to defy the United Nations. In the latest confrontation, he has all but dared the United States and its allies to retaliate.
Wary of the eroding will at the United Nations for military retaliation, Mr. Clinton and his aides repeatedly denounced Iraq's efforts to build biological weapons.
The President's aides have decided on this strategy as a way to shift attention from the suffering of Iraq's people to the consequences of Iraq's ability to make weapons of mass destruction. "This is a crisis of Saddam's making," Mr. Clinton said. "It can be unmade only when he can no longer threaten the international community with weapons of mass destruction."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At the White House yesterday, the President announced dispatch of a second carrier to the Persian Gulf. Samuel R. Berger, left, the national security adviser, and Erskine B. Bowles, the chief of staff, also attended. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)(pg. A1)
 
Chart/Map: "OVERVIEW: Steaming Toward the Gulf"
The United States has considerable forces in the Persian Gulf region that could be used against Iraq, including about 18,500 troops. Last year the United States used long-range B-52's to fire missiles at Iraq.
 
TURKEY -- As part of its patrols of the northern no-flight zone over Iraq, the United States has 28 fighter jets 2/3-- F-16's and F-15's 2/3-- and other support aircraft based at Incirlik, Turkey. Britain and Turkey also patrol the zone from the base, bringing the number of aircraft to about 50, with about 1,400 troops supporting them.
 
SAUDI ARABIA AND KUWAIT -- The U.S. Air Force and Army have about 120 combat and support aircraft as well as weapons and personnel at various bases in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.
 
EN ROUTE -- The carrier George Washington and other ships are en route to the Persian Gulf from the Mediterranean.
 
PERSIAN GULF -- The Nimitz carrier group includes 50 F-14's and F-18's and 27 other planes and helicopters. There are also two cruisers, four destroyers, three frigates and an attack submarine. All but the frigates are capable of firing cruise missiles like the Tomahawk, which have a range of 500 miles.

HEADLINE: A Package Deal Reduces Railroad Fares, but Not for All Commuters

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Nov. 14

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has an offer that many suburban commuters are finding hard to resist: Buy $60 worth of bus and subway fares on a Metrocard and get a 9 percent discount on a monthly rail ticket.
But some commuters who have no need for a Metrocard say that the deal, which starts in January, is unfair, and they are talking about taking legal action. 
 One such critic is Robin Schneider-Weissbratten, who rides the Long Island Rail Road every workday but does not use the city transit system. When she began commuting 20 years ago, she said, she chose to work in the garment industry so she could save on subway fares. Today she still commutes from Hicksville to Pennsylvania Station, then walks a few blocks to her job in textile sales in the garment district.
"Why should I pay more for my train ticket than the person sitting next to me, just because they take a subway to Wall Street?" said Ms. Schneider-Weissbratten. "We both take up the same amount of space, we both take a seat. It's discrimination." She hopes that riders who walk to and from the train stations will join together in a class-action lawsuit.
A co-worker, Joan V. Zuckerman of Valley Stream, agreed: "Whoever thought of this plan, I just don't think it makes sense. It's not fair."
Under the plan, the reduced fares will apply to any commuter who buys $60 worth of city transit rides on the Metrocard on the back of the monthly train ticket. Those tickets must be purchased through the Mail and Ride service of the Long Island Rail Road or the Metro-North Commuter Railroad.
In addition to the discounted train tickets, customers will get a bonus of four free subway or bus rides a month. The tickets and any unused credit for transit rides will expire at the end of each month.
The transportation authority said it adopted the discounts to reduce transfer costs for people who use both suburban trains and city subways or buses, to reward these high-volume users and to help the regional economy by making longer trips easier for working people.
"We are trying to do as much as we can for as many people as we can, but there will always be someone who is not satisfied," said the M.T.A.'s deputy executive director, Christopher P. Boylan. "The private sector offers people discounts based on volume, and now people who use our system more will get a discount."
Although some people have called in complaints, the general response to the discount has been favorable, transportation officials said.
"Everybody that came to the M.T.A. hearings loved it," Mr. Boylan said. In the first week of enrollment earlier this month, 8,500 riders signed up, which he said "is really quite good." The authority says it hopes for greater use of Mail and Ride because it is more efficient than ticket windows and machines.
So far, the reaction of commuter and transit advocates is mixed. One key supporter is the executive director of the Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee to the M.T.A., Beverly Dolinsky. She likened the discount to the time-honored marketing ploy that "if you buy a dozen of something, you get an extra one thrown in free."
Another commuter advocate said he favored modifying and expanding the incentives. "We have urged free transfers to the buses and subways," said the chairman of the L.I.R.R. Commuters Council, Larry Silverman, who sits on the M.T.A. board. "And I don't think the program should be limited to the Mail and Ride customers. The bottom line is to get people out of cars and onto trains."
The sharpest attack came from Joseph G. Rappaport, coordinator of the Straphangers Campaign for city transit riders. Because of unequal government subsidies, city transit riders already pay a bigger share of operating costs than suburban commuters do, and he said the discount worsens the imbalance. The discount also rolls back the 1995 commuter fare increase, he said, while the Metrocard bonuses of 11 rides for the price of 10, to take effect in January, will only partly offset the last transit fare increase.
"What is it with the M.T.A. that they just can't be fair?" Mr. Rappaport said. "It's another slap in the face of city residents who ride the subways and buses, who once again are getting a raw deal."
Critics also contend that since the discount is based on a percentage, it benefits long-distance commuters the most. On Metro-North, for example, the monthly ticket for the shortest trip, to 125th Street in Harlem, costs $94 monthly, with a discount of about $102 a year. For the longest ride, to the Waterbury area in Connecticut, the monthly ticket is $283, with a discount of about $306 a year. The four bonus Metrocard rides a month add up to about $72 a year.
"I would prefer a free transfer and to see it applied evenly," Mr. Silverman said.
Ms. Schneider-Weissbratten said that although she has no objection to giving commuters a break on city transit fares, she drew the line at two-tiered commuter fares.
After she wrote to the L.I.R.R. to complain, an official called her, she said. "He said this was the only equitable way to do it," she said. "I said, 'Equitable to whom?' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robin Schneider-Weissbratten says a fare discount is unfair because it excludes commuters like her who walk to and from city train stations. (Linda Rosier for The New York Times)(pg. B5)

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Loving and Hating Those Big Dream Machines

BYLINE: BY BRENT STAPLES

 BODY:
Some fathers joined the Elks, the Masons or Rotary. But during the 1960's my father, my grandfather and my uncles belonged to the Big Wheels, a club of men who drove trucks for a living and for whom the very act of breathing required vehicular motion. Every fourth Sunday the Big Wheels put on their sharpest suits and motored to meetings in Lincolns, Buicks and Cadillacs, the biggest, curviest, most lusted-after cars in American history.
Massively substantial dream machines symbolized prosperity and promise for men who had lived through the Depression and a war before landing in the fat and sassy 50's. Going into debt for such a car seemed as American and as righteous as tithing for the church. When a Big Wheel bought a new car, the rest gathered fervently around it, drinking in the rhapsodic lines, the chrome-laden hugeness. Those of us who were children then are in our 40's now, and it should come as no surprise that we are magnetically drawn to big cars. 
 This affection for enormous machines explains why the S.U.V., or sport utility vehicle, is flying out of showrooms even as the sages demonize it. Owners of small cars fear being crushed by S.U.V.'s. Environmentalists condemn them as gas-guzzlers. These are serious concerns. But beyond them lies a snide condescension toward the owners -- and an ignorance of the culture-wide habits that produced the bulk-up.
Americans accepted small, "sensible" cars but never embraced them. Detroit's early economy efforts -- Corvair, Falcon, Valiant -- were immediately bulked up because Americans declined to buy them small. Japanese imports have gone the same way, starting out as specks and ending up indistinguishable from bigger American models.
Subcompacts are underwhelming to consumers. The big three auto makers have to offer them at a loss to induce us to drive them. By contrast, virtually all of Detroit's profits now come from big cars that evade Federal conservation laws by posing as "light trucks."
Contempt for small cars is emotional at its core, but carries at least a facade of rationality. Small cars are noisier, harder to handle in bad weather, and worst of all you feel every bump. But even if small cars were impeccably made, they would collide with my generation's ancestral memory that an authentic car should be big and comfy -- and indistinguishable from the family living room. The mini-van failed in this regard because it is tinny, underpowered and dowdy. Its bread-loaf shape shouts "suburban runabout" and connotes a middle-aged driver on a trip to the supermarket. The sport utility vehicle's brutish appearance and pachyderm bulk resonate with a cultural archetype. It equals power, youth and virility in the male buyer's mind. The appeal is clearly subliminal, and as stealthy as a pheromone.
The Land Cruiser, Range Rover and Suburban have been beaten up pretty badly, but the worst is reserved for the Navigator, which just rolled off the line at 5,600 pounds, more than 17 feet long -- and 15 miles per gallon of gas. This is sorry mileage. But what's really sorry is Federal law that forbids it in a car but permits it in a "light truck."
To see even the Navigator as aberrantly large or irrational is to forget an entire century of auto making and, more personally, the Sunday auto worship I shared with my father and the Big Wheels. American cars are, inescapably, more than transport. They have historically been touchstones for both personal and cultural aspiration. Americans drove right into the 80's in sedans longer than any utility vehicle on the market or station wagons no less wide. General motors built its largest cars ever -- just under 20 feet -- in the teeth of the 70's, with several models only a hair shorter than the Cadillacs that traditionally topped the size charts. If not for the oil crisis, they all would have gotten wider and heavier still.
The new big cars are no more irrational than the cars that have obsessed Americans throughout the century. The persistence of S.U.V. sales in the face of assault on their safety suggests that these affections are not fading. Indeed, the pachyderms thronging through city streets show that the Big Wheel impulse runs very, very deep.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

LENGTH: 1412 words

HEADLINE: For U.S. Retailers, Grinch Brings a Tight Job Market

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Godiva Chocolatier is practically giving away candy to new employees. Managers at a Sears, Roebuck & Company store in Detroit are offering recruiting bonuses of $100. And August Max Woman, a clothing company, has raised part-time wages as much as 20 percent.
These are some of the lengths to which American retailers are going to attract help for the Christmas season. Low levels of unemployment not seen in more than a quarter of a century and the glowing health of other industries offering better-paying jobs have combined to create the most difficult holiday season in memory for retailers looking for extra sales help. 
 "I would say this is one of the most significant challenges retailers have faced in recent decades," said Bruce Van Kleeck, a vice president of the National Retail Federation, the industry's trade group. "The employment situation is so good for the United States not a lot of people are seeking jobs."
It is too soon to tell just how much this employee shortage will hurt the retail industry. But some implications are already clear. Offering steep discounts to seasonal employees and lifting wages may squeeze retailing profits, particularly if sales this holiday season are anything less than stellar.
A bigger question for the public is how the shortage will affect customer service. Shoppers -- many of whom already take a dim view of the service they receive in most retail stores -- may be in for longer lines at the cash register and fewer people to answer questions and help find merchandise in the right size and color. It is already easy to imagine plenty of harried consumers vowing to get their shopping done before Halloween next year.
"Anyone who puts in an application will be getting an interview," said Robin Lanier, a spokeswoman for the International Mass Retail Association, which represents 61,000 stores run by mass retailers.
"If you don't have the sheer numbers of bodies, leave aside the quality of people, it can be bad for service," she conceded.
"You also have the problem of turnover," Ms. Lanier added. "Younger employees are coming to work, then they suddenly get a better offer down the street and someone you were counting on has moved to someone else."
The national unemployment rate fell to 4.7 percent in October, the lowest since 1973, and some metropolitan areas like Minneapolis and Atlanta report jobless figures closer to 2.5 percent. For retailers, who usually try to increase their payrolls by 4 percent to 15 percent during the Christmas shopping season, the pool of available workers is looking increasingly shallow.
"Restaurants, movie theaters and hotels that generally attract the same type of individuals we do are all doing exceptionally well," said Mr. Van Kleeck of the national trade group. "So there is lots of competition for people."
In addition to offering higher wages and deeper employee discounts, retailers have resorted to such strategies as enticing retirees into the stores to wrap gifts and urging their own non-sales employees to earn overtime pay on the selling floor on weekends.
"We are definitely having to look harder for good people," said Bob Arruda, the store manager at the Bombay Company in Stamford, Conn. He said the company this year would offer 30 percent employee discounts to part-time help, compared with 20 percent last year. Bombay will also give, for the first time, a $75 bonus to any part-time worker who finishes the season.
Even temporary employment agencies, which have generally not provided labor for retailers' selling floors, are getting in on the action. Donald Stallard, the chief executive of Reserves Network in Cleveland, said that 5 percent to 10 percent of his 3,000 clients are now retailers looking for sales help. A few years ago, practically no retailers were using his agency.
For people like college students or the unemployed who cannot find full-time jobs, working in retail during the holiday season has long been a good way to earn extra money. That does not mean, though, that it is the most attractive place to work.
After the department store consolidations in the 1980's, many stores became stingier about sales commissions, especially for part-time help. Further, the pay is mediocre, the work can be demanding (pulling down 35 shirts for a snappish shopper who ends up buying nothing is nobody's idea of a good time), and the typical evening and weekend hours can be awkward to integrate with family life.
Pay is the easiest to change. A lot of retailers, used to paying little more than the minimum wage of $5.15 an hour plus commissions, are suddenly being forced to offer more.
"I would say that 25 percent to 30 percent of mall stores are luring them in with $6 to $8.50 an hour," said Karen MacDonald, a spokeswoman for Taubman Centers, a real estate investment trust based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., that owns shopping centers.
"Before, retailers never felt they had to offer higher than minimum wage. But it is an employee's market this year, and they have to work hard to keep them happy because there are so many other options out there."
At August Max Woman, a division of the Casual Corner Group, the starting hourly wage has been bumped from $5.50 to $5.75 or $6.75, depending on an applicant's experience. Target Stores, a unit of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, is offering higher pay to those prepared to work the least desired shifts. "If you have Sunday from 2 to 8, which is a difficult period, we might put an additional dollar an hour on those shifts," said Steve Kenady, the regional personnel director for Target.
Merchants are also offering juicier discounts for seasonal help. The Best Buy Company, an electronics retailer, lets holiday employees take 10 percent off right away instead of waiting the usual 30 days. The 10 percent discount at Target can now be used at Dayton Hudson's other stores, too. Godiva offers a whopping 50 percent discount, and a promise of fun on the job. "Who doesn't like chocolate?" asked Lisa George, the company's senior human resources director.
Melody Vaughn, who was hired to work as a sales clerk at a Pottery Barn in the Lenox Square Mall in Atlanta for the holiday season, said: "Being able to get a 20 percent discount at the holidays is the most important thing to me. Now I plan on buying all my Christmas gifts here. And working in a fun place with great discounts is better than a restaurant, where you smell."
Merchants are also resorting to clever recruiting methods. Best Buy gives any employee who refers help $100, up from $50. At the Sears in suburban Detroit, managers are offering $100 to charities that bring in candidates for seasonal employment. The Kmart Corporation solicits seasonal help through fliers inserted with its credit card bills. Many mall developers have set up on-site employment centers like the one at the Mall at Tuttle Crossing in Dublin, Ohio.
Retired people are another target group. Some retailers have sent recruiters to community centers or set up job fairs to persuade retirees to work for the season. "We find for some of our departments seniors do very well," said Jan Drummond, a spokeswoman for Sears. "Our customers like the maturity they bring to the job."
Indeed, Kimlah Hyatt, 60, a retired social services employee, said she could have had her pick of retail jobs and was thrilled to land a spot at Godiva in the Regency Square mall in Richmond.
"I have never had the opportunity to sell a beautiful product like chocolate," Ms. Hyatt said. "I got the best. The other people will have to take the dregs."
And if retailers cannot get help from the outside, they are happy to dangle carrots for those within. "A lot of corporate employees need extra cash at Christmas," said Marcy Jensen, the corporate recruiter for Best Buy. "We sat back and said, 'Why do we want them going to a Kmart when we need them in our own stores?' So, for the first year, we let them work evenings or weekends in the stores." Other merchants said they were offering similar programs.
But Wall Street, which has never paid much attention to the cost of part-time help, may be blind-sided if the shortage of help hurts retailers' bottom lines.
"Although it is difficult to assign a number," said Richard L. Church, a retail analyst at Smith Barney, "wage pressures increase selling costs. That is one factor that keeps me more cautious relative to others in terms of how good a season it is going to be."

HEADLINE: Albright Expresses Irritation After Talks With Netanyahu

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright expressed some irritation today with the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, saying after long talks with him that Israeli and American interests required faster movement toward Middle East peace.
"I made clear that for the sake of the Middle East peace process and for our broader mutual interests in the region, it is time for us to move on the peace process," Ms. Albright said at a joint news conference with Mr. Netanyahu. With America's moderate Arab allies distancing themselves from Washington at a time of crisis in Iraq, she called for "a greater sense of urgency" on the part of Israelis and Palestinians. 
 "I believe it is essential for both sides to live up to agreements and not to make any steps that make it more complicated to move the process forward," she said, then repeated firmly, "It is time to move the process forward."
Ms. Albright meets the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, on Saturday in Bern, Switzerland, to try for some visible progress before she makes a brief stop on Sunday at an American-sponsored Middle Eastern economic conference in Doha, Qatar, that major Arab nations are boycotting.
 The Palestinian Authority will also boycott the conference, The Associated Press reported from Gaza. The decision was made Friday by the Authority's cabinet and legislative council, the A.P. said.
American officials say the lack of progress between Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat caused that boycott, which is embarrassing to Washington and is damaging the American and Israeli positions in the region -- especially as Washington finds itself in a confrontation with Iraq.
Even the Israeli Foreign Minister, David Levy, has said he will not go to Doha, which Mr. Netanyahu denied was an insult to Ms. Albright, because the Israeli Minister for Trade, Natan Sharansky, is still going. Ms. Albright, for her part, said she would attend the Doha conference "because America keeps its word."
Ms. Albright said that her conversations with Mr. Netanyahu here were "useful," but that she would "reserve judgment" until she discovers how Mr. Arafat reacts to Mr. Netanyahu's positions. She said she would repeat similar admonitions to Mr. Arafat.
Mr. Netanyahu said Israel is "committed to keep our side of the agreements, and we'd like to see similar commitments from the other side."
Arab diplomats say Mr. Netanyahu's hesitation to carry out measures already agreed upon, like an airport and seaport in Gaza, is made worse by his clear reluctance to withdraw more troops from the West Bank, as he was to do in September.
Ms. Albright is meeting Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat to try to consolidate and build on the limited progress made in Washington last week in talks between Israeli and Palestinian negotiators, "to try to avoid the usual dissipation and slippage" that follows such talks, a senior American official said.

HEADLINE: Dominicans May Allow Voting Abroad

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG and LARRY ROHTER 

 BODY:
In a move that promises to turn the Dominican immigrant community in New York City into a powerful electoral force in its homeland, the Dominican Government is poised to grant its citizens abroad the right to vote from polling places where they live.
While planeloads of Dominicans have routinely flown home from New York City to vote in presidential elections, their numbers have been too tiny to make an impact. This move, however, would instantly give the Dominican community in New York City the second-largest concentration of votes in any Dominican election, exceeded only by Santo Domingo, the capital. 
 For years, Dominican immigrants, whose weekly financial remittances are vital to their homeland's economic survival, have argued that denying them the right to vote from their new homes amounts to a variation on taxation without representation. And yesterday, many, particularly those who bankroll the political parties themselves, cheered the imminent change in their status. The voting-rights measure, which is working its way through the Dominican Congress and is expected to be signed by its President, would grant even naturalized American citizens of Dominican descent the right to vote and to run for office.
"It's about time," said Nelson Camacho, 52, the owner of a car service in Washington Heights. He has lived in New York City since 1980 but returns to the Dominican Republic at least twice a year for visits and now plans to run from New York for a Congressional seat there.
"This will legitimize us," he said. "This will mean that we have not lost our status as Dominicans by coming here and helping our motherland to survive and prosper. Culturally, we are one with the people who remain at home, and legally, there is no reason to make any distinction either."
Some Dominicans in New York reacted anxiously to the news. They expressed concern that the measure would keep new immigrants tethered to the politics of their homeland, preventing them from integrating themselves into their new lives. It could keep them looking backward, they said.
"If this ends up meaning that Dominicans here have less enthusiasm for participating politically here, it will have been counterproductive," said Moises Perez, executive director of the Alianza Dominicana, a social-service organization in Washington Heights. "We have limited funds. If we end up sending them disproportionately to the Dominican Republic, not just to our families but to political parties as well, it weakens our position here."
At least 15 percent of the Dominican Republic's population of 7.5 million lives abroad, with some 500,000 Dominicans in New York City (not all of whom would be eligible to vote). Some 30,000 to 40,000 immigrants arrive in New York every year, and they are the most likely to keep alive their ties by voting.
Well aware of the clout of its dollars, the Dominican population in New York spearheaded the campaign to extend voting rights to the approximately one million Dominicans who live abroad.
"As soon as we are able to vote from the United States, we will change the entire politics of the country," said Fernando Mateo, a Manhattan businessman who is the leader of a group called the Pro-Vote Movement for Dominicans Living Abroad. "This is something that is going to change the whole mind-set of the country, because we will be the ones who make the difference."
Some Dominicans in New York are self-centered in their goals; they want to use their vote to pressure politicians to reform laws that make them second-class citizens, economically, when they invest in their homeland or retire there.
The voting-rights measure, part of a broader electoral reform package, was unanimously approved last week by the Dominican Senate and has broad support in the lower house of the Dominican Congress. President Leonel Fernandez Reyna, who grew up on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and still holds an American residency permit, or green card, is expected to sign the measure.
"He is himself a product of that community," said Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, who ran against Mr. Fernandez but is also a supporter of the plan.
If approved, the proposal would go into effect in 2000, when the next Presidential election is scheduled. As currently structured, the legislation would also make it possible for Dominicans living abroad to vote in congressional elections, beginning as early as 2002.
All three principal Dominican political parties already have regional offices in New York City. Since the 1980's, Dominican presidential candidates have regularly campaigned in the city, courting investors. Three years ago, bowing to pressure from New Yorkers, the Dominican Republic adopted constitutional reforms that recognized the right to dual citizenship, paving the way for this electoral reform.
The clout of New York's Dominicans was apparent when Mr. Mateo made a recent visit to his homeland, meeting with influential members of Congress and delivering a tough message: "No vote, no more money," as one Dominican government official summarized it.
"From now on, if you want to win, you'll also have to campaign here and understand the needs of Dominicans living here," Mr. Mateo said.
One proposal to expand the electoral reform calls for creating new Congressional seats to represent Dominicans abroad.
The mechanics of how and where votes would be cast remains unclear. Several Latin American countries, most notably Colombia, already allow their citizens living abroad to vote in presidential elections, typically from the nearest consulate. But because the Dominican community in the United States is so large, such an arrangement has already been ruled out.
Adriano Espaillat, a New York State Assemblyman who represents Washington Heights, said he planned to ask for help from local election boards and in other cities with large Dominican populations, and to request the use of polling sites at schools and churches.
Mr. Espaillat said his only concern was that, with the right to vote, the politics of the Dominican Republic would prove too great a distraction to Dominicans in New York. "We don't want this to be divisive or disruptive or to lead to a split in our community among Dominican party lines," he said.
But Ramona Hernandez, a Brooklyn resident who teaches Latino studies at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, said many young Dominican-Americans, those born or raised here, are too distant from the politics of the Dominican Republic to be divided by its party politics.
"Their mind is basically here," she said.
Mr. Perez agreed. "Unless the current rate of immigration continues, this is a plan that will affect one or two generations only," he said. "Twenty years from now, Dominicans will be concerned about leaving their mark here, not there, and the influence of this legislation will diminish."

HEADLINE: Asian-Americans Set To Flex Political Muscle

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14

 BODY:
For leaders of Asian-American organizations, the outcome of the 1996 elections promised to be a turning point. Voters chose two governors of Asian-Pacific descent, and in California, home to nearly half the nation's Asian-Americans, turnout among them reached record levels. Hopes rose that an Asian-American would win a Cabinet post in the Clinton Administration.
Instead, Asian-Americans have faced a solid year of bad publicity over campaign finance, and this week their hopes for a path-breaking appointment were stuck, at least for the moment, in the stymieing of Bill Lann Lee's nomination to be Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, his candidacy a casualty of partisan fighting over affirmative action. 
 But now, in law offices and civic organizations around the country, Asian-Americans are not only vowing to join the White House in pressing on for Mr. Lee. They are hoping that his setback will prove a catalyst to greater political involvement by a rapidly growing minority that has struggled for years with its stereotype as a "model," and are busy organizing voter registration and education drives to exercise their power.
"The experience with Bill's nomination has again brought home to the community that it's not enough to achieve, it's not enough to be respected in your field," said Karen Narasaki, executive director of the National Asian Pacific American Legal Consortium, a civil rights group in Washington that has helped lead the fight for Mr. Lee's confirmation.
"This has been another wake-up call that if we're going to actually be at the table, and to have Asian-Americans in high levels in the government, people are going to have to become more politically engaged than they were before," Ms. Narasaki said. "That may not take the form of increasing donations to political parties, but more involvement in the grass-roots political work of the community."
The nomination fight that has galvanized many Asian-Americans shows no signs of abating in Washington, where the White House chief of staff, Erskine B. Bowles, said of Mr. Lee today, "I assure you he will be the next Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights." Other White House officials said President Clinton had not decided whether to use powers enabling him to appoint Mr. Lee during the Senate's adjournment, or whether instead to wait until next year to continue the fight.
From the backbreaking work of building the transcontinental railroad to the high-tech triumphs of the Silicon Valley, the Asian-American experience has been a bittersweet blend. Partly because of immigration quotas and laws that until the 1950's barred Asians from naturalized citizenship, their economic advancement and academic achievement have long outpaced political involvement and electoral success.
But slowly, the sheer realities of demographics are beginning to change that. Asian-Pacific Americans now make up 10 percent of the population in California, which itself is home to about 40 percent of the nation's 7.2 million Asian-Americans. Asian-American turnout at the California polls hovered for years between 2 and 4 percent of the statewide electorate, but it rose to 5 percent in 1996, and by just after the turn of the century, some experts predict, it will reach 10 percent.
National surveys have repeatedly shown Asian-Americans to be among the most independent of voters, evenly divided as a group in party registration and splitting their ballots among candidates and issues case by case, with particular attention to immigration and civil rights.
In 1996, for example, surveys of Vietnamese-Americans leaving the polls in Orange County found a 2-to-1 registration advantage for Republicans but only a 54-to-46-percent edge for Bob Dole over Bill Clinton, and 70 percent opposition to Proposition 209, the ballot initiative that barred race- and sex-based preferences in public hiring and contracting, according to Stewart Kwoh, executive director of the Asian Pacific American Legal Center here.
"Generally we find that Asian-Americans don't really have a strong party affiliation; they really go to specific issues and candidates," said Mr. Kwoh, whose group held a "summit" of about 70 community leaders last Saturday to begin a permanent voter registration drive modeled on the Southwest Voter Registration Education Project, a group that has registered nearly 1.5 million Hispanic voters since 1992.
The Asian-American population is an amalgam of diverse ethnicities and national origins, and subgroups affiliate differently, Mr. Kwoh said, with Vietnamese-Americans tending to be Republican, Filipinos solidly Democratic and Chinese-Americans split among Republicans, Democrats and independents. But he and others say support for the Lee nomination and anger at the tactics of Mr. Lee's Republican opponents have spread across party lines.
All this leaves independent political experts wondering why Republicans, already so stung by Hispanic voters in states like California on questions of immigration, would risk alienating another emerging voter group by opposing Mr. Lee's nomination on political and policy grounds, even while acknowledging that he is well qualified for the post.
"I cannot conceive that they haven't figured this out," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political analyst at the Claremont Graduate School. "I mean, how many times do these people have to be hit in between the eyes with a two-by-four before they figure out the arithmetic?"
Don T. Nakanishi, the director of the Asian American Studies Center at the University of California at Los Angeles, who was a classmate of Mr. Lee at Yale 30 years ago, said he expected that "this extraordinary ideological controversy" over the nomination would prove to be a watershed in Asian-American political involvement.
"I think there's bitterness out there, but I also think in some ways maybe the campaign finance controversy, as well as what Bill's gone through, will become a rite of passage," Professor Nakanishi said. "One of the lessons clearly is that politics can be a rough game, and that in trying to advocate for Bill it has nothing to do with his education or his qualifications. It's politics.
"In that sense," he added, "I think we'll take things a lot less for granted, in terms of organizing and in being much firmer in terms of the kinds of commitments we want for the support we offer."
Although Asian-Americans have often parted company with other minority groups on political issues, the controversy over the nomination of Mr. Lee, long the Western regional director of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, has forged some new alliances. Opposition to his candidacy has been led by Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, and leaders of the small Asian-American community in Salt Lake City have linked up for the first time with the local N.A.A.C.P. chapter to support the nomination.
"They learned there were so many more things they could have been doing" with such an alliance, said Ms. Narasaki, of the Asian Pacific American Legal Consortium. "We hope to try to use this as an opportunity to keep building cooperation."
Ms. Narasaki recounted one brief moment in her own education in realpolitik. On Thursday, as she and other supporters of Mr. Lee, along with opponents, waited in a long line outside the Senate Judiciary Committee's hearing room in Washington, hoping to get in to watch deliberations, Clint Bolick, vice president for litigation at the Institute for Justice, a leading foe of the nomination, escorted a group in the back door as guests of Mr. Hatch.
"We didn't realize there was a reservation system," said Ms. Narasaki, who ultimately managed to talk her own way in. "How ironic that Clint Bolick was talking about preferences and favoritism, and that's what happens."
Bruce L. Ishimatsu, former president of the Asian Pacific Bar of California, said the fight over Mr. Lee meant that Asian-Americans would now work harder to cultivate candidates for office.
"We have been good citizens," he said. "We have been good contributors to the political process, and we're getting blasted for it. You will start to see some changes, targeting of offices for election and so on. There is a growing feeling in the community that we are virtually outsiders when it comes to the powers in government."

HEADLINE: Chinese Puzzle

BYLINE: By Lucian W. Pye; Lucian W. Pye is the Ford Professor of Political Science emeritus at M.I.T. and the author of numerous studies of Chinese political culture, including "Asian Power and Politics."

 BODY:

UNDERSTANDING
 CHINA
 A Guide to China's
 Economy, History,
 and Political Structure.
 By John Bryan Starr.
 Maps. 338 pp. New York:
 Hill & Wang. $25. 
 The American public has been put on notice that the big story of the 21st century is going to be the emergence of an awakened China. There remains, however, considerable uncertainty over how this prospect affects our long-held, contradictory stereotypes of a worthy, "good" China and a despicable, "bad" China. The periodic television reports on China tend to engage in overkill -- as with the Tiananmen Square massacre and the reversion of Hong Kong -- leaving the public in need of more balanced and nuanced information.
"Understanding China," by John Bryan Starr, based on a seminar he taught for 17 years at Yale University, provides an excellent introduction to China for anyone in search of solid but concise information about that complicated country.
Packed with facts and figures, but enlivened with firsthand observations, Starr's book is straightforward and unpretentious, like the presentations of an informed tour guide. He sticks closely to the facts and avoids theoretical interpretations that are not tethered to evidence.
Starr's approach is to identify the fundamental problems confronting China today and then to ask whether the Chinese political system is up to the task of resolving them. He strives to be fair and sympathetic, even to the point of giving weight to the Chinese views about human rights, and he calls for a supportive United States policy that goes beyond simple "engagement." Yet in the end, he says that China's intractable problems are going to be too much for the current political system.
By the time he has finished reviewing the problems of environmental degradation, inadequate infrastructure, population growth, failed state-owned enterprises, underfinanced education and the recent rise in both rural and urban discontent, he has no alternative but to reach what I would call a cautiously pessimistic position. "In sum," he writes, "China has a protracted and problematical time ahead."
The future, Starr contends, cannot be a continuation of the Deng era. Nor, he says, will there be a return to Maoist policies. He also rejects the possibility of China following the Taiwan model of a transition to democracy. "At the moment," he states, "there are no signs in China of a visionary and powerful leader ready to launch a move toward democratization. . . . Also lacking is a strong commitment to democracy on the part of a politically aware and active public."
He is not entirely comfortable with his conclusion: that the most likely prospect for China is an eventual collapse of the party-state system, a development that he believes could be followed by the People's Liberation Army taking on a semi-praetorian role.
It is easy to arrive at more optimistic forecasts for China by focusing on the many positive developments there and by playing down the troublesome, negative ones. What makes Starr's account important is that he has tried hard to balance all the positives and negatives, yet cannot escape a gloomy conclusion.
Still, the striking contrast between the concreteness of Starr's descriptions and the uncertainties about China's future highlights a troublesome contradiction that bedevils any attempt at prediction. Everyone knows that China is ruled not by law but by men, yet the leaders operate in secrecy, and so we have little basis for judging them. Instead, we end up overanalyzing the formal organization of the Government, even though we know it is less important than the personal relations of the rulers. Starr has effectively identified the problems China faces, but he is unable to tell us whether its future rulers will have the ability to muddle through, keeping China on an upward course. This rather more optimistic view requires stronger faith in China's system of rule-by-men than he is able to muster.
