SECTION: Section 7; Page 10; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1510 words

HEADLINE: A Long Way From the Back of the Bus

BYLINE: By James Q. Wilson; James Q. Wilson is the author of "Moral Judgment" and "The Moral Sense."

 BODY:

THE ORDEAL
 OF INTEGRATION
 Progress and Resentment in America's "Racial" Crisis.
 By Orlando Patterson.
 233 pp. Washington:
 Civitas Counterpoint. $24.50. 
 Three decades after the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1965, it seems that an intellectual defense of racial integration still needs to be written. Although most Americans, black and white, now judge people as unique individuals and not as racial symbols (this is the chief lesson of our contemporary racial transformation), too many, including many prominent leaders, continue to believe that symbols are all that matter. Orlando Patterson, a professor of sociology at Harvard and the author of distinguished books on slavery and the emergence of human freedom, takes on these people with "The Ordeal of Integration," a book that is defiant, even angry, often right and sometimes wrong.
His main argument is that extremists on the left and right have denied the extraordinary progress that has been made by Afro-Americans (a term Patterson, for reasons I will explain, deliberately chooses to employ). While recognizing that problems remain, Patterson writes that the extent of the achievement of the last 40 years in American race relations "cannot be overstated." He fleshes out this judgment with a summary of Afro-American progress in education, economic achievement, popular entertainment and public attitudes. (A fuller, more systematic account of this progress -- and of the shortcomings -- can be found in Stephan and Abigail Thernstrom's recent book, "America in Black and White: One Nation, Indivisible.")
Among Afro-Americans, Patterson reports, the middle class is now larger than the poor. This is a remarkable change from just 30 years ago. In 1967, Afro-American families headed by a married couple earned 68 percent as much as their Euro-American (again, Patterson's term) counterparts; by 1995, that had risen to 87 percent. There is, of course, an Afro-American underclass that is fed by out-of-wedlock teen-age births and that often expresses itself in crime and drug abuse. But that group is smaller than many imagine -- perhaps 900,000 people in all. Patterson laments its existence and describes its habits with painful honesty.
But the larger group is doing better than even it thinks. Fewer than 40 percent of Afro-Americans say they have ever faced discrimination in hiring, and 74 percent say they are satisfied with their lives. But a majority of Afro-Americans think that the quality of life for all members of their group has become worse or remained the same, and nearly two-thirds think that hiring discrimination abounds.
Patterson explains this conflict between what blacks think of their group and what they think of themselves in part by what he calls "liberal racialization." By this he means the tendency among some liberals who have condemned the use of race as a biological category to revive and give equally powerful meaning to race as a social category. Since real racism exists, there is some truth in doing this. But when every misfortune is laid at the feet of a white majority, occasional abuses by individuals are perceived as racial oppression.
This perception of racism causes a weakening of the human spirit by denying to people a chance to improve themselves. Patterson quotes the philosopher Sidney Hook on this matter: "One feels lessened as a human being if one's actions are always excused or explained away on the ground that . . . one is really not responsible for them." Or in Patterson's words, "if one is not responsible for one's problems, one can claim no credit for one's achievements."
Patterson has no patience with Afro-American writers who invent absurd stories about the natural superiority of blacks or perpetuate the ancient segregationist claim that anyone is black if he or she has "one drop" of black blood. He is angry at white liberals who keep Afro-Americans in a perpetual trap of racial identity, forever subjected to whatever white society should decide for them. He cannot abide Andrew Hacker, whose book "Two Nations" gave, in Patterson's opinion, a wholly deterministic view of racial (or, in Patterson's language, ethnic) identity.
The intellectual heart of Patterson's book is his rumination on the superiority of the doctrine of individual moral autonomy, by which he means "dignity and the ethic of personal responsibility." At root this doctrine requires one to renounce the whole idea of race, because racial identity is a form of social determinism. It is for this reason that Patterson refers to the people generally called blacks as Afro-Americans, no different as a group from Irish-Americans or Italian-Americans. Race, to him, has no biological or mental significance; it is a construct, invented by segregationists to justify segregation and perpetuated today by both those who sympathize with Afro-Americans in a way that sustains their special, and thus specially suppressed, status and those who criticize government policies aimed at helping them. To be free is to be free of group identity, whoever defines that identity and no matter how much individual members of the group claim to cherish it. Patterson is so much the integrationist that he wants "race" removed from the census tabulation.
Despite his dislike of racial categories, however, Patterson supports affirmative action. Racial identity, which he has rejected as a census label or a mode of thinking, now suddenly reappears as important enough to warrant special treatment. Patterson's view is that no society can fail to acknowledge some group claims. (In America, for instance, these include preferences for veterans.) He is not altogether happy with what affirmative action has actually produced. On college campuses, he finds "ethnic separatism, alternating with periodic outbursts of ethnic, gender and other chauvinistic hostilities." Nonetheless, he would like the program to continue "for at least another 15 years," but to be limited to women and Afro-Americans, excluding first-generation African and Caribbean men and many (but not all) Hispanic men. It would be cut back in "about five years" so that it no longer aided Afro-Americans and women from upper-middle-class backgrounds, and cut back again in 10 years so that only poor blacks and poor women would be helped. Fifteen years from today it would be ended, and replaced with a program that served all Americans from poor families, one that would continue so long as there is any poverty.
Nowhere does Patterson explain how all this would be done. What preferences would these groups get, and from whom? Why would white women benefit when they were never enslaved? How do you get bureaucracies to make the appropriate distinctions? Why, indeed, would one wish to preserve race as a category if racial identity is an undesirable form of social determinism? Can groups learn to live together as individuals if their access to opportunity is defined along racial lines?
There are compelling philosophical reasons to be skeptical of racial generalizations. A loose use of "race" denies the obvious fact that individual differences are vastly greater than group differences, however the group is defined.
Apart from his odd defense of affirmative action, Patterson extends his hatred of racial categories to whoever tries to measure the traits of people who classify themselves as white or black. He showers contempt on the authors of "The Bell Curve," Richard Herrnstein and Charles Murray, despite the fact that not only do their arguments in no way conform to what he imputes to them, but their emphasis on individual autonomy is entirely consistent with his own views.
Patterson's position is this: Even though a gap exists between the average I.Q. of Afro- and Euro-Americans, that difference arises wholly from the culture and is diminishing. Herrnstein and Murray are at pains to make much the same point. Whether genes explain differences in intelligence scores is a matter on which, as they put it, they "are resolutely agnostic." Nevertheless, in an irritating display of unreasonable ill temper, Patterson calls Murray an "academic racist," and links him unfairly with Leonard Jeffries.
The great paradox in this book, and the reason I have taken up his unfair criticism of "The Bell Curve," is that Patterson's central position -- that racial integration pursued so as to make each individual a competent moral person, evaluated by others for what he or she has accomplished -- is irrelevant to group differences in intelligence (or hair color, or life expectancy, or disease rates) however they are produced. Patterson rightly thinks that what matters is how each person is judged. How that judging is done ought not to depend -- and increasingly, in fact, does not depend -- on what group that person belongs to.
That is the core lesson of this country's long effort to create a just social system. Patterson understands this, but for reasons he does not explain, he cannot rest entirely comfortably with his own ideas.

HEADLINE: WINTER IN THE SNOW;
Cross-Country Central

BYLINE: By SUE HALPERN; SUE HALPERN, the author of "Migrations to Solitude" (Vintage), writes frequently about the outdoors.

 BODY:
DRIVING into the calendar-perfect village of Craftsbury Common in Vermont on a chill January day, it was not the snowy town green, or the picket fence enclosing it, or the fact that every house was painted white, that first caught my eye. These things I saw later. What I noticed was a girl, maybe 15, maybe younger, standing in front of the Craftsbury Academy, the town's well-regarded public school. She was wearing what seems to be the universal school uniform these days: baggy pants, baggy shirt, no parka. On one shoulder was slung a book bag. On the other -- and this is what got my attention -- was a pair of long, skinny cross-country skis.
"Look! I think we're here," I said to my daughter, pointing to the teen-ager. For years I had been hearing about Craftsbury, in Vermont's Northeast Kingdom -- how the snowfall there was reliable and profuse, how over 100 kilometers (60-plus miles) of groomed trails crisscrossed the town, how it had been the training site of Olympic nordic ski teams, and how skiing was as nearly as common a form of winter transportation in the town as it was in, say, Norway.
Our actual destination, the Craftsbury Outdoor Center, was two miles past the Common. I had heard about it, too: that it was one of the oldest ski touring centers in the Northeast, and that its director, John Brodhead, was one of the most delightfully fanatical cross-country skiers in the country. It was he, I had heard, who had figured out where, and how, to cut all those trails. Anyone who loves to strap on a pair of nordic skis and disappear into the landscape would understand why he wanted to.
My husband and I had decided to spend a couple of days in Craftsbury, in part to indulge in this disappearing act, but also to participate in what the Center's brochure described as a "family fun" weekend: ski touring, orienteering (being plunked in the woods with map and compass), skating and sledding for parents and children under 12. My daughter, who will turn 5 in the spring, had gotten her first pair of skis earlier in the winter, and we were looking forward to her getting her snow legs in the company of other children.
The Outdoor Center is ideal for parents with small, active children. (It is also ideal for parents of older children, and for adults without children, all of whom were also in residence on this particular weekend.) Housed at a former boarding school, accommodations are adequate and economical, not fancy or upscale. There are two main lodges -- former dormitories that have been made more lodgelike -- and three individual cabins. Rooms in the lodges, basic dormitory style, come in two sizes, small and less small, and some of the larger rooms have private baths. There is a sauna in one of the lodges, as well as a fitness room filled with rowing machines. In summer these lodges are home to rowers and aspiring rowers who come for Craftsbury's well-known sculling workshops. This is not a ski resort but a place for people who love the outdoors.
Days begin fairly early at Craftsbury. Breakfast in the communal dining room is at 8, and we were skiing before 9. We had come a day before the family weekend in order to log some miles along Craftsbury's extensive trail network, so after a lesson with a ski instructor for our daughter, my husband and I left her at our cabin with a sled and a baby sitter (easily arranged through the center) and set off.
Well, actually, we didn't set off directly -- we consulted the thermometer, noticed that although it was snowing lightly the temperature was waffling around freezing, and tried to figure out which wax to put on the bottom of our skis. Too warm a wax and our skis would be sticky and we wouldn't be able to glide, too cold and they wouldn't stick at all and we'd struggle for traction. We considered renting no-wax skis at the Outdoor Center's well-stocked and reasonably priced rental shop, but decided in the end to use our own equipment. (A mistake, probably, given the number of times we had to stop and rewax.)
Trails on the Craftsbury network are numbered, not named, and we chose Trail No. 6, a 10K run from the center to the hamlet of Craftsbury, which lies a few miles below its sister hamlet, Craftsbury Common. Though the trail was marked "most difficult" it didn't seem that way from the map, and indeed it wasn't.
 WE started in the woods, skiing quietly between the cedars, but the trail soon descended to the Black River, which we hugged for miles as it snaked through the bottom land. Then we gained some altitude, traversing more than one farmer's field, with panoramic views of the rippling Vermont hills and the mountains to which they lead. It was like footpath touring in England, only this was America, where the idea of property rights, and "no trespassing" are sacrosanct. This, in part, is what sets Craftsbury apart. More than 70 landowners participate, allowing trails to cut across their property.
It was still early in the day when we reached the end of Trail No. 6, but the snow had turned nearly to rain, and we were soaked and grateful to step out of our skis and into the warmth of the decidedly untouristy Craftsbury store. There we found freshly made doughnuts, cold cider and a table in the back. We cooled down, dried off, consulted the map, considered calling to be picked up by the Outdoor Center's shuttle bus, but decided to push on to Craftsbury Common, only two uphill miles away. The rain had turned back to snow.
We missed lunch at the Outdoor Center that day, but not dinner: three kinds of enchilada, a salad bar, fresh hot bread, peach cobbler. Breakfast the next day was pancakes, eggs, granola, muffins. The food, which is served buffet-style, is plentiful and healthy. (Beer and wine are available at the gift shop.) You work up an appetite skiing over dale and up hill, and the meals at the Outdoor Center more than satisfy it.
Still, if you want a break from the noise and bonhomie of the center's mess hall, there are other options, among them the Craftsbury Inn, in Craftsbury Village, and the Inn on the Common. But frankly, after a few hushed nouvelle courses at the latter, we were eager to return to the rough-and-tumble, chicken-and-biscuits atmosphere of the Outdoor Center.
Family fun began officially the next morning. Outside the ski rental building, John Brodhead led a group of children and their parents in some stretching exercises, then the kids split up for about a half hour of instruction. Though they were of varying levels and ages, it didn't seem to matter. My daughter was paired with some older boys who had never skied, and they all had a good time mastering the training hill.
When we reconvened, the children voted for a ski tour, so off we went, into the woods, on a loop that posed a few -- but only a few -- challenges to young skiers. John had them looking at animal tracks as well as ski tracks, and before long all of them had completed the milelong loop successfully. Later that day there was a snowshoe hike -- the center maintains a number of separate trails for snowshoers and also supplies the equipment -- and after dinner, a skating party. Because the skating pond is next to the warming hut, we could skate, get warm, drink cocoa, skate, look for constellations, get warm. There was a bonfire on the far side of the pond, and marshmallows, which turn out to be difficult to roast with mittens on, but not impossible.
Ski orienteering was on the schedule for the next morning, and though I worried about how children who could not read a book, let alone a map, would fare, the activity turned out to be a map-and-compass exercise for the older children and a scavenger hunt for the younger ones. The little ones were so excited to be hunting for the pink flags John had planted throughout the trail system that they barely noticed they were kicking and gliding across the snow, skiing forcefully and gracefully. Our weekend ended with a ski race, sponsored by the local Bill Koch League, a kind of Little League for cross-country skiing. As a payback to the community, the Outdoor Center plays host to the league, which is run by parents to encourage children to have fun on skis. The race, at least for the under-7 set, was not about going fast but about completion: everyone who made it around the .5K course was a winner. And they all did finish, even my daughter, who was the youngest, the smallest and the only one without ski poles. As she came into the home stretch, one of the boys she had been skiing with for the past couple of days saw her and urged her on. Others took up the cry, and soon everyone, young and old, was pulling for her. Her pace picked up, and she slid easily across the finish line.
 
Ski touring en famille
 
Getting There
The Craftsbury Outdoor Center, (800) 729-7751) is one and a half hours from Burlington and two from Montreal and is accessible via Vermont Route 14. The ski season goes from mid-December to mid-March.
 
Being There
Accommodations are least expensive at midweek, when they start at $113 a night for a double room with a shared bath that includes meals and trail passes. Additional adult guests in the same room cost $52 a night midweek and $57 on the weekend, while children under 6 are free and those between 6 and 12 pay half price. The most expensive accommodations are the three cottages, which cost $199 at midweek and $220 on the weekend, with the same surcharges for more than two people. A family fun weekend for a family of four is likely to cost between $250 and $450.
Ski rental: Skis, boots and poles are $10 a day. An hour and a half's private lesson is $30; a lesson for three to eight people is $60 a group.
Family Fun events: The center runs two family events: the family fun weekend, on Martin Luther King Jr. weekend, and family fun week, in February, during school vacation. It also runs ski camps for children and adults, and race weekends.
 
Dining Out
The Craftsbury Inn, (802) 586-2848, in Craftsbury Village, is a pleasant, family-run establishment that serves such entrees as poached salmon and chicken dijon. Dinner for two, without wine, is about $40.
The Inn on the Common, on Main Street in Craftsbury Common, (802) 586-9619, with a single 7:30 sitting, an extensive wine list, leg of Vermont rabbit on the menu and postdinner chocolates in the drawing room, is a more formal, candlelit place. Dinner only, and reservations are required. Dinner for two, without wine, is $70 plus 15 percent service charge and a 9 percent meal tax.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 131; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1442 words

HEADLINE: The Two Hollywoods;
Peace Is Hell

BYLINE: By Fareed Zakaria

 BODY:
Foreign-policy wonks in Washington are said to be hopelessly at sea in today's brave new world. They supposedly pine for the good old days of the cold war with its Soviet threat, nuclear danger, proxy wars and perpetual arms-control meetings. (Be still my heart!) But another town is struggling with this balmy time of peace as much as Washington -- Hollywood. Even though movie stars held cocktail parties for nuclear disarmament, the cold war was good for their profession. It nourished that distinctive American genre, the action-and-adventure movie.
 The cold war gave us genuine international tension. The stuff of its movies -- nuclear threats, blackmail, espionage and terrorism -- had a gripping, dangerous feel. The forces of the West were represented perfectly by James Bond -- elegant, inventive, hedonistic and always successful. But now, without an all-encompassing moral, political and strategic struggle, Hollywood has to stretch to find dangers that seem real enough, villains who seem evil enough and stakes that seem high enough. 
 To be sure, it is easy to overplay the cinema's interest in the Red menace. Perhaps because it was not a hot war, perhaps because of Hollywood's political culture, the cold war never worked as well on film as did World War II. There were, of course, movies with evil Communists, like "Funeral in Berlin," "Red Dawn" and "The Hunt for Red October." Still, the Soviets never achieved the supervillain status of the Nazis. In two great cold-war series they were not the villains at all. In Bond movies, evil was usually represented by an international crime cartel led by a weird plutocrat, and in John le Carre movies the Western agents were always equally flawed. "The Spy Who Came in From the Cold" is more anti-cold war than anti-Communist. But at least the moviegoer could be against something important.
 Action movies thrive on national enemies. They quickly identify the bad guys, usually by skin color, accent or uniform. Our two most successful villains, American Indians and Nazis, have been quite distinctive in dress and in language. Both were Hollywood's staple for decades after World War II and almost a century after the last Indian wars. When the makers of "Die Hard" wanted to create an intelligent, brutal criminal, they had Alan Rickman, an English actor, adopt a vaguely Germanic accent. His lieutenant was a blond Teutonic-looking guy named Karl. When things got really nasty they would actually speak to one another in German. But national enemies are now an endangered species, victims of three of the most powerful forces sweeping the world today -- peace, political correctness and globalization.
 Washington has no truly threatening great power foes, a situation that Hollywood has been trying to rectify since the late 1980's. First, the Japanese seemed a good bet, and "Black Rain" and Michael Crichton's "Rising Sun" could have been the beginning of a new wave. But while many in America -- including movie makers and policy wonks -- were willing to demonize Japan, Tokyo's economy fizzled out. Today it almost seems bad sportsmanship to mention the Japanese threat. Then came drug dealers, the featured attraction in the first post-cold-war Bond movie, "License to Kill." But they're not really a national group. Irish nationalists, as in "Patriot Games," and Kazakh terrorists, as in "Air Force One," are more persuasive. National liberation movements have that old-time passion. But the Irish, Kazakhs, Azeris and Serbs can work for a movie or two, not as set-piece villains in a continuing drama. They're local bad guys, not threats to world (or American) peace. When was the last Azeri bombing in New York?
 It's also hard to create national villains without national stereotypes -- a big no-no in the current multicultural atmosphere. Not only can American Indians no longer be stereotyped, they can barely be mentioned. A Princeton, N.J., mother says that her children, at a private school, are now taught to play "Cowboys and Pirates." (I wonder what the teacher would say if one of those bright, young things asked how Nevada ranchers could have fought Mediterranean sailors?) For a while it seemed acceptable to portray Arabs as fanatical and villainous, hijacking planes while praying to Allah. But people began to notice this double standard. Reviewing the Arnold Schwarzenegger film "True Lies," David Denby wrote in New York magazine: "The terrorists are treated contemptuously as a bunch of losers -- as fuzz-faced buffoons, shouting gibberish at one another. Shot, stabbed, torched, blown up, the Arabs, or whatever they are, drop like flies." Oh, well, back to the drawing board.
 And then there is globalization. Until recently, Hollywood earned most of its money from domestic audiences; foreign business was gravy. Today, entertainment is America's largest export industry. A first-class blockbuster can expect to make half its revenues from abroad. In this context, globalization has had a particularly dismal effect on movie making, writes David Kipen in The World Policy Journal. First, there is little need for dialogue: "Why bother writing good lines if they'll only be mistranslated?" Second, what takes the place of good writing is violence -- the Esperanto of the modern media world. An explosion means exactly the same thing in Taipei as it does in Dubuque. So do 10.
 Globalization also requires that characters perceived as bad guys in America must also be considered bad guys in East Asia. That's why the Chinese are problematic candidates for villainy. Not that the entertainment industry is averse to testing the waters with the upcoming Martin Scorsese movie "Kundun"; "Seven Years in Tibet"; "Red Corner" (a Midnight Express set in China), and the next James Bond movie. But while many people in East Asia worry about the rise of Chinese power, the Chinese do not have the historical reputation for aggression that the Japanese do. Besides, there are 1.2 billion potential Chinese movie buffs to think about. Dealing with the China problem highlights a tension between two powerful strains not limited to Hollywood: superficial moralizing and rapacious moneymaking.
 In the end, however, the movies have a solution. Like so much of fiction and nonfiction today, film has moved to the realm of the personal. Memoirs, autobiographies and psychobabble are in; history and politics are out. Villains are not villainous because they are Nazis or American Indians or are devoted to any larger cause. They are bad individuals, acting for entirely personal reasons. The terrorist in "The Peacemaker" is motivated not by ideological concerns but by narrow, solipsistic ones -- he is avenging the murder of his wife and child.
 The emphasis on the personal is, in a way, perfect for modern movie making because it allows for violence. First we must establish that the villain is bad, so we watch him blow up innocent people for 20 minutes. Then, in the next hour, we watch the good guys battle him. This need for violence to establish character spins out of control in a movie like "Face/Off," in which the good guy (John Travolta) and the bad guy (Nicolas Cage) change faces, so the director, John Woo, keeps reminding us which one to hate by having him kill a few dozen strangers. All of which is necessary to keep the audience on the right side. The key to a successful action movie today is righteous violence. Audiences cannot simply partake in gruesome barbarism; they must feel redeemed by it.
 But does this make for great cinema? "The Guns of Navarone," one of the most gripping adventure movies ever made, has very little violence. The moral and political context gives the movie its chilling tension. So it was with most of the best movies of this genre from the 1940's to the early 80's. Until the great global drama petered out.
 "The end of history will be a very sad time," wrote Francis Fukuyama in the concluding paragraph of his famous essay. "The willingness to risk one's life for a purely abstract goal, the worldwide ideological struggle that called forth daring, courage, imagination and idealism, will be replaced by economic calculation, the endless solving of technical problems, environmental concerns and the satisfaction of sophisticated consumer demands." In his book, "The End of History and the Last Man," Fukuyama asks whether human beings, increasingly bored by the banality of life, will yearn again for some larger meaning and thus be "ready to drag the world back into history with all its wars, injustice and revolution." And also its movies -- great, spine-tingling action movies.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 76; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 2454 words

HEADLINE: The Two Hollywoods;
The End Of the Middle

BYLINE: By Neal Gabler

 BODY:
One thing about Hollywood: it is always in the throes of a revolution. This year's revolution erupted last February when the Academy Award nominations were announced and only one big studio picture, "Jerry Maguire," was among the five anointed for Best Picture. The rest, including the eventual winner, "The English Patient," were what those in the business call "indie" productions, which is to say that they were distributed and in many cases financed by small independent companies operating on the periphery of the Hollywood plantation.
 Though the big box-office breadwinners are still oversize studio pictures, the indies' nominations sent shock waves through the industry. To the media they meant that the Ewoks had taken down Jabba the Hutt, while in Hollywood, power brokers were beating their breasts in contrition, confessing what everyone else already knew: that the creative balance of power had shifted from the major studios making "Twister," "Mission: Impossible" and "Independence Day" to the outsiders making "Shine," "Sling Blade" and "Trainspotting." 
 In truth, however, it wasn't quite as neat as that. Many of the so-called independents were actually subsidiaries of the major studios. They may have operated with a large degree of freedom, allowed to "green light" pictures whose budgets fell below a certain threshold, but their profits ultimately wound up in studio coffers. Increasingly, then, the independents were on the Hollywood plantation; they just weren't living in the master's house.
 And yet the very reason the studios created subdivisions like Fox Searchlight and Sony Pictures Classics or acquired indie companies like New Line and Gramercy was that they realized there was a significant difference between the kinds of pictures the studio apparatus was producing and those being delivered by the independents. And that was why the vigor of independent film making mattered. It wasn't economics that was at stake; it was esthetics.
 It is possible that Hollywood has never been as esthetically divided as it is now. As I write, the films reaping the critical hosannas are "Boogie Nights," "The Ice Storm," "Telling Lies in America" and "The Full Monty," all of which have been released by indies and all of which are smallish pictures that appeal to audiences seeking intellectual, emotional or esthetic stimulation. Meanwhile, the films reaping the top grosses include "I Know What You Did Last Summer," "The Devil's Advocate," "Kiss the Girls" and "The Peacemaker," all of which have been released by major studios and all of which appeal to audiences interested in action and cheap thrills. A film like Warner Brothers's "L.A. Confidential," a moody, modern noir that manages to combine intelligence with action, is now the rare exception.
 In other arts, this sort of division isn't unusual. By the 19th century, cultural aristocrats had their symphonies, their genteel novels, their Shakespeare and drawing-room comedies. The majority had their band music, their dime novels and pornography, their Shakespeare (the action without the language) and their melodramas.
 But almost from the start the movies have been different. Though they began early this century as an urban, working-class entertainment, they rapidly attracted the middle class and even, begrudgingly, members of the cultural elite. Elsewhere things may have been bifurcated, but in the movies there were essentially no high or low ends, just one large, gratifying middle, where you could find the comedies of Frank Capra, Warner Brothers gangster dramas, Fred Astaire-Ginger Rogers musicals and the westerns of John Ford.
 Today the great moviegoing public that sustained the middle is pretty much gone, though it has actually been endangered for decades. From 78.2 million weekly admissions in 1946, or over four billion for the year, the number of viewers has steadily and precipitously declined all the way down to 58 million by 1950, 25.1 million by 1960, to a low of 15.8 million in 1971. At the same time, the percentage of recreational dollars spent on the movies was taking a similar nose dive.
 Why did people suddenly stop going to the movies? The advent of television had a great deal to do with it, as did suburbanization and the patterns of recreation that accompanied it. Some people even blamed the declining quality of movies as the studio system fractured. But whatever the causes, the medium no longer bound the entire country together the way it had from the 20's through the 40's.
 For decades Hollywood tried to lure audiences back, at first with wider screens and 3-D and then with pictures like "Bonnie and Clyde" and "The Godfather" that borrowed heavily from the techniques of foreign films. But the industry was just treading water until the release of "Jaws" in 1975. "Jaws" was a one-movie revolution. In economic terms alone, it made so much money so rapidly -- a $260 million domestic gross -- that it invented the whole notion of the blockbuster. Even after adjusting for inflation, 9 of the 25 top-grossing films domestically of all time are post-"Jaws," despite the fact that movie attendance was a fraction of what it had been in the 20's, 30's and 40's.
 But it wasn't just money. "Jaws" also had an effect on the very nature of American films. No one would seriously argue that the bulk of movies before "Jaws" were masterpieces of sophistication or nuance, but even so those films were largely dependent on plot and character. Whatever the merits of "Jaws," the film helped tip the American esthetic from one that was essentially plot- and character-driven to one that is sensation-driven. Ever since, bigger, faster, louder has been the Hollywood mantra -- the only way to make the gigabucks.
 Yet the most important influence of "Jaws" may be something much subtler: the way it altered the traditional relationship between viewer and film. Movies had certainly arrived with ballyhoo before, but the viewing of the film itself was what the critic Robert Warshow once described as an immediate experience," a person responding to the screen in front of him.
 "Jaws" helped change that. The unprecedented media attention forced audiences into a less immediate posture. They inescapably found themselves responding not only to the film in front of them but also to the phenomenon of the film around them: its marketing, its media coverage, its success, its hype. In fact, the film itself became only one component of the movie experience, which was now not even an esthetic experience at all but some kind of vast new cultural happening.
 When movies are happenings though, their costs soar. Big-budget blockbusters are the only movies that give a studio real hope of returning $100 million grosses, the industry's new magic number, because they are the only ones that can generate enough excitement in the other media. They are also the only movies that can hope to compete against other blockbusters. With so much at stake, studios had to up the marketing budgets as well, so that both production and advertising costs began soaring exponentially, creating an endless cycle of ever-larger budgets and ever-larger marketing expenses -- a game of can-you-top-this that shows no signs of abating.
 And yet, perverse as it is, the system makes economic sense. Though the size of a picture's budget obviously doesn't guarantee a large audience, virtually every film that has had a megagross has also had a megabudget. Even the films that bomb here, like "Daylight" or "Waterworld," are more likely to be profitable abroad because they have lavish production values to display.
 Still, there is the matter of whom these movies are being made for. In the past, the industry didn't pay much attention to its audience profile. With a constituency nearly as large as the population itself, the old Hollywood always thought in terms of the audience, never an audience. It always tried to make films that appealed to the largest possible number of viewers, which is why movies were the art of the middle.
 By the 70's, however, it was clear the audience did not exist anymore. Instead, as admissions had plunged through the 50's and 60's, the audience realigned itself so that it was no longer a cross section of the country. More specifically, the moviegoers who had deserted film were primarily those moviegoers over 40. A result was that the movies became a medium for the young.
 Of all the factors affecting motion pictures, the age of the audience is probably the most salient. According to a survey conducted by Opinion Research Corporation for the Motion Picture Association of America last year, 67 percent of the audience is under 40, even though they represent just 50 percent of the population. What's more, 50 percent of the audience is between 12 and 29 years old, though they are now only 30 percent of the population. And even these figures understate the case, because young moviegoers go to the movies far more frequently than older ones: 26 percent of those 18 and older went once an month, compared with 48 percent of those between 12 and 17.
 So while the cultural divide in other media fell between high and low, the cultural divide in movies falls between old and young. The effect, however, turns out to look very much like that of high-low, in large part because the rapid turnover of popular culture has created widely divergent cultural experiences and tastes between generations. The parents of today's young moviegoers were weaned on old movies, "Leave It to Beaver," the Beatles and J. D. Salinger. Their children have grown up on "Sesame Street," MTV, Guns 'n' Roses and the "Star Wars" trilogy, so it's no wonder they want movies that pack a sensory overload. To them, movies are meant to be "roller-coaster rides" that shake you from your lethargy.
 The new global markets, which now account for roughly half of a studio film's grosses, only reinforce the new esthetic. Foreign audiences don't want small, sensitive, serious pictures from America. They can get those from their own national film industries. What no other country but America can produce are big, star-studded, special-effects-filled extravaganzas. These are some of our most popular exports because they speak the universal language of sensation.
 Today studios aren't even capable of making small films. Last year, according to the M.P.A.A., the average cost of a studio production was $39.8 million, up 325 percent since 1980, with an additional $17.2 million on average devoted to advertising, up 386 percent since 1980. Yet the alternative, to abjure stars and reduce the marketing campaign, would sentence a studio film to oblivion under the trampling herd of blockbusters.
 And that is where the independents come in. If the major studios have lost the nerve and knack for making small pictures, there are still executives who know how to produce them and distributors who know how to market them. By proving that there were profits to be made from films that were smaller, slower, softer -- and cheaper -- companies like Miramax have inspired an indie wave that has yet to crest. There are now dozens of indie companies, with half a dozen more reportedly in the offing -- everything from the studio-owned boutiques to Stratosphere Entertainment, a brand-new distributor started by financier Carl Icahn.
 Obviously, small films targeted at older audiences are not going to capture the grosses of "The Lost World: Jurassic Park" or "Men in Black." Even "The English Patient," for all its awards, grossed only $78.6 million. But if you release enough pictures, make them cheaply enough and then market them wisely, the singles can add up to runs -- which is one reason indies are so hot now. Last year Miramax released 39 films with a total domestic gross of $248 million, just about the gross of "Men in Black" alone, but nothing to sniff at either.
 For the older audience that had deserted the movies, the rise of the independents must seem like a godsend. At long last, these folks are getting their kinds of pictures again. But the independent surge has had another effect that bodes less well for the health of American movies. While no one was watching, the independents have been segregating audiences. There are now small films for older arty audiences and big films for younger action-oriented ones, which puts the movies exactly where literature, music, dance and art are: split.
 Even more important, the segregated audience has allowed film makers to segregate themselves, too. Not so long ago, for directors to succeed in Hollywood, they had to appeal to those who wanted excitement and those who purported to want something more. The great film makers of the past, from Howard Hawks to Alfred Hitchcock to Spielberg himself -- before he separated his serious film making ("Schindler's List") from his mindless film making ("The Lost World") -- all felt compelled to provide intelligent entertainment when that wasn't an oxymoron.
 It is only now, when our movies are either made for teen-agers or for adults, that we have come to realize how wonderful that balance between intelligence and fun, between art and entertainment, was. Art fructified entertainment and prevented it from devolving into a series of increasingly jangled and incoherent narratives that also yield instantly to pleasure," as the critic David Denby has described recent blockbusters. By the same token, entertainment fructified art and prevented it from becoming dull and desiccated. It now seems that it wasn't, as critics used to grouse, the lowest common denominator to which our movies were once pitched, but the highest.
 Now that the independents have relieved their film makers of the obligation to reach a large audience and studios have relieved theirs of the obligation to make intelligently crafted pictures, the split between art and entertainment is larger than ever and, one fears, never the twain shall meet. As a result, we tend to get pictures that are either silly or pretentious, bloody or bloodless, sensational or soporific, but seldom do we get pictures that give us both the sensory and intellectual pleasures that our best films, and even our less-than-best films, so often provided.
 As it stands, unless more film makers and studios are willing to buck the trend and try once again to reconcile small pleasures with big, intelligence with sensation, older audiences with younger, the movies will be providing half of something for each but not a satisfying whole for all. Surely the film industry can survive this way. But what would be truly, and sadly, revolutionary is for the medium that once united us all now to divide us.

PUB-DATE: November 16, 1997

SECTION: Section 6; Page 101; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 2481 words

HEADLINE: The Two Hollywoods;
Meeting Halfway

BYLINE: By Janet Maslin

 BODY:
The best movie moment of recent months didn't require much: just a few men standing on a welfare line, doing their damnedest to resist a disco beat. But this scene from the British comedy "The Full Monty" worked as a great sight gag, summed up the film's graceful way of fusing humor with poignancy and showed how one sharp, humane image could count for so much more than lavish overkill. Most of all, it bridged the chasm between independent cinema and Hollywood product by telling a high-concept comic story with loads of heart. Built on nothing but ingenuity and talent, it had no set place on the film-making spectrum between spectacle and soul, all-star and no-name, big and small. It was a moment that could work anywhere.
 Scenes like this are the building blocks for a viable film future, one that recognizes an increasingly inescapable precept: cross over or die. Two brands of bankruptcy -- fiscal for small films and distributors, creative for too many big ones -- give that idea unavoidable urgency right now. Crossover thinking supersedes the old-style conventional wisdom, which held that Hollywood was the place that built the Titanic (quite literally this Christmas). Studios made outlandishly big spectacles that depended on one narrative arc, three acts and the kind of formulaic elements that might not admit a free thoughtin all two hours. 
 Meanwhile, enterprising independent cinema was the iceberg on which the studios' big, lumbering product ran aground. It was the novelty act, the scrappy underdog, the reproach to all things slick, bogus and forced. In fact, these two Hollywoods now overlap constantly, as symbiotic in practice as they are theoretically opposed.
 "Did he recommend another movie where everybody ends up in a storm sewer shooting each other?" asks a character in Don DeLillo's new novel, "Underworld," nicely satirizing the stereotypical Hollywood no-brainer. The indie David to such a Goliath is thought of as more real and sensitive, even if that means two 20-something people in a room talking their relationship to death. But the biggest surprises on screen rarely come from either of these camps. They come from the middle and sneak into the mainstream. The best recent hybrids have been studio films like "Jerry Maguire" or "The People vs. Larry Flynt" or "L.A. Confidential," in which grand ambition, artful trappings and independence of spirit are perfectly intertwined. These films seduce the eye with the costly Hollywood blandishments that elude independents. But they never let the mind know exactly what to expect.
 Hybrids open new avenues in what might otherwise be a strictly bifurcated movie world. They energize the independent sphere, which has cut back markedly on adolescent navel-gazing; they also make studio films seek greater idiosyncrasy than the kind that comes from casting Dennis Hopper in a crazed villain's role. Crossover is the name of the game that, in theory at least, everybody can now win. The dividing lines are so fully blurred that Hollywood can freely borrow imagination (and, in the case of a "Con Air," lift an entire cast) from the independent realm. And smaller films can attract increasingly high-power-ed talent excited by the prospect of taking risks, even the risk that only a fraction of the audience will see exciting work done in this arena.
 I remember a particular moment when this became apparent: a lunch at the 1994 Cannes Film Festival just before "Pulp Fiction" was unleashed on the world. John Travolta and Bruce Willis traded war stories about the highs and lows of their Hollywood careers, including the disappointment of "Moment by Moment" and the dumbing down of the "Look Who's Talking" films. Still, it had suddenly dawned on even stars of this wattage that there was now an alternative to being either up or down on the Hollywood food chain. Now there was sideways. A two-way bridge had been opened between mainstream and alternative work. After this, nothing would be quite the same.
 To be sure, Hollywood spends plenty of time on automatic pilot. It still churns out formula films that are dead on arrival, films that reveal in their first 5 minutes that the remaining 115 will contain not a single spark. The studios also shoot themselves in the figurative foot with such aggressive and unimaginative marketing that these movies land with a built-in sense of deja vu. But they also, at their best, spin the most beautiful daydreams, creating a coveted gloss and Zeitgeist energy that cannot be matched in the world of the shoestring budget. Those things, and the importance of the movie star as a form of narrative shorthand -- as a person so vivid that his or her mere presence explains half of what an audience needs to know about a character -- are too good to change.
 The independent world is different, with its own acting royalty (Harvey Keitel, Julianne Moore, Samuel L. Jackson, Steve Buscemi) and its own conventions. It can no longer be mistaken for a farm team for the majors, even though directors who make electrifying first impressions are still seduced and subsumed by the Hollywood payday. (Lee Tamahori, who made the small, much-admired "Once Were Warriors," typically moved on to bigger, if not better, pastures with "Mulholland Falls" and "The Edge.") But independent talents have more reason than ever to keep their distance from such temptations. When a Hollywood film can fly in and out of public consciousness in a single weekend, there's added incentive for film makers to try the smaller, freer effort that needn't prove itself instantly and may stand a chance of sticking around. All it takes is the daring to realize that the great untested midrange of movie making is where a workable future lies.
The film world's opposite extremes are long established, but they did not in the past exist so piquantly side by side. A generation ago, the hot new film makers who personified creative independence worked in a more marginalized atmosphere. Directors like Martin Scorsese, Francis Ford Coppola and Jonathan Demme, along with Robert Altman and Woody Allen (whose methods make them the two most functionally independent film makers in America), shared an uneasy relationship with Hollywood. No wonder: Independence had renegade roots it could trace to Ed Wood, Roger Corman and the fringes of B-movie making. ("Easy Rider," 1969, was both indie and B.) Thus the nascent independent cinema had a whiff of rebellion -- economic, cultural and sometimes political -- that the big guns wouldn't often touch. Even high-profile studio films that share this audacity, like "Chinatown" or "Shampoo" or "Midnight Cowboy," have the feeling of independent forerunners in retrospect.
 But film making with an independent spirit, even when blessed with widespread acceptance as well as studio backing, remained largely subsidiary to Hollywood's main events, which were sinking ocean liners and torching office towers. Classics like "Badlands" and "Taxi Driver" and "Nashville" (a Newsweek cover at the same time "Jaws" hit the cover of Time) struggled for their toehold within the still-thriving mainstream. Epic-scale movie making sustained its hold over the audience's imagination and had not yet been sapped by the demands of home video and lowest-common-denominator worldwide marketing. Blockbuster frenzy, with all its megajolts, was only beginning. In the just-post-"French Connection" era, the car chase still seemed a reasonably novel idea.
 A new wave of American experimentation was on a spectacular rise, but it had not yet fully found its niche. That niche existed, but it was already occupied: by a thriving foreign cinema that brought American audiences art films reaching well beyond Hollywood's usual bounds. Viewers would turn here for the same edge of idiosyncrasy that today's best independents offer. "The indie of my childhood was 'La Strada,"' a friend of mine says.
 But foreign films began to hit their own qualitative slump. And by the mid-1980's they had left behind an art-house vacuum. The time was ripe: along came a new breed of American films to fill that gap. Some of these, personifying the early Sundance spirit at its most unrelievedly earnest, were talky and becalmed in ways that posed no threat to the studios' lavish comic-book adaptations. But this was also the time when Spike Lee, Joel and Ethan Coen, Steven Soderbergh and others began to astonish audiences, and when the Miramax juggernaut began building a much better marketing mousetrap. Suddenly this new talent had a place to flourish and a following eager to embrace alternative style.
 The work of these film makers is as different as "Barton Fink" and "Do the Right Thing," but certain ground rules apply. Indies are almost by definition less frivolous than their Hollywood counterparts, since Hollywood still manufactures giddy escapism better than anyone else can. ("Flirting With Disaster," another superb example of the crossover species, managed to combine studio-worthy whimsy with a well-developed dark side.) And beyond the occasional worrywart working in Hollywood, i.e. Albert Brooks, indies have cornered the market on solipsistic small talk. For instance, they have transposed the long, chatty (and cheap) car trip to a variety of other settings, like the convenience store of Kevin Smith's now-legendary "Clerks." Meanwhile, Hollywood maintains exclusive rights to the classic sign of screenwriters' panic, the scene that has everybody on the bus, in the restaurant or in the rest room suddenly chime in helpful advice about the main characters' love lives.
In recent years, when Hollywood's finest hour could be represented by "Schindler's List" while the great indie Oscar sweep was touched off by "The English Patient," it has become clear that the best films mean the best of both worlds. In gravity, scale and unlikely beauty, these two brooding films have much in common anyhow. Indeed, it was Parallel Universe Night at the 1996 Academy Awards show as the traditionally prize-winning type of performance came from Geoffrey Rush of "Shine," a nominal independent no more avant-garde than "Forrest Gump." Neither was "Sling Blade," another supposed left-field winner. Meanwhile, Tom Cruise did the best work of his career in "Jerry Maguire," which was as independent-minded as the year's other contenders but had the onus of a Hollywood pedigree. And it looked as if a full reversal had occurred. Independents were regarded as A-list movies. And the studios had forfeited supremacy, thanks to all those dopey neo-B's.
 The past year has been so creatively and fiscally disastrous that both sides must feel ready for retooling. Wave after wave of Hollywood lemmings hit the beach each Friday, vainly confident in their ability to draw viewers despite insane odds. (I write this in a week when two fine, original studio-distributed films, "Gattaca" and "Fairy Tale: A True Story," crashed and burned instantly on arrival. This is not even unusual.) Meanwhile, the independents have created their own glut, to the point where well-made Sundance films without the crossover clout of a "Big Night" or a "Welcome to the Dollhouse" may not get beyond the festival circuit.
 Yet the middle ground remains more of a no man's land than it needs to be. Experiments like "Copland," a little film full of big talent, or even "U-turn," Oliver Stone's wild-eyed answer to "Red Rock West," are still rarer than buddy shoot-'em-ups or comedies played in drag. Hollywood's reason for this used to be the celebrity insurance policy, even though it has grown alarmingly easy for the star vehicle to run out of gas. On the indie side, it can indeed be difficult for offbeat, diffident talents to flourish when working on a grander scale. Jim Jarmusch, Hal Hartley and Richard Linklater have done their best work drawing on little more than supremely deadpan acting and bone-dry humor. Unsettling, analytic film makers like Atom Egoyan ("The Sweet Hereafter") and Todd Haines ("Safe") make visually ambitious films with no need for compromise with audience expectations.
 Though every "Men in Black" buys more time for the old system and every "One False Move" or "Chasing Amy" or "Lone Star" creates hope for an alternative one, time is in a real sense running out. An older moviegoing generation has lost much of its loyalty to the medium that stopped seriously courting its attention. Though great films are the best form of virtual reality that we may ever know, younger audiences choose films that mimic the empty maneuvers of video games. And every time an "L.A. Confidential" fails to find the success it deserves, the world makes room for another knockoff of "My Best Friend's Wedding." If either Hollywood hopes to keep its following, it had better find ways to welcome bigger thinking onto the big screen.
 But that is beginning to happen, and with increasing frequency. When an "In the Company of Men" strikes a chord, it reveals not only its own insinuating power but also the weakness of bigger, more frivolous work with similar themes.
 The worried white male has been much in evidence lately, whether achieving near-sexual release while fighting a rampaging bear as in "The Edge" or humorously coming out of the closet as in "In and Out." Only in Hollywood could you find a virginal middle-age teacher with no idea of his sexual orientation or an entire auditorium full of students who speak out in his defense. And only far outside of Hollywood -- like Indiana, where "In the Company of Men" was made -- could you find plot twists cruel enough to make one of the story's queasy male supremacists physically sick.
 But the worried, would-be male strippers of "The Full Monty" offer what both sides hope for, the film that is itself the star. No remake, no spinoff, no best seller: just a film that does something entertainingly different and then wins over its audience through wit and will power. This sleeper also became a success on its own steam, which in an atmosphere of breathless hype is something rarely allowed to happen. Ads never even had the chance to mention the film's use of ceramic gnomes, which surely would have won an extra fan or two.
 Viewers trained to endure assaults by highly intelligent space insects (and by earthly beings definitely less so) can find hope here. "The Full Monty" made its mark because it amused audiences in the most basic, well-grounded ways and broke the two-Hollywood barrierin the process. And it's a reminder of exactly where crossover success finds its future. The more chances films take, the more the verdict lies with audiences. After all, it is viewers who create hits by spotting the talent and rewarding the bright idea and the brave effort. It is viewers who can cherish and sustain independence where it must remain most vital: in the mind of the beholder.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: Now You See Them . . . and See Them Again

BYLINE: By NANCY HASS 

 BODY:
THE MESSAGE ON THE ANSWERING machine from a movie critic pal in a distant city combined cultural commentary with a cry for help: "Want to go see the Travolta movie?" he asked acidly. Click.
I felt his pain. He might as well have suggested that we see the Robert De Niro movie. Or the Dustin Hoffman film. Or the one with Robin Williams. In each case his question would have been as unanswerable as a Zen riddle: all of these actors will have at least three movies out this winter, running consecutively or simultaneously on competing screens. 
 Talk about the short list. Not since the days of the studio system have so few stars appeared in so many films in such a short time. As the number of movies released nationally has increased almost exponentially in recent years, tried-and-true audience pleasers -- the list also includes Richard Gere, Anthony Hopkins and Kevin Kline -- appear with dizzying frequency.
It's little wonder American pop culture seems wallpapered by recurring faces: the stars who crop up over and over now, unlike those in the studio era, are largely men in their 40's and 50's. The only woman who is able to carry a major studio release is Julia Roberts, but she has been in just two movies this year. Jennifer Jason Leigh and Cameron Diaz may appear more often, but they don't have that sort of clout.
Mr. Travolta is the poster boy for multiple exposure. His comeback, which started in 1994 with his turn as the lank-haired, existentialist hitman in "Pulp Fiction," has made his name a verb in Hollywood circles -- as in, "That guy is washed up unless he can Travolta in that next project." Late next spring, he will have appeared in less than a year as a persona-flipping cop ("Face/Off"), a hapless security guard ("Mad City") and a somewhat sleazy President of the United States (Mike Nichols's "Primary Colors"). Go forward a couple of months and he'll also be a crusading lawyer in Robert Redford's "A Civil Action." Go back a few months and his credits also include "Michael" and "Phenomenon."
No matter how much audiences crave Mr. Travolta and other actors on the recycled short list, their omnipresence may, like the California sun, cause long-term damage. The flood of films has already had a dampening effect on movie grosses. Seeing the same faces can't help but water down critical reaction and dilute the force of a spectacular performance. Perhaps the memory of Mr. Kline's sweet schoolteacher in "In and Out" made the haunting loneliness of his philandering WASP in "The Ice Storm" easier to watch. But having the two films released simultaneously may also have robbed "The Ice Storm" of some of its chilling force.
How long has this been going on? Well, it may seem as if a short list of stars has forever appeared in many movies each season, but that's just another Hollywood illusion. True, during the heyday of the studios, from 1930 until the early 60's, some actors churned out as many as four or five films a year (in 1932, Bette Davis appeared in 10), but in the recent past, stars have been more elusive.
 
When a Single Film Was a Symbol of Status
In fact, in the 70's and 80's, it was considered a mark of superstardom to appear in only a single film a year. With the demise of the studio system, actors were free to steer their own careers and revolted en masse against the assembly-line pace of early Hollywood.
Barbra Streisand, among the biggest box-office attractions of the era, made only nine films in the 1970's. With "The Graduate," in 1967, Dustin Hoffman became a huge star, but he rarely made more than one movie a year throughout the next decade. In 1972 he made only the Italian "Alfredo, Alfredo," and the following year only "Papillion." In 1974 he was in "Lenny," and a year later he played Carl Bernstein in "All the President's Men."
"It made a lot of sense that in the 1970's actors thought exclusivity was important," said the cultural historian and film critic Neal Gabler. "It was a backlash against the studio system. Cagney compared himself to a race horse being whipped, which is probably just how it it felt."
A fear of overexposure also led some actors to make themselves alluringly scarce. In the 1970's, the rise and fall of one star, Elliott Gould, stood as the paradigmatic cautionary tale. Like many movie actors of the 70's -- including Ms. Streisand and Mr. Hoffman -- Mr. Gould was the antithesis of a matinee idol. But even though he was quirky and ethnic, the public seemed to embrace him instantly for his naturalness and approachability.
After his debut in "The Night They Raided Minsky's" in 1968, he appeared in more than 11 movies in 5 years, including "Bob and Carol and Ted and Alice," "MASH" and "The Long Goodbye." He was on the cover of Time. By 1975, however, filmgoers seemed to tire of his idiosyncratic presence. He kept working sporadically, but his career foundered.
More recently, the embodiment of overexposure has been Antonio Banderas. After his smoldering performance in "The Mambo Kings" in 1992, the Spanish-born actor was touted as a Rudolph Valentino for the 90's. Suddenly he was everywhere. After appearing in a string of films ("Philadelphia," "The House of the Spirits," "Interview With the Vampire"), his star flamed out quietly.
But these days most movie actors, and their agents, seem far less spooked by such tales. Had younger actors like Matt Damon, Ben Affleck, Claire Danes and Ashley Judd come of age under the studio system, they would have been groomed for years in a modulated stream of ingenue roles. As it is, they seem to have burst onto the scene full-blown, in a slew of supporting and featured parts.
Even Hollywood's royalty now seems eager to appear as often as possible. "In a way, Hollywood is re-creating the studio system," said Mr. Gabler. "The same oversized, everywhere-you-look icons are emerging. The difference is that this time, it's the stars and their managers who are controlling it."
Perhaps the most stunning sign of this shift can be detected by looking at the 60-year-old Mr. Hoffman: this season will be his busiest ever. He is in "Mad City," which just opened; Barry Levinson's satire "Wag the Dog," which opens next month, and Mr. Levinson's science-fiction thriller "Sphere," set for February.
 
Big Budgets Make The Short List Shorter
For top-shelf male talent, there are certainly enough roles to choose from. In fact, Hollywood's current economics are probably the main reason so many actors have lately been showing up in numerous films at a time. The number of national releases during the fall season, a 10-week period stretching from Labor Day until the day before Thanksgiving, has risen 50 percent since 1995, to about 45.
But despite the swelling number of movies made, the short list of stars remains, in a word, short. With production and marketing budgets growing bigger as well -- the average combined budget topped $60 million this year, compared with $15 million a decade ago -- producers and distributors are more wary than ever of untested headliners.
The suggestion that such risk-averse casting could eventually erode the market by numbing the audience evokes a one-word response from most studio executives: "Phenomenon." That movie, which got lukewarm reviews, made more than $120 million, and it is widely believed that this was on the strength of Mr. Travolta's presence alone.
"These days, studios are run by a lot of people, not just one big mogul," said the media sociologist and essayist Todd Gitlin. "These people are not gambling individually; they are all scrambling in a pack to cover their backs. They aren't looking for success; they're looking for a way to explain failure. If they stick to the short list of proven stars, even if the picture bombs, they can at least say, 'Hey, we did all we could.' "
Agents and managers say there are a variety of reasons their clients are more likely these days to churn out films at a grueling pace. To begin with, predicting precisely when a movie will be released is less and less an exact science. Actors may intend to space out their films more judiciously, but distribution is not in their hands. And recently, as both summer and Christmas grosses have slacked off, more and more films are being jammed into the same September-November hot zone.
"A lot of things can go wrong," said Lois Smith, a publicity agent who represents the omnipresent Anthony Hopkins. "There are scheduling conflicts, distribution snafus and editing crises. When the actors are making their deals, they don't know what weekend the film is coming out. That's really far in the future. They have no control over it."
Still, Ms. Smith concedes, actors know what risks they run when they "finish a picture on Friday and start another Monday morning." Once an actor has two or three movies in the can, the publicity machine goes into overdrive. "The public sees someone on 82 talk shows, and it's no surprise that they get tired," she said.
Often what drives the machine is old-fashioned ego. Managers say that they warn their clients about overexposure but that the caveats have been falling on deaf ears. "Believe it or not, actors are, underneath all the hype, real people with a host of emotional, human needs," said Elaine Goldsmith-Thomas of International Creative Management, who represents stars like Ms. Roberts. "Like most of us, they are susceptible to the gratification of being wanted. Their work is their identity."
 
Star Salary Offers Too Good to Refuse
And then, of course, there's the paycheck. With producers convinced that only a few actors are guaranteed to "open" a movie -- that is, deliver the all-important first weekend grosses -- the big stars can command astonishing money. Mr. Travolta last year signed a deal that is paying him $20 million a film for "Primary Colors," "A Civil Action" and a remake of "Have Gun Will Travel."
"When Dustin Hoffman was in his real heyday, in the 70's," said Ms. Goldsmith-Thomas, "salaries for stars were $500,000 a picture. It was easy to say, hey, I think I'll sit this one out. Today the salaries are often in the $5 million to $8 million range. It's much harder to say no to that."
The danger of overexposure still lurks, most agents and managers admit, but they insist that the key is choosing the right projects. In the studio era, actors like Marilyn Monroe and Gary Cooper were steered into cookie-cutter roles that enhanced their mythic stature but often left them creatively frustrated. These days, savvy performers make sure their roles stretch their image.
Mr. Travolta, many industry experts say, has made exemplary choices. "One minute he's a janitor in 'Mad City,' the next he's the President," said Mark Gill, marketing chief for Miramax Films, the Disney-owned studio that is the largest maker of independent films. "He is taking a long-range perspective, which is what distinguishes him from other actors who may find themselves backed into a corner."
Not all actors have the opportunity to chose from choice scripts. Some, especially those on the tier below current hot shots like Brad Pitt and venerable stars like Mr. Hoffman, make obvious mistakes, grabbing at whatever comes their way. Since 1990, Bill Pullman has made about two dozen movies without gaining star status; since 1992, Samuel L. Jackson has appeared in more than 30 films, many of which have been forgettable. But even actors who choose carefully, like Sean Penn, sometimes hit a wall.
Earlier this season Mr. Penn was in "The Game" with Michael Douglas; "She's So Lovely," directed by Nick Cassevettes, and Oliver Stone's "U-Turn." "The Game," in which he had a minor role, made a decent showing; the two other films were widely disliked by critics and did miserably at the box office. "Sean is very passionate about his work, and you really have to respect that," Ms. Smith said. "But careers are very delicate things, and they can't withstand an unlimited number of unsuccessful choices."
The risks remain, but many people believe that in our celebrity-crazed culture, having three or more films released in a single season can, in fact, enhance an actor's stature. "It's a game of perception," said the director Tom DeCillo, whose successful low-budget film "Living in Oblivion" lampooned the movie business in 1995. "These stars can make, say, three movies in a season, and if two stink and one's a hit, that's the one people remember; that's the one that sticks. Whereas if they only make one movie and it's a flop, that's the end of them."
Mr. DeCillo says the craze for casting a tiny list of stars in a slew of blockbusters has even filtered down to his level of independent filmmaking. His new film, "The Real Blonde," which will be released in February by Paramount, cost $15 million, barely the catering costs of some of the big studio releases. Still, there was "enormous pressure," he said, to cast stars.
He managed to reel in some B-list players with niche appeal, including Mathew Modine, Daryl Hannah and Kathleen Turner. But the distributors still clamored for him to replace Catherine Keener, an actress who has appeared in all of his films. Mr. DeCillo refused. "There is no more acting in films anymore," he said, referring to Hollywood. "They just want one of five guys on the short list to outrun fireballs."
 
A Dilemma and an Actor Who Sees Both Sides
With the pressure to cast stars -- albeit of less magnitude -- in even smaller movies, the independent film world has developed its own short list. Harvey Keitel, Christopher Walken and Denis Leary seem to be everywhere. Mr. Leary has been on both sides of the same-old-faces dilemma: he has been appearing in a number of films (including "The Matchmaker," which opened last month, and "Wag the Dog," with Mr. De Niro and Mr. Hoffman), but he has also experienced the difficulty of raising money for independent projects that don't include A-list actors. He says the situation has become surreal.
When he and the director and producer Ted Demme decided to go to a bank instead of a studio to finance their forthcoming film "Noose," they hoped to retain creative control. But the bank officers "came to us with a list of actors," said Mr. Leary.
"These guys in their suits told us who they wanted to see in the roles," he said. "One of the characters was an Irish guy, and they decided they wanted Antonio Banderas. It was crazy."
Some months later, Mr. Leary was in Atlanta performing his one-man stage show. Finding himself with a free afternoon, he decided to go to the movies at a nearby duplex theater. The two films that were playing were "Face/Off" and "Con Air."
"I thought to myself, What if I didn't want to see a thriller?" Mr. Leary said. "What if I didn't want to see guys get blown up or blow each other away?' I happen to like Nick Cage, but what if I didn't?"
