HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
A Master Who Confounded the Categorizers

BYLINE: By Phillip Lopate; Phillip Lopate, the author most recently of the collection of essays "Portrait of My Body," is writing a book of movie criticism.

 BODY:
"ROCCO AND HIS BROTHERS" is the kind of film you either embrace as one of the most powerful moviegoing experiences ever or dismiss as corny and overwrought. When it opened in 1960, this three-hour epic about five southern Italian brothers and their mother, who migrate to Milan driven by economic hope only to encounter tragedy and the family's destruction through the perversity of goodness, was as close as I could imagine to a novel on film.
The depth of characterization captured in the extraordinary performances of Alain Delon, Renato Salvatori and Annie Girardot, the piercing black and white photography by the great Giuseppe Rotunno, the intelligent screenwriting by Suso Cecchi d'Amico, the haunting score by Nino Rota and, above all, the warm, commanding direction of Luchino Visconti, cast a spell over me that I have never shaken off. Yet I understand when someone tells me the film left him or her cold, because "Rocco" and Visconti are not for everyone. 
 Perhaps more than any other giant of world cinema, Luchino Visconti makes critics uneasy, fitting untidily into the pat lineages of cinema history. He is usually credited as one of the founders of Italian neo-realism (along with Roberto Rossellini and Vittorio de Sica), but his love of melodrama, of grand passions spilling from overflowing canvases, turned him into a walking oxymoron of operatic realism, bisexuality and restrained extravagance.
Politically progressive, celebrating in many of his greatest films the vitality of the working class, he was also the supreme elegiast of his own aristocratic world. Accused of "voting left and living right" because of his taste for caviar and gloved servants, Visconti was a defiant individualist, a handsome man of royal, seductive presence -- and always a bit out of sync with his times, which may explain why he has gone in and out of style so often.
Now, two decades after his death, he is back in fashion. Starting on Friday, the Museum of Modern Art, with Ente Cinema and the Centro Sperimentale of the Cinematografia-Cineteca Nationale in Rome, is presenting the first complete Visconti retrospective in the United States, with restored prints of all 14 features and 4 shorts, including rarities never seen here.
Given a filmmaking career that spanned 35 years, it is a fairly tight body of work. This is partly because Visconti divided his energies between film, the theater and opera, and partly because he was a man of wealth and did not have to accept commercial assignments. Every film that bore his signature was a personal artistic project he wanted to make.
Visconti, who was born in 1906, came from one of the oldest, most noble families in Milan. His grandfather, the Duke of Modrone, had heavily supported La Scala opera house; his father was a cultivated playboy who arranged private theatricals in the palazzo, usually starring his mother, a talented musician who was the daughter of a millionaire industrialist. His parents had an open marriage, with infidelities on both sides, and they ultimately separated. Luchino adored his mother and was leery of his father, who sent him to cavalry school for discipline. The young man fell in love with horses, and spent 10 years racing and raising them.
It was not until his 30's, when he went to Paris, that he fell in with an artistic crowd. Two of his lovers, the fashion designer Coco Chanel and the photographer Horst Horst, completed his esthetic education. Chanel introduced him to the great French filmmaker Jean Renoir, who took him on as third assistant director for "A Day in the Country." From Renoir he learned not only the rudiments of filmmaking but also an appreciation for a humanistic cinema bursting with vitality, focusing on ordinary people, using natural locations and uninterrupted, deep-focus shots. The crowd around Renoir in the mid-1930's were all supporters of the social-democratic Popular Front, and Visconti, who had dabbled in Fascism, quickly moved leftward. He maintained allegiance to Italian Communism for the rest of his life.
RENOIR HAD PASSED ALONG A script based on James M. Cain's "The Postman Always Rings Twice," about a drifter and a woman who kill her husband, and Visconti decided to film this story as his first feature, "Obsession," using his own money. Visconti was drawn to hardboiled American writing; choosing such a pessimistic tale in itself constituted a veiled protest against the gung-ho state propaganda and frothy "white telephone" movies that were the staple of Mussolini's film industry.
"Obsession" (1942) has often been credited as the first neo-realist movie, because of its hardscrabble look and its sympathy for the downtrodden. But to the degree that Italian neo-realism was a specific response to a historical moment (the end of World War II) it would probably be more accurate to say that "Obsession" was pre-neo-realist. In fact, it had more in common with the sensual fatalism of French poetic realist films of Renoir, Julien Duvivier and Marcel Carne. While sharing many film-noir plot elements with the two American versions of Cain's "Postman," its pace is more leisurely, its tone more tender.
From all accounts, Visconti was an authoritative maestro from his first day of directing, and "Obsession" is as good a first feature as has ever been made. Visconti next cast about for a project that would more directly express his growing political commitment. Meanwhile he was financing the Resistance and hiding partisans in his house -- actions that eventually led to his being arrested, imprisoned and beaten.
Visconti's anti-Fascist credentials, in short, were probably better than those of any other neo-realist director by the time the war ended. He went out on a limb with his next opus, a three-hour semi-documentary, "La Terra Trema" ("The Earth Will Tremble," 1948), about impoverished Sicilian fishermen and their struggle to improve their lot.
IT DID NOT HELP THE FILM'S commercial possibilities that the fishermen spoke a dialect even average Italians could not fathom. But Visconti was not governed by box-office considerations: he wanted to make a cinematically beautiful agitprop statement, like Eisenstein's "Que Viva Mexico" or Orson Welles's "It's All True." And again he succeeded, with a moving, if at times tedious, film, magnificently photographed. The French critic Andre Bazin spoke of the "refined theatrical sense of Visconti, who makes compositions of the most down-to-earth reality as if they were scenes from an opera or a classical tragedy."
In the 50's Visconti rejuvenated Italy's national theater, with plays by Tennessee Williams and Arthur Miller, and directed legendary opera productions that featured Maria Callas, whose acting ability and stage presence he did a great deal to develop. To say that Visconti's films are operatic should not be read as disparaging. What he took from his knowledge of opera was a lyrical feeling for a story's architecture and a patient way of accumulating emotion until it burst like an aria. Visconti was unafraid of oversized emotion; his willingness to go for the big emotional payoff onscreen is brave and, for the most part, effective.
Another carryover from opera is the diva-ish presentation of the suffering woman who wreaks havoc. For instance, in the 1954 film "Senso," Alida Valli, as a highborn Venetian woman who enters into a degrading affair with a younger, narcissistic Austrian officer (played by Farley Granger), brings a hysterical conviction to the role.
"Senso" is one of Visconti's greatest achievements: a densely layered story set in the Garibaldi period of Italian nationalism, as much about the bitter lessons of history (idealism yielding to the status quo) as it is about erotic passion. Indeed, 19th-century history was a passion of Visconti's, and he became a stickler for accurate detail.
When male extras showed up for the opening opera scene wearing black top hats, Visconti blew up at his long-suffering costume designer, Piero Tosi, exclaiming that any ignoramus knew that in those days gray top hats were worn to the opera. Like Erich von Stroheim, who also splurged on details, he constructed narratives out of the dogged massing of physical fact until the past took on a three-dimensional solidity.
Nowhere does this weight of accurately observed detail more triumphantly bear fruit than in Visconti's other masterpiece set in the Risorgimento period, "The Leopard" (1963). Based on Giuseppe di Lampedusa's memorable novel, and anchored by Burt Lancaster's wonderful performance as a Sicilian nobleman who witnesses philosophically the transfer of power from his own aristocratic class to a grasping set of opportunistic parvenus, "The Leopard" is a mellow and melancholy feast.
Visconti the Marxist is fully aware of the need for the old order to disappear; Visconti the patrician conservative cannot help but imbue it with heroism and dignity. The concluding ball scene, in which the nobleman looks back with regret but accepts his class's death and his own, is a tour de force, as the camera glides from room to room, a vindication of Visconti's practice of taking his time and letting a scene settle.
It is precisely because Visconti made such long movies, however, that his work was so often mutilated by distributors and producers. The initial American release of "The Leopard" was not only egregiously dubbed but also hacked to pieces. The director, who had already seen "Obsession," "Senso" and "Rocco" suffer at the hands of censors and distribution companies, disowned the American "Leopard," crying out, "It is our destiny to be always in the hands of assassins."
"THE LEOPARD" marked a moment of equilibrium between Visconti's objective, dispassionate interest in the world and his need to express the more intense personal aspects of his character. Buoyed by his international prestige, he entered a phase that was more subjectively -- and, it must be said, self-indulgently -- expressive of his inner demons and family scars. "Sandra" begins the murky intermixing of incest, homosexuality and political perversions that continues in his overblown Teutonic phase: "Death in Venice," "The Damned" and "Ludwig." As his biographer, Gaia Servadio, observed, "He adopted realism when decadence was the accepted line, and he moved to decadence when realism was."
Because Visconti's masterworks -- "Obsession," "La Terra Trema," "Senso," "Bellissima," "White Nights," "Rocco and His Brothers" and "The Leopard" -- all belong in the early part of his filmmaking career, there is a tendency to view the later years as one long decline. Actually, Visconti finished up with two excellent pictures: the brittle, intelligent "Conversation Piece" (1974), with Lancaster and Helmut Berger, and "The Innocent" (1976), with Laura Antonelli and Giancarlo Giannini, a sensually compelling and hypnotically twisted tale based on the d'Annunzio novel.
Visconti always worshipped physical beauty. In the most barren rockpile in Sicily, he could not help but frame a stunning landscape worthy of Mantegna. Possessing all the refined taste in the world, he knew how to decorate and light a shot so that it glowed but did not crow. Still, he was as much a humanist as a mannerist, as "Rocco" amply demonstrates.
There is a funny anecdote, characteristic of the maestro at the height of his powers, when he tried to go backstage after an opera to see Callas. Prevented by the usher, Visconti yelled at him, "Don't you know who I am?" "Yes," replied the man, "and I know that you are going to die, just the same as I am." Visconti retorted: "You, yes; me, no!"
He often laughed afterward at this story. In the end, of course, the usher proved right, but not before Visconti had left a body of work whose noble vitality endures.

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Melvyn Weiss;
Blazing the Way in Class-Action Law

BYLINE: By SUSAN KONIG 

 BODY:
IN the legal world, Melvyn Weiss is perhaps best known as the "dean of the plaintiff's bar," and with good reason: a senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach LLP, he has been a pioneer in the field of class-action law.
Throughout his 30-year career, he won victories for plaintiffs in such landmark cases as the Drexel/Milken litigations, where he recovered nearly $1 billion for investors in Columbia Savings and Loan; the Washington Public Power Supply Systems Securities litigations, where he was one of three court-appointed lead counsels who recovered $775 million; Newman v. Stringfellow, in which he successfully represented 4,000 people exposed to toxic pollutants in Southern California and the much-publicized Exxon Valdez case. 
 Mr. Weiss is currently fighting to reform both the insurance and accounting industries, as well as to have United States tobacco companies held accountable for smoking-related illnesses. His is the largest American law firm to specialize in complex litigation, predominantly class actions, on behalf of victims of wrongdoing in securities fraud, environmental, consumer, anti-trust and mass torte (injury to persons or property) cases. The company has three offices nationwide.
After earning a bachelor's degree in accounting from Baruch College in 1957, Mr. Weiss received a J.D. from New York University Law School, where he is also a trustee. As a commissioner of the Nassau County Charter Revision Commission, he helped develop the proposal for the county's new legislative form of government. He is currently liaison counsel and a member of the executive committee -- pro bono -- for claimants in the Swiss bank litigation involving Holocaust confiscations.
Mr. Weiss lives in Oyster Bay Cove with his wife, Barbara. They have three children and five grandchildren.
Q. What made you decide to be a plaintiffs' advocate and get involved in class actions?
A. I started out as an attorney at a Wall Street law firm. It was there that I realized that victims of wrongdoing needed a counterforce against the big corporations. They needed law firms that were equal in ability and stature. So, I set out to build a firm with lawyers who were as good or better than the big firms' -- lawyers who also had the staying power to handle any case, no matter how long it lasted. That was critical, because these suits are contingency cases, meaning lawyers only get paid when they win. Some of them can last up to 10 years.
Q. How did class-action suits come about?
A. Federal class-action suits came into being in this country in 1966. Now, there are some forms of class action in parts of Canada and England, but nothing that compares to what we have in the U.S.
They came about because complex litigation has gotten so expensive that even large losses that you might think could finance an individual suit really can't. For instance, in the securities field, you may have a couple of people who've lost one million or two million dollars in a stock situation, while lots of others have lost hundreds of thousands of dollars. To level the playing field against the defense, you need the possibility of a big enough economic recovery to persuade a lawyer to take the risk.
Q. How many people constitute a class?
A. It's up to the courts, but they've held as few as 20 people to be enough, and as many as millions.
Q. How have class actions evolved over the years?
A. Their main use in the early days was in securities, anti-trust and some consumer cases. The defense bar fought against them for a long time, especially when plaintiffs' lawyers started using them in other areas, like mass torte: personal injury cases like silicone breast implants, asbestos, etc. To have mass certification, you need a predominance of common questions of law and fact, as opposed to "individual" questions. The defense bar argued that mass injury cases were predominantly about individual issues. And, of course, corporate America preferred to pick off each plaintiff one by one, making it so expensive that they wouldn't pursue it.
After awhile, though, even defendants saw class actions as a benefit, because they could wrap up all their problems in one package and dispose of it. But they'd already poisoned the well with their arguments. So now, we're going through a sea change in the way mass injury cases are handled. The legal community is considering whether they should be allowed to be "settled" as class actions, despite the fact that they may not be able to be litigated as such.
Q. What was it like pioneering these cases?
A. Sometimes, it could be hell. I really had no idea how they would end up. I was living from hand to mouth; I had long commutes and young children. Everything was at risk. As the firm grew bigger, we had a larger payroll, and the risk of failure was even more profound. There were more people relying on us. But I've always been a risk-taker by nature. I tend to look ahead, not behind. And everything worked out for the best.
Q. Things have changed with regard to class actions since you won victories like Drexel/Milken?
A. Yes. When Congress became predominantly Republican, they passed the Reform Bill in 1995, making it more difficult to file these cases in the securities industry. They created the illusion that these were frivolous cases, part of a litigation explosion perpetuated by greedy lawyers. Actually, the number of cases hasn't changed much over the last 20 years, despite an explosion in the number of securities that are traded, and the number of companies that are now public.
The accountants behind this bill failed dismally as auditors. In my view, they've not fulfilled their mandate to be independent and are easily swayed by the clients who pay their bills to get a certain result. And, they've attracted allies -- the hi-tech companies, mainly in Silicon Valley and Cambridge, Mass. We've found an awful lot of securities manipulation and financial wrongdoing in these start-up companies, because the stakes are very high. They can make fortunes overnight and then, five years later, they're gone. So, they don't like people like us standing up for those who are victimized.
Q. Is this true with other types of cases, like products liability?
A. Yes. There's a business round table spurred by companies like Dow Corning and Dow Chemical, who are trying to insulate themselves from accountability by getting Federal pre-emption. This means that if, for instance, a drug is approved by the F.D.A., no matter what happens to you as a result of using that drug thereafter, these companies can't be sued. That's pretty horrible.
Q. Your firm initiated the "Joe Camel" suits in California. How are lawsuits against the tobacco companies coming along?
A. A lot of the people suffering from tobacco-related injuries got hooked on the stuff during periods when the industry was lying about the impact. Even today, they're not telling the whole truth: they're unwilling, it appears, to put an unequivocal statement on a package that says cigarettes can cause cancer and are addictive.
When we were growing up and starting to smoke, the tobacco companies were already lying about what they knew the dangers to be. I have no problem with holding the industry accountable. The problem is, the court has to make a judgment whether common questions predominate over individual ones. They have to consider if there were other injurious influences -- did you live near a polluted waste dump, for example? But, when the A.G.'s hired lawyers to bring these actions as "economic" cases -- not personal injury -- to get back the money spent on health problems, that's when the tobacco companies started to break down.
President Clinton has helped a great deal. He's being very conscientious. I think, at this point, the settlement -- $358 billion -- is far too cheap. There are a lot of people not at the table yet who should be -- unions, states, counties, municipalities, companies that are self-insured -- all of which have picked up medical costs. When all of these claims become part of the settlement, and the amount is increased sufficiently to take care of them, then I think you'll see a legislative settlement. A lot of prognosticators feel this will happen by the end of the spring. I think it will take another $150 billion.
Q. You've long fought to reform the insurance industry, having won cases against New York Life, Prudential Life, to name a few. You are also lead counsel in a number of other high-profile insurance cases. What is being done?
A. The life insurance industry, which is regulated by each state, not federally, went virtually unregulated for 15 years since the early 80's with respect to their marketing practices. As a result, there was a lot of fraud. Companies were churning their customers, promising that premiums would vanish after a certain period of time and they didn't, and they were misrepresenting products as investment products when they were, in fact, insurance products. We got involved in these kinds of cases a couple of years ago. I formed a consortium of law firms around the country, and we've been taking on the biggest insurance companies. We've created an innovative settlement technique which has an alternative dispute resolution aspect to it. It's already been adopted by several courts.
Q. How did you get involved in the Swiss bank litigations involving Holocaust victims and their heirs?
A. I have to give kudos to a lawyer in Washington D.C., Mike Hausfeld, who I worked with on the Exxon Valdez case. He was the one who organized the pro bono effort; some lawyers in the case aren't working pro bono. The second he told me what he was doing, I was on board.
Right now, the judge is sitting on his decision as to whether or not we can continue this case in the U.S. I think that, if he rules our way, the odds of the case settling increase tremendously, as will the amount that we'll get for the victims.

HEADLINE: Theme Restaurants Draw Mall Crowds

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
T. J. CARROLL of Bellerose pointed at the fish in the ceiling-high aquarium at the Rainforest Cafe in Westbury. "Look at that!" T. J., 4, shouted to his mother, Margaret.
Moments later he looked up to see a monkey rocking on a swing above, his long tail swaying back and forth. 
 "It's a stuffed animal," Ms. Carroll told her son.
"But look at it," he said. "It's funny."
He took her hand and led her to the front of the retail area, where four parrots were on perches as an animal specialist, Marissa Schechter, explained their care. T. J. inched his way to the front, and his eyes widened as he spotted an alligator beneath Ms. Schechter's feet.
He stared intently for a moment and turned to his mother. "The birds are real, but the alligator is fake," he told her.
Later, as T. J. watched the parrots, Ms. Schechter said she had heard about the restaurant but was unaware it was such an attraction. "I came to see the mall, and this is what caught his eye," she said.
The mall is the Source, a two-story shopping center that opened on Sept. 5 as an extension of Fortunoff, a fixture on Old Country Road since 1964. A total of 35 stores dot the mall, and by the summer all 66 stores will be open, said the mall manager, Pamela J. Jurus.
The crowds, Ms. Jurus said, have been "above and beyond our expectations."
The successful economy, the mix of stores and the latest in franchises and food courts, in the opinion of retail experts, have combined to make the Source one of the hottest attractions in Nassau County. The neighboring Roosevelt Field mall, with the much-awaited opening of Nordstrom's last summer and a revitalized Bloomingdale's in a former A &S store, is also attracting large groups of shoppers, even before the holiday season starts.
The operations director for Rainforest, Michael J. Halpern, said the restaurant had had extraordinary business. The chain, which has nine other sites in the United States and three overseas, had expected Westbury to be one of its best. But crowds the first month, Mr. Halpern said, were so large that they were second only to the restaurant at Walt Disney World in Lake Buena Vista, Fla., where five-hour waits for tables are not uncommon.
"We served up to 2,000 and 3,000 people a day and 4,000 on Saturday and Sunday," Mr. Halpern said, adding that customers wait two to three hours for tables on weekends. "We thought people would find us during the holidays and we're happy they are finding us before that."
Next door at the Source is the Cheesecake Factory, where customers routinely wait more than two hours for tables. "They're crazy about us," said its executive vice president, Linda J. Candioty. "Long Island guests are incredible. They have an appetite for good food and good value."
The average annual sales in each of the 23 restaurants in the chain is $9.3 million, according to Ms. Candioty, and the company expects the Westbury store to exceed that. "This area has great demographics," she said. "Fortunoff is a great store, and the Costco, which is nearby, is the busiest in the country."
On a recent rainy Sunday crowds descended on both restaurants within minutes of the 11 A.M. opening. By 11:30, the Rainforest had a 20-minute wait for its 99 tables and 380 seats. By 1 o'clock, the wait was almost two hours, and it stayed there throughout much of the afternoon.
The waiting for one of the 300 seats at the Cheesecake Factory did not start as early, but by 2 P.M. it was running about 50 minutes.
"Both restaurants are destinations, not spur of the moment," said Mr. Halpern.
Virtually all of more than 20 people interviewed at the Rainforest said they had raced to sign up for a table when they arrived at the mall, rather than shop first.
"You normally can't get in here," said Lorraine D. Caruso of Mineola, who was on the Rainforest line with her granddaughter Jackie, 16. "That's why we're here at 11:30. My granddaughter is taking me out to lunch, and I wanted to come here."
She said two times before the Rainforest line was too long for her to wait. "It's like a Disney World," Mrs. Caruso said.
While waiting for her table, Robin S. Isaacs of Dix Hills held her daughter Jessica, 3, to show her the fish. Then Ms. Isaacs wandered among the T-shirts, sweatshirts, animal mugs, stuffed animals and other knicknacks.
Animated toy animals like jaguars, butterflies, apes and elephants lurk amid the vines and heavy foliage. "This is an ideal place for children," Ms. Isaacs said. "The concept is so educational. It shows different animals in their natural habitat and how important it is to keep the forests the way they are. If they are cut down there will be no place for the animals to live. It's one thing to see animals in a zoo. But here they are in their natural surroundings."
At the nearby We're Entertainment, Craig and Laura Merola of Laurel Hollow pushed a child in a stroller past the sweatshirts while their two other youngsters walked beside them.
"We're killing some time here," Mr. Merola said, adding that the Rainforest had a 20-minute wait and that this was her children's fourth visit. Asked whether the children had become bored, Mr. Merola turned to his children. "No!" they shouted in unison. One child, Jeffrey, 6 1/2, said he enjoyed watching the jaguar and leopards. "Sometimes they blink and wag their tail," he said.
In the nearby food court, Kami Radin of Long Beach and her two children munched on cinnamon and sesame pretzels and said they planned to return during the week to the Rainforest. "They are dying to go back," Ms. Radin said. "It's the big attraction."
As she ate the pretzel, from Auntie Anne's, she pronounced it quite good. An hour later customers were waiting 30 minutes for pretzels. Although Ms. Radin said there was no line at the Cheesecake Factory, she said it "looked a little fancy and was not appropriate for children."
"But I would like to go there with my husband," she added.
At a table at the Cheesecake Factory, Jake and Karen Rosenberg of Valley Stream were with their sons, 4 and 2. They said they had decided to eat there rather than wait at the Rainforest. "We didn't want to wait with the kids, and it was very crowded," Mrs. Rosenberg said. "We were overwhelmed by it. We just wanted a place to eat with the kids."
Mr. Rosenberg added that they had spent more than 20 minutes studying the menu, which has more than 200 dishes. "The menu is so complicated," he said.
On line to sign up for a table at the Rainforest, Jodie Z. Babbush of Canarsie said she had eaten there seven or eight times. Told that she would have to wait an hour for lunch, Ms. Babbush smiled and said:
"An hour is good. A few weeks ago on a Saturday we got here at 5:10 and got seated at 9:50. I knew the wait was going to be long. But I never anticipated it would be that long. If it was just a restaurant that stood alone I wouldn't wait that long. But there are shops around here."
Ms. Babbush said she had also eaten at the Cheesecake Factory and found that although "the food was magnificent, the restaurant was not kid friendly, because there was no children's menu."
Not everybody took the waiting in stride.
"It looks like a couple of hours wait," Steven Dalman said as he peeked into the Cheesecake Factory.
"It's too crowded," his wife, Elaine, said. "I'd never come back on a weekend. We were shopping at Fortunoff, and just walking into the mall was wall-to-wall people. I live near a mall in Smithtown, and it's not as crowded."
At the entrance to the Cheesecake Factory, Harvey A. Strickon and his wife, Linda, of Great Neck, were discussing the discounters in the mall like Loehmann's, the Nordstrom Rack and Off 5th Saks Fifth Avenue Outlet when the pager in Mr. Strickon's pocket began to vibrate. Pagers are given to customers on waiting lists rather than using a loudspeaker.
"Remember, you're name is Mintz," Mrs. Strickon told her husband with a chuckle as he went to answer the page. She explained that while waiting for a table someone named Mintz who could not wait any longer gave up his pager.
"When I came here the first week it opened, the mall was practically empty," Mrs. Strickon said. "I've been back periodically, and it's getting quite congested."
But no one eating at the Rainforest appeared upset with the crowds, the constant playing of jungle sounds over the loudspeaker and the re-creation of a thunderstorm every 22 minutes.
"It's part of the ambiance," Joanne Salvani of Lynbrook said as shouted to be heard. "And the kids love it. I'm going to bring my other grandchildren, too."
As her granddaughter Nicole, 12, pushed away an unfinished salad her grandfather, Mark, asked loudly: "Where else can you find this type of entertainment on Long Island? It's fantastic."

HEADLINE: ART;
Washington Exhibition Underscores Thomas Moran's Stature

BYLINE: By PHYLLIS BRAFF 

 BODY:
UNCANNY expanses of tall, lavender rock formations crowned in orange and silhhouetted against pink-tinged horizons were a revelation to Congress in 1872, when Thomas Moran's Yellowstone watercolors were presented as supporting evidence in the debates that led to the establishment of the National Park Service. The Government subsequently made the artist's panoramic canvases "Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone," 1872, and "Chasm of the Colorado," 1873-74, its first painting purchases for the Capitol, thus propelling him to national prominence.
Moran's successes over the next decade provided the financial basis for acquiring a former sheep pasture overlooking East Hampton's Town Pond and constructing a studio-residence in the Queen Anne-style currently favored by his artist-acquaintances in London. Beginning in 1884, and continuing for four decades, many of Moran's widely scattered geographic themes were painted on Long Island, including some that are currently featured in the stunning retrospective on view at the National Gallery of Art in Washington until Jan. 11, 1998. Moran, who was born in 1837 and died in 1926, followed the long tradition of using field sketches and composing and painting his canvases in the studio. 
 This grand retrospective examines 56 years, brings together approximately 100 oils, watercolors and drawings and features his most important projects. It is essential to understanding Moran's reputation since his significance derives from the way he tested his talents with the Western settings that make up the bulk of the material filling nine galleries on two levels of the museum. The presentation eliminates some thematic interests and gives short shrift to others, most notably his Long Island scenes, but admittedly, it is not the eastern landscapes, fine as many are, that make Moran stand apart. It was the intention of the museum, with Nancy Anderson as the exhibition's curator, to show what earned the artist a place in the history of American art.
Perhaps the show's most spectacular point is the room displaying the two Congressional purchases, each 12-feet in width, and the majestic "Mountain of the Holy Cross," a vertical canvas of comparable height that depicts a famed Colorado mountain side with snow accumulation in the configuration of a cross. Some may have considered this a comment on the divine ordination of America's scenic resources.
In the context of the 1870's, the three paintings reflect a country now crossed by the railroads that would make the economic development of the West a certainty. Moran's visions focus on the nation's glories and could have been read as celebrations either of progress or of the point when preservation concerns were crystallizing. The works are shown together for the first time as the triptych the artist had hoped to present at the Centennial Exposition. The Government had refused the 1876 loan request.
What impresses most visitors is Moran's gifts as a colorist. The feeling strikes most keenly in the gallery devoted to his interpretations of the tall, orange-topped buttes rising along the Green River in Wyoming. Gleaming, sometimes fiery images vibrate against his intense blue skies and are accented by resonant tones in the notations of foliage.
Absolutely spectacular swirling reds and yellows deliver tremendous visual energy in the exhibition's only example of the artist's interest in literary and fantasy subjects, the "Fiercely the red sun descending/ Burned his way across the heavens," inspired by Longfellow's "Song of Hiawatha." Its loose and vibrant approach is a reminder of Moran's long admiration for the paintings of Turner.
In fresh and sparkling watercolors that will come as a surprise to many, Moran seems to have used pigment expressively and imaginatively, with no limits on his daring. They can be delicate renderings of some of the world's most forceful, aggressive settings, and they often use translucent tonalities to suggest formidable rocky masses. A light and luminous "Hot Springs, Yellowstone," for example, depicts sequences of stone masses with translucent orange, transparent blue washes and thicker white gouache. Occasionally an area of color represents a landscape sensation with a freedom that today seems to be a compelling abstraction. The potential excitement for the modern eye adds to Moran's stature.
Large, major canvases are highlights throughout the exhibition. There is the broad view of powerful mid-Atlantic waves treated in "Spectres From the North," and the massive history piece, "Ponce de Leon in Florida," which Moran had hoped would be another acquisition for the Capitol.
But the spectacular effects come mostly from the views of sun-drenched peaks organized to allow the light flow to create great visual drama. Distances are vast, the geology wondrous, and there are grand, almost aerial views of mountains, with some offering just the right angle and scale to produce a feeling of vertigo.
By linking Moran's career to the rise, and eventual decline of Western themes, the exhibition overlooks the way he also responded to the developing taste for intimate, more accessible nature views and for nostalgic comments on a rural past that was rapidly vanishing. Long Island subjects served these ideas nicely and also afforded opportunities to include deep, distant horizons.
Loans are from across the country, with the most substantial quantity coming from the holdings of the Gilcrease Museum in Tulsa, Okla., where the retrospective opens in February. Its third and final stop will be Seattle.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Green River Cliffs, Wyoming" (1881) by Thomas Moran is on view at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

HEADLINE: A Book on China Dam

BYLINE: By ANNE C. FULLAM 

 BODY:
A DISSIDENT book protesting the damming of the Yangtze River in China is being published in Westchester.
Edited by Dai Qing, a Chinese journalist, the book, "The River Dragon Has Come: The Three Gorges Dam and the Fate of China's Yangtze River and Its People" is being published by M. E. Sharp Company, a small social sciences publisher in Armonk. 
 Promoting the Three Gorges dam project in Hubei Province, Chinese officials will speak Thursday at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan. Protesting the project, Dai Qing spoke before various groups in Washington last week. Ms. Qing will also speak at the Asian Pacific Economic Conference in Vancouver this week.
"Potential coffer dam failures, unusable navigation facilities and sedimentation problems threaten the safety and viability of the Three Gorges Dam project," wrote Owen Lammers, executive director of International Rivers Network, in a news release about the book. The organization is based in Berkeley, Calif., and dedicated to protecting rivers and watersheds around the world.
"This is merely the most recent evidence that science and engineering are taking a back seat to political agendas in order to erect this monument to China's hard-line regime," Mr. Lammers writes.
More than 1.2 million people will be relocated because of the project, which will create a reservoir nearly 350 miles long, the distance from Manhattan to Montreal.
Untold treasures will be buried as the project progresses. Archeologists estimate that nearly 10,000 sites will be lost once the river is dammed. Some above-ground treasures, like temples, will be relocated. But artifacts dating back 4,000 years will be lost.
Unmatched in engineering annals since the Great Wall, the great dam will have eradicated about 1,400 rural towns and villages by its completion in 2009.
Chinese officials hope the dam will solve China's projected energy crisis. Standing 607 feet high, the 1.3 mile-long dam will house 26 of the world's largest turbines.
Among the essays and field reports in the book are warnings from engineers and scientists, who cite a series of dam collapses in China in 1975, in a period of great flooding. More than 100,000 died after 60 dams broke.A former missile technician and military intelligence agent, Ms. Qing was imprisoned after the violence at Tiananmen Square in 1989. A columnist at one of China's largest dailies. she was also named a Nieman Fellow at Harvard University and a fellow at the Freedom Forum at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism.
 The book lists for $39.95. The M. E. Sharp Company has published other works by Ms. Qing. ANNE C. FULLAM

HEADLINE: A New UConn Campus Takes Shape

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
UNIVERSITY and city leaders alike are embracing the University of Connecticut's new campus in Stamford, a three-story, 243,000-square-foot building under construction at the corner of Washington Boulevard and Broad Street. The downtown campus, scheduled to open in January, will accommodate 3,000 students, double the number at the Scofieldtown Road campus in North Stamford, which is reverting to the city of Stamford.
The new campus arrives with a $10 million endowment largely from private corporations, an arresting design of steel and glass, and a mission: To mesh the academic interests of a college campus with the information-technology market growing around it. 
 A change in attitude among staff in Stamford has already taken hold. The old habit of calling it the "Stamford branch" is likely to spur a quick correction; its days as a mere appendage to Storrs, more than two hours' drive away. are over, they say.
At the heart of the new campus is the Connecticut Information Technology Institute, a degree program set up by UConn's engineering and business schools at Storrs. The program, known by the acronym CITI and supported by public and private initiatives, is meant to train a work force in information technology.
Stamford, the home of many technology-driven corporations, wants to broaden its support for these companies, and the city's economic development director, Kip Bergstrom, said a downtown UConn campus would fill that need nicely.
"On any given day, there are 200 job openings at information technology companies in Stamford," Mr. Bergstrom said. "These companies are doubling in size every year. If we want to keep that growth here, we have to supply the work force." The Mayor of Stamford, Dannel P. Malloy, said the campus would also offer a more sophisticated atmosphere and a younger night life to what Mr. Malloy calls "the most alive, busiest downtown between New York and Boston."
"This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for the university to reinvent itself, to put itself on the map in a highly focused technology category," he said. "We are an economic and financial services center. There are so many things to be a part of."
In order for UConn's Downtown Initiative, as the new campus effort is called, to get where it is today, proponents had to overcome the doubts of university presidents and state governors as well as a faculty in Storrs that saw development in Stamford as a drain on an already poorly funded state university.
L.C. (Whitey) Heist, a UConn trustee and an Old Greenwich resident who was president of the Champion Corporation, recalled faculty resistance as particularly fierce. "They see it as one less dollar for them," Mr. Heist said, "not one more dollar for the university as a whole."
That mood has since been assuaged by the financial support the Downtown Initiative has received from Stamford corporations, but Mr. Heist insisted the mood of resistance has not gone away. "It's not something you hear anymore on the Storrs campus," he said. "It's politically incorrect now. But do most of the faculty at Storrs think it's a good idea? No."
Traditionally the legislature has not been especially supportive of the university, and Fairfield County legislators even less so. But the early backing of two Stamford Democrats, House majority leader Moira Lyons and Senate majority leader George Jepsen, along with Republican Senator William Nickerson of Greenwich, was central in turning the tide and including Stamford as a key component of a $1 billion, 10-year package.
Gov. John G. Rowland, like his predecessor Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., was reportedly not warm to the idea initially, but is said to have since become more supportive. "I don't think he originally understood the implications of it all, but he came around quick," said Frank D. Rich Jr., a developer in Stamford and formerly a UConn trustee.
The implications include a campus that will be wired into the technological world around it as well as connected to the economic boomlet in lower Fairfield County.
Some of the Storrs faculty seem not only resigned to a downtown Stamford campus but positively ebullient about it. Thomas Gutteridge, dean of UConn's business school, speaks of the "fantastic potential" inherent in the new site and its relationship to the Stamford business community.
"We want to be known for excellence in technology," he said. "What we are seeing in Stamford is a common thread of technological sophistication."
Many of UConn's other satellite campuses -- the Health Center in Farmington, the law school in Hartford -- have forged identities by specializing in specific fields of learning. Even campuses that offer liberal arts degrees have their niches: The Avery Point campus in Groton, for example, has become known for its concentration in marine sciences.
Mr. Gutteridge foresees a similar concentration in business at the new Stamford campus: "Not that it won't have other things, but there is no question the Stamford campus will have a very strong business focus."
Fred Maryanski, UConn's vice chancellor and overseer of its regional campuses, notes the Stamford campus will continue to offer six undergraduate liberal arts degrees. But he agrees the "evolving focus" has been on business.
The Master's of Business Administration program has been one of the Stamford's biggest draws, with some 500 part-time students, and 50 more enrolled in the executive M.B.A. program. Now, the campus will be able to offer bachelor's degrees in business, too. Seminar and workshop programs will be set up in the evenings, according to Stamford's business school director, Birgit Berry, drawing on the area's large senior executive pool for both speakers and attendees.
Space won't be a problem at the new campus; two auditoriums, a computer center and two-story library are among its features.
But new programs require new faculty, and that, Ms. Berry noted, means money. "CITI will bring us additional faculty," she said, "but the undergraduate program will mean more full-time faculty, and money needs to come in for that. We have a great building going up, but if we don't get staffing, it's going to prevent us from growing."
Whether that building is completed in time to meet a Jan. 21 deadline for vacating Scofieldtown Road is a deeper concern right now than staffing. Complications have ranged from a construction company's bankruptcy to trouble with footings in what is left of the shell last used by Bloomingdale's in the 1980's. The original opening day had to be pushed back from October, and there are concerns it may be pushed back again.
UConn Stamford's interim director, Curtiss E. Porter, insists Jan. 21 is still a realistic deadline. "It's going to be a quick step, but it's very doable," he said.
Many in Stamford hope the campus will expand the number of undergraduate degrees it offers after a three-year phase-in program is completed. Mr. Heist likes the idea of introducing fine arts programming, noting the city's two major theaters as well as its proximity to Broadway.
UConn officials in Storrs uniformly dismiss the idea of a decentralized university program, even with the appointment last year of a new president, Philip Austin, previously chancellor of the University of Alabama, which has no central campus. Mr. Gutteridge calls the Stamford campus "a spoke in a wheel" that will still have its hub in Storrs.
But if the university's authority remains concentrated in Storrs, its orientation no longer seems as focused north of Hartford. Of the 19 trustees, Mr. Heist is one of three from Greenwich, geographically as far from Storrs as is possible without leaving the state. But Mr. Austin said he was in Stamford "every two, three weeks." "Our deans of business and engineering are down there repeatedly. We have made a substantial commitment, and this should be interpreted as UConn's commitment to Fairfield County."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Construction continues on UConn's new downtown Stamford campus at Washington and Broad. A Jan. 21 deadline has been set for leaving the old campus in North Stamford. (Joseph Kugielsky for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Energy Leader Gets the Ear of the President

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THOMAS R. CASTEN has been rising before the sun, the ideas flowing even before his head leaves the pillow. Position papers, a book, all are taking shape under headings like "The Environmental Benefits of Electric Company Restructuring" and "Combining Production of Heat and Power."
For 20 years, the 6-foot-1 Mr. Casten, a former Marine who served in Vietnam, said he has been waiting for someone of national importance to heed his message: power plants can become doubly efficient and in the process dramatically reduce their emission of greenhouse gases by capturing waste heat and turning it into steam for heating office buildings and houses. 
 One of the most effective and economical ways to help the environment, he said, is for electric companies to compete with one another on the open market instead of being hampered by outmoded regulations.
Now, at last, someone is paying attention to what Mr. Casten has to say. That someone is the President of the United States.
Mr. Casten, president of Trigen Energy Corporation here, was one of the industry leaders who gathered for a daylong White House conference on climate change held recently at Georgetown University in Washington. President Clinton engaged in intense discussion with a panel of experts, including Mr. Casten, in preparation for a 150-country meeting on global warming to be held next month in Kyoto, Japan. Negotiations for an international treaty to limit emissions of carbon dioxide are expected to culminate at the meeting, which is viewed as a first step in reducing the rate of increase of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.
Mr. Casten has shown his energy and determination in groups as diverse as the Boy Scouts, which, for his lifetime of service, named him the Distinguished Eagle Scout in Westchester and Putnam Counties this year, and the Westchester Philharmonic, which he helped start in 1983.
Scientists have painted a dire picture of what will happen on earth if heat-trapping carbon dioxide emissions, produced by the burning of fossil fuels, are not curtailed.
"My message today is simple," the 55-year-old Mr. Casten told Mr. Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and other members of the audience. "You can unleash market forces that will lower greenhouse gas emissions and reduce energy costs by opening electric markets to retail competition. America's entrepreneurs will eliminate energy waste, if given a chance to compete." Then he added: "When you go to Kyoto, play to our strengths. Tell the other nations that we will unleash our entrepreneurial strength to improve power plants worldwide."
A few weeks later, at the National Geographic Society in Washington, when he heard President Clinton's address on global warming, Mr. Casten said he was gratified to hear the following: "Here at home, we must move forward by unleashing the full power of free markets and technological innovations to meet the challenge of climate change." The President later presented a plan to reach the 1990 greenhouse emissions level by 2008 to 2012 with a $5 billion program of tax cuts and research and development for new technologies, incentives for companies that cut emissions early and an international-market-based emissions trading system.
Never mind that the President did not quite endorse deregulation and critics contend that the Government is moving too slowly to curtail greenhouse gases, Mr. Casten said. The ball, though still on the one-yard line at the wrong end of the field, he said, is at least in motion.
Trigen, a company founded by Mr. Casten and several partners in 1980, aims to cut fuel use and pollution in half by using the heat normally wasted in generating a product like electricity. The company, which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, operates with a system called combined heat and power to produce electricity, steam and chilled water for cooling from one source. Trigen -- the term trigeneration, which the company coined, refers to the generation of the three products -- serves customers like the Coors brewery in Golden, Colo., the John Hancock Building in Boston, the Nassau Community College and public buildings in Nassau County and government offices and other buildings in Philadelphia, Baltimore and St. Louis, among other cities.
The company, which had total revenues of $250 million last year, claims 70 percent efficiency for its fuel compared with 30 percent efficiency for most of the larger power plants in the country. What bothers Mr. Casten is that utility companies are not permitted to use the strategies and maneuvers that enable other businesses to grow and be innovative. Under current laws, utility companies lack the incentive for improvement, he said.
Mr. Casten said he believes that market forces are the answer to the global catastrophe -- at least where the United States is concerned. He approached addressing the President like an actor who has been studying his role for a long time: he was raring to go. "I wasn't nervous," Mr. Casten said in a recent interview in his office. "I've never been so prepared for anything in my life."
Before the Georgetown conference took place, President Clinton referred to Trigen and to Mr. Casten by name in discussing efficient energy production with a group of weather forecasters. After the conference, his picture appeared in The Washington Post with Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore, and magazine editorials repeated phrases nearly verbatim from his speech. To those who know the Colorado native, his effective use of the limelight came as no surprise. He was the founding chairman of the Westchester Philharmonic, and many credit the orchestra's continued success to his firm guidance in its early years.
But because recycled energy is not a widely familiar concept, Mr. Casten was not able to use his gifts for communication and persuasion in his own arena until recently, when the coming Kyoto conference forced a thorough study of the global warming issue. Now that he has the President's ear, Mr. Casten said, he is keeping a steady flow of information headed toward Washington about the benefits of deregulation. Opponents include members of the utilities industry as well as some environmentalists, who fear increased pollution if coal plants in the Middle West are allowed to make power for the Northeast.
"Markets don't work that way," Mr. Casten said. "Typically, an environmentalist is not somebody that really understands markets."
He referred to the dissension within the Administration about suggestions like taxing carbon -- a strategy Mr. Casten vehemently opposes -- and compared deregulating electricity with opening trade with China: it took a Republican, Richard M. Nixon, to do the latter, and it may take a Democrat, operating within a traditional Republican domain, to do the former. "This is not a popular political issue," Mr. Casten said. "This is Clinton thinking about his legacy. It is his fate to have been the President of the most powerful nation in the world when we found out, almost for the first time, that human activities had reached a scale where we were affecting the globe."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/Hudson View Gardens;
In Upper Manhattan, a 1924 Touch of Tudor Suburbia

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
THE labyrinth of long one-way streets in upper Manhattan just north of the George Washington Bridge gives the neighborhood a sequestered air. And one of the best-kept secrets is Hudson View Gardens, a 1924 garden-apartment co-op complex between Pinehurst Avenue and Cabrini Boulevard, from 183d to 185th Street. The complex has almost completed a restoration campaign begun six years ago, and the nearly suburban enclave is a delight for anyone dissatisfied with the traditional New York City apartment.
Hudson View Gardens was built by Dr. Charles V. Paterno. Although Paterno got his medical degree in 1899, he never practiced medicine; he instead joined his brothers Joseph and Michael in the family contracting business. Just after 1900 they began to concentrate on apartment development around the Columbia University campus at 116th Street and Broadway, and they hit a comfortable formula with the new type of 12-story elevator apartment buildings that were beginning to line West End Avenue and Broadway. 
 Apparently there was plenty of business, because by 1915 the brothers had established separate contracting firms and later built some of the most luxurious buildings on Park and Fifth Avenues.
Charles Paterno bought a plot of land on the high cliff overlooking the Hudson at 184th Street, where in 1908 he built a stone house similar to a castle on the Rhine. Its giant retaining wall is still obvious to northbound drivers on the Henry Hudson Parkway, just north of the George Washington Bridge. At the same time the new Broadway subway line was attracting other developers to upper Manhattan, and to protect his estate he bought an additional 20 acres a block away. The land sat empty through the 1910's, as Paterno built big buildings all over Manhattan farther south.
In 1923 he finally decided to develop the land and hired the architect George F. Pelham Jr., who came up with an unusually inventive plan. The long, north-south site slopes steeply down to the west from Pinehurst Avenue to Cabrini, and Pelham designed two solid walls of apartment buildings facing the avenues. But he made each line an irregular facade of peaked roofs and landscaped indentations, all in the Tudor style then becoming popular in suburban apartment houses.
In a brilliant move, Pelham and Paterno created a secluded enclave by placing the building entrances toward the center of the lot -- an area developers of other sites usually left as a barren concrete courtyard. Running a private street down the center -- it is still private -- they put the taller six-story elevator apartment buildings on the high side and the lower four-story walkup buildings on the low side, to distribute river views as widely as possible among the 354 apartments.
Because the westernmost buildings are downslope, this long central area has plenty of afternoon light. The craggy retaining walls and irregular stairways make a picturesque space, creating the feel of a medieval hill town. Because Paterno wanted to appeal to a higher economic class than that in the surrounding buildings, he built Hudson View Gardens as a co-op rather than a rental complex. In one advertisement in August 1924, the most expensive apartment was a two-bedroom for $10,000, with maintenance of $84 a month. Most apartments were one- or two-bedrooms.
For the target tenant -- someone who might otherwise live in a small midblock apartment in central Manhattan -- Hudson View Gardens was out of the way. So Paterno put everything he could into providing efficient apartments in beautiful surroundings. Kitchens were carefully planned and had automatic dishwashers; living rooms had built-in Murphy beds. There was central radio service with a rooftop technician in charge of monitoring incoming signals, a post office, a child's nursery, a barber shop, community rooms, a restaurant and a grocery.
IN 1925 Pelham wrote about the difficulty of marketing new ideas. "There is little of the pioneer in the speculative builder," he declared, because "the New York renter is indeed a timorous fellow." Perhaps because of this timorousness, 200 apartments remained vacant for a year, and Paterno increased his advertising budget from $50,000 to $400,000.
Andrew S. Dolkart, a preservationist and historian, moved into the complex a decade ago and has painstakingly collected Paterno's promotional literature. The newspapers of the day were filled with advertisements designed to look like news stories: "Fine Families Flock to Apartment Citadel" was the headline for one in The New York Times in 1924. Paterno even offered purchasers a money-back guarantee.
A look at the few available previous addresses of new tenants suggests that many were already living in upper Manhattan: Harry A. Kidder, an electrical engineer, moved from Wadsworth Avenue, and William Gettinger, an engraver, moved from West 160th Street. It is difficult to determine how well Paterno made out on his investment, but he did protect his clifftop castle from undesirable neighbors.
Mr. Dolkart said that Paterno's venture had apparently not influenced other builders -- the surrounding buildings are almost all standard in design.
In the 1920's Paterno bought an estate in Westchester near Armonk, and in 1927 he announced plans for a 90-story apartment house across the Hudson on the Palisades -- a venture with which he never went ahead. In 1939 he replaced his castle with five 12-story towers, Castle Village, so arranged to allow some view of the Hudson for the earlier buildings. Paterno died in 1946.
Like some other co-ops of its day, Hudson View Gardens did not permit sales to Jews. Walter Gray of Mount Kisco, N.Y., who grew up in in the surrounding neighborhood in the 1930's and 40's, when it was mostly Jewish, said that "we didn't exactly cry when they lost their unobstructed river views." Mr. Dolkart said the restriction barring Jews fell in the 1960's.
In 1991, he said, the co-op began a major exterior-restoration program to stop leaks in over 100 apartments. Carl Goedecke, a past president of the co-op and head of the building committee, would not provide the precise cost of the program but said it was "in the millions." Crews from Kay Construction are replacing roof slate, copper gutters and the half-timbering, and repointing and painting the stucco panels.
The most ambitious of the original services, such as the post office and the barber shop, are gone, but there is still a nursery, playground and garden.
The co-op also retains a gardener, Barry Turner, and the central area is now a leafy wash of grasses and shrubs in yellow, green, silver and orange, with occasional bright red berries.
Hikari Hathaway, a sales agent with Simone Song Properties, a firm specializing in Hudson View Gardens, said a two-bedroom apartment is now for sale for $149,000, with a monthly maintenance of $741.
Mr. Dolkart, who had lived at 92d Street and Amsterdam Avenue before he moved, now tells his acquaintances: "I live in paradise. When you come home at night you open the windows and it starts to rain, and you feel like you're in summer camp. It's the greatest hidden treasure in New York."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Interior courtyard and driveway of Hudson View Gardens in 1926. (Avery Library, courtesy of Andrew Dolkart); The co-op complex is nearing completion of a restoration begun in 1991. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
After Home Ownership, 'Home Keepership' Is Key

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

 BODY:
THOUSANDS of Long Island homeowners lose their houses to foreclosure each year, even though the region's unemployment rate of 4 percent is the lowest it has been since 1988.
Moreover, housing experts warn, mortgage delinquencies could get worse. They blame the easy availability of consumer credit, home equity loans that place a second mortgage on a house, the cut in salary that often occurs when people are forced to change jobs and the fact that more families with marginal incomes now qualify for mortgages under various programs designed to increase home ownership. 
 Lenders require buyers who apply for low-down-payment mortgages and loans that allow a high ratio of debt to income to receive pre-purchase counseling before they can qualify for such a loan. But post-purchase advice on how to budget or how to deal with a job loss or other crises is not a requirement. Job loss, illness, and divorce are the three main reasons people fall behind.
Recent Government figures show that home ownership is at a record high, with 66 percent of households now owning their own homes, said Jim Morgo, the president of the Long Island Housing Partnership, a nonprofit housing group in Hauppauge. He estimated that the rate of home ownership on Long Island was now close to 75 percent.
But helping buyers achieve home ownership is only half the story, he added. "Even though there is a boom in the local economy, and even though we have the highest rate of home ownership ever among low- and moderate-income people, we have to guard against the underside of home ownership and that is foreclosure," he said.
(In a foreclosure proceeding, the lender gets a court judgment for nonpayment of the mortgage. A court-appointed referee then auctions off the property.)
Last Monday, a conference on the foreclosure problem held in Melville brought together nonprofit groups, bankers and others in the real estate industry to discuss possible solutions.
The conference, called "Keeping the Dream," was co-sponsored by the Long Island Housing Partnership and Representative Rick A. Lazio, a Babylon Republican who chairs the House Subcommittee on Housing and Community Opportunity.
"The irony of it is that the American dream can become a nightmare for homeowners if they don't take the proper steps to deal with problems either before they happen or once they happen," Mr. Lazio said. "The people that are involved in housing have to be aware of that and what needs to be done is to develop local partnerships to work on implementing the strategies that are out there in a collaborative way."
LOANS going through foreclosure are at their highest level in 10 years, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, a trade group based in Washington. A survey of 22 million loans found that 1.08 percent were in foreclosure on June 30, 1997, compared to 0.96 percent in June 1987. In New York State the percentage rose over the same period from 0.46 to 1.65 percent.
New foreclosure actions, referred to as lis pendens, are on the increase, according to Atlantic Foreclosure Research in New Hyde Park. In 1995 there were 3,345 such filings in Nassau and Suffolk; in 1996 there were 3,426, and by Oct. 31 this year there were already 3,473.
Members of the housing industry say those numbers could be sharply reduced if homeowners sought counseling help as soon as they experienced financial difficulties.
"What we call 'home keepership' is becoming much more of an issue, and to eliminate future foreclosures we need educated consumers," said Andrew Thaw, president of the New York Society of Mortgage Professionals, which includes banks, mortgage bankers and others involved with the homebuying process among its members.
Nobody wins when a home is foreclosed on, said Lesley A. Wainwright, senior vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank. "Our interest is to help people attain the American dream, so we want to keep them in that house and do whatever we can to make sure that happens," he said.
Nonprofit housing groups like the Housing Partnership provide counseling for a minor fee or at no charge and can often negotiate a workout with a lender if a homeowner comes in for help before the situation reaches a crisis point.
Diane Patrizio, a counselor for the Housing Partnership, noted that many homeowners in trouble were people who bought their houses in the last year and a half, and who now cannot handle the payments. Very often, she said, a family qualifies for a loan only by getting a parent or other family member to co-sign the mortgage note.
The reality is that the parent is not going to step in when the family falls behind on its mortgage payments, she said.
And many people wait far too long to get help, she added. "If they are two months behind, we can call the mortgage company and try to work something out, but many people call us when they are six months behind and the house is going up for auction. At that point, I have to advise them, 'Get an attorney.' "
Lowering the interest rate on a mortgage to reduce monthly payments and make them more affordable is just one of the many strategies lenders can use to help a homeowner, said Michael A. Quinn, senior vice president of credit loss management at Fannie Mae. The publicly traded company is the nation's largest source of funds for home mortgages.
"Foreclosure is the last thing anyone wants," Mr. Quinn said. "What we want is for everyone who has a problem to have a shot at working it out."
FORECLOSURES represent only 0.5 to 0.6 percent of mortgages invested in by Fannie Mae, which last year did a total business volume of $211 billion worth of loans on single-family houses from lenders that originated them, Mr. Quinn said. Because the company has a number of workout options available, only about 50 percent of loans on which there are delinquencies ever reach the foreclosure stage, Mr. Quinn said.
Under new guidelines announced by Fannie Mae in September, companies that service its loans will identify those homeowners with past-due payments who are the most at risk and will work with them on resolving problems rather than spending resources on those likely to resume payments on their own.
Mr. Quinn said the idea was "to focus on people who need help the most early in the process, so that you can save a lot more people from foreclosure."
In a typical workout situation, the interest rate on a $62,250 mortgage was reduced from 11.375 percent to 8.5 percent resulting in a reduction on interest and principal payments from $638.35 monthly to $499.97 monthly.
Past due payments of $2,600 were added to the principal amount and the mortgage term was extended to pay for them.
Under another type of workout, Fannie Mae and the homeowner enter a written agreement under which monthly mortgage payments are suspended or reduced for a specific period to allow the borrower enough time to recover from a financial setback.
OTHER strategies include allowing a new buyer to take over the mortgage -- thereby making a sale easier -- or allowing the homeowner to voluntarily sign over the deed to satisfy the mortgage, avoid foreclosure and preserve his or her credit standing.
Homeowners whose mortgages are insured by the Federal Housing Administration, an agency of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, used to be able to negotiate a workout directly with H.U.D.
Under guidelines adopted last year, they are now referred back to their lenders, who in turn refer them to a H.U.D.-approved housing counseling agency that can advise them on what options are available.
Under a new policy, the F.H.A. also can pay for arrears on a delinquent mortgage to encourage a lender to restructure the loan. The amount paid by the F.H.A. is added on as an interest-free second mortgage which the homeowner must repay. Homeowners may call (800) 569-4287 for more information on counseling.
"We have been educating purchasers at the front end, and now we are educating the homeowners and the lending industry in terms of what can be done to help people keep their houses," said Juan V. Bautista, director of the single-family housing division at H.U.D.'s New York office.
Jonathan E. Zimmer, executive director of Action Housing, a nonprofit housing advocacy group in Pittsburgh, who was among the speakers at last week's conference on foreclosures, said new options might include programs similar to one developed by Pennsylvania.
The program provides state loans to homeowners who have lost their jobs through no fault of their own and who face foreclosure as a result.
Adopted in 1983, the program has helped almost 20,000 families save their homes, Mr. Zimmer said in a telephone interview.
"This is not a grant program, it's not a handout," he said. "It's a loan program that helps people re-establish themselves and rebuild their lives."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Rick A. Lazio, left, with Jim Morgo, president of the Long Island Housing Partnership. Mr. Lazio and the Partnership sponsored a Hauppauge conference on foreclosures. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)
