HEADLINE: SHOPPING AROUND;
A Retail State of Mind

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

 BODY:
FOR some it is compulsion, the need to possess yet one more thing. For many, it is clear-cut purpose, an essential item for home or work. And for others, it is a way to pass the time on a rainy day, or maybe just a cloudy one.
Whatever the reason, New Jersey is a state of highly motivated consumers who shop hard and shop often. They spend tens of billions a year -- about $77 billion last year, up from about $74 billion the year before -- on cars, groceries, clothes, home furnishings, gasoline, building materials, you name it. 
 New Jersey consumers have the second-highest per-capita income in the country, after Connecticut. And their households average more than $53,000 a year in buying power, according to Market Statistics, a New York company that analyzes spending data.
New Jersey, marketing analysts say, is brimming with ideal retail customers. The population is diverse -- essentially a racial and ethnic mirror of national census data -- comparatively affluent, well-educated and densely packed into a small geographic area. There is more retail spending per square foot in New Jersey than in any other state.
While California, Texas and Florida dominate domestic retailing by sheer size alone, New Jersey is America itself. The New Jersey consumer is the typical American consumer, happily following market trends that have made the United States, from coast to coast, a country that drives, eats and wears pretty much the same things.
New Jersey is the near-perfect retail petri dish, where retailers and marketers can study trends and fine-tune strategies. "New Jersey is probably at the leading edge of where the rest of the nation is going." says Dr. James. W. Hughes, an economist who is dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University,
People in New Jersey have less time to shop and are spending more money in "big box" discount stores like Wal-mart and "category killers" like Home Depot and Sports Authority, which seek to dominate their particular niche, offering more housewares or athletic gear than can be found in a traditional department store.
These megastores are sprouting rapidly around the state, offering longer hours and lower prices and perpetually stocked shelves thanks to some of the most advanced high-tech inventory control systems.
In New Jersey, a largely suburban state where pedestrians often seem to be in short supply, driving patterns have a heavy influence on where people shop. Window shopping in New Jersey is what you do in Home Depot in the aisle between lumber and aluminum siding.
To avoid traffic, potential shoppers are apt to drive in one direction but not the other, analysts say, which is why it sometimes makes sense for retailers to have a store on either side of the same road, the way gas stations often do.
And though it sometimes seems as if there are more malls than the state can accommodate, there is constant planning for expansions and new construction, including the Virginia-based Mills Corporation's desire to build the state's largest mall in the Meadowlands. But over-building, the experts say, is a real-estate issue and not a major concern for retailers.
Like malls across the country, existing malls here, many built in the 1950's, 60's and 70's, are adding more entertainment attractions and services to draw customers and to fight competition from other malls and from the new "big box" power centers, like one in Woodbridge that includes a Caldor, an Office Max, a PetsMart and a Shop-Rite.
The next trend that retail forecasters expect to see is the start of a megastore die-off in super-saturated markets.
"The number of power centers and category killers is growing so fast, somebody is going to have to assume the role of carnage on the retail landscape" said Dr. Hughes of Rutgers. "We are going to have big box busts. How many super pet stores can you have in one market area?"
At the same time that the big boxes and their big parking lots are being constructed on the outskirts of many New Jersey towns, local downtowns throughout the state are experiencing something of a renaissance.
Places like Morristown, Red Bank, Summit and Cranford have created downtown improvement districts, which allow municipalities to collect a special tax used to revive and support the business district.
Many of these towns are attracting small businesses that would never generate enough cash flow to survive in a mall but can flourish in a downtown setting with cheaper rents and loyal, local customer base -- second-hand book shops, for example, antique stores or clothing boutiques.
"Essentially you find that the towns that are attracting retail are the towns that are managed much like malls," says Beth Peterson, the executive director of Downtown New Jersey, an association of downtowns based in Summit.
"They provide things like the mall does, security, easy parking, marketing, beautification, all the things that shoppers have come to expect from a mall," she said. "They tend to provide the same kinds of things in terms of other entertainment like the malls do, concerts and crafts fairs and local events for kids that bring parents and grandparents. And they create traffic not unlike the malls."
There is little question that retailers, at every level, love the state of New Jersey.
In all, there are about 20,000 retailers operating some 50,000 establishments. They employ 575,000 people and generate $7 billion in sales taxes in New Jersey, according to the National Retail Federation in Washington and Melanie Willoughby, the president of the New Jersey Retail Merchants Association in Trenton.
In 1996, there were 1,131 shopping centers in New Jersey with 154.6 million square feet of leasable retail space, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers, which is located in New York and defines shopping centers by eight different categories depending on their size.
They range from neighborhood centers with between 30,000 and 150,000 square feet of retail space to power centers with between 250,000 and 600,000 square feet to super-regional centers with more than 800,000 square feet.
Each month last year, according to the council, about 5.6 million adults shopped at the centers in New Jersey. And construction began last year on 20 more shopping centers in New Jersey with a total of 1.4 million square feet of leasable space.
"A lot of retailers want to do business here," said Ms. Willoughby, whose organization represents 1,400 retailers and who points to the rapid expansion of Wal-Mart, Target and Home Depot as the latest sign of the state's market appeal. "They rapidly expanded here because of the value that they are able to receive. New Jersey is a mecca for retailers because you have more disposable income."
The rise of the category killer, the revival of the downtown, all are functions of a continuing conflict that is one of the major driving forces in modern American retailing: a love-hate relationship between the consumer and consumerism.
Shopping, like driving, is a way of life in New Jersey. It is also a pastime, a fall-back activity, like watching television. Whether people enjoy or despise it, however, is an unresolvable point of debate.
"People definitely like to shop," said Hazam Peralto, a 16-year-old from Cliffside Park who works after school at a Gap store in the Garden State Plaza. "Usually people will come into the mall saying they're looking for something specific and they'll leave with 50 extra items. They'll come for leisure time, for entertainment. 'We're bored, let's go to the mall. Let's shop.' "
Surveys of shoppers, however, show something else.
"People basically find that shopping is a chore," says Kurt Barnard, a consultant and president of Barnard's Retail Trend Report based in Scotch Plains. "It's a real chore. They do it because they have to. They need things. But they want to get it over with fast. Very few people today will tell you shopping is a source of personal satisfaction and happiness."
Both sentiments are valid, analysts say, and these contradictory notions -- that on the one hand people love to shop in New Jersey and on the other, people in New Jersey hate to shop -- are a key to understanding shoppers and shopping in this state and across the country.
"You are talking about retailing," Mr. Barnard said, feigning exasperation. "Whether in New Jersey or Arkansas, it makes no difference, what you need is not so much an economist but a sociologist, a psychologist, because really we are dealing with shifts in social attitudes, with shifts in life styles."
Those shifts include the predominance of two-income families and a vast decrease in the amount of time that the primary shopper (overwhelmingly the woman, studies show) in the family can spend instores.
But if you have to shop (and who doesn't?), New Jersey is a better place than most.
To start, the variety of stores is virtually boundless. On the high end, for example, is the Mall at Short Hills, with anchor stores that include Saks Fifth Avenue, Bloomingdale's and Neiman Marcus.
On the discount end, Wal-Mart, K-Mart, Caldor, Bradlee, Marshalls, Target have numerous locations throughout the state, not to mention the newer warehouse club stores like Price-Costco or BJ's Wholesale club and a host of stores with mid-range prices.
New Jersey's 6 percent sales tax is equal to Pennsylvania's and New Jersey has no tax on most clothing, which draws out-of-town shoppers from neighboring states, especially across the Hudson from New York City, which has an 8.25 percent sales tax on retail purchases.
According to the state Department of Travel and Tourism, visitors made 134.1 million day trips and 37.3 million overnight trips to New Jersey last year and made $5.7 billion in retail purchases.
One drawback for people who live in the state has been the ever-worsening traffic and parking situation. An unwillingness by shoppers to spend time on clogged roadways has hurt the enclosed regional shopping malls, experts say.
"First you have to drive to the mall," explained Kurt Barnard, the retail analyst. "Then, you have a lot of problems finding a parking space, then you have to fight your way into the mall. Getting back out later on can also be a daunting experience in terms of finding the car where you left it. You finally fight your way in the mall and what greets you? Well, hundreds of stores, many of which look exactly alike. You don't have time to deal with all of this."
The big box, category killers -- electronics stores like Nobody Beats the Wiz or Circuit City, book stores like Borders or Barnes & Noble -- tend to be found in clusters but often in separate buildings with their own parking lots.
"You drive in, it's a short walk to the store," said Dr. Hughes of Rutgers. "You buy what you want, get out, get home and get on with your life."
But all over New Jersey, from the Garden State Plaza in Paramus to the Cherry Hill Mall, from the Target store in May's Landing to the Wal-Mart in Clinton people are shopping and not all of them are moving at a frantic pace.
"It was raining out," said Anthony Vicidomini, who was with his fiancee, Heather Rogers, at the Home Depot on Mount Pleasant Avenue in Dover last Sunday afternoon. "We just wanted to get out for a while." They had driven about 45 minutes from their home in Sussex and also planned to go to a nearby Sears and a Price-Costco.
In their shopping cart, they had a pot to replant an overgrown cactus and a big bag of bird seed and they were looking at garage doors. Visiting a megastore made the drive worth it, said Mr. Vicidomini, 30 school custodian.
"It's worth it, if you are going to save 50 bucks," he explained. "Travel a little, pay three or four dollars in gas."
Christina Bowman, 76, of East Stroudsberg, Pa., had crossed the border at the other side of the state to shop at the Rockaway Townsquare Mall. Mrs. Bowman, a Brooklyn native, said she and her daughter Judy Alfieri, 53, were doing early Christmas shopping and had come to Rockaway in search of excitement and a greater variety of stores. "This is where you belong," she said. "This is where it's at. We come to Jersey, we feel alive."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 6; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1191 words

HEADLINE: SHOPPING AROUND: RENEWAL;
By Helping People Do More Than Shop, Local Merchants Find Ways to Prosper

BYLINE: By CARRIE BUDOFF

DATELINE: RED BANK

 BODY:
For 151 years, Clayton & Magee, a family-run haberdashery in Red Bank's downtown shopping district, supplied businessmen with some of the finest custom-made suits, silk shirts and woolen trousers in central New Jersey. When other men's clothiers in this quaint town along the Navesink River closed because of competition from a nearby mall, Clayton & Magee stood firm and barely altered its format.
But times have changed, and so has the business of dressing men and boys in a downtown retail district. Don Magee, who runs the store with his 80-year-old father, recently decided to sell off most (but not all) of the inventory to make room for pottery, hand-blown glass, books and funky furniture. Red Bank now has a "life style store," as Mr. Magee calls it, for men. 
 Men's clothiers were once the mainstays of Main Street, along with tailors and barbershops with the striped poles standing guard outside the door. But the demand for formal business attire has dropped off in recent years, as more people show up for work dressed in khaki pants and denim shirts from the Gap. Mr. Magee's decision to alter his store's focus is indicative of what many merchants are doing to survive without having to leave downtown.
"We are doing well, but not as well as we once did," said Mr. Magee, 47. "Downtowns are evolving into entertainment centers. In order to become part of that market, we have to be more fun. We are changing to adapt to the times."
Before the 1960's, each downtown in New Jersey served the shopping needs of an entire region. The upscale stores of Summit attracted customers from the affluent northeast portion of Union County, until the Mall at Short Hills was built. And Red Bank pulled in business from all of Monmouth County, but the Monmouth Mall in 1960 stole much of the traffic from the shop owners along Broad Street, the town's commercial spine.
"Downtowns were defeated in the regional retail wars of the 1960's, said Dr. James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "They have had to adapt and reinvent themselves, away from pure retail to a mix of festivals, art galleries, restaurants and theaters."
Downtowns are serving interests much wider i than just shopping, and that is allowing them not only to survive but also to compete with the regional malls, Dr. Hughes said.
Main Street is now the place for summertime jazz festivalss, New Year's Eve celebrations and spring flower shows. From May until December, Red Bank is host to 28 special events, ranging from a health fair to a 1950's flashback weekend with Studebakers and Elvis sightings.
Summit sponsors about eight festivals a year, and is looking to do more, said Joseph A. Steiner, president of the Suburban Chambers of Commerce and director of the Summit special improvement district.
"With as busy as people are these days, they need to get their shopping done and get in their socializing and entertainment all in the same place," said Carol Felker Kaufman, a professor of marketing at the Rutgers School of Business in Camden. "If a town can combine those things, that makes it fairly attractive."
Shop owners are also going beyond just selling products to entertaining their customers. Lace Silhouettes Lingerie here holds monthly make-over nights, psychic readings and afternoon teas. The store competes with a Victoria's Secret one mile south in The Grove, an upscale strip mall. But Anne Quinn, who owns Lace Silhouettes, said the special events keep her customers coming back.
"We can't sit back and wait for people to come," said Ms. Quinn, 43. "We have to catch their interest."
Red Bank, once called Dead Bank by dispirited residents, is experiencing a rebirth after hitting rock bottom in the late 1980's, when 30 percent of the town's 350 storefronts were vacant.
"There were years and years of deferred maintenance," said Tracy Challenger, director of the River Center, which is what Red Bank now calls its shopping district. "The infrastructure was in such a tremendous state of disrepair. The whole town was in a complete downward spiral."
Then in 1990 a local lawyer ran for Mayor on a platform pegged to improving Red Bank's shopping district and won. The Mayor, Edward J. McKenna Jr., 47, held public meetings so residents and shop owners could air their grievances. He made the borough government more business friendly by dismissing any zoning or planning board member who did not share his vision for Red Bank. Potential business owners can now obtain site approval in one day, and their operating permit the next day.
The town became a special improvement district in March 1991, which is similar in structure to a mall management office. The River Center operates with a director and a 30-member board of property owners and business representatives.
It is responsible for marketing, coordinating special programs, recruiting new businesses and awarding grants to merchants who want to beautify the facades of their shops. To stabilize the tax base, the downtown businesses pay 28 cents per $100 of assessed valuation, or about $1,000 a year, to underwrite the River Center programs. Now just three retail rental spaces are available, and Red Bank was recently dubbed the "hippest town" in the state by New Jersey Monthly magazine. (That phrase graces nearly every promotional item produced by the River Center.)
The approach that Red Bank is taking to keep its downtown economically viable is more aggressive than that of Summit, a town filled with people who commute into New York City each day to work. Although it has experienced low points just like most other downtowns, especially after the Mall at Short Hills was built, residents, whose median household income tops $73,000, have supported Summit's upscale stores.
Despite the relatively steady success Summit has experienced, a study of the business district commissioned by Summit Downtown and released last month pointed out some areas of concern. It stated that parking is limited and several large storefronts are vacant. More than half the store owners said business is declining, and 40 percent said they have considered relocating in the past three years.
A $5.5 million parking garage is being built to remedy the parking crunch, Mr. Steiner said. And there are plans to enliven the streetscape by extending the sidewalks for outdoor cafes and planting trees along the street. But until these improvements are made, Mr. Steiner said, Summit shop owners will continuing doing what has allowed them to endure the growth of malls and superstores: out-service their competitors.
That is why Deborah T. Mahoney, 37, fills her prescriptions at Rogers Pharmacy and buys soy milk from Nature's Market. She returns at night with her husband, Michael, and their 5-year-old daughter for dinner and a film at the five-screen theater, which opened in July in the basement of a former five-and-dime store.
"The downtown was one of the reasons why we moved here," said Mrs. Mahoney, who came to Summit in 1993. "We go into these shops and we get to know a familiar face."

LENGTH: 1188 words

HEADLINE: SHOPPING AROUND: SUBURBAN STRIP;
From Bowling Alley to Shopping Center as Times and Economics Change

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

DATELINE: LIVINGSTON

 BODY:
Birthday parties. Roller skating. Disco and rock-and-roll. From 1967 to 1986, these were the ingredients that made the Livingston Roller Rink the only place a child growing up in this bedroom community in Essex County wanted to go to celebrate a birthday, bar mitzvah or other special event.
Now, a scant decade after the roller rink closed, the site at 615 South Livingston Avenue has become a different magnet altogether: a strip mall with a dance studio, a photo-processing shop, a personal-fitness store, a nail salon and more. 
 "This place has changed and changed and changed," said Ann Lippy, whose family owns Fran Lippy Jewelers in the strip mall and whose children used to have their birthday parties at the rink.
To examine the history of 615 South Livingston Avenue is to go on an archeological dig, through layers of demographic changes and municipal planning or zoning issues.
It is a look, too, at a larger phenomenon: the thousands of strip malls lining New Jersey roads. Not the Route 46's, Route 10's or Route 1's, but the smaller arteries that often function as commercial spines for communities without downtowns.
"What's so vivid about the strip mall is that it is a visible struggle of a community as it tries to adapt to suburban sprawl," said Thomas Wright, director of the New Jersey office of the Regional Plan Association. "As a community struggles to identify itself and define itself, people can look to the strip mall -- what is it like? What does it offer? How has it changed? -- because it reflects us better than any poll would."
No one keeps tabs on many strip malls there are in the state, partly because there is little consensus on how to define the term, said Patrick O'Keefe, executive vice president of the New Jersey Builders Association. But what is clear is that strip malls became ascendant in the 1950's, an outgrowth of the boom in suburbanization, molded by land-use regulations, road planning and community impulses.
The strip mall has always been a very packaged product, said Robert W. Burchell, professor of urban planning at the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University.
In years past, a typical strip mall might contain a coin laundry, a bakery, a butcher, a liquor store, a uniform shop. Today, the laundry has become a dry-cleaning operation, the bakery a bagel shop, the liquor store a coffee bar, the uniform shop an upscale boutique for women's clothing.
And driving it all is a simple principle: convenience.
"The key to the strip mall is that it has to be close, and it has to have very good parking," Mr. Burchell said. "It has to give you what anyone who lives in the suburbs would want to get in their car and drive five minutes to."
The strip mall at 615 South Livingston Avenue -- which does not have a formal name and is referred to as "615" by the owner -- is, in some respects, different from the traditional strip mall in that it did not start out as rectangular block of stores lining a major thoroughfare.
In other ways, though, 615 South Livingston Avenue is similar to other small strip malls around the state. One, it exists as one of several shopping hubs in a town that has no downtown. Two, it cannot rely on window-shoppers, since sidewalks are an afterthought. And three, it has to compete with nearby malls (Livingston and Short Hills) and big-box retailers (Home Depot, Sports Authority and Comp USA).
"I think any retail space along Livingston Avenue is trying to find that chemistry where whatever they're selling is going to attract people to come in," said Charles Tahaney, the township manager. "It's a constant creative battle to compete with the mall."
Forty years ago, the roller skating rink didn't exist at all. It was a wooded area, stocked with pheasants, rabbits and deer, said Robert Goeckel, 78, who lives on East Harrison Place, right around the corner. It was much the same throughout the rest of the township: in 1959, 44.6 percent of Livingston's 8,960 acres was vacant. (In 1975, by contrast, that number had shriveled to 13.8 percent.)
In the late 1950's, 615 South Livingston Avenue became an official address, home to the Livingston Lanes bowling alley. With a barrel-shaped roof and 24,000 square feet, the bowling alley housed about 16 lanes and had a bowling league, according to the local weekly paper, The West Essex Tribune. But the place never did that well, Mr. Goeckel recalled, even after it added a business in which people operated miniature cars via remote control.
The bowling alley closed in 1967, replaced by the Livingston Roller Rink and its 90-by-180-foot floor made of Northern Michigan hardrock maple, said Marvin Facher, one of the former rink owners.
For years, it was a successful place, site of as many as 20 birthday parties a weekend and regularly staging roller-skating competitions. But in the 1980's, the rink ran into two major problems, Mr. Facher said: liability insurance was becoming hard to obtain, and the rink was attracting a rowdier crowd .
In 1986, the rink closed. And at first, the new owners, Slater Companies, brought in Finders Keepers, a large clothing store specializing in off-the-rack items, in keeping with the push in the 1980's for large retailers. But that store folded. Then Strawberry's, another big retailer of women's clothing, gave it a whirl, but that, too, proved unsuccessful. As a result, the owners decided to start carving up the space to put in smaller tenants that relied more on service and a homespun feel.
"It was a matter of survival," said Fred Slater, president of Slater Companies, located in Livingston. "You do what you have to do."
There was still turnover, to be sure. Palmer Video. Today's Teen. A carpet store. A specialty gift shop. All came and went, said Michele Sandler, owner of Michele's Dance Studio, which has been at the strip mall for more than five years.
But the strip mall has become much more stable in recent years, catering to Livingston's changing demographics: younger professional families, with children. In addition, Mr. Slater managed to add more parking to the back of the mall.
Now, the mix includes Michele's Dance Studio, Villari's Karate, Great Golf Learning Center, Donna's Kids & Co. (an arts and crafts business), Computer Training Service, Bob Levine Shoes, How Fit (personal training), Fran Lippy Jewelers, Lovely Nails, In Vision Eyecare and A.S.A.P. 30-Minute Photo. One store, most recently occupied by a retailer that sold skateboards and Rollerblades, remains vacant.
The direction of the strip mall mirrors the one desired by the township, which has been trying to beautify Livingston's shopping districts and promote local merchants in the face of ever-present competition from the mall and other businesses, said Eleonore K. Cohen, a Township Council member and former mayor.
"What I have found is that the stores that need walk-in people off the street, they don't seem to last, but the stores that are word-of-mouth, we're doing fine," Ms. Sandler said. "We're really neighborhood businesses. We depend on our neighbors, and our neighbors depend on us."

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Selling to the Man in the Gray Flannel Suit and the Lady of the House

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY

 BODY:
JAMES DEAN had just been killed in a car crash in Hollywood. In South Jersey, a news report on a local civic group began: "Pictures of the atom bomb tests in Nevada were shown as a feature of the meeting of the Moorestown Rotary Club Thursday."
In Manhattan, Walter Winchell giggled in his syndicated column: "Swedish movie censors permit their films to show bare-breasted dolls. (Yumpin' Yimminy!)" 
 And in East Orange, B. Altman's department store was advertising men's rayon sport shirts, $3.95 apiece.
It was Oct. 1, 1955. This particular date has been chosen to reflect on advertising for two reasons. First, even then, daily papers grew fat with seasonal advertising starting in October. And 1955, one decade after the end of World War II, was the year when the modern suburban consumer economy found its first real traction.
Viewed from 40 years later, ads that once burbled with hyperbole come into focus with a patina of irony.
In 1955, "The Man in the Gray Flannel Suit," Sloan Wilson's anxious novel about 1950's organization-man conformity, hit the best-seller list. On Oct. 1, Robert Hall, the discount clothier, was offering "Wool flannel suits (which have the $40 and more look) -- $29.95."
The Stetson company also had an advertised special that subtly evoked male insecurity: "The Skyrider men's hat! For comfort and compliments! The look of success . . . the habit of command! $12.95."
In 1955, Newark, Elizabeth and even Camden had major department stores that filled newspapers with ads to sell furnishings and engineer desires for a phenomenon that would eventually shutter their own downtown display windows: the vast, just-beginning middle-class migration from the core cities to the suburbs.
J. C. Penney's had a sofa and two chairs with custom slipcovers on sale for $69. Lit Brothers, announcing the opening of a store in Camden, had a seven-piece living room suite for $295. For $199.95 more, you could add an Admiral 24-inch television.
Nobody was selling radios, which hadn't yet become widely transistorized, portable and thus appealing to young people. Even so, newspapers were still petulant enough about the annoyance of television to print daily radio listings prominently above the television listings.
On the night of Oct. 1, one television highlight was the season premiere of "The Honeymooners," with a show that featured a skit about Ralph's buying the Kramdens' first television set, to keep up with the Joneses. (Make that the Nortons.)
Keeping up was advertising's unrelenting message in 1955. Perhaps reflecting that, consumer debt had shot up by 55 percent in just two years -- mostly attributable to automobile loans and newly popular department store revolving-credit accounts.
Car dealers crowed about status as much as performance. Mercury dealers of New Jersey had ads on Oct. 1 that extolled "The Big Mercury," with its V-8 engine as well as its "distinctive new grille."
"From blocks away you can tell it's a Mercury," they said. "There's no mistaking this proud beauty!"
A few pages later, Sinclair gasoline promoted a new additive that sounded as if it would propel that new Mercury to the moon. "Power-X!" roared Sinclair. "It's power-primed," the ad said, with "the same fuel used in 500,000-horsepower rockets."
"To the moon," of course, was where the bumptious Ralph Kramden routinely threatened to send his long-suffering wife, Alice -- always getting a hearty laugh in the process.
As hall monitor of the exploding consumer culture, 1955 advertising talked to women in a voice that insisted their proper place was in the home, submitting to the male breadwinner.
"Make housework easy, without nagging backache. Get Doan's Pills today," advised ads that appeared in what were then known as the women's pages. Nearby, a big ad for soap powder depicted a beaming mother sagely advising her small daughter while they sorted the laundry: "The men who make automatic washers prescribe All."
Women actually looking for jobs turned to classified-ad sections that were still segregated by sex: "Help Wanted: Female." In 1955, "fountain girl" and secretary jobs were ample for women. For males, salesmen, machinists and Linotype operators were in demand.
With the baby boom at full throttle in 1955, advertising strongly reflected the idea that a woman should manage the house, bear and raise the children, prop up her husband socially and still maintain the sexual allure of a Hollywood starlet. Advertising thus manipulated a pandemic of body-weight insecurity among American women. (From 1939 to 1955, the average woman's dress size had shrunk by four sizes). Weight-loss centers (not to mention amphetamine drug prescriptions) proliferated.
"For your health and figure" cooed Slenderize, a weight center in Union. Membership was $10.50 a month -- when $75 a week was considered a good middle-class salary, and a three-bedroom ranch house on a newly developed tract in North Jersey could be bought for about $12,000.
With a birth rate "approaching India's" by the mid-1950's, William Manchester wrote in "The Glory and the Dream," women represented only 35 percent of American college students -- a smaller percentage than before World War II. And two-thirds of these dropped out before graduation -- many to marry. (In the 1950's, the average age at which women married dropped from 22 to under 20.)
Ah, you say, but at least it was cheaper to run a household then. In 1955, Acme supermarkets in New Jersey advertised large eggs at 69 cents a dozen. Chicken of the Sea chunk light tuna was 51 cents for a 6.5-ounce can. The A. & P. had ground beef at three pounds for $1.
Last week, Acme supermarkets in North Jersey were selling a dozen large eggs for $1.49. Chicken of the Sea chunk light tuna (now in a downsized 6-ounce can) was 89 cents. And an A. & P. in Montclair had ground beef for at $1.39 a pound.
Taking inflation into account, a tuna fish sandwich is a whole lot cheaper than it was in 1955.
On the other hand, that $12,000 ranch house now costs more than $200,000, and both spouses work full time to pay for it.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST HARLEM;
Two Visions Compete for Struggling La Marqueta

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
During its heyday, La Marqueta, once known for its wide selection of Puerto Rican products, was a bustling shopping complex of 400 vendors that stretched five blocks on Park Avenue from 111th Street to 116th Street underneath the Metro-North viaduct. But since the 1970's, business has declined, and many attempts to revive it have failed. Today, only 20 vendors operate in a blocklong building between 114th and 115th Streets, one of the four remaining indoor buildings. Neither the renovation of that building nor a newly constructed outdoor plaza could lure customers.
Now two developers have proposed new plans to increase the market's visibility. But their sharply different visions have caused many East Harlem leaders to strongly embrace one developer over the other. And one, the Local Development Corporation Del Barrio, a nonprofit organization in East Harlem, has accused the city's Economic Development Corporation, which owns and operates the complex, of playing favorites by refusing to listen to its proposal for an entertainment complex. 
 "The city has not met with us," Eddie Baca, the executive director, said. "We don't want any promises. We just want to be heard."
Mr. Baca's plan includes a branch of Jimmy's Bronx Cafe, which is a trendy restaurant and nightclub near Yankee Stadium, and an ethnic-food court (with Hispanic, Chinese and Italian food) and a comedy club, both to be developed by Jimmy's. The plan also envisions a shopping center, an outdoor stage and a community center. Mr. Baca said the plan would also include a movie theater across the street from La Marqueta, on the west side of Park Avenue at 116th Street, and parking spots.
The other developer, Manuel Areces, who has worked in various facets of the grocery business for many years, has a simpler plan. He said that it involved only one building, known as Building 3 and situated between 113th and 114th Streets, and that he wanted to restore its old warehouse style.
And adding to the traditional Puerto Rican products, Mr. Areces said he would also offer products from South America and Central America to attract the Mexican and other immigrants who have settled in East Harlem. He said he presented the proposal to the city in the summer and that he did not have immediate plans for the other buildings.
Charles Millard, the president of the Economic Development Corporation, would not comment on either plan except to say that he was open to long-term proposals for La Marqueta.
"We are very much interested in having proposals for the other buildings," he said of the three vacant buildings.
Mr. Areces's plan stokes feelings of nostalgia among many in East Harlem, but they say that it might compete with existing grocery stores and that Mr. Baca's plan is more practical because it would not only provide family entertainment but also would attract tourists.
"La Marqueta was special because it used to be the only place you could find certain Puerto Rican products," Harry Rodriguez, chairman of Community Board 11, said. "Now, every bodega and Korean grocery carry these things. We need an entertainment complex because right now there isn't anyplace where you can take your family and have a nice dinner."
But Mr. Areces said his line of products would be unique and would not pose any threats to local businesses.
"We're going to provide our customers what they can't find in the other places," Mr. Areces said. JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
At a Family Castle, a Bridge Over a Financial Moat

BYLINE: By PERRY GARFINKEL 

 BODY:
SOMETIMES, the good news is also bad. How else to describe inheriting a 70-room, 12th-century castle in the heart of the Tyrolean Alps?
For one American couple, it was good news, because the castle is a national historic monument, includes an 800-year-old watchtower and is a storehouse of not only Austrian history but also of fond family memories. 
 But it was also bad news, because, along with the castle, the couple inherited a monumental financial drain. One roof repair bill alone totaled several hundred thousand dollars, and the Austrian Government was threatening to put a lien on the property if the necessary repairs were not made.
Should the couple keep the property and quickly go broke? Or unload it and deprive descendants of the chance to literally call their home a castle?
Faced with this choice, Christopher Kump and Margaret Fox figured out how to turn the potential albatross into a cash cow -- or at least how to cover enough costs to keep the castle in the family. They opened the castle, in Reith im Alpbachtal, Austria, as a bed-and-breakfast.
While the case may seem extreme -- how many people have a castle in their past or future? -- it speaks to anyone who receives a gift with more sentimental than financial value. In such cases the heart, not the head, may rule. And, in the end, the heart may even prove the wiser financial adviser.
Mr. Kump, 36, and Ms. Fox, 45, are chefs and co-owners of Cafe Beaujolais, a well-known restaurant she opened in 1977 in Mendocino, Calif. The Austrian castle, known as Schloss Matzen ("schloss" is German for castle), is a rambling, enormous, but somehow cozy building with secret passageways, two dungeons and a Gothic chapel. About 30 minutes east of Innsbruck by car, it has a sweeping view of the Inn Valley.
THE family history: Mr. Kump's grandfather, Ernest Kump, a prominent California architect of Austrian descent, bought the castle 40 years ago for $80,000 -- a deal even by 1957 standards.
In 1983, to save his family from paying high inheritance taxes, the senior Mr. Kump transferred ownership to a foundation of which he and his wife were beneficiaries. The foundation was based in Liechtenstein, a principality that offers generous tax breaks on inheritances. In 1994, with his health failing, he gave beneficiary rights to his son Peter, who had founded Peter Kump's New York Cooking School and helped establish the James Beard Foundation.
After Peter and Carolyn Kump divorced in 1965, he and Christopher spent many summers at the castle and took frequent food-themed excursions throughout Europe.
"Some of my best memories of time spent with my dad are right here," he said in an interview at the castle. "That's one of the major reasons I have such a strong emotional attachment and commitment to making this work."
In 1995, at age 57, Peter Kump died of liver cancer, leaving Christopher to make real his father's dream of turning the castle into a high-end inn and restaurant. Unfortunately, Peter Kump also left behind a pile of contractors' bills. Not only did the roof need repair but an original estimate of $200,000 came in at more than $500,000.
Christopher Kump sat down to evaluate his options with the family's lawyer, Jerry Cohen, of Weiss & Company in Manhattan. But Mr. Cohen was not encouraging.
"We debated whether it could be converted into an economically viable project or whether it was worth anything at all," Mr. Cohen said. "My conclusion was I wouldn't tackle it. It would be dropping money into a black hole."
Among the factors that made Mr. Cohen cautious were "an intimidating" heating bill -- an estimated $6,000 for this year -- and the fact that Austrian laws governing national monuments could change at any time.
Richard Peskin, an estate planning lawyer in Manhattan who specializes in foreign investment properties, questioned "whether Chris has inherited anything at all" because the castle is ultimately owned by a foundation. This, he said, could work to Mr. Kump's advantage. "With a nonprofit charitable foundation, the family is entitled to the profits but is not liable for losses," Mr. Peskin said.
Mr. Kump and Ms. Fox knew that selling the castle immediately was not practical -- not only were there no potential buyers, but 40 percent of a sale would go to taxes. But they thought that if they could get it up and running as a business, their chances of selling, if necessary, would be improved.
"I spent one sleepless night playing out the numbers," Ms. Fox said. "They didn't look great, but what really motivated me to go ahead with this scheme anyway was seeing how much the castle meant to Chris."
Mr. Kump said the project was "a chance to make my father's dream come true and possibly leave something quite incredible for our daughter." The daughter, Celeste, now 8 months old, is the beneficiary of the Liechtenstein foundation.
To make a go of it, they have had to cut corners and improvise. For roof and other repairs -- to walls, catwalks and radiators -- they borrowed about $600,000 in two mortgages from a bank in the nearby village of Brixlegg. They saved money by doing some painting and repair work themselves.
Since opening the bed-and-breakfast for part of the summer last year, the couple have alternated between spending one to two months in Austria and two months at home in Mendocino, running the cafe and a mail-order business, which together produce revenue of about $1.2 million a year. They pay an American couple $5,000 a month to serve as full-time managers and hosts at the castle in their absence.
Last month, they ended their first full season and plan to reopen in January for their first two-month winter season. Rates for rooms and suites range from $165 to $250, including a breakfast of Austrian meats, eggs, cheeses, pastries and breads. Mr. Kump estimated that room revenue for the summer season was about $36,000.
To build revenue, they offered guided tours of the castle, generating almost $11,000 this past season. Renting out parts of the castle for fashion shows, conferences and weddings was less successful, losing about $3,800 after start-up expenses.
Over the summer, a group of local supporters helped raise restoration money by organizing a program of cultural events and tours at the castle. Branches of the Austrian Government are helping to subsidize a new roof for the tower, which will be turned into a museum for local artifacts.
Ms. Fox has a talent for marketing and publicity. "The idea was to get as much exposure for as little expenditure as possible," she said. The largest expense was for advertising in the The New Yorker; under a special rate, they bought four one-inch display ads for the price of three -- a total of $3,237. The ads have generated about 25 bookings so far, she said.
Along with the usual methods of access to a business -- a World Wide Web site, an E-mail address, and a toll-free phone number -- Ms. Fox has sought other opportunities. She offered free nights at the castle as part of an Oktoberfest promotion by LTU, the German airline.
In Mendocino, she contributed five free nights at the castle -- to which American Airlines added free business-class air fare -- to a winner of a fund-raising raffle to benefit the Mendocino Cancer Resource Center. The couple also promotes the castle to Cafe Beaujolais diners by distributing brochures and featuring recipes that Mr. Kump picked up in Austria.
Ms. Fox joked that she's been thinking of pitching an idea to produce a PBS special called "This Old Schloss."
Mr. Kump said he was not yet sure whether he would be able to realize his father's dream of a gourmet restaurant in the castle. "We don't expect this place to be a source of real profits," he said. "We'd be totally satisfied if we can just pay the bills and divide our time between here and California."
Ms. Fox added: "This is nothing but a win-win situation to us. If I had listened to financial advisers when I took on the Mendocino restaurant, I never would have gone into it, and my life would be immeasurably poorer."

LENGTH: 449 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;
Concern Grows on Where Trash Will Go After Fresh Kills

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
For Brooklyn residents, particularly those living in Red Hook, Greenpoint and Williamsburg, the closing of the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island in 2001 looms like a giant headache -- a 13,000-ton headache, to be exact.
That is how much household waste the city will have to dispose of elsewhere every day, and people in areas that have taken commercial garbage for years are worried that residential trash will be sent their way, too. 
 At a City Council hearing on Wednesday, community activists testified about the effect commercial-waste transfer stations have had on their neighborhoods and the implications of even more truckloads of trash in those areas.
For Brooklynites, the anxiety level was especially high. Civic activists and the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, said that they had obtained information that six sites were being considered along the borough's waterfront -- in Red Hook, Greenpoint, Williamsburg and Sunset Park -- where residential garbage would be processed before being sent out of the city. Brooklyn is already home to 33 of the city's 55 commercial-waste transfer stations.
John McGettrick, the co-chairman of the Red Hook Civic Association, said Red Hook had successfully fought to close more than a dozen transfer stations since the 1980's. "After all of these years of fighting to revitalize the neighborhood, to have it come back at us once again is stunning," he said.
City officials said such fears are premature, because while the city plans to send away the waste now dumped at Fresh Kills, it has not yet determined where that garbage will be processed. Deputy Mayor Randy Mastro said that, ideally, the marine transfer stations where the trash is now processed before being shipped by barge to Fresh Kills would continue to be used. That, he said, would mean there would be no need for new land transfer stations.
He said the city is reviewing 13 proposals from private companies on how they could dispose of residential waste and use the marine transfer stations.
But Mr. Mastro said he could not discuss the proposals until the city has a serious interest in pursuing one because they contain confidential financial information. Some community activists expressed concern that by the time any proposal was made public, their input would be meaningless.
City officials conceded that if the marine transfer stations cannot be used, new land transfer stations would have to be built or existing ones expanded -- and that could only occur in areas zoned for manufacturing. Brooklyn has more of those zones than any other borough, many of them along the waterfront in areas like Red Hook and Greenpoint. AMY WALDMAN

PUB-DATE: November 16, 1997

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 3738 words

HEADLINE: The Rabbi's Lost Tribe

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF

 BODY:
RABBI KHAIMOV stood at his apartment window in Corona, Queens, salsa music rumbling from his radio. Upstairs, a dozen South Asian cab drivers came and went in shifts. One particular man likes to lift weights in the middle of the night, keeping the rabbi and his wife from sleeping.
"I cannot take this 'boom, boom,' " the rabbi said, pounding the ceiling with a broom handle. The noise returned like Morse code. "I must leave this place," he said, pulling at his chin. "Maybe I never should have come." 
 The rabbi peered across the alley, trying to catch the reflection of his upstairs neighbor in one of the windows. What he saw was himself: a stolid, middle-aged man with thick fists and an incisor capped in gold. He wore a black beret and his beard was freshly groomed, not with scissors, he said, which would be a sin, but with electric clippers. The shave made him look younger, but no less tired.
In the window, he saw a man nearing the end of the line. Amnun Khaimov, 42, was something of a wandering missionary in Uzbekistan during the early 90's. Most Jews had left when the Russians pulled out. But a few like Rabbi Khaimov stayed until Muslims chased them out with iron bars and clubs. He came to America two years ago to be near members of his family living in Brooklyn. By circumstances of his own choice, he has landed in this sagging, whitewashed apartment in Corona, living on a weekly $90 unemployment check and pinned down by Muslims, one of whom likes to lift weights at midnight.
"I left a good life in Brooklyn," he said into the window, his voice nasal, his syntax jagged. "A good apartment. I have job as a kosher inspector in Long Island and I make good money. I come here for the people, and now maybe there is nothing but this noise."
South Corona once had a small but vital Jewish presence. Built at the turn of the century by Russians who fled the czarist pogroms and then added to by the European refugees of World War II, the community once boasted four synagogues. The Italians came, and then Hispanic people and then the blacks. By the early 70's, the Jews abandoned the area for Long Island. Nothing remained of the old life but a bakery and one struggling synagogue.
Then the Jews started to trickle back. Again they spoke Russian, but this time they came from Central Asia and called themselves Bukharan, based on the name of their holy city, Bukhara, in southern Uzbekistan. In 1991, five Bukharan families moved to Lefrak City in Corona, a 40-acre housing complex north of Forest Hills. The word spread about Lefrak back home, and placement agencies in New York steered the Bukharans there. By 1995, there were 500 Jewish families in Lefrak City and hundreds more in nearby apartment buildings.
The first Bukharans who came to New York in the late 60's have become relatively prosperous, and some of the jewelers on 47th Street in Manhattan are Bukharans. Those who came in the 80's have learned English and managed to find jobs. But the late arrivals, who were managers and professors and tailors in the Soviet Union, have come to find scraps. Many of them are unemployed, on welfare and living in claustrophobic apartments in Queens.
A Russian bathhouse has sprung up in the neighborhood, but only "the rich," the Bukharans say, can afford the $15 to use it. The graffiti has changed from Spanish to Russian. Educated men now pick trash for their welfare benefits, and with the passing of each week, they begin to realize that their situation may be permanent. Their children have embraced MTV and have begun to play with drugs.
The rabbi and his wife, Esia, 42, moved near the most desperate people, in a six-floor building on Calloway Street named "Chateau." Here, most tenants are Bukharan Jews. There are also the Muslims and a salting of Hispanic and Indian immigrants. The place is woefully overcrowded; the walls are a flypaper yellow and two apartments have recently been set aflame.
"The children go wild," the rabbi said, limping around the kitchen table. "There is little hope and we must help."
The rabbi has not worked since a car ran him down the day after Passover last spring, splitting a pelvic bone and puncturing his lung. He and his wife live on small loans, his tax refund and the crumbs from his unemployment insurance.
The life of a beggared missionary has made his new wife ill. A slender, handsome woman who declines to shake hands with men, Esia Aronbaeva was born in Tajikistan. She came of age in Israel, studied computers and was taught to think for herself. She did not find ardor for the Torah until she came to New York to study design. Here she met Amnun Khaimov on a blind date, and was so impressed by his rectitude she married him three months later. Together they would do God's work.
She has taken to sleeping at the home of friends to avoid the noise. "I look like hell," she said. "I lost 10 pounds. I cannot sleep. I can't stand this building. But now we have no money to move."
A knock came to the door. Men began to arrive. Evening prayers are held in the rabbi's living room. They discussed welfare benefits and asked the rabbi if he has heard of any work. Soon there were 10 men, a minyan, enough to worship. The men sang songs and shouted.
Another rap at the door. It was the superintendent.
"You must leave," he commanded "or pay me $500 extra for the church."
The superintendent, Imer Lajqi, an Albanian, said his building has been out of control ever since the Bukharans moved in. "The kids run in gangs and burn the apartments," he said. "Things have gotten desperate here, and the Muslim and Hindus do not like the Jews. It's going to run into murder."
Now, it was late evening. A band of Jehovah's Witnesses were combing the halls for converts. A cloud of marijuana smoke hung over a group of Bukharan teen-agers dressed in crisp leather and chinos who watched them. They come in regular shifts: the Baptists on Sunday afternoon, the Jews for Jesus on Saturdays and the Jehovah's Witnesses arrive in the evenings.
The proselytizers are no longer strangers here, more like eccentric neighbors who come with the promise of a better life on Earth and the offer of free English classes. The teen-agers politely accepted the literature and one scratched his eyes red with reefer. In the lobby, an 8-year-old boy played unattended. The boy likes to practice his English.
"Where's your mother?" a stranger asked.
"I don't know. Where's yours, buddy?"
Outside, under the cold street lights, Sason Bodalov, 51, sang to himself: "I'm afraid the whole world will be my enemy."
Once a factory manager, Mr. Bodalov has no work, vodka on his breath and a bad case of diabetes. "Before, where I come from they say Jews drink blood, so I tell no one I am Jew," he said. "Before, I have many things for my family. Now, I have nothing. No good English, no work. My children work and maybe better for them."
He will not wash dishes or dig ditches for $5 an hour, he said, because he is too sick. "Anyway, I have a business degree from university," Mr. Bodalov said impassively. "For what?" He does not send his boys to a Jewish school, he said; he cannot afford it. He thinks public school is better anyway. He is sure they teach English there.
"Besides," he said. "American Jews think they are better."
He stood quietly smoking cheap cigarettes as the songs from the rabbi's apartment spilled out over the street. Mr. Bodalov heard them and wept.
 
Son of the Old Neighborhood Becomes the Father of the New
 It was a wind-swept Friday morning in Corona. Simhath Torah, the end of the yearly cycle of readings from the Bible. The bluster tore pieces of paint from the synagogue walls, scattering them like storm-borne leaves. Inside, the basement was cold because the congregation could not afford heat. The 300 Bukharan Jews were wrapped in shabby sweaters and shawls and mumbled through the Hebrew prayers they did not understand. "God help us," said an old woman from beneath her shawl. "There have been too many tears."
"Here, there is freedom of religion," Slavik Ilyazarov, 44, a recent immigrant, stuttered under the prayers. "This we are learning. We also learn that life is not so easy here."
Pointing first toward the sky and then toward the rabbi, Mr. Ilyazarov said, "He willing, we will."
The Bukharans place a good deal of faith in their charismatic rabbi, a son from the old neighborhood, a father of the new. He is a man who can be counted on to listen and procure small loans. At times, it seems that only he has the lining to stomach the despair. Perhaps he may deliver a home and decent life, they think.
Rabbi Khaimov is opinionated, rebellious and unyielding. Bukharans enjoy their music and expect their holy men to be accomplished tenors. The rabbi is tone deaf, and as the congregation raised its pitch to drown down his voice, he only sang louder.
This brought tittering from the women in the back of the synagogue. But this they could overlook. After all, they said, without the rabbi they would have no synagogue at all. It is a quizzical logic. There is little Jewish infrastructure on this side of the highway, and what support there is, it seems, the rabbi has managed to alienate. He publicly rails against the most prominent Bukharan rabbi in New York, calling him a thief.
What is more, the synagogue where they now pray has belonged for decades to a dwindling group of American Ashkenazic Jews, and Rabbi Khaimov has done little to salve this blistered relationship. When the Americans protested that the Bukharan rabbi and his people, who consider themselves Sephardic, were swarming into their temple and not paying for upkeep, he responded that their attitude was an abomination in the eyes of the Creator, Who would bring devastation upon them.
Who Rabbi Khaimov is is a matter of debate. He is, according to himself, a learned man with rabbinical bloodlines that stretch back over centuries. He is, according to critics, a confidence man with a story on his lips, a thumb in the Talmud and a hand on his wallet. Sifting through an epoch of allegory and actuality is a difficult exercise. Rabbi Khaimov explains it like this:
He was born in Bukhara in 1955. The grandson of a prominent spiritual leader there, he did not begin to study the Torah until he was 32. Like many in the Soviet Union, his religion was forbidden to him, but as he grew up, he knew he was Jewish, if only by name.
His grandfather was Rabbi Arikhay Khaimov, chief rabbi of the main synagogue on Central Naya Street in the Jewish quarter in Bukhara. It was 1938, when the men from Stalin's secret police came to destroy him. He and a wealthy Christian were accused of helping Jews escape to Palestine. It was true, said his son Khaim Khaimov, 72, who now attends his nephew's services.
During the next eight years. the rabbi's sons went to war, seven relatives disappeared and his wife died of a broken heart on April 12, 1945 -- the same day as Franklin Roosevelt -- Khaim Khaimov said. "The Ashkenazim came, too," he said. "They ran from Hitler and came to Bukhara. They prayed in the upstairs of the temple, the Sephardim down below."
Beyond the folklore and the songs, Amnun Khaimov learned little about Judaism. What he learned he taught himself: never drink and be ready to fight. "People never said in public that they were Jews because they were afraid to be beaten or have cigarettes put out on their woman's arm," he said over a plate of liver. He was never drunk and always ready. "I beat many Muslims with my fists."
Amnun Khaimov taught English at a local high school and sold photographs to tourists throughout his 20's and did not consider God until his own son was near death from pneumonia. When the boy's heart had failed, the father promised to follow Him if the boy lived. His son did live and the next morning, the father memorized the Hebrew alphabet.
In 1987, Amnun Khaimov started Hebrew studies at a fledgling Moscow rabbinical college, and left the Soviet Union two years later, to study under more knowledgeable men. He had vanished into Hungary and was not seen or heard from for nearly three years.
He said he was cloistered at the Countrywide Rabbinical Seminary in Budapest, where he studied Torah, the Hebrew language and ritual slaughtering. The monthly stipend was not enough to feed his wife and son and he sent them away. She eventually divorced him and moved to Israel. He stayed in Hungary, living on bread and salt.
Half-starved and skulking in the streets of Budapest, Rabbi Khaimov says he took a Russian passport to Bosnia on his summer sabbatical and enlisted in the Serbian Army. His job: comb the battlefields for the corpses of Serbian soldiers.
On his 47th day of active duty, as he was searching the woods for the missing leg of a corpse, Rabbi Khaimov said, he was attacked by a Muslim soldier. They struggled and he put a bayonet into the soldier's chest, but not before he took a blade in the back. There they lay, Muslim and Jew, their blood staining the Balkan mountains.
The future rabbi was paid $8,000 for his service (he said he refused to be paid in Deutsche marks) and was discharged. He returned to Hungary and finished his studies. In 1992, he was ordained a rabbi by the seminary.
When he returned to Uzbekistan, Rabbi Khaimov would find that most of the Jews had left and that there were few rabbis to tend to the small pockets of families who remained. He worked as a traveling crusader; first in Bukhara, then in Katta-Kurgan and finally in Navoi. He spent nearly a year in each city, working as a rabbi and kosher butcher. He taught the children. More importantly, he paid a dollar a week to anyone who would come to temple and pray.
Some of the rabbi's detractors call the war story a lie, a whisky-soaked tall tale. But the rabbi points to the scar on his back. As for the money from the war, people now living in New York remember.
"He saved the people,"said Alexander Aryev, 37, a tailor from Navoi. "Once there were 3,000 Jewish in my town. Then only 400 and no rabbi. No one knew how to cut the meat. Only he. Without him, we would starve."
 
What Does It Mean To Be a Rabbi, Exactly?
 While working as a ritual slaughterer and living in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, last year, Rabbi Khaimov was asked to become the spiritual leader of Lefrak City's 3,000 Bukharans at the complex's new Jewish center. After three months, saying they were fed up with the politics, he and his wife struck out on their own.
By all accounts of people attending services on Simhath Torah, Rabbi Khaimov is considered the steadying influence that has kept their tribe together.
"Some of us, we believe in God," Mr. Aryev said. "We have no place to go, but we know Khaimov. He will find the place."
What he found was the bronze and marble sanctuary of the Congregation Tifereth Israel synagogue on 109th Street and 54th Avenue in Corona, home to a dwindling congregation of Eastern European Jews who have prayed there since their fathers built it exactly 90 years ago. They, in turn, consider Rabbi Khaimov one part Rasputin, one part mountebank, with a beard full of oratory but little religious training.
"He is absolutely not a rabbi," said Irwin Goldstein, 66, who has been the cantor at the synagogue for eight years. "He is absolutely a shochet, a kosher butcher. But he doesn't know the Torah and he can't speak Hebrew. He ain't no rabbi."
Mr. Goldstein, who is Ashkenazic, said his congregation invited the Sephardim to come worship with them last March. Since then, Mr. Goldstein said, the rabbi's overwhelming presence, and followers, threatens to drown what remains of the Ashkenazic tradition at the synagogue. The Bukharan prayers are too long. The melodies of their songs are different. Their celebrations are more mystical and intertwined with Islamic tradition. This, he says, will never do.
More to the point, the old Americans suspect that the foreigners have their eyes on the main sanctuary and that they will be buried in the cellar.
"It's like he is a mercenary," Mr. Goldstein said. "He comes and tries to conquer and inflict their way of doing things."
For his part, the rabbi feels his claim to the synagogue is sanctioned by God. "Everything is built by Him," Rabbi Khaimov said. "Why they don't share? Crooked people never build straight things."
With time on his hands, the rabbi has taken to limping around the streets of Queens, in search of the children whom he heard were being attracted by the Christians.
The rabbi croaked in disgust as he stared into a Lutheran church in Briarwood. It was true what they said. The Jewish children and the old people were going to a minister there who taught them English from the New Testament.
"They don't even know what they're becoming," he said in a hangdog whisper.
He spoke with contempt of Yitzchak Yehoshua, the Chief Rabbi of the Bukharan Rabbinical Council of America, a powerful presence in New York. How can he see the faces of his people, smell the alcohol on their breath from his comfortable American home? He calls himself the chief? Rabbi Khaimov asked. Who lives among the people? Who understands their pain?
Rabbi Khaimov said his feud with the Chief Rabbi dates back to Bukhara, 1989, when Rabbi Yehoshua made a trip there to purchase Torah scrolls from Rabbi Khaimov's grandfather. When his grandfather refused, Rabbi Khaimov said, the brunt of Rabbi Yehoshua's anger fell to him. For his part, Rabbi Yehoshua confirms the story, but said he only wanted to take some of the scrolls out of Uzbekistan to preserve them. The Torahs have been disappearing, he said, fetching as much as $25,000 on the black market.
As for their relationship, the Chief Rabbi took the high road in describing Rabbi Khaimov as a decent man with leadership skills. In the next breath, however, he characterized him as a Russian with a strong Jewish identity but questionable Talmudic knowledge and flimsy credentials.
"I think he is a good butcher maybe, but he is no rabbi," Rabbi Yehoshua.
Rabbi Khaimov has what he says are ordination papers from the Countrywide Rabbinical Seminary in Budapest, a politically conservative school in Hungary that is recognized by the World Jewish Congress as a legitimate seminary.
Still, throwing salt on a powerful rabbi will not grow flowers.
 
After Prayers The Vodka Flows
 In the basement, on Simhath Torah, the celebration continued. The prayers took most of the morning. They were cursive and made longer as Rabbi Khaimov stopped to translate the Hebrew into Farsi, one of the Bukharans' languages.
Then the vodka flowed, the food served and the cigarettes lit. The small group of Ashkenazim who had prayed upstairs, stared through the basement windows.
Beneath the glass, two Bukharan men drank.
"There are no jobs, and everybody practically takes welfare," Sason Bodalov said. He wore a threadbare suit and had the haggard look of a man who has been driving all night.
"Yes, it is true," Boris Boruhov said. "But Smirnoff is good vodka."
"Of course," Mr. Bodalov said, his eyes shining like new coins, "But if I don't get some work soon, I'm going to die."
"How will you die?" Mr. Boruhov asked.
"I'll drown myself in the pool."
"You don't have a pool."
"Oh yes," Mr. Bodalov said. "That's right. Then I'll do it in vodka."
The men emptied their Dixie cups. Speeches were made by Jewish war veterans whom the Soviets claimed never existed. The women gossiped. And before the people walked home, they made a prayer for water. For a sign of rebirth.
That afternoon, the sky opened up and the rain fell for two days.
 
A Question of Identity
ABRAM ICARKHOV is an old man now, and Uzbekistan might as well be on the dark side of the moon. He thinks he will never see his hometown, Navoi, again or his big house, his garden with grapes and his three milk cows.
"I sold it all to come here, where all the people came," said Mr. Icarkhov, 68, a former cobbler with hands too worn to make any more shoes. He sold his estate for an enormous price, the equivalent of $10,000, in 1995. At least, it seemed like an enormous amount in post-Communist Uzbekistan, where a month's salary will buy two bottles of whisky.
But after Mr. Icarkhov arrived in the States, the money was gone in less than a year. He and his wife now get by through public assistance programs and help from their 30-year-old son, a dishwasher.
For many Bukharan Jews, who have their roots in the Central Asian republics of the former Soviet Union and identify with the city of Bukhara, the trip to America has ended in desperation.
No one knows for sure how many Jews lived in Uzbekistan before glasnost. The Soviet census of 1989 counted nearly 95,000, but the true number may have been twice that, said Nate Geller, director of cultural affairs for the National Conference on Soviet Jewry. "Many opted for the Russian nationality. To say you were a Jew meant you had no access to jobs."
And no one knows exactly how many Bukharans landed in Queens. Estimates range from 35,000 to 50,000, which is still more than the estimated 30,000 who have remained in Uzbekistan. So one latest chapter in the Diaspora is being written in central Queens.
The Bukharans are not typical refugees, said Manny Behar, executive director of the Queens Jewish Community Council, who estimates that 30 percent are unemployed. "Most have come with skills and education, but because they are the middle-aged who speak little English, opportunities for white-collar jobs are few," he said.
Moreover, although the Bukharans managed to hold on to their traditions during Soviet rule, they have come to realize that observing their traditions is not the same as observing Jewish law. Few understand Hebrew and the Torah, and so those who fled Muslim persecution have come to feel discriminated against by Orthodox Jews in America, they say.
"For decades, they thought they were observant," said Rabbi M. Mitchell Serels, director of Sephardic programs at Yeshiva University. "When they arrived here, they found that they were not. This is a blow to their Jewish identity, making them a minority within a minority."
In the scope of history, these problems are minor, Mr. Icarkhov said. After all, in America he can worship openly. "If I have to, I will crawl to the temple through the snow," he said. "I love God." CHARLIE LeDUFF

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 781 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
A Revival of Small Stocks: Big Rewards but More Risk

BYLINE: By ANN WOZENCRAFT 

 BODY:
WITH small companies in their sixth month of leading the market, investors need to realize that shopping for them is far different from shopping for the large outfits that had long set the pace on Wall Street.
And there may be many rookie shoppers out there, for the recent performance of small companies has been relatively very strong. The stocks of both large and small companies have been pummeled by the recent difficulties in Asia, of course, but even with the setbacks, the Russell 2000 index, which tracks small-capitalization stocks, has gained 8.7 percent since midyear. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is up only 4.2 percent in that time. 
 Analysts say small caps should keep outperforming the market for anywhere from a few to 18 months because of a strong economy, the capital-gains tax cut, a strong dollar -- which reduces the earnings of companies with overseas operations -- and other reasons. But whatever the period, the revival of long-ignored small stocks may underline their importance to a portfolio.
"Investors who don't have small-cap exposure are missing out on a big part of the equity market," said Claudia Mott, director of small-cap research at Prudential Securities. Small stocks represent roughly 10 to 12 percent of the value of all stocks.
But small caps, while better performers over the long run, are riskier than large caps. "Their stories aren't known, they're not as well-seasoned and they don't have the controls and reserves if the business slows down," said Thomas Maguire, fund manager for the Safeco Growth fund.
Moreover, analyst coverage of small caps is often minimal. While many analysts follow I.B.M., small companies may have only one analyst covering them, or none.
"You won't get a lot of help from your broker because many of these companies aren't on anyone's recommended buy list," said Gerald Perritt, president of Perritt Capital Management in Largo, Fla.
And because the press pays more attention to larger companies, small-cap investors often must use special publications. One source for small-cap newsletters is The Hulbert Financial Digest, which tracks the performance of many kinds of investment newsletters (888 485-2378, $59 a year).
If investors are to realize small companies' potential and ride out their volatility, they must also hold the stocks for a long time -- preferably five years or more.
"Most people do poorly investing in small stocks because they sell too soon," said Keith Mullins, a strategist at Smith Barney. "Those people in Seattle who had a good cup of coffee at Starbucks and sold when the stock doubled don't feel so smart now. In large stocks, though, valuation sensitivity is probably a very strong discipline."
But valuations are still important for small stocks.
One common rule, followed by Mr. Maguire, is to buy stocks only when their price-earnings multiples are appreciably lower than their expected earnings growth rates. If a company's earnings are growing at a 20 percent annual rate, he would like to pay no more than a 16 multiple for the stock. This strategy worked with Jackson Hewitt, a tax-preparation firm. Jackson Hewitt has an expected growth rate of 25 percent, while the stock had only a 12.5 multiple at the $21.25 price Mr. Maguire paid in July. It closed on Friday at $54.75.
Frank Reichel, manager of the Stratton Small Cap Yield fund, has advice on containing small-cap volatility: buy only stocks that pay a dividend. Last year, he paid $15.67 apiece for shares of Excel Industries, which makes car components. The stock, now at $18.75, pays an annual dividend of 2.7 percent. That assured income may have been comforting as the stock fell from $25 to $18 in September on the loss of some orders.
Given this volatility and the fact that small caps often make just one product, if any, Mr. Perritt also believes that 20 to 30 small caps are needed to equal the diversification one gets from 10 to 12 large stocks.
And avoid companies with much long-term debt, he advises. "The debt-free company can iron out its problems and get back in the growth mode," Mr. Perritt said. His Perritt Capital Growth fund invests only in companies with less than 30 percent of assets financed by debt.
Finally, Mr. Mullins said, it is important to understand a small company's finances. "If you're not willing to do a certain amount of number-crunching, you're probably better off going with a mutual fund," he said.
The top three small-cap mutual funds for the 12 months ended on Wednesday were Bridgeway Ultra Small Company (up 60.6 percent), State Street Research A Aurora (57.9 percent) and Safeco Growth, Mr. Maguire's fund (53.4 percent).
