SECTION: Section 3; Page 13; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1009 words

HEADLINE: MGM Can't Fill Seats at Premiere of Kerkorian, the Sequel

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
KIRK KERKORIAN, the Las Vegas-based financier, should have learned by now. Some of his past dealings may make investors, even naive ones, very wary of buying a minority stake in a company in which he is running the show.
But hope springs eternal, and so Mr. Kerkorian, the 80-year-old billionaire who controls Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, had recently planned to offer 13 percent of the company to the public for as much as $23 a share. 
 Investor reaction was so weak, however, that Mr. Kerkorian had to buy 3.5 million of the 12.5 million shares himself. And yet the stock, which went public on Thursday at just $20 a share -- the bottom of the estimated price range -- closed at only $20.375 on Friday.
"It is a magnificent short sale," said Seth Glickenhaus of Glickenhaus & Company, an investment firm, in a sardonic reference to a strategy investors use when they expect a stock to decline.
There are clear reasons for the poor showing. Not only does MGM have nearly $800 million of debt and no prospects for profits over the next few years, but it is solely dependent on the volatile film business. And Goldman, Sachs, which had planned to be among the underwriters, pulled out within the last month.
But investors with long memories may have been scared off for another reason. Mr. Kerkorian is a master at selling and buying back assets; he has bought and sold pieces of MGM, and some other companies, so many times it is hard to keep track. And over the years, unhappy minority shareholders in several Kerkorian-controlled enterprises have fought to get better deals when he bid to get their stock back.
Indeed, the MGM offering looks very much like a deal that aroused investor acrimony in 1982. Mr. Kerkorian controlled MGM/UA Entertainment, a company that then included both MGM and the United Artists studios. Unable to pay off its $675 million of debt, it faced a cash squeeze. So Mr. Kerkorian offered the public 15 percent of a subsidiary called MGM/UA Home Entertainment, a home-video business, and sold the stake at $12 a share.
At that time, Sumner M. Redstone, who is now chairman of Viacom but was then a leading theater owner, bought roughly half the offering. Two years later, after the parent company had reduced its debt, Mr. Kerkorian made a formal offer to buy back the public shares with notes that had a face value of $28 but were actually valued at $22.
Mr. Redstone, a tough and litigious executive, challenged the offer in court, arguing that the price was too low. Ultimately, Mr. Kerkorian agreed to pay shareholders $28 in cash.
Then, in 1984, Mr. Kerkorian had to withdraw another offer related to MGM/UA -- a deal to buy the half of the company that he did not already own. Several shareholders had argued in lawsuits that his cash-and-note offer, which had a face value of $25 a share and a market value of about $17 a share, was too low.
True, shareholders linked to Mr. Kerkorian often make good money, but in two well-known cases it was less than he made. Western Airlines is one. Mr. Kerkorian began buying its stock in 1968, and in 1976 sold back a chunk of the stake for $30.3 million -- an 18 percent premium to the market price.
And in 1979, Mr. Kerkorian bought 25 percent of Columbia Pictures for about $20 a share. The stock was already on a roll and continued to go up. Soon, Mr. Kerkorian began rattling his saber and threatening a takeover. The company ultimately bought him out in 1980 -- at a 29 percent premium to the market price.
ONE close associate defended Mr. Kerkorian's actions in the Western Airlines and Columbia situations. In the 1980's, greenmail -- paying a potential acquirer a premium to the share price so he will abandon a takeover attempt -- was an acceptable business practice, the associate said.
Also, some institutional investors are willing to take a chance on Mr. Kerkorian anyway. As one longtime film executive put it, "They may not believe in the economics of MGM, but it is worth the bet," given Mr. Kerkorian's track record. And if he tries to buy back their stake or reconfigure the company, "institutional investors today are more inclined to be litigious and not willing to stand for being taken," the executive said.
Moreover, in some cases during the last decade Mr. Kerkorian and his co-investors have profited equally well. For example, he began buying stock in Chrysler in October to December 1990, at an average cost of $5 a share. On Friday the stock closed at $32.3125.
Mr. Kerkorian has made subsequent purchases of Chrysler stock, which raised his stake to 13.7 percent. But an investor who came on board when Mr. Kerkorian made his first purchases would have seen the shares rise 550 percent by now, compared with a 199 percent increase for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. And, as even the skeptical Mr. Glickenhaus concedes, pressure from Mr. Kerkorian led Chrysler to buy back more of its stock -- 20 percent since 1990 -- than it might have otherwise.
Another example: Mr. Kerkorian took MGM Grand, the casino company of which he owns 61.6 percent, public in February 1988 at $10 a share. The stock is now at $39.75, up 300 percent. That compares with the 271 percent increase of the S.& P. during that time.
"Generally, investors have done well following Kerkorian's moves," said Harold Vogel, who follows the gambling industry for Cowen & Company.
Mr. Kerkorian's longest-running investment, in MGM/UA, may prove the point most compellingly. He initially tendered for shares of MGM in July 1969 at prices as high as $42 a share. By 1986, after Mr. Kerkorian had split the company in two and sold off both pieces, an investor who had bought at the 1969 price would have had stock worth $308.46. That is a 623 percent gain, compared with 112 percent for the S.& P. in the same period.
But in the interim there were legal tangles with other shareholders over various issues. Investing with Mr. Kerkorian can be hugely profitable, but in some cases paying attention to his wheelings and dealings is a part-time job at least.

HEADLINE: The Saddam Hussein Problem

 BODY:
The world has a Saddam Hussein problem. To say it that way defines the threat that he represents to the biosphere, the envelope of air and water that he proposes to infest with pestilences that respect no political boundaries. It also helps frame the reality that another round of American military action may be needed to deal with a man who seems determined to be both a nuclear renegade and a transporter of timeless plagues.
There have been no inspections of Iraq's germ-warfare programs since Oct. 29. Its fermenters can prepare anthrax for weapons use in a matter of days. Given the right conditions, an airborne release of anthrax over a city could kill as many as 100,000 people. Friday's departure of the inspection force means the system of arms control imposed after the gulf war has lapsed, leaving Iraq's neighbors and the global community in a situation of intolerable vulnerability. 
 A new system has to be put in place as soon as possible. All week, President Clinton was properly cautious about exercising the most solemn duty of his office, which is to decide when to risk American lives in combat. He called Friday for a new regime of diplomatic pressures aimed at forcing Mr. Hussein back into compliance with United Nations inspection requirements. The principal hope for a peaceful resolution rests with the French, who are at last pressing Iraq's leader to end his defiance. We also urge the President to consider imposing a no-flight zone across Iraq, forcing Mr. Hussein to contemplate a grounded economy and loss of his aircraft as the price of noncompliance.
But it is hard to argue with those who think all such steps will fail because Mr. Hussein believes events are trending his way or because he wants to be hit as a way to rally his people and divide his enemies. The U.N. Security Council remains divided over endorsing further military action. Fortunately President Clinton has authority under previous U.N. resolutions to make sure that the terms of the gulf war cease-fire, including arms inspections, are enforced. If this last round of diplomacy fails, Mr. Clinton will be justified in going to the enforcement procedure of last resort, which is the use of military strikes at Iraqi ground targets.
This could take the form of retaliatory attacks if the Iraqis fire on the U-2 surveillance flights that could resume as early as today. Mr. Clinton can clearly get Congressional approval, as he should, for the heavier blows that will be possible when Navy and Air Force units are in position in the coming days. Over time, this page has endorsed such action with great reluctance. But the risk that Mr. Hussein is mad enough to unleash biological agents avoided by the century's worst villains is simply too great. The U.N. inspectors have to get back into Iraq, by force if necessary.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
